HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Contrarian Bets on Growth In Japan Send Dollar Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the yen yesterday ahead of the release of a quarterly Japanese economic report that some traders gambled would surprise markets with hints of strength.
The dollar gained slightly against the mark after Germany's central bank left a money market rate there unchanged. The securities repurchase rate remained at 3 percent, though traders expect an increase later this year. 
 While the Tankan report, the Japanese central bank's quarterly measure of business sentiment, is expected to be gloomy, the chance of a positive report had many traders betting on the yen. "If it comes out bad, there's not going to be much movement," said Ralph Del Zenero, a First National Bank of Chicago vice president. "You hope for a better number and take a little flier."
The yen has been battered by the weak Japanese economy, which has left interest rates at record low levels. A surprisingly strong Tankan report would shift sentiment toward a rate increase, which could be expected to bolster the yen.
Evidence has been building that the report, to be released today, would be weak. Yesterday, reports on Japanese industrial output and retail sales for August were both weaker than expected. But in pieces of positive news, the Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry forecast a rise of seven-tenths of 1 percent in September industrial production and an increase of eight-tenths of a percent for October.
The Federal Reserve's decision to leave American interest rates unchanged was no surprise. But two reports that have the ability to move the market are due this week. Today, the National Association of Purchasing Management is to issue its reading of the economy for September, and on Friday, employment figures for September are due.
Late in New York yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 120.50 yen, down from 120.95 yen on Monday. The dollar traded at 1.7624 German marks, up from 1.7621. It declined against the British pound, which sold for $1.6168, up from $1.6093 Monday. The pound regained more of what it had lost last Friday on a report that Britain was considering participation in the planned European single currency sooner than expected.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Downsizing Opens a Door For a Sculptor

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
THE ROARING 20's served Corrine Weinberg well during the Go-Go 80's. Her detailed Art Deco sculptures of flappers and elegant couples, which cost as much as $30,000, sold briskly to collectors and executives who identified with the era's good times and easy money. But the art market eventually shriveled up when, like the old days, the economy nose-dived and executives were downsized out of existence.
So Mrs. Weinberg did a little downsizing, too. She makes cabinet handles and knobs that fetch one-thousandth the price that her flappers used to command. Working on a thick-planked table in her Yorkville apartment, she stays up late into the night with her tools and sheets of casting wax as she sculptures knobs that range from Art Deco pieces to bugs, animals and even a Texas Ranger's badge. 
 North River Mint, the company she founded last year with her husband, Harvey, sells its tiny textured pieces through 73 outlets nationwide that offer what the trade calls "alternative hardware." In her own alternative career, Mrs. Weinberg still taps into the spirit of the times, because her work appeals to homeowners who want to spruce up their rooms without busting the budget.
"People are redecorating in lieu of buying a new house," she said. "A knob can change the mood of a whole room."
It can also lift the spirit of an artist who refused to go away when the galleries closed their doors.
"If it's sculpture, I can do it," she said. "It's just a smaller scale for a different purpose."
The view of the East River from their apartment gives the Weinbergs a nice vista of Brooklyn and Queens, where they lived and met as teen-agers. During their marriage of "a long time," he was a business marketing and promotions executive, while she pursued her work as a self-taught artist.
She drew and sculptured, without ever quite having a vision of her own. That changed in 1980, when she and Harvey visited the Met.
 "WE walked down this long hall and there was this painting by Renoir," he said. "I asked her who did it. She said, 'Renoir, of course.'
He said to her: " 'You know that because you can recognize his style. I'll tell you something, you have no style at this point.' "
One morning the next week, she told him about a dream she had about flappers and the 1920's. That, she felt, was her style.
"It was more than just dancing and music, but an overall attitude people had at the time," she said. "It just thrills me. It was very sensuous. The clothing left a lot to your imagination."
It obviously captured other people's attention, because by the mid-80's she was selling thousands of pieces, having gallery shows and even being featured in the window of Tiffany.
 THAT changed when the recession settled in and galleries began closing, since mid-priced artwork like hers was not something you absolutely needed to have in order to live. A few years ago, her husband had an idea of his own, though. He took her to a local hardware store and showed her a selection of knobs. She could beat this stuff easily, he said. Besides, with his business knowledge, they could finally work together.
With the kind of attention to detail his wife favors in her work, Mr. Weinberg did exhaustive research before settling on the metals and manufacturing method he now uses for the individually hand cast pieces.
Mrs. Weinberg, who has designed more than 100 pieces, said the transition from fine art to hardware was smooth.
"The work I'm doing could bring art into the bedroom, kitchen or any room they choose to put my work," she said. "I have seen ladies' dressing rooms where closets go up to the ceiling, with dozens of cabinet doors with a different knob on each. It's a very artistic way of dealing with my designs."
With one or two new distributors signing on every week, the Weinbergs are busy planning to expand into clothing hooks and towel racks. Their pieces sell well in the $20 range, said Michael Rizzuto, a senior buyer at Gracious Home, which was the first store to feature the North River Mint. He still remembers when Mr. Weinberg came to him with his wife's sculpture portfolio and proposed making similarly styled knobs and hardware. He took to the idea and has encouraged the couple ever since.
"Somebody gave me a break," Mr. Rizzuto said. "I was the house carpenter here and with a decent knowledge of hardware I came up through the ranks. I lucked out, and that's why I probably want to spread it around."
You could say he opened the door for the Weinbergs. Luckily, they were ready with the knobs.

HEADLINE: Aim Sanctions at Iran, Not France

 BODY:
The $2 billion Iranian gas-field development contract signed by the Total Oil Group of France, Gazprom of Russia and Petronas of Malaysia is doubly unfortunate. It will provide new funds to a Government that is exporting terrorism, developing nuclear weapons and disrupting peace efforts between Israel and the Arab world. The contract could also trigger the first application of the Iran-Libya Sanctions Act, an ill-advised law that attempts to impose American penalties on foreign companies doing energy business with Iran or Libya.
The Sanctions Act, crafted primarily by Senator Alfonse D'Amato of New York and signed by President Clinton last year, is intended to force Europe's policies on Iran into line with those of the United States. Instead it drives Europe and America further apart. Washington and Paris should be talking about how to change Iran's unacceptable policies. Instead they are now engaged in a noisy, unproductive dispute over Congress's attempts to legislate beyond American borders. 
 This trans-Atlantic quarrel comes at a time when there are signs that Iran may be reconsidering its policies following the recent election of Mohammed Khatami, a relative moderate, as President. The West should now be sending coordinated signals that Teheran can secure increased international investment and an end to American sanctions if it abandons its dangerous behavior.
President Clinton must decide what penalties, if any, to apply against the offending foreign companies. At most, he could bar all three from any trade with the United States. He should instead emphasize diplomatic responses, including continued discussions with France, despite the rebuff Prime Minister Lionel Jospin gave Washington this week.
The United States, in defense of its own national security, rightly bans American oil companies, like Conoco, from developing Iranian energy resources. But most European countries dispute American contentions about Iranian terrorism and nuclear weapons programs and insist that maintaining what they call a "critical dialogue" with Teheran is the most effective way to influence Iranian policies.
In the case of France, with its extensive and long-established business dealings with Iran, this approach is a smokescreen for subordinating global security to commercial gain. France has also unhelpfully appointed itself the world's leading challenger of American diplomacy and economic ideas.
Iran's weapons development programs, support for terrorism and disruptive diplomacy pose grave dangers not only to American interests but to the security and prosperity of Europe as well. Washington needs to keep the strongest possible pressure on France to restrain its commerce with Teheran. Yet the D'Amato law dilutes the case by shifting the argument from Iran's dangerous conduct to America's legislative interference in its allies' sovereign affairs.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds End Quarter on Some Profit Taking

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities finished generally lower yesterday, though they closed out the third quarter far higher than where they were at the end of the second quarter.
Yesterday's decision by the Federal Reserve to leave interest rates unchanged, which had been expected, had little effect. But bonds briefly rose after the release of weaker-than-expected economic data. Those gains were eroded later in the day by profit taking ahead of today's report from corporate purchasing managers and Friday's release of September employment data. 
 As Thomas E. Donne, vice president and senior portfolio manager at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, put it, "Bond market participants are rarely comfortable, even when they are happy."
With the Fed choosing not to raise short-term rates, the market's focus now shifts to the November and December meetings. "Undoubtedly, the Fed kept its bias toward tightening in place," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management. Given the economy's momentum -- despite yesterday's reports, growth has been relatively robust of late -- the Fed might move to raise rates in November at any hint of inflation, he said.
Yesterday, the 30-year bond slipped 4/32, to a price of 99 24/32; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.39 percent, from 6.38 percent on Monday. That is still nearly four-tenths of a percentage point less than the yield of 6.78 percent on June 30, when the second quarter ended.
Mr. Donne said that for the broad bond market, July was good, August was terrible and September had turned out to be strong again.
"We're coming out of what appears to be another good quarter, maybe one showing about 3.50 percent total return" for investments, he said. "If you multiply that by four quarters, then it's a great year for bonds."
Most of the market's gains in the quarter have come in securities with long maturities, the end of the market most sensitive to expectations about inflation. After an uptick in the fourth quarter of 1996, inflation pressures for the most part have shown steady declines.
There was some nervousness in the bond market going into the third quarter because of the second quarter's strength. Market participants expected that the second quarter's rate of growth was unsustainable, but did not know how much it would slow. Of particular concern was the tightness of the labor market -- a concern that has been punctuated by strikes like the one at the United Parcel Service -- raising fears that inflation might be rekindled.
Some portfolio managers found it difficult to stick with traditionally high-return investments like corporate bonds and mortgage-backed securities because of the uncertainty over the direction of interest rates. In times of declining yields, mortgage-backed securities are often called in advance, leaving managers with voids in their portfolios.
Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston, said that in the third quarter market participants came to realize that the Fed had changed the theoretical framework it used to view the economy. During Congressional testimony in July, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, alluded to the idea that inflation could remain low despite a robust economy.
Despite the big movement in the 30-year bond, Mr. Alexy said, the third quarter was not as volatile as the second. The yield on the long bond in the second quarter rose to more than 7 percent; in the third quarter, it fell back to levels seen at the beginning of the year.
Mr. Alexy said he believed that the preference of investors has been shifting to the fixed-income market, from equities, in the last six weeks. "Going forward, I expect the Fed to keep rates stable and for consumer spending to be slower," he said. Those conditions, Mr. Alexy added, could result in the long bond's yield dropping to about 6.125 percent.

HEADLINE: New U.S. Envoy to Paris Ponders His Stormy Start

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Barely three weeks after presenting his credentials as the new American Ambassador to France, Felix G. Rohatyn found himself today in the middle of a full-fledged crisis over a $2 billion investment in Iran by the French oil company Total.
French officials from President Jacques Chirac and Prime Minister Lionel Jospin on down have made little secret of their contempt, shared by most governments in Europe, for American legislation that threatens sanctions against foreign countries that invest more than $20 million in Iran. And on Monday, Mr. Jospin went so far as to express enthusiasm for the oil deal, which had been a long time in the making for Total and its Russian and Malaysian partners. 
 "Why now?" Mr. Rohatyn asked himself, in shirt sleeves during an interview today in his New Deal-era embassy office off the Champs-Elysees. He was apparently taken aback by the timing of Total's announcement and Mr. Jospin's support for it.
"You know, at age 69, you are not surprised by much," he said. "Does it poison the relationship between France and the U.S.? I hope not. I don't believe it will. It shouldn't."
An open relationship, he said, would always have differences, but it should be able to overcome "singular events" like this one.
Mr. Rohatyn, a former partner of the Lazard Freres investment firm in New York City, implied that conversations he and other American officials have had with Europeans in high places about their dealings with Iran had not led them to believe a major confrontation would be in the works so soon.
Mr. Rohatyn presented his credentials to Mr. Chirac on Sept. 11, succeeding Pamela Harriman, who died on Feb. 5 after suffering a stroke. His perfect French and his expertise in the world of international finance both earned a warm welcome in the diplomatic and corporate salons of Paris, a capital preoccupied with preserving French influence in an increasingly competitive global economy that the French think is dominated by Anglo-Saxon interests.
"Globalization doesn't carry a threat, but it carries discipline, and then you always have a notion that we are imposing an American-style Anglo-Saxon capitalism," he said. "People forget that 10 years ago, we were being written off, and Japan and Germany were going to take over the world. Now that, like a lot of economic predictions, turned out to be wrong."
Mr. Rohatyn spoke coolly about the deal involving Total, which was once state-owned but is now almost entirely privately held. One way to view the issue, he said, was to see it as "three private companies deciding to make an investment, recognizing that there are risks in this investment because it flies in the face of the law in the U.S.A."
"They decided to make the investment, presumably because they thought the profit was greater than the risk, and they clearly knew the risk," he said. "They evaluated it, and now they have to deal with it, whatever that risk turns out to be."
Gazprom, a huge and politically influential Russian petroleum company, and Petronas, a Malaysian state oil firm, are partners with Total in the Iranian deal.
Mr. Rohatyn would not say today what steps he thought the Clinton Administration would take under the Iran-Libya Sanctions Act, often called the D'Amato law after Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, a Senate sponsor.
But he had an answer for French and other European critics of the D'Amato law and the Helms-Burton law relating to business dealings with Cuba; these critics complain that the laws are examples of attempts by Congress to legislate beyond American boundaries.
"The issue of extraterritoriality, you know, that's a little bit like modern art," he joked. "What is extraterritorial?"
After the European Union's executive commission threatened to disapprove the Boeing Company's merger with McDonnell Douglas last summer, he said, Boeing had to agree to remove exclusivity provisions from 20-year supply contracts with three domestic United States airlines -- American, Continental, and Delta.
"A lot of people back home thought that was extraterritorial," Mr. Rohatyn said. "It's not an open and shut issue." Beyond the problem of Total's decision to put $2 billion into exploitation of an Iranian gas field, he said, was a more important quandary facing Washington and its European allies. "That is, how does the West, how the European Union, France, and the U.S. deal with the behavior of a state that can pose a danger to Western society," he said.
Washington suspects that Iran has tried to develop nuclear weapons and missiles to deliver them, with help from unemployed Russian scientists. The European Union has its own problems with Iran; its member states withdrew their ambassadors from Teheran last summer after a German court found Iranian leaders directly responsible for the killing of three Iranian Kurdish opposition figures in the bombing of a cafe in Berlin in 1992.
"One of the unfortunate things about the timing of this," he said of Total's decision, "is that it may get in the way of what I think is clearly a more important discussion." That, he said, would include an evaluation of a change in direction by the authorities in Iran after last summer's presidential election there.
Keeping up good American relations with France despite continual French suspicions that America would secretly like to relegate its oldest European ally to the rank of a second-rate economic and military power bedevils every American ambassador to Paris.
One of Mr. Rohatyn's jobs has been reassuring banking friends and the numerous French officials he has been calling on that the United States does not oppose the European Union plan to create a common European currency, the euro, in 1999.
"We have an interest in a strong Europe, and Europe has an interest in a strong U.S.," he said. "The euro is a European construction. The criteria of who should join, when, what the parities should be, are all very important, somewhat technical issues in which we have no say, and no preference.
"There is this notion that we are threatened by the euro, that the dollar is threatened by the euro," he laughed. "It is absolutely not true. Our interest is in the outcome. If their decision is to go ahead, we hope that will be successful."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Albright Criticizes France
 Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright strongly criticized France last night for supporting the Total project, expressing frustration that "our friends and allies" did not agree with the United States' efforts to isolate Iran because of its support for terrorism.
Ms. Albright also said that while the election of Iran's new President, Mohammed Khatami, was "intriguing," his Government had done nothing to change what she described as Iran's sponsorship of terrorism, its pursuit of weapons of mass destruction and its efforts to undermine the Middle East peace process.
"It is also a grave concern to us that our friends and allies don't get it," Ms. Albright said, speaking to the Council on Foreign Relations in New York City. "They seem to think that there is some way that we can deal with them without in some way supporting" Iran's behavior.

HEADLINE: Pentagon Aide Warns Czechs to Upgrade Military for NATO

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: VIENNA, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Just as three Central European Governments began detailed talks this month on how their forces would be integrated into NATO, a senior Pentagon official warned the Czechs that they were trailing behind in upgrading their military, according to Czech and American officials.
Assistant Defense Secretary Franklin D. Kramer met with the Czech Defense Ministry two weeks ago and said the Government's military spending was not sufficient, the officials said. He also expressed concern about the lack of enthusiasm among the Czech public for membership in NATO. 
 The Czech Republic, Poland and Hungary were invited to join NATO at a meeting of the alliance in Madrid in July. Opening NATO to the three former Warsaw Pact countries has been a major foreign policy initiative of the Clinton Administration.
The Administration pushed for the inclusion of the new members but told them that they would have to modernize their outdated, Soviet-trained armies. A principal element of the Administration's argument has been that expanding NATO would not burden taxpayers.
This month the three Governments sent delegates to NATO headquarters in Brussels to begin the first round of specific negotiations. Mr. Kramer's criticism of the Czechs came just as they started.
Czech military spending, at 1.5 percent of gross domestic product, is the lowest of the three countries. In Poland it is 2.2 percent of gross domestic product. And Czech popular opinion lags far behind the roar of Polish public sentiment and the growing enthusiasm in Hungary, where military spending accounts for 1.7 percent of gross domestic product.
Because of recent economic difficulties in the Czech Republic, the Government has been under pressure to continue the downward trend in military spending.
"It's true that more needs to be done," said Jire Pehe, the foreign policy adviser to the Czech President, Vaclav Havel. "There needs to be increased public support, and the army needs to modernized and restructured."
Mr. Pehe said Mr. Havel had taken the unusual step of intervening in a Government meeting three weeks ago and insisting that the Czechs keep to a promise of increasing annual military spending by one-tenth of 1 percent of the gross domestic product over five years. Last week the Government approved a draft budget that included the increase. The budget still has to survive three presentations in Parliament.
The Czech Deputy Foreign Minister, Karel Kovanda, presented the military spending plans to President Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, at a meeting in Washington on Monday, an Administration official said. The Foreign Ministers of Poland and Hungary also attended.
Czech Government officials have known for more than a year that they were behind in meeting some NATO requirements but have been slow to remedy the problems.
This is in part because the Czechs have been good at selling themselves abroad but less adept at selling NATO at home. They have also basked in the knowledge that they have a big ally in the Secretary of State, Madeleine K. Albright, who was born in Czechoslovakia.
Public opinion surveys at the beginning of this year showed that about 35 percent of Czechs were in favor of joining NATO. Recently the number has climbed to 50 percent in some surveys, Mr. Pehe said.

HEADLINE: Experts Envision Battle Between Drug and Tobacco Companies

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
The increasing popularity of smoking-cessation aids like nicotine gum and skin patches portends intense competition between drug makers and tobacco companies to deliver smoke-free nicotine to millions of Americans who now smoke, tobacco researchers and market analysts say.
The desire of many smokers to quit and the availability of nonprescription nicotine replacements pose substantial financial risks for the tobacco companies and a huge market opportunity for pharmaceutical manufacturers, these experts say. 
 As a result, tobacco companies, in addition to selling cigarettes, are working on alternative devices of their own that deliver nicotine without the severe health risks of smoking. The drug companies, meanwhile, having already introduced nicotine gum and the nicotine patch, are now marketing a nicotine nasal spray and are developing related products, including a nicotine-laced lollipop.
An article being published on Wednesday in The Journal of the American Medical Association suggests that although their ultimate goals are different -- tobacco companies want to keep their customers for a lifetime, while the drug companies' products are aimed at weaning them from nicotine -- the two giant industries are on a collision course.
"A series of technological, economic, political, regulatory and social developments augurs a strange-bedfellows competition in which these industries will vie for shares of a new multibillion-dollar long-term nicotine-maintenance market," says the article, titled "The Emerging Market for Long-Term Nicotine Maintenance."
Pharmaceutical companies contend that their nicotine replacement products are to be used only temporarily, as a therapeutic aid to help cigarette smokers kick the habit. And until recently, public health officials had been unwilling to speak openly about encouraging development of products to support protracted "nicotine maintenance." Doctors and anti-smoking advocates have urged rapid smoking-cessation programs or quitting cold turkey as the only ways to address nicotine addiction.
But the principal author of the report in the journal, Dr. Kenneth E. Warner of the department of health management and policy at the University of Michigan's School of Public Heath, said in an interview that it was now acceptable to begin thinking about longer-term nicotine therapy, perhaps lasting for years. Such therapy could take the form of a so-called safe cigarette that delivers nicotine without the lethal byproducts of burning tobacco. Or it might be one of the nicotine replacement products now available over the counter, like Nicorette gum or the Nicoderm patch.
"When I first broached this idea three or four years ago, the public health community's reaction was one of horror," Dr. Warner said. "But now a lot of leading thinkers have become more sympathetic," given the recognition that long-term use of nicotine alone, whatever its health drawbacks, is by far preferable to a continuation of smoking.
Dr. Warner acknowledged that some health professionals might find the idea of long-term nicotine use undesirable. But as the cigarette companies and the drug makers rush to develop new nicotine delivery systems, he said, tobacco users will have numerous new means of satisfying their nicotine craving.
"I think the time is right to open this debate and do so with no blinders on," Dr. Warner said.
The SmithKline Beecham Corporation is the nation's leading marketer of nicotine replacement products, selling both Nicorette and Nicoderm through its Consumer Healthcare division. George M. Quesnelle, Consumer Healthcare's vice president for medical marketing and sales, said the company had no intention of marketing its products for long-term use to compete against the cigarette companies for customers.
"We have very opposite goals from the tobacco companies: to help people quit smoking," he said in an interview. "We're coming from diametrically opposed views."
Peggy Carter, a spokeswoman for the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, said the company's officials had not seen the article in the journal and so could not comment on it.
But she added, "We have never perceived ourselves in competition with drug companies."

HEADLINE: Syracuse and S.E.C. Settle a Case Alleging Bond Fraud

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
Budget officials in Syracuse fraudulently misled the bond market about the crumbling state of the city's budget in selling $23.1 million in bonds in late 1995 and early 1996, the Federal Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday.
The commission, in a settlement agreement with the city, said that Syracuse supplied misleading and mislabeled information about its revenue, which, among other results, made it appear as though the city had a budget surplus of $400,000 when it faced a deficit of $9.4 million. 
 Syracuse officials admitted no wrongdoing under the terms of the settlement, and the city's Mayor, Roy A. Bernardi, stressed that the problems cited by the S.E.C. were inadvertent and not deliberate deceptions. A spokesman for the Mayor said the two employees of the Finance Department who were named in the complaint had been reassigned to non-financial reporting duties.
"There was no deliberate effort on the part of any member of this administration to mislead securities investors," Mr. Bernardi said in a statement. "I am pleased that the S.E.C. in its report today recognizes these facts and the extraordinary steps we have taken to insure that problems of this nature will never again occur."
City officials said that the bonds were paid back in full and that no investor lost money.
But the bonds were sold at interest rates that were set on the basis of information supplied by the city that later turned out to be false. Credit analysts said bond buyers did lose money because they would have demanded higher interest rates on the city's debt had they known the truth.
The settlement comes as one more blow to New York's fifth-largest municipality, a once-solid manufacturing city that has struggled in recent years as its economy and its taxation system have come under severe stress. Its recovery from the recession of the late 1980's and early 1990's was far weaker than much of the state's -- or the nation's. And the city budget was further crimped beginning in 1991 when Onondaga County reduced the city's share of the local sales tax revenue.
Haphazard or inadequate financial reporting systems at City Hall made those problems worse, according to the bond-rating agencies that follow municipal finances.
"The recession impacted the city's finances negatively, but poor management systems compounded the degree of fiscal erosion," Standard & Poor's said in announcing a cut in the city's bond rating in March.
The Syracuse auditor, Minch Lewis, a Democrat who has been a vehement critic of the Mayor's financial management -- one of Mr. Lewis's reports led to the commission's investigation 18 months ago -- said yesterday that he believed the problems had still not been fixed. The city is still unable to produce monthly reports on its financial condition and has not done so for years.
"They're flying a $330 million plane with no instruments," he said, referring to the city budget.
The commission said in its settlement report that Syracuse had improperly counted tax revenues that had not yet been paid to the city and overstated the amount of money it had on hand. The city also labeled certain statements as having been "audited," which generally means that the material had been thoroughly checked, when in fact the auditors had expressed reservations. The misstatements collectively made the city's fiscal position seem more solvent than it was, which then made the city's bonds more attractive to the market. The S.E.C. sought no fines, penalties or criminal charges in the case.
Mr. Bernardi, who served as Syracuse's auditor for 20 years before being elected mayor in 1993 -- the first Republican mayor in 24 years -- said that many of the city's reporting problems resulted from trying to overhaul an antiquated Finance Department. The city was still using handwritten ledgers for its accounts when he took office, for example. That system has been replaced with computers.
A spokesman for Standard & Poor's said the settlement would probably not damage the city because the problems, as well as the commission's investigation, had already been factored into the company's most recent risk assessment of the city, in March.
"It's a restatement of something that was out there all along," said Richard J. Marino, a director in Standard & Poor's New York office. "I wouldn't anticipate any change in the rating at this time."

HEADLINE: Fur Is Coming Out of the Fashion Industry's Closet

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Perhaps it started in the spring, when the fashion model Naomi Campbell, who once posed nude for an advertisement that read "I'd rather go naked than wear fur," strolled down the Fendi runway draped in a sable-lined coat from the Italian fashion house. Or maybe it was this fall, when all the important American retail fashion directors announced that they were buying something with fur. But what surely sealed it was the September issue of Vogue, whose cover featured a baby-blue Mongolian lamb jacket.
Fashion is once again placing its bets on fur, so recently a pariah in the industry. 
 Fashion magazines have sold more pages advertising fur this fall than they have in recent memory. Vogue sold 28 pages of fur ads for its fall issues, the most in a decade, said its publisher, Ronald A. Galotti. At Harper's Bazaar, fall fur ads for 1997 are up 87 percent from last year and are also at a 10-year high .
In the September issue of W magazine, the fashion directors of Neiman Marcus, Nordstrom, Saks Fifth Avenue, Bergdorf Goodman, Bloomingdale's and Barneys New York all praised fur -- the first such group hug in years.
And maybe most striking, many more designers, often up-and-comers, now use fur in their collections, and in dozens of new ways. Indeed, 42 designers worked with fur in 1985, while nearly 160 do today, said Stephanie Kenyon, spokeswoman for the Fur Information Council. And they make far more than coats.
Fur is now used as trim on suits, woven through evening gowns and fashioned into handbags. The designer Michael Kors even sent a mink hooded sweatshirt down the runway last spring.
The rebirth of the fur business traces its roots to an odd confluence of circumstances, from a stronger economy and an expanding number of affluent people to growing annoyance with the tactics of anti-fur protesters to a mercurial swing in fashion and life styles, both of which have moved steadily from simplicity to conspicuous consumption.
To be sure, those who stand firmly against fur are enraged about the fashion industry's new embrace.
"Fur is not back," insisted Ingrid Newkirk, president of People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals. "We are pretty flabbergasted that the fashion press has picked up on the fur industry's constant barrage."
The emergence of new designers can be credited almost entirely to the fur industry itself, which spent millions of dollars reaching out to them, teaching them how to work with fur, modernize dowdy looks and convince the trend-obsessed fashion press that fur is once again hip.
The fashion press is an essential part of the equation: it gives the green light on trends to retailers, who in turn buy from designers, who then buy advertisements in the fashion press. And all these players seem determined to bring back fur from its very public downfall at the beginning of the decade, when fur-draped matrons were doused with paint as they emerged from Macy's.
Already, fur sales in the United States have crept back from a 1991 low of $987 million, to $1.25 billion last year. Though that is far below the 1987 peak of $1.8 billion, retailers around the country are confident that a rebound is under way.
"I started to see the handwriting on the wall in the summer of 1996," said Wanda Presburger, president of Somper Furs in Beverly Hills, Calif. "Clients started asking me to clean furs that they haven't had cleaned in a few years. They also started asking, 'What's new?' " She said her sales in 1996 were $1.6 million, a 20 percent increase from the previous year.
"It is absolutely tremendous," said Doyle Hoyer, president of Hoyer's Glasgow Ltd. in Fort Madison, Iowa. "I was up 18 percent last year over 1995, and the trend looks the same for this year."
Like cigars, large vehicles and red meat, fur may be on the brink of returning to the fold of socially acceptable indulgences as many wealthy consumers brush off early 1990's taboos in favor of flaunting their good fortune.
"Fashion is simply less drawn to the moral strictures that drove fur out," said Richard Martin, the curator of the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. "In the late 1980's, people avoided stiletto heels out of a sense of prudence and morality, and it was the same thing with fur. But those forces are certainly waning now. There is a certain cultural sense now that if it feels good, wear it."
Debbie Porter, a sales clerk in Morrison, Ill., bought her first fur coat six years ago but did not dare wear it too often for fear of confrontations with anti-fur protesters. "I would never wear it in an airport," she said. "That was just asking for trouble."
But lately she has draped herself in her ankle-length mink to go everywhere from dinner to the grocery store, pairing the coat with high heels or sneakers.
Demand for furs has clearly risen.The National Trappers' Association and other wildlife experts estimate that the number of wild animal skins now on the market is up at least 30 percent from 1992. The Seattle Fur Exchange, one of the two largest fur auction houses in North America, said mink prices at auctions this year were the highest ever.
Another reason for the return of fur, say people on both sides of the debate, is that Americans have grown weary of anti-fur protesters, who were often perceived as shrill and whose rhetoric often seemed peppered with contradictions.
The argument against animal products, for instance, is hard to swallow for those who wear leather shoes and nibble on chicken wings. And while many saw the rights of animals as a noble cause, many Americans became increasingly irritated at not being able to walk down the street without being accosted. An added twist is that synthetic furs have become so real-looking that often no one can even tell a real fur from a fake, making it hard for the anti-fur people to pick a target.
"The anti-fur movement had its moment and did sort of spend itself," said Julia Emberley, author of "The Cultural Politics of Fur" (Cornell University Press), which will be published in December. "Consumers have become somewhat cynical because the movement presented itself in a very morally self-righteous way. Many consumers feel that it is effectively an issue of consumer rights."
As for the overall boom in luxury goods, Ms. Newkirk of the animal-rights group added: "People know more about the cruelty than ever before. Smoking a cigar is not like anally electrocuting a chinchilla." Unpleasant images like that have been at the heart of the debate for a decade, and until recently animal-rights advocates -- also citing throat-slitting and paw-mangling traps -- seemed to be winning the debate handily.
A spokeswoman for the Fur Information Council, though, insists that anal electrocution is not done on fur farms and that animals are slaughtered much the way they are at animal shelters, which People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals insists is untrue. The group argues that killing animals for their fur is unethical no matter how it is done.
Demand for fur was so strong in the 1970's and early 1980's that furriers could not make enough coats, and prices rose sharply, leading to a flood of inexpensive knock-offs. By 1990, prices and profit margins had softened, and fur began to lose much of its fashion edge. Bargain-basement prices meant that anyone who saved a few dollars could get a cheap coat, which eroded a central appeal: exclusivity.
"Obviously, the fact that coats were being offered at $1,995 with installment payments enlarged the customer base," said Claude Potier, chief executive of Revillon, based in Paris. "But the women for whom the coat was a symbol of luxury were discouraged and bought fewer."
The 1990's also ushered in a recession, along with a short-lived austerity in style. Monkish looks dominated the fashion pages, right next to the grunge look. Cashmere, BMW's and club-hopping took a momentary back seat to flannel shirts, recycling and mulching. Animal-rights groups were in their heyday, and many furriers went bankrupt.
Then, in 1994, the fur business quietly began a public relations campaign of its own. Led by Saga Furs of Scandinavia, an international fur marketing organization owned by breeders in the region, the industry began to lure new designers. Saga financed trips to Copenhagen for dozens of designers, where it taught them how to work with fur, explaining the difficult sewing techniques and walking them through knitting and weaving of the material.
At about the same time, the Fur Information Council began its own counterattack. It placed advertisements in various fashion magazines to counter some of the animal-rights arguments and to try to convince fashion customers that fur was really acceptable.
Many women, of course, will still never go near fur. Margaret Godfrey, who runs Bagatelle, a leather-goods manufacturer, deplores it. "I know fur is selling better," Ms. Godfrey said. "But I don't work with it. I think the traps are terribly cruel. I don't fancy feathers, either."
But as Kim Major, who runs the fur salon at Bergdorf Goodman, sees it, as long as Vogue, Harper's Bazaar and W magazines keep doing large fashion spreads on fur, retail sales should follow. "The fashion press is backing us, and that is all we need," Ms. Major said. "It is easy to make a beautiful coat, but if that attitude change isn't there, we can't sell it."

HEADLINE: At the New Year, a New Day for Riverdale;
A Bronx Neighborhood Is Now a Lively Center for Orthodox Jews

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

 BODY:
Like many college seniors, Noah A. Hammerman finished his education last June with a B.A. in economics and no clear plan for the rest of his life. Unlike most, he saw his prospects in the Riverdale section of the Bronx and bought a kosher butcher shop there.
Now, he stands in his blood-spattered smock, a dark blue yarmulke pinned to his red hair, surveying the hubbub surrounding his first Jewish New Year as proprietor of the Arc of Glatt. He was raised in Riverdale's Orthodox community, and knows that its expanding ranks guarantee a demand for kosher meat. But Mr. Hammerman, 22, mused aloud that it was the presence of a full spectrum of Jews, from the most observant to the least, that clinched his decision. 
 Indeed, while the number of Orthodox Jews living in Riverdale is growing, they account for at most only a fifth of the community's Jews.
"People will come in and ask some question like, 'Can I have a shank bone for my plate?' and one of my non-Jewish employees will tell them they have the wrong holiday, that is for Passover, not Rosh ha-Shanah," Mr. Hammerman said. "I like the fact that there is a range of people here. I feel comfortable where I fall, even if where I fall is more religious than others. I don't shun anyone."
Riverdale is undergoing a profound transition. Once the preserve of foreign diplomats and media executives, the neighborhood is being transformed into a center for one of New York City's most vibrant Orthodox Jewish communities.
The transformation is more evident than ever this time of year, with 10 days of reflection and observance that stretch from Rosh ha-Shanah tomorrow to sundown on Oct. 11, Yom Kippur. The phone rings incessantly in the butcher shop, on Riverdale Avenue. Across the street, at Riverdale Hebrew Books and Gifts, the shelves are stacked with special prayer books and fancy ceramic dishes used to serve the apples and honey that herald a sweet year. Next door, Heisler's Bakery has amassed more than 2,000 orders for challah loaves.
"It will be bedlam," said David Heisler, son of the neighborhood's first kosher baker, who moved to Riverdale from the Grand Concourse 30 years ago. "It wouldn't be Rosh ha-Shanah if you did not have a line out the door, people getting edgy, stepping on each other's toes."
If the holidays make Orthodox Jews survey their neighborhood with a certain satisfaction, it makes the less religious Jews uneasy. Some residents fear that the swelling numbers of the Orthodox may signal that the non-Orthodox and non-Jews are unwelcome.
"You hear a sense of discomfort," said Bernard Stein, editor of The Riverdale Press, the weekly newspaper. "One woman told me that a house near her was bought by 'another Orthodox family.' You hear it in the way the voices drop in conversation, as if it is some secretive, not-so-good thing: 'He has AIDS.' "
Forty years ago, few Jews lived in Riverdale. The Riverdale Temple, a Reform synagogue, opened in an abandoned nightclub in 1947. When Jacob M. Sable, the first Orthodox rabbi to be assigned to the neighborhood, arrived in 1954, he had just five names for his congregation. Most mornings he approached people on the street to get a minyan, the required 10 for prayer.
But the erosion of renowned Jewish neighborhoods in the Bronx and northern Manhattan throughout the 1960's and 1970's changed that, with the middle class moving up from the Grand Concourse in the Bronx and Washington Heights in Manhattan. Today an estimated 35,000 to 40,000 Jews are among the 100,000 residents of Riverdale. Some 10 to 20 percent of those are Orthodox, an estimate based on membership in the three largest Orthodox synagogues, which have 1,400 families.
The last United States census found that in Riverdale the most common language spoken at home after English and Spanish was Yiddish. The Riverdale Jewish Center, the oldest Orthodox congregation, is building a new synagogue to increase seating capacity to 2,100 from 1,300.
"When I opened up eight years ago, I couldn't sell one of those religious books if I gave it away," said Israel Wilhelm, owner of the Hebrew bookshop, pointing to a wall now holding some 10,000 texts of scriptural interpretations.
Many Orthodox Jews choose to live in Riverdale for the same reason others choose it, its leafy streets and river views 30 minutes from Manhattan. The Orthodox are drawn both by the strength of Salanter Akiba Riverdale Academy, the main yeshiva for elementary-school children, and a spirit of cooperation among the different Jewish rabbis.
"Although we are an Orthodox synagogue, we are unorthodox in that we are open to people of all backgrounds, regardless of affiliation," said the Hebrew Institute of Riverdale's Avi Weiss, a rabbi known beyond Riverdale for his political activism but in Riverdale for opening the doors of his synagogue to all comers.
Harsh doctrinal differences do erupt occasionally. Some Orthodox rabbis recently lambasted the 100-strong women's prayer group that meets at the Hebrew Institute because they believe women should be excluded from leading prayer services, even for other women.
But some rabbis say there is also exceptional cooperation among Orthodox, Conservative and Reform synagogues. Residents believe that has to do with both the rabbis involved and the higher level of education and wealth in Riverdale, compared with other Orthodox centers.
"People here are more educated and more involved in real business, so they look more assimilated, but they still retain their religion," said Mr. Hammerman, the butcher. "People here can afford to do things; very religious people go to Aspen to go skiing. They are just more worldly here."
Riverdale has only small outposts of Hasidim, the more rigorously Orthodox Jews, but the Orthodox community has become more fundamentalist and more pointed in pushing less observant Jews to conform, according to Orthodox and non-Orthodox Jews alike in Riverdale.
Residents cite as an example the bagel wars. Lenny Moskowitz opened the Bagel Corner in 1966 and initially served all the synagogues, although he broke kosher rules by opening on Saturday, the sabbath. By 1993 the Orthodox trade was such that he opened a second shop, Rolen Bagels, a few blocks away. That shop is closed on Saturdays.
But the local rabbinical board overseeing kosher standards would not certify his new shop, he said, because he kept the first one open all weekend.
The shift right in Riverdale is attributed largely to young adults whose yeshiva teachers instilled in them an appreciation for the kind of cloistered communities prevalent in Eastern Europe before the Holocaust.
Some Orthodox Jews point out that this closer regard for basic standards is something happening in all religions, not just their own.
"Look at the Arab countries that were so liberal, like Egypt, where the fundamentalists are coming in and changing the nature of the country," said Deena Spindler, a member of the Riverdale Jewish Center.
But the shift makes others uncomfortable. Some residents object, for example, to halting renovation work on apartment buildings during Rosh ha-Shanah, and leaders of both the Reform and Conservative congregations express anxiety over the Orthodox fostering their private institutions. Some attribute an erosion in public school test scores to Orthodox families sending their children to yeshivas.
Rabbi Stephen D. Franklin of the Riverdale Temple, the Reform synagogue, said of the Orthodox, "If they don't send their kids, they won't care about the schools."
Although relations are usually civil, occasional conflicts lead to barbed public exchanges, like the outcry when the Orthodox were initially reluctant to distribute the telephone number of their new ambulance service.
Rabbi Franklin also worries about not being able to attract potential members to his Reform temple amid the Orthodox influx. The Orthodox leaders say Riverdale will not become an isolated enclave. Rabbi Jonathan Rosenblatt of the Riverdale Jewish Center said the Orthodox presence will help keep the real estate values stable, even if the public schools erode, and that congregants will remain active in community affairs.
But the face of Riverdale is undoubtedly changing.
A movie company recently wrote to residents of Fieldston, a neighborhood of expensive homes, to announce plans to shoot some Halloween scenes in late October. The shooting will coincide with Succoth, the holiday following Rosh ha-Shanah. Jews build outdoor huts during Succoth to commemorate the years spent wandering in the wilderness.
"One of my neighbors decided to write a letter, explaining that there would be Succoth huts everywhere," said Mr. Stein, the newspaper editor. "He wanted to tell them that it will be hard to get a clear angle for a Halloween movie."

HEADLINE: Survey Reveals More Pessimism in Japan

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 1

 BODY:
Japanese corporate managers have turned more pessimistic about the economy than they were three months ago and do not foresee improvement until 1998 at the earliest, the Bank of Japan said today in a widely followed survey.
The results of the quarterly survey, known as the tankan, were worse than forecast and offered the latest evidence that Japan's protracted economic weakness would not end soon. Japanese stocks and the yen fell sharply on the news, while yields on the benchmark Government bond -- a barometer of interest rate trends -- dropped to a record low of 1.83 percent before rebounding slightly. 
 "We're stuck with weak growth, and there's no end to it at this stage," said Michael Lockrow, an economist at Technical Data, an economic research firm.
The survey measures the sentiment of executives from 10,000 businesses. Almost every manufacturing group was more pessimistic, including auto makers, machinery makers and steelmakers.
The sentiment index for major manufacturers fell to 3 from 7 in the last survey, in June. That was less than the 8 the companies forecast in the prior survey and the 5 widely projected by economists. The index is derived by subtracting the percentage of those who feel pessimistic from those who are optimistic.
Most manufacturers are even less optimistic about their prospects. The major manufacturers' index will decline further to 1 in the next survey, in December.
Exports have been the economy's only strength. Yet while many big manufacturers are profiting from strong sales in the United States and Europe, this has intensified American pressure on Japan not to rely too much on exports.
At the same time, Japanese businesses cannot rely on much improvement in sales at home, where consumer spending has been suppressed by tax increases earlier this year.

HEADLINE: Colina Journal;
Latin America's Disabled: Unsafely Hidden Away

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: COLINA, Chile, Sept. 30

 BODY:
At a morgue in this suburb of Santiago, 20 bodies lay unclaimed today, a poignant illustration of how this society treats the mentally and physically handicapped.
They were among the 30 children and adults who died when fire engulfed Los Ceibos home for the mentally retarded. By late today relatives of only 10 of those killed had come forward to claim the bodies. 
 In Chile and elsewhere in Latin America, people often react to the disabled with a sense of shame, distance and helplessness, leading many families to abandon them in institutions operated by well-meaning but overburdened private foundations and church groups. Governments provide little money for such programs.
"They deposit these poor, helpless children in institutions as they would a check at a bank," said Sergio Prenafeta Jenkin, executive secretary of the National Fund for the Disabled, a Government agency. "The only problem is that many never come back to see them, and they remain in these facilities for the rest of their lives."
Many of the victims were burned beyond recognition on Monday shortly after midnight when an overheating electric lamp set off a raging fire that quickly engulfed a building housing the most severely disabled residents of Los Ceibos. Many were heavily medicated or in wheelchairs and could not escape. The fire left three other residents injured.
Some relatives of the victims at the home, operated by a nonprofit group called the Limited Child Assistance Foundation, said the eight attendants on duty the night of the fire had not been enough to oversee the 140 residents.
While many industrialized countries discourage warehousing the disabled in institutions and have passed laws to help them integrate into society, less developed nations like Chile still consider the mentally handicapped an aberration or embarrassment who should remain hidden from society.
Disasters involving the disabled have not been unique to Chile. Argentina has been debating the quality of its health care system for the mentally impaired since a suspicious fire in a mental hospital killed 79 people in 1985 and 30 patients died from malnutrition in a Government-run women's psychiatric hospital in 1990.
In the United States, the disabled have never been more visible, taking part in everything from work to organized sports. In Chile and other Latin American countries, they are rarely seen in public. When they do appear, people often point, giggle or treat them as if they should have remained indoors.
"We don't care about the disabled in Chile," Mr. Prenafeta said, "because we are a society that places too much value on success, and we leave those who do not prosper to fend for themselves. How can disabled children fend for themselves?"
Officials of the nonprofit foundation that operates Los Ceibos said half of the 3,500 residents in its 28 homes throughout Chile had been abandoned and did not receive visits from relatives.
Guillermo Vidal, vice president of the foundation, which is known by the Spanish acronym Coanil, said many families of the disabled were so poor that they were incapable of caring for the mentally retarded.
"It would be ideal if every family would assume its responsibility for these children," Mr. Vidal said, "but many of these kids come from families that live in such extreme poverty that they receive much better care in our hands."
About 400,000 of Chile's 13 million people are considered mentally disabled. About 35 percent of the population lives below the poverty line, and the average monthly salary is about $175.
On the other hand, Chile has become a model for economic reform in Latin America, having become rich in cash reserves and having established one of the fastest-expanding economies and lowest inflation rates in the region.
It is unclear exactly how much money the Government provides for the care of the mentally disabled, mainly because the money is administered by various agencies and there is no central department with responsibility for the disabled.
Most homes for the disabled are operated by church groups and independent foundations like Coanil that receive Government and private donations.
One estimate in the local press said the Government provided Coanil about $200 a month for each resident, or about 45 percent of the monthly cost of care.
Some family members of the fire victims at Los Ceibos said the home suffered from overcrowding and understaffing.
"There were not enough workers on duty that night, and that electric lamp should not have been there," said Rosa Ramirez Guzman, 57, whose 20-year-old daughter, Lucinda, died in the fire. "But I have nothing against the institution, because the attendants were the best. They treated my child better than I could, because I had to work very hard for a living."
Early reports of the fire on Monday misidentified the home, referring to it as Los Laureles, another home where some of the survivors had been taken.
Mrs. Ramirez is a single mother who lives in San Antonio, two hours west of Santiago. The last time she saw her daughter was last week, when she took a picture of the young woman standing next to a new bed that Mrs. Ramirez had taken to the home.
Today, Mrs. Ramirez and her other daughter, Magarita, carried that photograph with them as they walked through the charred remains of the home. "She's gone, she's gone," Magarita said, bursting into tears. "There's nothing left of the bed where she used to dream."
Fire officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said today that the ward contained highly flammable insulating material in the roof, which helped the fire spread rapidly, and lacked appropriate fire walls and exits for people using wheelchairs.
The fire officials agreed with victims' families that there had not been enough attendants on duty to remove the large number of incapacitated residents. The officials added that the nearest fire hydrants were two-thirds of a mile from the home.
Mr. Vidal of Coanil disputed accusations that the dormitory ward was a fire hazard, saying it had been recently upgraded to comply with all existing standards.
Mr. Vidal also denied that the home was overcrowded, saying it had about 90 full-time employees who worked in shifts. He said there was a list of 400 prospective residents waiting for vacancies.
Meanwhile, residents of Colina said gruesome images of the fire were forever etched in their memories, particularly scenes of young residents who believed that the fire was a game and continued to return to the burning building after they had been rescued by firefighters.
"It was surreal," said Miguel Lara, who lives near the home and helped in the rescue efforts. "Those poor, innocent children had no idea what was going on. Some of them were burned and could barely walk, or scooted along on their hands, but they were smiling as they kept trying to go back into the fire. They need our help."

HEADLINE: New Immigration Rules Hit Some Companies Hard

BYLINE: By MIRTA OJITO 

 BODY:
In SoHo, a Japanese restaurant closed its doors last Friday after the chef returned to Japan. In Westport, Conn., a construction company shut down when the owner, a Chilean immigrant, suddenly left with his family. And in a midtown Manhattan factory, where 25 employees work making fine jewelry 14 hours a day, the owner, a Ukrainian refugee, wonders whether he too should pack and leave.
Changes in immigration rules have prompted many immigrants in the New York area and across the country who are seeking legal status to return to their homelands in the last week, believing that such a move, however painful, is their best hope for someday returning legally. 
 It is impossible to tell how many people may have left the country in the recent exodus. But immigration lawyers and advocates believe that the wave of departures will have a great impact on some businesses, especially those that rely heavily on the expertise of foreigners, like detailed construction work, specialty restaurants and some highly technical jobs.
Already, in Manhattan, a popular downtown restaurant, Katana, closed after its chef, Nao Hiko Sugiyama, returned to Japan to continue his appeal for residency status in the United States, said Sam Firer, the restaurant's public relations man. Mr. Sugiyama's specialty was kaiseki cuisine, a rare food that originated with the Japanese tea ceremony.
Other restaurants in the city lost a significant number of employees last week and had to scramble to find replacements on short notice. Nobu, a Japanese restaurant in TriBeCa, lost 6 of its 20 waiters, said Richard M. Notar, the restaurant's general manager. "One day, I had a full staff," Mr. Notar said. "Next day, no waiters. And it is not easy to replace them. We are very particular about who we hire. And then there is the training."
The sudden exodus has been set off by two changes in immigration rules. One is the expiration of a three-year-old law that allowed illegal immigrants who were seeking green cards to obtain the documents here. Under the new rules, those close to obtaining a green card, which confers legal status, must go home to get the document.
Under a second change, which took effect on Saturday, immigrants who have been in the United States illegally for more than six months and who leave for any reason, including going home to get a green card, can be barred from returning for three years. Those who have been in this country illegally for more than a year can be denied re-entry for 10 years.
The Senate joined the House yesterday in delaying the expiration of the green-card rule, which was to happen yesterday, for three weeks. But experts said the brief reprieve would affect very few of the thousands of immigrants faced with the decision of whether to stay or go. The American Immigration Lawyers Association and about 80 other national organizations and big businesses, including Apple Computer and Hewlett-Packard, support a longer extension of the provision allowing those seeking green cards to stay here.
Those who left, like Mr. Sugiyama, played it safe, being willing to wait for their green card outside the United States. But those who stayed took a gamble. Their hope is that the expiring provision will be extended beyond the three weeks, so that they can continue to live here while seeking their legal status.
Judith B. Sporn, an immigration lawyer in Westport, said 99 percent of her clients opted to stay despite a letter that she sent them urging them to leave by the deadline.
"If they are wrong, they are in a lot of trouble," Ms. Sporn said. "But had they left, they would have had an incredible impact on businesses. There isn't a restaurant that does not need people like them. How are you supposed to have foreign specialties without the foreigners?" One who chose to stay, a client of Ms. Sporn's who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he was a Brazilian chef who works without a working permit. He stayed, he said, because there is nothing and no one waiting for him in Brazil.
"My wife is here, my job is here, my home is here," he said. "My boss told me that if I left, the restaurant would be in a lot of trouble."
That is Feodor Sheffer's dilemma. He is a refugee from Ukraine, who was denied political asylum two days before the deadline. Mr. Sheffer decided to stay in the hope that an immigration judge would grant him his asylum in January, his next immigration hearing.
Mr. Sheffer is the owner of the NK Star Corporation, a jewelry factory in midtown Manhattan that employs 25 people. If he leaves, Mr. Sheffer said, the factory will close and his employees will have no work.
Despite the disruption for some families and businesses, Rae D. Rosen, a regional economist for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said she did not expect the departures to have a broad effect on the economy. "The size of the labor market here is so great, that their departure will not have a significant impact, however painful to the individual it is," Ms. Rosen said.
Lawmakers who oppose the extension of the expiring rule say that if illegal immigrants leave, more Americans, who are now unemployed, will find jobs.
Allan Kay, a spokesman for Representative Lamar Smith, a Texas Republican who opposes the provision, said the Congressman "is deeply concerned about American citizens and legal residents not getting jobs because they are filled by people who are here illegally."

HEADLINE: Panel Urges That Immigrants Become Further Americanized

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
A Federal advisory panel called today for a major campaign to integrate new immigrants into American society, and it won support from an influential Republican Congressman for its proposal to dismantle the Immigration and Naturalization Service.
In its final report to Congress after five years of work, the panel, the United States Commission on Immigration Reform, also said that some decisions on applications for visas should be subject to review by a new Government agency. 
 That would represent a radical change. Now, would-be immigrants and their American sponsors generally cannot appeal decisions of consular officers who deny applications for visas. The panel would allow such appeals in some cases.
Bruce A. Morrison, a member of the panel, explained the reason for appeal rights by saying, "Lack of accountability in any decision-making structure is not tolerable."
The nine-member commission concluded its work with a ringing endorsement of the value of legal immigration, saying that migrants contributed to the nation's economic growth and productivity.
But it said that Federal and state officials must step up their efforts to incorporate immigrants into the nation's civic and political culture. For example, it said, newcomers need help in English-language skills and should be trained for high-tech jobs, so that they will move up the economic ladder.
Susan Martin, executive director of the commission, said that many children of Hispanic immigrants dropped out of school and that many immigrant teen-agers never enrolled in schools in this country.
Cecilia Munoz, deputy vice president of the National Council of La Raza, a Hispanic civil rights organization, said she saw great merit in the proposal for a new emphasis on the "Americanization" of immigrants.
"The United States has relied on immigrant families and on employers to help immigrants adjust to life in this country -- to find jobs and housing, to enroll in school, to open bank accounts," Ms. Munoz said. "If the Government and the larger society would invest in such services, we could get a huge return, and immigrants would make a quicker adjustment to American life. Immigrants are accused of not wanting to learn English, but they are eager to do so. Many English-language programs have enormous waiting lists."
The chairman of the House Appropriations subcommittee responsible for the immigration service, Harold Rogers, a Kentucky Republican, welcomed many of the panel's recommendations. He endorsed the proposal to dismantle the immigration service and distribute its functions among the Departments of Justice, State and Labor.
He agreed with the commission's conclusion that the immigration service was suffering from "mission overload," but not from a lack of money. Indeed, he said, the budget of the agency, $3.1 billion this year, has increased 50 percent in the last two years and has more than tripled in the last decade.
"At last," he said, "someone is telling it like it is. The I.N.S. is overloaded, and money is no longer an excuse. The agency has too much on its plate. It cannot control our borders, process immigrants and safeguard U.S. citizenship. We've seen tens of thousands of criminals granted the most precious benefit our country has to offer: U.S. citizenship. We have over five million illegal aliens residing in the United States, the same all-time high of 10 years ago."
The House Appropriations Committee recently instructed Attorney General Janet Reno to devise a plan to "transfer some of the responsibilities of the I.N.S. to other departments and agencies."
Advocates for immigrants and immigration lawyers were cool to the proposal to break up the I.N.S.
Jeanne A. Butterfield, executive director of the American Immigration Lawyers Association, said she doubted that immigrants would receive better service from the State Department than from the immigration service, which is now part of the Justice Department. From years of dealing with State Department officials, she said, "we know that they are opposed to review of their decisions, have no mechanisms in place to assure due process of law and are ill equipped to deal with the volume and complexity of cases that I.N.S. must adjudicate on a daily basis."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

INTERNATIONAL A3-10
 
French Catholic Church Apologizes for Holocaust
The Roman Catholic Church in France apologized for being at fault during the French collaboration with the Holocaust. The statement was an extraordinary admission of responsibility in a country that has struggled to come to terms with the actions of its World War II Government. A1
 
Israel Frees Hamas Founder
Israel freed the jailed founder of the Islamic militant Hamas movement, flying him in a helicopter to Jordan because of what it said was his worsening health. An Army statement said Sheik Ahmed Yassin was flown to Amman in answer to a request by King Hussein to take positive steps to help Middle East peacemaking. A5 

Blair Promises a Model Britain
Speaking to cheering delegates at the Labor Party's annual conference, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain pledged to run "one of the great, radical, reforming governments in British history." Mr. Blair has an approval rating of 77 percent. A6
 
Counter-Coup in Belgrade
Yugoslavia's president, Slobodan Milosevic, and his allies consolidated their power by ousting the reformer who had become mayor of Belgrade after months of demonstrations last winter. Mr. Milosevic also regained control of a television station. The moves were made possible by a split in prodemocracy forces. A6
 
A Slap at China Policy
The House Committee on International Relations approved a bill denying visas to Chinese officials who violate human rights. The move was meant to challenge President Clinton's China policy as the Administration prepared for a visit a month from now by President Jiang Zemin of China. But the bill's chances were considered uncertain in the House and slimmer in the Senate. A9
 
India, Pakistan Exchange Fire
Pakistan and India exchanged cross-border artillery barrages in the disputed region of Kashmir, leaving up to 21 people dead and 37 injured, reports from the two sides said. Each side accused the other of instigating the latest border clash. India and Pakistan have fought two wars in the last 50 years over Kashmir. India accuses Pakistan of arming and training rebels in the region, which Pakistan denies. The episode came a week after the Prime Ministers of India and Pakistan met in New York in an effort to bring such incidents under control. (AP)
 
Congo May Reject U.N. Team
The President of Congo, Laurent Kabila, indicated that he plans to seek the withdrawal of a United Nations team investigating alleged massacres in his nation, the former Zaire. "We request Kofi Annan," the United Nations Secretary General, "to ask them to leave," Mr. Kabila said.The team to investigate alleged massacres of Rwandan refugees has been in Congo for nearly six weeks seeking Government clearance to begin its investigation. (Reuters)

Deadline on Welfare Law Looms for Many States
With an Oct. 1 deadline looming, fewer than half the states say they will meet all the ambitious work goals embedded in last year's welfare law, creating a politically awkward situation for President Clinton and for some governors. The conservative supporters of the law are urging the Administration to impose financial penalties on non-compliant states. A1
 
Trade Accords Lack Support
The Republican leaders of both the House and Senate said legislation giving the President renewed authority to negotiate global trade accords had failed to gain enough support in Congress and blamed President Clinton for not doing enough to win Democrats to the cause. A1

Walter F. Mondale and Nancy Kassebaum Baker urged senators to restrict unregulated donations to political parties, but insiders said that the sponsors had not rounded up enough votes to pass such legislation. A20

Catholic bishops are advising parents of gay children to put love and support for their sons and daughters before church doctrine that condemns homosexual activity. A14

B1

Over the objections of gag-wearing free-speech advocates, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority adopted new rules allowing transit officials to reject advertising for the subway, buses or trains that might be offensive to "a significant segment of the public." The new rules also allow the transit agency to reject ads that it believes could hurt its business -- a provision that some advocacy groups said could be used to censor ads critical of the M.T.A.'s performance.
