HEADLINE: Betting Inflation Stays Dormant, Fed Leaves Interest Rates Alone

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve voted today to keep interest rates unchanged, again showing its willingness to tolerate strong growth as long as the economy displays no clear signs of incipient inflation.
With prices of both consumer and producer goods rising at barely perceptible rates, the Fed's decision not to change monetary policy had been widely expected by economists and in the financial markets. 
 But the decision pushed the central bank deeper into uncharted economic territory. In leaving its official rates unchanged, the Fed continued to set aside the long-held doctrine that robust growth at a time of low unemployment leads almost inevitably to rising wages and prices. It is betting instead that either a confluence of temporary factors or a more fundamental improvement in the economy's ability to expand without inflation will keep price increases under control.
"By conventional measures the U.S. economy seems like it should be overheating," said James Glassman, an economist at Chase Securities in New York. "But you have to have confirmation that there is inflation before you have a problem to address, and for the Fed there's no problem to address right now."
Economic statistics reported today did little to alter current perceptions of the economy.
Consumer confidence edged higher in September, from an already strong level, said the Conference Board, a business research group in New York. The group's index of consumer confidence rose to 128.6 in September from a revised 127.6 in August.
In a separate report, the Commerce Department said sales of new single-family homes fell a larger-than-expected 2.2 percent in August to an annual rate of 800,000, but that followed a climb of four-tenths of a percent in July and kept sales at a relatively strong rate.
The question is how long the current, almost ideal combination of robust growth, low unemployment and minimal inflation can be maintained. Under its chairman, Alan Greenspan, the Fed over the last decade has built a record of acting to suppress inflation long before it could infect the economy. With the long expansion expected to continue through this year, analysts said the Fed could face difficult decisions about whether to resurrect its pre-emptive strategy by nudging rates up at one of its next two policy-setting meetings, in November and December.
The Fed has raised rates only once during the surge in growth of the last 18 months. In March it raised its Federal funds target rate by a quarter-point, to 5.5 percent, near the end of a quarter in which the economy grew 4.9 percent.
The economy grew at a 4.1 percent pace in the first half of this year -- almost double the rate at which traditional economic models would predict inflationary stirrings -- and appears likely to have grown 3 percent or more in the three months ending today.
Unemployment stands at 4.9 percent, and has touched a 23-year low of 4.8 percent several times this year. Many economists believe that sustained unemployment of less than 5.5 percent ultimately leads employers to raise wages to attract workers, leading in turn to higher prices as companies pass their higher labor costs along to consumers -- a phenomenon that has been noticeably absent in the economy this year.
Fed officials as well as most private economists have consistently forecast slowdowns in the economy over the last 18 months that have either not materialized or proved transitory. If there is no sign by the end of the year that the economy is cooling off, the pressure on the Fed to tighten policy by a notch is sure to grow, analysts said.
"They always see a slowdown around the corner or under way," said David Hensley, an economist at Salomon Brothers in New York.
There are only the faintest signs of even preliminary inflation pressures building. The rate at which factories are operating, for example, has been creeping upward and last month stood at 83.9 percent of capacity, just below the level economists consider an early warning signal of production bottlenecks that can lead to higher prices.
The Fed's policy-making committee met at the same time that the Senate Banking Committee began considering President Clinton's nominees to fill two vacancies on the seven-member Federal Reserve Board.
The nominees, Roger W. Ferguson Jr. and Edward M. Gramlich, both stressed in their testimony to the committee that they considered achieving price stability to be the Fed's primary mission. Their statements were unsurprising given that the Republican-controlled Senate would probably not be willing to confirm them if they did not publicly place price stability ahead of the Fed's other legislatively mandated mission, promoting maximum employment.
But both Mr. Ferguson, a specialist in banking and technology for the consulting firm McKinsey & Company, and Mr. Gramlich, dean of the School of Public Policy at the University of Michigan, hinted that they saw the Fed as a pulpit to promote other goals as well.
"I strongly feel that both economic and social goals are important," Mr. Gramlich said. "Sometimes one's advice must be weighted toward economic practicality, sometimes toward humanity."
Mr. Ferguson, who if confirmed would be the third black Fed governor, said he was concerned by issues like income inequality and job creation, even if the Fed could not address them directly.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
ITT soars as its suitor, Hilton Hotels, and traders anticipate a court-ordered vote.

BYLINE: By Kenneth N. Gilpin 

 BODY:
The price of the ITT Corporation's stock jumped more than 8 percent yesterday, one day after a Federal judge ruled that the company's board could not split ITT into three companies without shareholder approval.
The ruling gave a big lift to the $70-a-share, $11.5 billion hostile takeover bid for ITT by the Hilton Hotels Corporation. The plan for a three-way split, announced on July 16, was part of a strategy devised by ITT to fend off Hilton's bid. 
 Investors, in their latest reaction to developments in a battle that began in January, pushed up ITT's stock price by $5.25 a share yesterday, to $67.75. Hilton's stock also rose, albeit more modestly: at the close, on the New York Stock Exchange, the shares were quoted at $33.6875, up $1.5625.
Hilton had taken ITT to court in Nevada, contending that the anti-takeover strategy was a violation of shareholders' rights.
ITT, which is based in New York, is incorporated in Nevada, and has not held a shareholders meeting since the spring of 1996. Under Nevada law, which requires that a shareholders meeting be held at least every 18 months, ITT was facing a deadline of mid-November for a meeting. ITT had sought to split up the company before a meeting could be held, but Hilton challenged that intention.
At a hearing in Las Vegas on Monday, Judge Philip M. Pro of the Federal District Court in Nevada agreed with Hilton's arguments, and ordered ITT to hold a meeting by Nov. 14 to consider the plan.
After saying on Monday that it would abide by Judge Pro's decision, ITT said yesterday that it would hold its annual meeting on Nov. 12 in New York City, at a site to be determined. Shareholders of record as of today will be eligible to vote at the meeting, ITT said.
After the ruling, Hilton said that it would welcome an opportunity to try to negotiate a merger agreement with the management of ITT. But ITT, which has flatly rejected that request in the past, did so again yesterday.
"We have nothing to discuss with Mr. Bollenbach," Jim Gallagher, an ITT spokesman, said, referring to Hilton's chief executive, Stephen F. Bollenbach.
Marc A. Grossman, a Hilton spokesman, said of the ITT response, "It is unfortunate, because we think there is a great opportunity to work together to create value for shareholders."
Securities analysts said that with such a short time left before the November meeting, ITT would find it difficult to push its stock price much above Hilton's $70-a-share offer, meaning that shareholders might look favorably on the bid.
Bruce Turner, the lodging and gambling analyst at Salomon Brothers, said, "Everything ITT did hinged on proceeding with their plan without shareholder approval." With that strategy foiled, "I don't think ITT can win," Mr. Turner added.
To raise its stock price, ITT has sold a number of noncore assets, including its 50 percent stake in Madison Square Garden.
When it announced its breakup plan in July, ITT said it would separate its remaining hotel and casino businesses, its technical school and its international telephone directory operations, as well as buy back up to 30 million of its shares at $70 a share and repurchase all $2 billion of its public debt.
"We look forward to the annual meeting and remain confident that our comprehensive plan provides superior economic value to our shareholders," Rand V. Araskog, ITT's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement yesterday.
Responding to one of Judge Pro's criticisms, ITT said it would eliminate a proposed staggered board at ITT Destinations, the hotel and gambling operation that Hilton wants most and that is the core of the company.
A staggered board, on which the directors come up for re-election at different times, is often used as an anti-takeover device.
Since late January, ITT has used the Nevada law permitting it to put off its annual meeting as a shield against Hilton, one that provided it time to sell assets in an effort to lift its share price and to formulate its defensive strategy.
But some law professors said the delay might actually have made it easier for Judge Pro to rule as he did.
"What ITT was proposing in terms of restructuring the company is sweeping in scope, but other companies, like AT&T, have done the same thing without shareholder approval," said Lawrence R. Hamermesh, an associate professor at the Widener University School of Law in Wilmington, Del., and a former corporate attorney.
"But when you do it as a means of deferring a meeting in which stockholders are threatening to throw you out, then the courts get excited," he said. "If ITT had had a shareholders meeting within the last 12 months, I don't know how much the judge could have said."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Business Activity Is Rising

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Business activity in the New York metropolitan region continued to expand in September from the previous month, the National Association of Purchasing Management-New York said yesterday.
The New York purchasing managers index rose to 60.3 percent last month, from August's 55 percent. A reading above 50 percent signals growth. The index has been above 50 percent every month since March 1996, after falling to 46.7 percent in February of last year. 
 Looking at the next six months, New York purchasers remained upbeat, with the monthly index of future conditions holding steady at 69.5 percent in September from August's 70.9 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Asians Suffer Further Damage On Malaysian's New Remarks

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Southeast Asian currencies again fell to record lows against the dollar yesterday, and analysts said further declines were likely because of continued concerns about the region's faltering economic growth.
Contributing to yesterday's decline was a speech on Tuesday by Malaysia's Prime Minister, Mahathir Mohamad. Reiterating comments he had made last month, Dr. Mahathir called for more regulations on currency trading. 
 David Bassanese, senior economist at Bankers Trust Australia Ltd. in Sydney, said: "We are at a point where fear is feeding on fear. As long as they come up with anti-market rhetoric, currencies and markets will come under pressure. We're getting into panic levels."
The Malaysian ringgit, the Indonesian rupiah and the Philippine peso all fell to record lows. The ringgit declined as much as 5 percent, to a rate of 3.41 to the dollar; the rupiah fell for a sixth consecutive day, losing as much as 2.6 percent, to 3,369 for each dollar, and the Philippine peso decreased as much as 2.9 percent, to 34.96 to the dollar, setting a record low for the fourth day.
The Singapore dollar, a strong currency in past periods, touched its lowest level in more than three years, and the Thai baht fell to its lowest level in eight days.
A number of Asian stock markets were also lower yesterday.
The currency troubles were touched off by the effective devaluation of the baht three months ago. It has fallen 41 percent against the dollar this year; Malaysia's currency has lost one-third of its value, and the Indonesian currency has fallen 42 percent.
The Singapore dollar, whose value is determined in relation to a basket of the currencies of its trading partners, has lost 10 percent against the United States dollar.
Andy Tan, general manager at MMS International, a financial services unit of the Standard & Poor's Corporation, said: "It no longer makes sense to pick a ceiling" for the American dollar's value against regional currencies. "Everything is being driven by sentiment."
Speaking on Tuesday at an Asia-Pacific regional meeting in Santiago, Chile, Malaysia's Prime Minister said, "I would like to suggest that we do away with trade in currency as a commodity." He added that although there were no immediate plans to regulate trading in the ringgit, "there must be some regulation" in the future.
His comments were ill timed, said Richard Gibbs, an international economist at the Macquarie Bank in Sydney. "We were starting to get to a position where stability was coming through."

U.S. Dollar Is Higher
 By The Associated Press
 The dollar rose against the Japanese yen in New York trading yesterday after a Japanese central bank survey showed business confidence in the country's economy weakening.
The dollar gained against the German mark on reports that a Bundesbank policy council member, Edgar Meister, said the dollar was not creating inflationary pressure. That dampened expectations that the German central bank would soon raise interest rates.
In late trading, the dollar was quoted at 120.90 Japanese yen, up from 120.50 yen on Monday. The dollar sold at 1.7734 German marks, up from 1.7624. It rose, too, against the British pound, which declined to $1.6152, from $1.6168 on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Betting the U.S. Economy on a Rising Stock Market

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Twice in the 1990's, the American economy has produced nearly identical periods of booming growth. Yet the experts looked at what was happening and saw in the first surge, in 1994, the makings of a disaster and in the second, this year, nirvana.
A big reason for the shift to optimism from pessimism appears to be the stock market. Sustaining the Dow Jones industrial average at record levels is gradually becoming as much a priority among investors as fighting inflation. And for the Dow average to keep rising seems to require a leap of faith that the economy will continue along its present prosperous course, unhindered by a rising inflation rate, or even the threat that this might happen. 
 "The stock market is coloring every decision," said Peter L. Bernstein, an economist and consultant. "It is no longer the consequence of confidence but the cause of it. It now extends way beyond itself in its influence, pushing into the background concerns about inflation."
The purveyors of the new optimism are the economists, executives, stock and bond traders, and the mutual and pension fund managers who, in their constant forecasts and pronouncements, shape the public perception of the national economy. Most take their cue from Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve. And in sharp contrast to the growth surge three years ago, Mr. Greenspan seems to have given his O.K. for this one to continue.
The Fed's announcement on Tuesday that interest rates would remain unchanged was the latest reaffirmation of this O.K. In the new dynamic, raising interest rates to slow the economy and keep inflation in check would almost certainly provoke a sharp decline in stock prices, and falling stock prices would in turn discourage spending and investment far more than in the recent past. With the Dow average up nearly 24 percent this year, rising stock prices have become for millions of Americans a powerful source of confidence, wealth and spending, sustaining the economy.
"We have a huge vested interest in keeping stock prices up," said Albert Wojnilower, senior economic adviser to the Clipper Group, a Wall Street firm. "Millions of people who have put their money into stocks want to be optimistic and corporations have invested on the basis of their optimism. It won't change unless we get slapped in the face with evidence of rising inflation."
The shift in attitudes -- from pessimism to optimism, from expectations of rising inflation and a weakening economy to a growing confidence that neither will happen -- shows up in striking fashion in a comparison of the two nearly identical growth periods, each covering nine months. The first, starting in October 1993, produced an average growth rate of 4.3 percent, which is quite powerful. During the second surge in growth, beginning last October and running through June of this year, the gross domestic product rose by an average of 4.2 percent, according to final data for the period, released last week.
The inflation rate also behaved in strikingly similar fashion in each period. It averaged 2.7 percent in 1993-94 and 2.4 percent in 1996-97. More important, the inflation rate fell during both periods. But while low inflation is taken as a given in the optimism of 1997, that was not the case three years ago. Although inflation was edging down, the great expectation then was that strong economic growth would inevitably generate a destructive rise in the inflation rate.
"We all thought then that inflation must follow excessively strong growth," said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch. "That same view would resurrect itself now in a second, of course, if Mr. Greenspan were to say that he was worried on this count. But he does not say that."
The unemployment rate also fell during both periods, although it was higher in 1993-94, averaging 6.5 percent, than in the most recent nine months, when the average was down to 5.2 percent. There is irony in this difference. With fear of inflation the dominant concern three years ago, there was much speculation that falling unemployment would soon result in labor shortages, rising wages and accelerating inflation as companies raised prices to pay the higher labor bills. An unemployment rate of just over 6 percent was thought to be the flash point.
Indeed, such thinking was a big factor in the Fed's decision to slow the economy and dilute the demand for labor by raising interest rates to 6 percent from 3 percent, starting in February 1994. Today, the unemployment rate is more than a percentage point below the 1993-94 level, but the unemployment-inflation tradeoff is hardly discussed.
"It is a very important concept in economic theory, but the discussion just died," said Robert Pollin, an economist at the University of California in Riverside.
Certainly changing circumstances help to explain the reversal in concerns. The budget deficit has fallen sharply, nullifying that as an inflation issue. The Fed has left short-term interest rates just below 6 percent, which helps in restraining the economy and inflation, some economists argue. Job insecurity and a flood of relatively inexpensive imports also help to keep down wages and prices. And the latest surge in economic growth without any sign of sharply rising prices has finally convinced many Americans that low inflation has become the norm.
To explain this sea change in the behavior of inflation, many economists, investors and executives have embraced the view that American workers have become more efficient and productive -- allowing profits and wages to rise without feeding inflation. The booming stock market, in this view, reflects this new era of rising productivity, pushing concerns about inflation to the back burner, says Mickey D. Levy, chief economist of Nationsbank.
Mr. Greenspan, in his public statements, has encouraged this thinking. The dissenters from this spreading optimism are becoming a distinct minority. One is Alan Blinder, a Princeton economist who was the Fed's vice chairman when interest rates were doubling in 1994 and early 1995. While voting for all the increases, he had argued that some should have been smaller. In his view, inflation does not suddenly shoot up, as if a trip cord had been released, but rises gradually, giving the Fed time to reverse the trend without overdoing rate increases.
Mr. Blinder still holds this view, but he argues that the tendency now to overlook inflationary pressures may have gone too far. "At the current low rate of unemployment and high rate of capacity utilization," he said, "we have to keep in mind the possibility of gradually mounting wage and price pressures."

HEADLINE: SOCCER;
British Quartet Rocks Jamaica

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

 BODY:
While surfing the World Wide Web earlier this year, Coach Steve Sampson of the United States came across a German soccer player named Michael Mason. The midfielder spoke little English and had never set foot in this country, but Mason's father was a retired serviceman born in Philadelphia.
Thus, under soccer's liberal rules, the son was eligible for the United States national team. Mason was signed up and, given his Internet connection, was handed the nickname Dotcom. 
 It is a common practice for soccer teams to cast a wide net for players. Jack Charlton, who coached Ireland during the World Cup in 1990 and 1994, was an acknowledged master. If a player had ever vacationed on the Emerald Isle, or stopped in to buy a wool sweater, Charlton seemed to find a way to make him eligible.
El Salvador has called up a naturalized Serbian and two Brazilians. And now, after struggling early in the final round of qualifying for the 1998 World Cup, Jamaica decided to take a plunge into the international talent pool.
During tomorrow night's game against the United States in Washington, Jamaica will feature four players from England who have revived a ragged, deflated team and given it a fighting chance to become the first World Cup qualifier from the Caribbean since Haiti in 1974.
Collectively, these British sons of Jamaican immigrants have been labeled the Fab Four, and the Beatles. One of them, Deon Burton, scored the winning goal for Jamaica (3-2-2) in both of its recent 1-0 victories over Canada and Costa Rica.
A victory over the United States (2-1-3) would vault the Reggae Boyz, as the team is known, to the top of the North American, Central American and Caribbean region with two games remaining. Three of the region's six teams will advance to the 1998 World Cup in France.
Rene Simoes, the Brazilian who has coached Jamaica to the verge of its first World Cup appearance, was reluctant to send out an international S O S last June. He wanted players who were born in Jamaica and who played in Jamaica. But he changed his mind after his team scored only two goals in its first five qualifying games. The Reggae Boyz had wasted a chance at victory in a 0-0 draw at home against an unprepared United States team in March. Then Jamaica lost a humiliating 6-0 game in Mexico after brawling with a Mexican club team during an earlier scrimmage.
Onandi Lowe, one of Jamaica's top players, simply walked off the field during the Mexico game after refusing Simoes's order to switch positions. He was later suspended for four years.
Faced with internal dissent and lapses in determination and organization, Simoes desperately needed to make changes. When Jamaica limped to the midway point of this final qualifying round in June, the coach decided to hold a casting call for players based in Britain.
"I knew there were more than 100 players in the United Kingdom who have parents from Jamaica," Simoes said. "My first attitude was to build a Jamaican product. But we needed more experience, a more professional attitude."
For a couple of years, Paul Hall and Fitzroy Simpson had been sending letters and press clippings to the Jamaican federation from their playing base in Portsmouth, England. When they came to Kingston for a tryout in June, they asked a teammate, the 20-year-old Burton, to join them. Not that the Jamaican federation had any great expectations about him.
"There didn't seem to be any harm in him coming, so we said O.K.," said Horace Reid, general secretary of the Jamaican federation.
Burton, whose father is from Jamaica, didn't have any high hopes of his own, either.
"I was just going there to get fit for the English season," he said. "This is all a big surprise."
The last three months have been a splendid blur. Burton has been transferred from Portsmouth to Derby County in the English Premier League. In Jamaica, he has gone from afterthought to national hero after his winning goals against Canada and Costa Rica. His shaved-head brilliance and cafe-au-lait skin tone have brought him the nickname of Ronaldo, a reference to the Brazilian star.
"From the looks of it, he's a bit better than me, and he has a lot more money," Burton said, jokingly.
Paired at forward with Burton, Hall has scored six goals in eight games (including friendlies) since joining the Jamaican national team. Simpson has helped build cohesion in the midfield. The fourth Beatle, Robbie Earle, has come out of the bullpen to relieve Burton. The English presence has allowed Simoes to dismiss another dissident, striker Walter Boyd, who criticized the coach for "wanting to be God" with his disciplinarian style.
"Hall and Burton are very comfortable with their backs to the goal, receiving the ball at their feet, and they are quick on the turn," Sampson said. "They have a great combination of speed and technical ability. With Simpson in the midfield, they have the English mentality, a high work rate. In the past, Jamaica was criticized for a lack of organization and work rate."
While Deon, Paul, Robbie and Fitzroy may not have the same resonance as John, Paul, George and Ringo, Jamaica has grown giddy over this incarnation of the Fab Four. Some 15,000 fans of the Reggae Boyz are expected at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium for Friday's game. A berth in the World Cup would have implications far beyond soccer.
"It would be a welcome push to the Jamaican psyche," said Reid, general secretary of the soccer federation. "Each day in Jamaica and the Caribbean we wake up to face the difficulties of the economy and employment. This would give us added incentive to go out and put in hard work. It would push our spirit and our motivation high. It would be the greatest achievement in the last couple of decades for this country and the Caribbean."

GRAPHIC: Photo: With Deon Burton, center, the Jamaican national team has a fighting chance to become a World Cup qualifier. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: The Tide Is Not Lifting Everyone

 BODY:
The Census Bureau set the White House aglow this week when it reported that in 1996 median income rose for the second consecutive year while black and Hispanic poverty rates fell. President Clinton said the report proved that his economic policies were working and that the middle class was finally on the rise. But a deeper look at the census report finds a gloomier perspective -- the middle class is not doing very well and the poor are falling further behind.
The backdrop for the report is an economy that has steadily recovered since 1991 and is growing at a healthy 3 percent a year. Unemployment has dropped below 5 percent to its lowest level in a quarter-century. Inflation is low and falling. Welfare rolls fell almost 10 percent last year. The minimum wage is rising. The economic landscape could not be better for middle-class families in general, and low-wage workers in particular. 
 Median income -- the income of households halfway up the income ladder -- rose about 1 percent last year, to almost $35,500 a year. Even so, that leaves the living standard of a typical family below its level in 1989, before the last recession took hold. Indeed, when adjusted for inflation, incomes fell on average for the bottom 60 percent of households over the past seven years, in sharp contrast to what happened after recessions in the 1970's and 80's. Worse, the median earnings of full-time male workers fell last year, despite plummeting unemployment rates. Family income went up because women earned more.
The poverty rate last year, 13.7 percent, was higher than in 1989, despite seven years of uninterrupted growth and a higher minimum wage. Black and Hispanic poverty rates were down last year, but not significantly; the drops might reflect sampling error. Growth used to be the salvation of low-paid workers. But over the past three years, the gap between rich and poor has not budged.
The weakness of the current recovery can be seen by comparing the 1990's with the 1950's, when median income rose by about 30 percent despite the economy's suffering two major recessions. The difference is explained by the fact that productivity in the 1950's rose at a rapid clip, whereas today it rises by barely 1 percent a year. Sluggish productivity gains produce sluggish income gains.
Those at the bottom are not faring well. Median income, adjusted for inflation, for the poorest 20 percent of families fell last year, even though the economy was zipping along. Mr. Clinton is right that recovery is beginning to pay off, though modestly, for the middle class. But the chilling lesson from the census data is that even a healthy economy leaves the poor firmly in a depressing place.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A record year for underwriting seems to be a certainty.

BYLINE: By David Barboza 

 BODY:
WITH the stock market continuing its phenomenal ascent and interest rates holding steady, stock and bond underwriting reached record levels last quarter, putting the new issues market on course to have its best year.
In the three months ended Tuesday, stock and bond underwriting rose 59 percent from the comparable period a year ago, totaling $343.2 billion, up from $216 billion, according to the Securities Data Company, which tracks underwriting. That puts Wall Street investment banks on pace to reach the $1 trillion mark for only the second time. 
 The gains have come in a market awash in mergers and acquisitions and flush with new corporate debt offerings. All call upon the tools of the investment banker, who helps supply corporate chiefs and others with the capital they seek.
"It's been a busy summer," said Jeffrey Weiss, head of the global debt syndicate at Lehman Brothers. "There's been a lot of corporate activity because interest rates have trended lower, and there are lots of acquisitions that have to be financed."
Indeed, about $201.7 billion worth of American mergers and acquisitions were announced in the quarter just ended, the second-best period ever, after the $213 billion in the third quarter of 1995, said Richard Peterson, a spokesman at Securities Data. Already this year, there have been $577.2 billion worth of deals, he said, a pace that could easily eclipse last year's record $649 billion.
Such activity has fueled a buoyant underwriting business, dominated by debt offerings. For instance, of the $343.2 billion underwritten last quarter, about 90 percent was in debt offerings, while the rest came from equity offerings. In the third quarter, the sale of bonds and other debt totaled $310 billion, up 65 percent from $188 billion a year ago.
The sale of new equities also gained, with common stock bringing in $30.2 billion, up from $21.1 billion a year ago. Of that total, initial public offerings raised $9.3 billion in the third quarter, up 18 percent from $7.8 billion a year ago.
Brian Hehir, co-chief of global capital equity markets at Merrill Lynch, said a large part of the surge in new offerings reflected the large cash inflows into mutual funds and broad stock market gains that saw smaller company and technology stocks soar in the third quarter.
"The overall performance of the stock market has been strong," he said, "and small and midcap strength helps drive up the level of new issuance; it certainly helps drive the I.P.O. market."
For the year, though, initial public offerings are trailing last year's record-breaking pace by about 29 percent. But several analysts said they expected the fourth quarter to be the best of the year particularly because of a surge in new international issues. "We have as big a backlog as we've ever had," Mr. Hehir said. "I.P.O.'s are poised to have a very big fourth quarter."
In the third quarter, Merrill Lynch, the mammoth retail and investment house, was once again the leading underwriter in debt and equity offerings, raising about $52.6 billion, followed by Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover; Salomon Brothers, J. P. Morgan and Goldman, Sachs. The 10 most-active securities firms accounted for 82 percent of all the underwriting business.
The merger of Morgan Stanley and Dean Witter helped catapult that firm into second place for the quarter, from seventh place a year ago, after underwriting 389 issues to raise about $49.2 billion, up from $15.8 billion a year ago. Morgan Stanley was the leading stock underwriter in the quarter.
Salomon was third in the quarter. Yet, had its recently announced merger with the Smith Barney unit of Travelers Group been completed, the new company would have tied for second. Salomon made big gains in underwriting mortgage- and asset-backed debt, leading all other Wall Street firms with $14.3 billion raised, up from $4.9 billion a year ago.
One reason why merger activity accelerated was low interest rates, which enabled corporations to sell debt to pay for a range of large acquisitions or planned takeovers.
"We've seen a lot of jumbo offerings this year, and at their root has been a steady merger market," said Randy Snook, a syndicate manager in the fixed-income division at Goldman, Sachs.
In all, Wall Street firms have raised $943.9 billion this year in just three quarters. For all of 1996, they raised about $967.7 billion, and in 1993 they raised a record $1.05 trillion. The number of issues is also climbing, gaining 28 percent, to 2,721 this year from 2,123 at this time last year.
But disclosed fees, or what is left over for Wall Street firms, were up just slightly in the third quarter, to $1.9 billion, from $1.7 billion a year ago. For the year, however, fees were down to $5.6 billion, from $6.7 billion a year ago.
Part of the reason is that equity underwriting declined as a percentage of overall underwriting; equity fees generally are higher.
There was also greater competition for business and an increase in one- and two-year financing deals, which bring lower fees.
Mr. Snook at Goldman, Sachs, however, said that the lower fees were not a sign of sluggishness. "Even though we're seeing lower stated fees, the business is very healthy," he said. "And the outlook for the rest of the year is very good."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Wanted: a global warming policy that stands a chance.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
IT'S crunch time at the White House on climate change policy. With the meeting on global warming set for Kyoto, Japan, in December, the Clinton Administration has less than three weeks to come up with its own proposal before the agenda is locked in place by meeting planners and America is reduced to the role of commentator.
Cynics have assumed that President Clinton would stake out the easy high ground, demanding more from developing countries (or the United States Congress) than they are prepared to give, thereby obviating the need for action. But the Administration is reportedly trying to piece together a plan that rapidly growing economies like China could live with, yet still buy some insurance against climate change. That is why White House policy wonks are now focusing on hybrid plans that limit greenhouse gas emissions, yet provide an escape hatch. 
 "The idea is to get started, but without fear of economic surprises," said Richard Morgenstern, a former Environmental Protection Agency official who is a researcher at Resources for the Future, a nonpartisan group in Washington.
The European Community is officially gung-ho to set ambitious emissions goals for the developed world and to meet them with the help of carbon emission taxes. The Clinton Administration, by contrast, is reluctant to agree to any policy with teeth unless developing countries -- notably China, India and Russia -- join in. Administration economists are especially taken with emissions trading plans that would allow private businesses in developed countries to pay their counterparts in developing economies to do the heavy lifting.
This opens two avenues for rationalizing doing nothing at all.
The Administration could earn brownie points with hard-line environmentalists by going along with the Europeans, effectively inviting the Republican Congressional majority to shoot down any agreement. House Speaker Newt Gingrich has already warned against an accord in which "the U.S. would likely bear too much burden." And Republicans would no doubt go to the barricades before approving a new tax on carbon emissions.
Or President Clinton could insist that developing countries fully commit to both targets and means for limiting emissions before he presents the deal to Congress. This would seem statesmanlike while indefinitely delaying the need to ask sacrifice from Americans.
The ease of procrastination explains the new interest in hybrid proposals from serious policy types in the Administration who want the President to take the lead in Kyoto.
The idea is simple, says Mr. Morgenstern, who, in collaboration with Raymond Kopp and William Pizer at Resources for the Future, has outlined its virtues on the group's Web site (www.rff.org). The researchers would set limits on total carbon emissions and parcel out rights to emit that can be traded between businesses and perhaps countries. But they would also guarantee that no one would ever have to pay more than a ceiling price for permits in the private market -- say $10 a ton -- by having governments sell any number of additional permits at the ceiling.
If the ceiling price were low enough, business might be willing to go along. Indeed, a few companies -- most notably British Petroleum, which announced a voluntary emissions monitoring program earlier this week in conjunction with the Environmental Defense Fund -- seem eager for modest actions that reduce business uncertainty. And since proposed charges for added permits aren't necessarily "taxes" in the Republican lexicon, they, too, might go with the flow.
The concept is unappealing to environmental lobbies that want strict targets and timetables. But Mr. Morgenstern suggests that the hybrid approach would call the bluff of perennially optimistic enviros, who argue that there is a cheap fix for every problem. And it would please many economists, who want to set up a framework for efficient containment of greenhouse gases before the risks of climate change are fully understood. "This would be a way to initiate a broad but realistic commitment," argued Robert Stavins of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard.
Warwick J. McKibbin and Peter J. Wilcoxen, authors of a climate change "policy brief" at the Brookings Institution (www.brook.edu), see other benefits. The price ceiling on permits could be set low enough, they suggest, to make it palatable for rich countries to begin containment without the cooperation of developing countries. Moreover, the chance to collect a fee on excess emissions would give revenue-hungry governments an incentive to enforce the standards.
The hybrid approach is too new to allow for a realistic assessment of its chances at Kyoto. But it is appealing on its face. More important, its prominence in current Administration thinking suggests that the White House is treating sacrifices in containing climate change as a problem in political coalition-building rather than a potential obstacle to Al Gore's election in 2000. "The real choice is not between a sharp reduction in emissions and a more modest policy," Mr. Wilcoxen said, "but between a modest policy and no policy at all."

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
In New York, All Sides Give Albright Advice

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
The problem with reaching out to the American people -- if you're Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright -- is that the American people feel free to reach out right back.
And since she is in New York, a city where foreign affairs are as much a part of the daily discourse as the weather, that means she gets plenty of advice. 
 "As I'm going to the ladies' room," Ms. Albright said, describing a visit to a Greek diner on the East Side of Manhattan on Saturday morning, "this guy gets me in the corner and says, 'You got to do something about Cyprus.'
"So then I'm walking along further and this woman yells out, 'Do something about our Prime Minister. You've got to push Bibi,' " less familiarly known as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.
"Coming back again, this guy yells out, 'When are we going to make sure we get those guys in Bosnia?' " she went on. "And then finally I go into this restaurant, which I thought was Italian but ended up being Albanian, and the daughter and father start explaining to me what has to be done in Albania."
And that was her day off.
No matter. Ms. Albright, to hear her tell it, has been relishing every minute of her return to New York City, now as Secretary of State after four busy, sometimes contentious years as the United States' representative to the United Nations.
Ms. Albright, here for the opening of the General Assembly, has held forth at the United Nations and the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for the better part of two weeks, conducting a flurry of diplomatic meetings and nearly as many social ones. (She has dined with everyone from Foreign Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov of Russia to the actress Glenn Close, whom she declared the only woman in Government to outrank her, since Ms. Close played a Vice President in "Air Force One.")
 
Diplomatic Pace Stepped Up
The opening of the General Assembly in September -- luring as it does foreign ministers, presidents and other dignitaries from around the world -- has traditionally been an opportunity for Secretaries of State to carry on the business of American foreign policy in a fairly concentrated way.
But even by her own frenetic standards, notorious for exhausting her staff, Ms. Albright has stretched the opportunity to new limits.
Since arriving with President Clinton last Monday, she has held "bilaterals" -- the one-on-one meetings that are the bread and butter of diplomacy -- with three dozen foreign ministers. She has presided over a meeting of the Security Council's 15 members, signed arms control agreements with Russia, Belarus, Kazakhstan and Ukraine and brokered modest progress in talks between Israel and the Palestinians.
All told, she has met more than 100 ministers or heads of state in some capacity or another -- from gatherings of the Southeast Europe Cooperation Initiative to the Organization of African Unity to the Persian Gulf Cooperative Commission.
The prodigious pace has produced some grumbling that her extended stay seemed a waste of time and money. (Last year, her predecessor, Warren Christopher, stayed barely a week.) But she brushed aside a question of whether a schedule of endless meetings -- usually starting over breakfast and continuing through dinner -- amounted to little more than "assembly-line" diplomacy.
"If you concentrate," she explained, "you can get an awful lot done."
 
Sharp Questions at School
Yesterday Ms. Albright carried on with her reaching out -- or "public diplomacy," as she likes to call it -- by attending a breakfast of corporate leaders and visiting two of the city's public schools.
At the Bronx High School of Science, one of the nation's elite public schools, she delivered a commencement-like speech encouraging students to embrace the globalization of the world's economy and culture. She then found herself facing some fairly sharp questions. One student even raised the thorny subject of the United States' failure to pay back dues to the United Nations, an issue that has bedeviled her throughout her meetings.
Ms. Albright also visited Theodore Roosevelt High School in the Bronx. Her aides said she had deliberately sought out a school where the students were less privileged than those at Bronx Science.
In the school's library, where Ms. Albright spoke, one student, Ada Valencia, a junior, stepped forward to say she did not have a question as much as a request: Could she shake her hand? She got a hug instead.
"I really admire her," she said afterward, in tears. "She's the highest paid woman in the country, and she came to my school."
While Ms. Albright, who makes $148,400 a year, might quibble with the description of her earnings, she often calls attention to the fact that she happens to be a woman, as she puts it. And it seemed to have its effect on the boys, too. Juan Lopez, a senior, said he was very much impressed, though a little confused, adding, "I thought it was Janet Reno who was coming."
 
Changing of Guard Stressed
It was hardly a showdown, but the Council on Foreign Relations celebration on Tuesday night of the 75th anniversary of its magazine, Foreign Affairs, offered the tantalizing prospect of sparks between the old, Henry A. Kissinger, and the new, Ms. Albright.
The former Secretary of State, called upon to introduce her, has sharply criticized the Clinton Administration's foreign policy, most recently its efforts in Bosnia, which Ms. Albright was intimately involved in shaping even before becoming Secretary in January.
In the end, however, there were nothing but niceties, though Ms. Albright seized on the chance to declare a changing of the guard when Mr. Kissinger spoke of the ties that bind those who have held the job as top diplomat.
"We are a fraternity of Secretaries of State," he said at the Council's stately building on East 68th Street. "We have shared unique experiences."
To which she replied, "Henry, I hate to tell you, it's not a fraternity anymore."

HEADLINE: Dow Again Passes 8,000, Rising 70.24

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The stock market rose yesterday after the Government reported that manufacturing activity cooled in September. The report, which traders took as an indication that the economy is not about to overheat, helped lift prices in the bond market, and the rally spread to the stock market, sending the Dow Jones industrial average above 8,000 for the first time since Aug. 20.
Yesterday, the Dow gained 70.24 points, to close at 8,015.50, just 243 points, or 3 percent, below its all-time high, set on Aug. 6. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also gained, climbing 8.13 points, to 955.41.
For the day, blue-chips outpaced smaller issues, but yesterday's Dow showing understated the strength of the broader market, where more than two issues gained for every issue that lost ground on the New York Stock Exchange.
Analysts said they were surprised at how tame the Dow was through much of the session, despite a powerful rally in the bond market and the optimism unleashed after Worldcom Inc. announced a $30 billion stock bid for the MCI Communications Corporation.
Since early August, the Dow has bounced around in a trading range, unable to mount the kind of 100-point rallies that came so easily earlier in the year. In fact, going into the last hour of trading, the Dow was up only 21 points, as investors bypassed the blue chips in favor of a wide array of smaller issues.
Although many analysts view the recent shift toward buying shares of smaller companies as healthy, some worry that a slowdown in the perennial market favorites could precipitate a decline in the larger market.
"The market's stuck between a rock and a hard place," said Robert F. Dickey, a technical analyst at Dain Bosworth. "It's a little unsettling that the broad market is so strong, and the big caps are just not cutting it."
Other analysts, however, like H. Vernon Winters, the chief investment officer at Mellon Private Asset Management, say the market is simply readjusting after a period of incredible gains.
"We had this substantial run in the market since the spring," he said. "We ran so hard, and so we needed a pause; the buying power was exhausted. Besides, we had this struggle going on between those who were accumulating stocks and those who were lightening up. There was a lot of rebalancing of portfolios."
In recent weeks, during the rebalancing, the market has steered a much steadier course, gently tip-toeing its way higher with a lot less volatility than previously.
And while blue-chip stocks have been under pressure in response to earnings warnings from some leading companies, a wide range of stocks have shown surprising strength, partly because many of those smaller companies posted strong second-quarter earnings and relatively low price-to-earnings ratios.
"For a while, small-cap companies were just hated," Mr. Winters said. "And now, everyone wants you to put your money into them. This large cap-small cap transition has been a major event."
Indeed, small-cap stocks have caught up to the large caps, and in many cases surpassed them. Yesterday, for instance, the Russell 2000 index of smaller-company stocks rose 84-hundredths of a point, to 454.69, notching its third consecutive record. And in the last six months, the Russell has risen about 33 percent, while the Dow has gained 21 percent.
Still, at the close of trading on Tuesday, the Dow ended the third quarter rising 3.55 percent -- its 11th consecutive quarterly gain, the longest such stretch in the postwar era. In the 1950's, there was a string of 10 consecutive quarterly gains.
The Nasdaq composite index also gained yesterday, adding 4.61 points, to close at 1,690.30. An earnings warning from Advanced Micro Devices hurt the index, with A.M.D. falling 5 9/16, to 27. Heavy trading surrounding the Worldcom-MCI deal, however, helped push volume on the index up to a record 970.6 million shares. Shares of Worldcom fell 1 3/64, to 34 21/64, while MCI rose 5 7/8, to 35 1/4.
Of the Dow's 30 component stocks, 25 gained yesterday, led by Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, up 1 15/16, to 94 3/8. The company had a breast implant case dismissed on Monday. I.B.M., which like much of the tech sector was buffeted by the A.M.D. warning, was the worst performer, down 2 1/2, to 103 1/2.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Rise on Weak Report From Purchasing Managers

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities rallied yesterday on an unexpectedly weak manufacturing report that suggested the economy is slowing enough to suppress inflation, substantiating the Federal Reserve's decision the day before to leave interest rates unchanged.
However, the market still must contend with tomorrow's monthly employment report, which by itself is capable of unnerving bond investors by stoking their concern about inflation. 
 Yesterday, the 30-year bond surged a full point, to a price of 100 24/32; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.32 percent, from 6.40 percent Tuesday. The primary influence on the bond market yesterday was the monthly report by the National Association of Purchasing Management, which showed manufacturing growth declined in September. Traders interpreted the report as a signal the economy might be slowing.
The purchasing managers' manufacturing index, a widely watched component of the N.A.P.M. report, fell to 54.2, from 56.8 in August. Although that still suggests further manufacturing momentum, it was below the market forecast of 56.5.
The N.A.P.M. prices-paid index -- viewed as a gauge of inflation -- rose to 54.7 from 53.8. But Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said, "The market paid less attention to this than usual in its bull run."
Mr. Fine noted that the release yesterday of both leading indicators and construction spending data for August were also market friendly. Construction spending declined three-tenths of 1 percent, following a 1.6 percent gain in July, while leading indicators rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent.
The market's advance also reflected purchases by traders who had bet on stronger economic data and sold bonds on a bet that prices would decline on inflation anxiety. As prices rose instead, these traders were forced to buy bonds to limit their losses, known as a short-covering rally.
In the municipal market, New York City's Transitional Finance Authority, which will pay for capital improvement projects over the next four years, sold its first bond issue.
The $650 million offering through underwriters, led by Lehman Brothers, was priced to yield a maximum 5.38 percent for bonds due in 2027, with another long maturity due in 2021 yielding 5.36 percent. Serial bonds with shorter maturities ranged from 3.90 percent in 1999 to 5.30 percent in 2017.
Alan L. Anders, treasurer of the Transitional Finance Authority, said he was pleased with the results, noting the issue sold less in yield than triple-A rated insured New York State paper. "In fact, it would have been 30 basis points less than New York City general obligation bonds had they been sold today," he said. "It represents a savings of $40 million over the life of the issue." Mr. Anders said the next sale would be at the end of this month, when the authority has an $840 million refunding of general obligation bonds.
According to Bloomberg Fair Value, the 10-year maturity had a yield that was about 41 basis points less than the city's general obligation bonds. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Sylvan G. Feldstein, municipal bond analyst for the Guardian Life Insurance Company, said that even though economic numbers abound this week there was good investor demand. Investors are generally drawn to a new name, particularly one with a strong investment grade rating.

HEADLINE: Latest Reports Give Economy A Little Chill

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
Manufacturing growth slowed for the second consecutive month in September, a group of manufacturing executives said today in a sign that the overall economy may be cooling.
The National Association of Purchasing Management's monthly report provided the first substantive reading of the economy's condition last month. An index derived from the report fell to 54.2, from 56.8 in August, as orders, production and backlogs all declined. 
 The result surprised economists, most of whom expected only a small change in either direction. The unexpected slowdown also buoyed the securities markets, which viewed it as a signal that inflation remained benign. Interest rates for the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell sharply, and the Dow Jones industrial average surged to close above the 8,000-point level for the first time since Aug. 20.
In what appeared to be another sign of slowing growth, both the Chrysler Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation said sales of cars and light trucks fell 14 percent last month, partly because of diminished demand. Other big auto makers report September sales later this week.
Other economic reports today also suggested sluggishness, though they were based on older data. The index designed to predict the economy's course advanced two-tenths of 1 percent in August, while spending on construction projects in August eased.
"All these indicate that the economy continues to move ahead but with some signs that perhaps the pace is slowing somewhat," said David W. Berson, chief economist at the Federal National Mortgage Association. But he added that whether this turns out to be the harbinger of a respite long sought by policy makers, it is clear that "we're not there yet."
On Tuesday, the Federal Reserve decided against raising short-term interest rates despite low unemployment and an economy that has not paused as anticipated this year. It is thought that the Fed is likely to raise rates at its meeting on Nov. 12 unless clear evidence of a slowdown exists.
Indeed, today's report by corporate purchasing managers offered the Fed little comfort on inflation.
The survey's price index climbed to 54.7 from 53.8, the highest reading since February, just before the Fed's March rate increase. The index of supplier deliveries, which is widely watched as an indicator of potential bottlenecks, eased only modestly, to 55.2 from 55.8, despite what analysts thought should have been a substantial impact from the end of the strike against United Parcel Service.
David Orr, an economist for First Union Bank, said that while manufacturing slowed the last two months, probably reflecting the huge buildup of inventories this year, "the level of activity is gradually moving up the inflation pressure gauges" that Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, is using as a focal point.
But while the group's price index posted its third consecutive increase last month, the September change was small: 19 percent of managers paid higher prices, compared with 20 percent in August, while 9 percent paid lower prices, compared with 10 percent. The rest reported no change.
"There appears little reason for concern" about inflation, said Norbert J. Ore, purchasing director for the Sonoco Products Company and head of the trade group's survey. He cited the "remarkably short list" of commodities that rose in price in September: aluminum, caustic soda, corrugated containers, linerboard, natural gas, soybean oil and zinc.
The two-tenths of 1 percent advance in the Conference Board's index of leading indicators, covering August, reflected increases in seven of the 10 components, with the main impact from an expansion of the money supply and a jump in orders at factories making consumer goods. The main drag on the index came from an increase in the number of people filing first-time claims for unemployment benefits.
As for the spending on construction, compiled by the Commerce Department, the three-tenths of 1 percent decline was the third lower reading in four months, but all were so modest that July's 1.6 percent gain -- revised up from five-tenths of 1 percent -- more than offset them.
The next significant look at the domestic economy comes on Friday with the release of the Labor Department's job-creation and unemployment data. The August rate was 4.9 percent, and many forecasters are expecting a 4.8 percent reading.

HEADLINE: U.S. Starts Trade Sanction Process Against Koreans and 4 Others

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
Seeking to show its toughness on trade both to other nations and to Congress, the Clinton Administration listed the countries today that it said were failing to live up to their free trade obligations, citing South Korea, in particular, for obstructing access to American automobile exports.
The report set in motion a process that could in time lead to sanctions against Seoul and four other trading partners -- Japan, Canada, Australia and the European Union -- as a result of disputes over particular industries or products. 
 It also raised the Administration's more general concerns over longstanding trade problems with nations including Japan and China. The United States was "increasingly concerned that Japan's progress in opening its market has slowed," it said.
The report cited China for "multiple and overlapping barriers to U.S. exports" of many types of goods and services. The trade deficit with the Chinese has grown rapidly in the last few years and now rivals the deficit with Japan, both in size and in political sensitivity here.
"While our large and growing trade deficit with China is the result of many factors, China's trade and economic policies are a significant contributor to that deficit," it said. "Opening China's market and bringing China's policies into conformity with international norms are the Administration's key objectives in the trade area and the best means" to address the deficit.
The report came as the Administration made some headway in its effort to win permission from Congress to negotiate new trade agreements on an expedited basis -- the so-called fast track authority. The Senate Finance Committee approved legislation that would grant the authority, although the prospects remained uncertain in the House. Page A16.
The Administration has tried to counter critics of free trade, many of them Democrats, by mounting aggressive efforts to insure that American companies get as much access as possible to foreign markets.
With the contentious debate over trade-negotiating authority as a backdrop, the writers of today's report were at pains to lay out in detail the steps the Government had taken in the last year, including winning the first five cases it had brought to the new international arbiter, the World Trade Organization.
"Enforcement of international trade agreements and U.S. trade laws underpins our entire approach to trade," said Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, whose office prepared the report.
In accusing South Korea of impeding American auto makers from entering that market, the Administration invoked provisions of United States trade law known as Super 301, which require the Administration each year to identify those countries whose policies are most hurting American exports.
The Administration has been under pressure from the auto industry to threaten the Seoul authorities with sanctions. The chief executives of General Motors, Ford and Chrysler are scheduled to meet on Thursday with President Clinton at the White House, where they are expected to discuss trade as well as other issues.
Invoking the law requires the Administration to open an investigation that can last as long as a year. If the dispute is not settled in the interim -- and if the investigation concludes that South Korea is violating a 1995 agreement with the United States to open its car market to American companies -- Mr. Clinton would be able to impose sanctions on South Korea.
Despite the 1995 accord, the Big Three auto makers have less than a 1 percent share of the Korean market, Ms. Barshefsky said.
Compliance with the agreement has been disappointing, the report said, noting that South Korea continued to put in place new barriers to American entry into the market. "Although some progress was made during recent bilateral negotiations to improve market access in Korea for foreign automobiles, Korea was not prepared to undertake the reforms which are necessary for real opening of its autos market," it said.
 Korean officials and industry executives said in Seoul early Thursday that the main reason for the difficulty the American car companies had experienced was the weak economy and lackluster auto sales there. They said the American accusations of unfair trade practices were unjustified.
In the other specific cases cited in the report, the Administration said it intended to bring action at the World Trade Organization. In the case of Japan, the Administration said American apples, nectarines, cherries and other fruit were being kept out of the market by Japanese rules requiring repeated testing for safety of pesticide treatments.
The Administration said Canada was unfairly subsidizing exports of its dairy products to the United States and violating the rules in enforcing import quotas on milk.
Australia, it asserted, is violating a prohibition on export subsidies for leather used in automobiles by providing loans and grants to the industry. And the European Union was said to be circumventing an agreement to limit subsidized exports of processed cheese.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Announces a Program to Reduce Illegal Drug Use

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Announcing a series of antidrug measures that he hopes to make the hallmark of a second term, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he would expand special police drug-fighting efforts into Queens and the Bronx, offer more treatment for addicts and make Washington Square Park a drug-free zone by placing it off limits to those convicted of selling drugs there.
In a speech billed as a major policy announcement, Mayor Giuliani told a roomful of administration officials and police commanders that he thought drug use could be reduced in the city, much as crime has been reduced in the last four years. "I want to be able to hold up a national magazine two or three years from now and have New York City lead America in massive reductions in drug abuse," Mayor Giuliani said. 
 The Mayor outlined a wide-ranging proposal, calling for tougher law enforcement, more treatment opportunities for addicts in prison, curfews for juveniles on probation for drug offenses, expanded drug education programs in schools and a new advertising campaign on the dangers of drugs.
The first phase of the antidrug strategy will begin in November, when the Police Department is scheduled to begin deploying 1,000 officers against drug traffickers in the South Bronx and the southern Queens neighborhoods of Jamaica and St. Albans.
The department, which now has 850 officers assigned to similar antidrug efforts in northern Manhattan and northern Brooklyn, has long credited the city's declining crime rate to its success in dismantling violent drug gangs. "These areas export crime to other areas of the city," said Tony Coles, a senior mayoral adviser.
Police officials did not explain in detail where the 1,000 officers would come from. But they noted that 1,300 new officers would graduate from the Police Academy this fall and said that the next class of 1,000 recruits would begin training in December instead of July 1998.
The various parts of the Mayor's drug strategy are expected to cost the city $80 million a year, said administration officials, who added that they expected a large part of the cost to be covered by state and Federal funds. Commissioner Howard Safir said that the Police Department's extended antidrug initiatives would cost $14 million to $17 million.
The antidrug strategy also focuses on the symbolic, like the effort to make Washington Square Park a drug-free zone. For decades the park has been not only the heart of Greenwich Village and the site of New York University graduations, but also one of the city's most notorious drug spots.
Hawkers there offer drugs to young and old alike, and it is the scene of annual smoke-ins and rallies by advocates of legalizing marijuana. Residents have long complained that despite repeated crackdowns by the police, the park persists as a drug spot, because drug dealers receive short sentences or probation and return to the park as soon as they are released. One drug dealer arrested last summer had been caught there 75 times before, the police said.
Mayor Giuliani said his administration was working with the court system and the Department of Probation so that people convicted of selling drugs in Washington Square Park would be barred from returning there as a condition of their probation. "Washington Square Park can be used for playing chess, not for shooting heroin," Mr. Giuliani said.
In staking out the war on drugs as a main priority of a second term, the Mayor's speech marked something of a departure in his campaign for re-election, which until now had largely focused on the achievements of his first term.
A spokesman for Ruth W. Messinger, the Mayor's Democratic rival, said Ms. Messinger was "very pleased that the Mayor has finally come forward to address the problem of drugs in New York City."
"We only wish he had demonstrated the same enthusiasm for dealing with the crisis in our schools and among our unemployed," added the spokesman, Leland T. Jones.
Dr. Mitchell Rosenthal, the president of the Phoenix House Foundation, a drug-treatment organization, said that it was the most sweeping antidrug proposal by any mayor since John V. Lindsay.
"The fact is that treatment works and addiction is curable," Dr. Rosenthal said. "What we have had are insufficient resources."
Pressing his case that drug abuse is one of the greatest problems facing the city, Mayor Giuliani said that more than 70 percent of the people arrested each year test positive for drugs and that 71 percent of the children in foster care in New York City have a parent with a substance abuse problem.
Mr. Giuliani, who has been trying to raise his national profile lately and gave a speech earlier in the week on the urban agenda at Harvard University, also made a series of recommendations for fighting drugs on the national level. He said drug policy should be made a priority of foreign policy, and called for tighter border controls and interdiction efforts, longer prison terms, and better drug treatment and education programs.
He said he would lobby for several changes in New York State law, including allowing felony charges against people who are convicted repeatedly on misdemeanors for selling drugs; revoking driving privileges for youths who use drugs, and creating the presumption of parental neglect for newborn babies who test positive for drugs.
Donna Lieberman, director of the Reproductive Rights Project of the New York Civil Liberties Union, said there was no compelling evidence that women who fail one drug test necessarily make poor parents. She stressed the dangers that could arise from separating families based on faulty test results. "You're putting their families into turmoil, you are splitting up families and depriving children of their parents without an adequate basis," she said.
Mayor Giuliani said he hoped to surprise critics and nay-sayers again by making his antidrug strategies a success, and pledged to come up with ways to measure the amount of drug abuse in the city.
"I have a feeling now that in this city there's a sense that you can do things that used to be considered impossible," he said. "Because we have been doing things that were considered impossible and made them possible."

HEADLINE: ON COLLEGE FOOTBALL;
Economics 101: Slaughter Makes Sense

BYLINE: By William C. Rhoden 

 BODY:
Early last month, a couple, perhaps in their mid-60's, took in the sights of Jacksonville, Fla. Their matching jackets and caps identified them as proud Central Michigan University supporters.
In fact, they were alumni, come south for what they jokingly referred to as "The Game." 
 A day earlier, the Central Michigan Chippewas had played the high-powered, top-ranked Florida Gators. The game was a Chippewa disaster. Florida won, 82-6, the worst loss in Central Michigan history.
But the couple were not angry. "Hey, we never thought we'd get to play a program like Florida," the man said. "We got $300,000 for the game, so it wasn't all bad."
In fact, Central Michigan received a $350,000 guarantee, but not everyone was thrilled. "We received some flak," said Herb Deromedi, the Central Michigan athletic director and former head football coach. "When I say flak, some people responded, and I responded back.
"No one complained when we beat Michigan State two out of three times." He was referring to victories in the 1991 and 1992 seasons. The game with Florida was actually scheduled in 1991, when Deromedi was the head coach. He became the athletic director in 1994.
In the fragile ecosystem of college football, administrators feed their football programs to predators as a way of keeping healthy. Athletes march bravely into combat, convinced that the sky is blue when it in fact is green.
"When you're in schools like ours, you have to look at your finances," Deromedi said. "It would be great if the money came from other sources. If John Smith came in and said, 'Here's $300,000 so you don't have to go to Florida,' that's fine. Then maybe you might want to rethink it."
Central Michigan is a member of the Mid-American Conference, an 11-team league that is trying to increase its profile by playing schools like Florida and Nebraska. Its other members are Akron, Ball State, Bowling Green, Eastern Michigan, Kent, Marshall, Miami of Ohio, Ohio University, Toledo and Western Michigan.
Bill Lynch, the head coach at Ball State, said that from the players' standpoint, there should be no shame. "It's a great challenge for them," Lynch said. "It's an opportunity for our guys to go play against teams many of them grew up watching. Every now and then, we knock one of them off."
Already this season, Marshall and Miami defeated Army, Ohio University defeated Maryland and Toledo defeated Purdue. Ball State lost to Indiana, 33-6, and lost to Purdue, 28-14. At the same time, Akron lost to Nebraska, 59-14, and lost to Louisiana State, 56-0. Last weekend, Bowling Green lost to Kansas State, 58-0, and on Saturday will play Nebraska.
Jerry Ippoliti, the Mid-American commissioner, looked at the routs and saw the glass as half full. "If I was a school like Kentucky and got beat, 55-28, by Florida, I'd be concerned about it," he said, "because we're talking about budgets that are about $24 million in their athletic program to maybe the highest we might have is $9 million. Look at Iowa-Iowa State" -- Iowa won, 63-20 -- "look at that rout. Iowa State has four times the budget any one of our schools has. They are in the Big 12. How do you justify that?"
It is one thing to compete as a Big 12 member and lose, quite another to accept an invitation to certain slaughter for a guaranteed profit. Ippoliti said the aim of the conference is to increase its visibility. "We've really focused on football the last four or five years because of having to maintain our Division I attendance requirements. Every one of our institutions, facility-wise, has improved their football stadium."
The bottom line of the Mid-American's search for higher visibility, its forays into elite competition, is to make ends meet and to do so as gracefully as possible.
"There are Title IX issues that now affect supporting men's and women's programs," Ippoliti said. "Therefore, $350,000 or $400,000 certainly is an enhancement to anyone's budget."
What about the student athlete, thrown into a situation that is often hopeless -- and humiliating? Ippoliti sees it as opportunity, not exploitation. "I think we have to look at our country," he said. "When you're looking at the philosophical approach to intercollegiate athletics, as in the business world, you're trying to do the best you can against the best. You never know until you try."
The Mid-American Conference will continue to take on the fat cats. Some members will take lumps, Ippoliti said, but the ebb and flow of college football virtually insures that, now and then, there will be a breakthrough.
"You never know when you'll hit the cycle," he said. "You hit the cycle when one of the elite teams are down, then you've got a chance to win." And if you hit the cycle when they're up?
"That's a risk," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 3, 1997, Friday

 CORRECTION:
The On College Football column yesterday, about the Mid-American Conference's rigorous schedule, omitted one school from the number in the conference. There are 12, including Northern Illinois. The column also misidentified Bowling Green's opponent for tomorrow; it is Northern Illinois.
