HEADLINE: MY NEW YORK;
On a Soaring Ride Of Reminiscence, Speed and Wonder

BYLINE: BY KATIE ROIPHE; Katie Roiphe is a New York author whose most recent book is "Last Night in Paradise."

 BODY:
My father left Flatbush 55 years ago, and now, on a bright fall day, I find myself going back to deepest Brooklyn, to Coney Island, to the last stop on the F train.
My date stops in front of the Cyclone that curls ominously above us. I am astonished that he wants to ride it. I feel twinges of panic on elevators and airplanes. But it seems too early in our acquaintance for him to know that I am too neurotic for roller coasters. My date does not give the impression of being afraid of anything. So we end up at the ticket counter. The ticket seller catches a crazy glint of fear in my eyes and says, "Nothing's happened to anyone in the seven years that I've worked here," and we hear the whoops and shouts and rattle of the cars above us and I look up at my date and wonder how well I really know him. 
 As we climb into the car it feels rickety and fragile. The wooden track rising against the sky reminds me of the dinosaur bones in the American Museum of Natural History, which is not a reassuring image. The other passengers are teen-agers from the neighborhood who look as if they do things every day that make the Cyclone about as exciting as a cross-town bus. The hand-painted signs warn us against losing handbags and beepers.
Once the Cyclone starts, it just doesn't feel safe. It shakes and moans. This is not the sleek modern sound of speed. This is speed from another era. It's the roller-coaster equivalent of reading by gas lamps or sending telegraphs. The Cyclone was built in 1927. "Don't worry," my date tells me. "There's a guy who checks every inch of it every day." But should we trust a roller coaster constructed before they knew about computers or television?
We are pulled into the sky. I feel as if I am nothing but a stomach, air and fear. As we hurtle to the top, I grasp my handbag, my date pressed against me, and I see the water and sky and sand, the crowd swirling below us, and it's the greatest view in the whole city, the thrill and terror blending into clarity, and I feel as if I've never really seen the ocean before.
Down below us is the boardwalk where my father used to come with his friends in the early 30's to swim and buy Nathan's hot dogs for a nickel. He rode the Cyclone in the brighter, grander days of its youth. He grew up only a few miles from here, on East 22d Street between Avenue T and Avenue U, in a house that I've never really seen. He drove us there once, but when we got to his block he suddenly put his foot on the gas, and we perceived his childhood house, the house he was evicted from during the Depression, as a blur of color. Now, I'm like a tourist in my father's childhood. I am sailing over the past he won't talk about. I am almost reaching it.
The track dips and the car zips down. My date and I are in our late 20's, and he at least seems very adult, but the years are stripped away by wind and fear and we are children again, clutching each other's hands.
It seems as if there is only a small chance that the metal bar will actually hold us in. At any moment we are going to fly out -- little dots against the horizon. I imagine us falling through the air, like astronauts in a movie, our hair streaming out in the wind, frozen in a black and white photograph the next day in the tabloids.
As we turn the curve, even the blase teen-agers shriek, but I am too scared to scream. It seems as if all of my energy has to be focused on staying alive. In 1911, the Cyclone's predecessor, the Giant Racer, flew off its tracks, killing two women.
It feels as if the earth is falling out from under us and I have to close my eyes, no matter what my date will think. We swoop and swerve and finally clatter to a halt. It has been 100 seconds.
I wonder why I feel so good. I feel sort of bruised and banged up but that feeling is part of the beauty of the Cyclone. It's about terror and the release from terror, about how close dreams are to nightmares, and how easy it is to escape from your life. A journalist from the turn of the century wrote, "Coney Island has a code of conduct all her own," and I know exactly what he means. The Cyclone gives you the feeling that nothing matters but the moment you are in, a feeling worth much more than the $4 price of the ticket. In fact, it may be the platonic ideal of dates -- a whole journey of risk and reassurance condensed into a minute-and-a-half.
As I step onto what seems like solid ground, I feel lightheaded and shaky and my date puts his arm around me. We pass a freak show and a dance contest in which couple No. 2 seems to be the best bet to win. The brightly painted food stands and arcades bear more of a resemblance to the old peep shows in Times Square than the glamorous architecture of Coney Island's past. But you can still feel the seediness and greatness of the place, the vague feeling of menace, of leisure and unemployment mixing, along with the elation of a day at the beach.
My date buys a large bag of Nathan's french fries, and I wonder how on earth he can eat after what we've just been through, and the crowd is milling around us with stuffed dogs and blown-up alligators tucked under their arms, and the sun glistens in the sand, and the sky is as blue as the cotton candy sold by vendors, and, for a moment, I am dazzled by the mysteries of another person and of the city itself.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In search of thrills and chills: Braving a ride last summer on the Cyclone roller coaster at Coney Island. (Associated Press)

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 6; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 2195 words

HEADLINE: Classical Music and Dance Guide

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in New York City.
 
Opera
 
THE AMATO OPERA'S "FALSTAFF." For 50 years, Anthony Amato has been conducting and directing pocket-size productions of repertory classics and rarely staged works, using chamber orchestrations and casts that combine amateurs who are enthusiastic enough about opera to learn a role and conservatory students who crave experience. The results are unpredictable, but for anyone used to hearing opera in the vast uptown houses, there is something to be said for the perspective afforded by an intimate staging, particularly in a comic work like Verdi's "Falstaff," the opening production of the golden anniversary season. Tonight and tomorrow at 7:30 P.M., Sunday at 2:30 P.M. Amato Opera, 319 Bowery at Second Street, East Village. (212) 228-8200. Tickets: $20 (Allan Kozinn). 

"CARMEN." The Metropolitan Opera's current run of "Carmen" survives into early October with much of its original cast intact. Denyce Graves, a welcome firebrand in the title role, will be around tonight and next Thursday. Placido Domingo gives way to Luis Lima on Thursday. The interesting new face will operate with his back to the audience. Yves Abel, a fast-rising young man with a bent for French music, will be the conductor both nights. Elsewhere, Franco Zeffirelli's production offers a placid, photographic attractiveness and should be balm for those not hellbent on modern metaphor. The orchestra and chorus promise to be splendid. Tonight at 8. (212) 362-6000. Tickets, $25 to $200. Sold out; returns may be available the day of the performance (Bernard Holland).
 DICAPO OPERA THEATER. This scrappy company is dedicated to presenting familiar and sometimes unfamiliar works in a wonderfully intimate theater. Leoncavallo's popular verismo melodrama "Pagliacci," the first offering of the season, might benefit from a close-up viewing. For all the crowd scenes, it is essentially the story of a fateful love triangle, played as a domestic drama. Tonight at 8. Also tomorrow at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 3 P.M. Dicapo Opera Theater, 184 East 76th Street, Manhattan. (212) 288-9438. Tickets: $25. (Anthony Tommasini).
 "L'ITALIANA IN ALGERI," the New York City Opera. If you share the sensibilities of most of the audience at the first performance, you may have a delightful time with Christopher Alden's new production of this Rossini lark, imported from the Glimmerglass Opera. But if you persist in looking for Rossini's sensibility, you may not find it amid garish trappings and predictable pratfalls. It all feels like a bad sitcom, and the music, surely the main point, counts as little more than tinkling soundtrack despite game efforts from several performers. Tonight at 8. New York State Theater. (212) 870-5570. Tickets: $20 to $85 (James R. Oestreich).
 "THE MAGIC FLUTE." The New York City Opera has several wonderful Mozart stagings in its repertory, and notable among them is this 1987 Lotfi Mansouri production that captures both the comic fairy tale qualities and the more sober glimpses into the human spirit that are bound together in "The Magic Flute." Thierry Bosquet's colorful sets provide a storybook backdrop for a solid and vocally secure cast. Tomorrow at 1:30 P.M. New York City Opera, New York State Theater. (212) 870-5570. Tickets: $20 to $85 (Kozinn).
 "MANON," the Metropolitan Opera. Jean-Pierre Ponnelle's idiosyncratic production of Massenet's wrenching tragedy was much maligned when it was staged in 1987, but although his scenic excesses remain, the production has been substantially rethought for the current revival. The work's emotionalism, skewered by Ponnelle, now blossoms, both in the fine singing of a well-balanced cast and in Julius Rudel's shapely rendering of the lush orchestral score. Most crucially, Renee Fleming conveys both the passion and inner turmoil that drives Manon in her descent from ingenue to courtesan, and Marcello Giordani offers a thoughtfully nuanced portrayal of the Chevalier des Grieux. Tomorrow at 8 P.M. (212) 362-6000. Tickets: $25 to $150 (Kozinn).
 "LA TRAVIATA," the New York City Opera. Susan Patterson, an American soprano, recently made her City Opera debut as Violetta in this production of Verdi's "Traviata" by Renata Scotto. Though vocally Ms. Patterson sang unevenly, she was an ardent and affecting heroine. The baritone Christopher Robertson is a rewarding Germont. Sunday at 1:30 P.M. New York State Theater. (212) 870-5570. Tickets: $20 to $85 (Tommasini).
 "TURANDOT," the Metropolitan Opera. In reviving Puccini's "Turandot," the Met pits Franco Zeffirelli's 10-year-old extravaganza of a production against a cast worthy of the competition. Jane Eaglen trumpets beautifully in the title role. Luciano Pavarotti is in good vocal shape as Calaf, though somewhat wobbly on his feet. Hei-Kyung Hong invests the part of Liu with some lovely singing and uncharacteristic vocal weight. James Levine and his orchestra are superb. "Turandot" is not rocket science, but its inspired simplicity has its effect. Mr. Zeffirelli's ministrations alternately add to and get in the way of the proceedings. Tomorrow at 1:30 P.M. (212) 362-6000. Tickets: $25 to $150. Sold out; returns may be available the day of the opera (Holland).
 
Classical Music
 
CHRISTINA KISS. The line between bravery and foolhardiness may be a thin one, and undertaking to perform the complete solo piano works of Liszt -- from memory -- in several dozen recitals might easily fall on either side. Christina Kiss, a pianist who was born in Budapest and has won prizes at several international competitions, undertook this project in 1990 and expects to complete it in 2005. She has both the bravura technique and the imagination to make it work, and in the 22d installment of her projected 50-concert traversal, she offers the "Soirees de Vienne," Nos. 1 to 3, "Historical Hungarian Portraits," "Souvenir de la Fiance," and Liszt's transcription of the Beethoven Second Symphony. Weill Recital Hall, Sunday at 2 P.M. (212) 247-7800. Tickets: $35 to $65 (Kozinn).
 KOCIAN QUARTET. This quartet from Prague was formed in the early 1970's, and is familiar to American listeners through a series of recordings that show its playing to be finely polished and full of character. Judging from its discography, its players' tastes range fairly widely, and that breadth is reflected in its New York debut program, devoted entirely to Czech composers. Included are Dvorak's Quartet No. 14 (Op. 105), Erwin Schulhof's vibrant Quartet No. 1, composed in 1924, and an intriguing 19th-century rarity, the Quartet in G (Op. 8) by Zdenek Fibich. The Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, Manhattan, Sunday at 5 P.M. (212) 288-0700. Free, but tickets must be reserved in advance (Kozinn).
 NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC. Kurt Masur's season-opening performances of the first three Brahms symphonies were satisfying and at times enlightening, showing an affinity born of the conductor's long experience with the music as well as an obvious affection for it. Now he reaches the Fourth, which he described last week in a public forum as a "result of a lifetime," the capstone of "a life symphony in four movements." Schubert's Third Symphony should also be given an idiomatic turn. And who knows? Perhaps Mr. Masur and Boris Berezovksy, a Russian pianist, will make something interesting of Liszt's wheezy inflation of Schubert's "Wanderer" Fantasy. Tonight and tomorrow at 8. Avery Fisher Hall. (212) 875-5030. Tickets: $20 to $75 (Oestreich).
 JEROME ROSE. A piano recital devoted to the last three piano sonatas by Schubert may sound like a heavy-going evening. But these works, while as mystical and searching as the late Beethoven sonatas, are also full of lovely tunes and bumptious dance music. The pianist Jerome Rose, best known for his recordings of the complete works of Liszt, will perform Schubert's posthumous sonatas at the Mannes College of Music, 150 West 85th Street, Manhattan. (212) 580-0210. Tonight at 8. Free (Tommasini).
 ST. LUKE'S CHAMBER ENSEMBLE. Arnold Schoenberg had a wonderful way of distilling other composers' works for presentation by the Society for Private Musical Performances in Vienna. Here, in a program conducted by Philippe Herreweghe, Schoenberg works his magic on Mahler: "Das Lied von der Erde," which Mr. Herreweghe has recorded in this form for Harmonia Mundi France, and the "Songs of a Wayfarer." Tonight at 8. Metropolitan Museum of Art. (212) 570-3949. Tickets: $30. Sunday at 2 P.M. Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park. (212) 840-7470. Tickets: $12 (Oestreich).
 TANGO. Over the last century, tango composers have transformed this Argentinian tavern dance into a complex expressive form, bringing complexities to its structure and blending its original rhythms with harmonic influences of jazz and contemporary European classical music. In recent years it has taken its place in the concert repertory, much as the minuet and the waltz did in centuries past. Gidon Kremer has lately become a champion of the tangos of Astor Piazzolla, and in this installment of the Next Wave Festival, Mr. Kremer and the Astor Quartet will present a concert of his music. Brooklyn Academy of Music, Majestic Theater, 651 Fulton Street, Fort Greene. Tomorrow at 7:30 and Sunday at 3 P.M. (212) 307-4100. Tickets: $20 to $45 (Kozinn).
 
Dance
 
CREACH/KOESTER. St. Mark's Church, Second Avenue and 10th Street, East Village, (212) 674-8194. An all-male ensemble dances its way through choreographic meditations on asceticism, the Bible, Michelangelo and AIDS-influenced poetry in Terry Creach's "Study for a Resurrection," to sacred music performed by Lionheart, a male vocal ensemble. Tonight through Sunday at 8:30. Tickets: $12 (Jack Anderson).
 NRITYAGRAM DANCE ENSEMBLE OF INDIA, Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400. The 11-member company from a village near Bangalore, dedicated solely to training dancers, offers varied examples of three great traditional forms of classical Indian choreography: Odissi, Mohiniattam and Kathak. Tomorrow at 8 P.M. Tickets: $20 (Anderson).
 "RIVERDANCE," Radio City Music Hall, (212) 247-4777. They're back, feet flying and fiddles playing, in a mega-celebration of Irish culture, with help from some friends from other countries. Tonight at 8; tomorrow and Sunday at 2 and 8 P.M.; and Tuesdays through Thursdays at 8 P.M. Through Oct. 12. Tickets: $37-$77; Ticketmaster: (212) 307-7171 (Jennifer Dunning).
 STARS OF THE KIROV BALLET. Two performances by dancers from this hallowed Russian ballet troupe at college theaters in the area will give New Yorkers a chance to see glowing chestnuts from the classical repertory including, if advance word on Russian touring repertory proves for once to be correct, the "Black Swan," "Corsaire" and "Diana and Acteon" pas de deux. Marius Petipa's "Satinilo" and "Arlequinada" pas de deux are also scheduled, as well as a solo by Boris Eifman performed by Farukh Ruzimatov, appropriately nicknamed "Razzle-dazzle" by the fans. Led by Ruzimatov and Yuliya Makhalina, the touring group also includes several New York favorites and new stars unknown here. The youngsters include Ilya Kuznetsov, Uliyana Lopatkina, Diyana Vishneva, Anastasiya Volochkova and Yevgeny Ivanchenko. Tomorrow night at 8 at Tilles Center, C. W. Post Campus of Long Island University, Route 25A, Brookville. (516) 299-3100. Tickets: $34 to $50. Sunday at 3 P.M. at Lehman Concert Hall, Lehman College, 250 Bedford Park Boulevard West, the Bronx. (718) 960-8833. Tickets: $20 to $30 (Dunning).
 TANZTHEATER WUPPERTAL. Brooklyn Academy of Music, Opera House, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100. "Die Fensterputzer" ("The Window Washer"), Pina Bausch's latest extravagantly scaled production, features a mountain of red flowers, a panorama of serious and comic dramatic situations and a window washer who is lowered onto the stage, squeegee in hand. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30, Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets: $50, $35, $20 (Anderson).
 THARP!, City Center, 131 West 55th Street, (212) 581-1212. Twyla Tharp is one of the few artists of whom the unexpected can genuinely be expected. Back in Manhattan (through Oct. 12) with yet another new company, one of the few predictable things about her, Tharp will present the world premiere of "Roy's Joys," set to and inspired by music written and recorded by the jazz trumpeter Roy Eldridge during his expatriate years in Paris in the 1940's and 50's. Program A will also include a revival of "The Fugue," an exhilaratingly astringent 1970 dance performed without music on an amplified stage. The three New York premieres that make up Program B are set to an astonishing range of scores that include work by Philip Glass, 18th- and 19th-century American religious songs, and "bachelor-pad music" from the 1930's through the 60's. Tonight at 8 (Program A); tomorrow at 3 and 8 P.M. (Program B) and Sunday at 3 P.M. (A) and 8 P.M. (B). Tickets: $25 to $45 (Dunning).

GRAPHIC: Photos: Victor Benedetti and Elisabeth Comeaux in "The Magic Flute." (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times); Fiddles and feet: Eileen Martin and Colin Dunne of "Riverdance." (Joan Marcus)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (94%);

HEADLINE: Don't Cut Legal Aid

 BODY:

To the Editor:
You report (news article, Oct. 1) that the Legal Services Corporation may face one of the biggest Federal budget cuts for the 1998 fiscal year, receiving only $141 million, half its current level. However, an amendment to approve $250 million for this legal aid source for poor families passed in the House by a vote of 246 to 176 on Sept. 25. A more generous Senate endorses $300 million. 
 Even $250 million is barely adequate to sustain the agency, which channels the Federal money to 275 local programs throughout the country. The programs provide poor and low-income people with free legal assistance for family, housing, employment, consumer and other life problems. While these may sound like routine issues, they are usually a matter of survival for families living on the economic edge.
 
CLINTON LYONS
Washington, Oct. 2, 1997
 
Executive Director
National Legal Aid & Defender Assn.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Yen Falls on Economy Woes; Mark Up on Rate-Rise Talk

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar climbed against the yen yesterday on further signs that Japan's economy was faltering, but fell against the mark on renewed speculation that Germany might soon raise interest rates.
The benchmark Nikkei 225 stock average plunged 2.17 percent in Tokyo to an eight-month low, a day after a closely watched central bank survey showed a growing number of Japanese manufacturers thought business conditions would worsen. 
 "It's hard not to be bullish on the dollar and bearish on the yen," said Robert Houck, a currency salesman at the Norwest Bank in Minneapolis. "Traders focused on the Japanese economy and said, 'Let's buy dollars.' "
The dollar settled at 121.65 yen in New York, up from 120.90 yen Wednesday. It fell to 1.7728 marks from 1.7734. The pound cost $1.6160, up from $1.6152.
Traders said signs that Japan's economy was faltering outweighed concern that trade tension between the United States and Japan might intensify, which tends to weaken the dollar.
The dollar's strength makes United States exports more expensive and gives Japanese exporters a price advantage over their American counterparts. Some traders are beginning to worry that United States officials may soften their support for a strong dollar if the trade gap with Japan keeps widening.
Dragging the dollar down versus the mark, a Bundesbank council member, Franz-Christoph Zeitler, said he was on guard against inflation. That resurrected intermittent concern that the German central bank might soon raise interest rates. "The price climate is not as trouble-free as it was half a year ago," Mr. Zeitler said. "We have to watch carefully how import prices develop."
A rise in rates to combat inflation would also help lift the mark by making bonds and deposits denominated in the German currency more attractive.
Mr. Zeitler's remarks follow last week's report showing German import prices rose nine-tenths of a percent in August, pushing the annual rate to an eight-year high of 5.4 percent. The mark's weakness relative to the currencies of Germany's major trading partners has helped cause the price increases.

HEADLINE: Room Service a l'Americain;
Old World Charm Bumps Into New World Economics

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

 BODY:
It's not that Sol Melia, a Spanish hotel chain, was in financial trouble. It's just that it wasn't sufficiently Americanized.
Founded on the island of Majorca in the 1950's by a young hotel worker-turned-entrepreneur named Gabriel Escarrer, Sol Melia had become one of Europe's fastest-growing hotel empires by the early 1990's. But Mr. Escarrer, realizing that the competitive terrain was shifting beneath him, put his son Sebastian in charge. 
 The younger Mr. Escarrer, who had held summer jobs as a teen-ager with the Coca-Cola Company in Atlanta and the International Business Machines Corporation in New York and studied business at the Wharton School in Philadelphia, set out to overhaul the company along American lines. He tightened management controls, created three brand names instead of one, separated the real estate holdings of the company from its management operations and, last March, went public.
Currently, the company is negotiating a strategic alliance with an American chain, he says, though he declines to identify it.
The reason he acted so forcefully, the 31-year-old Mr. Escarrer says, was his realization that profitable though Sol Melia was, it would get left in the dust in the 21st century if it did not jump on the bandwagon driven by the American chains. "Either you go for a niche," he said in a phone interview, "or, if you want to compete, you need to go global."
In the European hotel industry these days, everybody seems to be going global. With American chains breathing down their necks, most hotel companies figure they do not have much choice. And the way to go global, they are discovering, is pretty much to follow the trail blazed by the American giants -- with, of course, some graceful Old World twists.
They are making the shift at a time of great turmoil in the European hotel industry.
Construction is booming, both at the high end and the low end of the market, and a wave of mergers and acquisitions is sweeping the Continent as hotel chains search out allies to strengthen their market positions.
Yet, because the European hotel business remains dominated by independents -- fully 75 percent of the trade, compared with just 25 percent in the United States -- it remains vulnerable to penetration by American chains like Marriott International, Sheraton, and HFS Inc., which manages Howard Johnson, Days Inn and Ramada hotels. Sheraton is a unit of ITT.
"Europe is a very fragmented market," said Nigel Reed, an analyst with Paribas Capital Markets in London. "Booking systems, reservation systems, yield systems, all are in the Dark Ages." The current upheaval, he added, though wrenching, also provides European chains like the Accor Group in France and Britain's Forte P.L.C., a unit of the Granada Group, an opportunity to become world players.
And they are seizing it, largely by copying the American model. The Europeans are increasingly separating out real estate holdings from hotel management operations, a bookkeeping practice designed to raise the return on investment for hotel companies that was virtually unknown in Europe only a few years ago. And they are luring business travelers with such amenities as voice mail and computerized business centers.
Taking another page from the textbook, the Europeans are increasing their clout by merging forces, taking over weaker properties and pushing aggressively into the budget-hotel business. In March, for example, Accor announced it was teaming up with NH Hoteles, a unit of the Cofir beverages and hotel group in Spain, to open 60 budget hotels under Accor's Ibis brand around Madrid and other Spanish cities. And earlier, Hilton International, a unit of Britain's Ladbroke Group that acquired the Hilton name outside North America in 1988, announced an equity swap and marketing alliance with the Hilton Hotels Corporation of New York.
Increasingly, too, experts say, European hotel chains are following the American practice of moving into related fields, from family resorts to gambling halls. The Scottish Stakis Group, for example, which runs St. Ermin's in London, operates golf resorts in Scotland and casinos on the Channel Islands.
European hotels are also working to close the gadget gap. "American hotels, even medium-priced ones, are better versed in handling technology," said Werner J. Hein, a Washington lawyer who travels frequently in Europe. But Mr. Hein acknowledged that electronic amenities such as voice mail and telephone systems that lend themselves to laptop hookups are spreading. Air-conditioning, too, is becoming more widespread, though it is often still lacking, as many American visitors to London and Paris discovered during a heat wave this August.
To finance their growth, European chains have discovered the stock market. In Britain, six medium-range hotel companies were taken to the stock market in 1996, and two more have followed thus far this year. Mr. Escarrer's Sol Melia raised $275 million when it sold 45 percent of its equity on the Madrid exchange earlier this year, the first Spanish hotel chain to go public. Sol Melia's share price has soared by 120 percent since then, to almost 5,800 pesetas, or about $39.
Much of the action is in response to an American invasion of the European hotel trade. Marriott began dipping its toes in Europe's hotel waters two decades ago, but only two years ago plunged in with a construction and acquisition binge that has so far doubled the number of its rooms to more than 6,000.
Other American companies are spreading franchising practices to Europe. In 1993, for instance, Choice Hotels International Inc., the Maryland-based franchising company that is a unit of Manor Care, entered Europe with brands like Quality, Clarion and Sleep, and now boasts 360 hotels. By the end of the century, Choice executives expect the number to exceed 500. In the same period, HFS Inc., based in Parsippany, N.J., expects to increase the number of its hotels outside the United States to 1,000, from 300 now. Most of the additions will be in Europe.
Eric Pfeffer, the president and managing director of HFS Global Services, is leading his company's invasion of Europe. In recent months, Mr. Pfeffer has been negotiating agreements with European chains. In exchange for franchise fees, the Europeans will become part of an international brand and expect to benefit from HFS's global marketing muscle.
Mr. Pfeffer, in an interview, said that HFS, which has only 6 percent of its hotels outside the United States, expects to conclude agreements by the end of this year for two of its brands in at least 10 European countries. The agreements, he said, would help HFS "advance toward our goal of having 1,000 hotels outside the United States by the year 2000.
"The fruits of our efforts are now paying off," he said.
The Americans are not just aiming for the mass market, either. ITT's Sheraton unit, long a presence in Europe, controls the gilded Compagnia Italiana Generale Alberghi that boasts such jewels as the Ritz in Madrid and Des Bains on the Venice Lido. And in June, the American investor Asher B. Edelman surprised the hotel industry by offering $630 million for the French Societe du Louvre Group, which owns the fabled Le Crillon on the Place de la Concorde in Paris.
The European hotel business has become "very attractive" to American investors, Mr. Edelman said by phone from New York. "Luxury is being substantially reborn; tourism and business travel have picked up substantially. And it's helped by the weakness of European currencies."
Furthermore, with European independents in need of global reservation links, American providers of franchising and booking services are having a field day signing up new customers. The American companies are not only bringing their names and technology, but are also changing in subtle ways the way the Europeans run their hotels, stressing consistency of service on a continent where you might find the sheets turned down one night but not the next, and introducing American-style quality controls.
To be sure, one of the attractions of Europe for American tourists has always been the charm of its old hotels, with their creaky elevators and dark wood armoires and polished-brass bathroom fixtures, in contrast to the cookie-cutter plastic look back home.
Even so, the shakeout in the European hotel industry bestows undeniable benefits on American travelers. The increased competition has helped keep rates down. And the spread of American-style chains has cut costs further by providing the sort of creature comforts and services that in years past could be counted on only in luxury hotels.
Neil C. Longhurst, an American executive with the Ford Motor Company in Spain, says he now routinely checks into budget hotels in Europe. "I sleep there, and that's it," he said. When he ventures into more opulent settings, he says, he thinks to himself, "That's nice, but I don't need it."
For all the influence of the American chains, the Europeans insist they are not about to become Yankee clones. For one thing, they say, regional differences on the Continent are too great to allow the uniformity of style and service that is possible in the United States.
That is why Mr. Escarrer split Sol Melia, which operates 215 hotels in 25 countries (including the United States), into five geographical divisions. "At many levels, I am very Americanized, like the Americanization of our management style, with bottom-up communications," he said. "Having said that, our style remains for sure not American, though not Spanish, either."
A Sol Melia hotel in Brussels may have a Spanish restaurant, yet the style of the hotel remains distinctively Belgian, he said. "In Latin America, we are Mexican, we are Brazilian, we are Costa Rican. We may give a hotel some Spanish flavor, but there will be more local flavor than Spanish, and for sure not American."

HEADLINE: Virginia A. Dwyer, 76, Former AT&T Executive

 BODY:
Virginia A. Dwyer, a former senior vice president for finance at the AT&T Corporation and one of the first women to gain a top position at a major American company, died on Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. Miss Dwyer, a resident of Manhattan, was 76.
The cause of death was cancer, her brother, Jack, said. 
 Miss Dwyer spent her entire 43-year career at AT&T, starting as a clerk and rising to vice president and treasurer in 1979. In that capacity, she directed the company's stock and bond financing, at the time second in size only to the Federal Government's money-raising operations. Miss Dwyer was also responsible for three of the largest corporate stock offerings -- each exceeding $1 billion. In 1984, she was named senior vice president for finance.
After the breakup of the Bell System in 1984, Miss Dwyer was also responsible for planning the stock distribution for the seven regional telephone companies that resulted. When she retired in 1986, Miss Dwyer was the highest-ranking woman ever at the company.
She was the first chairwoman of the board of trustees at the University of Rochester in New York.
In 1943, Miss Dwyer graduated from the University of Rochester with a bachelor's degree in economics and worked in New York City as a statistical clerk for Western Electric, an AT&T manufacturing subsidiary. In 1953 Miss Dwyer received a master's degree in economics at New York University and became chief economist at Western Electric in 1972. She moved to the parent company as assistant treasurer three years later.
She is survived by a sister, Marie Buley of Seaford, N.Y.; her brother, of Naples, Fla.; 8 nieces and nephews, and 13 great-nieces and great-nephews.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Jump 1.3% On Big Electronics Demand

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Orders placed with factories increased 1.3 percent in August, helped by the strongest rise in demand for electronic components in almost four decades, the Commerce Department said today.
The increase, which was near analysts' expectations, was the third consecutive monthly gain. The Commerce Department revised July's rise upward today, to half a percent from the two-tenths of 1 percent reported initially. 
 Inventories increased four-tenths of 1 percent in August, the same as in July.
The August data for factory orders were released one day after the National Association of Purchasing Management said manufacturing growth as measured by its index slowed for the second consecutive month in September. A slowdown in orders, production and exports contributed to September's decline in the index.
Some of that weakness could reflect economic problems in Japan and Southeast Asia. Weaker Asian demand for American products could be "the greatest vulnerability of the U.S. economy," said Paul Kasriel, an economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
As for factory orders, economists caution that it is difficult to discern trends from month-to-month shifts in the data, which are heavily influenced by large changes in orders for commercial jetliners and military weapons.
Today's report showed that orders outside of the volatile category of aircraft and other transportation equipment increased eight-tenths of 1 percent during August. Excluding the military industry, factory orders rose 1.3 percent.
Orders for durable goods, which are made to last three or more years, advanced 2.7 percent, with demand for electronic equipment and aircraft accounting for the bulk of the increase. Orders for electronic components jumped 76.9 percent in August, the largest increase since February 1960.
Orders for nondurable goods like food and clothing decreased four-tenths of 1 percent in August, the first drop since May.
Manufacturers' shipments, a gauge of current demand, fell eight-tenths of 1 percent. Unfilled factory orders, a measure of pent-up demand, increased 1 percent.
Separately, the Labor Department said the number of first-time jobless claims filed last week increased by 1,000, to a seasonally adjusted 308,000, in line with analysts' expectations. The decline in claims during the previous week was revised to 1,000 from the 2,000 initially reported.
The four-week average for new jobless claims, a less volatile measure of employment conditions, fell to 308,750, from 313,000 the previous week.
A low level of initial jobless claims, coupled with a low four-week moving average, "is consistent with solid job growth," said Cary Leahey, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics Ltd. in Valhalla, N.Y. He said he expected "big numbers" on Friday when the Labor Department releases its September employment report. Analysts expect the data to show a large gain in payrolls following the return of about 185,000 striking workers at United Parcel Service.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Surge in Lower East Side Apartments

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Manhattan's strong residential market is having a ripple effect on the Lower East Side, where property owners are renovating into rental apartments the upper floors of older buildings, floors that for decades were empty or used for storage, and new housing is springing up on empty lots.
The activity, which started about a year ago, reflects that this neighborhood east of SoHo, long home to immigrants and known for its bargain shopping, is becoming a less expensive alternative to such areas as SoHo, TriBeCa and Greenwich Village, brokers said. 
 Along Orchard Street -- between East Houston and Hester Streets, and the side blocks in between -- the upper floors of 10 five-story buildings dating from the 1860's have been refurbished, creating 100 studio and one-bedroom market-rate rentals. Also, 20 more structures, with 200 more rentals, are under construction or planned. The activity is also spreading eastward onto other blocks, where conversions as well as new construction projects are at various stages of development or planning. Two weeks ago, the Zucker Organization of Manhattan, for example, broke ground for a new market-rate rental building with just under 100 apartments on Second Avenue, between Avenues B and C.
And Asian Americans for Equality, a nonprofit housing and economic development organization long active in the neighborhood, has three new projects planned that would create close to 100 1ow- to moderate-income residences, said Julio Colon, its deputy executive director.
All told, the projects could produce close to 1,000 market-rate and mixed-income residences, most of them rentals, said Sion Misrahi, who runs a real estate firm on Rivington Street bearing his name. "With every other nook and cranny spoken for in Manhattan," he said, "this is the last frontier for reasonably priced real estate."
Martha Danziger, district manager of Community Board 3, which guides growth in the area, said, "Yes, the activity is positive because having the upper floors of buildings empty or even used as storage is not a sign of health."
It has also brought mixed-income residences to an area that has its share of low-income housing, and it has not resulted in widespread displacement, some community leaders and real estate executives said. But others are concerned that as empty buildings become harder to find, rents will rise, forcing out low-income residents.
The story of how the residential floors became vacant began in the 1920's with the passage of Federal restrictions limiting the number of immigrants to the United States, and later the enactment of a New York State law requiring modernization of the apartments, including fireproofing and the installation of toilets within each apartment.
"The lack of demand and added cost convinced a lot of people to discontinue renting the residential floors," said Stephen H. Long, director of the study center of the Lower East Side Tenement Museum. In the years since, the residential real estate market -- even during the mid-1980's building boom -- had not filtered into the Lower East Side.
Fueling the activity in recent months are the climbing rents for apartments elsewhere in Manhattan and the improving image of the neighborhood. Increased police presence over the last few years has curtailed prostitution and drug sales, and the formation of the Lower East Side Business Improvement District five years ago has helped to reverse the decline of small businesses and to stabilize the area.
Another factor is that new restaurants, shops and retail outlets, including Tahari and Kenar, which sell women's clothing, also have opened in recent years. So have bars, performance spaces and clubs, but so many that Community Board 3 is discussing ways to cap their number to avoid saturation. The business improvement district is also encouraging those that serve food to open during the day "to bridge the day and nighttime traffic in the neighborhood," said Matthew A. Bauer, its executive director.
Rents in the neighborhood have risen. Newly renovated one-bedroom apartments with 450 to 550 square feet rent for $1,195 to $1,295 a month, and two-bedroom units with 700 to 800 square feet go for $1,695 to $1,995, Mr. Misrahi said. One-bedroom apartments in established areas like Greenwich Village and the Upper East and West Sides, for example, rent on average for $1,695 to $2,295 a month, according to Mr. Misrahi.
Tenants moving into the area are mostly young single professionals and couples. One is Eric Brothers, 22, who recently graduated from New York University and works for a company in the financial district.
"Its an up-and-coming area," said Mr. Brothers, who also is a guitarist for a band called Burt Waters. "It's different and has a lot of bars and places to hang out in." So in June, he rented a one-bedroom apartment at 175 Orchard Street. "Compared to the tiny spaces at ridiculous rents I was finding, this apartment is pretty good for the money," he said.
The renovation at 175 Orchard Street was done by the property owner, Shimon Avadi. He also runs Shulie's, a women's clothing store, and a Tahari outlet in the building's ground-floor retail space.
"With uptown rents going crazy and apartments in short supply, it made common sense," Mr. Avadi said of renovating the building. The $500,000 project, completed last November, created 15 one-bedroom units and one studio. They range in size from 400 to 500 square feet and in monthly rent from $950 to $1,200. All are leased, Mr. Avadi said.

HEADLINE: In August, Fed Had Concern On Labor Cost

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers decided unanimously to hold interest rates steady at their Aug. 19 meeting but expressed concern about rising labor and health care costs.
The Federal Open Market Committee voted 10 to 0 to leave its target for the Federal funds rate on overnight loans at 5.50 percent, minutes of the session showed today. They also showed that the committee maintained a bias toward raising the Fed funds target if needed to guard against accelerating prices. 
 "The members remained concerned about the outlook for inflation," the minutes read. "Some signs were beginning to emerge that wages and other labor costs might be experiencing increasing pressure."
At its latest meeting Tuesday, the policy-making committee again refrained from altering monetary policy. Consumer prices are rising at the slowest pace since 1996 even as the economy expands and the jobless rate hovers below 5 percent.
Minutes of this week's session will be available Nov. 13, after the Nov. 12 committee meeting. The committee meets eight times a year and the minutes are released several weeks later.
The committee last raised the Fed funds target a quarter-point on March 25, expressing concern that the economy's rapid growth could translate into accelerating inflation. Since then, inflation slowed even as the economy expanded at a rapid pace.
At the August meeting, committee members viewed the two-week strike against United Parcel Service of America as a possible "harbinger of more militant labor negotiating attitudes," the minutes showed.
Committee members also expressed concern about what they called anecdotal evidence of a "less benign outlook for health care costs."
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has suggested that labor costs have been suppressed by a general tendency of workers to be more concerned with job security than wages. Medical costs have been restrained by the trend toward managed care.

HEADLINE: Safety Standards for Imported Food

 BODY:
Global trade allows Americans to satisfy their appetites for strawberries in spring, apples in midsummer and asparagus in autumn. Last year 38 percent of fruits and 12 percent of vegetables consumed here came from foreign fields. But getting fresh produce year round also means that consumers are exposed to foreign food production systems that may not be well regulated. Although the vast majority of the 30 billion tons of food imported annually is wholesome, recent incidents of illness caused by tainted Guatemalan raspberries and E. coli-contaminated domestic meat and fruit juices have made food safety a public concern.
Yet even as food imports have doubled since the 1980's, Federal health inspections of imports have been cut in half. Since the Food and Drug Administration samples less than 1 percent of food imports at the docks, tainted food can easily reach consumers undetected. 
 In a sensible effort to tighten food safeguards, President Clinton asked Congress yesterday to give the F.D.A. power to halt imports of fruits, vegetables and other food products from countries that do not maintain food safety standards equivalent to those in the United States. That would give the agency the same authority that the Department of Agriculture has long exercised over imports of meat and poultry. Monitoring the agricultural and food handling practices in exporting nations will be far more effective than random checks at the border. The Administration will seek $24 million in 1999 to send F.D.A. inspectors abroad.
The President is also asking government agencies and representatives of the agricultural sector to draft standards of good agricultural practices, such as keeping latrines away from vegetable fields and screening food workers for hepatitis, to guide both domestic and foreign growers.
Foreign producers are already denouncing the plan as an unfair trade barrier. But there is no reason to believe that asparagus growers in Mexico will be asked to live by higher standards than growers in Washington State. In the long run, Federal efforts to bolster consumer confidence in the wholesomeness of imported food will help the American appetite for foreign produce grow.

HEADLINE: Anheuser-Busch Queried On Distribution Practices

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
The Justice Department is investigating whether Anheuser-Busch Inc. has been using its enormous muscle to squeeze smaller competitors out of the beer market.
Anheuser-Busch, the maker of Budweiser beer, said the Justice Department was looking into its marketing and distribution practices. Competitors, particularly microbrewers, contend that Anheuser-Busch, the industry leader, has been trying to keep their brands off of store shelves. 
 The investigation, they said, centered on Anheuser-Busch's practice of enticing beer distributors to agree to exclusivity contracts and a program that offered them cash incentives to do so.
A spokeswoman for the Justice Department said that an investigation into industry practices was under way but added that she could not comment on specific targets of a continuing inquiry.
Anheuser-Busch, which is based in St. Louis and has a 45 percent share of the United States market, said it was notified yesterday that it was the subject of an investigation and said it intended to cooperate fully.
"We are confident that all our practices are entirely legitimate and legal," said Royce Estes, vice president of corporate law at Anheuser-Busch.
At issue is the company's practice of granting wholesalers exclusive rights to distribute its beer in a given area in return for an agreement not to do business with Anheuser-Busch competitors. "Because we are completely reliant on them for product distribution, we have put in place incentives to encourage the sale and distribution of our products," Mr. Estes said. "This is a common business practice. Participation in these programs is voluntary."
Several analysts said that the inquiry, which was first reported in The Wall Street Journal, would probably have little effect on the company and that the Justice Department would have difficulty building a case against the beer maker.
"There are other distributors in the marketplace that aren't Anheuser-Busch distributors, so if microbrewers want to get their products to market they have other options," said Skip Carpenter, an industry analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "I think it would be a very tough case to prove."
While Anheuser-Busch maintained that the distribution program was voluntary, critics said it applied pressure to persuade distributors not to carry other brands. Nonetheless, because of the strength of Anheuser-Busch's brands, wholesalers might have little financial incentive to deal with lesser-known brewers anyway.
"If you're a wholesaler, you've been very successful with them and you know what their resources are," said George Thompson, an analyst with Prudential Securities. "You've seen them build several brands very successfully. It's probably not, for the most part, the wholesalers that have any particular complaint about the policy."
Yet several small breweries have filed lawsuits against the company to challenge its sales and marketing tactics. Advocates for small beer makers say Anheuser-Busch's practices are clearly intended to eliminate weaker competitors, which raises antitrust issues, they said.
"The distributors are supposed to be independent," said Doug Green, an economics professor at San Jose State University, who is also a consultant to microbrewers. "What they are doing is exercising their power over them. As long as they are supposed to be independent, then exclusive dealing is something that needs to be looked into as an antitrust matter."

HEADLINE: PCS to Expand Drug-Claim Role

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Oct. 2

 BODY:
Eli Lilly & Company's PCS Health Systems unit agreed today to administer pharmacy claims for 5.9 million health plan members of Humana Inc., as PCS seeks to increase its mail-order business.
The agreement calls for PCS to handle 30 million prescriptions annually for an undisclosed amount through the year 2000. PCS, based here, currently oversees about 300 million prescriptions a year valued at around $10 billion. 
 Humana said the accord was expected to cut costs and help improve its pharmacy service by using PCS's technology and economies of scale. The move comes after Lilly took a $2.4 billion charge in the second quarter to write down the value of PCS.
Some of the 30 million prescriptions will be processed through PCS's mail-order operation in Fort Worth. That will let PCS druggists fill the prescriptions and have more contact with doctors, which industry analysts said was expected to result in more sales of Lilly drugs. The move comes, though, as PCS is being watched by the Federal Trade Commission to insure that it does not favor Eli Lilly drugs over those of competitors.

HEADLINE: Car Makers Voice Complaints About Limiting Gas Emissions

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
President Clinton met this evening with the chief executives of General Motors, Ford Motor and Chrysler to promote his trade policies, but received instead an earful of complaints about the Administration's interest in limiting emissions of gases that may contribute to global warming.
The White House held the meeting the day after threatening South Korea with trade sanctions if it did not remove auto import limits. But the auto executives were more worried about the Administration's stance on global warming for a United Nations conference in December, and took the opportunity this evening to tell the President just what they thought. 
 Alex Trotman, Ford's chairman and chief executive, was particularly critical of the Administration for considering legally binding limits instead of voluntary targets. "That would be bad for the auto industry in terms of jobs and the economic vitality of this country," he told reporters outside the West entrance to the White House after the meeting.
Stephen Yokich, the president of the 800,000-member United Automobile Workers union, joined the Big Three executives at today's meeting and expressed misgivings afterward about possible moves to limit emissions of gases that may contribute to global warming. Auto exhaust has been linked to this greenhouse effect.
"We're taking a hard look at it because it is our jobs that are concerned," Mr. Yokich said.
While the Administration has not yet made specific proposals to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, the possibilities include higher taxes on gasoline or tighter fuel economy requirements for new vehicles. The auto makers make most of their profits on big sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks that might not meet tighter fuel economy standards unless fewer are sold or the vehicles are redesigned in smaller versions at considerable cost.
Mr. Trotman contended that if the United States did accept binding limits on emissions of gases that contribute to global warming, only American companies would be forced to comply because legal systems and public pressures are weaker in some foreign countries. The American auto makers also fear that the more lenient rules being drafted for 132 developing countries, including South Korea, would give an advantage to manufacturers in those countries and might create an incentive for them to move factories overseas.
"There will be an incentive to move plants," said Mr. Trotman, who stopped short of threatening to move Ford factories abroad.

HEADLINE: Messinger Ad Strikes Back at Giuliani Over a Commercial on Sex Businesses

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
Ruth W. Messinger released a new television advertisement yesterday in an effort to rebut a Giuliani campaign commercial that she says distorts her position on sex businesses in New York City. Her ad accuses the Mayor of using "false quotes" and of "throwing garbage."
About a week ago, Ms. Messinger called on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to withdraw the commercial in which an announcer says twice that the Democratic mayoral candidate once said that "sex businesses give New York character." But the Republican Mayor's campaign has continued to run the ad, prompting Ms. Messinger to respond directly to the allegation with her own commercial. 
 Ms. Messinger's new advertisement begins with her seated next to a television set. After the screen of the set displays the Giuliani ad in question, Ms. Messinger quickly turns the television off with a remote control.
"Isn't this just what you'd expect from Rudy Giuliani?" Ms. Messinger says calmly in her ad. "False quotes. Absurd accusations. Garbage. Rudy Giuliani may not want to talk about the city's future, but I do." The commercial goes on to outline the issues that she has focused on during her campaign -- overcrowded schools, domestic violence, unemployment and homelessness.
Ms. Messinger's new ad prompted another round of fingerpointing from both mayoral campaign offices, with each side accusing the other of starting the negative campaigning.
"Until last week, we were running our 'why I want to be mayor ad,' " said Leland T. Jones, spokesman for Ms. Messinger. "But the Mayor went up with his nasty ad, and it was important to respond to his garbage. We had to get the record straight."
In a statement, Fran Reiter, the Giuliani campaign manager, said: "For six months, Ruth Messinger has run a singularly ugly and negative campaign seeking to demonize Mayor Rudy Giuliani while refusing to say anything about who she really is and what she really stands for. This commercial is simply the latest demonstration of Ruth running away from her record."
Mr. Giuliani's aides have not been able to provide direct proof that Ms. Messinger had made the remark about sex shops.
Ms. Messinger also filed a Federal lawsuit yesterday against the City University for what she described as a violation of her First Amendment rights by CUNY. Since September, she has complained that CUNY officials have illegally barred her from speaking on Oct. 14 at Kingsborough Community College in Brooklyn.
In her lawsuit, she has asked the court to issue an order that would require the university to stop enforcing a policy that forbids candidates to speak at City University campuses unless their opponents are invited to attend. An employee with the City University's public affairs office said no official was available yesterday to comment on the suit.
City University officials have said that allowing Ms. Messinger to speak without extending a similar invitation to Mr. Giuliani could jeopardize the university's tax-exempt status. Federal tax laws prohibit nonprofit institutions like schools and churches from supporting candidates, from lobbying politicians or from otherwise engaging in political activity.
But visits to City University campuses have been common for many candidates during campaigns. Mr. Giuliani has made such visits both as the Mayor and as a mayoral candidate, and Ms. Messinger has spoken on City University campuses at least three times in this year's campaign.
"We hope the court moves quickly on this and hands down a decision before the invitation date that we have to speak at Kingsborough," Mr. Jones, the Messinger campaign spokesman, said. "We intend to be there on Oct. 14."

HEADLINE: French Oil Official Asks If U.S. Law Reaches Iran

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 2

 BODY:
One of the warmest memories of Thierry Desmarest, chairman of the French oil company Total S.A., came when, fresh out of France's finest schools, he was on his own managing a mine in New Caledonia.
"I was 18,000 kilometers away from my immediate superior with no faxes and telephone connections -- it was fantastic!" he said. 
 Last Sunday he realized how far he had come when he went to Teheran and signed a $2 billion agreement to develop one of Iran's largest natural gas fields. The deal brought a firestorm of criticism from the United States, which says Iran supports terrorism, but drew praise from the French Government.
Since then the faxes, phones and telegrams have poured in, many of them, the company says, with support from around the world, including some from American oil executives. Few adopted the official United States view that the deal violates an American anti-terrorism law and could subject Total to economic sanctions.
"To say the incremental share of our project in a country already producing 3.6 million barrels of oil a day will help finance terrorism while the country already possesses huge revenues from its hydrocarbon exports is absurd," Mr. Desmarest said this afternoon in his offices atop a 30-story tower on the outskirts of Paris.
"I never practicsed politics, but it seems to me the concept of extraterritoriality is not compatible with our day and age," he added.
A courteous 51-year-old whose main strength is never to show emotion, Mr. Desmarest seemed unable to suppress a smile as he said, "It was, I believe, Ms. Albright who said politics, after all, is part principles and part pragmatism."'
This was a sarcastic reference to an earlier statement by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright explaining why Washington does not place sanctions on China but has no qualms advocating them for Myanmar, when both countries are accused of violating human rights.
Ever since the agreement was signed to develop the South Pars natural gas field with Gazprom of Russia and Petronas of Malaysia, Mr. Desmarest has been caught in a fight between two traditional allies.
For its part, the European Union has threatened a trade war if the United States acts on what much of the world regards as imposing American law on sovereign nations.
"We will respect all legislation applied by the United Nations, France or international law," he said. "But we are under no obligation to apply an American law produced by a domestic lobby for narrow interests."
His remarks reflect a common view among international oil executives. Faced with a looming shortage of oil, major producers are scouring the globe for production possibilities and chafe at restrictions imposed by the United States.
Executives from major American oil companies argue that sanctions rarely force governments to change their policies, and that Americans are shut out of projects in some of the most promising areas as rivals like Total sew up lucrative deals.
"We cannot isolate ourselves from half of the world's oil and gas reserves and believe that it does not have a negative impact on the United States," said Archie W. Dunham, president and chief executive of Conoco.
At Total, Mr. Desmarest's shy manner, his gray suits and his aristocratic air, the hallmark of graduates of the "grandes ecoles," have earned him the nickname Little Prince. But Mr. Desmarest, a mining engineer who became chairman and chief executive in 1995, is also known as the "central computer," a manager with a finely honed mind who forgets nothing, analyzes everything and moves audaciously.
He confesses that he was taken aback by the American reaction. "I was surprised by the magnitude of the coverage," he said.
The confrontation was long in coming. European Union members who do a lot of business with Iran and Libya have long opposed American laws with extraterritorial dimensions: written in the United States but meant to affect trade beyond American borders. There is little question that France, Russia and the European Union knew, as one senior French foreign affairs official put it today, "they were opening the abscess" with the Iranian move.
Mr. Desmarest does not say quite that, but his feelings about the law are barely disguised.
"We operate in 100 countries," he said. "In all these countries we make sure our operations are clean. We pay proper wages and treat people decently. But it is not our job to change the governments or impose policy."

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
Wolves May Be Limited By Garnett's Contract

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
On the surface, Kevin Garnett was back in good graces with Ned and Mabel from Mankato. The throng of Minnesota Timberwolves fans who had turned on him over the summer were delighted to see their Kevie sign with the home team -- for more than $125 million over six seasons.
The 21-year-old Garnett -- a reclusive holdout all summer who turned down $103 million in August -- played blackjack to the nth power and won, with a roughly $21 million annual salary. And one of the National Basketball Association's small-market teams warded off a maddening fear of free agency, of losing its All-Star forward to Chicago or some other ridiculously rich franchise. 
 But the reality of buying your dream house usually hits after the down payment. And the Timberwolves' owner, Glen Taylor, was talking about a potential six-year diet of rice and beans yesterday. By agreeing to the richest multiyear deal in team sports, the franchise must now find a way to keep its burgeoning playoff team together.
With the point guard Stephon Marbury eligible for a contract extension next July and the All-Star forward Tom Gugliotta able to exercise an option-out clause in his deal next summer, a good measure of imagination will be sorely needed.
"All I can say is, three to four years, yes, we can run profitably," Taylor said. "But five, six and seven years from now, I don't know. We may have to get by getting more minimum-salaried type players. Unless some things happen that I don't know about right now, it's going to be difficult."
The flip side is that Taylor, with his deep pockets, has shown an extraordinary commitment, one that Garnett's agent, Eric Fleisher, feels will become a lightning rod for other players.
"I think everybody got what they wanted," Fleisher said.
"The deal was structured in such a way that some of those things could be permitted down the road," he said, a reference to larger salary payments in later years. "I believe certain franchises have created an atmosphere where players want to play. And I think Minnesota has done that."
The 6-foot-11-inch Garnett signed a contract that was front-loaded in order to create salary-cap room for future signings. But it is not too difficult to do the math and realize the potential problems. At $5.5 million a year, Gugliotta was the team's highest-paid player. Marbury, the schoolboy legend from Brooklyn who has been darting past the league's best point guards at 20, will be highly sought.
Even if both players are somehow compensated by Minnesota, what kind of money will be left to lure a key role player who could push the Timberwolves into title contention? The lone hope may rest in the owners' possibly re-opening the collective bargaining agreement next spring to change the league's economics.
For an owner such as Taylor, who paid $88 million for the entire franchise two years ago, the check writing has only begun. Was it really a good deal?
"Yes and no," Taylor said. "We're happy we got Kevin, but we wanted to pay considerably less. I would say the difference between the first offer we made and the one he took was basically the type of players that will surround him.
"But we're going to be creative. And maybe we can attract some guys that are willing to play for a team like this. I would have never imagined this two years ago. I paid one and a half times for Kevin what I paid for the whole thing. It makes absolutely no sense. But I have a franchise."
And a very rich young star. Garnett, who averaged 17 points and 8 rebounds a game last season, signed a deal that surpasses Shaquille O'Neal's seven-year, $120 million contract signed last summer with the Lakers. O'Neal and Patrick Ewing, who signed a four-year, $68 million pact in July with the Knicks, will make about $4 million less than Garnett in annual salary. Only Michael Jordan's one-year, $33 million contract with Chicago is worth more for one year.
"We sat and talked for about three hours after it was done," Fleisher said. "It was like draft night for him again. No one could imagine this kid out of high school two years ago being picked in the top five. He came out of nowhere. We were both a little numb."

In a Shake-Up, Kodak Replaces Consumer Chief
Kodak replaced the head of its ailing consumer division, David P. Biehn, left, part of an accelerating effort to cut costs and reconstruct its photography business.
 
 Kodak said Mr. Biehn would be replaced on Oct. 13 by Robert Keegan, who now runs the company's professional division. The announcement comes a week after Kodak said it would dismiss 200 senior and middle managers, or about one-fifth of the managers worldwide, and warned that earnings for this year could be off by as much as 25 percent. Page D4.
 
Raytheon-Hughes Deal Is Approved
Raytheon won approval from Federal antitrust officials to buy the military business of Hughes Electronics, but the companies agreed to take several steps intended to maintain competition. D18.
 
Orders Gain for Third Month
A strong increase in demand for electronic components contributed to a 1.3 percent rise in factory orders in August, the third straight monthly advance. D2.
 
Federal Reserve policy makers expressed concern about labor and health costs at their Aug. 19 meeting, even as they left interest rates unchanged, minutes showed. D3.
 
Stocks and Bonds Advance
Most major indexes rose to records in a modest stock market rally, led by small-cap and technology shares. The notable exception was the Dow Jones industrial average, but it still managed a 12.03-point gain to close at 8,027.53, its second consecutive finish above 8,000 since Aug. 20. D6.
 
Treasury securities rallied further on optimism that September unemployment data released today would provide further evidence of benign inflation. The 30-year bond yield settled at 6.30 percent, down from 6.32 and near its low for the year. D16.
 
Anheuser Tactics Draw Scrutiny
The Justice Department is investigating whether Anheuser-Busch has been using its enormous muscle to squeeze smaller competitors like microbreweries out of the beer market. D17.
 
Business Data Services Being Sold
Knight-Ridder is selling its on-line business information service, including its best-known brands, Dialog and Datastar, to M.A.I.D. of Britain for $420 million. D5.
 
Hypertension Drug Is Approved
Sanofi, the French drug maker, and Bristol- Myers Squibb have received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to market Irbesartan, an anti-hypertension drug. D6.
 
Clinton Acts on Imports of Produce
President Clinton said he would ask Congress to empower regulators to ban imports of fruit and vegetables from countries that do not meet American food safety standards, acting after outbreaks of disease linked to the increasing global trade in produce. A1.
 
A Cool Reception
Mr. Clinton also met with the chiefs of the Big Three auto makers to tout his trade policies, but received instead an earful of complaints about the Administration's interest in limiting emissions of gases that may contribute to global warming. D2.
 
Iraq Tension Lifts Oil Prices
Crude oil prices rose to their highest level in four months because of tensions between Iraq and United Nations weapons inspectors and concern over an impending strike by oil workers in Colombia. D13.
 
CNN Won't Run Global Warming Ads
CNN told a coalition of industrial companies that it would no longer broadcast the group's advertisements criticizing the Clinton Administration's negotiating stance in talks on controlling global warming. A12.

New Evidence in Diana's Crash
French investigators have determined that paint found on the Mercedes in which Diana, Princess of Wales, was killed came from a black Fiat Uno that apparently collided with the Mercedes just before it smashed into a tunnel support pillar, officials said. No one has reported having been involved in a collision. But some witnesses told the police they saw another car and a motorcycle weave in front of the Mercedes moments before it crashed. A3

NATIONAL A10-13
 
Clinton Urges Controls On Imports of Produce
President Clinton, acting after several outbreaks of disease were linked to the burgeoning global trade in produce, announced that he would ask Congress to require Federal regulators to ban imports of fruit and vegetables from countries that do not meet American food safety standards. The move, urged by regulators since shortly after Mr. Clinton took office and welcomed by industry and consumer groups, would empower the Food and Drug Administration to safeguard foreign fruits and vegetables in much the same way that other Federal regulators check meat and poultry from overseas. Her decision is contained in a letter to be sent Friday to House Republicans who have demanded for months that she seek the special counsel and move the investigation outside the Justice Department. While it remains uncertain whether she will ultimately make such a request, her decision takes the Justice Department one step closer to it. A1

HEADLINE: Attacking and Defending The Internet, Yet Again

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
When the authorities said yesterday that the New Jersey teen-ager accused of sexually assaulting and strangling an 11-year-old neighbor was himself the victim of sexual assault by a man he met in an America Online chat room, people on both sides of the Internet debate had the same reaction: not again.
Not again, said those who believe that a spate of highly publicized sexual abuse cases related to the on-line world underscores the need for tougher laws. "This gives further support for the argument that the Internet should not be exempt from the laws that protect kids in every other medium," said Cathy Cleaver, director of legal policy at the Family Research Council. 
 Not again, said those who think that those same cases give people the impression that the on-line world is a nesting ground for deviants. "I think we need some sort of 'Internet Anti-Defamation League,' " wrote Thomas F. Hespos Jr., on an E-mail discussion group called the World Wide Web Artists Consortium.
A chat room is an on-line forum in which people can exchange their typed messages about a particular subject -- say, the Yankees, grunge music or Quentin Tarantino. The "chats" are interactive, which means that if someone in New York types out, "The Yankees will win the World Series," someone in Atlanta could respond instantly, "Don't think so." And then someone from Baltimore could weigh in, with the result being a staccato list of messages.
Most of the conversations are short and rather mundane, but chat rooms are exploding in popularity, partly because people are mesmerized by the prospect of finding likeminded souls out in cyberspace, and partly because people can use a pseudonym -- say, JohnDoe123.
On any given night, America Online alone has perhaps 100,000 people chatting in 19,000 rooms created by both the company and subscribers, said Tricia Primrose, an America Online spokeswoman. Put all the Internet servers together, and there may be 1 million people across the country chatting on a given night, said Kate Delhagen, a senior analyst at Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass.
At the same time, that anonymity has been used as a mask by people looking to engage in illicit activities. As a result, most on-line companies offer software tools to prevent children from entering certain chat rooms. The problem is, many parents do not know how to use those tools or do not bother doing it: on America Online, only about a quarter of parents use the software, though that proportion is growing.
In the legal arena, there are two major areas of concern: disseminating explicit information and luring children for sex.
In 1996, President Clinton signed the Communications Decency Act, which sought to prohibit the distribution of indecent material to minors over the Internet. But in June, the United States Supreme Court struck down the law, saying it impinged upon free speech.
It is the solicitation part, though, that is now the primary focus of several lawsuits and state legislation. The Family Research Council believes that tougher laws are required to punish criminal activity somehow enabled by the Internet, Ms. Cleaver said. But the American Civil Liberties Union says that there are already sufficient laws punishing people who try to solicit children -- whether it is using the Internet, the telephone or any other means, said Ann Beeson, a staff attorney at the American Civil Liberties Union.
If there is one area of consensus, though, it is the sense that more people need to understand that cyberspace is not much different than the real world.
"The on-line world is not immune to people with less than good intentions any more than the off-line world is," said Ms. Primrose of America Online. "The same rules apply: Don't talk to strangers. Don't give out your personal information. And don't agree to meet somebody without telling a parent or going with a parent."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Retail Space Shortage

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
The same frenetic real estate market that has made it so hard to find an apartment in New York City is tightening the supply of retail space, too. The number of stores available to rent in Manhattan fell to 1,893 from 2,205 in the first six months of this year, according to a study by Garrick-Aug Associates Store Leasing, a retail brokerage firm.
The expansion in Manhattan of national chains like Nine and Company, Athlete's Foot and Borders Books and Music, along with a brightened economy, has fueled much of the growth in retailing, said Faith Hope Consolo, senior managing director for Garrick-Aug. 
 During the same period, the average asking rent rose to $61 from $57 per square foot per year.
