HEADLINE: America Has a Labor Shortage. Europe Has the Answer.

BYLINE: By Norbert Walter; Norbert Walter is chief economist of the Deutsche Bank Group.

DATELINE: FRANKFURT

 BODY:
One month, the financial markets are bent over backward because the United States economy is supposedly growing too fast. Interest rates are pushed higher. The next month, fresh statistics cool the inflation fever, and the markets calm down.
But what would really turn America's "inflation tango" into something more dangerous would be a broad rise in labor costs. This possibility, which would increase inflationary pressures, seems the main concern of Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve. 
 Leaving aside the debate about exactly how low the American unemployment rate can fall without fueling inflation, the reality remains that finding talented workers in the American labor market is becoming more difficult.
For a while longer, employers will still be able to draw workers from the ranks of those who until recently were not actively seeking work. Productivity increases have also eased some pressure.
These buffers, though, may not suffice to keep inflation at bay over the long haul. Assuming the American economy keeps growing above 2.75 percent a year, labor will get very scarce -- unless the United States makes more creative use of international labor mobility.
If it can take advantage of this safety valve, I am convinced the United States could have an unemployment rate below 4 percent and still avoid inflation. If the United States doesn't have enough workers, and if low-wage countries like India and China can't provide enough of the highly skilled labor that America needs, then Europe may have the cure.
Though growth forecasts are turning cautiously positive, few analysts predict any meaningful reduction in European unemployment. Europe's pressing need (finding jobs for its people) happily coincides with America's pressing need (finding people for its jobs).
The skills of Europe's work force are particularly well suited to fill this need. Increasingly, the labor shortages threatening the American economy are in the "new collar" occupations -- technically skilled jobs in the manufacturing and service industries that require specialized training, but usually not a college degree.
Europe's labor resources are quite rich in these areas, a result of the huge investment in job training made by the continent's corporate and public sectors. This expertise -- in computer-assisted design and manufacturing, for example -- is an ideal fit for the current needs of American business.
Suppose a grand bargain could be arranged whereby many of Europe's unemployed packed up and moved to greener pastures in the United States?
American immigration laws already have provisions that allow the recruitment of skilled labor abroad, but the administration of the law has been uneven at best. Perhaps all that is needed is for the rules to be interpreted more broadly -- or for American employers to make more creative use of them.
If this strategy works, then American corporations would gain a vast pool of qualified workers, many of whom already speak excellent English. The American people would win as inflation fears caused by low unemployment gradually disappeared, pushing down interest rates for consumer loans and home mortgages. The Europeans would finally find solid jobs, and the European governments could slash unproductive social spending.
Is this a pipe dream? If French or German workers won't move just a few miles to find a job in Europe, how can migration across the Atlantic be a credible option? And can the Europeans live without the long vacations and other fringe benefits they have long felt entitled to?
Yes, many Europeans who were raised in an era of generous benefits tend to be immobile. But there is anecdotal evidence that the situation is changing, particularly among the young and better educated.
 A German newspaper, the Neue Presse, has reported a sharp rise in the number of Germans inquiring at the American Consulate in Frankfurt about the possibility of immigrating to the United States.
Is it even conceivable that American officials would accept a major increase in immigration? With jobs plentiful and American voters increasingly optimistic about their personal financial prospects, perhaps the needs of the American economy will prevail over politics.
And at this moment, Europe's and America's labor needs are a perfect match.

HEADLINE: Auto Sales Weaken as Buyers Await Deals

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 3

 BODY:
Call it the car buyer's revenge.
Auto sales slowed in September, and as a result auto makers are expected to announce a new round of rebates and discounted lease deals as they vigorously try to woo more buyers into showrooms. 
 "I wouldn't be surprised if sales pick up again, but only as a result of further incentives," said Nicholas J. Colas, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston in New York. "Incentives will rise further if this persists."
For the industry as a whole, sales dropped 3.8 percent in September. Two of Detroit's Big Three auto makers reported their September sales results today. The General Motors Corporation said its sales rose 3.7 percent in September, compared with the period a year ago, while the Ford Motor Company said its sales slipped 1.5 percent.
Ford expected its sales to be even worse, and it began offering buyers discounts of $500 to $2,000 yesterday, even on its 1998 models that have just reached showrooms. The 1998 Mercury Villager mini-van, for instance, carries a $2,000 rebate, and it can be financed with a four-year loan at 1 percent interest, far below market rates. Wall Street analysts expect G.M. and Chrysler to announce new rebates as soon as next week.
And that is sweet revenge for those out shopping for a new car. For years and years, manufacturers got away with raising prices with each new model year. But lately, customers have been holding tight to their checkbooks and waiting for cars to go on sale.
As a result, manufacturers dropped many sticker prices on their 1998 models, or at least held price increases below inflation. Apparently, that is not enough for many buyers.
"If it ain't on sale, it doesn't sell well," said Joseph S. Phillippi, an analyst at Lehman Brothers. "A little incentive goes a long way in this market."
The seasonally adjusted annual rate of sales, at 15.1 million in September, slowed from its pace earlier this summer. But Wall Street analysts expected the slowdown to be short-lived, and pointed out that September marked the third consecutive month that industry sales topped a healthy 15 million annual pace. "Things are pretty much steady here, and we'll see a better annual rate for October," said David B. Healy, an analyst at Burnham Securities.
Perhaps most surprising this month were G.M.'s results, which were stronger than analysts expected and marked the third consecutive month of sales increases. The company's market share reached 33 percent, its highest level since December 1995.
G.M. attributed the stronger sales to the many new models it introduced earlier this year -- including the Pontiac Grand Prix, three new mini-vans and the Chevrolet Malibu. "We've said all along that the new products we introduced in the 1997 model year would fuel momentum and that's happening right now," said Ronald L. Zarrella, G.M.'s North American sales, service and marketing chief.
G.M.'s sales of mini-vans, pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles rose 7.3 percent in September, while its car sales rose 1.3 percent.
While Ford reported an overall sales decline of 1.5 percent last month, analysts had been expecting worse. Ford's truck sales rose 8.3 percent, but the overall results were pulled down by Ford's abysmal car sales, which fell 12.2 percent. Ford said that the weak sales reflected fewer discounted sales to fleet buyers like rental car companies.
Other auto makers reported mixed results in September. Nissan said its sales plummeted 32.5 percent. Mazda said its sales fell 11.1 percent. Volkswagen said its sales dropped 15.2 percent and Jaguar said its sales fell 9.1 percent. The Chrysler Corporation said on Wednesday that its sales declined 14.1 percent in September and Toyota said its sales fell by the same amount.
But many auto makers fared better. Mercedes-Benz sales jumped 75 percent, partly because its new American-built sport utility vehicle is so popular. BMW sales rose 4.8 percent. Hyundai sales climbed 2.5 percent. Porsche sales soared 44.8 percent and Audi sales rose 5.3 percent. Honda sales increased 9.1 percent.
All percentage calculations are based on a daily selling rate because there were 25 selling days last month but 24 in September 1996.
The Toyota Camry beat out the Ford Taurus in the best-selling car race for the 1997 model year, which ended in September. Toyota sold 385,814 Camrys, while Ford sold 367,496 Tauruses. The nation's best-selling vehicle is the Ford F-Series pickup for the 16th model year in a row. Ford sold 751,492.

HEADLINE: Markets Soar, Then Plunge, On Their Way To Slight Gains

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
For those not watching yesterday, nothing much happened in the bond and stock markets as prices ended a little higher.
But the marginal gains came after a tumultuous day of trading that saw wild swings in prices and interest rates as the bond and stock markets gave up most of their spectacular early gains, which were prompted by weaker-than-expected employment figures. 
 Before the afternoon collapse, the price of the 30-year bond was up almost two points, with the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, plummeting to 6.16 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped more than 100 points, and other major stock measures were up 1 percent or more.
But then the rallies unwound, with the price of the 30-year bond falling as much as a point and the yield jumping to 6.37 percent. This reversal helped undermine stocks; the Dow fell more than 70 points, and the other indexes gave up most or all of their gains.
While traders and analysts had trouble pinpointing the reason for the retreat, they cited several factors: selling by hedge funds and central banks to take profits on the bond rally; investor worry that interest rates may have fallen too much, and selling by large institutions to take profits in stocks. They also cited a surge in crude oil prices -- and inflation concerns -- as tensions rose between Iran and Iraq and the United States dispatched the aircraft carrier Nimitz to the Persian Gulf.
Traders were also mystified that the September jobs report -- which showed moderating economic growth and no additional wage or inflation pressures -- did not produce a more lasting rally.
"The rejection of this morning's data is baffling to many of us," said Patrick Dimick, a Treasury market analyst with UBS Securities.
Despite the trading frenzy, analysts contended that the economic fundamentals for both stocks and bonds remained positive. And although the day's huge gains were given up, the modest finish seems to support that view, with several key stock indexes at new highs and the yield on the 30-year bond at its lowest since February 1996.
The Dow inched up 11.05 points, to 8,038.58, just 220 points from its record high. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 4.57 points, to 965.03, a new high, while the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index climbed 13.46 points, to 1,715.87, also a new high. The price of the 30-year bond climbed 7/32, to 101 9/32, as the yield fell to 6.28 percent, from 6.30 percent on Thursday.
The September jobs report, which ignited the early rally, showed an increase in nonfarm payroll jobs of 215,000, well below the forecast of 325,000. But even more surprising, said John Lipsky, the chief economist at Chase Manhattan Bank, was the tiny 1.1 percent increase in the index of hours worked for the third quarter. The index, he said, was hardly up and indicated that economic growth for the third quarter would be 3 percent or less.
If that is the case, that would be a slowdown from the 4.1 percent pace for the first six months of the year and could put the economy on a moderating course that would allow the Federal Reserve to leave interest rates alone.
With bonds already soaring by the time the stock market opened, the Dow and other indexes shot up.
But the Dow began to lag behind the other indexes as the indications of slower growth undermined some of its economically sensitive cyclical stocks, including DuPont, which fell 1 13/16, to 60 3/8; Union Carbide, down 9/16, to 47 7/8, and International Paper, down 1/2, to 54 13/16. Stocks that had given recent earnings warnings, like Coca-Cola, also did not fare well in the rally. Coke fell 1/2, to 62 3/8.
"If the economy slows, it is not good for economically sensitive stocks, and the Dow is the most cyclically oriented," said Charles Pradilla, chief investment strategist at Cowen & Company.
Questions were also being asked in the bond market, traders said, as there seemed to be few buyers at the high bond prices that were reached in the surge after the release of the jobs report at 8:30 A.M. Investors seemed to be assuming that the Fed would never raise interest rates and might even cut rates, said Richard Berner, chief economist at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. Matthew F. Alexy, the chief market strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston, said there was "sticker shock."
Mr. Dimick of UBS Securities said that the morning euphoria had been further undermined by talk of hedge funds selling five-year notes and central banks selling 10-year notes.
The rise in crude oil prices raised concerns about inflation but also, some analysts said, gave investors an excuse to sell, especially because the stock and bond markets were already reversing direction. The price surge, which had been building all week, came after Iran sent jet fighters on Monday into an area of Iraq used by Iranian opposition groups that is part of the no-flight zone enforced by the United States.
Crude oil for November delivery soared 99 cents, or 4.6 percent, to $22.76 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the highest since Feb. 19. It was the biggest one-day gain in prices since March 18. Prices for November crude rose $1.89, or 9 percent, during the week.
"Clearly things in the Middle East frightened the market," said Gail Dudak, chief investment officer at UBS Securities. "I think the reason the market can reverse so quickly is that investors are very nervous because it's very, very richly valued. If the market is cheap, it can sustain a lot of bad news. But if it's richly valued, it can't."
Stocks and bonds may also have been rattled a little by another sharp decline in the value of the dollar against the German mark and other European currencies.
In late trading in New York, the dollar fell eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 1.7572 German marks, from 1.7728 marks on Thursday. The dollar also dropped against the French franc and the Italian lira. It was little changed against the British pound, dropping to $1.6155 from $1.6160. And the dollar rose against the Japanese yen to 122.03 from 121.65.

HEADLINE: Job Growth Was Modest Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3

 BODY:
For a second consecutive month, America's employers have added only modest numbers of new workers to payrolls, the Labor Department said today, releasing September data widely regarded as further evidence that the pace of economic growth is slowing.
The figures also showed that the unemployment rate remained at 4.9 percent last month, still near the lowest levels in 23 years and a reflection of the economy's strength. Still, economists said the slowdown in job growth represented a welcome sign for the inflation-wary Federal Reserve. 
 "It's a legitimate indication of a slight cooling," said Richard B. Hoey, chief economist at the Dreyfus Corporation.
Investors, seizing on the possibility that the Fed will find it unnecessary to restrain the economy with higher interest rates, initially drove prices sharply higher for bonds and stocks. Much of those gains, however, were relinquished later.
Payroll growth totaled 215,000 jobs last month, far less than the 325,000 expected. Moreover, about three-quarters of the increase represented employees returning to work after the August strike against the United Parcel Service.
That meant the actual number of jobs created last month was about 54,000, a modest increase akin to the 40,000 jobs created in August.
September payrolls were held down partly by a decline of 47,000 in local education jobs that reflected the problems the Labor Department's statisticians are having with school calendars. Support staff, like cafeteria workers, typically leave at the end of the school year and return in the autumn, sometimes taking other jobs in the summer.
One prominent question raised by today's report, the first broad survey of economic performance for the month, was whether the sluggishness in late-summer job growth reflected a slowing of demand for workers or a depletion of the labor pool.
Another possibility, one mentioned by Philip L. Rones of the Labor Department, was that this might be little more than statistical "payback" for a huge increase in jobs, now revised up to 384,000, in July.
Joseph Liro, an analyst at CIBC Wood Gundy Securities in New York, found confirmation of a slowing economy in the latest data, noting that payroll growth averaged 187,000 a month during the third quarter as a whole, down from 206,000 in the spring and 218,000 last winter.
"One thing came through loud and clear," he said. "For now, employment growth is on a downward trend."
But William C. Dunkelberg, chief economist for the National Federation of Independent Business, cited his survey of that group's members showing 25-year highs for hiring plans and hard-to-fill openings to conclude that "job growth may have slowed because there is no one left to hire."
Others expressed skepticism that the labor pool was essentially empty. "If that were the case, we'd be seeing a lot more pressure on wages" and more overtime work, said Eric Green, senior economist at the Paribas investment bank.
The September report showed average hourly earnings had risen 4 cents, or three-tenths of 1 percent, including the effect of a Sept. 1 increase in the minimum wage. Over the last 12 months, earnings have risen 3.6 percent.
The length of the private-sector workweek edged down six minutes last month, while factory hours and overtime were unchanged, though all three measurements remained at high levels.
It is possible, some analysts suggested, that the economy is slowing only temporarily, in response to a large buildup of unsold products during the first half of the year.
"In no way, shape or form does this represent a significant decline in economic activity, just an inventory adjustment, as we expected," said Mickey D. Levy of Nationsbanc Capital Markets in New York.
Manufacturing jobs fell 16,000 in September, mainly reflecting the temporary closing of several automobile plants for inventory adjustment and a sizable job loss in the apparel industry. Factory jobs had gained 48,000 in August.
According to the department's survey of households, the proportion of the unemployed who had quit their last jobs fell sharply in September, to 12.9 percent from 13.7 percent, after rising for much of this year. Although the "job leavers" rate often swings widely from month to month, some analysts said the September result showed that workers were less confident about finding better jobs and thus tended to cling tighter to current ones.
The report pointed up large gains made by adult black men over the last year compared with adult black women. The men's jobless rate has tumbled nearly two percentage points, to 7.8 percent from 9.7, while the women's has eased only to 8.4 percent from 8.7 percent.
Alexis Herman, the Secretary of Labor, said in an interview that she had directed that some extra data covering worker education and job skills, currently collected but unpublished, be included in the monthly report beginning in January.
"Not everyone is sharing in this prosperity," she said, pointing to the widening earnings gap between the well trained and the ill trained.
Over all, the household survey found 89,000 fewer people employed in September. But because of a reduction of 13,000 in the labor force, that decline was not enough to raise the unemployment rate from its August level of 4.9 percent. The 4.8 percent rate posted in July matched the lowest level since late 1973.
Regionally, the jobless rate in the Northeast stayed at 5.3 percent last month, while the Midwest showed an increase of three-tenths of a percentage point, to 4.2 percent, and the West was up one-tenth of a percentage point, to 5.7 percent. The South's jobless rate edged down one-tenth of a percentage point, to match the national average of 4.9 percent.

HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN FINANCE;
Text of the Attorney General's Letter Sent to the House Judiciary Chairman

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3

 BODY:
Following is the text of a letter from Attorney General Janet Reno to Representative Henry J. Hyde, the Illinois Republican who is the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, as made public today by the Justice Department:
On Sept. 4, 1997, the Department of Justice received a letter from you and the other 19 majority party members of the Committee on the Judiciary of the United States House of Representatives in which you request the appointment of an independent counsel to investigate possible fund-raising violations in connection with the 1996 Presidential campaign. You made that request pursuant to a provision of the Independent Counsel Act (the Act), 28 U.S.C. 592(g)(1), which provides that "a majority of majority party members of the Committee on the Judiciary . . . may request in writing that the Attorney General apply for the appointment of an independent counsel." The Act requires me to respond, setting forth the reasons for my decision on each of the matters with respect to which your request is made. 28 U.S.C. 592(g)(2). 
 With respect to each of the matters mentioned in your letter, I have considered all the information known to me as a result of the Department of Justice's ongoing investigation into campaign finance allegations; I have not confined myself to the facts set out in your letter, which are apparently drawn in substantial part from press accounts, and which in some cases are inaccurate or incomplete. You should also know that because many of these matters are the subject of active, ongoing investigation before a grand jury, I am extremely limited in the extent to which I can reveal details concerning these matters. However, I will address each of your identified areas of concern in turn.
With respect to two of the matters mentioned in your letter, I have initiated a "preliminary investigation," as that term is defined in the Independent Counsel Act. The first concerns the allegation involving former Energy Secretary Hazel O'Leary and a $25,000 donation made to a charitable organization by Johnny Chung. The preliminary investigation in that matter began on Sept. 19, 1997. A copy of the notification to the court initiating the preliminary investigation is enclosed.
The second involves allegations that Vice President Al Gore solicited political campaign contributions as defined in the Federal Election Campaign Act (F.E.C.A.) in telephone calls that he made from his White House office. The preliminary investigation in that matter began on Oct. 3, 1997. A copy of the notification to the court initiating the preliminary investigation in that matter is also enclosed.
In each of these cases, I concluded, based upon the results of an initial 30-day inquiry, that a preliminary investigation was necessary. As required by the Act, I will report to you at the end of the preliminary investigation of these matters as to whether or not I have sought appointment of an independent counsel.
With respect to one additional matter identified in your letter -- information indicating that the President may have made phone calls from the White House to solicit political contributions within the meaning of the F.E.C.A. -- I initiated a 30-day initial inquiry pursuant to the provisions of the Act on Sept. 15, 1997. If, at the conclusion of that inquiry, I determine that the information is sufficient to warrant further investigation of whether the President may have violated Federal criminal law, then I will order the initiation of a preliminary investigation into that matter, as well. As required by the Act, I will inform you of my decision at that time.
With respect to the other matters discussed in your letter, I have not initiated a preliminary investigation. If an independent counsel is ultimately appointed with respect to any of the three matters outlined above, I will consider whether these matters, among others, should be referred to the independent counsel as necessary to fully investigate and prosecute the matter on which an independent counsel is sought, or as related to that matter. However, none of them warrants a preliminary investigation pursuant to the Independent Counsel Act.
As you know, matters relating to campaign financing in the 1996 Federal elections are under active investigation by a task force of career Justice Department prosecutors and Federal Bureau of Investigation (F.B.I.) agents. I recently added to the task force significant numbers of new investigative and attorney personnel. The task force is continuing to pursue the investigation vigorously and diligently. I can assure you that I have given your views and your arguments careful thought, but at this time, I am unable to agree with your view that an independent counsel should be appointed to handle the investigation of those matters not already subject to Independent Counsel Act procedures.
I would like to briefly address your general observations regarding the Independent Counsel Act. I agree that the statute requires that I conduct a preliminary investigation when I find specific and credible evidence that a covered person "may have violated any Federal criminal law." 28 U.S.C. 591(a). This does not, of course, mean that the Act is triggered by speculation or innuendo. Nor is it triggered, as you put it, when it is merely "possible" that a covered person committed a crime; rather, it requires specific and credible information which supports a conclusion that a crime may have been committed. This is the standard that I have consistently applied in making determinations under the Act, and I will continue to do so.
I also agree that I am not permitted under the Act to decline to conduct a preliminary investigation based on a lack of evidence of the required criminal state of mind. That is a correct reading of the Act.
However, I must again correct one misunderstanding of the Act contained in your letter. As I explained in detail in my letter of June 19, 1997, to you, in order to invoke the discretionary clause, it is necessary that I find the potential for an actual conflict of interest, as opposed to the mere appearance of a conflict of interest. The plain language of the Act so requires, and its legislative history could not be more explicit. My testimony, which you quote at length, is inapposite; I was describing the basis for the mandatory provisions of the Act. The portions of my testimony quoted by you in your letter have no application to the discretionary provisions of the Act.
Let me now turn to the specific allegations in your letter. You request that I seek appointment of an independent counsel with respect to five broad areas.
a. Bribery of the President. You identify a number of particular political (and, in one case, nonpolitical) donations or contributions by six different individuals and entities -- Johnny Chung, Ernest Green, Charlie Trie, Lippo Companies, Mark Jimenez and his employees, and residents of Guam -- and you suggest that those donations or contributions were made in exchange for particular official actions by the President. You correctly note that if this suggestion is accurate, these transactions could violate a number of Federal criminal statutes. However, at this time we are aware of no specific and credible evidence -- indeed, we are aware of no evidence whatsoever --indicating that the President may have demanded, sought, received or accepted, or agreed to receive or accept, any of these donations or contributions in quid pro quo exchange for official action, or participated in any criminal conspiracy to do so. Indeed, your letter cites no more than speculation in newspaper articles based on the fact that certain Government actions favorable to a contributor followed or preceded a contribution. However, it would be inappropriate to commence a criminal investigation every time an elected official took action that benefited any contributor, in the absence of actual evidence that there may have been a quid pro quo. We are aware of no such evidence in the matters to which you refer.
Moreover, several of the transactions to which you refer, based on available information, involve mere access to the President or the White House, purportedly obtained by virtue of political donations. The courts that have addressed the issue have held that such access in exchange for political contributions is not an "official act" that can provide the basis for a bribery or extortion prosecution. See United States v. Carpenter, 961 F.2d 824, 827 (Ninth Circuit, 1992) ("granting or denying access to lobbyists based upon levels of campaign contributions is not an 'official act' "). Indeed, one court has focused on the constitutional right to "petition the Government for a redress of grievances" guaranteed by the First Amendment in refusing to find that alleged gifts provided in hopes of access to an elected public official could amount to a scheme to defraud the public of the official honest services:
We do not think that the desire to gain access, by itself, amounts to an intent to influence improperly the legislators' exercise of official duties. The Government points to no legislative duty to provide equal access to all members of the public; and, from a practical standpoint, we doubt one exists. United States v. Sawyer, 85 F.3d 713, 731 (Fourth Circuit, 1996). To the extent that the allegations you have set out suggest simply a decision by an elected politician to provide access to political contributors, we conclude that no Federal violation is suggested.
The campaign financing task force is investigating the circumstances surrounding many of these contributions for other potential violations. Should it develop any evidence that suggests that the President or any other covered person may have participated in any criminal conduct in this regard, I will invoke the procedures of the Act.
b. Unlawful use of Government facilities by the President. You next cite two types of events involving the President that occurred within the White House -- Democratic National Committee coffees and overnight stays by guests in the Lincoln Bedroom --and suggest that these constituted illegal solicitations of political contributions (in violation of 18 U.S.C. 607), or were benefits made possible by Act of Congress provided in exchange for political activity (in violation of 18 U.S.C. 600), or amounted to illegal conversions of Government property (in violation of 18 U.S.C. 641).
Section 607 does not apply to events occurring within the residential areas of the White House, and applies only to solicitation of so-called "hard money" contributions. Many of the events you mention may fail to meet even these preliminary requirements of a section 607 offense. Even more broadly, we are aware of no evidence, and you have directed none to our attention, that would suggest that the President requested or received a contribution within the meaning of the F.E.C.A. from anyone in the course of either the coffees or the overnight visits by his guests. Merely entertaining his supporters in the White House does not constitute a violation of section 607. There are, as you are aware, other difficult legal issues under section 607 as well, but it is sufficient for the moment to discuss only these.
Like the bribery and extortion statutes, section 600 does not apply to providing access in exchange for political contributions; rather, it provides criminal penalties only for promising "any employment, position, compensation, contract, appointment or other benefit, provided for or made possible in whole or in part by any Act of Congress" in exchange for political activity. As broad as this statute may be, it does not cover mere access, as you assert. An elected official who decides to provide access to a political supporter is not providing a federally funded benefit such as Federal employment or a Federal contract. We are unaware of any legal precedent or legislative history that would suggest that section 600 is applicable to anything other than the sort of "benefits" expressly set out in the statute.
Section 600 was originally enacted as section 3 of the Federal Hatch Act of 1939, "An act to prevent pernicious political activities." The Hatch Act arose out of extensive hearings by the Congress into political abuses, many of which arose out of the New Deal benefit programs that began during the 1930's, and which are documented in the report by a special Senate Committee, popularly known as the "Sheppard Committee." Senate Report No. 1, 76th Congress., 1st Session. (1939). As is plain from the report, and as reflected in the language of section 600 itself, Congress was concerned with what was found to be widespread coercion of political support from unwilling citizens in exchange for employment, contract benefits, or other benefits flowing from Federal relief programs:
We have heard from the lips of our people who are working on the W.P.A., and those receiving direct relief, that intimidation, threats, and coercion have been exerted upon them respecting their vote at our elections. That in many instances the threat has been made that if the worker, or the recipient of direct relief, did not vote for the party, or the candidates, as requested the worker would be immediately discharged from the W.P.A. and the recipient of direct relief would not receive further assistance. 84 Congressional Record H9604 (daily ed. July 20, 1939)(remarks of Representative Springer).
Thus, based on the language of the statute itself and the legislative history describing the concerns that led to passage of the statute, we conclude that visiting the President in the White House is not a federal program "benefit" within the meaning of 18 U.S.C. 600.
Finally, you suggest that section 641, the criminal statute barring conversion of government property, was violated by the President when he used the White House for his "private use." The White House is the personal residence of the President, provided to him for his "private use" during his term in office. The mere occupancy and use of the space that has been provided to him as his home is not a criminal theft or conversion of government property. Furthermore, the law recognizes that political events may take place in the White House so long as their costs are reimbursed. 5 U.S.C. 7324(b)(1); 5 C.F.R. 734.503(a). To the extent that any of these events may have occurred in settings or been of a nature that reimbursement of expenses to the Government was required, and to the extent that there may be questions outstanding as to whether appropriate reimbursement was made, we have no evidence that the President played any role in that process or made any decisions concerning whether or how reimbursement should occur.
Thus, the facts known to me at this time do not indicate that the President -- or any other covered person -- violated any of these criminal statutes in connection with these events. If additional facts should come to light warranting a reassessment of that conclusion, I will do so.
c. Tax violations by the Vice President. You next note that the Hsi Lai Temple, in Hacienda Heights, Calif., is a tax-exempt organization and allege that by attending a political fund-raising event at the Temple the Vice President participated in a conspiracy to evade taxes owed by the Temple and to impair the lawful functions of the Internal Revenue Service (I.R.S.), in violation of 26 U.S.C. 7201 and 18 U.S.C. 371. The task force has been engaged in thoroughly investigating that event, and as a result has gathered considerable information concerning the Vice President's role in it. To date, we have discovered no information that indicates that the Vice President may have violated the laws you cite, or any other law, in connection with the Hsi Lai Temple event. Absent specific and credible information to that effect, I cannot initiate a preliminary investigation under the Independent Counsel Act.
Should a tax-exempt organization engage in activity prohibited by virtue of its tax-exempt status, the violation may lead to revocation of the organization's tax-exempt status and assessment of taxes due. Such matters are within the jurisdiction of the I.R.S. Of course, tax privacy laws mean that we have no knowledge of whether any such process is underway. However, if in conducting any examination involving the Hsi Lai Temple, the I.R.S. determines that the Temple or any individuals may have violated federal criminal tax law, then the I.R.S., using its normal enforcement criteria for referrals, may refer that matter to the Justice Department for further investigation or prosecution. If such a matter implicates a person covered by the Independent Counsel Act, then the preliminary provisions of the Act would be triggered. In any event, we aware of no evidence at this time to suggest that the Vice President was a knowing participant in any conspiracy to violate the nation's tax laws or to obstruct the I.R.S. in its functions.
d. Extortion of campaign contributions by the Vice President. You suggest that the Vice President's solicitations of political donations and contributions constituted illegal extortions or solicitations of a bribe. In order to constitute extortion, a solicitation of political campaign contributions must involve some threat of violence, the wrongful use of a victim's fear that economic harm would result from not providing the funds being solicited, or involve a quid pro quo bribe. 18 U.S.C. 1951(b)(2) (definition of extortion); 18 U.S.C. 872 (extortion by officers or employees of the United States). The Vice President is an elected public official and is entitled to seek the financial support of the public. A mere request by him for the assistance of potential donors is not extortion; nor is it a request for a bribe.
You do not identify any particular instances of threats or other extortionate conduct by the Vice President. The press reports quoted by you, in which anonymous individuals allegedly stated that they "felt pressure," are not sufficient to suggest a violation of law. Should any information come to light that the Vice President may have actually threatened any of the donors whom he allegedly called seeking political contributions, we will, of course, reassess our conclusions under the requirements of the Independent Counsel Act.
e. F.E.C.A. violations by the President and Vice President. Finally, you suggest, in general terms, that an independent counsel must be appointed to investigate the involvement of the President and Vice President in possible illegal conduit contributions and contributions by foreign nationals. You suggest that because the President and the Vice President were closely involved in the fund-raising of the Democratic National Committee, "reasonable people can ask" whether they participated in alleged violations of the law. While the task force is closely scrutinizing allegations of illegal fund-raising, it has to date uncovered no evidence indicating that either the President or the Vice President engaged in conduct constituting a criminal violation of the F.E.C.A. 2. Conflict of Interest -- The Act's Discretionary Provisions.
In addition to your contention that there is specific and credible information suggesting that covered persons may have violated the law, you also renew the argument advanced in your last letter that investigation of any of the campaign financing matters created a potential conflict of interest warranting my use of the discretionary clause under the Independent Counsel Act.
In urging me to conclude that this investigation poses the type of potential conflict of interest contemplated by the Act, you point to the facts that I was appointed by, and serve at the pleasure of, the President, and that in the past I ran for office as a Democrat. These facts are not by themselves sufficient to establish a conflict of interest with respect to investigations that do not involve alleged criminal conduct by a covered person. As I have noted before, except in extraordinary circumstances not presented by the facts known to us at this time, it is not a conflict of interest for the Department of Justice to investigate allegations of corruption and wrongdoing within the Executive Branch, even at relatively high levels. I cannot accept the suggestion in your letter and from others that merely because some of these allegations involve events that were participated in by the President or Vice President, or involve individuals known to the President or Vice President, or might have an adverse impact on the Democratic Party, there ought to be an independent counsel.
You also allege that in some instances I and the Department have provided to the White House "sensitive information" pertaining to the task force's investigation. I assure you that any such information provided to the White House has been furnished properly pursuant to my national security obligations and has not impinged in any way on the interests of the criminal investigation. My obligation to keep the President informed of matters affecting the national security has not created any conflict with the Department's conduct of the criminal investigation. Moreover, even were an independent counsel to be appointed, I would still retain my responsibility to relay to the President relevant intelligence necessary for him to exercise his responsibility to protect the national security.
You further cite as evidence of a conflict of interest my opposition to Congressional grants of immunity for what you describe as "low-level figures" such as persons who served as conduits for illegal contributions. The decision to confer immunity upon potential criminal defendants is a significant one, and making it without adequate consideration or information can have a damaging impact on criminal investigations, either by depriving the Department of leverage to secure a witness's full cooperation or by immunizing conduct that is more serious than appears. Indeed, in this case, some of the immunized witnesses revealed in their testimony that they were not mere conduits but had also destroyed relevant documents. Accordingly, the Department of Justice has always attempted to consider these decisions carefully. I am confident that an independent counsel would do the same.
As I have previously pointed out to you, there are times when reliance on the discretionary clause is appropriate, and I have done so myself on a few occasions. However, in each of those cases, I considered the particular individuals involved and the particular factual context in which the allegations against those persons arose, and concluded that it would create a potential conflict of interest for the Department of Justice to investigate the matter. Moreover, even after finding the existence of a potential conflict, I must consider whether under all the circumstances discretionary appointment of an independent counsel is appropriate. In each case, therefore, the final decision has been an exercise of my discretion, as provided for under the Act.
I have undertaken the same examination here. Based on the facts as we know them now, I have not concluded that any conflict of interest would ensue from our vigorous and thorough investigation of the allegations contained in your letter.
In conclusion, I assure you, as I have before on numerous instances, that allegations of violations of federal criminal law with respect to campaign financing in the course of the 1996 federal elections will be thoroughly investigated, and, if appropriate, prosecuted. The Task Force continues to review documents and interview witnesses in connection with many of the events discussed in your letter. If at any time in the course of the investigation we are made aware of information that a covered person, or a person as to whom the Department of Justice would have a conflict, may have violated the law I will invoke the appropriate provisions of the Act. But with all due respect for your views to the contrary, at this point it appears to me that -- with the exception only of the three specific allegations which have triggered review under the Independent Counsel Act --these matters should continue to be investigated by the Department of Justice and its career investigators and prosecutors. Should future developments require me to reconsider my decision, I will do so.

HEADLINE: Proposed Rent-Control Increases Put Off

 BODY:
State housing officials have suspended rent increases for about 55,000 rent-controlled apartments in New York City until there is a resolution of a lawsuit filed by landlords trying to preserve the rent increases.
The lawsuit, filed in State Supreme Court in Albany earlier this week, asks that the rent increases be imposed despite a law passed by the New York City Council last month that rolled them back by throwing out a disputed method for calculating rents. 
 The State Division of Housing and Community Renewal has sent notices to the tenants, many of whom are elderly, telling them to keep paying their old rents. Notices had already been mailed out detailing the higher rents.
For some, rents could rise by more than $100 a month under the proposed increases. Others could be billed more than $1,000 for back rents for 1996.
Only apartments under rent control, the more restrictive of the city's two forms of rent regulation, would be affected.

HEADLINE: It's a Far Cry From New York

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BONN, Oct. 3

 BODY:
Even since William P. Bratton, New York's former Police Commissioner, visited Germany this summer to preach a gospel of zero tolerance toward crime, the German authorities have been publicly and divisively pondering a question: will what is called the New York model of combating crime work in Germany's big cities?
For years Germany's inner-city crime figures have been nudging upward. Railroad stations, once the pristine emblems of a prosperous country, have become havens for addicts, beggars, graffiti artists and homeless people. Drugs are peddled openly at Hamburg's main railroad station. In Berlin violent crime rose 15 percent from 1994 to 1996. 
 "What I am worried about is the fear of many citizens that there are lawless areas of our cities," said Franz-Josef Kniola, the interior minister of North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany's most populous state.
Klaus Eisenreich, a spokesman for the police union, said: "A lot of people, especially older people, don't dare go out on the streets at certain times. People don't let their children go out in some areas. The threshhold of violence is much lower." It was his union that invited Mr. Bratton for discussions in Berlin and Hamburg in August.
Today, Germany marked the seventh anniversary of its reunification. But the event has forfeited its onetime euphoria to a sense that this land of 80 million is faring poorly in a painful readjustment: no longer is it the prosperous and protected front-line bastion of the cold war, but a stumbling giant at the heart of Europe, prey to pressures and economic disparities once held in check.
As the German authorities seek to contain the fallout of growing joblessness and of borders open to the much greater economic dislocations of Eastern Europe -- both cited as causes of increased crime -- they also face the problem of combating lawlessness without awakening memories of the Third Reich or of Communist dictatorship.
In the former East German state of Mecklenburg, for instance, the state authorities are seeking to introduce a new law that would give the police much greater powers to question people on the street and gain access to people's personal data. Similar laws are already in force in Hamburg, Bavaria and Brandenburg.
"Where a police law like that comes into force, people no longer live in a state governed by the Constitution," said an opponent, Hans Lisken, a former senior policeman and constitutional expert.
Not only that, the notion of high-profile policing in the New York mold has raised worries among some senior German police officers that more intrusive policing will create what Dieter Schenk, the head of Berlin's plainclothes police force, called an explosive situation among "the underclass and the ethnic minorities" most likely to affected by a "zero tolerance" onslaught.
"Why didn't we have these ideas much earlier?" Mr. Schenk wrote in an article published in the newsmagazine Der Spiegel, referring to the idea of cracking down on aggressive begging, sidewalk drunkenness and other minor crimes, as suggested by Mr. Bratton. "The answer is simple: because it doesn't work as easily as that."
Mr. Schenk said the New York model put increasing pressure on individual police officers to "clean up" their cities, setting in motion a growing confrontation between the police and the public, which he blamed for allegations of widening police brutality in New York.
"The latest reports from New York of police excesses and growing protests confirm that this process of escalation has broken out mightily," he wrote.
By New York standards, the levels of crime in Germany seem modest. The murder rate in Berlin last year was 8.8 per 100,000 residents -- Germany's highest -- compared with New York's 13.4. The 350 robberies per 100,000 residents in Hamburg -- also a German record -- compared with 588 in New York. Rape in Germany was at its highest in Munich, with 16.3 per 100,000, compared with 29 per 100,000 in New York.
But for many Germans, the most telling comparison is not with a distant city across the Atlantic, but with the days before reunification.
"After reunification and the opening of the borders there was a significant increase in crime," said Claus Henning Schapper, a senior official in the Lower Saxony state interior ministry in Hanover. He said in a telephone interview that the authorities there had decided on more aggressive policing, with 200 more officers on foot patrol and an end to tolerating what he termed "bagatelle crime."
He said groups of Albanians and Romanians were responsible for break-ins, an organized market in stolen cars destined for Poland and Russia and a surge in imported organized crime.
Even though statistics show that organized crime peaked in 1993, "people believe our towns are no longer safe," Mr. Schapper said.
"The worst increase is in crime by young people," he added. "There's a lack of jobs and apprenticeships. We can only get rid of this kind of crime by giving people jobs and training."
Indeed, seven years after reunification, joblessness not only stands at record levels for all of Germany -- around 4.4 million, or more than 11 percent -- but the figures show that unemployment in the former East Germany, where Communism once subsidized full employment, is almost double that in the former West Germany.
The sense among many eastern Germans of being outsiders in the west seems almost to have grown.
Joachim Gauck, a former priest in East Germany who now heads an agency in charge of the old East German secret police files, drew comparisons between the mood in eastern Germany today and the mood in West Germany immediately after World War II. Then, he said, some Germans voiced nostalgia for Nazism's "autobahns, jobs and hardly any crime." These days, he said, eastern Germans yearn similarly for "kindergartens, full employment and hardly any crime."
Thus it is barely surprising that Chancellor Helmut Kohl should have identified crime as a central issue in the campaign for the national elections due next year.
In Germany, routine policing is the responsibility of the 16 states. A majority of them are governed by the opposition Social Democrats, making it easy for Mr. Kohl to place responsibility for growing crime on political adversaries.
At the same time, the politicization of crime puts pressure on the local authorities."They always polish the sheriff's star at election time," said Pico Jordan, a leader of the opposition Green Party in Hanover, discussing the decision in Lower Saxony to adopt a "zero tolerance" policy toward petty crime.
"This time, they want to pull out the biggest Colt .45 they can find," he said.

Auto Makers Offering Rebates as Sales Slump
The car industry saw a sales decline of 3.8 percent in September, as two of the Big Three auto makers reported their monthly results yesterday. General Motors said its sales increased 3.7 percent, while Ford Motor said sales slid 1.5 percent. 
 Ford, however, had expected results to be worse, so to revive sales it began offering buyers discounts of $500 to $2,000. The 1998 Mercury Villager mini-van, shown here, carries a $2,000 rebate. Analysts expect G.M. and Chrysler to announce new rebates as soon as next week. D2.
 
Half of BZW on the Block
Barclays, Britain's third-largest banking company, abandoned grand ambitions to build a global investment bank, announcing that the least profitable parts of its BZW subsidiary will be sold. BZW's executive resigned, and Barclays stock fell on the news, reflecting investor disappointment that no buyers had immediately stepped forward. D3.
 
A Contract Offer Is Rejected
The board of the Continental Airlines pilots' union rejected a contract offer from the carrier, saying that it did not raise pilots' salaries up to industry standards. D2.
 
The Indonesian Rupiah Plunges
The Indonesian rupiah tumbled as much as 9.3 percent against the dollar amid concern that high interest rates and slowing economic growth could lead to losses at the nation's banks and other companies. The turmoil of other Southeast Asian currencies continued as the Malaysian ringgit fell as much as 1.9 percent, and the Thai baht and the Singapore dollar each declined less than 1 percent. D4.
 
Election Fraud Charged
A former regional director of Smith Barney, Robert B. Maloney, was charged with Federal election fraud. The Government said he had funneled $39,000 through co-workers to his brother's Congressional campaign. D2.
 
Libya Evading Economic Sanctions
Libya is buying American-made goods through front companies in Europe to evade economic sanctions imposed by Washington. Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's Government has been able to obtain everything from American-made computers to a portable diesel fuel refinery, fuel pumps, pipe-laying machines and well-drilling equipment. A1.
 
Investors Buying Bed Maker
Two San Francisco investment firms will pay up to $875 million for joint control of Kinetic Concepts, a San Antonio-based maker of therapeutic beds for paralyzed or severely ill patients. D3.
 
Nikko Leaders Resign
Eight executives of Nikko Securities, including the chairman and the president, resigned to atone for the firm's involvment in a widening scandal over hush money that was paid to a Japanese racketeer. D3.
 
Ground Beef Recalled
Nearly 444,000 pounds of ground beef was recalled because of possible contamination with E. coli bacteria. The meat was produced by BeefAmerica Inc. of Norfolk, Neb., and distributed nationwide. A16.
 
Daily News of Los Angeles for Sale
The estate of Jack Kent Cooke, the owner of the Washington Redskins football team, has put The Daily News of Los Angeles up for sale. The paper has a circulation of 203,000. D2.
 
Orange County Official Sentenced
A former assistant treasurer of Orange County, Calif., Matthew Raabe, was sentenced to three years in prison and was ordered to pay a $10,000 fine for his role in the county's 1994 bankruptcy. Mr. Raabe was found guilty in May of felony charges stemming from the largest municipal bankruptcy in history. D2.
 
Pepsi and Suntory Form Venture
Suntory, Japan's largest whisky distiller and second-biggest soft drink company, is forming an alliance with Pepsico. Suntory gets a franchise to make, bottle and sell Pepsico soft drinks like Pepsi-Cola, Diet Pepsi and Mountain Dew in the deal. D4.

HEADLINE: Clinton Hones Sales Pitch On Global Warming Pact

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3

 BODY:
As it seeks a new treaty to fight the threat of global warming, the Clinton Administration has turned marketing on its head: first comes the sales pitch, and later the product will be unveiled.
Call it publicity or call it education, the results of the campaign that is now reaching full boil could profoundly affect the proposal for controlling climate change that the Administration takes to Kyoto, Japan, in December. There, the nations will try to agree on a binding treaty to limit emissions of heat-trapping gases like carbon dioxide, which comes mostly from burning fossil fuels. 
 The Administration wants to broaden its public support before its negotiators present specific targets and timetables for greenhouse gas emissions. The proposals will probably not be the steep and urgent cuts supported by American environmentalists and some foreign nations, but at least a meaningful first step toward someday stabilizing the levels of greenhouse gases that have been relentlessly building up in the atmosphere.
It's a tough sell.
"If anybody tells you this is not a tough issue, they are lying," said Todd Stern, a senior White House aide who is coordinating climate policy. "We have to put together options for the President that are economically viable, that are environmentally viable, and that are politically viable -- both in the international and domestic context."
"We have to stand on the rooftops and scream, because there are those who have a vested interest in not seeing action on climate change," said Kathleen A. McGinty, the chairwoman of the Council on Environmental Quality, referring to powerful opposition to a treaty, led by energy-intensive industries and their labor unions.
Ms. McGinty said the Administration hoped to present details of the United States proposal when international negotiators next met in Bonn later this month.
But even before those details are known, the campaign to build support for it comes to a climax of sorts on Monday when carefully selected greenhouse experts assemble at Georgetown University for a daylong conference.
The meeting is half a conventional policy seminar where ecologists, economists and lobbyists can have their say. But it also resembles a political convention, a chance to put Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore in the best possible light as they take on a knotty political problem.
"What I want to do is to deal with the central political problem here," Mr. Clinton told a group of television weather forecasters on Wednesday. "I don't mean political in terms of party politics, I mean political in how the body politic, how our society responds to this."
He also said: "Right now, while the scientists see the train coming through the tunnel, most Americans haven't heard the whistle blowing. They don't sense that it's out there as a big issue. And I really believe as President, you know, one of my most important jobs is to tell the American people what the big issues are that we have to deal with."
To counter the Administration, its critics have mounted a $13 million advertising campaign contending that a treaty binding industrial nations to deep cuts in energy use would be unfair because it would not make the same demands on developing countries. And, they argue, such a treaty would damage the United States economy by imposing energy taxes or other punitive costs on companies that burn fossil fuels.
For its own sales pitch, the White House is deploying many tools of a classic political campaign: stump speeches and photo opportunities, the carefully staged meetings, alliances with advocacy groups, and the nearly daily events, like the meeting with the meteorologists, aimed at reaping free media coverage.
The campaign began shortly after President Clinton, under pressure from environmentalists and European nations to act more aggressively, told the United Nations in June that he would marshal American public support for a treaty.
He assigned Mr. Stern, an experienced White House aide, as a temporary climate "czar" to coordinate the Administration's efforts. Mr. Stern brought additional staff from other agencies to help out, and began laying the groundwork for Monday's high-profile public meeting.
President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore also met with small groups of sympathetic business leaders, scientists and environmental advocates.
Cabinet members hit the hustings, giving dozens of speeches to push the Administration's cause.
On Tuesday, for example, Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt told the Union of Concerned Scientists, which supports controls on greenhouse gas emissions, that success in the cause "depends on all of us, together, taking up the burden of advocacy."
Indeed, environmental advocacy groups have been working strenuously to influence the press and the public, to mobilize their millions of members, and to persuade the Clinton Administration to call for deeper, faster cuts in greenhouse gas emissions. The scientists' group issued a call by about 1,500 scientists, including 102 Nobel laureates, more than half of all the living laureates in the sciences, urging significant cuts by industrial nations in the next few years, followed eventually by limits on the developing world. The statement called global warming "one of the most serious threats to the planet and to future generations."
In a poll conducted in August, before the industry's ad campaign began to air, about three-quarters of registered voters surveyed said they believe that global warming is a serious problem and that a treaty with deep cuts in emissions is needed. The Mellman Group Inc. conducted the poll for the World Wildlife Fund.

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 764 words

HEADLINE: Time for a Real Campaign

 BODY:
In a month, New York City voters will elect the mayor who will lead the city into the next millennium. Right now they have a good idea of how the incumbent, Rudolph Giuliani, has performed over the last four years, but little sense of his vision for the future. His Democratic opponent Ruth Messinger has told them a lot about where she thinks Mr. Giuliani has gone wrong, but much less about how she would run things herself. It is time for both candidates to start talking specifics.
This week Mr. Giuliani did outline what he wants to do in the area that has always been his strong suit -- crime-fighting. The Mayor's ambitious plan for reducing drug sales in city neighborhoods is, in general, a sensible mix of drug treatment, education and tougher enforcement. Ms. Messinger's plan to improve the schools promises better pay for teachers and administrators in return for more efficiency and accountability. 
 That still leaves a whole city worth of issues to be explored. One of the most critical is the unemployment rate, which hovers close to double digits. Another is the city budget, which is nowhere near structural balance. The Mayor has plugged recent gaps with windfall tax revenue but has done nothing to show how he would cover the huge deficits in the future. Both problems haunted the city long before Mr. Giuliani became Mayor. But he has not been able to deliver on his promise to fix them. It is imperative that he tell the city why he thinks he failed, and what new steps he is contemplating.
Ms. Messinger is far from presenting a full-blown program of her own, although her campaign staff promises a major speech on economic issues next week. After a brave early call for increased union productivity, she has not returned to the subject. But she has made some criticisms that Mr. Giuliani should address. One is the difficulty in managing a city work force that is protected by both union and civil service regulation. The city has long been locked in a system in which some workers accept bad conditions and mediocre pay in return for triple-plated job security. It is a losing deal for both sides, and if Mr. Giuliani wants to be known as a real reform Mayor, he will address it.
Both candidates have made promises not to raise taxes, but there are still tax-related issues that need to be addressed in concrete terms. Single-family homeowners get preferential property tax treatment over the owners of apartment co-ops and condominiums. Small and medium-sized businesses are paying more than their share compared with large companies that threaten to leave town if they are not given special treatment. Ms. Messinger has been a critic of the tax abatement program in the past. The campaign would benefit if she defined criteria to govern such tax reductions and challenged Mr. Giuliani to respond.
On the issue of health, Ms. Messinger has vowed that if she is elected she will not sell any of the city hospitals. But she has yet to explain how she would improve them. Given the fact that Mr. Giuliani's own attempt to sell some facilities has failed, he too should talk about what he will do to fix a system he seems to be stuck with.
Ms. Messinger's staff says she agrees "philosophically" with the Mayor on welfare reform, but disagrees with the way he is instituting it. Those disagreements are far from technical, since, unlike Mr. Giuliani, she believes that recipients who are required to work should be allowed to organize and bargain collectively with the city. Ms. Messinger needs to talk much more about what a workfare program would look like in her administration.
Both candidates should give the city a broad vision of how they would plan for the transportation needs of the future. New Yorkers deserve a long conversation about traffic congestion, subway overcrowding in Manhattan and Queens, troubles with the dreadful Gowanus Expressway in Brooklyn and the possibility of restoring rail freight service into the city in order to cut truck traffic.
Neither has offered an opinion on how much money taxpayers should put up to keep the Yankees in New York. Both would spend money to keep the team in the Bronx. Ms. Messinger, with some quibbles, opposes subsidizing a stadium in Manhattan. Mr. Giuliani would support a Manhattan site as a last resort. But we need a better sense of how much city money either regards as a reasonable price to retain the team. The fact that Mr. Giuliani is negotiating with the Yankees now makes this delicate. But without information, the public has a right to worry about a December surprise.

INTERNATIONAL A3-6
 
Ship Moves to Persian Gulf After Iran and Iraq Clash
The Clinton Administration has sent the aircraft carrier Nimitz rushing to the Persian Gulf in hopes of deterring bellicose acts by Iran and Iraq, Pentagon officials said. A1 

Libya Eludes U.S. Sanctions
Libya is using front companies in Britain and other NATO countries to obtain American-made goods, avoiding barriers imposed by Washington, according to American and European officials. A1
 
Germans Ponder Police Powers
Crime rates are lower in German cities than in New York, but Chancellor Helmut Kohl and other authorities are urging a New York-style high-profile role for the police. Seven years after reunification, many Germans say their cities are unsafe. But memories of the Third Reich and of the Communist dictatorship make many shudder at the idea of extra police powers. A5
 
Squelching Metaphors in Paris
A book published in Paris argues that much contemporary French philosophy consists of "intellectual impostures" -- the book's title -- and displays a complete indifference to what words mean. The authors, an American physicist and a Belgian colleague, were particularly exercised by what they see as arbitrary usage of scientific terms in the "postmodern" movement. A5
 
Tired of Talk Radio?
ORCA-FM, the world's first all-whale radio station, received broadcasting approval from regulators. The station will track the clicks, howls and whistles made by more than 500 killer whales that pass through Robson Bight, near Vancouver, British Columbia. Rival radio operators in the region were not cowed, especially as ORCA's transmission area will be limited to a radius of just 10 miles. A4
 
Cuba Delays Plot Trial
Cuba has postponed the trial of an American accused of plotting against the Government, giving his legal team time to arrive from Florida. Walter Van der Veer was arrested last year and charged with gathering materials for Molotov cocktails and plotting attacks against police and tourists; he could become the first United States citizen to face the death penalty in Cuba. Cuba appointed a public defender for Mr. Van der Veer, whose lawyer in Florida, Ellis Rubin, said he considered himself an "observer." (AP)
 
Chinese House Arrest
China has restricted the movement of a former Communist Party chief after he urged them to reconsider the Tiananmen Square movement, a human rights group said. The group, Human Rights in China, said that Zhao Ziyang is no longer allowed to leave his guarded compound in central Beijing, to use the telephone or to receive visitors. Mr. Zhao has been under house arrest since 1989, although previously he was allowed to play golf and to travel. (AP)

Reno Clears President On Campaign Questions
Sweeping away dozens of campaign finance abuses involving President Clinton that Republicans had cited to demand an independent prosecutor, Attorney General Janet Reno absolved Mr. Clinton of any misuse of his office or impropriety in raising money or in allowing contributors to stay overnight at the White House and said there was no evidence that he sought contributions in exchange for political favors. Clinton Gets Hearing Aids
President Clinton was fitted for small hearing aids in both ears after tests confirmed that he had suffered moderate loss of high-frequency hearing. Mr. Clinton has complained privately for several years that he has difficulty hearing in crowded rooms and at noisy rallies. The deterioration in the President's hearing was found at his annual physical examination at Bethesda Naval Hospital. The President's health was otherwise found to be excellent, doctors reported, although he continues to suffer from heartburn, allergies and episodic lower-back pain. A1

NEW YORK/REGION B1-5
 
Parents Had Sought Care For Murder Suspect
Three days before a sixth-grader from Jackson Township was strangled while selling school candy near his home, a state judge refused to order long-term psychiatric treatment for the 15-year-old boy now charged with the murder, court documents show, even though the teen-ager's parents had sought that care. The judge ruled against treatment largely because a hospital psychiatric screening unit had determined two days earlier that the youth was not a danger to himself or others, according to the records. A1
 
Housing Goals Fell Short
A landmark agreement that created housing for thousands of the city's homeless mentally ill has quietly expired but officials say it did not build enough apartments for the hundreds of troubled people who continue to seek permanent housing. B1
 
Toxic Mold Closes Library
The Tottenville Library on Staten Island, which reopened in 1993 after a $1.9 million renovation, has been closed again and the doors sealed shut after a toxic mold was found growing inside the walls and the ventilation system. The mold can cause skin rashes, heart palpitations, respiratory problems and chronic fatigue. The mold is believed to be particularly dangerous to children. B1
 
Mayor Widens Funding Lead
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's campaign reported that it had raised $633,000 in just two weeks in September, far more than the $105,000 collected by the campaign of his Democratic opponent in the mayoral race, Ruth W. Messinger. B1
 
No Answers in Bus Crash
The police said the driver of the bus that went out of control for seven blocks along Fifth Avenue, killing one man and critically injuring another, had abnormally high blood sugar, which led them to believe that he might have suffered a diabetic convulsion. Relatives said he was not diabetic but that he was an epileptic and that he had throat cancer and severe asthma. Investigators said they have ruled out a heart attack. B3

Employers added only modest numbers of workers to payrolls in September for the second straight month, but the unemployment rate remained at 4.9 percent, near the lowest it has been in 23 years. D1

Auto sales slowed in September, dropping 3.8 percent for the industry as a whole. As a result, auto makers are expected to announce a new round of rebates and discounted lease deals as they try to woo more buyers into showrooms. D2
