HEADLINE: Aggressive Justice System in Jacksonville, Fla., Intervenes to Ward Off Juvenile Crime

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

DATELINE: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.

 BODY:
After hitting a young girl in the head with a brick, 7-year-old Freddie would have had a predictable fate in most cities.
Shuffled through an overburdened juvenile justice system, he would most probably have been sent to see a probation officer a few times. Then, whatever had made him so violent so young would simmer until the next in perhaps a lifetime of violent outbursts. 
 But with his arrest here on charges of aggravated assault, Freddie entered a juvenile justice system that many law-enforcement officials portray as one of the most innovative and comprehensive in the country, one that prosecutes children more aggressively than anywhere else yet also intervenes earlier and more thoughtfully to prevent them from becoming young criminals.
It is in some ways a paradoxical approach, to lock up young people -- and sometimes parents -- at a rate that some might find Draconian and, at the same time, to pay for specially devised social and educational programs.
Inspired by the research of criminologists whose work usually gets no further than academic journals, the system -- actually a series of programs and policies put together by the local prosecutor, Harry Shorstein -- seems to have had striking success.
The premise is the "pre-emptive strike," reaching young people before they commit multiple crimes, and the office has programs intended to reach children at every age level who seem headed for trouble.
For the youngest, like Freddie, Mr. Shorstein convenes meetings with agencies that would not normally share records and, stretching his legal authority if necessary, gets parents to put the children under state supervision in exchange for deferral of court action. Junior high students are taken on tours of jails to hear young inmates talk about the hard life inside. And high school students who commit violent crimes find themselves tried, at a record rate, in adult court. Those convicted serve time in a separate wing of the county jail, where they go through special schooling and counseling.
It is hard to measure precisely what effect the program has had. But juvenile crime, which has dropped across the country in the last two years, fell earlier and far more sharply here. Mr. Shorstein, the State Attorney for the judicial district that encompasses the city, began putting his policies into place in 1993. By 1996, juvenile arrests for murder were down 72 percent, rape down 52 percent, robbery 54 percent, aggravated assault 39 percent and auto theft 58 percent.
David Rasmussen, a professor of economics at Florida State University who has evaluated the program and concluded that it has prevented more than 7,200 crimes, said the secret to its success "is the interrelatedness of the program."
"The whole, I suspect, is much greater than the sum of its parts," Professor Rasmussen said.
By appealing to both law-and-order conservatives and liberals who advocate treatment and education, Mr. Shorstein has largely managed to avoid criticism. But he is not without skeptics.
"Whenever crime goes down, politicians have a tendency to take the credit," said Bill White, the city's chief assistant public defender. "There is no way Harry can know for sure it was his work that brought the arrest rate down."
Mr. White noted that there had at first been some violent incidents and abuse in the juvenile floor of the jail. But he added that he had to give Mr. Shorstein credit.
"His intentions are good, and he is trying some things in a system that doesn't work, that have no statutory authority and no funding from the legislature," he said.
The part of the program that Freddie is involved in deals with the youngest lawbreakers. Criminologists have found that most juvenile crime is committed by a tiny number of young people whose troubles begin as early as age 6 or 7, but given the chaotic state of most juvenile court systems, the authorities usually know little about a child's background and are unable to identify the potentially most dangerous offenders.
What Jacksonville has done to remedy this is surprisingly simple. Each week, representatives of the police, the school board, the state child protective service organization and local hospitals meet under the leadership of Melissa Levy, a psychologist hired by Mr. Shorstein, to share their information about children age 6 to 15 who have committed a crime or had serious trouble at school.
In Freddie's case, with all the available records on him assembled, the group learned that he had been born addicted to drugs and with congenital syphilis to a mother who was a cocaine addict. His mother and father, who were not married, have both been reported for child abuse. Freddie had been required to repeat kindergarten.
With such a troubled background, the group decided, Freddie was likely to continue being delinquent. So the prosecutor's office got Freddie and his mother to sign a contract placing the boy under its supervision for a year, in exchange for a delay in any court action. Under the contract, Freddie must attend school and his mother attend parenting classes. In addition, Freddie receives extra tutoring and counseling to control anger. The family is assigned a volunteer mentor, who can visit the home at any time to monitor Freddie.
Syteria, 15, entered the program a year ago after being arrested on a shoplifting charge and being suspended from school for disciplinary problems.
"Instead of them sending me to jail, they tried to make my life better, visiting me at home," Syteria said. "I like it," she added. "I feel much better about myself. I was just doing stuff to get attention."
The centerpiece of Mr. Shorstein's program has been his aggressive use of a state law that gives prosecutors in Florida the most sweeping discretion of any state to try juveniles in adult criminal court.
In 1993, when he introduced his policy, Mr. Shorstein tried and won convictions against 494 juveniles in adult court, the most of any city in the United States.
But instead of sending those convicted to Florida's juvenile prisons, Mr. Shorstein arranged to keep them in Jacksonville, at the newly built Duval County Jail, where they are all housed on one floor, separate from adult inmates. There, Mr. Shorstein has installed a well-functioning school along with drug and sex education courses and counseling for returning to the outside world. For those who complete their sentences without bad conduct reports, criminal convictions are withheld, enabling them to tell prospective employers they have never been convicted of a crime.
Demetrius Davis, 18, spent 13 months in the jail after being convicted of armed robbery. Once in the jail, away from the distractions of home and his neighborhood, he found it easier to concentrate on his school work, raised his grades to A's and B's, received a high school equivalency degree and is now studying at a community college and working as a stock clerk at a supermarket.
"I thought it was kind of harsh," he said. "But the word is out on the streets. That's why there are fewer kids in the jail."
At one point in 1994, there were as many as 198 young people in the county jail; now there are 74.
In creating the programs, Mr. Shorstein, a 57-year-old former marine, has often acted without explicit legal authority or by stretching his authority.
He issues warrants several times a year for violations of a seldom-used Florida law requiring parents to keep their children in school. Then, often with television news cameras at the ready, he has the parents arrested.
But before the warrants are issued, the parents are given a chance to work things out at hearings run by volunteers who work in Mr. Shorstein's office.
One recent day, Verlean Spellman had been summoned to appear at a hearing with her three children, ages 8, 10 and 11. None of the children had ever been in school and all were illiterate.
After a prolonged argument, Ms. Spellman agreed to sign a contract with the school district to enroll and keep her children in school.
It was a neat legal trick, Mr. Shorstein acknowledged. He did not have the legal authority to force her to sign the contract, but he could enforce it once she did.
Mr. Shorstein, the only elected Democrat in his three-county district, has defied the usual political labels. "I always have to say I'm not a liberal," he said. "That is the nastiest word you can call someone in my circuit."
Mr. Shorstein decided to make juvenile justice his priority soon after he was initially appointed State Attorney to fill a vacancy in 1991, when he was stunned one day to learn that crime by young people had soared 27 percent in Jacksonville in just one year.
"Instead of trying to prevent kids in their prime crime years from committing criminal acts, we spend a disproportionate share of the resources of our criminal justice system on locking people up in their late 20's when they are in the declining years of their criminal careers.
"Three strikes and you're out is the most popular idea in history," Mr. Shorstein said. "But it costs $600,000 to $700,000 to lock a 25-year-old up for life, when he is probably going to stop committing crimes soon anyway, while if you take a 15-year-old and incarcerate him for a year, at a cost of $25,000, you will prevent more crime."
To back his commitment, he has hired assistant state attorneys to specialize in juvenile crime and has used his limited budget to hire psychologists and educators.
Some colleagues question his policies and methods.
"Some other state attorneys in Florida feel Harry is a maverick and a nut, going beyond his legal authority and usurping the jurisdiction of other agencies," said Frank Orlando, a retired juvenile court judge and director of the Center for the Study of Youth Policy at Nova Southeastern University School of Law in Fort Lauderdale. "But at least he is trying out ideas and filling a vacuum."
Under another program that needs little financing or special authority, 25 students who are regarded as severe discipline problems by their schools, and therefore "at risk" of becoming delinquents, are brought to the juvenile court each Friday to witness a trial and then to the jail to talk with the youthful inmates, often their friends or relatives.
William Isom, a tall, heavyset 17-year-old who was convicted of armed robbery, shuffled out in handcuffs and leg irons to talk with the student visitors one recent week.
"I was just chilling with my friends, drinking and smoking some weed, and down robbing people," Mr. Isom recounted. "Everybody was doing it, so I didn't think anything of it."
But now in jail, he said, "I have to get up at 4 A.M. and it's lights out every night at 7, and there's no TV."
Professor Rasmussen has calculated that this program may have averted as many as 1,500 property crimes in three years, though Mr. Isom admitted, to his regret, that it had not deterred him. "I was brought here two years ago, in the same room," he told the group, "but I wasn't listening."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In a program in Jacksonville, Fla., William Isom, 17, in leg irons and in prison for armed robbery, talked with students who were at risk of committing a crime. The program is believed to have averted crimes. (Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Making a Dry Report More Interesting

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
Edward S. Seeley Jr.'s 49-page report on New York City's economy and transportation system might easily have suffered the fate of so many technical planning studies that emerge from city government -- the ignominy of being unread. The report says that New York's economy is expected to produce more jobs over the next 25 years than its transit system can handle, and that major investments must be made now to capture the potential growth. Planners and economists would find that predicament fascinating.
Mr. Seeley, long a respected voice in the transportation planning world -- he wrote the chapter on New York's transit system for a landmark study in the early 1980's that became part of the blueprint of how the system was refurbished -- was also nearing retirement age. Largely unknown to the general public, he and his work were about to pass from the scene. 
 But Mr. Seeley's boss at the New York City Department of Transportation, Commissioner Christopher R. Lynn, has now pronounced Mr. Seeley's last paper to be a "fake." Mr. Seeley, the commissioner says, is "essentially a clerk," who takes things improperly off other people's desks to write reports on his own time as a "little hobby." Mr. Lynn said his department has authorized no formal examination of how the region's network of rail and roads and subways might limit job growth in the future and that he sees no point in even reading beyond Mr. Seeley's executive summary.
"Because it's unauthorized and because it's a fake and because I haven't asked for it and because it's not on my agenda, it's not worth considering, as far as I am concerned," Mr. Lynn said.
Mr. Seeley, a 64-year-old former deputy assistant commissioner, retired abruptly this week, one day after a reporter called city officials to ask about his report.
In a telephone interview from his home in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, Mr. Seeley deflected questions about whether he was forced out of his job, saying he had been intending for some time to retire. Mr. Lynn said he had never met Mr. Seeley and did not know the circumstances of his departure.
But the report, and the questions it raises, have nonetheless opened a window on the workings of this one agency, and the interplay of politics and personality in government that usually remains hidden.
Mr. Lynn conceded that it was possible that the study had been ordered before he came to the department 14 months ago. But the agency that coordinates planning in the region also had no record that the study had been formally ordered.
One transportation expert in New York who was familiar with the report and Mr. Seeley's retirement, but who would speak only on condition of anonymity, said he believed the primary reason for Mr. Lynn's reaction was that spending billions on rapid transit -- and the attendant tax increases that would likely go with it -- was simply not on the agendas of the department, or of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani as he runs for a second term.
"The reality is that Ed did this study and they had a nervous breakdown when they realized somebody had read it," the expert said, referring to Mr. Lynn and his top aides.
Mr. Lynn is also no stranger to controversy. Last year, when he was Commissioner of the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission, he used his office to punish a cabdriver who had given poor service to his domestic partner. As Transportation Commissioner, he was forced to apologize to Manhattan residents after a novel overhaul of traffic flow on the Queensboro Bridge went badly awry, leaving much of the nearby area in gridlock.
Friends and colleagues who have risen to defend Mr. Seeley, including some major planners and transportation experts around the country, say he is an original thinker in his work and a bit of an eccentric in personal style (he wore a blue suit to work for years and told colleagues he had a closet full of identical ones), but fundamentally a gentle man.
"He was a scholar of transportation -- he was the kind of guy you could call up and he would always know everything there was to know about transportation," said Mr. Seeley's supervisor in the 1980's, David Gurin, who is now the planning commissioner for the Toronto region. "In a department where things weren't always eloquently written, Ed's were. He always wrote up his findings in a precise way, and a clear way," Mr. Gurin said. He said that describing Mr. Seeley as a clerk was "obscenely inaccurate."
Mr. Seeley, who also wrote crime novels and had worked as a film maker before taking a job with the city 26 years ago, said he thought the focus should stay on the report itself, not on him.
The report, titled, "The Transportation Implications of Manhattan's Job Growth Potential," says specifically in its introduction that it is not meant to be a statement of city or state policy, but rather an update for the department's long-range planning and is being disseminated in the interests of discussion and "information exchange."
Its core argument is that the New York City metropolitan region has the economic potential of adding about 2.5 million jobs in the next few decades, but that Manhattan in particular -- where many of the new jobs are expected to be created -- does not now have the transportation capacity to seize all of that potential.
The study, using the projections of job growth for New York City that have been accepted by the Metropolitan Transportation Council, a state agency created to coordinate planning in the region, says that routes in and out of Manhattan from the suburbs to the north and the west will have to be expanded, probably using rail, if the jobs are to be captured. That expansion of rapid transit would cost billions of dollars.
That is not a particularly new argument. For example, the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit planning and research group in Manhattan, said much the same thing in a major planning study of the region issued last year. The association's board was presented with a summary of Mr. Seeley's study last week.
Regina Armstrong -- an economist at Urbanomics, a consulting company in Manhattan that prepared the job projection numbers for the region that became the numerical backbone of Mr. Seeley's study -- also praised his work.
Ms. Armstrong said her main quibble was with her own projections, which have been overtaken by New York's economic growth.The job increase that she had expected by 2000 is now expected in 1998 and 1999, making Mr. Seeley's argument all the more compelling, she said.

HEADLINE: Tropical Forests Are Ravaged by Free Trade

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Sept. 27 editorial on Southeast Asia's forests recommends that the United States respond to the deforestation crisis by banning plywood made of tropical hardwood. But such a ban is unlikely because it would be inconsistent with the Administration's goal of free trade. 
 If Congress enacted such a restriction, the United States would face a challenge of "unfair trade practices" from Indonesia in the World Trade Organization. In 1991 the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a predecessor to the W.T.O., ruled that the United States could not restrict imports because of the way they are made or harvested.
Your second alternative -- requiring country-of-origin labeling on wood products -- has been challenged by some industry groups and developing countries as a "technical barrier to trade." Must free trade mean that whoever makes products most cheaply, at whatever social cost, wins? Some of us in Congress oppose "fast track" authority for trade legislation unless there are guarantees that labor and environmental issues will be addressed.
 
GEORGE MILLER
Member of Congress, 7th Dist., Calif.
Washington, Sept. 30, 1997

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 4; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 248 words

HEADLINE: Tropical Forests Are Ravaged by Free Trade;
Labels Won't Work

 BODY:

To the Editor:
A Sept. 27 editorial says that to act against the fires caused by deforestation of Southeast Asian forests for production of exported plywood, the United States should either ban plywood made of tropical hardwood or require country-of-origin labeling on wood products "so consumers can refuse to buy them." The first alternative is logical, but the second is not. 
 Country-of-origin laws are based on the idea that some consumers consider origin relevant to purchasing decisions. But consumers may shun, or favor, products from particular countries for many reasons. The reason doesn't matter. No national policy objective is served except that of providing possibly useful information to the consumer. But where there is an independent national policy objective, the proper actions are diplomacy and economic sanctions. Information won't deter buyers who don't know or care about the environment or who buy on the basis of price.
The law already requires that imported products show the country of origin to the consumer. To go further -- for example, requiring labels as to the origin of product ingredients -- could raise questions of legality in the World Trade Organization.
While Government should be encouraged to combat wanton devastation of Asian hardwood forests, passing responsibility off to "informed" consumers is neither effective nor appropriate.
 
RUFUS E. JARMAN
New York, Oct. 1, 1997
 
The writer is a customs and trade lawyer.

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 6; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 126 words

HEADLINE: Tropical Forests Are Ravaged by Free Trade;
Indonesia's Progress

 BODY:

To the Editor:
To call for a ban on products from a developing country as you did in your Sept. 27 editorial "Asia's Forest Disaster" will hamper the significant progress Indonesia has made in the management of some of the world's largest forest resources. 
 Every possible effort is being made to end the fires burning out of control in several parts of our country.
Recent catastrophes, including drought, earthquakes, a tragic plane crash and forest fires, along with a financial crisis, have brought deep grief to many Indonesians.
Your editorial's judgments do nothing to help those who suffer the effects of these disasters daily.
 
DARMOSUTANTO BUDIMAN
Deputy Chief of Mission
Embassy of Indonesia
Washington, Oct. 2, 1997

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1712 words

HEADLINE: Some Local Cheers for 'Creeping Socialism';
A Few Towns Build Their Own Cable Companies

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: HARLAN, Iowa

 BODY:
In an America where free-enterprise advocates have routed their critics, few people would expect local governments to plunge into competition with the private sector in the fast-evolving information industries. Yet that is what is happening in a growing number of communities.
From old mill towns like Holyoke, Mass., to port cities like Tacoma, Wash., to suburbs like Newnan, Ga., south of Atlanta, voters and local officials are telling their municipal utilities to go ahead and invade private-business turf, starting with the cable-television industry. 
 Residents of these towns are fed up with rising cable rates, lack of local control over programming and the industry's slow pace at upgrading networks, according to utility officials. Increasingly, they also worry about the economic impact of long delays in getting residents and local businesses easy access to high-speed Internet links, inexpensive video-conferencing and other electronic building blocks of economic growth.
"The sentiment is that this is just as important as offering water," said Jeff Strane, a manager at Newnan's utility. "Atlanta is a tier-one city, but things they get there take years to trickle down to Newnan."
The movement seems to be strongest in Iowa. Early this year in Alta, 88 percent of the voters supported the creation of a municipal video and telecommunications network, despite a campaign by the local cable-television company, a unit of Tele-Communications Inc., calling it "creeping socialism." The vote was 91 percent in favor in Spencer, even though the incumbent cable company, Triax Cablevision, outspent proponents 130 to 1. TCI, based in Englewood, Colo., adopted a low profile in the recent election in Muscatine, on the Mississippi River, where the vote was 94 percent in favor of public competition.
"People feel abandoned by large companies that are too busy merging and competing for business in other areas," said Robert Haug, executive director of the Iowa Association of Municipal Utilities.
TCI and other critics warn that
innovations in technology are likely to make investments like Harlan's obsolete long before the debt piled up to finance them can be paid off. They argue that only densely populated cities can generate sufficient electronic traffic for competing video networks. And they say that the local governments will inevitably be drawn into disruptive conflicts over what citizens see on the public network and how they use it.
"When they sell these things to the public, they downplay the risks," said Tom Graves, the spokesman for the Iowa Cable and Telecommunications Association, whose 230 members include the major cable-television operators and telephone companies. In some cases, Mr. Graves said, public utilities enjoy special tax and finance breaks.
Cable companies have responded to the consumer revolt by cutting rates and improving local service. In Harlan, a quiet town of 5,000 surrounded by cornfields, that makes for some lively competition. Harlan spent $3.8 million to build a fiber optic and cable network that passes every home and business. It has signed up more than 1,000 cable customers in its first year, despite TCI's opposition.
Services the town's utility says it might add in the future include local telephone competition for the GTE Corporation, teleconferencing and home-security monitoring.
Despite worries that municipal utilities are out of their depth in information technology, Harlan residents so far see only benefits. Corey Nelson, one of Harlan's early Internet customers, was thrilled at taking just three minutes to download the latest version of NetMeeting, a chat room program. It took a friend in Pennsylvania nearly an hour, he said. "And with this system, I don't use the phone line so I can still make or receive calls," Mr. Nelson added.
"This is opening up the world to our kids," said Ken Sprague, the technology coordinator for the local school district, who can now simultaneously connect 290 students at three schools to each other or the Internet. Soon, he said, Harlan's teachers will be able to arrange interactive conferencing with parents or children who are sick at home.
Allen W. Burchett, owner of Sta-bilt Construction, a road-repair company, plans to use the Internet lines to bid on Federal projects. He figures he will get the bidding results more quickly, enabling him to schedule other work he might otherwise have to pass up.
So far, though, the biggest impact has been in cable television. The residents who have signed on for cable service get more channels and clearer pictures for less money than TCI charged before competition. For the first time, shut-ins have been able to see local football games on the local access channel, town officials say. And residents say they like having a local board of citizens control what stations are offered on the service, not faraway cable executives.
TCI aims to provide "fair prices," and upgrade service regularly, according to Debora Blume, a company spokeswoman. But, she conceded, service is "definitely better" in towns where it faces competition.
Indeed, TCI chose Harlan as one of the first 30 Iowa towns to get digital service that will provide a clearer picture and raise the number of channels from 35 to 77. More dramatically, it cut the price for its extended basic service in Harlan by nearly 40 percent this summer. And it also rolled out marketing offers like three free months for returning subscribers.
"We had three TCI salesmen come to our door, each one adding another month of free service," said Cleo Anderson, who switched back to TCI in August after calculating he would save $100 this year. "But I told them I'm going back to the town if they raise their rates a dollar. I won't send a check out of town to save a few cents."
Such reactions are bad news for cable operators like TCI, which count on big profit margins from their monopoly franchises in most communities to service their heavy debts and fuel expansion. They already face growing competition from satellite-television systems and, in some populous areas, from ground-based telecommunications giants like Ameritech.
The cable operators' competitive worries do not stop at the town's limits. The equipment a community buys to receive programming by air or satellite and the computers it uses to manage the network are usually able to handle business in nearby towns that are willing to wire themselves. Harlan recently invited 19 neighbors to discuss such partnerships. Newnan already has one up and running with the public utility in nearby Fairburn, Ga. And Waterloo, Iowa, which has no public power utility, decided to create a public communications utility that could tie into the public network in next-door Cedar Falls.
"If this was terribly complicated, we wouldn't be doing it in rural Kentucky," said William J. Ray, superintendent of Glasgow, Ky. Glasgow's eight-year-old system is offering to deliver cable to Bowling Green, a city 30 miles to the west.
The financial hazards are not trivial, though. Paragould, Ark., which began offering cable television in 1991, has raised property taxes to cover its municipal utility's debts. Elbow Lake, Minn., sold its system to the local telephone cooperative, which also bought the competing private cable operator, after three years of steep losses. TCI representatives say fly-by-night consultants sometimes present towns with feasibility studies lacking such basics as maintenance budgets.
Cable companies have been the main corporate targets for the public utilities because the level of dissatisfaction with their service often runs high. Even small communities can quickly sign up hundreds of paying customers. But local phone companies may also be vulnerable, particularly if local utilities ally themselves with large private partners looking to take advantage of the 1996 Federal Telecommunications Act that deregulated the industry.
Hawarden, in Iowa's northwest corner, recently began selling both cable-television and phone service, the latter in partnership with Pioneer Holdings L.L.C., an MCI Communications affiliate. Harlan, Tacoma and many others say that they, too, will most likely compete in the phone business by leasing lines to private phone companies or in some other form of alliance, rather than managing the entire business as they do in cable television.
Even prominent backers of Harlan's investment like Mr. Burchett favor using private partners if possible to speed up revenue growth and spread risk. Harlan projects that it will take a decade to break even on its investment, far longer that the private sector would tolerate.
The uncertainties in local governments' leap into the information business are mind-boggling. A big question hanging over everyone is how much of the traffic that currently runs on wired networks will shift to wireless technology. But public utility officials note that the investments might be justified even if the new communications services never become profitable.
With deregulation nipping at their traditional business, some public utilities believe they need high-tech communications systems for remote meter reading, controlling power equipment and other operations that make energy delivery more efficient. If these systems can be designed to offer video, Internet and other services to increase revenue, so much the better.
"We went into this because we had a $1 billion investment we wanted to protect during deregulation," said Court Brickman, a spokesman for Tacoma City Light, which is planning a $95 million network capable of carrying cable television, Internet, high-speed data transfer and phone services to 140,000 households and businesses in the Tacoma area.
Still, the hope of spurring economic growth has often been a decisive factor in communities' decisions to create communications networks.
That makes it hard for private competitors to argue that it is financial madness for public utilities to compete in information services without indifference to the community's future. "The first time we dealt with this was when they voted in Cedar Falls in 1994," said Ms. Blume of TCI. "We could see there's a real fear of being left behind on the information highway."

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2; Page 68; Column 3; Home Design Magazine

HEADLINE: Keyboard Virtuoso

BYLINE: By Terry Trucco; Terry Trucco writes about design, travel and dance for The New York Times and other publications.

 BODY:
No two pianos sound exactly alike, but appearance is quite another matter. Consider the classic grand -- substantial yet sensual, with a curvaceous lid and a lustrous case poised on three sturdy legs. For more than a century, this has been the standard-bearer, the masterstroke, the music-lover's version of the Model T -- available in any color you want as long as it's black.
 Not everyone yearns for a classic, however, which explains the rebirth of the art-case piano in the last few years. By strict definition, an art-case piano is a musical instrument encased in a one-of-a-kind artwork commissioned and designed for a specific site. But the term has expanded to embrace new and old pianos sheathed in decorative trappings, from a magnificently carved 1860 Victorian rosewood grand by Steinway & Sons, pictured on the previous page, to an austere, white sycamore upright with ebony inlays built a decade ago by the English furniture designer David Linley. Carvings, paintings, gilding, marquetry, ormolu and exotic wood veneers are hallmarks of the art-case piano; they can even turn up all together on a single instrument. Indeed, a piano case can flaunt almost anything, from centipede-style legs to built-in brass candlesticks to a coat of pink lacquer. 
 "People usually don't know exactly what they're looking for when they shop for an art-case piano," says Leopold Holder, whose company, The New York Piano Center, in Manhattan, rebuilds pianos. "They're just looking for character."
 Character is an option because, unlike a trombone or a flute, a piano is also a piece of furniture.
 "Part of the challenge of designing keyboard instruments lies in attractively disguising their mechanical nature," explains Laurence Libin, the Frederick P. Rose curator of musical instruments at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
 Decorative pianos stretch back almost to Bartolomeo Cristofori's invention of the pianoforte in the early 18th century in Florence. Among the oldest decorative survivors is a charming instrument from 1767 finished in tulipwood veneer and embellished with painted flowers and a gilt-gesso scrolling border. It is on permanent exhibit at the Shrine to Music Museum, on the campus of the University of South Dakota in Vermillion.
 The art-case piano's heyday coincided with the instrument's immense popularity in both Europe and the United States in the second half of the 19th century. As sweetly carved pianos became a staple of the well-dressed Victorian parlor, wealthy people demanded splendiferous pianos, custom made for their homes. Between the 1860's and 1930's, top European piano makers, including Broadwood, Erard, Pleyel, Bluthner, Bosendorfer and Bechstein, commissioned designs and adornments from artists like the Pre-Raphaelite painter Edward Burne-Jones and well-known European cabinetmakers -- Louis Marjorelle, Francois Linke and Emile-Jacques Ruhlmann. Demand was so great that Steinway established its own art department, in Astoria, Queens, at the turn of the century, replete with carvers, artists and gilders.
 Art-case pianos had no trouble showing off the prevailing fashions of their times, whether they were Gothic, Renaissance and Empire motifs or fanciful interpretations of Louis XIV, XV and XVI, Art Nouveau and Art Deco designs. Though upright pianos were often decorated, the more desirable grand piano presented a larger, flashier surface for ornamentation.
 "At a time when the piano was the entertainment center of the home, these pianos were for people who wanted to show off," says William Garlick, a Blue Point, N.Y.-based keyboard consultant for antique and contempory instruments.
 But the Depression squelched most demand for art-case pianos. By the end of World War II, the art-case piano market was dead, killed off by rising costs, a lack of skilled craftsmen and the inherent modernity of the unadorned black grand. "In the 1960's and 70's, art-case pianos were so anachronistic, people got rid of the carved legs," Garlick recalls.
 Nowadays, majestic carved legs are a significant part of the antique art-case piano's attraction. Behind the decorative piano's renewed desirability lie the current appeal of unique objects and a flourishing economy.
 "Most of my clients with art-case pianos want something you won't see everywhere," says Anthony Ingrao, a New York interior designer who recently acquired a 1920's Chinese-Chippendale-style piano trimmed in a Greek key pattern for a client. "You can build a room around a great piano," he adds.
 It certainly can cost a mere fortune to buy a quality art-case piano. In 1980, a dazzling art-case Steinway grand from 1883, displaying complex carvings, marquetry, gilding and romantic Pre-Raphaelite paintings by the high-Victorian British artist Lawrence Alma-Tadema, sold at Sotheby's for $390,000, an auction record for a musical instrument at that time. Fine rebuilt instruments in decorative cases, dating from 1890 to 1930, start at around $15,000 by a lesser-known maker, lower than the cost of a new quality piano -- a Steinway grand, for example, can sell from $29,000 to $75,000, depending on the size. But elaborate models in pristine condition with gilding, carving, marquetry and exquisite veneers easily top $100,000, as do most new art-case pianos.
 Costs are high because art-case instruments, whether antique or new, require special attention. With 12,000 moving parts, pianos consist of three basic elements: keyboard (hammers and action parts), interior (sounding board, strings, tuning pins) and case. Art-case pianos demand the same attention to keyboard and interior as any piano, but to restore or build a case requires precise, labor-intensive cabinetmaking skills like French polishing, a technique of rubbing on shellac, and gilding. At Klavierhaus, a bustling piano workshop and showroom near Lincoln Center, the owners and brothers Gabor and Sujatri Reisinger recently inspected an elaborate but worn Steinway grand from 1904 in need of restoration. The marquetry case, with eight types of woods, required stripping, repairs and a French polish; the legs had to be reinforced, and the swirling brass moldings would be sent to France for regilding. "These pianos help keep Old World craftsmanship from dying out," Gabor Reisinger says.
 Despite the allure of old pianos, new art-case ones are appearing, albeit gradually. This fall, Ibach, a German piano maker, is introducing a startling but graceful rectangular piano with a glistening black case balanced on three brushed-steel legs designed by the architect Richard Meier and costing about $116,000. Bosendorfer already offers a boldly sculptured red and black piano with 24-karat gold inlays and solid-brass legs designed in 1990 by the Austrian architect Hans Hollein. It is available for $125,000. (The mechanized, push-button lid suspends in the air when opened.) And the American art-furniture designer Wendell Castle has created five art-case pianos, including a splendid concert grand constructed with Steinway in 1994 for the Toledo Museum of Art in Ohio. The piano's pale curly maple veneer case seems to float atop two enormous curved supports in dark cocobolo veneer. Of the other pianos, only one, a sycamore upright, is for sale -- $115,000 at Maximiliaan's House of Grand Pianos in New York.
 In 1988, Steinway commissioned Castle to design its 500,000th piano, an architectural concert grand with the names of more than 800 professional pianists who use Steinways inlaid like ribbons on the case. (The piano is on exhibit through the 15th of this month at Steinway Hall in New York and will then tour Japan.) This fall, to celebrate the 200th birthday of its founder, Henry E. Steinway, the company unveiled a new art-case piano based on a model from the years when Joseph Burr Tiffany, a member of the family that opened Tiffany & Company, headed Steinway's art department.
 Maximiliaan Rutten is a dealer whose jam-packed showroom, in the New York Design Center, is an art-case piano wonderland. He describes his typical client as "wealthy and sophisticated, often young professionals from Wall Street, interested in a good investment and a work of art." Interior designers visit frequently, professional musicians less so. "They're more interested in the musical than the decorative part," Rutten says. "And only a few professional pianists can afford more than one instrument."
 A new generation of piano designers is hoping to transport the craft -- and its devotees -- into the 21st century. Though known for his use of the piano curve in his architecture, Richard Meier abandoned it when he did the design for Ibach. "I love the shape of the traditional piano, but I wanted to push the design in a different direction," he says. His solution: a piano that is "more three-dimensional, with the bottom shaped, as well as the sides and top."
 John Diebboll, an architect in New York, has designed more than 60 pianos. Though all exist only on paper, he hopes to have one built soon. Witty and unexpected, his designs feature a piano shaped like a pup tent, a piano inspired by the Chrysler Building and a Murphy bed piano that folds out of a wall. His latest series of designs, on view Oct. 15 through the end of the year at Klavierhaus, honor pianists and include a jazzy black piano with red and white keys, intended for Thelonious Monk, and one with legs carved to look like wolves for the classical pianist Helene Grimaud. "Not much has been done with piano design for years," Diebboll says. "But you quickly realize the possibilities are endless."

PUB-DATE: October 5, 1997

SECTION: Section 7; Page 26; Column 2; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1080 words

HEADLINE: What the Left Left Behind

BYLINE: By Peter Beinart; Peter Beinart is a senior editor of The New Republic.

 BODY:

THE FUTURE ONCE
 HAPPENED HERE
 New York, D.C., L.A., and the Fate
 of America's Big Cities.
 By Fred Siegel.
 260 pp. New York:
 The Free Press. $24. 
 For close to a generation now, since the defeat and discrediting of pre-civil-rights-era mayors like Sam Yorty of Los Angeles and Frank Rizzo of Philadelphia, urban politics have been the province of the American left. The absence of ideological competition in the nation's biggest cities has played an important, and pernicious, role in shaping both contemporary liberalism and contemporary conservatism. It has allowed liberals to ignore mounting evidence that their large, generally unaccountable social service bureaucracies have not improved the lives of the poor. And it has allowed conservatives, unfettered by actually having to govern cities, to turn them into a running metaphor for the cultural changes that their rural and suburban constituents fear.
In this environment, "The Future Once Happened Here" is a subversive book. In tracing the fate of New York, Washington and Los Angeles in recent decades, Fred Siegel, a professor of history at the Cooper Union for the Arts and Sciences, bitterly attacks the left-liberal consensus that has to varying degrees dominated the governance of each of the cities he examines. But he does so as a dedicated urbanite who, unlike many on the right, is not only at home with cultural diversity but also deeply attached to it. This perspective is typical of the vibrant and influential group of thinkers affiliated with the Manhattan Institute's publication City Journal, which Siegel once edited. And it is a view that has significantly influenced iconoclastic mayors like Stephen Goldsmith of Indianapolis, John Norquist of Milwaukee and Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York, whom Siegel once advised. It is, moreover, a perspective that both parties are having great difficulty coming to grips with.
Siegel argues that in the mid- to late-1960's America's cities were traumatized by riots and the threat of riots on the part of their alienated African-American residents. The liberal elites then coming into power -- defeating conservative white ethnics and ushering in the era of liberal domination of the cities -- responded, in Siegel's view, by taking an enormous gamble. Convinced that black poverty justified black anger, they abandoned the stern principles of personal responsibility that their predecessors had advocated and instead created a vast social welfare system premised on the idea that dependence on government is healthy. Siegel calls this "the riot ideology," and he blames it for two phenomena that have bedeviled cities ever since: a crime explosion that he terms "a rolling riot" and a huge government expansion that drove taxes so high that they chased out private industry and led to fiscal disaster.
Siegel's central argument is provocative, but it stretches at times awkwardly over the particularities of his three very different locales. More than half the book is about New York, and the argument seems tailor-made for that city, particularly for the mayoralty of John Lindsay. It is less convincing when applied to Washington and Los Angeles.
Siegel contends, for instance, that Mayor Marion Barry was allowed to ruin Washington because he skillfully used the threat of riots to secure white liberal support. Yet white liberalism matters much less in Washington, with its largely intra-black politics, than it does in New York. And a thesis based on white guilt doesn't offer much guidance as to why Barry won re-election in 1994, when he had no white support whatsoever, and when the memory of the 1968 riots in the District of Columbia was more than 25 years old. The riot ideology doesn't entirely fit Los Angeles, either, since its government never constructed a welfare bureaucracy as huge or as dysfunctional as New York's or Washington's. This is not to say that Siegel's chapters on Washington and Los Angeles are not valuable -- he evocatively captures the political cultures of both. But these narratives pretty much stand alone, and his occasional efforts to link them to categories and explanations imported from New York feel labored.
Even with regard to New York, however, the riot ideology thesis leaves a central question unanswered. Siegel suggests that the cities veered off track when they stopped trying to apply to African-American migrants from the South the moral standards used to assimilate earlier waves of poor immigrants. But he stops short of saying that the earlier models would have worked, given the much more profound oppression that American blacks faced. Indeed, he admits that New York's New Deal politics -- which proved so successful in assimilating Italians, Irish and Jews -- largely ignored the plight of the city's black population. Nor does he grapple with the widespread perception that black politics turned nationalist and sometimes violent in the 1960's in part because the Southern-oriented civil rights movement, with its integrationist norms, had few answers for the economic problems of blacks in the urban North.
Still, Siegel's book is a useful addition to the contemporary debate about the causes of urban decline. "The Future Once Happened Here" will unsettle liberals, who in recent years have stressed economic explanations for the decline of the inner cities, conveniently ignoring liberal policies that may have undermined the attractiveness of work and driven out private business. At the same time, because Siegel comes to his critiques from his urbanism, he diverges sharply from ideologically conservative positions. He criticizes the 1996 welfare bill for its attack on immigrant rights, and he mocks Newt Gingrich for depicting New Yorkers as dependent on the Federal Government when Gingrich's own Congressional district, like many similar districts throughout the South, receives enormous Federal subsidies.
Today, candidates and thinkers who advocate a new culturally open yet morally and fiscally disciplined politics are making cities what they have not been for decades -- competitive and dynamic realms of American governance. One can see this spirit today in New York, both in Rudolph Giuliani's reassertion of moral standards over the city's public spaces and in Ruth Messinger's call to make city garbage collectors compete with private companies. To this more hopeful story "The Future Once Happened Here" provides an impassioned prologue.

HEADLINE: Europe on the Shoals

BYLINE: By Walter Russell Mead; Walter Russell Mead is the president's fellow at the World Policy Institute at the New School in New York City.

 BODY:

Europe Adrift
 By John Newhouse.
 339 pp. New York:
 Pantheon Books. $27.50. 
 Europe is in worse trouble than you think, says John Newhouse in "Europe Adrift." After finishing this comprehensive and extremely well-informed book, most of his readers are likely to agree.
The analysis by Newhouse, a guest scholar at the Brookings Institution and a consultant to the State Department, goes beyond the conventional catalogue of woe. The problem is not just with unemployment, the welfare state or the Balkans. For Newhouse, the rot in Europe starts at the core, with a lack of leadership in Bonn, Paris and London. And the author, one of the most seasoned and well-connected American observers of the European scene, sees little hope for change.
Start with not-so-united Germany, which has yet to come to terms with new international choices. Before unification, West Germany's foreign policy was simple and clear. Its ties to the United States both reassured its European partners and provided defense against the Soviet Union. Otherwise, its ties to France were the anchor of its foreign policy. By accepting France's political pre-eminence in the European Union -- and agreeing to pay a disproportionate share of the bills -- West Germany reintegrated itself into respectable Western society and enjoyed extraordinary prosperity as a peaceful and contented country.
Now Germany is torn. Deeply worried about the potential for instability and poverty among its former Warsaw Pact neighbors to the east, Germany is a prime mover in seeking the eastward extension of both NATO and the European Union. This sets off alarm bells in Paris, where German hegemony in Europe has, in some circles, replaced United States hegemony as the perceived key threat to France's precarious place in the international major leagues.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl, currently enmeshed in a series of political problems that some observers have labeled Kanzlerdammerung, or Twilight of the Chancellor, sees his historical mission as cementing Germany into a strong political union with its neighbors before European politics become renationalized. The ambitious plan to create a single European currency is part of Kohl's vision; so too were his plans, rejected by both Britain and France, for the construction of a European political union along federal lines.
Flaws in the project for a single currency and Anglo-French resistance to a federal structure for Europe mean, Newhouse believes, that Europe will miss the historic chance to bind Germany into a multinational structure. Kohl, the last German Chancellor out of the old Bonn Republic mold, will be succeeded by other, younger figures who may not share his visceral commitment to Europe.
Newhouse is bitterly critical of French and especially British leadership since German unification. Their failure to respond positively to Kohl's proposals for federalization, he fears, means that Europe will drift back toward its bad old nationalistic ways. This may be too harsh. Kohl has asked his partners to choose between a "European Germany" and a "German Europe," and this, undoubtedly, is how he sees the possibilities for the future. But is life really so simple? Kohl's ambitious program for political union -- shaped by German interests, priorities and timetables -- may not be so much an alternative to German domination of Europe as a form of it.
But if Newhouse's analysis of British and French policy toward Germany is slightly too dark, his recognition of the limits on Europe's ability to address its other major problems is right on the money. Europe does not face classic threats to its security today. No Napoleon or Hitler plots its conquest; no armed, barbarian hordes cluster at the frontiers. Yet Europe remains profoundly insecure. Its southern rim is one long arc of crisis, from instability in the Caucasus to the simmering feud between Greece and Turkey to the still-explosive situation in the Balkans to demographic explosion in North Africa and Islamic uprising in Algeria. Eastward, what some call "Weimar Russia" remains a troubling enigma, and the present members of the European Union are very far from agreement on how to expand to include even the most promising of the Central European republics.
Faced with this sea of troubles, Europe has essentially thrown up its hands in despair. Contemporary European leaders lack the vision and historical imagination to tackle problems like the poverty and political violence in North Africa. Powerful domestic forces in both Greece and Turkey prevent those two countries from compromising their bitter differences -- and meanwhile the rise of Islamic fundamentalism and the costly war against Kurdish separatists slowly undermine the foundations of the Turkish state.
Grim as all this sounds, Newhouse doesn't predict imminent catastrophe. Europe may be drifting, but at the moment it isn't drifting toward disaster the way it did, say, during the decades before the last two world wars. Initially, at least, the cost of Europe's drift will be measured in opportunities lost and problems not solved. Only later, when the unattended troubles of North Africa, Russia, Turkey and the Balkans have festered for a while, and when Europe's internal politics have been poisoned by prolonged economic stagnation and the re-emergence of national rivalries, will the true cost of Europe's indecisiveness be known.
Let's hope that Newhouse is too pessimistic. Europe has muddled through before. English-speaking observers have long predicted a breakdown in the French-German partnership at the heart of contemporary affairs. A European monetary union may not look promising, but it doesn't have to end in shambles. And even if it does, Europe has overcome much worse in the past. It is a resilient place, and after surviving Genghis Khan, the Black Death and modern totalitarianism, it may even be able to endure Chancellor Kohl and President Jacques Chirac.
Still, "Europe Adrift" is a timely and important warning. One hopes that its message will be studied and heeded by national leaders and opinion makers on both sides of the Atlantic. Bad as they are, none of Europe's problems are completely past fixing, and Newhouse's always thoughtful and often brilliant descriptions of the issues will serve as a very useful guide for those looking for answers.

HEADLINE: Books in Brief: Nonfiction;
Feats of Clay

BYLINE: By Eric P. Nash

 BODY:
Above the heads of New York City dwellers lies a mythic realm peopled by pensive gargoyles, mossbacked mermen, dashing Mercurys and enough animal characters -- foxes, flying fish, sea horses and salamanders -- to populate a Japanese folk tale. Susan Tunick's TERRA-COTTA SKYLINE: New York's Architectural Ornament (Princeton Architectural Press, $45) is a first-rate Baedeker to the astonishing variety of terra cotta decoration in the city. Terra cotta (literally "burnt earth") is kiln-baked clay, a light, economical architectural material capable of holding high definition and rainbow hues. The rise of the terra cotta industry and the New York skyscraper are inseparable: the facade of Daniel Burnham's Flatiron Building of 1901-3 featured richly modeled masks of Greek women, and Cass Gilbert's Woolworth Building of 1910-13 was clad in cream-colored terra cotta in a flamboyant Gothic style. The use of terra cotta reached its acme in 1930-31 with the sea-colored McGraw-Hill Building (now badly chipping); fell into a serious slump with post-World War II glass and steel buildings, and is now making a small return with the restoration of such clay classics as City Center. Some technical chapters on how terra cotta is actually produced may make the average reader's eyes glaze over, but the enthusiasm of Tunick -- who is also president of the Friends of Terra Cotta, a preservation society -- for her subject is contagious. Peter Mauss's photographs are breathtaking. Eric P. Nash

HEADLINE: CHOICE TABLES;
In Seattle, the Ingredients Shine

BYLINE: By MELISSA A. TRAINER; MELISSA A. TRAINER is a food writer living in Seattle.

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to food, Seattleites are a dedicated lot. Although they expect to find the bounty of the Pacific Northwest at the city's markets, they often go so far as to grow, gather and catch many of their own ingredients.
Green thumbs tend organic vegetable gardens, berry patches and fruit trees in urban backyards. When the fish are running, hardy souls grab their rods and head for the water, and when berries are dangling from vines and wild mushrooms are poking through mossy forest floors, outdoor enthusiasts head for the hills with baskets in hand. 
 With such savvy food lovers around, it's no surprise that Seattle is a top-notch food town. Local chefs celebrate the region's abundance, using choice pickings in both traditional and serendipitous ways. King salmon is as likely to be turned into gravlax as chowder. Fresh edible flowers can be found in salads and on sorbets.
Some of the heaviest hitters on the country's culinary scene are analyzing the local market and setting up shop. Last December, Roy Yamaguchi, whose original Roy's is one of Honolulu's most popular restaurants, opened Roy's at the Westin. In January, Wolfgang Puck came to town with his wife, Barbara Lazaroff, and opened ObaChine in the downtown Meridian shopping and restaurant complex.
In mid-September, Mr. Puck launched Wolfgang Puck Cafe in the recently built Harbor Steps residential and commercial complex. In a telephone interview, Mr. Puck explained why. "Seattle is a small, but still very good market." he said. "For me as a cook, it's especially good because you have so many fine ingredients in the Northwest."
Here is a look at a few of Seattle's newer places and its tried-and-true favorites:
 
Flying Fish
Situated in Belltown, one of Seattle's hottest neighborhoods, Flying Fish has been drawing an eclectic crowd since its doors flew open two years ago. As the restaurant's name suggests, the focus is on seafood. The cooking of the proprietor and chef, Christine Keff, shows a strong Asian influence.
For a first course we chose the oyster sampler, which consisted of six Canadian oysters on the half shell, three Evening Coves from Vancouver Island and three Malpeques from Prince Edward Island. Both the raw oysters were well complemented by a mignonette ice.
The crabcake with the lemongrass mayonnaise was a very modern interpretation of an old favorite. The cake was crispy and chock-full of Dungeness crab. The lemongrass condiment was a nice alternative to the more typical accompaniments of tartar sauce and lemon wedge.
We went on to try the fried Alaskan razor clams, which were crisp and extraordinarily large, a fine rendition of what can so often be a greasy disaster. To sip while savoring, we chose Chateau Ste. Michelle "Cold Creek" Chardonnay 1995 from the Columbia Valley of Washington ($50).
For an entree, my husband, Christopher, opted for one of Ms. Keff's signature dishes -- the whole fried snapper served with spring roll wrappers, a pineapple-anchovy sauce, and mounds of mint, basil, coriander and bean sprouts. The traditional Vietnamese dish is an eye-catcher, and heads turned as our waitress presented it.
Unfortunately, the snapper had stayed in the fryer a bit too long, and was a tad dry when mixed with the herbs and wrapped in the spring rolls. My Thai curry soft-shell crabs with green papaya salad and rice cakes hit home, however. The curry was well balanced, and the Chesapeake Bay soft-shells were pleasingly petite, crispy outside, and succulent inside.
To wrap things up we chose a nectarine crumble with vanilla bean ice cream and a bowl of marionberry and raspberry sorbets. The crumble was satisfying and flavorful but a bit too heavy. The latter, which highlighted two of the Northwest's many fat and juicy berries, was right on the money.
 
Roy's
Roy's in Seattle is one of the 12 restaurants opened by Roy Yamaguchi around the world. The original opened in Honolulu in 1988, and since then this chef has expanded to Tokyo, Guam, and the Philippines, to name a few destinations.
Most of the dishes globe-trot between Asia and Europe and incorporate culinary techniques from each. The restaurant wins high marks for serving eye-catching and attractive combinations. Unfortunately, it sometimes falls short when it comes to serving well-flavored and properly prepared dishes.
While waiting briefly for our table one busy Saturday night, we admired the bright nautically inspired mural and dark hardwood floors at the entrance, which lent a warm and cheerful atmosphere. After being seated in one of the restaurant's intimate rooms, we ordered appetizers of crispy seafood potstickers with mango sauce and blackened ahi with hot mustard sauce. The potstickers, artfully arranged on top of the sweet sauce, were a bit too fishy for my taste and too chewy. The tuna was more successful, seared and still raw on the inside, and the accompanying sauce an incendiary complement.
Curious about the imu oven pizzas, we inquired. Our waiter explained that in Hawaii an imu is an underground oven. Admitting that it would be hard to replicate an authentic imu in a downtown Seattle hotel, he explained that the restaurant bakes its pizzas in a wood-fired oven. Undeterred, we ordered a grilled vegetable and feta rendition; unfortunately, the crust was not crisp and the vegetables were flat and rather soggy.
My husband's main course of duck with mashed potatoes and a star anise cranberry sauce was quite good. The tender slices of duck were fanned over a creamy potato puree, with the spicy tart sauce balancing some of the duck's richness.
My sesame-seared halibut with black bean sauce, topped with a mound of deep fried noodles, was less appealing. The fish was overcooked, and the black bean sauce so salty that I suspect someone in the kitchen incorporated the fermented beans into the sauce without rinsing them first.
For dessert we skipped Roy's melting hot chocolate souffle and opted for the Mount Kilauea. Consisting of three layers of ice cream and garnished with spicy dragon cookies, the dessert was a serendipitous take on baked Alaska.
 
Ray's Boathouse
Whenever we want to enjoy well-prepared Northwest seafood in a relaxing setting, we head to Ray's Boathouse. Smack on Puget Sound and boasting views of the Olympic Mountains, the restaurant looks out on fishing vessels, sailboats and kayakers cruising by. Although the menu features some Asian-inspired dishes, such as black cod in sake kasu, most of the food prepared by Charles Ramseyer, the executive chef, is grounded in European techniques and combinations.
We started with Nova smoked southeast Alaskan king salmon and Ray's Northwest clam chowder. Presented in three large heaps and accompanied by horseradish cream, capers, red onion and pumpernickel, the rich buttery salmon was a knockout. The clam chowder, containing small diced new potatoes, onion, and carrots, was rich and wonderfully clammy -- proof that sometimes the simplest dishes can be the most elegant.
My main course of halibut cheeks with brandy prawn sauce, wild rice and haricots verts was also very good. The chubby cheeks were moist and tender, and the sauce was velvety and slightly pink from the small tender prawns cooked in it. Christopher's pan-seared Fraser River sockeye salmon with a mushroom fume blanc was cooked rare, rich with the aromatic medley of chanterelles and shiitakes.
For dessert the chocolate raspberry torte was well executed, and the warm blueberry crisp with hazelnut ice cream a hands-down winner.
 
Rover's
About 10 minutes from downtown, Rover's offers contemporary French fare in the intimate charm of a clapboard house. The chef and owner, Thierry Rautureau, hails from the Muscadet region of France and has been pleasing Seattleites and visitors for more than 10 years. Relying on seasonal Northwest ingredients, Mr. Rautureau creates an a la carte menu daily as well as carefully developing vegetarian and nonvegetarian five- and eight-course tasting menus.
After hearing about the tasting menus and being told by our waiter that the chef was happy to mix and match according to a customer's specifications, my husband chose the eight-course tasting menu ($89.50), while I ordered a la carte.
Although our waiter offered to choose appropriate wines for each course, we simply opted for a bottle of Cameron Willamette Valley Chardonnay Vintage Reserve 1994 ($52).
To some people, an eight-course meal might seem excessive. Thankfully, Mr. Rautureau presents each course in very sensible portions and understands that such a meal should unwind at a comfortable pace.
The first course was a soft scrambled egg, its shell topped with lime-scented cream and osetra caviar. The gently cooked egg was delightfully creamy, the caviar a luxurious addition. The second course consisted of a smoked salmon tian with a cucumber salad, the crunchy refreshing slices of cucumber a pleasant contrast to the cold-smoked fish.
In the three courses that followed before our entrees, Mr. Rautureau continued to incorporate Northwest favorites, such as halibut, morels and diver-harvested scallops, in a classic and tasteful manner. Before the main course arrived, we were presented with sorbets to cleanse our palates. We found my husband's spice-infused pinot noir sorbet a bit too clovey and autumnal; my rose-scented geranium sorbet was lightly flavored and very refreshing.
The halibut with pomme mousseline and morels was our favorite. Four hefty medallions topped a silky smooth and flavorful potato puree. Tucked between the fish and puree was a decadent saute of morels. The venison with huckleberry sauce was less successful. Although the huckleberries were a lovely treat, the venison was a bit tough and the dish rather heavy for a summer evening.
For dessert the huckleberry clafouti with vanilla ice cream was a nice Northwest interpretation of a homey French favorite, the pancake-like pastry topped with a cheerful Johnny-jump-up and permeated with berry flavor. My husband's peach and apricot soup was accompanied by a fallen chocolate souffle and garnished with intensely-flavored red and white fraises des bois. The miniature berries, plucked from wild plants that are being farm-raised in nearby Mount Vernon, were simply incredible.
 
Shiro's Sushi Bar And Restaurant
Seattle's sushi lovers beat a path to Shiro's Sushi Bar and Restaurant. Shiro Kashiba, the chef and owner, buys only the freshest seafood and presents it artfully to his dedicated clientele.
The modest-sized spot in Belltown can fill up quickly. We arrived at 5:30 one Monday evening and were lucky enough to snag the last two seats at the sushi bar. Although we would have been served just as graciously at one of the restaurant's 17 tables, the sushi bar is the place to sit at Shiro's.
After ordering a round of Sapporo beer, we admired the glistening local albacore tuna, smelt and live geoducks in the case before us while Mr. Kashiba joked with everyone at the counter and thoroughly answered questions. He also speculated on when the eagerly awaited matsutake, an exorbitantly expensive and coveted wild mushroom found in forests of both the Pacific Northwest and Japan, would be arriving. (It is in now and will probably be available until mid-October.)
Feeling welcome and relaxed, we started with smelt umeshiso age. Local smelt was laid out, spread with sour plum sauce and topped with a shiso leaf before being rolled up, deep fried and sliced. It was spectacular and so good we ordered another round. Soon there was a run on smelt and Mr. Kashiba, to his dismay, was sold out for the night.
We then ordered sunomono, a traditional marinated seafood salad. The artfully arranged salad of steamed soft clams, octopus and shrimp with pickled cucumbers and seaweed salad appealed to the eye as much as the palate. The still-moving geoducks were next; when sauteed with quartered mushrooms they were tender, buttery and sweet.
Unable to resist the soft-shell crabs, we asked for a spider roll. A piece of nori was laid out and spread with rice, flying fish roe, cucumber and radish sprouts; then the deep-fried crab was arranged with its claws hanging off either end. When rolled up, sliced, and served with claws in the air, the presentation resembled a tarantula.
Before we called it quits, our congenial sushi-bar neighbors told us to order the sour plum hand roll. We heeded their advice, and were happy we did. Sour, salty, and sweet, the roll -- which had sour plum sauce, shiso leaves, rice and vegetables wrapped in seaweed -- was delightfully digestible and satisfying. With that and a cup of green tea, we were set.
 
A comfortable new cafe in the Puck empire
 Last month Wolfgang Puck embarked on his second Seattle venture, the Wolfgang Puck Cafe. (The first was ObaChine, opened in January.) One of 13 around the country, the cafe is across from the Seattle Art Museum in the heart of downtown. Offering everything from Mr. Puck's wood-fired oven pizzas to a small but carefully selected array of oysters, the restaurant is already drawing a stream of customers. The casual atmosphere and friendly staff make the cafe as comfortable for moms carting tots as for well-heeled executives seeking a high-quality nosh.
When my husband and I headed to the cafe for a midweek lunch, we brought our toughest critic, our 2-year-old daughter. We were greeted with smiles, offered a high chair and presented with a simple children's menu. We quickly chose a cheese pizza for Carolyn before perusing our own menus.
We started with the smoked duck quesadilla ($6.95). Drizzled with guajillo chili sauce and sour cream, it was quite appealing. My prosciutto pizza with pesto, Roma tomatoes, goat cheese and roasted red peppers ($9.95) was irresistible. My husband's smoked turkey sandwich on herbed focaccia ($8.75) was moist and flavorful, and the generous but not gargantuan serving made it a good midday choice.
While we had lunch, our waitress checked in from time to time and our daughter polished off her pizza without a bit of coaxing from us. For those reasons alone, we'd head back to the Wolfgang Puck Cafe in a heartbeat. M.A.T.
 
Bill of fare
Thanks to a buzzing restaurant scene and the region's thriving economy, Seattleites are dining out in droves. The flip side of such excitement is that it can often be hard to get a reservation on short notice.
While scheduling dinners at many of the restaurants included here, I called a couple of days in advance and was often told the only available spots were at 5 or 9:30. I soon learned that if I wanted to eat at the civilized hour of 7:30, I had to make reservations up to a week in advance. I suggest visitors do the same.
Flying Fish, 2234 First Avenue; (206) 728-8595. Dinner daily. Three-course dinner for two with a bottle of wine, $75. Smoking at the bar only.
Roy's, 1900 Fifth Avenue, Seattle; (206) 256-7697. Breakfast, lunch and dinner daily. No smoking. Three-course dinner for two with a bottle of wine, about $85.
Ray's Boathouse, 6049 Seaview Avenue, N.W.; (206) 789-3770. Lunch and dinner daily. Three-course dinner for two with a bottle of wine, $85. No smoking in the main dining room, only in the upstairs lounge.
Rover's, 2808 East Madison; (206) 325-7442. Dinner Tuesday through Saturday. Five-course dinner for two with a bottle of wine, $150. No smoking.
Shiro's Sushi Bar and Restaurant, 2401 Second Avenue; (206) 443-9844. Lunch Monday through Friday, dinner Monday through Saturday. Reservations accepted for tables but not for the sushi bar. There is a small separate smoking section. Smelt umeshiso age, $5.50; sunomono (seafood salad), $6; sauteed geoducks, $6.50; soft-shell crab spider roll, $10; sour-plum hand roll, $3.50.
Wolfgang Puck Cafe, 1225 First Avenue; (206) 621-9653. Lunch and dinner daily. Pizzas, $7.95 to $14.50 (for smoked salmon). Pastas, $8.95 to $13.95. Wine by the glass, $4.50 and up. M.A.T.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 68; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 574 words

HEADLINE: The No-Complaints Generation

BYLINE: By Ian Fisher

 BODY:
"I have a dream," says julie reisman, 18, a freshman at the University of Wisconsin in Madison. "To design golf clubs. I know that sounds stupid."
Not really, but Reisman is still embarrassed, as if drivers and irons were a letdown to the grandly seditious tradition of the American undergrad. Her goals may be square, but her frankness is refreshing. For most students in the 90's, rebelliousness, if it exists at all, has been largely a style statement. For Reisman it isn't even that, and judging by a recent visit to Wisconsin's sprawling, 40,000-student main campus, she's not unique in this. Today's freshmen no longer see the point of even striking the pose. 
 In fact, at a school with a famous legacy of activism, members of the class of 2001 look a lot like Chelsea Clinton, the smiling, well-behaved First Daughter who packed off to Stanford this fall. They're smart, ambitious and uncomplaining. Like Chelsea, they actually seem to like their dysfunctional parents. Unlike her, they don't know (or care) much about politics, and their main civic passions are local: jobs, families and community. Distinct from students earlier in the decade, they are less worried about the economy than about their ability to measure up to its seemingly perpetual boom. "The American ideal isn't just about living on a farm with animals," says Shannon Boden, a freshman from Appleton, Wis. "It's also about living in a $350,000 house. There's more pressure to make the six-figure salary."
This isn't to say that today's freshmen are mindless materialists -- they seem overwhelmed by the complexity of problems, like race or the environment, passed down by parents who won a round of more clearly defined battles. They're unimpressed with rebellion, in part because they're smart enough to know that it's been fully co-opted. "You can't shock anyone anymore," says Leah Olson, Boden's high-school friend.
Indeed, the entire idea of novelty has shifted: freshmen in 1997 draw on the last 40 years of popular culture to create a comfortable mix that no one bothers to call new. Hair can be short, long or gone. Most people dress somewhere along the grunge-punk-hippie continuum -- Doc Martens one day, Birkenstocks the next. Like students of every era, they say they want self-discovery while getting a good education. They want a fair amount of fun. (Madison freshmen were thrilled when The Princeton Review named their campus the nation's No. 2 party school.) Later on, they want a family -- one that doesn't start too early, but lasts.
Consider, as a random-but-typical snapshot of freshmen 1997, Adam Butler and Jeff Angarola, roommates in a huge coed dormitory called Sellery Hall, which is filled with packs of baffled 18-year-olds. They are friends from a suburban Chicago high school. Their room is jammed with every convenience: two refrigerators, a microwave, a blender, a stereo. They play in an alternative band, which once would have meant that they were alienated. But they're business majors. When asked about their goals, they talk bluntly about personal success.
Is that all there is? No. Butler talks about succeeding with "the right attitude, to live well and help people out." But success is very important, and for Butler it constitutes a sort of rebellion -- against the old "slacker" stereotype that follows late-90's kids like an unwelcome fog. "You prove people wrong," he says. "You succeed in their faces."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 87; Column 1; Magazine Desk
