HEADLINE: Food;
Cod Is Good

BYLINE: By Molly O'Neill

 BODY:
As cod goes, so go the fortunes of the working fisherman. This oft-heard sentiment is as true today as it was in 1784, when Massachusetts hung a carving of the cod in its Statehouse, in grateful appreciation.
The beef of the sea, as cod is sometimes called, was the source of New England's early wealth. It was also the first fish to be traded globally -- the Basques having perfected salt cod in the Middle Ages -- and even today, the economy of Iceland still depends on it. 
 But most of cod's larger spawning grounds -- off New England, Newfoundland and in the North Sea -- have been depleted, says Mark Kurlansky, author of "Cod: A Biography of the Fish That Changed the World." Only Iceland and Norway have managed (through severe restrictions and restocking) to maintain a stable catch, while Russia has been overfishing one of the last rich repositories -- the Barents Sea -- like crazy.
Kurlansky, who worked as a commerical fisherman in New England to put himself through college, knows of the dwindling supply firsthand. Cod, he says emphatically, is in danger. And while statistics in America, as well as in Europe, reflect this, nothing tells the tale quite as well as cod's shifting social position.
From the 11th century until the 1950's, cod was poor people's food. So abundant was the supply that cod was considered common. Salt cod had been a staple for both the French and British Navies; it was the food of slavery, and the Catholic peasant's Friday dinner.
Suddenly, however, cod is chic. Salt cod in particular has become the darling of fine restaurants in Paris and New York, where it fits right in with the fashion toward homey, old-fashioned food. Not that any cook would have reason to complain about this development, since cod, above all else, is accommodating and versatile. No culture lacks a cod repertory, and it is difficult if not impossible to maim or render inedible this firm white fish with the large, snowy flake.
If you can cook salt cod, you can cook Caribbean and Mediterranean food. If you can perfectly broil or braise a fresh cod, you can congratulate yourself on having mastered the basic tactile instincts that separate the recipe-dependent cook from the real McCoy.
Neverthless, as Kurlansky is sad to report, the array of delicious cod dishes now appearing -- and commanding steep prices in trendy restaurants -- has poignant implications. Fancy cod is emblematic of a fading feast.
 
Brandade Tante Colette
 
 1 pound boneless, skinless salt cod
 2 medium baking potatoes, peeled, cut in 2-inch chunks, boiled until tender and mashed with a fork
 6 medium garlic cloves, minced
 1/2 cup extra-virgin olive oil
 1/2 cup heavy cream
 1 teaspoon kosher salt
 Freshly ground black pepper to taste.
1. The day before serving, cover the cod with water, changing water every few hours. Soak overnight. Drain the cod, cut in 4-inch chunks and cover with fresh water in a large saucepan.
2. Bring almost to a boil and remove from heat. Cover and let stand 15 minutes, then drain. When the fish is cool enough to handle, use a knife to scrape away any fatty skin, and remove any bones.
3. Place the cod, potatoes and garlic in a food processor and pulse to combine. Continue pulsing, off and on, while adding the oil in a steady stream. When the oil is completely incorporated, add the heavy cream in the same way. The idea is to incorporate the oil and cream so the mixture keeps some of its texture. Season and serve with garlic toast.
Yield: 8 appetizers.
 
Joann Coats's Codfish Balls
 (adapted from "THE Provincetown Portuguese Cookbook, " by Mary-Jo Avellar)
 
 1 pound boneless, skinless salt cod
 3 medium baking potatoes, peeled and cut into 1/2-inch cubes
 1 medium onion, minced
 1 teaspoon chopped parsley
 1 pinch nutmeg
 Freshly ground black pepper to taste
 1 tablespoon kosher salt, or to taste
 3 eggs, separated
 4 cups vegetable oil.
1. Soak the cod overnight as above. Drain and cut into 1-inch squares, removing any remaining bones. Place the cod in a deep pot with the potatoes, cover with water and bring to a boil. Lower heat and simmer for 15 minutes, then drain.
2. Mash the potatoes and cod with the onion, parsley, nutmeg, pepper and salt (how much depends on the saltiness of the cod). Stir in the yolks. Beat the egg whites until stiff but not dry and fold them into the potato mixture.
3. Heat the oil to 350 degrees in a medium saucepan. Drop rounded tablespoons of the mixture (about 8 at a time) into the hot oil and fry for 2 minutes, turning once or twice, until golden. Drain on paper towels. Allow the oil to return to 350 degrees between each batch. Keep warm in a 300-degree oven until all are done.
Yield: 8 to 12 servings.
 
Portuguese Kale-and-Salt-Cod Chowder
 
 1 pound boneless, skinless salt cod
 1 tablespoon olive oil
 1 pound linguica sausage (or chorizo), cut into 1/2-inch disks
 1 small onion, chopped
 2 medium baking potatoes, peeled and cut into 1/2-inch dice
 4 quarts chicken broth
 8 ounces kale, stemmed, rinsed and coarsely chopped to make 6 cups
 2 bay leaves
 1/2 teaspoon chili-pepper flakes
 1/2 cup fresh mint, minced.
1. Soak the salt cod overnight in cold water, as above. Drain and tear the cod into bite-size pieces, removing any remaining bones. Cover the cod with fresh water and bring nearly to a boil. Remove from the heat, cover and let sit for 15 minutes. Drain and set aside.
2. Warm the olive oil in a large soup pot over high heat. Add the sausage and cook, stirring constantly, for 3 minutes to lightly brown. Reduce the heat to medium, add the onions and cook, stirring frequently until the onions are nearly soft, about 5 minutes. Add the potatoes and toss. Add the chicken broth and bring to a boil. Add the kale, bay leaves and chili- pepper flakes. Return to a boil, then lower the heat and simmer for 30 minutes. Skim the fat off the top of the soup. Add the cod, adjust the seasoning, ladle into bowls and sprinkle each with fresh mint.
Yield: 8 servings.
 
 Le Cirque's Potato-Wrapped Truffled Cod
 
 12 tablespoons unsalted butter, room temperature, cut into 12 pieces
 2 large baking potatoes, peeled and sliced thin lengthwise
 2 3/4teaspoons kosher salt
 Freshly ground black pepper to taste
 4 8-ounce cod fillets
 1 ounce black truffle, sliced very thin
 1 bottle good Italian red wine
 3 medium shallots, minced
 1 stem fresh thyme
 1 tablespoon heavy cream
 1 pinch sugar
 2 medium leeks, white only, cut into thin strips, 2 inches long.
1. Melt 2 pieces of the butter. Toss the potatoes with the melted butter and season with 1 teaspoon salt and pepper to taste.
2. Season the cod with 1 teaspoon salt and a few grinds of pepper. Lay out 4 10-inch squares of plastic wrap on the counter. On each square lay enough slices of potato to fully surround the cod. Place 1 fillet on each square and lay 3 slices of truffle on each. Wrap the cod in the potato slices, cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for 1 hour.
3. Boil the wine, shallots and thyme together for 20 to 30 minutes, until reduced to half a cup. Strain through a very fine sieve. Whisk the cream into the reduced wine. Over a low flame bring the wine and cream to a boil. Remove from heat. Whisk 6 pieces of butter into the sauce, 1 piece at a time. Return to very low heat if necessary to fully incorporate the butter into the sauce. Season with 1/4 teaspoon salt, 1 pinch of sugar and fresh pepper. Remove from heat, cover and keep warm.
4. Melt 2 pieces of butter in a skillet. Add the leeks and cook over medium heat until soft about 10 minutes. Season with 1/2 teaspoon of salt and pepper to taste. Remove from heat, cover and keep warm.
5. Preheat the oven to 400 degrees. Place a nonstick pan over medium heat and heat the remaining butter until very hot. Add the fish and cook for 2 1/2 minutes per side, until the potatoes are browned. Bake for 5 minutes and serve on a bed of leeks with a drizzle of sauce.
Yield: 4 servings.
 
Fresh Cod Baked With White Beans And Linguica
 
 1 pound dried white beans
 1 tablespoon olive oil
 5 ounces linguica sausage (or chorizo), minced
 2 onions, minced
 4 cloves of garlic, peeled
 2 1/2teaspoons kosher salt
 1/2 teaspoon coarsely ground black pepper
 2 14 1/2-ounce cans stewed tomatoes, drained
 1/2 cup oil-cured black olives, pitted
 1/8 teaspoon chili -pepper flakes
 6 6-to-8-ounce cod fillets
 2 tablespoons fresh rosemary.
1. Rinse the beans and place them in a large Dutch oven. Cover with cold water, place over high heat and bring to a boil. Remove from the heat, cover and set aside for a half hour, then drain.
2. Warm the oil in the Dutch oven, add sausage and cook for 2 minutes, add onions, garlic and drained beans, cover with cold water and cook over medium-low heat until almost tender, about 40 minutes. Drain excess liquid. Season with 2 teaspoons salt and pepper to taste. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees.
3. Pulse tomatoes, olives and pepper flakes in a food processor to combine. Arrange the cod on top of the beans. Sprinkle with 1/2 teaspoon of salt. Spoon the tomato mixture over the fillets and sprinkle with rosemary. Cover and bake in the oven until the fish is cooked and the beans are tender, about 20 to 30 minutes.
Yield: 6 servings.

HEADLINE: The New Look of Liberalism on the Court

BYLINE: By Jeffrey Rosen; Jeffrey Rosen is the legal-affairs editor of The New Republic and an associate professor at the George Washington University Law School. His most recent article for the Magazine, about Kenneth Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, appeared in June.

 BODY:
The most unguarded conversation i've had with justice ruth bader ginsburg occurred at the Washington Opera. It was two years ago, during the first intermission of a production of "Cosi Fan Tutte," and I ran into Justice Ginsburg and her husband on the stairs. "Cosi" is the one about the two lotharios who make a bet that their girlfriends will be faithful, disguise themselves as Albanian soldiers, try to seduce each other's girlfriend and find that the women aren't faithful after all. The director had tried to add a feminist twist by having the women overhear the bet in the first act, so that they were only "pretending" to be unfaithful in the second. I suggested to Justice Ginsburg that perhaps this conceit was hard to reconcile with the sexual double standards of the 18th century, which were central to the plot and reflected in the traditional translation of the title: "Never Trust a Woman."
Justice Ginsburg, as I recall, was wearing a black velvet cape, and she looked at me indulgently with her unblinking eyes. The Italian title, she pointed out, was in the third person plural. "They are all like that" would be a more accurate translation, she suggested. And so, she said, there was no reason to assume from the title that Mozart and his librettist, Lorenzo Da Ponte, approved of male infidelity any more than they approved of female infidelity, or that they thought women inherently more or less trustworthy than men. 
 Justice Ginsburg's elegant reconception of the 18th-century text epitomizes the vision of mainstream, equal-treatment feminism that she championed as an advocate and an academic in the 1970's. She rejected the traditional idea that women and men occupy separate spheres, in which women are naturally passive and men aggressive, and she challenged laws treating men and women differently, especially those designed to protect "the weaker sex." In June 1996, in her opinion for the Court ordering the Virginia Military Institute to admit women, she enacted this view into law. "Generalizations about the way women are, estimates of what is appropriate for most women," she wrote, "no longer justify denying opportunity to women whose talent and capacity place them outside the average description."
The boldness of Justice Ginsburg's opinion in the Virginia Military Institute case may seem hard to reconcile with the sensibility that informs the rest of her jurisprudence. She is, in most cases, a paragon of judicial restraint. In her four years on the Supreme Court, she has shown as a Justice precisely the same qualities that guided her for 13 years on the Court of Appeals: an affinity for resolving cases on narrow procedural grounds rather than appealing to broad principles of social justice; a preference for small steps over sweeping gestures, and an aversion to bold assertions of judicial power. Nevertheless, Ginsburg's opinions about sex discrimination share with the rest of her jurisprudence a focus on the individual choices faced by individual men and women rather than on historical abstractions or philosophical generalizations.
As an avatar, in most cases, of judicial minimalism, Justice Ginsburg is the antithesis of Justice William Brennan, the liberal lion of the Warren Court of the 1960's, who died in July at age 91. (Ginsburg visited Brennan during his last weeks; she told clerks that he always responded best to women, and playfully asked her for a kiss.) And in the wake of Brennan's death, it seems appropriate to ask what, precisely, it means to be a liberal Justice in 1997.
In June 1993, when President Clinton nominated Ruth Bader Ginsburg to the Supreme Court, he called her the Thurgood Marshall of the women's rights movement, self-consciously comparing her work as an advocate to that of the last Justice to be appointed by a Democratic President, 26 years earlier. The comparison of the advocacy of Marshall and Ginsburg was apt: both transformed antidiscrimination law by starting with the least controversial cases and working their way up. Yet Ginsburg's most important achievement as a Justice has been to wean liberals from the judicial sensibility that Marshall and Brennan came to embody. For more than a generation, critics of the Warren era have argued that Justices like Brennan and Marshall were too quick to short-circuit national debates that should have been resolved in the legislatures.
Imprisoned by their old paradigms, some political conservatives have implausibly attacked Ginsburg as a judicial activist. "According to Justice Ginsburg's theory of democracy, the majority gets first shot at solving the problems to the satisfaction of Federal judges but not the last word," Pat Buchanan said in an attack on Ginsburg during the last Presidential campaign. "The Court gets the last word."
In fact, Buchanan had it precisely backward: Ginsburg has proved to be a far more restrained Justice than her conservative colleagues. A recent survey by the libertarian Institute for Justice examined Supreme Court opinions between 1993 and 1996. The survey lamented the fact that the Justices least likely to strike down laws infringing civil and economic liberties were President Clinton's appointees, Justices Ginsburg and Stephen Breyer, who voted to uphold Government power in two-thirds of the cases examined. But the inadvertent corollary of the study was the identification of the most activist Justices as Anthony Kennedy, Sandra Day O'Connor and Clarence Thomas, all of whom voted to second-guess the executive and legislative branches three-quarters of the time. In the most hotly contested constitutional cases of our day, involving Congress's ability to pass affirmative-action programs, or to construct voting districts for the benefits of racial minorities or to regulate gun control or campaign finance, the conservative Justices have become the partisans of judicial activism and the liberal Justices, Ginsburg most of all, have become the partisans of judicial restraint.
Because of President Clinton's understandable inclination to promote his first Supreme Court nominee, and at the same time to appoint the first female Chief Justice in the history of the United States, Justice Ginsburg, who is 64, is increasingly mentioned as a candidate to replace Chief Justice William Rehnquist, 73, if he should choose to retire during a Democratic Administration. And the same qualities that make it very unlikely that Ginsburg will ever be a visionary leader as an Associate Justice -- her minimalism, her jurisprudential as well as personal restraint and her emphasis on avoiding constitutional conflicts rather than engaging them -- might make her an effective Chief Justice for a divided Court.
Since her nomination to the court, I've experienced with Justice Ginsburg something like what Nicholson Baker describes in the chronicle of his search for John Updike: she remains, always and everywhere, just out of reach. When Justice Byron White retired in 1993, some of Ginsburg's feminist colleagues were lukewarm about her Supreme Court candidacy on the grounds that her jurisprudence was too conservative and her vision of equal-treatment feminism not radical enough. Like some other commentators, I suggested that she might be an ideal candidate for a President who identified himself as a New Democrat and sought to wean liberals from the excesses of the Warren Court. For although her political instincts were liberal, she had been, as an appellate judge, the model of judicial restraint.
After her nomination, she sent me a generous note, fanning my hopes of becoming a judicial Boswell. ("You planted the idea," she wrote. "I'll try hard to develop it.") But grandiose visions of intimate conversations about judicial restraint over tea in the Justices' dining room were quickly abandoned, and with the exception of the encounter at the opera, I had no further contact with her until last spring, when I wrote to ask whether she might agree to be interviewed.
Justice Ginsburg replied, as she does in many of her judicial opinions, by trying to delay the decision until another day. "Like Scarlett," she wrote, "I'll think about it tomorrow." She then suggested that if I could put off the article for a little while, she would give me an exclusive interview in 2010. When I asked, in the meantime, for a tour of her chambers, she invited me to stop by on the Friday after the last day of the term, a few moments before she was due to leave for the Glyndebourne Festival in England to see "The Marriage of Figaro."
Justice Ginsburg has cloistered herself on the second floor of the Supreme Court, above the rest of her colleagues: she consolidated a set of rooms that had previously been used by retired Justices and their clerks, creating a space far larger than the first-floor suite that traditionally falls to a junior Justice. Ushered in from the antechamber, I found Justice Ginsburg standing near the desk of her cool, gray chambers. There was a black-granite table, airy beige curtains and a Joseph Albers painting, "On Tideland," a gray and red abstraction on loan from the National Museum of American Art. "Elegance is refusal," Diana Vreeland observed, and as Justice Ginsburg greeted me cautiously, it was hard not to be struck by her improbable glamour. Scarcely more than five feet tall, in a turquoise Chinese-silk jacket with matching wide-legged pants, her black hair pulled tightly back in a ponytail, she looked like an exquisite figurine.
With the unearthly self-possession of Jacqueline Kennedy conducting a White House tour, Justice Ginsburg showed me her favorite photographs. Here she is with Luciano Pavarotti at the Italian Embassy. Here she is with her dear friend Justice Antonin Scalia, after their joint appearance in "Ariadne auf Naxos" at the Washington Opera: he is wearing knee breeches and a wig; she has a silver Marschallin's dress and a lace fan. Here she is with Justice Scalia in India, sitting on top of an elephant of the maharajah of Rajasthan: she has sunglasses on and a kerchief around her head; he is wearing a jaunty Hawaiian shirt. Here is a signed photograph from President Clinton, taken on the day of her nomination. "To Justice Ginsburg," it reads. "What a day this was." We talked more about the operas she was going to see in England, which was the only topic that seemed safe to broach. Suddenly, the tour was over, and with a little wave, after inviting me to browse through her chambers at my leisure, Justice Ginsburg opened a private door near her desk and vanished.
Finding myself alone, I perused her bookshelves with some embarrassment. There were many books about civil procedure; but there were also a surprising number of popular books about contemporary feminism, including Deborah Tannen's "Talking From 9 to 5" and Anita Hill and Emma Jordan's "Race, Gender and Power in America." There was a shrine to Puccini, with Art Nouveau posters from the early 20th century. Soon Justice Ginsburg's secretary walked in. The Justice had telephoned from the car, she said, and wanted to call my attention to one photograph in particular. It shows her son-in-law with her infant grandson. That, the Justice wanted me to know, was her dream for the future.
At the time, I took the comment to be a platitude about the joys of grandchildren; but a little later, I realized that Justice Ginsburg may have been saying something more subtle about the transformation of sex roles. Soon after she joined the Court, I recalled, she had introduced herself, as new Justices traditionally do, by granting an interview to The Docket Sheet, a newsletter for Court employees. Toni House, the Court's public-information officer, asked her why she had agreed to a flexible schedule for one of her law clerks, David Post. Ginsburg replied that when Post applied for a clerkship, he was caring for his two small children during the day, so that his wife could sustain a demanding job as an economist. "I thought, 'This is my dream of the way the world should be,' " Ginsburg enthused. "When fathers take equal responsibility for the care of their children, that's when women will be truly be liberated."
Many of Ginsburg's feminist ideals seem to have been shaped by the experience of her own happy marriage to Martin Ginsburg, a tax professor at Georgetown Law School who is also a tax lawyer at Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson. For the past 43 years, the Ginsburgs' marriage has been one of the more inspiring advertisements for the possibility of connubial equality and mutual respect. "I hate Marty Ginsburg," Roger Wilkins, an American-history professor at George Mason University, said during a joint appearance with the Ginsburgs at a panel on balancing public and private life, held in May at Wheaton College. "It's not because in a town known for its ephemeral fashions, he's carrying on this lifelong love affair with this wonderful woman. It's because he cooks." Wilkins added: "The culture in black America is 'Why can't you be like Mike?' In my house it's 'Why can't you be like Marty?' "
Martin Ginsburg does indeed cook -- he taught himself by reading Escoffier while serving in the Army at Fort Sill, Okla. -- and he takes pleasure in challenging traditional sex roles by preparing elaborate banquets in the classical style for Justice Ginsburg's clerks, colleagues and friends. "Just before the President's State of the Union address on Feb. 4," Justice Ginsburg boasted during a recent speech, the nine Justices and their spouses "enjoyed a delectable dinner in the Justices' dining room, catered by volunteer superchefs Mary Kennedy and Marty Ginsburg." ("Justice Thomas," she added, "won the annual betting about how long the address would go.")
Sitting side by side onstage during the Wheaton forum on public and private life, the Ginsburgs played off each other with deadpan affection. "As a general rule," Martin Ginsburg announced, "my wife does not give me any advice about cooking, and I do not give her any advice about the law. This seems to work quite well on both sides." The Ginsburgs were asked how their daughter and son benefited or suffered from having dual-career parents. (Jane, 42, is a professor of copyright law at Columbia; James, 32, is a producer of classical-music recordings in Chicago.) Justice Ginsburg referred the questioner to a recent book, "Mothers and Daughters," in which she posed with Jane, sitting cross-legged on the floor of her bedroom, in gray pants and a navy blue sweatshirt that read "Super Diva!"
"When Jane was having her first child in Paris, it was a difficult birth, and she was feeling rotten," Ginsburg recalled. "And she called. And we were on the phone for hours. But the idea that she would call me, and not her best friend, to talk her out of what almost every woman goes through soon after childbirth, when you're feeling ungainly, and maybe the child isn't breast-feeding, and you feel you're getting rejected and unattractive. When she was at that moment, she called me. So I figure that I'd done something right." Ginsburg's impassive face lighted up with a small, warm smile, and her husband added the punch line. "I must tell you," he said, "that she called collect."
Justice Ginsburg's frequent public references to her husband and her children may seem unusual for a Supreme Court Justice. But the experience of raising a family in the 1960's and 1970's while distinguishing herself as a scholar and an advocate has clearly shaped her jurisprudence as well as her politics. The story of Ginsburg's own early experiences with sex discrimination has often been told. She graduated at the top of her class at Columbia Law School in 1959, after transferring from Harvard when her husband got a job in New York. Although she had been recommended for a clerkship with Felix Frankfurter, then approaching the end of his 23-year tenure on the Court, he refused to hire her when he learned, in her words, that "I was married and had a 5-year-old daughter." After clerking for Judge Edmund Palmieri of the Federal District Court in Manhattan, in 1963 she began teaching civil procedure at Rutgers Law School in Newark. With typical industry and attention to detail, Ginsburg learned Swedish and co-wrote the leading academic treatise on the Swedish code of civil procedure.
In 1972, the first year Title IX of the Education Amendments was extended to academic institutions, Ginsburg was invited back to Columbia to teach civil procedure and sex-discrimination law. At a recent Columbia event honoring Ginsburg, Diane Zimmerman, one of her protegees who now teaches at New York University Law School, recalled that the handful of women on law faculties in the early 1970's often had decided it was necessary to forgo family life. "These women were awe-inspiring, but not people we would have felt comfortable emulating," Zimmerman said. By contrast, she continued, "we had Ruth Ginsburg, who had kids she liked to talk about, a husband that she loved and admired, who was accessible to us as a model for the possibility of being a woman and not having to engage in those strategies if they weren't comfortable for us."
In 1971, Ginsburg had founded the women's rights project of the American Civil Liberties Union, for which she supervised the selection of cases and the writing of briefs, and argued six cases before the Supreme Court. As an advocate, she sought to convince the Court that legislation ostensibly designed to benefit or protect women could often have the opposite effect. She chose to represent a series of male plaintiffs who had been denied benefits earmarked for women, urging the Court to articulate a legal rule for evaluating sex discrimination that could be applied neutrally to either sex. Although Ginsburg was attacked by feminists in the 1980's as "phallocentric" and "assimilationist" for having represented male plaintiffs in the 1970's, her universalist perspective was highly appealing to male judges, who had to be educated to see the unfairness of sex distinctions that had long been accepted.
"It's the classical Jewish way of arguing against intolerance -- that you argue against exceptions from fairness not in the name of the particular exception but in the name of the general principle," says Leon Wieseltier, the literary editor of The New Republic, who is a close friend of Ginsburg. Wieseltier recalls that once, when Ginsburg was consoling him over the death of his father, she spoke movingly of the death of her own father. She then sent him a copy of a letter written in 1916 by Henrietta Szold, a founder of Zionism in America. By Jewish tradition, only male children can recite the Kaddish, a prayer of mourning for parents. If there are no male survivors, a stranger may act as a substitute, but Szold gently rejected a male friend's offer to say Kaddish in her place after her father died. "I believe that the elimination of women from such duties was never intended by our law and custom," Szold wrote. "Women were freed from positive duties when they could not perform them, but not when they could." Wieseltier compares Ginsburg's objections to sex discrimination in Jewish law to her objection to sex discrimination in American law. "In both cases," Wieseltier says, "she was as much an aggrieved rationalist as an aggrieved woman."
One of Ginsburg's former A.C.L.U. colleagues, Kathleen Peratis, testified during Ginsburg's confirmation hearings that her restrained litigation strategy in the 1970's anticipated her restrained judicial philosophy in the 1980's. "She insisted that we attempt to develop the law one step at a time," Peratis said. "Present the Court with the next logical step, she urged us, and then the next and then the next. Don't ask them to go too far too fast, or you'll lose what you might have won. She often said, 'It's not time for that case.' We usually followed her advice, and when we didn't, we invariably lost."
Deborah Jones Merritt, a former Ginsburg clerk who teaches at Ohio State University, makes a similar point. "I've heard her say that she was a particular admirer of Thurgood Marshall's strategy for challenging segregation in the courts," Merritt told me. "He started not in the hardest case, challenging segregation in elementary schools, but in the easier cases, involving professional schools."
When she recalls her landmark cases today, Justice Ginsburg inevitably focuses on the individual stories rather than abstract questions of social justice. At a recent forum at Columbia University about sex discrimination, Ginsburg told the story of Weinberger v. Wiesenfeld, the case that she said "epitomized for me all that we were doing in the 70's. It concerned a young man whose young wife died in childbirth and left an infant in his sole care. He pledged that he would be the primary caretaker of the child, and he sought Social Security benefits to aid him in that endeavor, but the benefits were for women only. They were labeled mothers' benefits."
At this point, Ginsburg's eyes began to sparkle and she became, in her regal way, passionate. "This led to a unanimous judgment in favor of claim; but the Justices divided in their reasoning," she continued. "The majority thought it was discrimination against the woman as wage earner, because she paid the same Social Security taxes but her family received different benefits. A few thought it was discrimination against the man, because he didn't have the same opportunity to give personal care to the baby as the woman would have had. And one, my Chief, thought it was discrimination against the baby." The audience laughed on cue. Ginsburg concluded by noting that "the baby in that story is today in his last year of college and has recently applied to Columbia Law School."
In cases involving women's issues in the 70's, the Court, Ginsburg argues, "largely trailed and mirrored changing patterns in society -- most conspicuously, the emergence of the two-career family." For this reason, and somewhat surprisingly, Ginsburg views her landmark victories in the 70's as an example of judicial restraint rather than judicial activism. "For the most part, the Court was neither out in front of, nor did it hold back, social change," she said in a recent speech. "Instead, what occurred was what engineers might call a positive feedback process, with the Court functioning as an amplifier -- sensitively responding to, and perhaps moderately accelerating, the pace of change."
Before her appointment to the court, Ginsburg famously criticized Roe v. Wade on the grounds it tried to lead, rather than follow, a social revolution in attitudes toward abortion, and in the process precipitated a political backlash. Legislatures in the 1970's were beginning to liberalize their abortion laws, she argued in her Madison lecture at N.Y.U. Law School in 1993. If the Court had merely struck down the extreme antiabortion restriction at issue in the case, rather than presuming to devise an elaborate trimester scheme that governed all abortion restrictions in all states, she said, the decision might have been far less controversial and the political momentum for liberalizations might have continued.
On the Supreme Court, Justice Ginsburg has continued to style herself as a cautious codifier of popular opinion rather than a crusader for social reform. Yet it could be argued that in cases involving sex discrimination, she has shown some crusading zeal. In a recent speech at the University of Virginia, Ginsburg herself called the decision ordering the Virginia Military Institute to admit women "a stunning change from the Court's rulings in 1873 that women could be excluded from the practice of law in Illinois without offense to the Federal Constitution and, in 1961, that women in Florida need not be placed on lists from which jurors are drawn."
How can Ginsburg's V.M.I. decision, which represents the culmination of her vision as an advocate, be reconciled with her general commitment to judicial restraint? "It just can't be reconciled," says Gerald Gunther of Stanford Law School, a former teacher of Ginsburg's and a close friend. "She clearly is a crusader on that issue." The broadest way of reading the V.M.I. decision is that it enacts the Equal Rights Amendment by judicial fiat, by declaring that sex discrimination is almost (but not quite) as constitutionally suspicious as racial discrimination. "There is no practical difference between what has evolved and the E.R.A.," Ginsburg told students at the University of Virginia, adding, "I would still like it as a symbol to see the E.R.A. in the Constitution for my granddaughter."
If the V.M.I. decision is indeed seen as the "practical equivalent" of the E.R.A., then all sorts of sex distinctions that continue to have widespread popular support, from single-sex private schools to the exclusion of women from military combat, might be called into question as well. This would represent precisely the same short-circuiting of a hotly contested political debate that Ginsburg has decried in other contexts.
There is, however, another way of reading the V.M.I. decision. Like all of Ginsburg's opinions, it resolves the question before the Court, while studiously refusing to speculate about other cases in the future. Viewed as a belated judicial recognition of a transformation in popular attitudes toward public military academies, the V.M.I. decision might be seen as more symbolic than revolutionary. If the V.M.I. case comes to stand for the proposition that public, single-sex military academies are unconstitutional while the exclusion of women from combat is permissible, it would be logically puzzling but of a piece with the rest of Ginsburg's jurisprudence, which is more concerned about case-by-case particularism than philosophical consistency. In Ginsburg's own mind, the V.M.I. decision seems to represent nothing more than the codification of a social revolution in the role of military academies that had occurred a decade earlier. When Phyllis Schlafly, who advocates a more traditional role for women, criticized the V.M.I. decision, singling out Ginsburg's "activist determination to write her radical feminist goals into the Constitution," Ginsburg, who is unusually sensitive to public criticism, jokingly responded in a speech, "The judgment was 7-1, for goodness' sake!" And when Josiah Bunting 3d, the superintendent of V.M.I., circulated several stanzas of light verse written by an aggrieved friend of the institute, Ginsburg quoted it in the same speech: "Pilloried by politics/By unjust courts denied/Now for the Institute's true sons/Its past must be their pride." Then she added, "Many of the sons have grown up, however, and I take heart from them."
Whether or not one accepts Justice Ginsburg's notion that the V.M.I. decision is an evolutionary rather than revolutionary decision, in the rest of her jurisprudence, she appears to be the most restrained Justice on the Court. In this respect, she has shown precisely the same judicial sensibility that she displayed on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit. As a Justice, and as a lower-court judge, she has demonstrated a meticulous attention to procedural details. In her careful, narrowly written opinions, there are few glimpses of Ginsburg's own policy views; instead, she scrupulously describes the relevant precedents and applies them in a terse, carefully worded way.
Above all, Ginsburg is a particularist, approaching cases from the bottom up rather than the top down. "I always think of Justice Ginsburg as a very particular person," says David Post, the former clerk, who now teaches law at Temple University. "She looks at the world as a collection of particulars. In a sense, it's a very small vision. She narrows things down. She looks at a case and says, 'What's going on; why are they suing; who are the people; what's going on in the background?' She likes to look at larger questions through the lens of smaller stories of people's lives. She wants to take individuals as individuals." In this regard, her feminist vision and her judicial sensibility are of a piece: both focus on the individual choices made by individual plaintiffs and defendants.
In the wrong hands, of course, a mission to do justice between individual parties can become a license for judges to act as platonic guardians, guided by nothing more than their personal reactions to individual cases. Ginsburg's particularism, however, is more of a sensibility than an inflexible judicial philosophy. And her judicial deliberativeness and restraint mirror her personal deliberativeness and restraint. "Mother is tremendously sentimental, but she could also be somewhat austere," Jane Ginsburg told the authors of "Mothers and Daughters." "When I did something bad, which happened often, my dad would yell, but my mother would be real quiet and I'd know she was very disappointed in me."
Ginsburg's sparse, highly compressed writing style is particular, too: reading it, one can imagine the unessential words being pared away with a fine-tip pen. "Language matters more than you can imagine," David Post says. "I've seen her agonize over individual words many times. Not terms of art, but adjectives. . . .It's very important to her to get every word to say exactly what she wants it to say, with all the connotations she wants." Leon Wieseltier puts it this way: "She's not just deliberative as a matter of principle but as a matter of temperament. A conversation with her is a special pleasure because there are no words that are not preceded by thoughts."
In speeches, Justice Ginsburg has attributed her deliberative temperament to her own mother, who admonished her constantly, once she reached her teens, to "be a lady!"
"To her, the term 'great lady' was a most honorable one," Ginsburg told the graduating class of Wheaton College. "It meant hold fast to your convictions and self-respect, be a good teacher, but don't snap back in anger. Anger, resentment, indulgence in recriminations waste time and sap energy."
Ginsburg's jurisprudence clearly reflects the influence of her law-school education and early academic experience as a teacher of civil procedure. She attended Harvard and Columbia law schools during the heyday of the legal-process movement, when scholars like Herbert Wechsler argued that lawyers could best pursue the ideal of neutrality by focusing on procedural rather than substantive questions. "Professor Wechsler was twice my teacher in law-school days," Ginsburg told a recent gathering at Columbia. "He seemed to me then, as he has ever since, to combine the power and beauty of the Greek gods Zeus and Apollo. He is my teacher still. Of all the books I use in chambers, the one I consult more than any other is Hart and Wechsler" -- the great casebook about the jurisdiction of Federal courts.
More than any of her colleagues, Ginsburg often conceals or sublimates her personal views of the merits of a case by focusing on legal process. "It is an extremely revealing fact about Ruth Ginsburg that she taught civil procedure for 17 years," notes Peter Huber, a former clerk who is now a fellow at the conservative Manhattan Institute. "It tells you something profound. Procedure is the one area of law where your outcomes are severely limited; procedures have to be neutral precisely because they apply equally to your friends and your enemies." As a result of her "almost Talmudic reverence and respect for the process of law," Huber says, "I think she is the most apolitical liberal you can be. She has this terribly old-fashioned notion that rules can get written down or can evolve through a common-law process and can build upon each other to create a decisional fabric."
Ginsburg's emphasis on procedure has no doubt helped to sustain her longtime friendship with Antonin Scalia, which dates back to their days together on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit. For years, the Ginsburg and Scalia families have gathered together for a black-tie New Year's dinner at the Ginsburgs' elegant apartment in the Watergate. (Martin Ginsburg and Maureen Scalia share the cooking.) "Her emphasis on process is why she's always been on such excellent personal terms with Justice Scalia and Bob Bork," says Huber, who often joins the Ginsburgs and Scalias for New Year's dinner. "You can't feel very politically antagonistic toward someone who is centered on the process rather than the politics."
It seems fair to wonder, nevertheless, whether Ginsburg's friendship with Scalia, and her emphasis on procedure above all, has caused her to sidestep some of the most important intellectual debates on the Rehnquist Court, which are largely conducted on Scalia's terms. Scalia insists that the Court should decide cases in accordance with the original understanding of the Constitutional text. There is a vigorous debate among judges and legal scholars about whether or not the intentions of the framers and ratifiers of the Constitution can be meaningfully resurrected. But because of the energy with which he presses his arguments, Scalia has forced even the Justices who reject his methodology to respond to his historical claims. For example, when Scalia, writing for the Court in June, struck down part of the gun-control law known as the Brady bill, three liberal dissenting Justices -- David Souter, John Paul Stevens and Stephen Breyer -- had a fierce debate with Scalia about whether the views of James Madison or Alexander Hamilton should be dismissed as eccentric and whether the constitutional legacy of the New Deal should be preserved or ignored.
Justice Ginsburg did not participate in this debate; she tends to abstain from most broad historical debates, often resorting to procedural arguments to conclude that constitutional questions should be sent back to the lower courts. Consider the Agostini case last term, which involved the constitutionality of a New York City program that sent public-school teachers into parochial schools to provide remedial education. Five members of the Court, at the urging of the Clinton Administration, upheld the program and overturned an opinion by William Brennan, Aguilar v. Felton, that represented the high-water mark of church-state separationism.
Rather than engaging the constitutional debate, Justice Ginsburg, in her separate dissent, focused not on the substantive meaning of the First Amendment but on a question of civil procedure. She said that Justice O'Connor had misinterpreted Rule 60(b) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, which, in her view, did not allow the Supreme Court to re-examine the 12-year-old decision. A proper application of the rules, Ginsburg concluded, "would lead us to defer reconsideration of Aguilar until we are presented with the issue in another case."
Justice Ginsburg believes, however, that deciding only the case before her, and delaying related questions until they are ripe for decision, is a quintessentially restrained position because it enables citizens, legislators and lower-court judges to disagree about important constitutional issues and to resolve their differences democratically.
Because of the respect Justice Ginsburg has earned from liberals, who appreciate her feminist advocacy, and from conservatives, who recognize her otherwise restrained sensibility, she is increasingly mentioned as a plausible candidate to succeed William Rehnquist as Chief Justice. There is no reliable evidence that Rehnquist is inclined to resign after 11 years as Chief; but Court watchers and clerks have idly speculated for the past several years that he might step down sooner rather than later. In the event that he does retire, a Democratic President might be tempted to appoint the first female Chief Justice of the United States.
Ginsburg herself has done little to discourage the speculation. In her speeches, she likes to quote from a letter by Sarah Grimke, the feminist and antislavery lecturer from South Carolina, who visited the Supreme Court in 1853. In the letter, Grimke says she was invited to sit in the Chief Justice's chair. "As I took the place," she wrote, "I involuntarily exclaimed, 'Who knows, but this chair may one day be occupied by a woman.' The brethren laughed heartily. Nevertheless, it may be a true prophecy." At this point, Ginsburg pauses and looks at the audience. "Today," she says with a little smile, "no one would laugh at that prophecy."
If President Clinton were looking for a Chief in the model of Earl Warren, a gregarious backslapper with a big heart who builds coalitions by sheer force of personality, Justice Ginsburg would not be his woman. She is, in many respects, a loner, and her opportunities for informal interactions are limited by her solitary work habits. She works most efficiently alone, and at home, often staying up until 2 or 3 in the morning for long periods of concentrated writing and thinking. "She likes to sleep late, work at home and come in when she's ready to do whatever faces her there," says David Post, her former clerk. "When the Court isn't sitting, she can come into the office between noon and 6 in the evening." By late afternoon, some of the other Justices are no longer around.
Even when she is at the Court, Ginsburg is unlikely to engage in banter, because she prefers to communicate in writing. Ginsburg's desire for precision of language, and her emphasis on "getting it right and keeping it tight," as she puts it, have not always made her popular with law clerks in other chambers. The memos that she sends commenting on the opinions of other Justices often consist of small technical suggestions and the correction of typographical errors, all marked in her precise hand with a black or red pen. This attention to technical detail dates back to her days as an advocate, when she was famous for correcting the typos in her colleagues' briefs.
Ginsburg has less personal contact with her colleagues than, for example, Justice Stephen Breyer, a more expansive personality who talks frequently to Justice Anthony Kennedy, whose chambers are next to his, and to Justice Clarence Thomas, who sits next to him on the bench. Nevertheless, Ginsburg puts a high premium on cordial relationships with her fellow Justices because of her passion for collegiality. "In recent terms, the Court has been remarkably collegial, deciding cases unanimously at least twice as often as we divided 5-4," Ginsburg told the judges of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in June. "The tone of our opinions, too, has become less adversarial, with hardly a nasty comment so far this term." Ginsburg is closer to some Justices than others -- she especially admires William Rehnquist, whom she calls "my Chief," but is reportedly frostier to Justice Anthony Kennedy. Even so, her ideal of collegiality has helped to sustain her mutually respectful relationship with all her colleagues.
Asked recently at the American University about her relationship with Sandra Day O'Connor, Ginsburg replied: "Justice O'Connor provided grand aid to me when I arrived. She was like a big sister. She knows my Chief very well: they were classmates in law school and later lived in the same town. She told me many things that made my life easier that first year." Had the presence of two women changed the Court? a student asked. Ginsburg replied: "Our robing room, since the 1993 term, has a women's bathroom equal in size to the men's. But the troops are not yet fully adjusted to the change. Twice this term, distinguished advocates arguing before the Court -- a Harvard Law School professor and the Acting Solicitor General" -- Laurence Tribe and Walter Dellinger, respectively -- "began their responses to my questions, 'Well, Justice O'Connor.. . .' Last time that happened, Sandra smiled and crisply said: 'She's Justice Ginsburg. I'm Justice O'Connor." Although the academic from New York and the former state legislator from Arizona are too temperamentally different to be close friends, according to clerks, they appreciate each other's achievements and support.
It would be foolish, in any event, to select the next Chief Justice on the basis of his or her capacity to schmooze. The most important power of a Chief Justice is the power, whenever he or she votes with the majority, to decide which Justice will write the opinion for the Court. (When the Chief Justice dissents, the most senior Justice in the majority has the power of assignment.) From a purely tactical point of view, the most pressing challenge facing a liberal Chief Justice could be to use the power of assignment to win over the swing Justices, Kennedy and O'Connor, and to insure that opinions are written as narrowly rather than as broadly as possible. Because of the narrowness of her focus, Ginsburg seems well positioned to find common ground with her conservative colleagues. "It helps in building collegiality if you don't take zealous positions, if you don't write in an overwrought way, if you state your position logically and without undue passion," Ginsburg said in a recent speech. "Another way is to ask, 'Is this conflict really necessary?' Perhaps there is a ground, maybe a procedural ground, on which everyone can agree, so that the decision can be unanimous, saving the larger question for another day."
Ginsburg, in short, would most likely be far more of an impartial Chief than a crusading one. "Maintaining the kind of respect that the Court has, I think, is the greatest challenge that's facing the Court at this time," she said at a recent forum at Columbia Law School. Nevertheless, it is hard to imagine her not wanting to leave her mark on the Court in some way. "She's very long term," says David Post, "and she's always considering the implications of small moves. For example, there's a little doctrine in international civil procedure. She'd say, 'In order to make sure that's shored up, we'll drop this footnote in a case that has nothing to do with international civil procedure.' Why she wanted to preserve that little doctrine, I never knew. But I was persuaded of the integrity of her vision."
In his generous eulogy at Brennan's funeral, Justice Souter said: "The life of the man is over. So is the liberal era when Justice Brennan's voice was the voice of the Supreme Court." Perhaps Justice Ginsburg's quieter and more restrained voice best represents the liberal era of the future. Or, to put the point another way, now that liberals have stopped relying on the Supreme Court to fight their battles for them, perhaps their goal, like Ginsburg's, should be a Court that is as legalistic as possible, suspicious of grand theories, deferential to the political branches and more given to small steps than sweeping gestures. This is hardly an exhilarating model for the next Chief Justice; but Ginsburg's example shows us that for better rather than for worse, the age of judicial exhilaration is over.
Just before she left me alone in her chambers, Justice Ginsburg paused before a stack of books on her desk. She wanted a judicial biography to read during her flight to London and had recently borrowed two from the Court's library. One was Joseph J. Ellis's "American Sphinx: The Character of Thomas Jefferson," the story of the remote aristocrat who was so suspicious of Federalist judges that he insisted that the President had the power to appeal directly to the people, over the objections of the Supreme Court. The other was Jean Edward Smith's "John Marshall: Definer of a Nation," about the brilliant but personally unassuming Chief Justice and foe of Jefferson who won over his colleagues by intellectual force, fought against class distinctions on the bench by pioneering the use of black judicial robes and reinvented the Court in his own image. Which to choose? After a suitable pause, Justice Ginsburg said she thought she would take the Marshall. It was then, without further explanation, that she disappeared.

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 2; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: The View From: Stamford;
From Sleepy Town To High-Rise City

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
AN often-heard plaint of Stamford residents, on returning to the city years after having moved away, is that they no longer recognize their home town. Indeed, it is not uncommon even for those who still live in the city to get lost amid the high-rise glass towers that seem to have sprung up without design, without symmetry.
But perhaps that is not surprising. No city or town in the state has changed so drastically as Stamford has over the last 20 years. And, following a respite in new construction because of the recession of the late 1980's and early 1990's, which sent the office building vacancy rate as high as 30 percent, Stamford seems to be on the verge of a new wave of high-rise building. 
 "Stamford was a small sleepy town, and now it's a fairly big city," said Sandra Goldstein, the executive director of the city's Downtown Special Services District. "And, overall, things are a lot better."
Not everyone would agree. While aware that something had to be done following the exodus of companies like Yale & Towne, which once employed 10,000 people, more than a few residents believe that Stamford went too far. In the process, they feel the city surrendered much of its charm.
The transformation of the city from an industrial-based economy to service-oriented companies has created thousands of jobs of a different kind. It has also enriched the city with more tax revenue, though the promises of lower taxes as a result of the development has never materialized.
And the explosive business growth has also put a strain on city services, sent housing prices skyrocketing, resulted in the demolition of thousands of structures -- many of them landmarks -- and created immense traffic problems on the Connecticut Turnpike, the Merritt Parkway and secondary roadways like High Ridge and Long Ridge roads.
Onetime graceful boulevards like Summer Street and Bedford Street are now high-speed thoroughfares designed to get cars in and out of the city as quickly as possible.
Even civic leaders and corporate boosters who exult over statistics like a 7 percent vacancy rate in office space, also concede that transportation problems are bound to get worse soon.
By next year, about 2,000 employees will have moved into the Swiss Bank Corporation's North American headquarters, under construction near the Connecticut Turnpike and the Stamford Transportation Center. More will follow when the next two phases of the project, encompassing more than one million square feet, are finished. Three developers have also said they plan to build office buildings of more than 20 stories in downtown Stamford.
"If all of these projects go through, we're talking about another 10,000 workers," said Joseph McGee, vice president of public policy and programs for the Stamford Area Commerce and Industry Association. "But all of this growth is appropriate under the city's master plan."
The continued development apparently will be an issue in the November mayoral election. The Republican candidate, Charles Klein, a relative unknown who is challenging the Democratic incumbent, Dannel P.Malloy, said last month that the city is being turned into a "concrete canyon" and vowed to stop "high-density overdevelopment."
Not surprisingly, none of the officials of the Commerce and Industry Association, the Stamford Chamber of Commerce or the Stamford Downtown Special Services District interviewed opposed increased development.
"It's the way people get to work that is the problem," said Mr. McGee, commissioner of the State Department of Economic Development before joining the Commerce and Industry Association. "It is critical that more people come to work by train and bus. As it is, 95 percent drive to work alone. If we can reduce traffic on I-95 by 5 percent, it would make a big difference. But Metro-North has to provide more frequent intrastate service. That is the key."
So, too, is an adequate supply of workers -- unemployment is just 3 percent -- frozen out by by high housing costs in Stamford and a decline in the number of rental units. (When more units are built, they are invariably luxury apartments.) Presently, about two-thirds, or 60,000, of the people who work in Stamford live outside the city, many of them more than 30 miles away.
Twenty years ago, Stamford was at a crossroads of sorts following an urban renewal program that had resulted in the relocation of about 1,200 families and the displacement of more than 300 businesses. Only one major international corporation, GTE, had built a headquarters building in the city (Pitney Bowes has been headquartered in Stamford since 1920), while one other, Champion International, was planning to build downtown.
During the next decade, scores of companies, taking advantage of tax packages, moved into the city. Some, following the lead of the Xerox Corporation, built spacious headquarters on campus-like settings in quiet suburban, and even farm, settings, to the consternation of environmentalists.
As retail business in downtown Stamford continued to decline, a new fortress-like enclosed shopping mall, known as the Stamford Town Center -- though it is anything but -- opened in the early 1980's. With more than 100 shops, it has thrived, to the detriment of many long-established and locally owned downtown stores. This was particularly evident on Bedford Street, where upscale shops shut down and were replaced by an eclectic mixture of discount stores and other nondescript shops.
In recent years, another part of downtown, around the Old Town Hall, has enjoyed a renaissance, largely because of the efforts of the Downtown Special Services District, headed by Ms. Goldstein, formerly a member of the city's Board of Representatives.
New restaurants and nightclubs have proliferated, as have new movie theaters, and the city, once dormant at night, is drawing people in from nearby cities and towns in Fairfield and Westchester counties.
The Stamford Center for the Performing Arts is also thriving at two sites on Atlantic Street: the Rich Forum and the recently renovated Palace Theater. And the new University of Connecticut Stamford branch, which will be moved next year from its North Stamford location to the former site of the Bloomingdale's store on Washington Boulevard, is expected to further enhance the downtown cultural scene.
For all the changes, something has been lost, though some neighborhoods like Springdale and Shippan have remained relatively unchanged. In the literal sense, it is 700 buildings, many of them graceful homes that lined Summer and Bedford streets for more than half century.
"It's been a cataclysmic upheaval," said Renee Kahn, the director of the city's Historic Neighborhoods Preservation Program, who has fought, mostly unsuccessfully, to preserve landmarks. "Stamford has become a town without a visible past and with no sense of community."
Among the landmark buildings that were demolished were the National Guard Armory, from which servicemen went off to both World Wars; the Roger Smith Hotel, once the city's main hostelry; the former City Hall on Atlantic Street, and the Salvation Army and Visiting Nurses Association buildings. The Old Town Hall, the Post Office and the old Advocate building "are the only landmarks left," Ms. Kahn said, "and if we lose them, we've lost everything from the past."
Even Neil Sherman, the former president of the Stamford Chamber of Commerce, while lauding the city's economic resurgence, said that the city seemed to lack a collective community spirit.
"What development has occurred has been imposed on the community," said Mr. Sherman, now the executive director of the Coastal Fairfield County Convention and Visitor Bureau in Norwalk. "And now, the largest issue for a successful Stamford is to develop a sense of community, something that is now missing."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Construction continues on the Swiss Bank building, above; J. Seward Johnson's sculpture at Atlantic and Broad, left. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times; Helen Neafsey for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Q. & A.

A New Mortgage On a Condo
 
Q. I am going to refinance my condominium. What kind of closing expenses can be eliminated or reduced if I get a new mortgage with a lower interest rate from the bank that holds my current mortgage? . . . Victor Maltsev, Rego Park, Queens.
A. Douglas F. Wasser, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said there were several ways a homeowner might be able to save money on a refinancing, regardless of whether the refinancing was with the current lender or a new one. 
 The most significant potential source of savings, Mr. Wasser said, are New York City's mortgage recording taxes. Ordinarily, he said, a borrower must pay a tax of 1.75 percent of mortgage amounts under $500,000 and 1.875 percent on mortgages over that amount when the new mortgage is recorded.
"The tax is actually one-quarter of one percent higher, but the lender, not the homeowner, generally pays this additional portion," Mr. Wasser said.
Mortgage taxes can be reduced or even eliminated, however, when a borrower and lender enter into what is known as a "consolidation, modification and extension agreement." Such an agreement, Mr. Wasser said, essentially results in an amendment of the existing mortgage to conform with the terms of the refinancing. If the refinancing is only for the existing balance of the old mortgage, he said, a new mortgage is unnecessary and no tax is due because tax is only imposed when a new mortgage is recorded.
If the borrower wants to borrow more than the balance of the old mortgage, then he or she signs a new mortgage only for the difference. The old mortgage and the new one are then consolidated, with tax being imposed only on the new amount being borrowed.
Additional savings may be available on a refinancing, Mr. Wasser said, if the borrower obtained title insurance on the property within the previous 10 years. If he has done so -- and if the borrower makes that fact known to the new title insurance company -- the company may charge a discounted premium on the new policy.
Mr. Wasser said that using the existing lender on a refinancing might lead to some additional savings on processing fees. However, he said, the borrower should insure that such savings are worth forgoing more competitive loan packages that may be offered by other lenders.
"I recommend a consultation with a good residential mortgage broker," Mr. Wasser said.
 
Giving Interest On Security Deposits
 
Q. I am subletting an apartment from a co-op sponsor. Are sponsors who have more than six apartments required to give their tenants interest on security deposits? . . . Nelson Acotts, the Bronx.
A. Paul M. Gulielmetti, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said that the state's General Obligations Law requires that security deposits advanced for the rental or use of apartments in buildings containing six or more family dwelling units must be deposited in an interest-bearing account.
"I can find nothing in the case law that would exempt rentals within co-op buildings by sponsors, or for that matter, by unit owners, from that requirement," Mr. Gulielmetti said.
Accordingly, he said, an individual who owns and rents out even one apartment in a building with six or more residential units must deposit the tenant's security in an interest-bearing account. By law, he said, the owner is entitled to an annual administration fee equal to one percent of the amount on deposit. Any interest earned above that one percent belongs to the tenant.

HEADLINE: A French Director With a Taste for the Gritty and Unglamorous

BYLINE: By LESLIE CAMHI

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
AS SHE SITS AND TALKS IN her agent's offices on an elegant boulevard near the Place de l'Etoile, the director Claire Denis is a long way from the remote French colonies and the working-class urban neighborhoods in which she has set each of her four feature films. But Ms. Denis navigates the distance gracefully.
She's an elfin woman with a shock of white blond hair, a small face that tenses with extreme concentration and a voice that's surprisingly bright and deep. She's also a daring filmmaker, who for the last decade has been breaking and remaking the esthetic and political codes of French cinema. 
 Her most recent film, "Nenette et Boni," which opened in New York on Friday, explores the troubled, inscrutable relationship between a disaffected teen-age brother and his pregnant younger sister as they move through the parallel economies and faltering social services of the port city of Marseilles. Beautiful, lost youth is the film's constant focus.
"My way of making films is tied to desire," says Ms. Denis, who is 49. "Not just the physical desire for another person but desire in general. All my films function as a movement toward an unknown other and toward the unknown in relations between people."
The power of this approach was evident as early as "Chocolat" (1988), the director's first feature. Loosely based on Ms. Denis's childhood in French West Africa, this story of colonial officials and their servants in the Cameroon of the 1950's centers on the mysterious and intimate tie between a young French girl and the African domestic who looks after her.
"Chocolat" made Isaak de Bankole, who played the servant, a star; it was the first of three films in which the director's eye focused, with passionate curiosity, on the intersection of European, African and West Indian cultures, and on the bodies of black men. (It also began the collaboration between Ms. Denis and her camerawoman, Agnes Goddard, who has worked on all her major films since then.)
In 1991, "No Fear, No Die" starred Mr. de Bankole and Alex Descas as partners who raise and train cocks for fights organized by a white entrepreneur in a deserted commercial zone outside Paris. Three years later came "I Can't Sleep," inspired by the true story of Thierry Paulhin, a black, gay transvestite who, with his white lover, murdered at least 20 elderly women in Paris during the 1980's. "The press called him a monster," Ms. Denis says. "My question was, Could I have been the mother of this monster, or his sister?"
Amid critical praise, "I Can't Sleep" earned the director vicious attacks in the right-wing news media, but she also received a flood of letters, she says, "from ordinary people, who felt that it spoke to the loss of social and affective ties that is perhaps the primary pain of our modern condition."
"Nenette et Boni" was born of Ms. Denis's collaboration with Gregoire Colin and Alice Houry, two young actors who starred in "U.S. Go Home," a short film she made three years ago for French television. That film is a portrait of a teen-age brother and sister growing up in a desolate Parisian suburb in the 1960's.
LIKE "CHOCOLAT" IT IS loosely autobiographical; when Ms. Denis, at the age of 13, returned with her family to France from Africa, she lived in the same suburb, or banlieu. (Later, she went to college, and then to the Institut des Hautes Etudes Cinematographiques, the prestigious state-run film school, before a decade of working as an assistant to directors like Jacques Rivette, Wim Wenders and Jim Jarmusch.)
These and other suburban neighborhoods, abandoned by the French middle class, are now impoverished ghettos inhabited by immigrant communities; they're the subject of sociological speculation, political debate and the so-called films de banlieux, a new cinematic genre. Intimate, sensual and complex, "Nenette et Boni" is in part Ms. Denis's reaction to the stereotypes of the banlieux genre.
"It's a neighborhood film," she says. "Though I don't show postcard shots of the city, I wanted Marseilles to be present in the characters, in their language and way of being."
Boni (Gregoire Colin) drives a pizza truck around the streets of Marseilles; when he's not baking and serving pies, he's reveling in overwrought sexual fantasies that focus on his neighbor (Valeria Bruni-Tedeschi), the voluptuous wife of a baker.
He lives with assorted friends in a house he inherited from his dead mother. One day, his sister, 15-year-old Nenette (Alice Houry), appears at his door. She has run away from school because she is pregnant; the child's father, she says, "doesn't exist." Their own father (Jacques Nolot) runs a lamp store and has problems with the mob; his attempts at paternity are useless. Nenette regards her growing middle with misery and stubborn lack of interest, but her predicament begins to startle Boni out of his daydreams.
Ms. Denis's gift is to integrate the characters so fully in their milieu that they emerge from it almost insensibly. "It's always been interesting for me to refuse the idea that everything in a film be organized around the main characters and their needs," she says. "I like the idea that viewers arrive as strangers in what appears to be a total mess, and little by little the main characters materialize."
Contemporary Marseilles is a place of conflict between a vibrant (and ancient) immigrant community and supporters of Jean-Marie Le Pen's extreme right-wing (and anti-immigrant) National Front party. In "Nenette et Boni," the actor Alex Descas has a small role as a black gynecologist. "Curiously, it's very rare to see that kind of role in French film," he says. "If you take the subway, or go into a cafe, or a courtroom, or a bakery, you'll see black people, Asians, Arabs. All that exists; why not show it in film? Well, for Claire, it's natural and normal."
Yet the roots of "Nenette et Boni" go deeper than politics. "When I was an adolescent I read Jean Cocteau's 'Les Enfants Terribles,' " Ms. Denis says. "Later I thought about the constant haranguing between brothers and sisters that exists alongside the unacknowledged desire for this bond of childhood to be their real love story, the one that binds them forever."
Growing up the eldest of four siblings, she only realized later, she says, that "the bond between brothers and sisters is troubling and mysterious, a blood tie as in ancient Greek tragedy."
Mr. Colin's performance as Boni is at once raging, sex-starved and tender. The role was written for him. "What I love about working with Claire," he says, "is that she lets the actor imbue the character with everything he is at a given moment. She never gives orders; she offers a critique of what she's seen."
This approach has much to do with Ms. Denis's faith in her medium. "Cinema has this incredible way of making us feel what psychology can't explain," she says. "You can read 15 books about serial killers, but that has nothing to do with the way you may look at people in the subway, or your own brother, or your mother, that mysterious element that makes you sense that what unites us, as human beings, is our opacity for each other. Cinema is made with light and shadow, but the beauty of light is that it delimits shadow. And that element of shadow is the part of cinema I'd like to continue exploring."

GRAPHIC: Photo: TO BE YOUNG AND TROUBLED IN MARSEILLES Alice Houry, left, in the new film "Nenette et Boni," about a teen-age boy and his pregnant runaway younger sister, and the film's director, Claire Denis, in Paris. (Strand Releasing/Monlau/Rapho)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography
