SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 2; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2965 words

HEADLINE: ART;
Glory Days for the Art Museum

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI

 BODY:
ROBERT P. BERGMAN IS SURE HE IS having the last laugh. Sixteen years ago, when he left an enviable post as associate professor of fine arts at Harvard to become director of the Walters Art Gallery in Baltimore, "I got a lot of pats on my shoulder from my colleagues," he recalled recently, "a lot of 'Poor Bob, there he goes to dust off the sarcophagi.' Museums were on a trajectory to be marginalized."
Not quite. "The last 15 years have given lie to that," said a beaming Mr. Bergman, who is now director of the Cleveland Museum of Art. "This is a good time for museums." 
 That is an understatement. Gaze at the crowds at the Museum of Modern Art in New York on any Friday night. Consider the multitude of corporate party planners who vie to hold events at the Art Institute of Chicago, the lines snaking outside the National Gallery of Art's recent Picasso exhibition and the $15 ticket price the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston is now charging for that same Picasso show -- possibly the highest ever for an art museum -- and the picture looks better than "good." It looks as if the 90's are the age of the art museum in the United States, perhaps even the golden age.
Undeniably, there are more of them -- more than 1,200, up 50 percent since 1970. Many musems are constructing new buildings or expanding old ones: the Modern in New York, the Getty in Los Angeles, the Norton Museum of Art in West Palm Beach, the Henry Art Gallery in Seattle, the Milwaukee Art Museum, the Houston Museum of Fine Arts, to name just a few.
While dance companies, orchestras, serious theater groups and the other "high" arts -- with the possible exception of opera -- struggle to retain their audiences, American museums are setting one new attendance record after another. In the last year, an average of nearly 17,000 people walked up the granite steps of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York every day, about 11 percent more than the year before. Nationwide, art museums drew an estimated 100 million visitors last year.
The attractions of art museums are many, beginning with the practical. Most charge less than the price of a movie ticket. Visitors can usually go when they want and stay as long as they like. They don't have to get dressed up. Once inside, they can choose their own path, stopping to look at something -- or not. They can talk during the "show." Children are welcome.
More profound cultural changes are also at work. People are attracted to museums because American culture is increasingly visual. Image began to reign supreme over the written and spoken word once television started to dominate the national consciousness, beginning in the 1950's, a trend reinforced by the explosion in influence of movies and video. Americans, particularly young ones, learn their news on the tube and their history in the movie theater, and what interest they have in the high arts is best satisfied by the visual richness of museums.
"Young people today are lookers, with more of a visual sense than their elders," said Michael G. Kammen, a Pulitzer Prize-winning professor of American history and culture at Cornell University. "They are less likely to curl up with a book than go to see art." Picasso trumps Dickens.
Museums are also in step with another aspect of American culture: we are a nation of shoppers, and shaped behaviorally by the experience. "People are used to the shopping mall, where they can walk around and stop where they wish," said Nicholas Fox Weber, a cultural historian. "And you can do that in a museum, whereas you can't in a music or dance performance." Whether visiting the mall, holding the remote control or grazing before an open refrigerator, Americans are used to picking and choosing their own course.
And what choices they have at museums! Painting, sculpture, video, installation or decorative art; blockbusters, rotating special exhibitions or permanent collections; historical themes, current ones or controversial presentations on the social issues of the day -- all are available with a minimal commitment of money or time.
As cornucopias replete with items from prehistory through yesterday, many museums easily hold more allure than their cultural brethren. "Merce Cunningham is not going to appeal to everyone -- it's just a kind of dance that will not draw everyone," said Joan Jeffri, director of Columbia University's Research Center for Arts and Culture. "But a museum with many departments can appeal to many more people."
Many museums are doing so consciously, inviting in diverse audiences with new kinds of exhibitions and programs. Critics, for example, deplored the Modern's "High and Low," a 1990 exhibition exploring the connection between avant-garde art and popular culture -- but the public loved it, and it helped spawn many exhibitions related to popular culture and to fashion. "Much more than performing arts groups, museums have come to be perceived as democratic in orientation," said Paul DiMaggio, a sociology professor at Princeton University who has long studied arts participation.
Nowadays, of course, museums are much more than great art treasuries -- and shopping malls. They also convincingly play the part of classroom, meeting place, restaurant, playground, park bench, party palace, cinema, singles bar, conversation provocateur, travel agent, lecture hall, wine bar, and -- when a particularly compelling exhibition or event occurs -- the place to see and be seen socially.
"Forget Grand Central as metaphor for milling, dashing New York. The Great Hall of the Metropolitan Museum of Art is the crossroads of culture, a chockablock Breughel canvas of tourists, families, even questing singles," proclaimed a recent advertisement for the Metropolitan.
That bustling Breughel, however, does not please all art world denizens, some of whom fear that exuberance may be luring museums into overexpansion. Some institutions are already getting caught in a vicious circle: the bigger they grow, the more money they require. To cope, they are plumping up their restaurants and retail shops and expending the bulk of their effort staging tried-and-true exhibitions (read: Impressionists and Picasso) to guarantee an audience.
Equally troubling to connoisseurs, the age of museums is not to be confused with the age of art or the age of art appreciation. Much museumgoing is not about art at all. It's simply social, rather like visiting a Barnes & Noble bookstore or meeting friends for a cappuccino. It's entertainment, not enlightenment or inspiration. It's a great date, a fun family outing.
"People want more activities, rather than a place for quiet contemplation," said Douglas D. Schultz, director of the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo. "It's gotten to the point where we have to be competitive with other venues for their entertainment dollars."
 
A Lady Named Mona Lisa And Other Blockbusters
Back in what might be described as the dark ages for museums, they were places in which the halls literally were dark, designed for contemplation and existing primarily for elite visitors. Nothing changed that as much as the blockbuster, which brought ordinary people into museums.
In popular lore, the blockbuster was fathered by the King Tutankhamen exhibition in 1977, and midwifed by Thomas Hoving, who during his time as director of the Metropolitan arranged a steady stream of them.
Actually, Mr. Kammen pointed out, a lady by the name of Mona Lisa single-handedly gave birth to the blockbuster some years earlier. In 1963, Leonardo's smiling, enigmatic masterpiece was lent by the Louvre for a brief visit to the National Gallery of Art in Washington and to the Metropolitan. She was mobbed. In New York alone, more than a million people stood in line between Feb. 7 and March 4, waiting hours to file past the painting. It was the largest crowd ever for a single painting at the Met and one of the largest crowds ever at the museum, period. Museum directors took note.
Then Tut, which went on a national tour, created a spectacle -- television coverage, riches from merchandise spinoffs and huge lines of new museumgoers in several cities. Soon, museums started seeking out these special "once in a lifetime" offerings. Today, like holidays invented by greeting card companies, they come around on a regular basis. And it is the rare large museum whose annual schedule does not contain at least one such show.
John R. Lane, who recently resigned as the director of San Francisco's Museum of Modern Art, explains the thinking behind that strategy with his two-audience theory. One group comes to a museum "because it wants to be challenged and to see something new," he said. "And there's another audience, a much bigger one, that is seeking a cultural experience and doesn't want to make a mistake. It won't go to the Museum of Modern Art to see a Projects show for a new artist, but it will go to MOMA to see a Picasso show."
It is no accident that at the moment, there are at least four Picasso shows: "The Dark Mirror: Picasso and Photography" at the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston; "Picasso: The Engraver -- Selections From the Musee Picasso, Paris" at the Metropolitan; "The Graphic Art of Pablo Picasso" at the Orange County Museum of Art in Laguna Beach, Calif., and the early Picasso exhibit in Boston. On Nov. 8, the High Museum of Art in Atlanta joins the crowd with "Pablo Picasso: Master Works From the Museum of Modern Art."
Impressionists like Monet and Renoir and Impressionism exhibitions tie or surpass Picasso's draw, and museums deploy the word whenever possible. The Metropolitan's 1994 exhibition "Origins of Impressionism," for example, was really a realist show of canvases painted in the 1860's. Impressionism officially began in 1874.
 
A Magic Bullet Called Marketing
As blockbusters grew in number, something else was happening. Well before their cousins in the performing arts, museums discovered marketing. Some of their campaigns are not yet as sleek and sophisticated as corporate campaigns, but as the millennium looms, "museums are clearly moving into the 20th century in terms of marketing," said Robert Bailey, a vice president at Audience Insight, a market research company that works for many arts groups.
They have had to. America's entertainment economy offers an exciting new experience at seemingly every turn. With only so much time for leisure, people are constantly winnowing winners from losers. Museums have taken up the challenge in the broadest sense.
The smart ones have thus capitalized on their inherent advantages by adding others. The Albright-Knox, for one, increased its family activity days, which help children explore an art theme with a short tour, a hands-on art project, a performance and a game. The Los Angeles County Museum of Art just extended its hours until 8 P.M. five days a week and 9 P.M. on Fridays to accommodate working people, even as the Modern in New York began opening a half hour earlier, at 10:30 A.M., to accommodate tourists. In Boston, the Museum of Fine Arts -- which recently started opening seven days a week -- will not close its doors until 10:30 P.M. on Fridays during the Picasso exhibition (and 9:30 P.M. on two other days).
Many museums have improved their labeling, lighting and audio guides. They've installed more seats and parking spots. They've improved the food in more restaurants with varying ambience and prices.
"Museums are becoming more and more enjoyable," said Glenn D. Lowry, director of the Modern. "We've made an enormous effort to become open, friendly places." Museums are now what tourism experts call destinations.
With what looks like a stroke of genius, museums have also targeted Americans where they live: at the shopping mall. The once-chaste stalls that used to hold art books and reproductions now teem with T-shirts, toys, baseballs, scarfs, playing cards, jewelry, tote bags, glassware, you name it -- often in displays that would do Bloomingdale's proud. (Nelson D. Rockefeller, who was pilloried for selling reproductions in the 1970's, would probably be amused.)
In the last five years, while gallery space at nearly 120 large museums was growing by 3 percent, the amount of space they gave to museum stores jumped by nearly 30 percent -- with good reason. Besides bringing in money, "these retail institutions have helped popularize museums," said Ms. Jeffri of Columbia.
 
Worrying About a Downside To the Museum Boom
Museums may be too popular, to some.
There is nothing sinister about mounting crowd-pleasing exhibitions or selling museum replicas. But plotting marketing strategies steals management time from art. As for the blockbusters, they are expensive, and having to offer them can lead museums to neglect or diminish whole areas of the art world, like conservation. It is well known that exhibitions of contemporary art disappoint when attendance figures are added up, even in large cities. Many museums continue to plow blithely ahead with less popular exhibitions anyway, but they may come to find that they do so at their economic peril.
"The gate is dependent on the exhibition program," said Mr. Lane, who after overseeing the move to a new San Francisco Modern two years ago had to offer exhibitions to lure 600,000 visitors a year, triple the old goal. "There is a direct relation between the exhibition program and the level of attendance, and there is a direct relationship between the level of attendance and sales at the museum store, and there is a direct relationship between the rental of space and an attractive exhibition. And the choice of exhibitions has a significant impact on the size of membership, because members get head-of-the-line privileges."
Cassandras worry that letting the box office influence programming will lead inevitably to exhibitions that sate the nation's abundant appetite for entertainment, rather than inspire. "It's a danger," conceded Mr. Bergman, who is also chairman of the American Association of Museums. "Given the economic pressures, we'll be under pressure to increase revenues, and moving down is a problem."
Marketing was on many minds at April's annual meeting of the association, whose members include historical societies and science centers as well as art museums -- and high culture's archenemy, the Walt Disney Company, was invoked many times for its ability to please crowds. Typical was a speech by a museum consultant, Kathleen Brown of Lord Cultural Resources, who said, "There are pieces of the Disney experience that are clearly resonating with people, and we need to figure out which ones to pick up."
Philippe de Montebello, the director of the Metropolitan, who has less reason to worry about this than his colleagues, shudders at such thoughts. He recently lamented the situation in a voice-in-the wilderness speech to other art professionals.
As museums pressed toward more marketing, more programs and more technology, he warned: "We should pause and reflect on the occurrence of an ever so subtle but real shift in emphasis on the part of the institution itself and the public alike from the work of art to the museum itself as the primary experience. When people say, 'Let's go to the museum,' increasingly they mean something rather different from 'Let's go and look at some pictures.' "
"The trouble is," Mr. de Montebello added, "that works of art, for the most part, are not fun. In fact, they can be difficult, challenging, even provocative, and they don't yield their message in the blink of an eye -- which is what is expected of people looking to have fun. Seriousness, uplift, knowledge and, naturally, pleasure are what art museums are meant to provide."
Mr. Bergman is more concerned about something that underlies museums' quandary: the shrinking, and graying, of the art-literate audience. "Kids are not getting exposed to music and art," he complained. "We worry that people will not have a visceral reaction because they are not being exposed to it." That is critical because as long as most American museums remain private rather than public institutions, "success is tied to their ability to develop sustained relations with their audience," said Mr. Lowry. That means more emphasis on converting visitors to members.
On that score, museums have mixed track records. Overall, membership is increasing slowly -- except where there is a major blockbuster. Then, once new members are through the door for a special exhibition, the trick becomes getting them to move on to the permanent galleries and thus renew -- which is where those new installations, better labels, audio guides and other ploys come in.
The alternative, or perhaps accompanying, strategy centers on special events. People -- particularly young people -- will join a museum to obtain invitations to exclusive social events. In July, for example, the Guggenheim held two Austrian wine tasting parties. Why? Well, it was also exhibiting "From Durer to Rauschenberg: A Quintessence of Drawings, Masterworks From the Albertina and the Guggenheim." It was a reach, but at least there was an art element; many museums are simply giving parties in their galleries.
These challenges do not undermine the fact that museums are on a high. But they do suggest there are tough choices to make about sustaining it.
Mr. Lowry, of the Modern, is an unalloyed optimist. Sitting in his sleek office overlooking the museum's sculpture court, he bristled when asked if these were gilded times. "Golden age implies a dark age before and a falloff in the future," he said. "I'm not convinced of the former premise or the latter. I think we're in a remarkable moment, which can be sustained over time." But it will, by common consent, take some work.

HEADLINE: The Problem: Getting There From Here

BYLINE: By JAMES LOMUSCIO 

 BODY:
OF all the projects and programs aimed at improving transportation in Connecticut over the past 20 years, the single most important event came by way of accident, a tragic one. It happened on June 28, 1983. At 1:30 A.M. that day a 100-foot northbound section of the Mianus River Bridge on the Connecticut Turnpike collapsed. Three people died and three more were injured as vehicles plunged into the shallow river in Greenwich.
Nearby residents would later say they heard some type of loud rattling days before as trucks traveled the bridge. And along with shock and outrage came endless questions. Was the Mianus River Bridge, which carried about 90,000 vehicles a day, an exception to an otherwise sound system, or was it symptomatic of a transportation system that for too long had been allowed to deteriorate? Soon, the Connecticut Department of Transportation was hurled into a crisis and put under national scrutiny. 
 "You have to look at Mianus as the single, biggest event because of the byproducts that came out of it," said Harold Harris, Deputy Commissioner of the Transportation Department. "It focused attention on the fact that we had allowed our infrastructure to deteriorate considerably."
How had poor maintenance left the state's roads and major thoroughfares dangerous? What was the role of the State Department of Transportation -- formed in 1969 to take over from the State Department of Highways in existence since 1895 -- in this life and death matter?
Actually, an infrastructure fund for transportation had been set up by the legislature around the time the new Department of Transportation was established to unite the Department of Aeronautics, the Connecticut Transportation Authority and the Commission of Steamship Terminals, as well as the Department of Highways.
But Connecticut's financial woes in the 70's refocused priorities. Dedicated transportation funds were funneled back into the state's general fund, "to pay other bills," said Mr. Harris. The situation got little attention until the Mianus River Bridge collapsed.
What followed was the General Assembly and then Gov. William A. O'Neill formulating and passing in February of 1984 a 10-year, $5.5 billion Transportation Infrastructure Renewal Program. The money was earmarked specifically for maintaining and improving the state's transportation system, including 364 structurally deficient bridges owned by towns and cities. The fund received money from a variety of sources, including gasoline taxes, Federal grants and general fund transfers.
Along with rehabilitating existing roads, the state moved ahead with new construction projects including: a flyover connector from eastbound Interstate 84 to northbound Interstate 91 in Hartford; a new Charter Oak Bridge connecting East Hartford and Hartford; the extension of Route 9, the central Connecticut expressway; the construction of high-occupancy vehicle, or H.O.V., lanes on Interstate 91 North and Interstate 84 east of Hartford; the completion of the first section of Super 7 in Norwalk, a road that has been the center of debate and legal wrangles in Wilton for more than 20 years, and the opening of Interstate 291 in Manchester in September of 1994, which marked the completion of Connecticut's Interstate system.
Meanwhile, the state's rail service got a long-overdue overhaul. In 1985 the Transportation Department and the Metropolitan Transit Authority of New York joined forces to create the Metro-North Commuter Railroad.
"Again, it allowed for the targeting of resources to help what had become a very bad railroad," said Mr. Harris. "There was a time when the wheels were literally falling off some of the trains. By creating the infrastructure program, we could invest more than $1 billion in rails and buses over the last decade."
The creation of Metro-North had a significant impact on southwestern Connecticut. Today, about 90 percent of the region's commuters to New York City ride the train. In 1990 the state initiated another commuter rail service, Shore Line East, which provides service between Old Saybrook and New Haven.
But with all the changes, the biggest challenge facing Connecticut seems to remain out of the Transportation Department's control: increased intrastate road traffic.
"Since 1973, highway travel has increased by 84 percent while the total road mileage has increased by less than 3 percent," says Susan Reynolds, a spokeswoman for the Transportation Department.
In spite of the high-occupancy vehicle lanes, the Federal Clean Air Act and carpooling initiatives like Metropool in Stamford, Rideworks in New Haven and the Rideshare Company in Windsor, not to mention corporate initiatives for employees to find alternate means to work, more vehicles are on the road. And many of them are gas-guzzling, four-wheel-drive, truck-type vehicles.
In fact, the number of registered motor vehicles in the state has grown at a rate that has outpaced population, and transportation officials now say Interstate 95 is at 180 percent of the rush hour capacity for which it was designed. Twenty years ago, it was said to be at 80 percent. Even the elimination of tolls -- phased out after a toll booth accident that killed seven people in Stratford in 1983 -- has not accelerated the rush hour commute. At the same time, says Ms. Reynolds, "we're not building any new roads."
"In the next 25 years, I would be surprised if you'll see more than 25 miles of new highway," said Emil Frankel, Commissioner of Transportation under Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. "You'll see selective improvements, but there definitely won't be a widening of I-95 or the Merritt Parkway."
Mr. Frankel noted that while the state's transportation system is now one of the best in the Northeast, the state cannot become complacent. He says his biggest concern right now is a movement to reduce the gasoline tax. He said the gas-tax cut would starve the transportation system while encouraging more people to drive. To generate more transportation revenue and to discourage more single-occupancy vehicles at drive time, Mr. Frankel even suggested reinstituting tolls.
"Not barricade tolls, but some kind of electronic toll technology," said Mr. Frankel, who is now a lawyer at Day, Berry & Howard in Stamford. "We should even consider instituting user fees to create revenue."
Christopher P. Bruhl, president of the Business Council of Southwestern Connecticut, works with the Coastal Corridor Coalition, a group of business, civic and environmental organizations from Branford to Greenwich. The group focuses on traffic's impact on local economies and their quality of life.
Mr. Bruhl blames increased traffic over the past 20 years on a phenomenon known as "edge cities," communities such as Stamford that have burgeoned outside of New York.
"Where they are commuting now is to Stamford, not Manhattan," he says about the intrastate traffic from as far away as New Haven.
But the transportation system designed in the 1950's and 60's was for a different Connecticut, one where factory workers commuted to Bridgeport and corporate riders as far east as Westport took the train to New York.
"We can't build more lanes on I-95, and we can't build another Merritt Parkway," said Mr. Bruhl. "All of those decisions have been made for us by history, by environmental policy, by funding and by legislation. You just can't do it.
"But we can change how people use the system," he added, saying that intrastate rail service can be increased, while more commuter parking lots can be built at eastern train stations.
One such initiative under way is a $35 million Intermodal Transportation Center planned for Bridgeport. It will link trains, buses, taxis and the ferry from Bridgeport to Port Jefferson, N.Y. In addition to transportation alternatives, Mr. Bruhl said companies have to take the lead in adjusting their own work days, using technology, perhaps, to let some employees work one day a week at home.
How crowded is the Connecticut Turnpike in southwestern Connecticut? The average rush hour speed in Stamford weekdays is about 26 miles per hour, said Mr. Bruhl, as about 7,300 cars daily between 7 and 8 A.M. go over a car-counting cable in Norwalk. Just decreasing that time slot volume by 5 percent, or 500 cars, via train travel or other means would increase speeds to about 44 miles per hour, he said.
Getting a small percentage of commuters to seek out alternative forms of travel, said Mr. Bruhl, "is a lot easier than dealing with the Western world's fascination with the automobile."
"The D.O.T. sees their role as building, maintenance, safety and operation," he said. "But their responsibility now is to also change how people use the system."

(Photographs by Janet Durrans for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Reinventing Cities In a Mixed Market

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
IN 1977 many big city dwellers were skeptical of reports that the third largest concentration of Fortune 500 companies after Manhattan and Chicago was in Fairfield County. More than 100 companies had moved to Connecticut by then, mostly out of New York City, and 33 of them were on the Fortune 500 list, about the same number as Chicago's.
Today the county and Stamford in particular have emerged as a major financial center in the northeastern megalopolis from Washington to Boston. Within the 38.3 million square feet of corporate offices in the county are 14 Fortune 500 companies and 31 Fortune 1000's. The completion of Swiss Bank's headquarters in Stamford will add 1.2 million square feet to the total. 
 Plans for a few new office buildings in Stamford and Norwalk are on the horizon, but nothing will be built until rents, now in the mid-$20's per square foot, reach the mid-$30's.
The rest of the state has had its ups and downs over the past two decades. Hartford's record one-hundredth of 1 percent office vacancy rate in 1981 rose precipitously with the downsizing of its insurance companies. "We are starting to come out of it but vacancies are at 24 percent," said William Farley, head of Farley-Whittier Real Estate.
New Haven and Bridgeport are attempting to reinvent themselves after years of economic stagnation. Bridgeport, stung by the state's refusal to allow a gambling casino to jumpstart its economy, is banking on a $50 million state bonding package to pay for several projects, including the mixed-use development of its Steel Point waterfront site, and a baseball stadium.
Seeking a substitute for lost manufacturing and shipping industries, New Haven is supplanting them with "education, the arts, and bio-medical research," said Barbara Pearce, the owner of H. Pearce Real Estate. The average price of a house is down to $70,000.
In Greenwich the average house, according to William Pitt Real Estate, costs $1,106,806, up from $726,261 in 1991. Wall Streeters flush with profits have sent home sales to record highs along the Gold Coast, and the shortage of land has generated a trend to buy a property, tear down the existing house and build a new, larger and more luxurious one.
Credit for Stamford's metamorphosis, said Jon Smith, the city's planning director from 1973 to 1993, goes to Robert Rich, president of the F. D. Rich Company. "His urban renewal plan was reviled unfairly by people who historically react unfavorably to change," said Mr. Smith. "He was at the head of a very short list of developers willing to tackle it. Westinghouse wanted to turn downtown into one big warehouse."
"Until the late 60's there was no office demand here," said Mr. Rich. "Redevelopment was scheduled to be light industrial and research." But when the New York Stock Exchange threatened to leave Manhattan, a few corporate executives decided it was time to re-establish their companies in the suburbs where they already lived, free of crime and crowds, and at lower cost.
"American Can went to Greenwich, Pepsico went to Purchase, and Olin came to Stamford," said Mr. Rich. Later he built the Landmark Building, Stamford Town Center mall, Marriott Hotel, Biltmore Apartments and some half-dozen major office buildings, filling in most of the 130-acre urban renewal excavation where small businesses, stores and dwellings had stood. Other developers followed with office buildings in Westport, Greenwich, Darien, Fairfield, Norwalk and Shelton.
At the same time, Arthur Collins, founder of the Collins Development Corporation, was challenging the notion that quality housing must be large, custom and set on a couple of acres. He obtained approval in Greenwich to build condominium homes on small lots at the 150-acre former Lyon Farm. An eager public snapped them up at $150,000 in the late 70's. It was called "cluster zoning," and it gave the builder additional units in exchange for dedicating a third of the acreage to the town as open space.
"It allowed people to live in the Greenwiches of the world for less than half the cost of a house," said Mr. Collins. Today Lyon Farm homes list for $650,00 to $1 million.
Mr. Collins went on to build offices and 1,325 luxury condominium units in Stamford, Greenwich, Shelton and the 19th-century waterfront of South Norwalk, until speculative construction ended in the real estate collapse of the 80's, bringing near-ruin to him and the Rich organization. Both companies lost substantial numbers of properties, but they have regrouped, with their sons joining the companies.
Rental housing, scorned by many Connecticut communities as potential slums, got a makeover in 1986 when Charles Berman, former head of Trammell Crow's northeastern real estate operations and now president of his own company, Avalon Properties, built 1,000 units in Middletown.
The units were typical of Avalon's clustered New England-style villages, with swimming pools, fitness rooms and basketball courts, common rooms and landscaping, priced at market rates. Occupancy rarely drops below 95 percent among the company's 2,781 units statewide. Apartments at Avalon Grove in downtown Stamford rent for more than $2,000 a month.
But Avalon continues to battle lawsuits brought by towns opposed to its use of Connecticut's 1989 Housing Appeals law, which permits developers to build more units in exchange for setting aside 20 percent of the total number of units at rents based on a state formula. Towns must prove that a project would be injurious to the general welfare in order to reject it.
A growing number of developers have applied the concept to single-family homes of around 1,700 square feet on small lots, popular with young couples, singles and empty nesters, but neighborhood resistance remains resolute. "I don't detect even grudging acceptance of the Housing Appeals law," said Timothy Hollister of the Hartford law firm of Shipman and Goodwin. "If anything, towns are becoming more sophisticated in opposing applications for these projects."
Lawsuits are also arising in communities where the Foxwoods Casino, operated by the Mashantucket Pequots, and the Sun Casino, run by the Mohegan, are enjoying phenomenal success. Residents of North Stonington and Ledyard fear that the Pequots are acquiring too much land and that towns are losing sovereignty.
"We have not seen an increase in residential construction, except by, and for the tribes," said Richard Erickson, director of the Southeastern Regional Planning Agency, "and there hasn't been any retail or food service developing." By attracting and keeping patrons inside, anticipating their every need and desire, the casinos effectively shut out local restaurants, shops and theaters.
Beautifully rural Litchfield County, where celebrities hide away in handsomely renovated farmhouses, remains largely unspoiled, because to get there one must take narrow, winding, infuriating Route 7. But New Milford, gateway to the county, has been discovered and is developing at a gallop with new housing and businesses, road and sewer improvements as well as school construction.
Wherever people move to escape high costs and get a piece of the good life, dozens of new Wal Marts, K-Marts, Home Depots, discount clubs and designer outlet stores follow, and so have malls. Connecticut has 17 of them, with more on the way.
Rank-and-file employees of Fairfield companies who could not afford to live near their jobs gravitated to hundreds of new exurban subdivisions offering homes at modest prices. Longer commutes were an acceptable tradeoff but they have turned Interstate 95, the Merritt Parkway and Route 7 into rush-hour parking lots. Housing development has also altered agriculture. New housing, built on land sold to developers by farmers, was a major force in reducing the 26,000 farms in the state in 1910 to 3,900 today.
Mark Costello of CB Commercial Real Estate, observed that "over the next 20 years we will need a more mixed economy -- more progress in the industrial sector, and transportation for labor to get to jobs."
He is also concerned about "the attrition of independent owners and developers to Real Estate Investment Trusts" like Reckson, which now owns the Landmark Building, and Equity Office Properties, owner of several major Stamford office buildings.
"And they are on the prowl for more," he said. "REIT's view buildings as pieces of a puzzle. The question is will they be as sensitive to local issues and philanthropic causes as the F. D. Riches and other local developers were?"

HEADLINE: Pioneer in the Nuclear Age, and in Its Steep Decline

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
WHEREVER America is going, Connecticut often seems to get there first, and that includes nuclear technology. The state was one of the first to jump in, and now seems on its way to being one of the first out.
The technology once seemed a natural fit for the state, which has only two traditional energy resources: the little bit of hydropower that nurtured its earliest industries, and the technological sophistication of its work force, from engineers to technicians to mechanics. It also has a thirst for energy for its high-tech factories, offices and homes. 
 But the idea that nuclear power is dependable and economical has come and gone over the past 20 years, and the idea that power can be cleanly, cheaply supplied by fossil fuels imported from far away has gone and then come back.
The changes are stunning. Twenty years ago, Connecticut Yankee was on its way to earning the record as the largest single nuclear producer of electricity in the world, in the vanguard of a wave of reactors that were supposed to total 1,000 by the turn of the century. Millstone 1 and 2 were helping to minimize the impact of oil price shocks, and Millstone 3, under construction, promised to further loosen the treacherous noose of oil dependency.
But that was not all. Stamford was headquarters to Combustion Engineering, which built nuclear reactors and in Uncasville, another firm built nuclear fuel. Electric Boat, in Groton, turned out a steady stream of nuclear-powered submarines and the United States Navy ran a landlocked submarine reactor in Windsor Locks, for training.
Almost all of that has gone away.
"We wouldn't have predicted it," said Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, of the industry's withering. "Ultimately, I think it's bad." Nuclear reactors can run well, he said, even if Northeast Utilities' reactors don't. "In Connecticut the problem is basically a screw-up in the management," he said. Someday, he said, more will be built. "Not tomorrow, but probably in a decade or more -- more like two or three decades -- we will come back to nuclear power because we'll be concerned about the impact of fossil fuels on the economy," he said. In the very long term, he said, "people will start to realize we're running out of fossil fuels."
Maybe so, but Northeast, which often got more than half its electricity from reactors, got just 28 percent last and this year it will be less.
Amazingly, the system still works. Everyone can see that, because the lights stay on and because a web page (http://www.cvx.com/) gives an up-to-the-hour picture of the balance between supply and demand.
But as a technology, nuclear power seems to be withering. Combustion Engineering was swallowed by a European conglomerate, Asea Brown Boveri, in 1990, and there are no nuclear reactors to build in this country; only a few around the world. The site of the nuclear fuel plant is prospering as a casino. Of the 259 power reactors ever ordered in this country, more than half were canceled. The Navy closed its training reactor, because it sends fewer crews to sea now. That has also cut most work at Electric Boat, which is building one last big attack submarine.
And Connecticut Yankee, reliable though it was for most of its life, turned out to be not worth running. Last month the state even argued that it has been poorly run, in a way that increased contamination and the decommissioning cost.
More stunning yet, though, is Millstone 3, a multibillion-dollar miscalculation. When ground was broken it was supposed to cost $400 million. By the mid 80's the price had risen to over $3.5 billion, but Northeast Utilities said its power would be cheaper than oil-fired power as early as 1989.
The utility hired a forecasting company, then called Data Resources Inc., which said that not only would oil be expensive, but that low-sulfur fuel, the kind Northeast burned, would reach $181 a barrel by the year 2000. If that seemed outrageous, Data Resources had company; the United States Department of Energy's Energy Information Administration predicted a world oil price of nearly $300 per barrel by then, assuming continuing high inflation. There seemed no alternative to pressing on.
But for the last few years oil has sold for about $20 a barrel. And most electricity comes from something even cheaper: natural gas. Twenty years ago, Connecticut was at the end of a very long natural gas pipeline from the Gulf Coast, meaning shortages for the state; now, it is in the middle, served by a pipeline from Canada as well, the Iroquois. "The Iroquois was a signpost of things to come," said James R. Shuckerow, the director of wholesale power contracts at Northeast. "No longer will New England be at the end of the pipeline. In many respects, we are at the beginning." Gas coming over the Iroquois is mostly from western Canada, but Mr. Shuckerow and others say that newly discovered gas in the Canadian Maritimes may put New England even nearer the beginning of the distribution system.
Joel M. Rinebold, the executive director of the Connecticut Siting Council, a state agency that passes judgment on each proposed new power plant, said that today, "There are more options and alternatives, as simple as that." These include conservation and new technologies that are just becoming competitive or are expected to be soon: solar cells, wind turbines and fuel cells, the latter manufactured in the state.
Those alternatives have had a profound effect on the value of Millstone 1 and 2, because they determine the value of a kilowatt-hour, and thus the value of the plants' output and therefore of the plants themselves. The Department of Public Utilities Control asked Northeast to recalculate reactor value on that basis, and in July the company said that the value to its customers of operating Millstone 1, as opposed to closing it, was a scant $68.9 million. Millstone 2 was $488 million.
People with long experience in the energy field, nuclear and otherwise, are stunned by the changes. Paul Blanch, for example, moved to Connecticut in 1966, as an instructor at the submarine reactor in Windsor Locks, and went on to become a nuclear engineer at Northeast Utilities. He, like the state, has made a long journey since then; he found technical flaws with nuclear reactors and said the company harassed him as a result; eventually the Nuclear Regulatory Commission agreed. He quit four years ago but was rehired in February, to help fix the company's nuclear problems.
Two years ago the four reactors represented about one-sixth of the capacity the state would need on a peak day, and to Mr. Blanch and many others, the idea of the state doing without all of them was impossible. "I didn't think we could possibly survive," he said. "It's all economics right now," said Mr. Blanch. "The Nuclear Regulatory Commission and the nuclear industry is well aware of the non-competitive or borderline competitive situation nuclear is in." Companies have been scrimping, he said, and the government is ignoring safety problems because "they have to not impose anything significant that's going to cause economic hardship on these utilities."
At the Connecticut Siting Council, Mortimer A. Gelston, the chairman, said that in the next year and a half the state as likely to see 1,500 megawatts of new natural gas-powered electric generating capacity. That is almost half as big as the shut-down nuclear capacity.
"We're going to be pretty dependent on gas, which bothers me," said Mr. Gelston. That fuel, he said, is "nothing but a stop gap measure to get us out of this hole we're in." He and others point out that at the time Millstone 3 was being built, natural gas was in such short supply that a Federal law barred construction of new plants using it. He, too, is surprised that the state has done well with no reactors. Of Northeast's executives, he said, "they all must have gone to church every Sunday to get through this year."
The constant factor is that nothing has been constant. Mr. Rinebold, of the siting council, also teaches a course in environmental issues at Central Connecticut State University in New Britain. As teaching materials he keeps the old Data Resources projections "as an example of the dynamics of our fuel supply," he said. "Even with the best projections, the best forecasts, things change."

HEADLINE: From Subs to Casinos, an Economic Upheaval

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
IF one were to compress the last 20 years of the the state's economy into just two points on a time line -- 1977 leaping directly across the years to 1997 -- the result would look as placid as the Connecticut River in October, taking its own sweet time, going nowhere in particular.
Total employment would appear to have inched up at a slow-growth pace of around 1.3 percent a year, and some industries -- like banking, which employs about the same number of people in the state today as it did during the administration of President Jimmy Carter -- would look as if they'd barely changed at all. 
 But that is not what happened, of course, and placid is the last word one should use to describe those two tumultuous decades. Like the scene in "Fantasia," when the age of the dinosaurs comes to its climactic close -- earthquakes splitting the land and new mountains suddenly thrusting themselves up -- much of Connecticut's economic landscape was reshaped over the last 20 years. The period began quietly and ended quietly, but the middle years still resonate.
Huge new industries, like casino gambling, arose from nothing. Military hardware manufacturing shuddered and fell. Once powerful cities like Hartford and New Haven stumbled, while others, notably Stamford, ascended, shifting the state's economic center of gravity to the south. New kinds of manufacturing took root, and smaller companies increasingly became the engines of job growth. Exports and connections to the world economy became increasingly crucial.
The job growth that looks so calm when stretched over decades was in fact, on a year-to-year basis, more like white water rapids. Almost all of it occurred in a burst in the 1980's, followed by a sharp fall at the decade's end. After five years of economic recovery from that last recession, Connecticut still has fewer jobs than it did a decade ago.
"Connecticut has experienced more variation in the last 20 years, economically, than any state in the nation," said William A. McEachern, a professor of economics at the University of Connecticut. "We've seen it all."
Banks are perhaps the starkest example of what happened: Through the 1980's, as the industry was deregulated, Connecticut saw an explosion of growth. The number of banking jobs in the state rose by 63 percent in just 11 years, to 44,000 in 1988 from about 27,000 in 1977.
Then, with the onset of the recession, all that growth, and more, was erased. The reversal was symbolized for many residents in early 1991 when the venerated Connecticut Bank & Trust, with its classically buttoned-down blue C.B.T. signs, was taken over by Federal regulators. In the years that followed, more than 24,000 banking jobs were eliminated, according to the state's Department of Labor.
The surging economic changes in turn had political and social implications. The boom and bust cycle of the 1980's made, and then broke, the political career of one governor, William A. O'Neill, and colored nearly every act of his successor, Lowell P. Weicker Jr. as he struggled to deal with a huge recession-driven deficit in the state budget. Residents saw the national image of their state transformed -- from an example of burnished, how-to-get-it-done success in the mid-1980's into a symbol of the decade's excess and bloated over-optimism just a few years later.
"The engines of growth have all changed," said Donald L. Klepper-Smith, who tracked the state's economy for 18 years at Southern New England Telephone before starting his own economic and demographic consulting firm, called DataCore Partners, last year. Mr. Klepper-Smith says he believes a key theme of the last two decades has been the breaking down of the old state economy based around a few immense pillars -- manufacturing, military and insurance -- and its replacement by dozens of smaller specialized industries that Mr. Klepper-Smith believes are ultimately building a stronger and more stable economy.
The new Connecticut economy can be seen at places like Startech, a Wilton-based company that began manufacturing this year, in association with a Canadian company, a high-tech waste-incineration system that burns at temperatures approaching 40,000 degrees Fahrenheit -- hot enough to return materials to their original atomic components. The company has only 20 employees so far, but -- crucially -- has chosen Connecticut as the place where it will manufacture its machines.
The new economy can also be seen in places like Stamford, which has become an increasingly important national center in a particular niche of the insurance industry -- the reinsurance business -- even as the mainstream insurance industry's historic home along the corridor running from Hartford to New Haven has retreated and retrenched.
And the change can be seen in the state's southeastern corner, where a new economic pillar has emerged in casino gambling and tourism. Beginning in 1992 with the rise in Ledyard of the Foxwoods High Stakes Bingo and Casino, and then last year of the Mohegan Sun Casino in Uncasville, entertainment and tourism jobs have surged in number even as the old military industrial empire of Electric Boat declined. Foxwoods, owned by the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe, now employs 11,400 people; the Sun employs about 5,200. That total, by sheer coincidence, is almost exactly the number of jobs that Electric Boat has eliminated in the region in recent years.
Economists say that part of what makes 1977 seem like another world entirely is that so many different business cycles found their peaks and troughs in this one period. Beginning in 1979, for example, there were two sharp back-to-back recessions, followed by an explosive period of growth that then ended with the deepest economic downturn since the 1930's, a period that Mr. McEachern, the professor of economics, has dubbed, "The Great Recession."
In the world of military contracting, the state was also entering a new cycle of procurement in 1977, as the military and the industry were, in Pentagon parlance, "ramping up," for a new generation of war machines. At Electric Boat, two whole classes of submarines for the Navy were then in the initial stages of construction that year -- The Los Angeles and the Trident -- which would both peak their production years in the mid 1980's, and keep 25,000 workers employed for years. The eighteenth and final boat in that combined series -- the last Trident sub -- was commissioned just last month.
Another quirk of the last two decades, economists say, is that for much of it, Connecticut -- in one extreme or another -- was wildly out of sync with the rest of the nation.
The chief economist for the Fleet Financial Group, Nicholas S. Perna, said he remembered driving on Interstate 84 to his office in Hartford in 1987 or 1988, and seeing motel after motel filled by construction workers from places like Louisiana and Florida who had come North for the work and the high wages, as Connecticut's own internal labor market had become overwhelmed by the surging demand. "Those were the best times that people had seen in a long time," Mr. Perna said.
Then in the recession that followed, when the state lost 9.5 percent of all its jobs -- more than New Jersey or New York state and far more than the rest of the nation, which saw only 2 percent job losses -- the downturn was compounded by forces that again seemed unusually focused in the state: the end of the cold war, a drop off in commercial aviation orders and the sudden, immense pressure to cut costs in labor-intensive industries like insurance.
But 1997 looks in many ways like an echo of 1977. The state's economy seems to have entered a period of relative calm, growing but not booming. Economists say that the restructuring of the economy over the years also put the state more with in line the national economic rhythm than it has been at probably any time in the last two decades, which could dampen the highs, but also soften the lows in the future cycles to come.
"It's back to the future," said Mr. McEachern. "In 1977 we were getting ready for the 80's -- I still remember how exciting that sounded: "the 80's," he said. "Now we're getting ready for the millennium."

HEADLINE: Those Were The Days . . .

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
AS years go, 1977 was a pretty good one in Connecticut. The economic outlook was so bright that some workers, sure they could always find a job elsewhere, went on strike to get more of a piece of the pie. Teachers in Waterbury and Greenwich walked picket lines, musicians struck the Hartford Symphony, gravediggers held up picket signs at Catholic cemeteries.
In the capitol city of Hartford, old and sometimes historic buildings were being ripped down while new office towers were rising and The Hartford Courant could report that in an era of decline in downtown districts around the country, Hartford was building "on its reputation as a rare success story." 
 The atmosphere was so heady that the most heated debate of the year was not over ponderous subjects like taxes or schools or minority rights. It was about some rocks. An artist, Carl Andre, had been hired, for $87,000, to elevate a small city green into a work of art. So he got 36 boulders and arranged them to suggest, he said, Connecticut's geological past. That was it. An uproar followed over what is, or is not, art.
The years since have seen monumental change. The economy soured. Many industries failed or went South, along with a lot of people. The state's three biggest cities, Hartford, Bridgeport and New Haven, became poor and agitated. It will never be identified as the state's happiest period. But it was a fascinating one, for good and bad, with an interesting cast of characters strutting and fretting across its stage.
William A. O'Neill racked up more time as governor -- 10 years, 10 days -- than any other person in that office since Jonathan Trumbull in the Revolutionary War era. And a Mayor of Bridgeport, Mary C. Moran, gained a smaller measure of fame by attempting to declare her city bankrupt.
The roof of the Hartford Civic Center, laden with ice from a wet and cold winter, fell in. It was replaced in two years for games of the Hartford Whalers -- only to see the team eventually skate down to North Carolina, amid the near hysterical wail of fans and sports writers.
The state's legal drinking age also fell, to as low as 18, and then went by steps back up to 21, causing great anguish among some young people who had to keep changing birth dates on identification cards.
Thirman L. Milner of Hartford became the first black person elected as Mayor of a New England city and the Waterbury Mayor, Joseph J. Santopietro, went to prison for taking illegal payments from developers, tax evasion and embezzlement.
Nathan Hale of Revolutionary War fame became the official state hero and Prudence Crandall, who started a school for young black women in the last century, became an official state hero, both by action of the General Assembly.
A phenomenon known as Husky Mania gripped the state as the University of Connecticut's men's and women's basketball teams shot to new and dizzying heights. When the women's team became the national collegiate champion in 1995, its two aces, Rebecca Lobo and Jennifer Rizzotti, became modern state heroes, by popular acclaim if not by legislative dictum.
Benjamin J. Sisti and Jonathan Google became unofficial state villains by bilking hundreds of people out of millions of dollars in a real estate scam that really gave white collar crime a bad name.
In a supreme twist of fate, two small Indian tribes, the Mashantucket Pequots and the Mohegans, the first nearly totally destroyed in the Colonial period and the other in peril of being removed from the state by the Federal Government in the last century, became incredibly wealthy through establishing gambling casinos on their reservations. Now the Indians are fawned over by bankers and builders and politicians, if not by neighbors of their domains, who say can't get out of their driveways because of the cars whizzing by on the way to the casinos.
The Nautilus, the world's first atomic submarine, returned home to Connecticut as a permanent tourist attraction but the four nuclear plants in the state were all shut down because Federal regulators were not satisfied with the safety record of Northeast Utilities, the state's main supplier of electric power, or its treatment of whistle blowers.
One man became almost a household name because he disappeared. Victor Gerena was a guard for the Wells Fargo Armored Service Corporation until one day in 1984 when he tied up two fellow employees in West Hartford and disappeared with $7 million in cash, the second-biggest robbery in the country up to then. The government claimed the money was stolen to finance a campaign by Los Macheteros, a Puerto Rican nationalist group, to overthrow the United States presence on the island, and four members of the group were convicted in Federal Court in Hartford in 1989 for roles in the robbery. But Victor? Despite 13 years of wanted posters and a $500,000 reward, he has not been seen since.
The Hartford Board of Education hired a private company, Educational Alternatives, to run the city's schools. Then the Board fired the company, followed by the state firing the Board. People wondered why children in the city's schools were not learning much.
A hurricane named Gloria knocked out the lights of more than half the state's homes. Tornados are not given names but one that could be called Mr. Mean cut a three-mile swath through Windsor Locks and left vintage planes at Bradley International Airport scattered all about, like a scene from World War II.
Danbury State Fair, 112 seasons old and the state's biggest, gave way to a newer symbol of the times, a shopping mall.
Although Connecticut will never be taken for Mississippi, the Ku Klux Klan did make a few forays into the state, most noticeably a demonstration in Meriden in which the local police complained they did not get enough support from the State Police. At the next Klan event, a cross burning in Windham County, the police outnumbered Klansmen and spectators combined.
The state's General Assembly in 1980, should have received a most-effective-gimmick award for a last-ditch effort to avoid a state income tax. Such a tax had traditionally been a taboo subject, not even to be whispered, because legislators just knew that if the state adopted such a tax all the folks in Fairfield County who had fled the New York income tax would move back, leaving Fairfield a vast wasteland.
So the state budget was balanced by taxing gross receipts of oil companies doing business in the state. The affected oil companies noted they would simply pass the cost along to consumers in Connecticut. But by that time the legislators were in hiding.
Connecticut finally did get an income tax, in 1991, through the auspices of Lowell P. Weicker Jr. A three-term Republican United States Senator who lost his race for a fourth term and then decided he would enjoy being Governor. So he formed his own party, called A Connecticut Party, and ran, pledging no income tax. He won and changed his mind about an income tax. At an anti-tax rally on the State Capitol grounds, an estimated 40,000 cheered as the Governor was hanged in effigy. Mr. Weicker decided he wanted to spend more time with his family and declined to run again. In the last state election, John G. Rowland, a Republican Mr. Weicker had beaten, finally won the governor's job with only 36 percent of the vote in a three-way race.
The income tax remains. Like the rocks in the little park in Hartford, it may be eternal.

HEADLINE: Legacy of One-Party Rule and the 'Pledge'

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

 BODY:
WHEN Ella T. Grasso won her second term as Governor nearly 20 years ago, two basic truths prevailed in Connecticut politics: the Democratic Party called the shots, and its leaders were adamantly opposed to an income tax.
Today, those rules have been turned upside down. The Democrats lost the races for Governor in 1990 and 1994. And one year after the first defeat, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., an independent, narrowly passed a state income tax, largely with the support of Democratic lawmakers. 
 Yet, with another election coming up next year, politics in this state continues to revolve around the Democratic legacy and the income tax.
In 1998, Gov. John G. Rowland, a Republican, may face a challenge from United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, the daughter of the state's former Democratic party boss, John Bailey. Her candidacy evokes the glory days of a well-oiled Democratic organization that was not weakened by internal strife, and it also poses a fundamental question: Are people ready to return to a Democratic Party that no longer views the income tax as electoral poison? "The public's perception has obviously changed," said Edward L. Marcus, the state's Democratic Party chairman who once opposed the income tax but now accepts it as a fact of life. "I don't doubt that Rowland will campaign again on eliminating the income tax, but people will not believe him. They will see it as strictly a campaign ploy."
Mr. Rowland, who in the 1994 contest promised to wipe out the income tax by 2000, disagreed. "The Democrats don't have a prayer," he said in a recent interview. "They can never get to where we are on tax issues," a reference to his claim to have cut the tax rate by one-third for as many as half of the state's taxpayers.
The Democrats still maintain a strong grip on state politics. They control both houses of the General Assembly, four out of the state's six seats in the House of Representatives and both seats in the Senate. If they can add the governor's office to their list next year, their hold will approach the lock on power that they enjoyed in much of the 1970's and 1980's.
But the party organization's influence has changed from the days of Mrs. Grasso, widely identified as Mr. Bailey's last political candidate, and her successor, Gov. William A. O'Neill.
Mr. Bailey, who controlled the state political party from 1946 until his death in 1975, "directed the most efficient Democratic machine of the Atlantic Coast," the journalist Theodore White wrote in "The Making of the President 1960" (Atheneum Publishers, 1961). In his heyday, no decision was made in the legislature without his approval.
Under Mrs. Grasso, who first took office in 1975, the party organization declined. "No one missed John Bailey more than Ella Grasso," Senator Joseph I. Lieberman wrote in his book, "The Legacy: Connecticut Politics 1930-1980" (Spoonwood Press, 1981). "His absence was a major reason why her first year as governor was one of the unhappiest of her life."
The General Assembly had become more independent, having established its own nonpartisan budget and research agencies a few years earlier. Legislative staff positions were no longer the sole province of the party chairmen, but either impartial civil service hires or political appointments by legislative leaders. The legislature's newfound power was demonstrated in 1988 when the state opened the $53 million Legislative Office Building to accommodate its growing workload and staff.
Also during this period, rifts within the Democratic Party became more prominent. Before Mrs. Grasso won re-election to her second term in 1978, she faced a primary fight from her own Lieutenant Governor, Robert Killian, a dispute that once would have been unimaginable. Eight years later, Mr. O'Neill, who took over when Mrs. Grasso resigned in ill health in 1980, was challenged by the Democrat and former Congressman Toby Moffett.
True, under Mr. O'Neill the party still retained clout. David McQuade, an aide to Mr. O'Neill, recalled that the governor would make no appointment without first clearing it with the party chairman from the town where the appointee lived.
Yet by the time Mr. O'Neill stepped down from office in 1990, the party was in disarray. The party lever, which allowed voters to cast all votes for the party line and made it cumbersome to split the ticket, had been dropped in 1986, meaning candidates relied even less on their parties. By 1990, unions and progressive groups that began recruiting their own legislative candidates a decade earlier, had succeeded in electing several dozen liberal lawmakers who were not beholden to the party hierarchy.
In a sign of how twisted politics had become in Connecticut, a group of conservative Democrats broke with liberals in their party and joined with Republicans in 1989 to oust liberal Speaker of the House Irving Stolberg and give the job to State Representative Richard Balducci, a moderate Democrat.
Last year, for the first time in recent history, the number of registered voters who were unaffiliated with either party surpassed the number of registered Democrats. (Democrats continue to outnumber Republicans by about 200,000, with 670,000 in 1996 to the Republicans' 470,000.)
These troubles reflect the changing political landscape that led to the Democrats' loss of the governor's office and the passing of the income tax.
Before Mr. Weicker's election in 1990, his two predecessors, Mr. O'Neill and Mrs. Grasso, had taken what was known as the "pledge," a vow to never consider an income tax. "If anybody showed up in their office demanding an income tax," said Tom Scott, a Republican who organized the 40,000-person "Repeal the Tax" rally in late 1991, "they would have shown them the door."
This arrangement fell apart at the end of the 1980's when the state fell into a deep recession. The state budget, which relied heavily on a sales tax that varied heavily with the economy, began running a serious deficit. Mr. O'Neill's popularity plummeted, and he chose not to seek re-election.
The 1990 race was a turning point. The state needed to address its fiscal crisis. The choice was either draconian cuts or an income tax. The Democratic candidate said he would put the issue of the income tax to voters in a referendum. The Republican candidate, Mr. Rowland, took the "pledge."
And Mr. Weicker, a former Republican Senator who had lost his seat in 1988 and was making the run as an independent, fudged. While he likened an income tax to "pouring fuel" on the fire of recession, he also said everything was on the table. Several liberal Democrats, who saw Mr. Weicker as their best hope for an income tax, swung behind him.
Mr. Weicker won 40 percent of the vote, defeating Mr. Rowland by three percentage points.
In August 1991, after an eight-month legislative battle that involved Mr. Weicker vetoing three budgets that did not include an income tax, he and the liberal wing of the Democratic party, joined by a handful of Republicans, passed the tax without a vote to spare in either chamber.
Today, the political ramifications are still being sorted out.
Mr. Scott, a former State Senator who ran as an independent anti-income tax gubernatorial candidate in 1994, recently said that Mr. Rowland would not have won in his second bid for the office, if he had not taken the pledge again. Mr. Scott's candidacy is widely credited with pressuring Mr. Rowland to promise to eliminate the tax, after he initally called for only reducing it.
In turn, Democrats insisted that the income tax was not a decisive issue in the 1994 election and that their defeat was an aberration resulting from the vagaries of a race that had not only a Democrat and Republican but two strong independent candidates, including Mr. Scott and Mr. Weicker's Lieutenant Governor, Eunice Groark, a strong income tax supporter who received 19 percent of the vote.
Mr. Rowland won with 36 percent, against the Democrat, William E. Curry Jr.'s 33 percent and Mr. Scott's 11.
Three years after Mr. Rowland took office, the income tax still accounts for about one-fourth of the state's revenues -- even with Mr. Rowland's cuts. And it remains a pivotal issue in the coming election.
Democrats, who now focus on reducing property taxes, will undoubtedly harp on Mr. Rowland's apparent failure to live up to his promise to eliminate the income tax.
In turn, Mr. Rowland will cast the Democrats as the party that passed the tax.
"Obviously, I've reduced the income tax every year," Mr. Rowland said. "And every step of the way the Democrats fought me on cutting it."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
A Supermarket for Struggling Hartsdale Downtown

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD

DATELINE: HARTSDALE

 BODY:
THE long-awaited opening of a new supermarket, a needed anchor to this hamlet's struggling downtown, is scheduled today on East Hartsdale Avenue. It promises to enliven a shopping district that has lost much of its vitality because of chronic vacancies.
The I.G.A. supermarket will occupy a 6,500-square-foot space vacated by Gristede's in 1994. Its much ballyhooed opening represents the culmination of a concerted effort by the Town of Greenburgh and the local retail community to replace Gristede's with another food operator willing to do business in a small downtown. 
 "Over the years, I turned away other potential tenants for the space," said Toby Ritter, whose family owns approximately 25,000 square feet of space in downtown Hartsdale. "I wanted to hold out for a supermarket because I felt that was in the best interest of the community."
Mr. Ritter acknowledges that his position put a real strain on the downtown and that it might have been easier to lease the space sooner. "It was a big hardship for the other merchants," he said. "Some of my tenants were really struggling and when I could provide breaks in their rents I did."
After Gristede's closed, there was a 40 percent drop-off in business, according to a study conducted by the town's Planning Department. "There was a momentum of everything going downhill," said Paul Feiner, Supervisor of the Town of Greenburgh. Within the last year , he pointed out, the downtown has lost a bookstore, a Hallmark's card store and Whittaker's, a well-known local pharmacy.
The Hartsdale business district, an eighth-of-a-mile strip near the Metro-North train station, is bordered by the Bronx River Parkway on one side and a phalanx of co-op apartment buildings stretching to Central Park Avenue on the other. Like many other town centers, it has fallen prey to economic vagaries in recent years and was largely ignored in favor of the plethora of nearby shopping centers and the malls in White Plains.
But many residents, particularly those living in co-ops along East Hartsdale Avenue, valued the convenience of walking to a food store, rather than having to travel by car to larger supermarkets on Central Avenue, according to Jerry Cohen, president of the co-op board at 180 East Hartsdale Avenue, the apartment building closest to the shopping district. "We have a lot of seniors who can't easily get to the other stores," Mr. Cohen said. "Frankly I don't know what they have been doing."
To remain vacant for so long while waiting for a supermarket was risky at best, Mr. Ritter said, since supermarket chains are loath to lease downtown because of space limitations and a too-small business base.
Gabriel Scavello, the owner of the Hartsdale I.G.A., said the size of the store did concern him. "This is actually a pretty small store for I.G.A.," otherwise known as the Independent Grocers Alliance, a franchise company. "Their stores are usually 20,000 to 30,000 square feet."
Mr. Scavello said he had been interested in the location for a long time. "I love the area and wanted to be in Westchester," he explained. He said he thought the location was particularly ideal for his business because of its proximity to a wide variety of customers.
"We're near Scarsdale on one side and Central Avenue on the other," Mr. Scavello explained. "That's a very diverse group of customers and we'll be able to serve them all."
HE plans to offer an asortment of merchandise that will include fresh produce, meats and fish, as well as imported and prepared foods. "We'll have every price point, from the most expensive to store brands."
To catch the commuters who pour through the train stations in the mornings and evenings, the store will be open from 7 A.M. to 9 P.M. "People can run in to get an egg sandwich and coffee to go in the morning," Mr. Scavello said. "And they can get a prepared supper to take home at night."
Mr. Feiner considers Hartsdale the center of unincorporated Greenburgh. "It's a symbol," he said. "In the past, when people got off the train, they saw a street that had no pride. Now, hopefully, they'll see a lot of activity."
He said that he had made the improvement of Hartsdale a priority of his administration. Recently the town installed new wrought-iron lampposts and refurbished DiSanti Plaza, a little sitting park near the train station.
Mr. Feiner has also hired a planning and design team to develop long-term strategies.
"We still need to examine the underlying symptoms of why the supermarket went out," he said. "We don't want to just repeat this process in another few years."
A marketing survey has already been sent out to merchants and residents. "That's always our first step," said John Shapiro, a partner in Abeles Phillips Preiss & Shapiro, Manhattan-based planning and real estate consultants.
"Before making any recommendations, we need to know what people like and what they feel is missing," Mr. Shapiro said. "I don't think we need to reinvent the wheel here. Hartsdale is an intrinsically charming downtown, but something's off. It should be a high quality miniature shopping center."
Stephanie Bellino, president of Blum & Bellino, a real estate brokerage, said Hartsdale's troubles had been caused more by economic conditions than any failed strategy. "I wouldn't attribute the problems 100 percent to the lack of a supermarket," she said. "Even without it, we've been able to find tenants. When some businesses go under, it's their own fault."
Ms. Bellino, who recently announced her candidacy for Town Supervisor, disagrees with the need to hire outside consultants. She points to the Cheesery, a cheese shop in Hartsdale that is moving to larger quarters. "I already have someone lined up for the space they're leaving," she said.
And Ms. Bellino noted that the former Whittaker's space was the only major vacancy left in the downtown, and that Rockwell's, the pub/restaurant chain is reportedly interested in leasing it. The space is owned by Mr. Ritter, who said he was "inches away from inking the deal with Rockwell's." It would be the fourth Rockwell's in Westchester.
When word got out, there was some concern from other food operators about the competition. "But Rockwell's is such an attractive tenant and such a generator of activity, I don't think people will object too much," Mr. Ritter said.
For Mr. Feiner, it's like a dream come true. "Everything's happening at the same time," he said. "It's great, but now we've got to figure out how to make it last."
