HEADLINE: Over the Years, Government Has Taken a More Visible Role

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
TWENTY years ago, 2000 seemed so far away that the various government and civic groups that would later be formed to study how to prepare for the millennium had not been thought of yet.
It was a time when Westchester was obsessed with its high electric rates and prepared for a public referendum on a plan to oust Con Edison. One of the biggest issues of the day was what to do with the ever-increasing amount of garbage that county residents and businesses generated, because the Croton Landfill was under a long-standing court order to be closed in 1981. 
 In 1977, there was no significant number of the homeless in Westchester, but there was a severe shortage of what was called affordable housing. The State Legislature had not yet financed a 10-year parkway improvement plan for Westchester; there was no such village as Rye Brook, and General Motors was happily settled in the village of North Tarrytown, which had not yet been renamed Sleepy Hollow. The business story of the time was that Texaco was about to move its world headquarters to Harrison.
At the time Alfred B. DelBello could not have predicted that within five years he would resign first as Westchester County Executive and then a year later as the state's Lieutenant Governor. State Senator Joseph R. Pisani of New Rochelle contemplated running for Governor; Representative Bruce Caputo was waging a war in Congress against the latest political scandal, nicknamed Koreagate; State Senator Linda Winikow of New City (whose district included Greenburgh) was a few years away from making waves about the state's divorce laws, and Jacob Javits seemed a permanent institution in the United States Senate. Within just a few years, they would all be political has-beens: Mr. Pisani and Mrs. Winikow would be indicted and convicted, while Mr. Caputo would fade into the background after he falsely claimed on his resume to have served in Vietnam. Mr. Javits would lose a three-way election that would propel an upstart, Alfonse M. D'Amato to the Senate; one of his earliest supporters in Westchester was Andrew P. O'Rourke, then Chairman of the County Board of Legislators.
And in 1977, the county-owned Westchester County Medical Center was yet to open, and when it did a short time later it was to empty beds and amid concern -- particularly from other hospitals -- that the region did not need another hospital. There was talk about closing it entirely. The Republicans dominated countywide politics, holding 33 of the 35 judgeships in the region. (Today there are about 11 Democrats). The only countywide Democrat elected to office was Mr. DelBello. Yet to come was the first -- and only -- Democratic County Clerk, Andrew J. Spano. Back then, the Republicans outnumbered Democrats in enrollment by about 40,000; today, it is the reverse, and that major political shift has led to a near-solid political alliance between the Republican and Conservative Parties.
Government was expanding, with new departments and offices being created; the idea of downsizing and the privatization of government services -- a current controversial issue -- had not yet specifically emerged.
But a hot issue of the moment was whether the elected office of sheriff should be abolished and its functions merged with the Parkway Police. It was a different time in some ways, but Yonkers was dealing with a lawsuit that ultimately found it guilty of discrimination in housing; and the Westchester County Courthouse in White Plains, completed three years earlier, was crumbling.
In the last two decades, county government has been relatively free of scandal. The notable exception came to light in 1989 when the State Commission on Government Integrity held hearings in Westchester and investigated the relationship between political patronage and government jobs and contracts. In 1990 the commission criticized the overly close relationship between Republican Party leaders and county officials.
Life has changed in Westchester, and events have proved the adage that the more things change the more they stay the same. Some problems, like what to do about garbage, have been solved with the construction of a garbage-to-energy incinerator in Peekskill and the institution of recycling programs. Only when their memory is jarred, do people remember the controversy over abolishing the Sheriff's Office. In contrast, other problems, like high taxes caused in some part by social service programs, remain an issue. Still other problems, never dreamed of 20 years ago, like the housing of the homeless, have surfaced.
Evelyn M. Stock, a Scarsdale resident who is president of the New York State League of Women Voters and served as president of the Westchester Chapter from 1985-87, said: "Is the county a better place to live in? I guess the fact that it is still a good place -- with all the downsizing of companies and other economic problems -- is remarkable in itself.
"I think we've done well with welfare and workfare, with maintaining and adding to our open space, among other things. As far as I can tell, the problems of housing are the biggest ones facing Westchester. But government officials are doing what they can to try to make this a county in which you like to live. Unfortunately, it's a very expensive place."
Herman D. Geist, a Republican who was chairman of the Board of Legislators from 1970 to '73 and has remained active in various volunteer posts, said that he thought the quality of life in the county was better years ago, but that "I couldn't think of living any place else." On The plus side, he said, was the continued improvement of Westchester Community College, the cleanup of the Hudson River, the closing of the Croton Point Landfill and expansion of the sewage system throughout the county. On the minus side, Mr. Geist complained that the so-called old guard has left office and the "the new guard doesn't have the historical background."
Old guard or new guard, there has been one constant over the last 20 years, Mr. DelBello, the former County Executive, said: the county government has become more visible and more active since his tenure.
"When I ran for County Executive for the first time in 1973, the county government was basically invisible," he recalled.
"After I was elected, I introduced a series of things: bicycle Sundays, offices for senior citizens, for youth, for women and the free Philharmonic concerts. We also started attacking some very significant problems, such as solid waste and what to do about the Medical Center. All of this turned the government from a limited-purpose government to one that worked to get things done. There was a level of excitement in the 70's that doesn't seem to exist today. People were much more civically involved. We had so many volunteers, and people used to come out at night for meetings. Today, you don't get that. It seems like people are going home extremely tired, with both the husband and wife working, and have less interest in becoming involved."
Mr. DelBello, elected in 1973, was the first and only Democrat in that office. He resigned in 1983 to become Lieutenant Governor and then resigned that position two years later to take a corporate job. He is in private law practice but has come full circle in one way -- he was recently appointed the interim chairman of the Westchester County Health Care Corporation, which will govern the County Medical Center. It was during Mr. DelBello's term in office that the direction of the Medical Center was changed to specialized care -- a decision that probably saved it.
Anthony J. Colavita, who was the chairman of the Westchester Republican Committee from 1979 until 1995 and of the State Republican Committee from 1985-89, said he believed the county gets better every day.
Mr. Colavita, who is a lawyer with the State Insurance Department, said, "Obviously, the county has changed in all ways, not only governmentally but politically, with there now being close to 40,000 more Democrats than Republicans." He credited the county government, under Mr. O'Rourke, with rebuilding the County Center, opening a recycling center in Yonkers, reducing welfare costs and "cutting back on spending and taxation, which I think is the No. 1 problem facing counties like Westchester.
"People like Westchester, but they don't want to spend a lot of money to keep it that way," he added.
Those interviewed for this article agreed that the greatest challenge for Westchester in the years ahead is to find ways to keep taxes down while maintaining the services and frills that people are accustomed to having.
Mrs. Stock of the League of Women's Voters said she believes that so far the county has been able to cut spending without significantly reducing services for the needy and its support for parks and cultural programs. She predicted that such a balance would continue to be harder to achieve in the future.
She also argued that campaign-finance reform is crucial to insure the integrity of the political system. The league had supported a plan to have public financing of some Westchester elections, but the Board of Legislators last summer could not override Mr. O'Rourke's veto of a resolution that was the first step toward accomplishing that.
"The risk is more for the future, for the next 20 years," she said.

O'Rourke, who is not running for re-election, center, and Andrew J. Spano, former County Clerk who is running for county executive. (Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Before Downsizing, Jobs Seemed Secure in a 'Golden Age'

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
IN 1977, employees of International Business Machines wore white shirts to work and were virtually dismissal proof. Westchester had only three major hotels, and the first visitors and convention bureau was organized. Companies were leaving Manhattan in droves to resettle in the county. And 500 automotive workers were on the General Motors plant payroll in North Tarrytown.
The year "was the dawn of Westchester's golden age, the prelude to the up-up-up-skies-the-limit mood of the 80's," said Thomas Spitznas, an economist based in Mount Vernon. "But over-inflated expectations brought about over building, followed by the stock market crash of October 1987, triggering seven lean years, made leaner by downsizing." 
 And in the wake of that came a new disruption.
"In measuring job growth in the private sector, the county was always better off than New York City," Mr. Spitznas observed. "That was the case until 1987, when the county started to lose jobs in the private sector at a swifter rate than the rate in New York City. One-third of the jobs in Westchester, gained in the preceding 10 years, vanished."
As did the market share of many businesses. Moreover, the economic recovery in the county in the last decade, measured by job growth, has been slow.
"Westchester lags behind New York City and Nassau County," Mr. Spitznas said. "The reason is that New York City is doing a better job of holding on to businesses, and another player has entered the arena. A newly aggressive Jersey City is proving to be a surprisingly hot competitor, stepping ahead of Westchester in the race to attract new business."
And housing, or lack of it, is a major cause of the growing labor shortage hampering business growth in the county.
"What we need and don't have, is a range of housing -- affordable to both renters and home buyers," Mr. Spitznas emphasized.
If the last decade has been darkened by downsizing and the disappearance of some of Westchester's largest corporations, on the bright side has been the emergence of new, smaller companies, which have been formed in the same period, said Lawrence E. Dwyer, president of the Westchester County Association, a private business-based civic membership organization in White Plains.
"It's a new phenomenon," he said. "Entrepreneurs are starting companies that are exerting a different pull. These are high-tech companies on the cutting edge with a global focus. For example, when 'right sizing' took place at I.B.M., those highly skilled people became consultants, and some eventually formed their own groups. We have 20 or more colleges in the county turning out a trained work force, which is a boon for the high-tech companies here."
As for blue-collar workers, Westchester cannot be competitive in that job market, Mr. Dwyer said.
"Look at General Motors," he said. "The high cost of energy is a major reason for the closing of the Tarrytown plant."
Westchester, lacking major employer sectors like manufacturing, agriculture and defense, relies on small businesses to serve as its economic engine today, said Andrew N. Karlen, head of the Small Business Council of the Westchester County Chamber of Commerce in White Plains.
"According to statistics from the State Department of Labor, 80 percent of Westchester businesses employ less than 10 workers," Mr. Karlen said. "And running parallel to the decade of corporate downsizing, which I feel has finally run its course, are dramatically altered workplace values. A decade ago, it was hard to discuss being laid off, but today, it is almost a badge of honor."
Small-business incubation centers, actual tax and regulatory relief and paperwork reforms are part of a business vocabulary that was rarely heard two decades ago, he added.
Although the confluence of technology and corporate downsizing has helped create a successful new breed of business owners, other Westchester small-business owners, particularly retailers, are suffering, he said.
"National chains are campaigning to saturate Westchester in ways that were inconceivable 20 years ago," he said. "Power-box retailers like Home Depot and Sam's Club have already opened here. Others are in the planning and approval process."
The impact in communities where 'these juggernauts' have settled, has already been felt, he said. "Small local retailers have closed, causing the loss of hundreds of steady jobs for local residents," he said. "It is a matter of deep concern for every small-business owner and municipal planner."
Twenty years ago, the economic impact of tourism in Westchester was so infinitesimal it was unmeasurable, said Harold E. Vogt, chairman of the board of the Westchester Convention and Visitors Bureau and president and chief executive of the county's Chamber of Commerce.
"If we got 10 calls a year for information regarding Westchester, it was a lot," he said. "In 1977 we decided to act and came up with the first issue of the Westchester Visitors and Convention Guide, hopefully to attract outside interest in the county."
In the years that followed, the initial efforts were expanded.
"Today in a partnership between the County Office of Tourism and the Convention and Tourist Bureau, we issue a 68-page information guide, which is distributed widely," Mr. Vogt said. "Last year, for example, we fielded 14,300 calls for information about Westchester."
Helped by the marketing efforts of the bureau, Mr. Vogt said that last year the county ranked second after New York City in the highest taxable hotel sales in the state.
"And the record highs reached by our tourism industry in 1996 will be surpassed this year," he said.
Last year the total economic impact, measured by taxable hotel sales, county tax revenue, state sales tax and annual industry payrolls was about $480 million. This year's figures will be even higher. Georgia Kalayjian, president of the Westchester Convention and Visitors Bureau, said the Professional Golfers' Association tournament alone, which took place over seven days in August, brought $70 million to $100 million in new dollars to the county.
"New dollars are those spent by visitors; 40 percent of them came from outside the tristate area," Ms. Kalayjian said, adding that the economic spinoffs from the P.G.A. championship will continue to benefit Westchester for years.
"Over 1,000 media representatives covered the tournament, which was seen in 110 countries," she said. "That kind of publicity is fantastic. For instance, when the P.G.A. tournament was held in St. Louis, nine companies moved to the St. Louis area soon afterward. We can expect the best, that businesses, both here and abroad, planning relocations will now consider moves to Westchester."
In 1977, Steven Cohen, currently president of the Westchester Banker Association, began his banking career. Mr. Cohen, now vice president of Republic National Bank of New York, headquartered in Yonkers, said the last two decades have been marked by vast changes in the banking industry in Westchester.
"First of all, with the change in the banking laws of 1976 came deregulation, which made it possible for New York City banks to invade Westchester's turf," he said. "For the first time, our home-grown banks were facing competition from big commercial city banks. The two largest Westchester banks in existence then, the National Bank of Westchester and the County Trust Bank, were eventually taken over by larger banks from outside the county who were expanding on every street corner. Former restaurants turned into bank branches overnight, so eager were the city banks to establish a presence in Westchester."
Eventually, Mr. Cohen said, many of the small savings and loans also disappeared, and with them, the neighborhood character of the banking industry.
"Customers used to be fiercely loyal to their bank," he said. "It was not unusual for a bank to have members of three generations of families as customers. Bankers then made what we call 'character loans' to small businesses on the strength of knowing the borrower."
He observed that lending today is more complex and difficult. "The character of lending has changed," he said. "Many small businesses are hurting because it is more difficult and expensive for them to get loans."
Banks now require detailed information submitted by an accountant, he said.
"Not only has it become more costly to make an application but because of the excesses and bad loans made during the 80's, banks have become much more conservative in their lending practices." he said. "The result is that small businesses without access to capital are suffering."
Twenty years ago, I.B.M., with 12,000 full-time employees, was Westchester's dominant employer, occupying 15 to 18 percent of all the available office space in the county, said John Rostenberg, president for the New England region of Insignia/ Rostenberg-Doern.
"Westchester caught fire in the mid-70's," he said. "I was working for Cross and Brown, the largest corporate broker in Manhattan at the time, and we could see the suburban market gaining momentum following in the wake of the Fortune 500 companies like I.B.M. and Nestle -- and AMF -- that were building new headquarters here. They established Westchester as one of the premiere office markets in the nation, and names like White Plains, Armonk and Purchase became known around the country as the home of major companies and therefore desirable areas."
Mr. Rostenberg, a pioneer in leasing suburban office space, added, "The 70's were good, and although over two decades the cycle has had its ups and downs, on balance Westchester has fared well."
Although corporate downsizings continue to hamper the office market, he said, several positive developments in the corporate sector bode well for Westchester in the long term.
"I.B.M. is nearing completion of its new headquarters facility in Armonk," he said. "Nine West Group is moving into its new headquarters on Westchester Avenue in White Plains, and Swiss Re America broke ground in June on a new 300,000-square-foot headquarters complex off Route 120 in Armonk. Looking at the availability of Class A space, it is apparent that with another deal or two in a large building we'll be out of space. By the year 2000, I predict we'll have new buildings up, older buildings will be retrofitted or torn down, and Westchester will still be the headquarters for both international companies and numbers of small-to-midsize companies that will have either moved into the county or expanded their existing operations here."
The county's original developers, the big three that built the buildings that led to Westchester's role as a premiere business location -- the Robert Martin Company, the Schulman Realty Group and Halpern Enterprises -- were all family-owned businesses in 1977 They supplied the bulk of first-class office space and industrial space, corporate headquarters and office parks, now occupied by major and minor companies.
Yet changes in the law and pressures from lenders and national developers have changed the face of family-owned businesses. By 1996 the Halpern company had merged with Reckson Realty Associates of Melville. Some years before, the Schulman Realty Group had arranged with its lenders to take over its properties on I-287, known as the Platinum Mile. And in January, the Robert Martin Company, the last of the original developers, merged with Cali Realty, a real estate investment trust in Cranford, N.J.

HEADLINE: With Maturity and Financing, the Arts Expand and Blossom

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

 BODY:
MANHATTAN cast a long shadow on Westchester's art scene in 1977. City venues were considered more glamorous, professional and trustworthy. Many people figured that for the price of a baby sitter and parking they were at least guaranteed the best play or concert money could buy.
Painters, film makers and writers lived in the county but met their colleagues in the city. A visit from a working artist was a rarity in the schools. County arts groups were still novices at obtaining grants and gaining recognition, and many exhibitions seemed amateurish. 
 The arts scene has matured along with other aspects of Westchester life, and today the arts permeate every community. Many municipalities have their own arts council; the Westchester Arts Council's budget has grown to $1.8 million today from $180,000 in 1977, and audiences are attending events closer to home. In 1995, 1.3 million people attended performances or exhibitions in the county, according to the Westchester Arts Council. A first-time joint study by the council and the county's Cultural Affairs Department showed that the arts make a significant economic impact on the county.
Total expenditures by Westchester's nonprofit arts organizations and their audiences in 1995 were $54.2 million. The spending supported more than 2,000 full-time jobs, provided $49.2 million in personal income to residents and generated $4.5 million to local government and $5 million to state government.
A visit to organizations like the Neuberger Museum of Arts or the Performing Arts Center at Purchase College, the newly named Music Conservatory of Westchester in White Plains, the Paramount Center for the Arts in Peekskill or the Katonah Museum of Art confirms the burgeoning of events and programs. "There has been a real blossoming, a lot of expansion here," said Judy Matson, director of the county's Office of Cultural Affairs. (A copy of the Economic Impact Study is available by calling 285-2922.)
Janet T. Langsam, executive director of the Westchester Arts Council, said music has acquired prominence among the arts, winning the largest number of grants from the council and garnering the largest audiences. Theater and dance groups were slower to develop, she said. In fact, although many new organizations have been formed in Westchester in the last two decades, theater groups have most often failed.
Among the most recent additions to the county's arts roster are the Fleetwood Stage Company, based at Wildcliff Center for the Arts in New Rochelle; the Hudson Valley Writers Center, which occupies the newly renovated Philipse Manor Railroad Station in Sleepy Hollow, and the Westchester Chamber Orchestra, based in New Rochelle. In all, 90 groups are affiliated with the Westchester Arts Council; others receive council funds through grants.
Individual artists have also benefited from the growth of arts organizations. School programs received a boost in the late 70's, when the Federal Comprehensive Employment Training Act, known as CETA, enabled artists to teach short-term projects in classrooms. As funds for school-based art and music instruction began to decline, arts organizations mobilized to help. The movement toward arts-in-education began in quiet pockets, almost as a form of self-protection. If the arts disappeared from public education, some groups asked, who would attend future performances?
Educational research dovetailed with the growing presence of community-based arts groups in the schools. Listening to Mozart improved math skills, researchers found. Dance led to improved verbal performance, while painting and mask making harnessed the energies of the hyperkenetic. "Multiple intelligences" became a new phrase, and the arts mushroomed as therapies and teaching tools.
Simultaneously, the school reform movement looked to the arts to strengthen the core curriculum. The Westchester Arts Council received a three-year matching grant of $250,000 from the National Endowment for the Arts for its program Arts Excel, which aimed to teach subjects like writing, math and history through artistic disciplines. Arts Excel is now self-supporting, Ms. Langsam said. The council's arts and education roster lists 120 artists today, compared with 60 in 1990. In addition, many museums and orchestras have their own education programs.
County government contributed $85,000 to the Westchester Arts Council in 1977; the amount last year was $470,000. Arts support crossed political boundaries, but county financing did not keep up with inflation, Ms. Langsam said. She said the county had helped in other ways, like producing highway signs leading to arts sites and paying for the economic impact study. The weakening of the National Endowment for the Arts has cast a pall over planning in the country's arts community and has led art leaders nationwide to seek new forms of financing. Public-private partnerships have shown promise in Westchester, Ms. Langsam said, as municipalities jointly obtain matching funds.
Some fear that the withering of the roots will eventually hurt the tree. "The National Endowment always gave us support whenever we tried to push the envelope," Ms. Langsam said, citing efforts to diversify audiences and take the arts to the disabled. "Who else would support that kind of risk-taking? That innovational component may be gone."

HEADLINE: It's in the Numbers: Waves of New Faces

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
THE last two decades have brought many changes in Westchester County. But nowhere can they be seen more clearly than in the county's shifting demographics. The most pronounced changes have taken place in the racial and ethnic makeup of Westchester. While the county for the moment remains predominantly white and wealthy, it will not be that way for long.
Once an enclave of country clubs and posh estates -- an issue of Worth magazine last year listed 20 Westchester towns, villages and hamlets among the 300 wealthiest in America -- the county now is also known for its emerging minority population and its areas of poverty. 
 "You still see signs of money everywhere," Noreen L. Preston, an economist with the County Planning Department said recently, "in the expensive cars on the street, in the upscale neighborhoods, in the boutiques in downtown areas and in the variety of businesses that cater to the rich. But also, there are more profound changes taking place. Increasingly, this is a county of tremendous diversity -- from the very wealthy to the poorest newcomers who are making their way up the economic ladder."
Just two census counts ago, whites outnumbered blacks more than 9 to 1. In 1970, there were 802,722 whites and 85,042 blacks in Westchester. By 1990, however, the ratio was less than 6 to 1: 695,738 whites and 120,388 blacks.
More changes in the racial and ethnic makeup of Westchester are in store, according to a study released in July 1995. By the year 2020, black, Asian and Hispanic residents will equal the number of Westchester's whites, according to the study by the County Planning Department.
There are broad implications for the distribution of wealth in the county, with an ever-widening gap expected between the haves and have-nots in the population, according to a 1995 report by the New York Metropolitan Transportation Council, a regional planning organization, and other studies.
Since 1970, nearly three million immigrants have moved to the region, and half of those have been admitted under the family reunification provisions of the immigration law, which contributes to "tight concentrations of newcomers in ethnic enclaves," the council's report said. That has been reflected in the continued growth of the county's cities.
Census predictions indicate that by 2020, Hispanic residents will make up 24 percent of the county's population, up from 9.9 percent in 1990. Asians and people from the Pacific islands will constitute 10 percent of the population, up from 3.7 percent five years ago. And the number of black residents will grow to nearly 17 percent from 13 percent at the beginning of the decade.
By contrast, the white population will decrease to slightly less than 50 percent, from 73 percent in 1990.
Those figures represent only part of the shifting picture of the last two decades. The population has changed in other ways. As the Metropolitan Transportation Council's study indicated, the gap between the very rich and the very poor continued to widen. "The rich got richer and the poor became even more impoverished," Ms. Preston said.
In 1979, the top fifth of wage earners in Westchester averaged $70,736 in annual income; by 1989, that figure rose to $102,293, accounting for inflation.
The bottom fifth of wage earners fared less well, going from $5,431 in 1979 to only $6,063, accounting for inflation, a decade later, according to the County Department of Planning.
Economically in 1970, Westchester ranked fourth in per capita income, compared with 3,147 counties in the nation, according to the United States Census that year. By 1995, Westchester dropped to sixth place in that category.
Income issues aside, the county's population also grew much older -- a trend that is expected to continue as people live longer and baby boomers age. In 1970, there were 34,770 people over the age of 75 living in Westchester; by 1990, that number had increased to 56,067.
Overall, the fastest-growing group in the county is the elderly over the age of 85, with 13,794 people in the county in that age category. By 2020, that number is expected to double, according to projections from the county's Planning Department.
The county has also become better educated in the last 20 years, with the number of college-educated residents almost doubling, to 213,298 in 1990 from 111,085 in 1970.
On the employment front, the major employer in Westchester in the 1970's was International Business Machines, where 10,400 full-time workers earned their living. New York Telephone employed 4,010 workers, General Motors, 4,000 and General Foods, 3,400.
By 1995, Westchester County had become the largest employer, hiring 9,230. I.B.M. followed, but by then, the number had dropped to 7,100 -- in part because of downsizing that took place in the late 80's and early 90's. The third-largest employer was the United States Post Office with 3,900 and Nynex with 3,000. In the corporate sector, the numbers continue to change as companies downsize, rebuild and relocate.
Gone from the scene is General Motors in Sleepy Hollow, the third-largest employer two decades ago. The automaker shut down its assembly plant in the summer of 1996 after 81 years in Westchester and left town. That in turn has left county officials scratching their heads over what to do with the 97-acre riverfront site. A plan to develop the site for residential use is being considered.
Also gone are some of the larger Fortune 500 companies, being replaced in part with a variety of mid-size and smaller concerns -- creating what Planning Commissioner P. Lynn Oliva called a "more diverse marketplace," which is reflective of the many demographic shifts that have taken place. "We're not a one-industry town anymore," Ms. Oliva said, "and sometimes change is frightening, but a healthy county is one that is dynamic."
Frank M. Surdey, a regional economist for the New York State Department of Labor, described the changes as "a reshaping of the economic landscape."
Overall, Westchester's labor market grew by 21 percent to 387,900 workers as of July 1997, compared with 320,000 workers for the same month 20 years ago, Mr. Surdey reported.
As reflected in the departure of General Motors, manufacturing jobs declined by 40 percent, to 39,500 in July from 66,200 for the same month in 1977, his figures showed.
By contrast, the services sector grew by 79 percent, to 142,000 jobs in July from 79,700 jobs 20 years ago.
The jobs in finance, insurance and real estate also expanded, to 26,500 from 16,900 over that same period, a 57 percent increase.
Meanwhile, the unemployment rate dropped to 4 percent in July from 6.6 percent in July 1977.
Both times, Westchester fared better than New York State and the nation. In July 1977, the unemployment rate for the state was 8.7 percent, and the unemployment rate for the nation was 7 percent. In July of this year, the state's unemployment rate was 6.5 percent and the nation's was 5 percent.
Looking at population numbers, there were fewer people living in Westchester, down to 874,866 in 1990 from 894,104 in 1970, according to the census. Women continued to outnumber men, with 470,898 women and 423,206 men in 1970 and 459,586 women and 415,280 men in 1990.
Looking ahead, the population is expected to grow an average of less than 1 percent a year, and by the year 2020, it will reach 905,000. The population is not likely to exceed 910,000 in the future, based on limits determined by employment opportunities and the availability of housing, according to the Planning Department. The latest population estimate was 893,400 last year.
And while the cities to the south -- Mount Vernon, New Rochelle and Yonkers -- continued to be where the greatest density of the county's population lived, the numbers in towns and villages to the north grew. Yorktown, for example, saw its population more than double to 33,467 in 1990 from 16,453 in 1960. Similarly, Pound Ridge's population rose to 4,550 in 1990 from 2,573 in 1960. And Somers' numbers grew to 16,216 from 5,468 during that period.
Looking to the future, census figures indicate that most of the county's population growth will be in the southern part, in cities like Mount Vernon and Yonkers, where members of minority groups settle.
By 2020, 46.6 percent of the county's population, slightly less than in 1990, will live in the south. Thirty percent of the county's population, slightly more than in 1990, will live in the northern part of Westchester. And about 23 percent, slightly less that five years ago, will live in the central area.
On the real estate front, the average price of a single-family home over two decades rose to $374,899 last year from $137,475 in 1981, the earliest year for which there are figures, according to the Westchester County Board of Realtors.
Looking ahead, the type of housing that will be built in the county to comply with demand is expected to change. As the racial makeup of the county changes, there will be a demand for more multifamily housing, including rental units.
Housing development is expected to be limited in the north, where the Croton watershed covers 60 percent of the area, because of New York City's strict watershed regulations.

Rural Life Preserved -- Sunnyfield Farm in Bedford is typical of many areas in northern Westchester County. (Photographs by Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)(pg. 1)

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Remaking Part of Downtown White Plains;
Mixed-Use Plan For Former Macy's

 BODY:
An ambitious public/private partnership involving the transformation of a city block in the heart of downtown White Plains has been proposed by Manhattan-based developer Tishman Speyer Properties, co-owner of Rockefeller Center.
At a recent meeting with the White Plains Urban Renewal Agency, the developer detailed its plans to buy the 352,000-square-foot former Macy's department store, at Main Street and Mamaroneck Avenue, and replace it with a residential, retail and entertainment complex. 
 "The strategy is to redevelop the site, creating a multilevel, mixed-use project," said Kenneth Narva, a principal with PEG/ Park, of White Plains, retail and architectural consultants on the project. "It would be anchored on the lower levels with entertainment and retail and have residential units above."
Tishman Speyer expects to close on the Macy's sale by the end of the year, said Steven Wise, project manager. It is also interested in acquiring additional properties, possibly an entire city block between Main Street and Martine Avenue.
"They have asked us to consider designating the entire block an urban renewal area," said Mayor Sy Schulman, "which means we could condemn property and then acquire it on their behalf by eminent domain."
Downtown merchants, especially in the area surrounding the former Macy's, have been struggling ever since the department store, a Main Street fixture since 1949, moved last year into the nearby Galleria Mall. And now Woolworth's, directly across Main Street, will close by the end of the year, leaving a handful of small discount and novelty stores without a retail anchor.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Easing the Pain in Downtown Stamford;
When GTE Walks Out, Zurich Re Will Walk In

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn.

 BODY:
WHEN GTE announced last April that it would put its 483,000-square-foot Stamford building on the market and move to Irving, Tex., by early 1999, the news was not entirely unexpected, given the volatility of corporate relocations.
But losing a $21 billion telecommunications giant and coping with a large block of empty office space was certainly cause for concern in the city. 
 There was also a psychological factor. GTE had been the first company to have a building constructed for it and then fully occupy it amid the chaos of urban renewal more than 20 years ago. The glass-sheathed inverted ziggurat that it completed in 1973 on Tresser Boulevard gleamed as an image of a new Stamford rising from the rubble.
Two months ago the Zurich Centre Group of Manhattan -- a subsidiary of the Zurich Group, a conglomerate of insurance, reinsurance and financial-service companies based in Zurich -- announced that it had contracted to buy or lease the GTE building for an undisclosed figure and renovate it for occupancy in early 2000.
"The effect was twofold," said Jeffrey Dunne, senior vice president at CB Commercial Real Estate, speaking as an uninvolved observer. "There were two developers -- Hines Interests LP and Toombs Development Company -- vying to build a new building for Zurich Re," as the Zurich Centre Group is known.
"When this huge building became available," he continued, "it stopped what would have been the first substantial new construction since 1989," except for Swiss Bank's 1.2-million-square-foot headquarters nearing completion. "It also says something about tenants. Rather than wait for a project to be built in the time promised, the tenant will take an available building if it suits his needs."
So well did the GTE building suit Zurich Re that the insurance company contacted GTE directly and the deal was arranged without a broker. GTE does have an agreement with Cushman & Wakefield and with Roger Staubach, the head of the Staubach Company, a tenants' broker, for handling its real estate activities nationwide.
But in this instance, said Ronald Kulpinski, GTE's vice president for corporate real estate, "we exercised our exclusion provision with Cushman & Wakefield when we came to an agreement with Zurich Re."
"It couldn't be better for Stamford," said Owen J. Brown 3d, senior director at Cushman & Wakefield in Stamford, "that here's a prime property that never got to market." Rents, he said, are approaching the $30 a square foot mark and will continue to rise until Hines and the others start building.
GTE's explanation for its move was a need for consolidating certain corporate and operating-unit staffs at its Texas headquarters. Construction of a 160,000-square-foot building has begun in Irving, where 10,000 people are employed by the company. GTE is also building a 400,000-square-foot suburban campus for its cellular operations on Route 400 outside Atlanta.
About half of its 650 Stamford employes are expected to move to Irving in waves through the end of 1998. A transition center has been set up in the Stamford building to help employees find new jobs if they don't want to move, or helping them adjust to a new environment if they go.
GTE pays for relocation "from soup to nuts," said J. Randall MacDonald, executive vice president for human resources and administration. "There is an allowance for everything from selling to buying a house, attorneys' fees, moving costs, spending three days looking at the lay of land around Dallas, helping hang the curtains."
Salaries, he said, are set nationwide, and are not reduced because of the cost-of-living differential between Connecticut and Texas. If people are laid off they receive a $2,000 stipend to further their education or for computer training.
Zurich Re had been searching for a location in lower Fairfield County for nine months, but could find nothing large enough to fill its needs. When it struck a deal with GTE the state informed them of a financial perquisite created by the General Assembly in 1984 to induce small insurance companies to come into the state and help revive a sagging insurance industry.
John Paul, director of business recruitment for the State of Connecticut, described the financial vehicle as "an insurance investment fund -- like a mutual fund in which wealthy individuals could invest and create capital, and the insurance company would get a dollar-for-dollar tax credit." The fund, he said, is a private, not state, entity.
Zurich Re, he said, will invest $190 million, and over a 10-year period receive that amount in corporate tax credits from the state, plus the return on its investment.
"In return, the state," said Mr. Paul, "gets a fast-growing company with over 400 employees -- a large benefit to the region and state in income, property and sales taxes." The building and six-acre site are assessed at $27.4 million; its annual property tax bill is $783,000.
Still to be decided is the manner in which the building will change hands. GTE originally leased it from the builder, the F.D. Rich Company, developers of the 100-acre urban renewal district. When the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation foreclosed on the property in 1993, GTE continued to lease it from the F.D.I.C.
"By contract we can sell our leasehold," said Mr. Kulpinski, "or we will exercise our purchase option -- buy the building from the F.D.I.C. for the mortgage balance, and sell it to Zurich Re." He would not disclose the amount.
Failure of either party to complete the transaction, he said, would result in financial consequences for Zurich Re, or GTE's relinquishing title. But, he said "both parties are delighted and see nothing in our way."
A second GTE building in Norwalk, built and owned by the company, was put up for sale in July. Completed in 1983 on the 66-acre site of a former Catholic seminary, it has served as a training center for GTE executives.
FITTED out like a luxurious hotel, it contains 120 rooms, 28 meeting rooms, plus dining rooms, game rooms, cocktail lounges, a fitness room and, on its grounds, tennis courts and jogging trails. It is also used by Pitney-Bowes, GE Capital, and Champion International, among others, for a daily rate based on the rooms and amenities required.
"There is a possibility that one of those companies will be the buyer," said James Banks, director of marketing and business development for the City of Norwalk. Under zoning restrictions, the property can only be used as a training center. Edward Weiss of Cushman & Wakefield's Manhattan office said that a decision may be forthcoming this month.
A third building, which GTE constructed at the foot of Washington Boulevard in Stamford, was completed in 1986 as a home for its telephone operations. The 250,000-square-foot building cost $49 million and was completely furnished but never occupied. "The telephone operations were installed at our headquarters in Dallas instead," said Mr. Kulpinski.
A year later Stamford, needing a new City Hall, bought it for $45 million.
GTE may lease back a small amount of space from Zurich Re, and Zurich Re may lease out additional space that exceeds its requirements. The building can accommodate 850 employees.
"We will move about 400 people from our New York offices at One Chase Manhattan Plaza, and 85 people from offices at Canterbury Green in Stamford into the GTE building," said Nick Carter, assistant vice president of communications for Zurich Re.
Afterward the company will retain a limited presence at One Chase Manhattan Plaza.
"We're sad to see GTE go," said Christopher Bergstrom, director of Economic Development for Stamford. "They were a major citizen, active in community schools and organizations. But from the time they changed their minds about expanding on Washington Boulevard we have been waiting for the other shoe to drop."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Zurich Re has contracted to take over GTE building above in Stamford. GTE is now marketing its executive-training center in Norwalk, right. (Photographs by Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
The Preachers: A Test of Political Faith

BYLINE: By Brett Pulley; Brett Pulley reports from Trenton for The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
The mood inside the camp of James E. McGreevey was jubilant last week after the Democratic gubernatorial candidate delivered an impassioned appeal for support from the Black Ministers Council of New Jersey, a statewide group with the growing political power.
"We were electrified," said Kelli Drakeford, Mr. McGreevey's director of constituent services, who accompanied the candidate at a meeting in Trenton on Tuesday, where he answered questions posed by about 50 of the council's ministers. Each gubernatorial candidate had appeared before the ministers, who wanted to know what they would do to address the problems of the state's cities, such as deteriorating schools and disproportionately high auto-insurance rates. After Mr. McGreevey, the ministers spoke to Murray Sabrin, the longshot Libertarian Party candidate, and then to Christine Todd Whitman, the Republican incumbent. "Jim was tremendous," Ms. Drakeford said. 
 But while Mr. McGreevey and his campaign staff may have thought his description of plans to restore urban areas made for an impressive sermon, the ministers were not so sanguine. "In his passion, he didn't really respond to the questions," the Rev. Reginald Jackson, the group's executive director, said. As a result, Mr. Jackson and his colleagues refused to say whom they would endorse in the Nov. 4 election.
For McGreevey, this was a devastating blow. Anything less than an endorsement from black leaders is tantamount to an endorsement for the Governor. Mrs. Whitman has assiduously courted the ministers for the past year, and it seems to be paying off. As Ms. Drakeford said, the tepid reaction from the ministers has caused "concern" inside the McGreevey camp.
The ministers criticized both Mrs. Whitman and Mr. McGreevey. (Mr. Sabrin, who opposes government and affirmative action, was a non-starter in the view of the ministers.) "Neither one responded decisively or definitely to the questions we asked," said Mr. Jackson, who is pastor of St. Matthew's A.M.E. Church in Orange. "They were vague and non-specific." If Mr. McGreevey is to score an upset, he needs a strong turnout from black voters, and he needs about 85 percent of those who do turn out to vote for him. By refusing to speak out in full support of Mr. McGreevey, the ministers, who represent 600 churches across the state, are refusing to guarantee the Democratic candidate that they will urge their congregations to go to the polls on his behalf. Mrs. Whitman, on the other hand, knows that a weak turnout from black voters will bode well for her. In 1993, for example, only 8 percent of the 2.5 million people who went to the polls were black. Not only was the turnout among blacks weak that year, but Mrs. Whitman was able to get 25 percent, or a total of 50,000 votes, from those blacks who did go to the polls. Mrs. Whitman beat the Democratic incumbent that year, Jim Florio, by just 26,000 votes. If the turnout among blacks is low again, or if Mrs. Whitman once again gets such a large percentage of blacks to vote for her, she can probably rest assured of returning to the State House for a second term.
This is why both candidates have become so obsessed with courting the leadership of the black ministers council. For months, Mr. McGreevey and Mrs. Whitman have been treating Mr. Jackson and his colleagues as if they possess some golden passport into the political souls of black folks. Earlier this month, Mrs. Whitman received an endorsement from a much smaller group of black ministers known as S.U.P.P.E.R., or Spiritual, Unified, Prophetic, Political, Economic Revival. But the big prize for the candidates is the black ministers council, and each of them remains determined to win the support of the organization's leaders. In recent days, Mr. Jackson has been pondering numerous gestures aimed at winning his favor -- an invitation from the McGreevey camp to give the invocation at a campaign event with President Clinton when he comes to New Jersey; an invitation to sit with Democratic leaders during one of the gubernatorial debates; and an invitation from Mrs. Whitman for the ministers to join her for a gathering at Drumthwacket, the Governor's mansion.
"There's a lot of pressure on us on this one," Mr. Jackson said.
But the ministers seem to be enjoying the attention. They keep insisting that, even though they typically give overwhelming support to Democratic candidates, they are not to be taken for granted this year. "The Democrats think that automatically we're supposed to go with the Democratic candidate," Mr. Jackson said. The ministers are expected to issue a "report card" this week, grading the candidates on issues that concern the council members.
The desire to win the ministers' favor is understandable. After all, their churches organize people and get them to the polls. And even though its tax-exempt status prohibits the council from endorsing a candidate, individual ministers can make their own endorsements.
But in the end, each minister accounts for only one real vote. And in their zeal to impress the shepherds, the candidates seem to be forgetting the flock. Instead of spending so much time courting church leaders, why not spend more time actually campaigning in the cities. If the candidates have a real urban agenda, they should hit the streets and tell people what it is. Convince them that their votes will make a difference in their lives, and that they are not simply hearing stale promises.
The candidate who does that by Election Day will get an amen from the congregation, and the preacher.

SECTION: Section 13; Page 6; Column 3; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 422 words

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;
A Mercedes-Benz Taxi Gets Fares and Stares

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
In almost every way, it's like all the other cabs in town, dressed in yellow with a light on top. But Branislav Kulka's taxi is a Mercedes-Benz, the only one in New York. In a city where residents are used to hailing basic Fords and Chevies, that's a difference that stands out.
"I think more people have taken a picture of this car than of the Empire State Building," Mr. Kulka, who is known as Brian, said last week. During the year he has driven it, he said, his cab has become something of a tourist attraction in its own right, receiving admiring stares from passers-by and declarations of undying devotion from passengers. He has even been featured on Japanese television, Mr. Kulka said, with his Mercedes. 
 The car is a 1996 300D. An immigrant from Croatia who has been driving taxis and limousines in New York for 30 years, Mr. Kulka says he bought the cab for his own comfort and for economic reasons. Although it cost $40,000, compared with $23,000 or so for a conventional taxi, he expects it to last at least six or seven years, double or triple the life of its cheaper counterparts.
Diesel fuel costs him about $10 a day, far less than the $25 or more other drivers pay daily for gasoline. And superior shock absorbers help preserve his back on bumpy city streets, he said, "something to think about when you spend half the day and night behind the wheel."
Of course, Mr. Kulka did not invent the idea of using a Mercedes as a cab; in Europe, cars like his are the industry standard. In New York, however, where the officially sanctioned cars are large domestic sedans like the Chevrolet Caprice and Ford Crown Victoria and, recently, a few minivans, its use is "considered experimental," said a spokesman for the Taxi and Limousine Commission, Allan J. Fromberg.
"He's on the road until we decide whether his car is appropriate," Mr. Fromberg said, adding that the trial was open-ended at this point. While Mr. Kulka has the only Mercedes, he said, any medallion driver may ask for a similar test period for any car.
In the meantime, while awaiting final approval, Mr. Kulka gets few complaints from his passengers. Some, like Susan Bode of SoHo, say they think that his cab might be a little too small for a rider with a lot of packages, but she conceded that the ride was very smooth.
Others, like the Manhattan theater producer Peter Holmes a Court, think that it's simply great. "I feel honored to be here," he said last week, smiling, as he got into the taxi for a ride. BERNARD STAMLER

HEADLINE: Beyond Fairness;
Picking and Choosing Among the Truly Needy

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: CLINTON, Mo.

 BODY:
TO put a harsh light on it, everyone's a beggar at the Samaritan Center. Just off the courthouse square of this little city in the foothills of the Ozarks, the private charity is a disheveled barn of a room, stacked with food, castoff clothes and toys. It's the last resort for the city's indigent, and like them, Carolyn Kelsay, the center's director, has her hand out, a posture that makes her as queasy as she says it makes her clients.
"We could not operate here," she said, "without the generosity of the people of Henry County," of which Clinton is the seat. But her cases have grown from 450 a month in 1996 to as many as 700 a month now. And her $98,000 annual budget, 98 percent of which is raised locally, is only 5 percent above last year's. 
 "I hope I don't make the people who come feel like they're begging," she said. "I have to beg, and that is very hard for me."
Welcome to the new American welfare system, or the 90's variation on the privately supported settlement house culture of a century ago. With the Federal Government's scuttling of the old system last year, the paycheck is in and the automatic taxpayer-financed welfare check is out. Yet many states are finding that the lawmakers' go-to-work goals are unattainable. Many of the poor can't or won't go to work, states are finding, and even some of those who do find work still need help.
 
Less Trickle-Down Charity
With needs still strong and resources tight for the nation's private charities, begging has become the new imperative for both givers and takers. In the process, the Government's arbitrary, one-size-fits-all definitions of fairness are giving way to the home-grown definitions of thousands of diverse charities. Out is the capriciousness of a system built on eligibility standards that gave a $300 monthly check to a mother with a car worth up to $2,000 and denied assistance to one with a car worth $2,001. In is the capriciousness of unregulated and money-strapped charities making subjective judgments on who will get a blanket and a bed.
From former President George Bush's celebration of a "thousand points of light" to President Clinton's Philadelphia summit on volunteerism in April, the Government has been exhorting the public to take on more of the downtrodden's care and feeding. So far, however, the nation's points of light haven't seen the benefits.
The American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel says that after years of little growth, charitable contributions to nonprofit organizations have risen 16 percent during the past two years, to $150.7 billion. But Ann Kaplan, the group's research director, attributed the surge to a booming stock market and a strong economy. And even with the rise, philanthropic giving remains at 2 percent of the gross domestic product, the level of at least the last three decades.
Further, Ms. Kaplan said, most of the recent increases support colleges and universities, hospitals and the arts. Much of what people give human-service charities -- $12.2 billion last year -- is spent on disaster relief, and only a small amount given to religious organizations specifically goes to the poor. "I would say less went into poverty relief last year than in 1995," Ms. Kaplan said, "and less in 1995 than in 1994." So, as any American with a mail slot knows, charities have redoubled their begging.
But the likelihood that private donors will close the gap between the needs of the indigent and diminishing Government aid is slim, says Richard Steinberg, a professor of economics and philanthropy at Indiana University. With each $1 cut in Government aid to the poor, he said, charitable contributions make up "no more than 35 cents and perhaps less."
Still, for many poor people, whether on public assistance or not, the private neighborhood charity is a cozier refuge than the welfare office. At the Samaritan Center, a family of four can pick up $100 a month in free food items and 20 items of clothing per person. Clients can also get help in staying off the street with payments of utility bills or rent.
"They're quicker, friendlier here," said Carri Gomez, 28, a mother of five. The Samaritan Center helped provide Ms. Gomez with food while she finished high school and has given her work learning clerical skills so she can get a better job.
More important, charity advocates say, the judgment calls made by organizations like Ms. Kelsay's about whom to help and how best to help them might be more effective in tackling the roots of poverty than the government's old assurance of a steady welfare check.
 
Knowing When to Say No
"Saying no when you're a church has a different meaning than saying no when you're the government," said Sharon M. Daly, the social policy director for Catholic Charities U.S.A. in Washington. The government, she said, codifies justice into rules so that all people in similar economic circumstances are treated equitably.
"But if you're a church," Ms. Daly said, "you have to go beyond justice to charity and love in trying to reach out to this person. In our tradition, we might not give a person what he's asking for. But we might give them what they need." Instead of a check, she said, "we might get you mental health treatment, or a substance program or family counseling."
Sometimes, however, charities make claims on their supplicants' souls in return for aid, said Julian Wolpert, a professor of public policy at the Woodrow Wilson School at Princeton. "It can involve greater mentoring and greater expectations that the recipient will behave in a way that is essential to his or her welfare or salvation," he said. In return for food or a voucher, for example, a benefactor might ask a client to come along to church.
And now and then, a charity's judgment calls can be less benign, as Ms. Gomez discovered last year in San Diego, before she moved here. "They judge you by your race," she said. "I went to the Catholic church because I'm a Catholic. The English-speaking father says he doesn't have any funds. I go to the Spanish-speaking father and he gets me some help."
Ms. Kelsay said she tried hard to play fair: "You want to give them all a chance. There are people you want to cry with. There are people you want to kick out."
In today's climate, however, she must pick and choose. "I tend to help people who are trying to help themselves," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Carolyn Kelsay, above right, is the director of the Samaritan Center in Clinton, Mo. The private charity has helped Carri Gomez, filling out forms at left, to learn the clerical skills she needs to get a better job. (Photographs by Don Ipock for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Those Shiny New M.B.A.'s Get Signing Bonuses, Too

BYLINE: By DEBRA NUSSBAUM

 BODY:
WHEN Eric Dunkelberg, 27, finished his M.B.A. at Emory University last spring, he chose among nine job offers. Almost all of them included a signing bonus.
Mike Kanarios, 27, received three job offers with signing bonuses while finishing his M.B.A. this year at Duke University. The job he accepted paid a $10,000 bonus. 
 Linda Carlson, 36, left a credit card company this year to work for a privately owned investment firm as a manager in software development. Her signing bonus was about 20 percent of her first year's salary.
The signing bonus, once associated with professional athletes and top corporate executives moving from one company to another, is now commonplace for many M.B.A.'s, according to company recruiters and college placement officers. With low unemployment and a robust economy, such bonuses are seen as a way to lure the best employees.
In a survey this summer of 396 companies by the Society for Human Resource Management in Alexandria, Va., 154 employers said they had used signing bonuses to attract desired candidates. Of those employers, 43 percent had created the bonuses within the last year, said Barry Lawrence, the society's spokesman.
"It's market driven," said Karen Odom Stephens, associate director of human resource communication at Price Waterhouse in New York. She said the company had offered bonuses with increasing frequency in the last few years.
"In the top 20 schools, it's an expectation," said Steve Backers, manager of M.B.A. college recruiting for the Intel Corporation, confirming that Intel uses signing bonuses "when it's necessary." Also, this year, Intel expanded its stock options program to include all company employees as a long-term incentive, Mr. Backers said. New hires get stock options but must stay a certain period before exercising them.
In a survey answered by 600 graduating M.B.A.'s at 11 of the nation's top business schools last year, 80 percent said they had received signing bonuses, up from 62 percent in 1995, said Dan Nagy, director of placement at the Fuqua School of Business at Duke University. At Duke, bonus offers of $2,000 to $42,000 were reported by the M.B.A.'s graduating this year.
At the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, 90 percent of the almost 800 spring graduates received signing bonuses, with the average about $20,000.
"This is the most we've ever had," said Andrew Adams, Wharton's director of career development and placement. "It does seem to be on the incline. These graduates are in such incredible demand, and the economy is doing extremely well."
At the Goizueta Business School of Emory University in Atlanta, there has been a steady increase in the number of signing bonuses offered in the last three years; the average is $10,000. This year, more than half the 150 graduates received bonuses, the highest share to date, said Samantha Renfro, director of M.B.A. career services.
"It's a very good market out there," said Mr. Dunkelberg, who went to work for a textile company in Georgia after receiving his Emory degree. "Since people with less experience were getting signing bonuses, my expectations were to get one."
The types of companies offering bonuses have expanded. Investment banking and consulting firms have offered bonuses during the last decade, but the incentives are also popping up in the automotive, consumer goods and chemical industries, said Mr. Adams of the Wharton School.
When Mr. Kanarios graduated from Duke, he had offers with signing bonuses from Procter & Gamble, Chrysler and General Motors.
Mr. Kanarios accepted a job with G.M. as a senior financial analyst. Like Mr. Dunkelberg, he said, he saw many other graduates getting signing bonuses and expected it would be part of a package. "There's an expectation," he said. "If someone didn't offer one it could be somewhat of an insult, but it's not a deal-breaker. It does help you when you're coming out of school."
Placement officers said many students used the bonuses to pay off debt from M.B.A. programs that have usually cost them more than $20,000 a year.
Money may also give a psychological charge to the employee. "They are even more psyched up coming into the job," Mr. Dunkelberg said of the recipients. "Money creates loyalty. It's extra incentive."
Interestingly, to students like Mr. Kanarios, the bonus or even the salary is often not the most important issue in job hunting.
"You are thinking more of where you're going to be a few years down the road," Mr. Kanarios said. "You don't want to go somewhere that you'll get pigeonholed."
In his survey of 600 students last year, Mr. Nagy found that less than half accepted the job offer with the highest compensation. When Mr. Nagy and Mr. Adams have asked students to rate what is most important, money does not come in near the top.
Part of the reason, they say, is that most of the offers are fairly comparable financially, but most workers are now more concerned about the responsibilities associated with a job, its location, career opportunities, the corporate culture and life-style issues. "We meet with hundreds of students every year and it's rare we talk about weighing a decision based on salary," Mr. Adams said.
Ms. Carlson said people in information technology and software development were often most interested in "who is using the latest technologies."
"People will take a lateral move to get new adventures," she said. "These are people who are up all night because they are working on something at home. It's a passion, and more money does not fix the problem."
