SECTION: Section 13; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 3322 words

HEADLINE: For Guts, Glory and Absolutely Nothing Else;
The Ways of Pudgie Walsh: 41 Years of Neolithic Combat of the Semipro Fields of Brooklyn

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
NOTHING stops Pudgie Walsh. Nothing. And thus, on this drowsy, sun-splashed Brooklyn morning, he could not imagine that he would be unable to break into his car trunk. He had bagels inside the trunk and it wouldn't open. His jaw was set. His mien was determined. The man was hungry. So: he jiggled the lock. He pounded the trunk. He swore at the trunk. He beseeched the gods. The trunk was unyielding. No bagels in Brooklyn.
At least it is rarely this way on the playing field, where Robert Walsh, in the unsung world of semipro football, nearly always gets his way. Mr. Walsh, whom everyone calls by his childhood nickname of Pudgie, is the girthy, raspy-voiced coach of the Brooklyn Mariners, a semipro football team that, in a city overfed with professional sports, plays for its own muted version of football glory at Kings Bay Field in Sheepshead Bay. As the only coach the Mariners have known in their 41 years of existence, Pudgie has come to encapsulate what semipro football is all about: heart, dedication and high anxiety. The job requires that he constantly assemble fresh talent to display on the field, adroitly drum up money for equipment and bring harmony and inspiration to part-time players who operate in the penumbra of big-time athletics. 
 Already this season, his Mariners had rung up six victories against one loss and were rolling toward another shot at the national championship. A triumph over the Long Island Seahawks, a team that in various incarnations (including the Brooklyn Knights and the Brooklyn Kings) has been a bitter foe since 1963, would keep them tied for first place and secure them a playoff berth. "I'm a motivator, all right," Pudgie said, flushing from his mind any memory of his inability to motivate his car trunk to open. "I can turn it on. Believe me, I can turn it on. There's a little Knute Rockne in me. Maybe make that a lot of Knute Rockne."
Pudgie, who is 63, has known numerous sweet weekends since he got into this brutal business. His players are big, quick, strong -- and they win with a mesmerizing regularity. In his 41 years as coach, they have claimed 23 divisional titles and prevailed 16 times in the local playoffs, and in 1991 captured the national championship of the semipro universe, achieving some degree of feathery fame by edging the Palos/Orland Force, a team from outside Chicago, 14-7. By his recollection, there being no record books in semipro ball, Pudgie has endured the indignity of just three losing seasons and has won 412 games against only 85 losses. "It's not because I'm a great coach," he said. "I'm not. We run a very simple system. We don't do anything too fancy. But I'm an organizer. I'm a recruiter. I'm a motivator."
Given the almost routine success of his team, Pudgie is something of a legend in Brooklyn. When the fans rumble to their seats for a Mariners home game -- a good crowd amounts to 150 people -- they all know the familiar squat figure treading the sidelines. He made his living as a New York City firefighter, but he departed that perilous occupation in April of last year after 39 years battling hundreds of fires. Now he has plenty of time to apply his ribald virtuosity to his beloved Brooklyn Mariners.
Far removed from the overmoneyed ranks of pro football, this is sport for the sheer fun of it. The average salary on the Mariners is $0.00. In fact, the top salary is $0.00. Nobody has yet to land an after-shave endorsement. Pudgie earns nothing. ("I get my phone bill paid -- sometimes.") Only the trainer and the referees receive money, and they don't get slammed by tacklers. A photographer also gets $75 to videotape a game so that the coaches can study the action.
The team is an omnibus collection of about 55 men, most of whom played college football. They are now police officers, firefighters, house painters, stockbrokers, plumbers, sanitation workers, correction officers, salesmen -- men in their 20's and 30's with an undying love of a game that leaves them nursing sore bodies well into the workweek. Pudgie's son, John, a salesman, plays free safety and returns punts and kickoffs. A detective played 15 years before his howling body made him stop. One player was so devoted that when his company gave him an assignment in Bermuda in 1994, he flew back on weekends and suited up. "They catch the Mariners fever and they don't want to leave," is how Pudgie explains the allegiance.
Relatively few professions have been unrepresented on the team. A few years ago, two brothers were on the roster who were reputed to be drug dealers. "They weren't bad," said Anthony Pecorella, an offensive guard who works on Wall Street. "They played on the special teams. We just read in the paper that one of them got shot. As I recall, back when they were playing, one of them got shot during the season."
Some of the men were on the cusp of fulfilling boyhood fantasies and becoming the kind of football players who are paid for what they do and show up on Sunday television. A few even found their way to the pro camps; a handful lasted until the final cut, including Pudgie's current quarterback, Rob Higgins, who got to that tantalizing juncture with the San Diego Chargers. "I've had guys who played during the 1988 strike, and I've had guys who played in the U.S.F.L. and arena football," Pudgie said. "But I never had anybody who played with me who played in an actual legitimate N.F.L. game."
Pudgie eased into his car and pulled out. He spotted two men long beyond their playing days conversing on the corner. "There's my staff," he shouted out the window, beeping his horn. "I've got the oldest staff in the world."
One of the men sneered and whipped a wad of crumpled paper at Pudgie's car. "Some respect I get, huh?" Pudgie snarled. "The bums."
 
A Team That Runs On Half a Shoestring
 The Mariners Bar and Grill is an angled, wood-paneled affair, with twirling ceiling fans, on Avenue S and East 35th Street in Marine Park, one of those funky street-corner repositories of good cheer and good booze that you see in neighborhood after neighborhood. On a sun-streaked Friday morning, Pudgie Walsh sat sprawled in a chair at the table cater-corner to the entrance. He essentially looks like a fire hydrant with eyeglasses. He wore shorts and a black Mariners T-shirt saluting their 1991 national championship year. He emitted an air of bland composure.
Pudgie basically uses the bar as his office. Named after the team, the place is something of the Toots Shor's of semipro ball. The wall opposite the bar is plastered with Mariners photographs, and there is a painting of the team done by one of the players on a side wall. Pudgie is an exceptionally focused man. Even with only one somewhat attentive person across a table from him, he loves to repose here and discourse on himself and the prodigal virtues of his team.
Pudgie was born (and still lives) in Marine Park, where football enthusiasm was pervasive. His father was a police officer. After high school, where he did not play football, Pudgie joined the Navy but saw water in small doses. He was made a dental technician in Bainbridge, Md. "I should have seen the world for free," he said. "Instead, I saw a lot of mouths. And I saw a lot of blood inside people's mouths -- especially when I worked on them."
Done serving his nation's teeth, he was a runner for a Wall Street investment firm for a year and a dental supply salesman for a month. He joined the Fire Department and found something there. "When you work in the Fire Department, you have to be tough," he said. "You crawl into a burning building and reach out for a baby and the baby's arm comes off in your hand. You never get over the hurt. But there's tremendous satisfaction of doing your job."
Always enamored of football, he played linebacker and running back on assorted sandlot teams. In 1957, he signed on with the Mariners, a newly formed team named for the fife and drum corps of an American Legion post that was its original sponsor. (The post is gone now.) It competed against five other teams in the Brooklyn Football League. Before the first game was played, the coach got into a strained argument with the players over whether the team should compete on a rain-soaked field. The team wanted to; the coach didn't. He quit. The players asked Pudgie to fill in. He agreed to coach for one year, no more. The team went 9-2 and lost the championship game, 12-0. Pudgie saw his future come joltingly into focus. He has yet to yield command.
Semipro ball is a fragile universe, with teams and leagues continually succumbing to abating interest or weakened economics, but the Mariners have proved resilient. After its most recent league, the National Minor League, folded last year, the Mariners joined a new group, the Garden State Football League (three of its teams being based in New Jersey). The season began in the undulating heat of August, and the Mariners' final regular-season game is today in Philadelphia, after which, as one of the top four teams in the standings, they begin the playoffs. "We have such a big offensive line this year that we can run pretty much anything," Pudgie said of his team's stellar record. "Our line averages 6-3, 290 pounds. They're not men. They're moose."
The team runs on half a shoestring. Pudgie finds it hard to estimate a given year's operating budget, because so much depends on how many departing players turn in their uniforms. So many don't, and then Pudgie has to buy new equipment. This negligence infuriates him. He phones the players. He writes the players. He shrieks at them: Give me the uniforms! Still, many resist. "I have 25 players on a list who owe me uniforms," he complained. "It really bugs me. The nerve of the guys."
All in all, Pudgie guesses that it takes roughly $20,000 to keep the team playing for a season. That covers league fees, the rent for their home field, buses to away games (other teams in the league are in New Jersey, Philadelphia, Connecticut and Long Island), equipment, and referee and trainer fees.
Part of the revenues to meet the budget flows from the $6 admission fee to home games and from sales of T-shirts and hats. Most of it, however, accumulates from a raffle. Each player gets a book of 30 tickets to sell at $10 each. If he sells them all, he gets a Mariners jacket. The raffle winner gets two pretty good tickets to the Super Bowl, along with lodging and expenses.
Recruitment is always on Pudgie's mind, and whenever he encounters a promising football player, he unleashes his pitch. "I am one persistent Irishman," he said. "I should have become an insurance salesman. I would have been a millionaire."
A telephone repairman who plays on another team now trooped into the bar. Pudgie greeted him cordially and sounded him out about how he was faring with his team.
The phone guy frowned and said: "Last week, we only had 15 players. The coach suited up."
Pudgie turned over a thought in his head, and said: "You should play with us. We need a fullback."
After absorbing some inordinate flattery from Pudgie, the phone guy said maybe he would and handed over his number. Then he said he had to go; telephones had to be fixed.
Pudgie shouted a parting comment: "Tell Tommy I want my pants back. He's got a pair of my pants."
 
A Practice Field Of Rocks and Glass
 The cars pulled up and parked at a slant outside the Kings Bay practice field at the corner of Avenue Z and Coyle Street. It was a little after 8, and the Sheepshead Bay neighborhood was deserted and engulfed in slumberous quiet.
Practice is always on Wednesday night -- roughly 8:30 to 10 -- and excepting a police officer caught up in a shootout or a firefighter preoccupied with a flaming building, Pudgie expects most of the players to be there. The team practices only this solitary evening each week. How much can you demand of part-time players who are paid nothing?
The field is pathetic. Pudgie describes it as a horror, and it is a generous assessment. To a large extent, it is rocks and shards of glass. Getting on toward 8:30, the familiar huge '78 Buick puttered to a halt on the sidewalk, almost on the field itself.
"Hey, dress up, men," one of the players announced. "The Pudge is here. Our mentor."
The locker room was a rusted trailer rig parked permanently at the perimeter of the field. It was tight inside, so thick-muscled players changed quickly and moved out onto the field. The derisive locker room humor of football took place mostly on the scraggly grass.
"Man, that's an ugly shirt you got on. Get it out of the trash?"
"Nah, got it from your wife."
The forecast had been for rain and strong winds. The rain held off but the winds came, and the temperature plunged. It was not a night that had much good in it.
Muscle was padded and buckled. The uniforms were red and white. The team deliberately takes it easy in practice. No real hitting is tolerated at the scrimmage line. Pudgie can't risk injuries inflicted by his own players.
None of the three quarterbacks showed up, so Rich Visco, the fullback and tight end, did the passing during the receiver drills. Pudgie liked to work on the kicking game in practice, but the kicker stayed home, too. He has to drive in from New Jersey, and he doesn't always feel like it. This is how it goes in semipro ball.
The Mariners' one loss this year, to the Hartford Mustangs, came in a game when nine starting Mariners failed to make it, including John Walsh, who was getting married in California. Pudgie missed the game too, feeling obliged to be at his son's wedding. In another game, Pudgie's starting quarterback was among the absentees because he was the best man at a friend's wedding. Pudgie lectures his players to try mightily not to get married or have pregnancies culminate during football season.
Pudgie moved among the caged faces, taking in the grunts and verbal brutalities of the game, yelling at their mistakes. "I stress block, tackle, get off the ball, don't make mistakes," he said. "We pride ourselves on not making turnovers. We don't go for innovative. We can't do anything too fancy. I only have an hour and a half a week to practice these guys."
Pudgie has his crusty side, and his style for making substitutions tends to be extremely direct. "Sometimes Pudgie will walk right onto the field during a game and say to a guy, 'You're garbage, get off the field,' " said Mr. Pecorella, the guard from Wall Street. "It's totally unprofessional, but that's Pudgie."
Still, players get attached to him. "I love the guy," Mr. Visco said. "He's always there if you need him. If you lose, of course, you never hear the end of his mouth." An operations manager on Wall Street, Mr. Visco has been on the team since he was 18, and at 33 his body has been recommending that this be his final season. Pudgie tells him that he "bleeds Mariners red."
In no way is Pudgie one of those cunning coaches who devises ingenious game plans and calls every play himself. He is known for his brimstone oratory, not his X's and O's. His assistants take command of the play-calling. By and large, the only plays that Pudgie calls are inexplicable ones.
During one game, the Mariners intercepted a pass on third and long at their own one-yard line. There was a penalty on the play against the other team. Instead of declining the penalty and getting the ball, Pudgie took the penalty and gave the ball back to the other team. Mr. Pecorella remembers screaming at him: "Are you crazy? What's wrong with your head?"
The opposing quarterback was sacked on the next play. On fourth down, the punter shanked his kick. The Mariners got the ball on their 40 instead of their 1. "That was a totally weird call," Mr. Pecorella said. "Pudgie Walsh is always making these totally weird calls. And then they work out. It drives me nuts."
The players were cold. The swirling wind whipped the field. They could go now, but first they had to listen to Pudgie. It was his time to rouse them for the next game's rough action.
"Now we're doing well, and we're going to keep pounding and pounding and pounding," he said. "Because I'm going to make you. I'm not going to let you do anything but win. You will win and then you will win again. Because you're Mariners. And there's 41 years of tradition. You're Mariners and you're going to be on top of the heap. Now let's go."
With that, they all joined hands in a big huddle and yelled, "One, two, three, yeah!" into the inky sky. Sufficiently pepped up, they changed back into their mortal clothes and dissolved into the night. Other work beckoned tomorrow.
 
During a Game, 'I Become a Maniac'
 On a crisp Friday evening a week ago, the game began well for the Brooklyn Mariners. The Long Island Seahawks picked up only two yards on their first possession. The Mariners then chewed their way to a 32-yard field goal. The thuds and grunts told it was a sweaty, physical game, and the bigger size of the Mariners was having its expected effect.
Not unexpectedly, Pudgie was in the foulest of moods. Another game scheduled to precede the Mariners game ran well over, delaying the kickoff by nearly an hour. Pudgie stalked the field an emotional vortex, barking at anyone who came within a mile of him. At the start of the season, Pudgie always reminds his players that he loves them ("Actually, some of them I only like"), but he cautions that during a game "I become a maniac."
Indeed, studying Pudgie prowling the sidelines is like watching someone who has just learned his pension has been canceled the day after his real-estate taxes tripled. He literally quivers with pent-up rage. Players often weigh whether they ought to chain him to something, muzzle him or simply kill him. Pudgie considers it a miracle no player has ever decked him.
Pudgie didn't like it when a defensive back trotted off the field, vocally celebrating a tackle he had made. Pudgie positioned his face, flame-red, at most a millimeter from the player and, his voice loud enough to be heard in New Jersey, roared, "You play football and shut your mouth or you're out of here!"
He didn't like it when a player mistakenly went onto the field at the wrong time, advising him: "You are such an idiot. You are so incredibly stupid it amazes me."
Just about everyone else, including the referees, his coaches, visiting fans and his best friends, were at one point or another the unlucky recipient of unsanitized, unrestrained Pudgie vitriol.
"Pudgie is out of his mind tonight," Mr. Pecorella said. "But I've seen him worse. I'd say he's a 9. When he swallows his false teeth and starts gagging on them on the sidelines, that's when he's at a 10."
Playing before more than 200 of their boisterous, beer-nourished partisans, the Mariners rose to Pudgie's invective and the crowd's demanding chants. They began the second quarter by smartly marching almost the length of the field for a touchdown. When they put seven more points on the board early in the third, padding their lead to 17-0, the outcome seemed ordained.
Pudgie was not yet satisfied. "Dominate them," he exhorted the defense. "Dominate them." The final score was 20-7.
The victory sweetened the Mariners' record to 7-1. The opposing coach pumped Pudgie's hand and said, "Once again, Pudgie, once again." Pudgie summoned the players to the center of the field, where he told them emphatically: "That was Mariners football. You came. You wanted it. You took it." Then, as was team custom, the players knelt on one knee and recited a prayer. Out of the edge of his eye, Pudgie spied a Seahawks player who had formerly been on the Mariners and hollered that he wanted his shirt back.
Moonlight limned the players' faces. It had passed midnight and become Saturday morning. Ballyhooing fans wobbled out of the scarred bleachers. Pudgie Walsh got into his '78 Buick a contented man. Joy in Brooklyn.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
Europe Heads a Very Short List Of Foreign Investment Prospects

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
INVESTORS looking to diversify abroad from pricey American stock markets face an ever bigger quandary: The places most insulated from a downturn in this country are places you may not want to send your money.
Japan is still mired in recession. Much of the rest of the Far East is in currency or other turmoil. And while the top-performing funds this summer focused on Russia and Mexico, many people were wary of their risks. As for Latin America, markets are thin and, in any event, tend to rise and fall with those here. 
 So internationally minded investors, almost by default, keep gravitating to Europe. And while no European stock funds even appeared among the top 10 international equity funds in the spring, there were 7 among the leading 20 during the third quarter.
Merrill Lynch EuroFund A was best of the group, and sixth on the overall list, with a gain of 10 percent; the next-best European fund was Mutual European Z, up 9.3 percent, then Fidelity Europe Capital Appreciation, up 8.8 percent.
Europe is a compromise, to be sure: The chief risk, other than a strong dollar, is the huge, Wall Street-like run-ups already posted across the Atlantic. Much of that has come in anticipation of monetary union scheduled for January 1999 and the deregulation and corporate restructuring this has inspired.
"There's no question that Europe stands next in line to follow the United States on the economic growth curve," said John Boich, senior portfolio manager for two international funds sponsored by Montgomery Asset Management in San Francisco.
"But this market has priced in pretty high expectations," he added, "so I'm a cautious believer."
While the casual American observer might think otherwise, judging from the unending discussion and jockeying for position, market strategists seem convinced that Europe's monetary union will come as scheduled, a prospect that has already been contributing for years to the Continent's investment appeal.
"People are looking at it pretty much as a fait accompli," said Anthony Cragg, a manager of international funds at Strong Capital Management in Milwaukee. He called the process of financial integration and the market disciplines it implies a "big impetus" for companies to become more efficient to meet new competition, both at home and on a broader, pan-European playing field.
Another important attraction for investors in Europe, according to Richard C. Pell, investment strategist for Bank Julius Baer in New York, is the fast-growing interest in stocks by individual investors there who traditionally have tended to rely on bonds and real estate. Discount brokers are springing up: Fidelity, Vanguard and other American mutual fund groups have arrived and various European companies have started to repurchase their shares and taken other steps to lift the value of their stocks.
Moreover, Mr. Pell argued, "Europe has a retirement savings crisis" that would mean heavy institutional demand for stock by companies with largely unfunded pension plans.
Integration, Mr. Boich observed, means that member countries give up the powerful fiscal and monetary levers on which they have relied to guide their economies. What fills this void, he said, are measures to adapt to the new competition -- privatization of state-owned enterprises, free rein for technology to promote efficiency and other loosening of control.
"Deregulation will be the big thing," said Marc Slendebroek, head of European research for Zurich Investment Management in London, citing recent examples like the sharply extended store hours in Germany and the Netherlands.
At the same time, powerful cultural forces still hobble European labor markets, where double-digit unemployment rates are common. But the successful United States model and the rigors of the marketplace are eroding all manner of restrictions, Mr. Slendebroek observed. "When the going gets really tough," he said, "people get a lot more friendly toward change."
Among the most appealing opportunities in Europe, portfolio managers say, are in rapidly growing Ireland, in the strengthening of the currencies of Spain, Portugal and Scandinavia, and in what Mr. Boich called the "untold story" of deregulation in air, rail and bus transportation on much of the Continent.
Italy, vying to qualify as an original member of the European Monetary Union, is seen as likely to pay off well for investors who bet on lower interest rates. Researchers at Paribas, the French-based bank, predict reductions of three-quarters of a point in Italian interest rates in December or January.
Despite Europe's understandable pull -- and the negatives attached to much of Asia these days -- some international strategists say they are alert to pounce on bargains in the Far East, particularly Japan.
"There will be a time when everybody's written it off -- and it comes back to life," said Strong's Mr. Cragg of Japan, home of the world's second-largest stock market.
Even now, when its economy is at best flat, he said, "Japan I think is oversold."
FOR American investors, it also has the advantage of being a market with very low correlation to those in this country, thereby "providing a different rhythm, a different cycle, to your portfolio," Mr. Cragg said. The Strong International Stock fund currently has 12 percent of its $220 million portfolio invested in Japan and 14 percent elsewhere in Asia, a combined share that nearly matches its 28 percent commitment to Europe.
And John D. Spears, co-manager of the two funds run by Tweedy, Browne, an investment firm that has built a reputation for uncovering individual stock bargains wherever they can be found, said he seeks out the cheapest 10 percent of Japanese stocks in terms of price-to-book value, which sell for only half as much as a comparable group of American securities.
Still, with deregulation in Japan mostly just talk for now and its interest rates already so low as to bar significant cuts, most observers remain leery of the country's prospects.
"Japan will probably reform policy just enough to skirt disaster," Rosanne M. Cahn of Credit Suisse First Boston has advised clients.
As for Japan's neighbors in Southeast Asia, few seem to find much favor.
They face "a far more challenging and competitive international climate" than that region did in its last slump a decade ago, said Joseph P. Quinlan of Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter. "One round of currency devaluations will not go very far in addressing and redressing the structural problems of Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2784 words

HEADLINE: Capitalism With A Vengeance

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
BILL BROWDER started buying Russian stocks before there was a stock market here. It was 1993, the year President Boris N. Yeltsin defeated Communist hard-liners by shelling the Parliament. Industrial output was collapsing; inflation was rampant.
Investing? Russians with money were smuggling billions of dollars out of the country. There were no exchanges, no prospectuses, no earnings reports and almost no earnings. 
 But there was stock. Under Mr. Yeltsin's privatization program, shares in thousands of former Government enterprises were auctioned off or given to workers and managers. Most people thought these shares were worthless; Mr. Browder thought they were cheap. As Salomon Brothers' 29-year-old manager for Russian equities, and then later on his own, he went to places like Siberia and Tatarstan to snap up shares in oil companies, mines and utilities.
Today, that looks smart. Wearing dollar-sign cuff links and working a few blocks from the Bolshoi Theater, Mr. Browder, now 33, runs what could be the most successful investment fund in the world this year. Shares in the Hermitage Fund, which began in April 1996 with $25 million from Republic National Bank in New York, doubled in 1996 and have nearly tripled again since January. With new money pouring in from wealthy investors and institutions around the world, Mr. Browder now manages $1.2 billion in Russian stocks.
Russia is hot. Six years after the collapse of the Soviet Union, the land of Lenin and Stalin is suddenly gripped by stock-buying fever. Its nascent stock market has shot higher lately than any other, tripling in the last 18 months. Professional traders now swap shares over an electronic trading system. Foreign investment funds like Hermitage, often registered in tax havens like the Cayman Islands, Cyprus and Guernsey, where Hermitage is based, have channeled about $3 billion into Russian stocks. Moscow's top hotels are swarming with Western bankers, brokers and deal makers.
"Almost every major emerging-market stock fund is here," said Dirk Damrau, head of research at Renaissance Capital Group, one of Moscow's biggest investment firms. "Anyone who was in Latin America or Asia or Central Europe is now here."
The boom has been driven by two things: a conviction that Mr. Yeltsin's economic changes are making Russia safe for capitalism and, more opportunistically, the lure of incredibly cheap assets -- the upshot of privatization plans that bore little resemblance to capitalism as practiced in the West.
Russian companies control some of the world's biggest oil reserves, its biggest supplier of natural gas, its biggest nickel and platinum mines and thousands of huge if decrepit factories. Yet even today, the combined stock value of Russia's 50 biggest companies is less than $150 billion -- about the same as Exxon or Coca-Cola.
The big debate now is whether Russia is still cheap, after the tremendous run-up in stock prices. Most investors agree that the easy money has already been made. But they disagree deeply on whether the market is poised for yet more growth.
By any measure, investing in Russia is a mind-bending experience. Russian companies are in a shocking state of disrepair, needing either billions of dollars in reconstruction or outright demolition. Many managers have brazenly looted assets or ceded control to organized crime bosses. Others have manipulated profits through new holding companies, circumventing original shareholders. Only a few companies report audited financial results; many report almost nothing at all. And many stocks trade so rarely that it can take weeks to buy or sell them.
But the markets here are not filled with penny stocks and Ponzi schemes, though there have been some extremely dubious enterprises. And like most former Communist countries, Russia has had its share of blatant fraud and pyramid schemes.
Many Russian companies, though, are very real -- and very huge. The money pouring into Russian stocks has come overwhelmingly from foreign investment funds whose investors are from Wall Street, London, Hong Kong and elsewhere. While Russia remains too wild for most mutual funds or institutional investors like insurance companies, its sheer immensity has made it impossible to ignore.
Still, the stock boom here is curiously disconnected from the real economy. Most of the trading is between offshore hedge funds. Very little money has actually flowed into the companies themselves because only a handful have raised capital by selling new shares.
And Russia's economy is still a mess. Growth is essentially zero; industrial output has only begun to stabilize after five years of decline. Outside the glitter of Moscow, this remains a land of bleak poverty.
So how surreal is investing in Russia? Consider Unified Energy System, the country's main electric utility and its most-active stock. Its shares have soared nearly 600 percent this year, from 7 cents to 40 cents, after the company reported a modest profit last year on revenues of about $1.7 billion. But those revenues include several hundred million dollars in unpaid customer bills -- and investors don't yet know exactly how many millions or whether U.E.S. will be able to collect much of the money.
Or consider Avto Vaz, which makes 70 percent of all cars in Russia. Despite tough import restrictions that protect it from competition, the company lost $442 million last year and owes $500 million in back taxes. Its cars roll out of the factory with an average of 42 defects apiece and are widely loathed by Russian consumers. But the stock has climbed tenfold, from $1.60 to $16 in the last year, because no one believes the Government will shut down the company.
Some of Russia's biggest oil companies, meanwhile, have systematically shifted their profits into new holding companies -- and out of the reach of most ordinary shareholders. Indeed, many of the most successful investors in Russian stocks have been those who found ways to bet on the side of managers who were draining profits from other shareholders.
"What's important to know is who really owns the stock and whether they are on your side," said an American money manager here, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "If you're fighting against the side of management, you're probably going to lose."
 
The Traders
Modern Trappings, Obsolete Methods
At first glance, the trading room at Troika Dialog, the biggest brokerage firm in Moscow, looks like a carbon copy of trading operations in London or New York. But appearances are deceiving.
Several dozen clean-cut men in oxford shirts and conservative ties sit at banks of computer screens, periodically calling out orders on the telephone. The screens flash lists of buyers and sellers for about 200 stocks: Lukoil, Aeroflot, Rostelecom, Moscow Telephone and others. Trades are entered and logged at the touch of a button.
The banter ebbs and flows between English and Russian, but the topics would be familiar in any trading room: bid-ask spreads, sports, difficult clients, night life and who is suddenly buying up 10,000 shares of XYZ stock. During lulls, the traders wolf down hot lunches from foam containers; some practice golf putts in the aisles.
None of this existed two years ago. Aslan Khalichkhov, at 29 a veteran of the Moscow market, still has trouble believing the pace of transformation. When he started in 1994, "trading" began when an armored truck would pull up to the cavernous Russian exchange building and unload several million dollars in cash.
"The truck would come at 3 P.M. every day," Mr. Khalichkhov recalled. Inside, brokers set up at long tables and waited for people to bring in bundles of the vouchers that entitled holders to shares in newly privatized companies.
"It really was 'over-the-counter,' " he said. "At the end of the day, you would change the voucher for money. Then the truck would show at 6 or 6:30, and we would hand over the vouchers."
Today, about 100 million shares trade daily over the Russian Trading System. Like the Nasdaq system, which electronically links brokers and dealers in the United States, the R.T.S. allows brokerage firms to post competing prices for stocks and execute orders electronically. It is modern, fast and so far free of scandals.
But the old Russia endures just below the surface. Except for about two dozen major stocks, most companies trade so thinly that fund managers often wait days or weeks to complete a big transaction. Reflecting the risk of holding thinly traded stocks, the gap between the prices at which brokers are willing to buy and sell a particular stock can be huge. On one recent day, the highest bid for Novosibirsk Tin Plant was $69, while the lowest selling price was $90.
Indeed, fund managers say most Russian stocks are not exchanged over the R.T.S. system at all; instead, they are bought or sold in private phone calls between clients. To find a hard-to-get stock, fund managers usually hire brokers to scour the town where a company is based.
Even if traders do buy and sell shares electronically, it usually takes at least a week before the shares actually change hands. That is because brokers must re-register the shares, a cumbersome process that often means sending documents back and forth between local registrars who may be thousands of miles apart. If glitches occur, and they do, weeks can pass before the trades are officially complete. By contrast, trades on Nasdaq are settled in three days.
The lag time worries many traders because it increases the risk that a big investor will back out of a trade and prompt a chain reaction of defaults by other traders caught in a sudden squeeze. No calamities have yet occurred, though traders say small-scale defaults are frequent. "It's a ticking time bomb," said Fred Berliner, a burly and bearded former hedge-fund manager from New York who runs Troika's trading room.
 
The Pioneers
Potential Windfalls, Financial Quicksand
Bill Browder's first epiphany about Russia came four years ago, during a visit to a fleet of fishing trawlers off Murmansk. It was the math that amazed him.
A soft-spoken M.B.A. from Stanford University who had worked for Salomon in Central Europe, Mr. Browder was advising managers who wanted to take a controlling stake in the Government-owned fleet, which was becoming a private company.
The company had 100 ships, each less than 10 years old, which cost as much as $20 million apiece when new. Yet under Government formulas, the managers were able to buy 51 percent of the company for $2.5 million. Put another way, the ships were being sold for a fraction of their real value.
"I came here, saw what was going on and said, 'This is incredible,' " Mr. Browder recalled recently.
In the helter-skelter rush to privatize some 13,000 companies, shares representing a third of Russia's industrial infrastructure were being valued at about $3 billion just four years ago. Newly private oil companies had stock market valuations that translated into pennies per barrel of oil reserves.
When Russia had a bank panic in 1995, Mr. Browder noticed that Russia's one real bank, which had 70 percent of all deposits and thousands of branches, was relatively solid. Its stock value translated to about $5,000 per branch -- bricks and mortar included -- and has since soared as the dust has settled.
Opportunity? "This was not rocket science," Mr. Browder remarked.
But this was Russia, and nothing was simple. Many Russian companies viewed shareholders with indifference or hostility, and some still do. Many managers had never asked to have their stocks trade publicly, and they had their own ideas about how to manage company profits. But suddenly their stock was "public" because workers had sold their free shares for a quick gain.
The lack of attention to "shareholder value" was especially glaring at several of Russia's biggest oil companies, where, under one approach to privatization, workers had been given preferred stock equal to about 25 percent ownership. The preferred shares had no voting power but an automatic claim to 10 percent of the company's profits as a dividend. Initially, they sold at a huge discount to ordinary common stock, but as awareness of their dividend potential spread last year, they soared in value by about 1,400 percent.
But that was not the end of the story. Many of the exploration and drilling companies had also been herded together by the Government under new holding companies. By 1996, profits in the original companies started to evaporate, and their share prices languished. The profits, meanwhile, showed up in the new holding companies, some of whose shares have soared more than 1,300 percent this year.
Others might have sued or screamed. Mr. Browder, detecting the profit shift early, decided instead to start unloading much of his preferred stock and start buying shares in the holding companies. These stocks could be acquired from managers at subsidiaries who had swapped their original stock for that of parent companies.
Not surprisingly, shareholder grievances here have become increasingly heated.
In one of the biggest brawls, a group comprised largely of American investors has battled managers at a big Russian steel company, Novolipetsk Metal Works. The Americans investors, led by an offshore fund called Cambridge Capital Management, own slightly more than half the stock but have not been able to get a seat on the board, despite winning eight court decisions. Meanwhile, the company has reported that profits plunged $493 million in 1996.
Last month, dissident shareholders led by Western investors put pressure on a subsidiary of Yukos Oil to drop a stock offering they feared would dilute their shares.
But before they could celebrate, company executives surprised them by announcing yet another reorganization that opened new possibilities for diverting profits.
Mr. Browder, who owns shares in the Yukos holding company, is not concerned. "When a company does terrible things to the subsidiary," he said, "I would rather be on the side with the power."
 
The Buccaneers
Steady Nerves, Foreign Checkbooks
Eighteen months into Russia's bull market, Russians themselves remain conspicuously absent from daily trading.
Most Russians are still struggling just to pay their household bills. And pension funds, insurance companies and other institutional investors are just starting here; all together, domestic Russian investment funds manage only about $24 million, according to Skate Investor Services, a Moscow stock research company.
Instead, most of the money pouring into stocks here has come from offshore investment funds like Hermitage. Such funds now manage about $3 billion, most of that from wealthy and adventurous foreign investors. And even that sum is just a tiny fraction of the money that goes into, say, Southeast Asia.
"Right now, it's still for buccaneers," said Viktor B. Sakharov, president of the fledgling Moscow Stock Exchange.
The Russian market could edge closer toward becoming a target for more conventional investors over the next two months, however.
Both Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company and the International Financial Corporation, an arm of the World Bank, plan to include the stocks of Russian companies in their indexes of global emerging stock markets.
A presence on those rosters could draw considerable money from institutional investors, many of whom try to line up their global stock portfolios with the weightings of such indexes.
A big subject of debate is whether Russians who secretly shipped some $50 billion out of the country since 1992 have now begun bringing it back -- perhaps through the offshore funds.
The question is impossible to resolve with certainty, but most money managers say the answer is no.
"Foreign investment will be the key to the recovery," said Mr. Damrau of Renaissance Capital. "The flight capital will probably come back only after the more conservative foreign investors have come back."
What will draw them here to stay?
Analysts say that the Russian economy will need to show steady growth after five years of nightmarish depression.
Russian companies must begin generating real growth and profits, too, rather than relying on ridiculously valued assets to lure investors.
And money managers must gain more confidence that Russia's commitment to markets is for real.
"Russia is rapidly becoming a much more normal place," said Mark Cooke, chief investment officer at Brunswick Capital Management, an investment company in Moscow.
But, he added, "This is not going to turn into a conventional, cozy little democracy overnight."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Russian Market remains something of a free-for-all. "Right now, it's still for buccaneers," says the president of the Moscow Stock Exchange, above. (Peter Blakely/Saba)(pg. 10)
 
Charts: "Bear Traps in the Russian Stock Market"
Factors that make investing in Russia wilder than in the United States:
 
AUDITS Most companies still do not produce audited financial results; hardly any produce audits that conform with American Generally Accepted Accounting Principles or International Accounting Standards.
 
PROFITS Profits can be shifted among companies through transfer pricing arrangements: An oil production company might sell its oil at low cost to a separate holding company for resale at much higher profit.
 
SHAREHOLDER REPRESENTATION Though Russian laws theoretically guarantee shareholders proportional representation on boards of directors, some companies blatantly refuse to comply. Example: Novolipetsk Metal Works, which has blocked Western investors who control over 50 percent of its stock from getting any seats on its board.
 
FOR RUSSIANS ONLY Some stocks can be bought only by Russian investors, including much of the stock of Gazprom, the world's biggest natural-gas distributor. Gazprom American depository receipts are twice as expensive as identical shares in Russia.
 
HIDDEN TRADING More than 200 companies have stocks quoted on the Russian Trading System, but as much as 80 percent of trading is not formally reported. Brokerage firms do not have to report trades between themselves and their clients, and most such trades go unreported. Indicators of stock activity are not necessarily accurate.
 
TRADING Not over 'til it's over. Actual settlement of trades over the Russian Trading System can take five days or longer, because shares must be reregistered in a cumbersome process. If a trade is not settled within a week, an investor can legally back out.
 
"Follow the Money"
Analysts say one of the hazards of investing in Russian stocks is the ease with which profits can be shifted among the business units of Russia's complex business groups. An example is Sidanko Group, the country's second-biggest oil company. Its publicly traded subsidiaries all reported losses or earnings declines for the first half of 1997, while the parent company's earnings were tripling. Holders of certain subsidaries' shares received returns far below the Moscow market's average. (Sources: Bloomberg Financial Markets (stock performance); Brunswick Brokerage; Creditanstalt)
 
"Russia's Bargain Basement"
The big driver of the stock market has been the chase of cheap assets. Here are some current examples that suggest Russia may still be a bargain.
 
PETROLEUM
Oil for 75 cents a barrel. That is the average stock market capitalization for Russia's giant oil companies, calculated against their oil reserves, versus more than $11 for American companies.
 
UTILITIES
Power plants at one-fifth the market rate. Russian electric utility stocks price them at $201,000 for each megawatt of generating capacity, versus about $1 million for each megawatt to build a new plant.
 
COMMUNICATIONS
Moscow City Telephone's stock value is $870 for each access line, compared with anywhere from $1,000 a line in the United States to $3,000 a line in fast-growing developing markets like Brazil. (Sources: Brunswick Securities, Moscow; Hermitage Capital Management)(pg. 10)
 
Graph: "Is It a Bubble?"
While Russia's economy has been growing slowly, if at all, the Moscow stock market has soared since the spring of 1996. Graph plots the Moscow Times index since January 1995. (Source: Russian European Centre for Economic Policy)(pg. 11)

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
Behind the Roar of Stock Funds, Bonds Quietly Gain More Appeal

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY MIDDLETON

 BODY:
CORRECTLY anticipating that interest rates would decline this year, Steve Savage took a plunge into the riskiest type of Government bond mutual funds -- and it paid off. "When rates got down to 6.30 percent, I was up 30 percent," said the investor, who is also editor of the Value Line Mutual Fund Survey newsletter.
Long-term interest rates did not stay that low, rising to 6.39 percent at the end of the quarter. But that still provided handsome profits for those, like Mr. Savage, who took big risks, and good returns for investors in the less exciting, and also less risky, normal run of bond funds. And rates fell from that level to below 6.30 percent by the end of last week, on reassuring economic reports. 
 The average mutual fund that invests strictly in United States Treasury securities returned 9.5 percent in the year ended Sept. 30, according to Lipper Analytical Services.
That is not much by some standards. Funds that invest in a mix of United States stocks were up 32 percent. But while far more money goes into stock mutual funds than into bond funds, the latter group seems to be gaining appeal after years of watching cash move to the greener pastures of equities.
Over the last couple of months, Treasury-only bond funds have seen good cash flows, said Robert Adler, president of AMG Data Services. "Clearly, Treasury-only funds are the beneficiary of some reallocation that may be occurring from stock funds," he said.
Various industry data suggest that the third quarter will be the first one since 1993 in which Government bond funds had a net inflow of cash.
For bond investors, there are two types of risk in American bonds. The first, credit risk, is the risk that the borrower will not pay. Buying Government securities eliminates that concern.
The second is interest-rate risk, reflecting the fact that existing bonds will fall in price if rates rise. In general, the longer the maturity of the bond, the greater that risk. The flip side, of course, is that if rates fall, the value of existing bonds will rise. That is what has happened in the last year.
Stock fund investors, of course, face the risk that the entire market will melt down, as happened briefly almost 10 years ago. Watching the recent climb in stock values, some recent buyers of bond funds may be fearing a repeat of that crash.
But many fixed-income analysts say bonds are particularly attractive right now, whatever one thinks about the stock market, and Government bonds are the favorite.
"I've been in the market for 17 years, and I've never seen a better market for bonds than the one that exists today," said Robert Kapito, vice chairman of Blackrock Financial Management. "And the high-quality bonds, the Government bonds, will probably be the best performers" over the next few months.
Mr. Kapito, whose firm runs the Compass Capital mutual funds, cites four factors buttressing a market that is strong and highly likely to remain so for an extended period:
* Rate increases are very unlikely because the Federal Reserve seems satisfied that the current level of economic growth will not ignite serious inflation.
* The dollar is very strong, attracting foreign investors, who prefer Treasuries to corporate debt.
* A shrinking Federal budget deficit requires less issuance of new bonds, driving up the value of existing ones.
* Spreads to other bonds, from gilt-edged corporate to junk and emerging-markets debt, are among the narrowest in recent history, so investors do not give up much yield to enjoy the freedom from credit risk that Treasuries offer.
David Horner, a senior financial strategist at Merrill Lynch, said he would not be surprised to see rates fall below 5 percent. At just over 6 percent now, the rate on the 30-year Treasury bond is more than four percentage points higher than inflation this year. Since World War II, the spread has averaged 2.5 points.
Bond funds invest in an array of securities, from Treasuries to junk (the two extremes of credit risk) and from short-term securities to long-term zero-coupon bonds (the two extremes of interest rate risk). Most bond funds have assets in mortgage-backed securities or high-grade corporate bonds, which have relatively little credit risk but offer yields a little better than those of Treasuries.
The largest category of Government bond funds -- those that own mortgage-backed securities in addition to Treasuries -- had assets of $73.7 billion as of Sept. 24. Funds that specialize in mortgages had $42.7 billion, and Treasury-only funds had just $12.8 billion, according to AMG.
But, reflecting how unpopular bond funds have been until recently, only the last group is larger than it was in January 1994, just before the Fed torpedoed the bond market with the first of several rate increases.
The yields on bonds other than Treasuries are relatively stingy. Mortgage-backed securities yield little more than half a percentage point more than Treasuries, while high-quality corporate bonds are less than half a percentage point above the mortgage-backed securities.
BOND professionals look at duration -- a measure of how long it will take to get most of the money from a bond, including both principal and interest -- as a measure of interest-rate risk. The higher the duration, the more a bond will rise in price if interest rates fall.
"The 30-year Treasury has a duration of 11, meaning every 100-basis-point move changes returns by 11 percent," Mr. Kapito said. (A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.) The duration of 10-year bonds is 7, so a move of 100 basis points would change the price by 7 percent. Two-year bonds have a duration of 1.3, he said.
Bonds with maturities of 5 to 10 years are called intermediate. Short-term funds own securities that mature within five years.
Most bond funds are in the intermediate category, which offer about 80 percent of the yield of long-term debt but with less risk. The largest Government bond fund, the $9.53 billion Franklin U.S. Government Securities I, has a duration of 4.2 years.
Bonds that pay interest only at maturity, called strips or zero coupons, are the most sensitive to interest-rate changes. Mr. Savage of Value Line reaped his profits from two American Century funds, Benham Target Maturity 2020 and Target Maturity 2025. The funds own Treasury zeros maturing in those years.
Not every fixed-income expert is enamored of Treasury bonds.
"Our Treasury position is relatively low," said Barbara Kenworthy, who manages several Prudential mutual funds, including Prudential Government Income. That portfolio currently has about one-third of its assets in Treasuries; the normal weighting is one-half.
"We think the market is in a trading range," she said. "There's still some upside, even at these levels, but we don't see enough to push interest rates below 6 percent." So she plans to deliver returns through the higher yields available on mortgages.

If so, it will be the first quarter since 1993 that such funds took in more cash from investors than they paid out in redemptions. Chart shows net cash flows into or out of Government bond funds. HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Fed Policy On Rates Seems Tough After All

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve's policy-making committee met last week and, again, did not raise interest rates -- a move that, for some, is evidence that the central bank is prolonging its "experiment" with inflation and growth.
Look closely, though, and you find that the Fed is not being so experimental, after all. Adjusted for inflation, the Fed's short-term interest-rate target is keeping the economy on a tighter leash than many people realize. 
 Those who are worried say the Fed, by not raising interest rates, is ignoring the traditional view that strong growth with low unemployment inevitably leads to rising wages and prices. But at the same time, analysts agree that it would be very hard politically for the Fed to raise interest rates now with no sign of an inflation threat.
In fact, though, it is the very absence of inflation that is making Fed policy more restrictive than it may appear.
The Fed's short-term interest-rate target is the Federal funds rate, the interest charged on overnight loans between banks. At present, the nominal Fed funds rate is 5.5 percent, last increased in March, when the Fed raised it one-quarter of a point.
But interest rates adjusted for inflation are a better measure of the drag that the Fed is putting on the economy, because they reflect real costs to the borrower. And after subtracting the Consumer Price Index increase for the last 12 months, the real Fed funds rate is 3.28 percent. Between the Fed's quarter-point increase and the sharp decline in inflation this year, that is up from 2.22 percent in February. While the economy is growing faster than last year, the price index is up only 1.6 percent at an annual rate through August, half the 3.3 percent of 1996.
To see how restrictive these real short-term rates are, look at February 1994, when the Fed began a yearlong series of increases in the nominal Federal funds rate, to 6 percent from 3 percent. At the time, the real, inflation-adjusted rate was an average of nine-hundredths of 1 percent for the last 12 months -- or almost zero -- according to James E. Glassman, senior United States economist at Chase Manhattan Bank. The Fed's credit policy was very easy.
By the time the Fed finished that round of tightening in February 1995, the real Fed funds rate had risen to 3.14 percent; the average for the next 12 months was 3.01 percent. While much tighter, it was not as restrictive as this August's 3.28 percent. "It's hard to find indications that the Fed's policy is too easy," Mr. Glassman said.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve and the focus of speculation about a conversion in thinking at the central bank, allowed that the real Fed funds rate was pretty high last February. It "might be at a level that will promote continued non-inflationary growth," he told Congress, "especially considering the recent rise in the exchange value of the dollar."
This trust in a high real Fed funds rate was reiterated at the August meeting of Fed policy makers. In the just-released minutes of that session, they said they left the nominal Fed funds rate unchanged because the real rate was "high by historical standards and provided some assurance that the current stance of policy would not accommodate a significant increase in underlying inflationary pressures."
So because the Fed is already tight, future increases should not have to be big. And if the economy slows some, maybe there will be none at all.

HEADLINE: Winning Ugly;
Bashing America for Fun and Profit

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE Ugly American has a new look around the world.
The first image, drawn from the best-selling 1958 novel and the subsequent movie starring Marlon Brando, was of the meddling, culturally obtuse ambassador in Southeast Asia. Soon the archetype had metamorphosed to the overfed, camera-laden tourist, loudly demanding a cheeseburger in a Paris cafe. 
 But if you are Malaysian these days, there is nothing uglier than an American currency trader -- the breed that Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad assailed recently as "morons" who triggered a 36 percent decrease in his nation's currency and shattered his dreams of building an Asian Silicon Valley. If you are French, the ugliest Americans reside in the United States Senate -- Alfonse M. D'Amato and Jesse Helms are frequently named -- and believe that America has the right to reach beyond its borders to punish companies that fail to obey American dictates about dealing with Iran and other rogue states. That explains why France, and the rest of the European Union, cheered last week when the French oil company Total said it would risk American sanctions and invest $2 billion in an Iranian gas project, along with the Russian oil giant Gazprom and -- no coincidence here -- Malaysia's state oil concern.
In Canada, where proximity can certainly make the heart grow less fond, hardly a day passes when the airwaves are not popping with denunciations of the next-door neighbor's latest insolence. The latest was the American demand for a special exemption (Korea) from the Canadian-inspired treaty to ban the use of land mines. When other nations refused to go along, Mr. Clinton declined to sign. And now the usual trade and fishing disputes have escalated into some of the nastiest political spats in years.
Casting America as arrogant -- even vilifying American power to suit a domestic audience -- is old sport around the world. But in the past few months, it has taken a new turn. From Beijing to Berlin, the complaint these days is that America's remarkable run of prosperity in recent years has made it unbearable. Its detractors complain that the United States not only wants to set the rules for the world (often in the guise of letting market forces reign); it also wants to use its power to dictate exceptions to those rules. More than a few see conspiracies at work. Fuming Asians like Mr. Mahathir charge that the real American aim is to crush rising competitors; the French see an effort to shove American-style capitalism down Europe's throat; the former President of Switzerland and one of the country's leading bankers speculated this year that the American-led hunt for Nazi gold was really an effort to destroy their country as a competing financial center.
The pushed are starting to push back. Prime Minister Lionel Jospin of France said last week that he "rejoiced" at the news that Total had decided to thumb its nose at the Iran-Libya Sanctions Act, an extraterritorial inspiration of Mr. D'Amato's that became law last year. "No one accepts the idea the Americans can make laws that apply on a global scale," Mr. Jospin said. "If not, the planet would be a different place and we would not be the old, independent nation that we are."
President Boris N. Yeltsin could not resist joining in, saying on Russian TV, "Thank God that Russia, France and Iran are independent, freedom-loving states, and interference from any other state is not to be tolerated." It's hard to remember the last time a major leader described Iran in quite those terms.
Funny, though, the image of America the all-powerful doesn't travel well from, say, a meeting of finance ministers in Hong Kong to a Congressional hearing in Washington. You wouldn't know that everyone was talking about the same country.
Consider current arguments over extending Presidential authority to negotiate new trade accords around the world -- the "fast track" bill that has stirred a raging argument in Washington lately.
 
The Home View
In hearing after news conference, many Democrats (and some Republicans) complain that America has never signed a major trade agreement that did not end up placing American workers at a disadvantage to smaller, swifter economic rivals.
And on the far left and the far right, fear is greater than ever that the United States is giving up too much national sovereignty to newly created international tribunals like the World Trade Organization, which has the power to rule whether national laws violate trade agreements. (Here's the scorecard so far: The W.T.O. has rendered decisions on five cases brought by the United States against other countries, and Washington has won all five. It has settled another seven. The U.S. has lost three cases brought by other nations, all minor.)
"What's weird here is that people who look at the same facts come away with different conclusions," said Rahm Emanuel, a senior adviser to President Clinton, who is trying to push through the trade bill. "Our competitors see an America that is confident, aggressive, winning every contest we enter. And many in Congress see an America that keeps losing in the world economy. It boggles the mind."
Why these diverging world views? The oft-cited explanation, of course, is that such disputes have arisen with the purported end of ideological conflict. When the Communist era divided the world into two camps, rifts over trade and other grubby issues that the State Department once dismissed as "low diplomacy" (compared with the supposed "high diplomacy" of arms control) were secondary to a grander cause. Clearly, though, other forces are at work.
The spread of American-style capitalism is one. This was fine with the Malaysians, Indonesians, Thais and others when foreign capital was flooding over their borders. Banks lent with abandon, often for projects that made more political sense than economic sense. And property markets soared as everyone bought into the myth that emerging markets would always emerge upwards. Little heed was paid to the fact that speculative investment can flow out as fast as it flows in.
 
'Perception Gap'
Now Southeast Asians have gotten a taste of how speculators make their pile: finding good-sized cracks in the way a nation is managing its economy and then betting against its currency. Sometimes that adds gasoline to an economic brushfire, burning down the whole forest.
"This is where the big perception gap comes in," said Jeffrey Garten, dean of the Yale School of Management and former Under Secretary of Commerce. "Most Americans feel that our brand of capitalism is either the answer to everyone's problems at best, or benign at worst. Nobody outside the U.S. shares that view. That doesn't mean they don't adopt our brand of capitalism, but they do it because they feel they have no choice.'
Or as Mr. Mahathir said recently, with much sarcasm: "We are told we are not worldly if we do not appreciate the workings of the international financial market. Obviously we are not sophisticated enough to accept losing money so that the manipulators can become richer."
Mr. Mahathir is from the old school of North-South conflict; his younger aides say they know that when it comes to international markets, American-style rules are becoming world rules. That is not the case when it comes to economic coercion toward foreign-policy ends.
 
Selective Isolation
Most of the world sided with the Europeans last week week when they argued that Congress had no right to punish non-American companies, like Total, for their activities beyond American borders. This year the same argument raged over American sanctions on foreign firms that do business with Cuba. And such sanctions are proliferating these days, the product of a Congress frustrated that other nations profit from dealing with countries America is seeking to isolate.
The problem with this approach is that America isolates only those countries it can afford to isolate. The Clinton Administration, for example, insists that the world must contain Iran, but "engage" China -- where there is a lot more American money on the table.
That's the real problem, one European diplomat complained recently: America is not only ugly again, it is inconsistently ugly.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
More Work, Less Play Make Jack Look Better Off

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
THE Census Bureau announced last week that the median income of American households rose in 1996 for the third year in a row, even after allowing for inflation. At last, the economic expansion appears to be lifting a lot of boats. Certainly the Clinton Administration says so. After years of stagnant incomes, the President said, "America's middle class, no longer forgotten, is rising fast."
But there's a less sanguine explanation buried in the Census report and in other Government data. Fathers and mothers, sons and daughters are working longer hours for roughly the same hourly pay. It is not higher wages but extra time on the job that is the main source of the rising household income. That is a precarious affluence. When the economy weakens, as it inevitably will, the extra work can disappear abruptly, as it did in the aftermath of the last recession. Raises are harder to reverse. 
 The time spent at work by members of the typical household, particularly the men, had been declining for years since the 1960's as incomes rose. The new leisure time had become a proud feature of the American life style. But starting in 1982, the trend reversed and the time devoted to work has risen ever since, apparently accelerating in the 1990's. Just why is not clear, but a major reason -- apart from supplementing skimpy raises -- may be job insecurity, according to two economists researching the trend.
Like bears gorging themselves in anticipation of winter, American workers are taking on work in these good times to offset the bad years they have been conditioned to expect. "Companies are offering the work, and people are self-insuring themselves, taking all the hours they can get because they are not sure they will have hours next year," said Barry Bluestone, a labor economist at the University of Massachusetts.
Mixing data from several sources, Mr. Bluestone and Steven Rose, a senior economist at the Educational Testing Service and a former Labor Department official in the Clinton Administration, found that for workers between 25 and 54, the average number of hours worked rose to 1,980 a year in 1995 from 1,840 in 1982. That was the low point in the post-World War II period, having fallen to that level from 1,975 hours in 1967.
Census Bureau data suggest a similar trend. Women were flooding into the work force in the 60's and 70's, of course, but men were pulling back even faster. Since 1982, however, men, too, have been working more.
"A lot of people ask, 'How come the economy is doing so well, but wages are so stagnant?' " said Charles Nelson, deputy director of the Census Bureau division that issues the annual income report. "Part of the answer is that because the economy is booming, you are adding more workers and more hours for those who are working. So there is more income out there."
Such explanations don't go unchallenged. The Census Bureau data are based on surveys in which a cross-section of Americans is asked how many hours they worked in the recent past. Some researchers argue that people tend to exaggerate; when workers are asked to record their activities every half-hour or so, their diaries show much less work than they had recalled.
"The discrepancy comes about," said John Robinson, a University of Maryland sociologist involved in the research, "because you are a good American if you put in long work hours. So people claim they have put in long hours." But the diaries do not measure additional weeks of work. And Mr. Robinson does not count as work time spent on coffee breaks, personal phone calls, lunch hours, visiting a dentist -- all more common in the new service economy.
"Martin Luther got all his best ideas on the toilet; is that work?" said Daniel Hamermesh, a labor economist at the University of Texas in Austin. "Work is less structured today than it was 30 years ago, when time clocks were more prevalent, but Government data is still based on the structure of work in the old days."
Definitions aside, the 140 hours a year added to the average worker's time on the job since 1982 are coming primarily from more weeks of work. The percentage of women jobholders working "full-year, full-time" -- that is, at least 35 hours a week as well as 52 weeks a year -- rose to 54.6 percent in 1996 from 51.1 percent in 1989, on the eve of the last recession, the Census Bureau reports. Some of that is from second jobs. For men, the percentages were 70.7 last year, up from 68.3 in 1989.
 
A Better Deal
"The explanation for the rise in household income has to be that the people in most households are working more, not that their individual wages are rising," Mr. Nelson said, citing Government data on wages. The Bureau reported last week that the median income of the nation's 101 million households, the majority of them families, had risen by 1.2 percent in 1996, to $35,492, after rises of 2.7 percent in 1995 and 0.7 percent in 1994. From 1989 to 1994, household income fell, and by more than it has since risen.
Some economists, particularly Mr. Rose and Mr. Bluestone, see in the rising number of hours worked an explanation of how the unemployment rate -- 4.9 percent in September, the Labor Department reported on Friday -- can get so low without generating labor shortages and wage pressures.
Most of the extra hours, they say, come from jobholders who accept offers from their employers to work more weeks each year. Rising overtime and, for the unemployed, fewer weeks between jobs also raise the annual average. The result is flexibility for employers. During periods of low unemployment in the past, workers felt more secure in their jobs, so they pressed for higher wages rather than more hours.
"There is no question," Mr. Rose said, "that a raise is a better deal than more hours on the job, when you consider that a 5 percent raise is the equivalent of two and one-half extra weeks of work."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Working Harder to Stay Afloat"
The Census Bureau reported last week that households have recaptured the income they lost in the recession of the early 90's. But to sustain that level of income, more and more people had to work in full-time jobs, especially women. The chart shows the percentage of men and women workers with year-round full time jobs from 1970-1995. (Source: Census Bureau)

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Boris & Jacques Show

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
French President Jacques Chirac met with Boris Yeltsin in Moscow to cook up an Iranian natural-gas deal that would (1) enrich their business interests, (2) gain a diplomatic foothold in the Persian Gulf by helping terrorists obtain missiles and (3) distract their restive unemployed by sticking a thumb in the U.S. eye.
When Vice President Al Gore tried to brief his counterpart, Prime Minister Chernomyrdin, on solid U.S. intelligence that Russian scientists were secretly helping the terrorist state of Iran build a 1,200-mile missile that would hold hostage the populations of Tel Aviv, Ankara and Riyadh, the American was tartly rebuffed. 
 Then Boris and Jacques sprang their surprise: a $2 billion deal undercutting U.S. attempts to hold back the spread of nuclear missiles. They accompanied this with dire warnings that the U.S. had better not enforce its laws against companies that do business with rogue states. By what right, they demanded, could the U.S. penalize European companies that flouted U.S. law?
That was "extraterritorial."
The new U.S. Ambassador to France, Felix Rohatyn, dared to point out that the recent demand by the European Union that Boeing break its deals with U.S. airlines was "extraterritorial," too. But such tortious interference was O.K. with Europe when directed at the U.S.
How will the Clinton Administration respond to this thumb in its eye and setback to its dual containment of Iran and Iraq -- a sensible, tough-minded strategy that could save tens of millions of lives? In matters Russian, our doughty Secretary Madeleine Albright is manipulated by her doughy deputy, Strobe Talbott. Figure Clinton to settle for gentle finger-wagging at Iran.
This will win the applause of the blame-America-first, business-is- business, forget-human-rights lobby such as is centered in Washington's Nixon Center for Peace Through Appeasement. James Schlesinger, Carter's Energy Secretary, leads its business-is-business charge; Maurice Greenberg, whose insurance companies make huge profits in China and who is an acolyte of Singapore's Lee Kuan Yew, wields the backstairs influence with the foreign-policy establishment.
Here's evidence of that influence: Greenberg, China's insurance broker, hired Frank Wisner, the disappointed seeker of our Paris embassy post, to be his vice chairman. And whom do you suppose Clinton-Gore just chose to "investigate" the Russian scientists' aid to Iran's missile-builders? Wisner, along with Yuri Koptev, Russia's suspect space bureaucrat. That'll be some investigation.
Clinton is actually trying to balance cordial relations with cocky Boris and Jacques against the safety of Israel, Turkey, Egypt and Saudi Arabia. Muddling through won't do; backbone is required.
Beyond urging Clinton to enforce the law, what can Congress do to see that some risk and some opprobrium is attached to those in the U.S. and abroad who flout U.S. laws?
Do not overlook the power of public oversight. Just before Russia's Gazprom (which enriches the Chernomyrdin family) and France's Total Petroleum made their $2 billion deal with Iran, Total limited its exposure to U.S. retaliation by selling its 1,600 gas stations to Ultramar Diamond Shamrock of San Antonio, Tex., taking back an 8 percent stake in that company.
Pretty shrewd way of avoiding the consequences of helping terrorists get missiles. But perhaps Congress's banking committees can bring in Joe Kerry of Merrill Lynch, who doesn't return my calls, and Total's dealmaker at First Boston and ask them publicly if they knew of the Iran deal beforehand.
Roger Hemminghaus, the C.E.O. of Diamond Shamrock, which provided the cover for Total's maneuver, tells me he had "no knowledge, to my knowledge" of the impending huge Iran deal.
A consumer boycott may be difficult against an oil company, as the sly French knew, but the average person with mutual funds can legitimately ask what institutions hold big chunks of Total's American front-company stock. According to Bloomberg News, the biggest are Brinson Partners; Equitable's Alliance Capital Management; Wellington Management, and Capital Research and Management. Divestiture is always an option.
And then, while we're at it, let's find out which mutual funds have how many billions of private American money in Chernomyrdin's Gazprom.
They took a risk. Actions have consequences. As they say, business is business.
