SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1136 words

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:

TELECOMMUNICATIONS
$30 Billion Bid for MCI
Worldcom Inc., an upstart long-distance telephone company based in Jackson, Miss., barged in on a grand trans-Atlantic alliance with a surprise offer to buy MCI Communications for $30 billion in stock. That is $9 billion richer than the offer MCI had accepted from British Telecommunications. Analysts said MCI, America's No. 2 long-distance carrier, would be hard-pressed not to accept the higher bid unless British Telecom makes a counteroffer or there are antitrust objections. Through a relentless series of acquisitions, Worldcom has grown from obscurity into the nation's fourth-largest long-distance company and a leading carrier of Internet traffic. The takeover would be the largest in American history. The offer, appropriately, came in a phone call.
 
TOYS 'R' US
Rough Play in Retailing
Not everything is fun and games at Toys "R" Us, a judge ruled. Upholding F.T.C. charges, Judge James P. Timony said that the company, the dominant toy retailer, used its market muscle to force leading toy makers, including Mattel and Hasbro, not to sell popular lines like Barbie and Mr. Potato Head to its emerging chief competition -- warehouse clubs like Price/Costco, BJ's and Sam's Club. The company said it would appeal the ruling to the full five-member commission. F.T.C. officials said that would mean a final decision would not take effect until after the Christmas season. 

TRADE
Paris vs. Washington
Prime Minister Lionel Jospin of France offered total support for a $2 billion investment in Iran by the French oil company Total -- a move that puts the new American Ambassador to France, Felix G. Rohatyn, in the middle of a full-fledged crisis. Like other Europeans, French officials have made little secret of their contempt for American legislation that threatens sanctions against countries that invest in Iran. But Washington is determined to show its toughness on trade. The Clinton Administration accused South Korea, Japan, Canada, Australia and the 15-member European Union of having failed to live up to their free-trade obligations. The report could lead to sanctions against them.
 
THE ECONOMY
Fed Sees No Threat
Surprising no one, Federal Reserve policy makers left interest rates unchanged. After all, the economy seems to be behaving nicely, growing enough to keep record numbers of Americans employed -- the jobless rate was unchanged at 4.9 percent in September -- but not enough to stir inflation, as the latest economic data show. Incomes rose six-tenths of a percent in August, the Commerce Department reported, and spending increased three-tenths of a percent. Orders placed with factories increased 1.3 percent in August. However, manufacturing growth slowed for the second consecutive month in September, the National Association of Purchasing Management reported.
 
MARKETS
Upward, but More Slowly
Markets advanced in the third quarter, although the pace slowed. The Dow Jones industrial average set another closing high -- 8,259.31 on Aug. 6 -- but ended the quarter at 7,945.26, up 3.55 percent, well under the 16.5 percent surge in the second quarter. Earnings warnings by some blue-chip companies, including Coca-Cola, Eastman Kodak and Procter & Gamble, inspired investors to turn to smaller stocks. Consequently, the quarter's best-performing index was the Nasdaq composite, which climbed 16.89 percent after gaining 18.04 percent in the second quarter. In the bond market, Treasury securities finished the quarter far stronger, pushing the yield on the long bond down to 6.39 percent from 6.78 percent on June 30. It ended the week at 6.28 percent. The Dow ended the week at 8,038.58, up 116.40, and the Nasdaq composite closed at a record 1,715.87.
 
SALES
Pocketbooks Stay Closed
What love affair does not have some troubled times? Now, even Americans' love of the road seems to be cooling. Chrysler's sales have slipped 7.1 percent this year from a strong performance in 1996, and they tumbled 14.1 percent last month with sales of mini-vans, Jeeps and pickup trucks down a surprising 13.9 percent. Over all, sales of domestically produced cars and trucks fell 6.4 percent last month, with G.M. up 3.7 percent and Ford down 1.6 percent. Honda and Subaru had gains, while Toyota and Saab reported declines. Retailers had slower-than-expected sales growth in September because consumers stayed home at the beginning of the month to watch television coverage of the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, Telecheck Services reported.
 
US AIRWAYS
A Deal With Pilots
US Airways and the union representing its 4,700 pilots reached a tentative contract agreement after more than a year of negotiations. The carrier, which has had record profits lately, would pay its pilots 1 percent more than the average wage of pilots at its four largest competitors and create a new low-cost carrier, US2, to compete with rivals like Southwest Airlines and Delta Express. The focus is now on Stephen M. Wolf, US Airways' chairman, who pledged that if the pilots helped him reduce costs, he would buy new aircraft and expand the airline. Airbus Industrie extended the deadline for ordering up to 400 planes until the union's rank and file could vote on the contract. Separately, nearly 10,000 reservations takers, gate agents and ticket sellers at the airline voted to join the Communications Workers of America, a big coup for the union.
 
PEOPLE
The Price of an Obsession
With no apologies to Tony Hillerman, a senior vice president of the Engelhard Corporation became a thief of time. Francis X. Vitale Jr., who put together one of the world's finest collections of 18th- and 19th-century European clocks, said in Federal District Court in Camden, N.J., that he had embezzled more than $12.4 million from Engelhard to indulge his obsession. . . . Ray Ozzie, the computer programmer who created I.B.M.'s popular Notes software, has formed a new company, Rythmix, to design new software that complements Notes and that may or may not be sold by I.B.M. . . . Seeking to slash costs and rebuild its photography business, Eastman Kodak said David P. Biehn, 54, the head of its ailing consumer division, would retire. Robert Keegan, 50, who now runs the company's professional division, will replace him.
 
TRUE BLUE
The Pepsi Generation at 100
Preparing to celebrate its 100th anniversary in 1998, Pepsico's look will be changing a bit. New cans for Pepsi, Diet Pepsi and caffeine-free Pepsi brands will be a bright royal blue with the word Pepsi in vertical white lettering on the can. "Coca-Cola is doing its best to own red, so the natural tendency is for Pepsi to want to own blue," said Aubrey Balkind, chief executive of Frankfurt Balkind Partners, which works on corporate identity projects.

HEADLINE: Merian L. Kirchner, 66, Dies; Inspired the Betsy-Tacy Books

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Merian Lovelace Kirchner, the little girl whose pleadings for just one more bedtime story gave birth to a beloved series of children's books, died on Sept. 25 at a hospital on Staten Island. She was 66 and the daughter of Maud Hart Lovelace, the creator of the Betsy-Tacy books.
Friends said the cause was emphysema. 
 It was her mother who lived and wrote the Betsy-Tacy life, not so much creating as copying her characters whole from her own turn-of-the-century childhood in Mankato, Minn., or Deep Valley, as it is known in the 10 main Betsy-Tacy books and three satellite volumes.
But it was little Merian Lovelace, growing up in the 1930's in Garden City, Long Island, who first demonstrated that her mother's girlhood had more than passing appeal. She pestered her mother so often for a new story about Betsy Ray and her friend Tacy Kelly that Mrs. Lovelace, who had concentrated on short stories and historical novels, decided to put Betsy and Tacy on paper.
The result has been something of a literary cult.
For although Betsy Ray and Tacy Kelly have never quite achieved the stature of, say, Nancy Drew, they have spawned a 1,000-member Betsy-Tacy society and a Betsy-Tacy home page (http://virtuflex.com/ Betsy-Tacy/), and they have turned Mankato into a tourist attraction.
Aside from the fact that Betsy was an uncommonly independent young heroine, a bustle-era girl who took her own ambitious career plans for granted, the books have exerted a special appeal because unlike Nancy Drew, who was blond, perfect and 18 forever, Betsy and her friends grew older in each successive book.
When the first book, "Betsy-Tacy," covering Betsy's meeting with Tacy at age 5, was published in 1940, Mrs. Kirchner was 9. By the time she got to Smith College, she was something of a minor celebrity, letting her classmates read the proofs of the latest installment.
The last book, "Betsy's Wedding," was published in 1955, a year after her marriage to Englebert Kirchner, a German-born writer.
As the daughter of a woman who turned her own childhood into literary fodder, Mrs. Kirchner might have been expected to continue the tradition.
But except for a column she wrote for the Betsy-Tacy Society newsletter, she showed little interest in her childhood and none in fiction.
Not that Mrs. Kirchner was especially rebellious. It was just that she decided to follow in the footsteps of her father, Delos Lovelace, a Minnesota-born journalist who was once city editor of the old New York Sun. (He was also the author of the novelization of the movie "King Kong," which helps explain why he named his daughter after the movie's director, Merian C. Cooper.)
Settling in Greenwich Village as her parents had done a generation earlier, Mrs. Kirchner held a series of jobs in journalism, contributing to a book on civil rights for Newsfront Publishers, working as a freelance book editor, and ending her career as a senior writer for the magazine Medical Economics.
After her mother's death in 1980, Mrs. Kirchner helped keep the Betsy-Tacy flame alive, working closely with the Betsy-Tacy Society and campaigning for reissues of the books. Her husband died in 1992.
For all her role in the creation of the Betsy-Tacy series, Mrs. Kirchner never appeared as a character, except by implication.
At the end of "Betsy's Wedding," as her husband, Joe, is about to go off to World War I, Betsy speaks of their plans to have a little girl named Bettina, not realizing, perhaps, that in time the little girl would make her mother write it all down.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Merian Lovelace Kirchner, left, and as a child with her mother, Maud Hart Lovelace (the real-life Betsy), left, and Frances Kenney Kirch (Tacy). Mrs. Lovelace began to write the Betsy-Tacy series because of her daughter's enthusiasm for her tales of a turn-of-the-century childhood. (Don V. Becker, 1992)

HEADLINE: Stalking Africa's Newest Game: Hostile Celebrities

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

DATELINE: CAPE TOWN

 BODY:
Although he hates the title, Fanie Jason is known as South Africa's only paparazzo.
Other than President Nelson Mandela and Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu, this country does not have many faces that are recognized overseas, so he does not get rich at his job. Last year, one minor celebrity he relentlessly tailed for a British tabloid sued and nearly bankrupted him. Since then, that man has become famous as a symbol of fury at paparazzi: Earl Spencer, the brother of Diana, Princess of Wales. 
 The case of Spencer v. Jason, which drew in a press freedom institute and a top constitutional lawyer, pitted two figures who inspire both admiration and disdain in others.
Mr. Jason is a quick-thinking photographer who has fought his way up, out of the poverty and despair of a black township. He stalks his targets relentlessly and admits that he has lied or played on white guilt to trick people into posing. Since Diana was killed in a car crash in Paris while fleeing photographers, he has received death threats, he said.
Earl Spencer is widely admired for the eulogy he gave at his sister's funeral and for saying paparazzi and newspaper editors had "her blood on their hands." But he was briefly a journalist himself, and speaks to gossip writers when it suits him.
Celebrity-poor South Africa became a battleground for him because he moved his family here two years ago, ostensibly to get away from the attention he was getting in Britain as Diana's brother. He was one of a handful of well-known Europeans and Americans who have vacationed or moved here since apartheid sanctions were lifted.
That influx is Mr. Jason's bread and butter, and he is not embarrassed about what he does. "I have a Toyota now, and a computer," he said. "Thanks to paparazzi."
Mr. Jason grew up in Guguletu, a black township just outside Cape Town, the eldest of six children of a mother who worked as a maid and a blind father who was unemployed.
For decades, Mr. Jason scraped by as a freelancer. He bought stolen cameras because they were cheap. He shot pin-ups for Drum, a black magazine, while working as a driver for a cosmetics company.
But he considers himself a newsman. In the 1980's, he photographed anti-apartheid protests, and was once jailed with Archbishop Tutu. Last year, covering a march against crime, he was hit by 38 pieces of bird shot, he said. In 1994, when the former black homeland Bophutatswana exploded, he traveled 20 hours by minibus taxi to get there because he could not afford a plane ticket. He says he has paid his own way to photograph the genocide in Rwanda and unrest in Hebron.
But before the London tabloids began phoning him, he often earned a pittance. He said, for example, that he had taken a picture of Archbishop Tutu opening his swimming pool to poor children and that a local paper would pay him only $3 for it.
But for other pictures, British papers have paid him as much as 6,000 pounds -- $9,000 -- for a shot. "Six thousand pounds?" he said. "That's abracadabra where I come from."
His first tabloid commission was to get a picture of the girlfriend of Mark Thatcher, son of the former Prime Minister of Britain, Margaret Thatcher. Mr. Thatcher moved to Cape Town in 1995. Mr. Jason went to the woman's house dressed in overalls and, in broken English, asked for a job as a gardener.
"While I was talking to her, my cell phone went off in my pocket," he said. "She said: 'You want gardening work, and you have a cell phone? I guess this is the new South Africa.' " He told her it was a child's toy and retreated. He then followed her for a week and hid in a flower bed to shoot pictures as she picked up her children at school.
He tricked Eva Herzigova, the Wonderbra model, into posing by telling her he was a fan and asking for a picture together. He sneaked up on Michael Jackson while he was dining in Sun City. When the former husband of Camilla Parker-Bowles, Prince Charles's girlfriend, honeymooned here with his new wife, Mr. Jason phoned them from the lobby. They said they wanted nothing to do with The Daily Mail, so Mr. Jason quickly changed his story and said The Mail was a local black paper. "They came down and posed," he said, and the pictures were on the front pages in London the next day.
When Earl Spencer started building a house in the Constantia suburb of Cape Town, a British tabloid asked for a picture. Mr. Jason disguised himself as a workman, hiding his camera in a lunch box. "I was stacking some bricks, and he walked by," he said. "I said, 'Hi, boss,' and he nodded, and I took a couple of snaps a few seconds later."
He also photographed the Earl's estranged wife and children, who were living in a different house. Then, he got a big break -- a maid he knew said her employer had a bed and breakfast where the Earl was meeting a girlfriend. He paid her to get the license plates of their cars, and promised her $420 if he got a picture of them together. Then he went to the girlfriend's house and befriended the gardener, hoping to confirm the story.
He said The Mail, fearful of being sued, did not run his article for months, until the woman's devastated husband had sold his own story to another British paper.
Meanwhile, the Earl had sued him, asking for a court order preventing any photographs of him or his family without his permission. That prompted the Freedom of Expression Institute, which defends press freedom here, to step in to underwrite Mr. Jason's defense.
The first judge granted a temporary restraining order preventing him from photographing the Earl.
"That really concerned us," said Alexandra Kuhn, coordinator of the institute's legal defense fund. "A public figure should be photographable when out in public."
The judge who heard the motion for a permanent order -- during which Mr. Jason was defended without charge by Wim Trengrove, a prominent constitutional lawyer -- insisted that the two sides settle, Miss Kuhn said.
Mr. Jason agreed to stop photographing the Earl's wife and children, to photograph him only in public places and to stay 10 yards away from him and 50 yards from his house. But, before the settlement was reached, he took another photograph of the Earl and was fined about $4,800 for contempt of court.
While he was in Israel, Mr. Jason said, his furniture and computer were seized to cover the debt.
Earl Spencer's lawyer declined to discuss the case. A message left with her asking the Earl to call was not returned.
Even Mr. Jason's backers say he is ruthless about his job and, in so many words, he admits it. "It puts bread on the table," he said.
Some of the paparazzi in Paris have been accused of taking pictures of Diana as she lay dying. Asked if he would do the same, Mr. Jason said: "Sure. I've taken hundreds of pictures of dead bodies. I'd commit professional suicide if I walked away from that. But I do feel sorry for her. She was a nice person."

HEADLINE: Tax Cuts Help the Wealthy in the Strong Economy

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
In the tough years of the early 1990's, the states raised taxes that hit the poor harder than the affluent. Now that the booming economy has made the states flush with money, they are cutting taxes -- for the affluent.
Sales and excise taxes, which fall more heavily on people at low income levels, were raised $11.7 billion from 1990 through 1993, data from the National Conference of State Legislatures show. These taxes have been cut by just $200 million, or less than 2 percent of the amount of the increase, since 1994. 
 From 1990 through 1993, the states raised income taxes, the major state tax burden on affluent people, by $8.2 billion. Since 1994, the states have more than reversed these increases with income tax cuts totaling $9.8 billion. (All the figures have been adjusted for inflation.)
In other words, individual income taxes accounted for 32 percent of all state tax increases from 1990 through 1993, but 72 percent of all state tax cuts since 1993.
"In most states, these changes have made already regressive state tax systems more regressive," said Nicholas Johnson, who studies state taxes for the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington. A report on state taxes by Mr. Johnson and Iris J. Lav is posted on the Internet (http://www.cbpp.org/ 930sttax.htm).
Sales and other taxes that are considered regressive (because their impact declines as incomes rise) were raised by 36 states in the early part of the decade, while only 9 states have cut these taxes since 1994. But only 20 states raised income taxes in the early 90's, and 20 states have cut income taxes since 1994, the budget center found.
Elizabeth Davis, a policy analyst at the Center for the Study of States in Albany, said the budget center's report "fits with what I am finding, which is that poor people now are bearing more of the burden of state taxes.
"States in the past few years have been cutting personal income and corporate income taxes right and left," she said, "especially in New York and New Jersey, whereas they have not cut sales taxes much at all."
The National Governors' Association cautioned that a deeper analysis of the details behind the tax data might show less vivid differences.
"You have to be real careful about sales taxes and whether they really are regressive," said Raymond C. Scheppach, executive director of the association. "A lot of states have exempted food, and many do not tax services, and so their sales taxes are designed to not be as regressive as an across-the-board sales tax."
Mr. Scheppach also faulted the budget center's analysis for not taking into account the early 1980's, when "many states raised income taxes and imposed surcharges because they had to."
But Mr. Johnson said he believed that a more detailed analysis would show that the shifting of state government tax burdens toward low- and moderate-income people was even worse than the report's figures suggested. He said many states had reduced services to low-income people in the 1990 recession and raised fees for services, like mass transit systems, that have a greater impact on the working poor.
Over all, the states count on sales and similar regressive taxes for just under half of their revenue. Individual income taxes, imposed by 41 states, produce nearly one-third of state revenue.
More increases in sales tax rates are unlikely in the near future, said Sally Adams of CCH State Tax Review, a publication for tax lawyers, "because a savvy public notices." But, she said, eight states have increased cigarette taxes, and five have raised gasoline taxes, both of which tend to fall more heavily on people with low incomes.
The techniques by which the states have cut income taxes have also tended to favor affluent people, the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities said.
The budget center found that 19 states had a maximum personal income tax rate of 7 percent or more in 1993, compared with 15 states today. Two more states, Maryland and Rhode Island, have enacted tax cuts that will reduce their maximum income tax rate below 7 percent in the next few years. Reducing the highest rate benefits only the residents with the highest incomes.
The report singled out Iowa as an example of a state that shifted tax burdens onto the poor. Iowa raised its sales tax from 4 percent to 5 percent in 1990, but since then, Gov. Terry E. Branstad, a Republican, has made an across-the-board decrease in individual income taxes, which tends to benefit high-income people more. New York, Ohio and Delaware used similar strategies that shift tax burdens to low-income people, the report said.
Only two states, Georgia and Missouri, have made significant cuts in sales taxes.
"In most states," the budget center's report said, "tax reductions or increases are considered without much information or debate over the extent to which various income groups would benefit or be harmed." Only Minnesota routinely makes such analyses public before tax changes are made.

HEADLINE: A Spanish Princess's Wedding Is Rich in Regional Symbolism

BYLINE: By The New York Times

DATELINE: BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 4

 BODY:
Princess Cristina, the third in line to the Spanish throne, married a Basque commoner who is a professional athlete today in a ceremony that paid tribute to Spain's diverse regions.
The Roman Catholic service in the 13th-century cathedral was principally in Spanish, but also used Catalan, the regional language spoken in Barcelona, where the bride lives, and the Basque language, the groom's native tongue. Crowds lining the 10-mile procession route waved little blue flags that read "Best Wishes" in the three languages. 
 Princess Cristina Federica de Borbon y Grecia, 32, is the first member of the Spanish royal family ever to hold a salaried job; she prepares photographic exhibitions for a savings bank foundation. The groom, Inaki Urdangarin, 29, is a professional handball team player. They met last year at the Atlanta Summer Olympics.
The wedding of the middle child of King Juan Carlos I and Queen Sofia was in step with the royal family's efforts to strengthen links to all the country's regions. It is a style that has helped make the royal family enormously popular since the monarchy was restored in 1975 after the death of the right-wing dictator, Gen. Francisco Franco.
But the televised storybook images from the Catalonian capital of the smiling princess in a long white gown -- scenes made available without charge by state-run television to stations around the world -- did not show a growing undercurrent of political tension between Spain's regions and Madrid.
The wedding served as a weekend pause in the battle of words.
The minority conservative Government of Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar controls Parliament thanks to support from the Barcelona-based Catalonian nationalist coalition, which in return has extracted concessions for greater control over the regional budget.
The Catalonian political leader, Jordi Pujol, was seated one row behind the Prime Minister in the cathedral today. Mr. Pujol has been staying at arm's length from the Government, partly because of incidents like the one at a recent benefit concert in Madrid that was supported by the central Government in which a performer was loudly heckled for singing in a dialect of Catalan.
But Mr. Aznar's relations are even worse with the Basque Nationalist Party, which withdrew its support for him last month after failing to win control over regional unemployment policy. The party leader declined an invitation to the wedding.
The Catalonian and Basque regions have been the traditional economic powerhouses of Spain, attracting job-seekers from poorer Spanish regions. They are also the two regions that have voiced support loudest for independence. The Basque region has an active separatist group that for years has used bomb attacks and kidnappings to fight Madrid.
The history of the regions made the match of the Spanish Princess, who has lived in Barcelona for five years, and the tall Basque athlete all the more engrossing for ordinary Spaniards.
"Just because we have our own language and culture doesn't mean that we reject Spain," said Alicia Ruiz, 22, a waitress at a hotel near the cathedral. "It's a shame how they think of us."
The King's oldest daughter, Princess Elena, also married a commoner, in Seville in 1995. That leaves only Crown Prince Felipe, 29, unmarried. And he has not expressed any wish to hurry to follow his sisters.

HEADLINE: Freshman Democrat Is Dogged by Relentless Foe

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4

 BODY:
The champagne bubbled, balloons kissed the ceiling and Loretta Sanchez stood center stage two weeks after the election, savoring the clatter of voices at her official victory party, thinking to herself it was all finally over.
She had defeated Representative Robert K. Dornan, the brash Orange County, Calif., conservative, by 984 votes, and she had done it in her first-ever run for Congress. It was the biggest upset of the election season; an upstart Hispanic Democrat had managed to upstage Mr. Dornan, an Irish Catholic Republican stalwart, in his own Republican stronghold. 
 But nearly 11 months later, Ms. Sanchez is still trying to beat back Mr. Dornan and jam him into a dark closet somewhere, preferably one that is soundproof. Hardly a day goes by, she said, that she is not shadowed by the former eight-term Congressman, a man best known for bombast.
Twice when she has gone to vote on the House floor, there he was, glad-handing his onetime colleagues across the way. Often when she reads a newspaper, there he is, on the front page, calling her a lapsed Catholic. A scan of the radio dial turns up Mr. Dornan again, on the Oliver North show. Even in the sanctity of her office, Mr. Dornan is there, in the guise of his son's voice, booming messages into her answering machine, a charge Mr. Dornan denies.
"I thought I had seen the last of Bob Dornan," she said. "I won the election. Let's get on with it. But people won't let me get on with it."
Mr. Dornan has contested the election, charging that it was stolen from him by bad ballots cast by people who were not United States citizens, or in some cases, not legal United States residents. The Committee on House Oversight has been investigating the claim for nearly 10 months, digging through Immigration and Naturalization Service work sheets and Orange County voter rolls.
The inquiry has led to flashes of revolt among Democrats, who call it an inquisition aimed more at frightening away Hispanic voters than uncovering fraud. Republican leaders counter that evidence is mounting in Mr. Dornan's quest to unseat Ms. Sanchez. There seems little question that some bad votes were cast. The issue remains: how many? Democrats contend the number falls far short of 984.
"It puts the Republicans in a difficult position," said John Pitney, a former deputy director of the Republican National Committee and now a professor of government at Claremont McKenna College in California. "On the one hand, they don't want a seat taken away from them by fraud. But between Dornan's personality and Democratic accusations of sharp anti-Latino bias, there is a downside to it."
There is a sense of unease, a feeling of perpetual preoccupation, about the whole affair for Ms. Sanchez, and it is clearly felt inside her Capitol Hill office. A few framed photographs sit on tabletops, and assorted inspirational messages hang on the walls. But the oversize bookcase sits forlorn, close to empty.
There is one stand-out decorating touch. A couple of model B-2 bombers sit near her door, as if to defy her opponent, the man some called "B-1" Bob for his support of the earlier B-1 bomber.
In beating Mr. Dornan, Ms. Sanchez became more than an ordinary freshman lawmaker. The 37-year-old businesswoman became a political celebrity, an icon for Democrats and underdogs alike. "She has become a symbol," said Representative Robert Menendez, the New Jersey Democrat who spearheaded the successful vote to banish Mr. Dornan from the House floor in September after an acrimonious exchange with him there.
Busboys and Capitol Hill police officers thank her for ousting Mr. Dornan. Strangers who would never recognize their own representatives stop her at airports in places like Chicago and Houston. People at the grocery store ask her for autographs. And she is a major draw at conventions and luncheons around the country.
Ms. Sanchez even managed to steal a bit of the limelight at a dinner for President Clinton. "I really just came to meet this Loretta Sanchez," she said people told her.
In the House, where Republicans hold a frail 11-seat majority, Democratic Party power brokers have made a point of rallying around their prize, making it clear that her primary mission is to endure, and, above all, get re-elected. The President has offered her a ride on Air Force One. She was seated next to Vice President Al Gore at a meeting with the Hispanic Caucus. And Democratic Leader Richard A. Gephardt and Representative Barbara B. Kennelly of Connecticut, among others, are jumping in to help with fund-raising.
Just last week, several members, sporting orange ribbons in solidarity, delayed work on the House floor to protest the committee's investigation.
For Ms. Sanchez, however, this sudden jump from businesswoman to political symbol is a mixed blessing. Nobody much cares about her ideas on immigration, small businesses or education, despite her repeated attempts to focus on those issues. It is her battle with Mr. Dornan that captivates them.
The daughter of Mexican immigrants, Ms. Sanchez never held elective office before last November. She ran for a seat on the five-member Anaheim, Calif., City Council once and came in 8th out of 16 candidates. Her background was pure business, a degree in economics, a master's in business administration, a job as a financial analyst.
During much of the campaign, Mr. Dornan painted her as anti-Catholic because of her stand in favor of a woman's right to choose an abortion, a "pretend Hispanic" and a carpetbagger. But, she said, the charges didn't stick. Too many people knew her, knew her history, knew her parents and her six brothers and sisters.
In a county undergoing seismic demographic shifts, Ms. Sanchez seemed the perfect antidote to the divisiveness threatening Asians, those of Spanish heritage and whites, her colleagues say.
She grew up straddling two worlds, speaking Spanish at home, English everywhere else. She married a man with not a drop of Latino blood in him. Her mother, who attended school through the third grade, cooked tortillas and tamales for her children at dinner and also volunteered as a Brownie troop leader and bake sale organizer.
Every week her father, who worked at a rubber and plastics factory, chose a chapter from a book in Spanish -- "Don Quixote" was a favorite -- and made every child in the family deliver book reports.
There was little wiggle room with some of the family's cultural traditions. Dating was out, for the most part. And curfews were written in stone; on prom night, it was midnight. Some habits just stuck with her, like sewing, which she learned from her mother. On inauguration night this year, Ms. Sanchez made her own dress, a shimmery gold gown, in four hours.
When her parents first moved to Anaheim, then a neighborhood of few Hispanic residents, one "For Sale" sign after the next popped up on their street. But Ms. Sanchez said if she was ever discriminated against, she did not notice.
Ultimately, she was drawn to Congress out of disappointment with Republican views on immigration and women's issues. And her neighborhood seemed headed toward decay.
Xavier Becerra, the chairman of the Hispanic Caucus and a California Democrat, encouraged her to run. "Her tenacity, that's what I liked about her," he said. "The fact that she's still standing and has not lost her way, or her sense of humor, shows she is a strong woman."
Being the new kid on the block is difficult enough in Washington, Mr. Becerra said. Throw in a commute to California, where her husband still lives, constant requests for interviews, meetings with lawyers and, above all, Mr. Dornan's shadow, "then you have something that's a tremendous load," Mr. Becerra added.
So far, the committee's investigation has cost Ms. Sanchez about $300,000, for legal fees, at a rate that increases by $10,000 a week. What little time she has left after her Congressional duties is spent raising money. That means lots of late nights and weekends on the phone.
"I usually am always working," she said. The last movie she saw in a theater, "The English Patient," opened last year.
"My family has suffered the most," she said. "I mean, I'm Hispanic. I live 10 minutes away from my mom. I was used to having a cup of coffee with her in the morning or after work. And if I don't show up for a couple of days, there is a message on my machine saying, 'Are you still alive?"'
Democrats see the committee investigation as an orchestrated effort by Republicans to sap Ms. Sanchez's campaign fund and her energy.
"It's a diversion," Ms. Kennelly said.
Already, Republicans sense vulnerability. Ralph Reed, the Christian Coalition wunderkind turned political consultant, has accepted a Republican Councilman from Anaheim as a client in the next race for the Congressional seat and calls winning back the district "do or die."
Her critics say that Ms. Sanchez's voting record, which seldom strays from the Democratic Party line, will contribute to her undoing in a district that is still strongly conservative. And her inexperience sometimes shows. She has committed a few public gaffes, pretending, for example, to be a staff member when she picked up the telephone in her office late one evening in front of a Los Angeles Times reporter or scolding Mr. Gephardt on C-Span for not returning her calls.
Mr. Reed calls her an "accidental Congresswoman," who won because Mr. Dornan was too busy running for President to focus on his Congressional seat.
But Ms. Kennelly, the veteran lawmaker who will run for governor of Connecticut next year and who took Ms. Sanchez in as a roomate for five months, disagreed.
"You don't get to Congress as a woman unless you are successful in other areas," she said.
Ms. Sanchez copes by trying to blot out distractions. Or by exercising. In good weather, she jogs three miles along the Mall in the morning. If not, she puffs away in the House gym, sometimes next to Speaker Newt Gingrich and Tom DeLay, the Republican whip in the House. She does not care that she is the only woman who uses the gym. She has been busy making a strong suit of armor for herself.
"I know the truth," she said. "The truth is, I went against a system that was stacked against me. I worked very hard to change the system, and it worked."

HEADLINE: Why Are American Workers Losing Ground?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
You are right to oppose President Clinton's cheerful interpretation of the latest Census data about the rise in median income by stating that "even a healthy economy leaves the poor firmly in a depressing place" (editorial, Oct. 2). You are also to be commended for publishing William Greider's Oct. 1 Op-Ed article, in which he asks, Who is going to buy the excess output produced by the global economy, whose workings "erode the worldwide consumption base"? 
 But your editorial regrettably accepts the popular rationalization of mainstream economics that "sluggish productivity gains produce sluggish income gains." How so, given all the downsizing and computerizing in progress for so many years?
Much more plausible is the explanation to be derived from Henry Ford's wisdom -- if you want to have paying customers, make sure that they are adequately paid as producers.
 
MARK PRICEMAN
Larchmont, N.Y., Oct. 2, 1997

HEADLINE: Why Are American Workers Losing Ground?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
It is misleading to suggest that stagnant median incomes can be entirely explained by sluggish gains in productivity (editorial, Oct. 2). You do not mention that this slow growth has been accompanied by the highest corporate profits on record. 
 This apparent paradox was explained by Stephen S. Roach, chief economist for Morgan Stanley, who pointed out that the present economic recovery is a "labor-crunch recovery" -- one that flourishes only because corporate America has dramatically reduced its cost by putting "unrelenting pressure on its work force" (Op-Ed, Aug. 24).
Both high corporate profits and stagnant median incomes can mostly be attributed to the same cause: out of the stream of income (productivity) that the economy has been generating during this recovery, a larger flow than usual has been diverted from the nation's workers to its major stockholders.
 
KEVIN RISTAU
St. Paul, Oct. 2, 1997
 
The writer is education director of the Jobs Now Coalition.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 14; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 242 words

HEADLINE: Why Are American Workers Losing Ground?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"The Tide Is Not Lifting Everyone" (editorial, Oct. 2) correctly pinpoints the fact that the current recovery has yet to produce a prosperity that includes working-class and poor families. However, you argue that the reason the 1990's recovery has not produced income gains commensurate with the 30 percent rise in the 1950's is that productivity today is rising at a tepid 1 percent clip. 
 This argument would lead one to conclude that worker income should be rising at that same modest rate. In fact, it is only in the last year that wages have begun to creep up. Moreover, overall productivity growth is up for each year of the recovery. Following your argument, this improvement should by now have produced median family incomes higher than the 1989 peak. But, as the recent Census Bureau data show, median family income is still 2.7 percent below the 1989 level.
The causes of the disjuncture between family income and economic growth are many. But one major cause is the decline in worker bargaining power -- unionization -- at the same time that employer power has strengthened in the wake of technological change and globalization.
Until workers are able to enhance their bargaining power, we will see a long-term erosion in real median family income, even in the face of productivity growth.
 
GREG TARPINIAN
New York, Oct. 3, 1997
 
The writer is executive director of the Labor Research Association.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
Smiling on Smaller Stocks

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
CALL it the revenge of the small stocks. In the third quarter these stocks not only outperformed their larger brethren -- a rare event in itself recently -- but by a margin not seen since the fourth quarter of 1992.
The small stocks began their ascent in the spring, and in the most recent quarter they nearly doubled the return of the Standard & Poor's 500 index of large stocks. In recognition, four of the five professional money managers who created hypothetical retirement portfolios for The New York Times are adding funds that own smaller stocks. 
 "Over the last few years, large-cap funds have done extremely well, and we want to take advantage of the fact that small- and mid-cap funds haven't participated in this rally," said Eric M. Kobren, president of Insight Management and editor of Fidelity Insight, an independent newsletter in Wellesley, Mass.
"We've started to see that market percolate over the past few months, and we think there's a lot more room to grow," he said. His portfolio of Fidelity funds rose 11.65 percent, to place first in the quarter.
Because he has become concerned about his exposure to large stocks through Fidelity Dividend Growth, Mr. Kobren is selling that position and buying shares in Fidelity Mid-Cap Stock, whose portfolio has a weighted median market capitalization of about $3 billion. And while the fund's manager, Katherine Collins, likes growth stocks, Mr. Kobren said, "we like the fact that she is not a momentum-type investor who will invest in emerging growth-type companies selling at infinite multiples."
He also sold Europe Capital Appreciation and bought Fidelity International Value. The move "gives us a little more diversification, as Europe has seen interest rates rise and their currencies, after bottoming out, appear to be rising again." International Value will also provide exposure to Japan, where Mr. Kobren said he expects growth to pick up.
THE domestic market has reached a turning point, agreed Jack A. Brill, a San Diego investment adviser who builds portfolios of "socially responsible" funds. "I think that, at this point, large-cap stocks have leveled out and the smaller stocks will be back in favor," said Mr. Brill, whose portfolio rose 9.28 percent, placing third.
As a result, he is reducing his position in Domini Social Equity to 20 percent of his portfolio, from 25 percent. The fund aims to mimic the sector distribution of the S.& P. 500 but to do that and still own only stocks that meet social criteria, it picks from both the S.& P. 500 and the 500 next-largest stocks. He is also shrinking his position in MMA Praxis Growth, a large-cap value fund, to 10 percent from 15 percent.
He is using the proceeds from those sales to buy Ariel Appreciation, a socially responsible fund that buys small- and mid-cap stocks. It "holds no technology stocks, has a low turnover rate and caters to the patient investor," he said.
Sheldon Jacobs, who edits the No-Load Fund Investor in Irvington, N.Y., retains the overall lead among the five managers with a gain of 116.21 percent since the contest began more than four years ago, on July 7, 1993. The five portfolios have risen an average of 94.84 percent, compared with 136.01 percent for the Vanguard Index 500 fund, which mimics the S.& P. 500.
The performance of the hypothetical portfolios, tracked each quarter by Lipper Analytical Services, excludes sales charges, transaction costs and tax considerations because most retirement money is held in tax-deferred accounts. The managers can choose any fund open to new investors and can shift money quarterly, but the portfolios were intended to grow for 20 years.
All five portfolios made money in the third quarter. Still, none beat the 11.82 percent average for diversified domestic stock funds as calculated by Lipper.
The portfolio constructed by John Rekenthaler, formerly of Morningstar Inc., the Chicago fund research firm, was taken over by Susan Dziubinski, editor of Morningstar Investor. (Mr. Rekenthaler has joined John Nuveen & Company.) Ms. Dziubinski said the portfolio, which rose 9.53 percent in the quarter to earn second place, was quite conservative, and she began making changes to lift its potential return.
She replaced Templeton Global Smaller Companies with Small Cap World, saying she thought its managers were better domestic stock-pickers.
She also sold Fidelity Trend because its manager, Arieh Coll, "is definitely a rising star at Fidelity, and I can see the company moving him onto a bigger fund at some point." She replaced it with the Yacktman Fund. "Don Yacktman's growth-at-a-reasonable-price approach works over the long haul," she said. "And while his concentrated style can be risky -- the most recent portfolio holds just 36 names -- I have a long time horizon."
Finally, Ms. Dziubinski added Colonial Newport Tiger, noting that its focus, the Pacific region, has been one of the worst-performing market segments over the last few years. "I want to be there for the rebound, and Colonial Newport Tiger is the Cadillac" of Pacific funds that exclude Japan, she said.
Mr. Jacobs, who placed fourth this quarter with a gain of 9.27 percent, is adding Hotchkis & Wiley Small Cap to increase exposure to small stocks. He likes its size, just $41 million in assets, and its value orientation.
Mr. Jacobs eliminated Vanguard Emerging Markets Index. Given the recent jolts to the emerging markets, he said, some countries may take considerable time to recover. As a result, he said, "I now prefer an actively managed fund, which can dramatically change its country weightings." His pick is Montgomery Emerging Markets because of its performance and the fact that it is diversified among up to 32 countries. The Vanguard fund owns stocks in just 14 countries, he said.
Harold Evensky, an investment adviser in Coral Gables, Fla., placed last in the quarter with a gain of 4.42 percent. But he plans no changes other than rebalancing his portfolio back to its percentage allocations at the start of the last quarter.
"Once again, overall performance has been dragged down by our international allocation," Mr. Evensky said. "The safety provided by diversification is not a free lunch. The benefit is never having all of your investments in the wrong place at the wrong time. Diversification may not make you rich, but it will not make you poor."

The fund's 9.3 percent change was a drop, not a rise.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE -- In 2 Corners of City, a Surge in Hispanic Power;
Brooklyn Area May Put Puerto Rican on Council

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
Watching Angel Rodriguez enter the Sunset Park Senior Citizen Center is something like witnessing the second coming of Elvis. Men shout and offer handshakes; women swoon and demand besos, or kisses. Mr. Rodriguez, 40, circulates, giving hugs, besos and advice, even joking about his bulging belly with a group of women.
This, said Mr. Rodriguez, the Democratic nominee for the 38th Council District, is his base: the elderly who know struggle and know him, a "regular guy trying to help the community." 
 Mr. Rodriguez's larger base is Sunset Park, the heart of the district and his home for 20 years. If, as expected, he wins in November, he will be the district's first Councilman from Sunset Park and the first Hispanic to represent a district whose contours were drawn for just that purpose.
The 38th begins at the south end of largely working-class Sunset Park, cuts a fat swath north to take in the middle-class blocks of Windsor Terrace and a slice of Park Slope, moves into Red Hook with its dense public housing, turns sharply right, narrowing, then broadens to take in Boerum Hill's brownstones and the Gowanus and Wyckoff housing projects.
Its contorted shape was sketched in 1991, part of a redistricting plan intended to give minorities greater political representation. In the 38th, the goal was to give Hispanic voters a greater chance to win the seat, although the district has significant white, black and Chinese populations. But Joan Griffin McCabe won in 1991 and in 1993. She did not run again this year.
Mr. Rodriguez, a self-employed management consultant and accountant, was encouraged to run by Felix W. Ortiz, the State Assemblyman from the 51st District. Mr. Rodriguez campaigned door to door and won 2,204 of the 6,708 votes cast, avoiding a runoff in the five-way primary.
Mr. Ortiz said he admired Mr. Rodriguez: the son of a Puerto Rican mother who herself moved from welfare to sweatshops to factories, he put himself through school and started his own business. He became heavily involved in the community, from coaching youth sports teams to establishing a nonprofit group to offer computer training in Sunset Park.
But Mr. Rodriguez's only political experience has been as a Democratic district leader, and some critics question a political novice's ability to maneuver successfully within the Council's sophisticated land-use and budget processes. Mr. Rodriguez said his priorities included bringing a high school to Sunset Park, increasing housing for the elderly and pushing a plan to replace the Gowanus Expressway with a tunnel.
Critics say the creation of the 38th points up the flaws in redistricting: it did not guarantee a Hispanic election, but did string together geographically distant and culturally and economically disparate neighborhoods.
But the president of the Institute for Puerto Rican Policy, Angelo Falcon, pointed to the tripling of Hispanic Council members since 1990, and said redistricting had provided political parity. It had not, he noted, proved a panacea.
"The question now," Mr. Falcon said, "is how do we hold these representatives accountable, make them more effective voices?"
The district will likely be redrawn in 2001 because the United States Supreme Court has ruled that districts cannot be shaped to enhance a racial or an ethnic group's political prospects.
"I don't think we'll see districts that look like that," said Esmeralda Simmons, head of the Center for Law and Social Justice at Medgar Evers College, who helped create the 38th. AMY WALDMAN

CORRECTION-DATE: October 12, 1997, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday about the number of Hispanic elected officials in New York City misstated the number of State Senators from the city who are Hispanic. There are four, not two.

HEADLINE: Stalking Africa's Newest Game: Hostile Celebrities

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

DATELINE: CAPE TOWN

 BODY:
Although he hates the title, Fanie Jason is known as South Africa's only paparazzo.
Other than President Nelson Mandela and Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu, this country does not have many faces that are recognized overseas, so he does not get rich at his job. Last year, one minor celebrity he relentlessly tailed for a British tabloid sued and nearly bankrupted him. Since then, that man has become famous as a symbol of fury at paparazzi: Earl Spencer, the brother of Diana, Princess of Wales. 
 The case of Spencer v. Jason, which drew in a press freedom institute and a top constitutional lawyer, pitted two figures who inspire both admiration and disdain in others.
Mr. Jason is a quick-thinking photographer who has fought his way up, out of the poverty and despair of a black township. He stalks his targets relentlessly and admits that he has lied or played on white guilt to trick people into posing. Since Diana was killed in a car crash in Paris while fleeing photographers, he has received death threats, he said.
Earl Spencer is widely admired for the eulogy he gave at his sister's funeral and for saying paparazzi and newspaper editors had "her blood on their hands." But he was briefly a journalist himself, and speaks to gossip writers when it suits him.
Celebrity-poor South Africa became a battleground for him because he moved his family here two years ago, ostensibly to get away from the attention he was getting in Britain as Diana's brother. He was one of a handful of well-known Europeans and Americans who have vacationed or moved here since apartheid sanctions were lifted.
That influx is Mr. Jason's bread and butter, and he is not embarrassed about what he does. "I have a Toyota now, and a computer," he said. "Thanks to paparazzi."
Mr. Jason grew up in Guguletu, a black township just outside Cape Town, the eldest of six children of a mother who worked as a maid and a blind father who was unemployed.
For decades, Mr. Jason scraped by as a freelancer. He bought stolen cameras because they were cheap. He shot pin-ups for Drum, a black magazine, while working as a driver for a cosmetics company.
But he considers himself a newsman. In the 1980's, he photographed anti-apartheid protests, and was once jailed with Archbishop Tutu. Last year, covering a march against crime, he was hit by 38 pieces of bird shot, he said. In 1994, when the former black homeland Bophutatswana exploded, he traveled 20 hours by minibus taxi to get there because he could not afford a plane ticket. He says he has paid his own way to photograph the genocide in Rwanda and unrest in Hebron.
But before the London tabloids began phoning him, he often earned a pittance. He said, for example, that he had taken a picture of Archbishop Tutu opening his swimming pool to poor children and that a local paper would pay him only $3 for it.
But for other pictures, British papers have paid him as much as 6,000 pounds -- $9,000 -- for a shot. "Six thousand pounds?" he said. "That's abracadabra where I come from."
His first tabloid commission was to get a picture of the girlfriend of Mark Thatcher, son of the former Prime Minister of Britain, Margaret Thatcher. Mr. Thatcher moved to Cape Town in 1995. Mr. Jason went to the woman's house dressed in overalls and, in broken English, asked for a job as a gardener.
"While I was talking to her, my cell phone went off in my pocket," he said. "She said: 'You want gardening work, and you have a cell phone? I guess this is the new South Africa.' " He told her it was a child's toy and retreated. He then followed her for a week and hid in a flower bed to shoot pictures as she picked up her children at school.
He tricked Eva Herzigova, the Wonderbra model, into posing by telling her he was a fan and asking for a picture together. He sneaked up on Michael Jackson while he was dining in Sun City. When the former husband of Camilla Parker-Bowles, Prince Charles's girlfriend, honeymooned here with his new wife, Mr. Jason phoned them from the lobby. They said they wanted nothing to do with The Daily Mail, so Mr. Jason quickly changed his story and said The Mail was a local black paper. "They came down and posed," he said, and the pictures were on the front pages in London the next day.
When Earl Spencer started building a house in the Constantia suburb of Cape Town, a British tabloid asked for a picture. Mr. Jason disguised himself as a workman, hiding his camera in a lunch box. "I was stacking some bricks, and he walked by," he said. "I said, 'Hi, boss,' and he nodded, and I took a couple of snaps a few seconds later."
He also photographed the Earl's estranged wife and children, who were living in a different house. Then, he got a big break -- a maid he knew said her employer had a bed and breakfast where the Earl was meeting a girlfriend. He paid her to get the license plates of their cars, and promised her $420 if he got a picture of them together. Then he went to the girlfriend's house and befriended the gardener, hoping to confirm the story.
He said The Mail, fearful of being sued, did not run his article for months, until the woman's devastated husband had sold his own story to another British paper.
Meanwhile, the Earl had sued him, asking for a court order preventing any photographs of him or his family without his permission. That prompted the Freedom of Expression Institute, which defends press freedom here, to step in to underwrite Mr. Jason's defense.
The first judge granted a temporary restraining order preventing him from photographing the Earl.
"That really concerned us," said Alexandra Kuhn, coordinator of the institute's legal defense fund. "A public figure should be photographable when out in public."
The judge who heard the motion for a permanent order -- during which Mr. Jason was defended without charge by Wim Trengrove, a prominent constitutional lawyer -- insisted that the two sides settle, Miss Kuhn said.
Mr. Jason agreed to stop photographing the Earl's wife and children, to photograph him only in public places and to stay 10 yards away from him and 50 yards from his house. But, before the settlement was reached, he took another photograph of the Earl and was fined about $4,800 for contempt of court.
While he was in Israel, Mr. Jason said, his furniture and computer were seized to cover the debt.
Earl Spencer's lawyer declined to discuss the case. A message left with her asking the Earl to call was not returned.
Even Mr. Jason's backers say he is ruthless about his job and, in so many words, he admits it. "It puts bread on the table," he said.
Some of the paparazzi in Paris have been accused of taking pictures of Diana as she lay dying. Asked if he would do the same, Mr. Jason said: "Sure. I've taken hundreds of pictures of dead bodies. I'd commit professional suicide if I walked away from that. But I do feel sorry for her. She was a nice person."

HEADLINE: A Spanish Princess's Wedding Is Rich in Regional Symbolism

BYLINE: By The New York Times By The New York Times

DATELINE: BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 4

 BODY:
Princess Cristina, the third in line to the Spanish throne, married a Basque commoner who is a professional athlete today in a ceremony that paid tribute to Spain's diverse regions.
The Roman Catholic service in the 13th-century cathedral was principally in Spanish, but also used Catalan, the regional language spoken in Barcelona, where the bride lives, and the Basque language, the groom's native tongue. Crowds lining the 10-mile procession route waved little blue flags that read "Best Wishes" in the three languages. 
 Princess Cristina Federica de Borbon y Grecia, 32, is the first member of the Spanish royal family ever to hold a salaried job; she prepares photographic exhibitions for a savings bank foundation. The groom, Inaki Urdangarin, 29, is a professional handball team player. They met last year at the Atlanta Summer Olympics.
The wedding of the middle child of King Juan Carlos I and Queen Sofia was in step with the royal family's efforts to strengthen links to all the country's regions. It is a style that has helped make the royal family enormously popular since the monarchy was restored in 1975 after the death of the right-wing dictator, Gen. Francisco Franco.
But the televised storybook images from the Catalonian capital of the smiling princess in a long white gown -- scenes made available without charge by state-run television to stations around the world -- did not show a growing undercurrent of political tension between Spain's regions and Madrid.
The wedding served as a weekend pause in the battle of words.
The minority conservative Government of Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar controls Parliament thanks to support from the Barcelona-based Catalonian nationalist coalition, which in return has extracted concessions for greater control over the regional budget.
The Catalonian political leader, Jordi Pujol, was seated one row behind the Prime Minister in the cathedral today. Mr. Pujol has been staying at arm's length from the Government, partly because of incidents like the one at a recent benefit concert in Madrid that was supported by the central Government in which a performer was loudly heckled for singing in a dialect of Catalan.
But Mr. Aznar's relations are even worse with the Basque Nationalist Party, which withdrew its support for him last month after failing to win control over regional unemployment policy. The party leader declined an invitation to the wedding.
The Catalonian and Basque regions have been the traditional economic powerhouses of Spain, attracting job-seekers from poorer Spanish regions. They are also the two regions that have voiced support loudest for independence. The Basque region has an active separatist group that for years has used bomb attacks and kidnappings to fight Madrid.
The history of the regions made the match of the Spanish Princess, who has lived in Barcelona for five years, and the tall Basque athlete all the more engrossing for ordinary Spaniards.
"Just because we have our own language and culture doesn't mean that we reject Spain," said Alicia Ruiz, 22, a waitress at a hotel near the cathedral. "It's a shame how they think of us."
The King's oldest daughter, Princess Elena, also married a commoner, in Seville in 1995. That leaves only Crown Prince Felipe, 29, unmarried. And he has not expressed any wish to hurry to follow his sisters.

HEADLINE: Freshman Democrat Is Dogged by Relentless Foe

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ By LIZETTE ALVAREZ

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4

 BODY:
The champagne bubbled, balloons kissed the ceiling and Loretta Sanchez stood center stage two weeks after the election, savoring the clatter of voices at her official victory party, thinking to herself it was all finally over.
She had defeated Representative Robert K. Dornan, the brash Orange County, Calif., conservative, by 984 votes, and she had done it in her first-ever run for Congress. It was the biggest upset of the election season; an upstart Hispanic Democrat had managed to upstage Mr. Dornan, an Irish Catholic Republican stalwart, in his own Republican stronghold. 
 But nearly 11 months later, Ms. Sanchez is still trying to beat back Mr. Dornan and jam him into a dark closet somewhere, preferably one that is soundproof. Hardly a day goes by, she said, that she is not shadowed by the former eight-term Congressman, a man best known for bombast.
Twice when she has gone to vote on the House floor, there he was, glad-handing his onetime colleagues across the way. Often when she reads a newspaper, there he is, on the front page, calling her a lapsed Catholic. A scan of the radio dial turns up Mr. Dornan again, on the Oliver North show. Even in the sanctity of her office, Mr. Dornan is there, in the guise of his son's voice, booming messages into her answering machine, a charge Mr. Dornan denies.
"I thought I had seen the last of Bob Dornan," she said. "I won the election. Let's get on with it. But people won't let me get on with it."
Mr. Dornan has contested the election, charging that it was stolen from him by bad ballots cast by people who were not United States citizens, or in some cases, not legal United States residents. The Committee on House Oversight has been investigating the claim for nearly 10 months, digging through Immigration and Naturalization Service work sheets and Orange County voter rolls.
The inquiry has led to flashes of revolt among Democrats, who call it an inquisition aimed more at frightening away Hispanic voters than uncovering fraud. Republican leaders counter that evidence is mounting in Mr. Dornan's quest to unseat Ms. Sanchez. There seems little question that some bad votes were cast. The issue remains: how many? Democrats contend the number falls far short of 984.
"It puts the Republicans in a difficult position," said John Pitney, a former deputy director of the Republican National Committee and now a professor of government at Claremont McKenna College in California. "On the one hand, they don't want a seat taken away from them by fraud. But between Dornan's personality and Democratic accusations of sharp anti-Latino bias, there is a downside to it."
There is a sense of unease, a feeling of perpetual preoccupation, about the whole affair for Ms. Sanchez, and it is clearly felt inside her Capitol Hill office. A few framed photographs sit on tabletops, and assorted inspirational messages hang on the walls. But the oversize bookcase sits forlorn, close to empty.
There is one stand-out decorating touch. A couple of model B-2 bombers sit near her door, as if to defy her opponent, the man some called "B-1" Bob for his support of the earlier B-1 bomber.
In beating Mr. Dornan, Ms. Sanchez became more than an ordinary freshman lawmaker. The 37-year-old businesswoman became a political celebrity, an icon for Democrats and underdogs alike. "She has become a symbol," said Representative Robert Menendez, the New Jersey Democrat who spearheaded the successful vote to banish Mr. Dornan from the House floor in September after an acrimonious exchange with him there.
Busboys and Capitol Hill police officers thank her for ousting Mr. Dornan. Strangers who would never recognize their own representatives stop her at airports in places like Chicago and Houston. People at the grocery store ask her for autographs. And she is a major draw at conventions and luncheons around the country.
Ms. Sanchez even managed to steal a bit of the limelight at a dinner for President Clinton. "I really just came to meet this Loretta Sanchez," she said people told her.
In the House, where Republicans hold a frail 11-seat majority, Democratic Party power brokers have made a point of rallying around their prize, making it clear that her primary mission is to endure, and, above all, get re-elected. The President has offered her a ride on Air Force One. She was seated next to Vice President Al Gore at a meeting with the Hispanic Caucus. And Democratic Leader Richard A. Gephardt and Representative Barbara B. Kennelly of Connecticut, among others, are jumping in to help with fund-raising.
Just last week, several members, sporting orange ribbons in solidarity, delayed work on the House floor to protest the committee's investigation.
For Ms. Sanchez, however, this sudden jump from businesswoman to political symbol is a mixed blessing. Nobody much cares about her ideas on immigration, small businesses or education, despite her repeated attempts to focus on those issues. It is her battle with Mr. Dornan that captivates them.
The daughter of Mexican immigrants, Ms. Sanchez never held elective office before last November. She ran for a seat on the five-member Anaheim, Calif., City Council once and came in 8th out of 16 candidates. Her background was pure business, a degree in economics, a master's in business administration, a job as a financial analyst.
During much of the campaign, Mr. Dornan painted her as anti-Catholic because of her stand in favor of a woman's right to choose an abortion, a "pretend Hispanic" and a carpetbagger. But, she said, the charges didn't stick. Too many people knew her, knew her history, knew her parents and her six brothers and sisters.
In a county undergoing seismic demographic shifts, Ms. Sanchez seemed the perfect antidote to the divisiveness threatening Asians, those of Spanish heritage and whites, her colleagues say.
She grew up straddling two worlds, speaking Spanish at home, English everywhere else. She married a man with not a drop of Latino blood in him. Her mother, who attended school through the third grade, cooked tortillas and tamales for her children at dinner and also volunteered as a Brownie troop leader and bake sale organizer.
Every week her father, who worked at a rubber and plastics factory, chose a chapter from a book in Spanish -- "Don Quixote" was a favorite -- and made every child in the family deliver book reports.
There was little wiggle room with some of the family's cultural traditions. Dating was out, for the most part. And curfews were written in stone; on prom night, it was midnight. Some habits just stuck with her, like sewing, which she learned from her mother. On inauguration night this year, Ms. Sanchez made her own dress, a shimmery gold gown, in four hours.
When her parents first moved to Anaheim, then a neighborhood of few Hispanic residents, one "For Sale" sign after the next popped up on their street. But Ms. Sanchez said if she was ever discriminated against, she did not notice.
Ultimately, she was drawn to Congress out of disappointment with Republican views on immigration and women's issues. And her neighborhood seemed headed toward decay.
Xavier Becerra, the chairman of the Hispanic Caucus and a California Democrat, encouraged her to run. "Her tenacity, that's what I liked about her," he said. "The fact that she's still standing and has not lost her way, or her sense of humor, shows she is a strong woman."
Being the new kid on the block is difficult enough in Washington, Mr. Becerra said. Throw in a commute to California, where her husband still lives, constant requests for interviews, meetings with lawyers and, above all, Mr. Dornan's shadow, "then you have something that's a tremendous load," Mr. Becerra added.
So far, the committee's investigation has cost Ms. Sanchez about $300,000, for legal fees, at a rate that increases by $10,000 a week. What little time she has left after her Congressional duties is spent raising money. That means lots of late nights and weekends on the phone.
"I usually am always working," she said. The last movie she saw in a theater, "The English Patient," opened last year.
"My family has suffered the most," she said. "I mean, I'm Hispanic. I live 10 minutes away from my mom. I was used to having a cup of coffee with her in the morning or after work. And if I don't show up for a couple of days, there is a message on my machine saying, 'Are you still alive?"'
Democrats see the committee investigation as an orchestrated effort by Republicans to sap Ms. Sanchez's campaign fund and her energy.
"It's a diversion," Ms. Kennelly said.
Already, Republicans sense vulnerability. Ralph Reed, the Christian Coalition wunderkind turned political consultant, has accepted a Republican Councilman from Anaheim as a client in the next race for the Congressional seat and calls winning back the district "do or die."
Her critics say that Ms. Sanchez's voting record, which seldom strays from the Democratic Party line, will contribute to her undoing in a district that is still strongly conservative. And her inexperience sometimes shows. She has committed a few public gaffes, pretending, for example, to be a staff member when she picked up the telephone in her office late one evening in front of a Los Angeles Times reporter or scolding Mr. Gephardt on C-Span for not returning her calls.
Mr. Reed calls her an "accidental Congresswoman," who won because Mr. Dornan was too busy running for President to focus on his Congressional seat.
But Ms. Kennelly, the veteran lawmaker who will run for governor of Connecticut next year and who took Ms. Sanchez in as a roomate for five months, disagreed.
"You don't get to Congress as a woman unless you are successful in other areas," she said.
Ms. Sanchez copes by trying to blot out distractions. Or by exercising. In good weather, she jogs three miles along the Mall in the morning. If not, she puffs away in the House gym, sometimes next to Speaker Newt Gingrich and Tom DeLay, the Republican whip in the House. She does not care that she is the only woman who uses the gym. She has been busy making a strong suit of armor for herself.
"I know the truth," she said. "The truth is, I went against a system that was stacked against me. I worked very hard to change the system, and it worked."

HEADLINE: Deterring Immigration

 BODY:

To the Editor:
A Sept. 29 editorial suggests that the solution to illegal immigration is to deter entry at the border. There is a misconception that illegal immigrants typically sneak into the United States from Canada or Mexico. In fact, a larger number of them enter the country legally as visitors or students, but they become illegal by remaining beyond their authorized staying period. Strengthening border security will only go so far. 
 A better solution would be to increase penalties for employers who hire illegal immigrants. If employers feared a heavy prison sentence, a substantial fine and the threat of losing their businesses as punishment for hiring illegal immigrants, this would more than neutralize the economic benefits of cheap labor.
As immigrants found it increasingly difficult to get work, there would be less incentive to come here illegally.
 
CONSTANTINOS E. SCAROS
Cliffside Park, N.J., Sept. 29, 1997
 
The writer is an immigration lawyer.

HEADLINE: At the U.N., a New Voice Stresses Balance in Approaching Human Rights

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 3

 BODY:
The Government leaders who flock to the United Nations every autumn to make speeches, drink toasts and dabble in back-room diplomacy found something new on their appointment calendars this year: human rights and Mary Robinson.
Mrs. Robinson, who resigned a largely ceremonial post as President of Ireland last month, has been the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights for barely three weeks, but she has already been busy: soothing China, upsetting Algeria, reacting calmly to Afghanistan and warning the Democratic Republic of Congo, the former Zaire. 
 "She is at ease with difficult issues and confident in dealing with them," said Stephanie Grant, program director at the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights.
Mrs. Robinson, 53, a human rights lawyer, has become the world's official conscience at a time when human and civil rights issues have moved nearer to the center of debates on international security or global trade.
"It is only a moral voice if you have real credibility," she said in an interview. Credibility, she said, grows from impartiality, not neutrality. "I need to be seen to be fair and impartial," she said.
Toward that end, she has tried to stress a sense of balance: weighing a country's social and economic gains as well as its progress in civil and political rights. That approach played into her discussions here with China's Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, one of many officials she met in recent weeks.
"By this measure, more credit would be given to a very large country like China with its huge progress in the right to education, food, shelter," she said. "It is phenomenal what they have achieved. And they feel, I think, more than irritation. They feel a sense of lack of respect, a lack of recognition."
This emphasis on economic and social rights as well as "cultural and spiritual values" may eventually create friction with American human rights groups and officials who want to focus primarily on political and civil freedoms. But such concerns have been muted so far, and her appointment drew wide praise in the United States.
But last week, she already came under attack from Algeria for what it called an infringement of sovereignty after she said the country's violent confrontation with Islamic militants had become a matter of international concern.
There were also those in the poorer countries who opposed naming a European to the post. Mrs. Robinson said she deals with such opposition by talking with developing nations about "my Irishness."
The history of her country, she tells audiences, was one of imperial exploitation, violence, famine and poverty, and thus it has much in common with many countries today. To Asian leaders, she promises open debate about Western and Eastern values.
Discussing the Taliban, the militant Islamic movement that has taken control of most of Afghanistan, Mrs. Robinson does not align herself with those demanding reduced United Nations assistance because of the Taliban's harsh treatment of women.
"I intend to try to get more informed Islamic legal thinking than I've had so far," she said. "I think the problem, particularly in Afghanistan, is that this is not a village culture growing up from the communities. Village cultures are in fact very accommodating of different viewpoints. This is young men being prepared to fight a fight, and part of that is their militant sense of the Islamic law.
"We're not going to make real progress for women in Afghanistan unless we can do it within their culture," she said.
The office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, based in Geneva, was created in 1993. The first High Commissioner, Jose Ayala-Lasso, an Ecuadoran diplomat, began work in 1994.
Mr. Ayala-Lasso, who resigned this year to become Foreign Minister of Ecuador, took office under a cloud of criticism from human rights groups wary of his association with a former military government. He also faced the task of consolidating a messy collection of human rights offices at the United Nations. By the time he left, Mr. Ayala-Lasso was credited with giving the office some substance and order.
Mrs. Robinson said that she now has an opportunity to build on those achievements. She expects to name a deputy in the coming months to further strengthen her small team working in Geneva and New York on a very limited budget. Diplomats expect her to chose someone from Asia, Africa or Latin America.
Human rights groups are hopeful that under Mrs. Robinson the High Commissioner's office will have real authority.
She wants to create a human rights network within the United Nations and to support local rights groups operating in countries like Cambodia, where an expensive United Nations effort to build democracy is threatened, or in Congo, where the Government of Laurent Kabila has resisted United Nations investigations of reported massacre sites.
"As High Commissioner I will probably have uncomfortable meetings over the coming years with every Government," she said, adding that she would have to take international politics into account without becoming entangled in it.
