HEADLINE: Supreme Court to Consider Major Case Concerning Race in the Workplace

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
The new Supreme Court term opening Monday brings the Justices their most important affirmative action case in years, an employment dispute that could rewrite the ground rules for taking race into account in both public and private workplaces.
This case, an appeal by a New Jersey school district that dismissed a white teacher to preserve a black teacher's job, is one of 59 cases the Court has agreed so far to review. The Justices added 10 of those cases to the list just last week and will continue accepting new cases through January. For that reason, the new term, which runs until late June or early July, is not yet fully in view. 
 It would be hard for this or any term to match the fireworks of the Court's last session, during which the Justices struck down three major Federal statutes and made a huge amount of law in the course of handing down 80 decisions.
But if there are few potential landmarks on the docket so far, the cases present interesting and even unusual issues ranging from sex discrimination in Federal immigration law to the First Amendment implications of excluding minor-party candidates from campaign debates on public television to the dispute between New Jersey and New York over Ellis Island. The Justices announced last Monday that they would hear arguments between the two states over where to draw the boundary of their respective jurisdictions.
Much of the initial discussion about the new term centers on the New Jersey affirmative action case, Piscataway Board of Education v. Taxman, No. 96-679, which will be argued in January. The case gives the Court its first chance in a decade to apply Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the principal Federal law prohibiting employment discrimination, in the context of affirmative action. During that decade, the Court has moved to the right on questions of race and the country is engaged in an unresolved debate on affirmative action.
While Title VII, taken literally, appears to bar all race-conscious decision-making in employment, the Court in the past has interpreted the law more flexibly to permit some voluntary affirmative action beyond what might be strictly necessary to remedy past discrimination.
But in the Piscataway case, a Federal appeals court ruled broadly that any consideration of race is illegal under Title VII unless undertaken as a remedy for actual discrimination. Applying that analysis, the court awarded damages to a white teacher who lost her job when a New Jersey school board, trying to shrink the high school business department by one teacher, invoked its affirmative action plan to preserve the job of a black teacher with equal seniority who was the department's only black member.
The school district's appeal gives the Court the opportunity to rule either narrowly or broadly: narrowly on the validity of the particular layoff decision, which the Court will almost certainly find to have been improper, or broadly on the appeals court's theory of Title VII, which would eliminate most voluntary affirmative action plans.
The possibility that the Court might take that further step is what has elevated the Piscataway case to the term's front rank. The Clinton Administration, which has shifted its position in the case over the years, now urges the Justices to rule narrowly that the white teacher's rights were violated but to avoid a ruling on the "extraordinarily broad issue" on the validity of race-conscious employment decisions in general.
A second Title VII case presents a novel issue: whether the law, which the Court has interpreted broadly to protect against sexual harassment on the job and sexually hostile environments in the workplace, also applies when the offensive behavior involves people of the same sex.
In this case, Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, No. 96-568, a man accused his employer of tolerating a hostile environment on an offshore oil rig where, the man said, he had been harassed and sexually attacked by other male workers. The Federal appeals court in New Orleans dismissed the lawsuit, ruling that Title VII does not apply to same-sex harassment. The Justices agreed to review the case because other courts have disagreed.
A third discrimination case challenges a provision of the Immigration and Naturalization Act that makes it more difficult for a foreign-born illegitimate child of an American parent to acquire United States citizenship if it is the father rather than the mother who is the American.
If the mother is a United States citizen, citizenship for the child is essentially automatic. But a child seeking to establish citizenship through an American father, as in this case, is barred by the law from doing so unless the father had established evidence of paternity and agreed to provide support before the child turned 18.
The case, Miller v. Albright, No. 96-1060, was brought by a Filipino woman, now in her 20's, whose American father obtained a paternity decree in the Texas courts too late to meet the deadline. The State Department denied her citizenship application in a decision that the Federal appeals court here upheld and that the Clinton Administration continues to defend.
The Administration asserts that Congress has the right to insist that children born in this situation have a close tie to the United States as a prerequisite for automatic citizenship. A child's relationship with a mother is likely to be closer than the relationship with an absent father, the Administration says, adding that Congress "is not constitutionally required to ignore real differences in the situation of citizen mothers and fathers."
Of several important business cases on the docket, one is being described by antitrust specialists as the most important case in that field to reach the Court in 20 years. The question in State Oil Company v. Khan, No. 96-871, is whether manufacturers or wholesalers can place ceilings on the prices that retailers can charge for their products without automatically violating Federal antitrust law.
Under a 1968 precedent that prohibited a newspaper from limiting the prices its independent carriers could charge for home delivery, setting retail price ceilings has been regarded as price-fixing, which is automatically illegal under the Sherman Antitrust Act. The Court has made no distinction between the collusive maintenance of high prices among competitors, an illegal practice that is not at issue, and a manufacturer's effort to limit the retail markup its own dealers may take.
The Clinton Administration and several major manufacturers' groups, reflecting recent trends in antitrust analysis, are urging the Court to revisit the question on the ground that limits on retail markups bear little economic resemblance to classic price-fixing, do not suppress competition, and tend to be beneficial to consumers. Retailers' groups and most state attorneys general disagree, however, asserting that the 1968 precedent, Albrecht v. Herald Company, protects small dealers and franchise owners from undue pressure from their suppliers.
Another high-stakes business dispute finds credit unions and banks, which compete in a growing number of consumer financial services, on opposite sides. The question in National Credit Union Administration v. First National Bank and Trust, No. 96-843, is the appropriate definition, under a Depression-era law, of modern credit unions, many of which have expanded far beyond the small employee or community-group structure that marked their beginnings.
Under the law, membership in Federal credit unions is limited to "groups having a common bond." In 1982, the National Credit Union Administration reversed a longstanding policy and permitted credit unions to take in unrelated groups of members as long as each group had its own "common bond."
A group of banks sued to challenge the new interpretation, and the Federal appeals court here found it to be invalid in a ruling that threatens the membership base of thousands of credit unions. Whichever side loses at the Supreme Court is likely to seek help from Congress. As an initial matter, the Court must first decide whether the banks were proper parties to challenge the policy.
An important First Amendment case asks the Court to decide whether government-operated public television stations have the same editorial discretion as other stations, or whether they are essentially public forums in which the normal rules of journalism do not apply.
The question in Arkansas Educational Television Commission v. Forbes, No. 96-779, is whether all legally qualified candidates have a right to participate in a debate sponsored by a public station, as held by a Federal appeals court, or whether the station may make a journalistic judgment to exclude minor party or independent candidates who have little chance of electoral success.

HEADLINE: L. T. Johnson, 91, Plaintiff Who Helped Integrate U. of Kentucky

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Lyman T. Johnson, the plaintiff in a lawsuit that led to the integration of the University of Kentucky in 1949, five years before the Supreme Court paved the way for the desegregation of all public schools in Brown v. Board of Education, died on Friday in Jewish Hospital in Louisville, Ky. He was 91 and lived in Louisville.
Mr. Johnson, a native of Columbia, Tenn., was the grandson of slaves. He held a bachelor's degree from Virginia Union University and a master's degree in history from the University of Michigan, and had been teaching at Central High School in Louisville for 13 years when he applied for the University of Kentucky's 1948 summer session. He said he hoped to do graduate work toward a doctorate in history and political science.
The university's registrar said in March 1948 that its policy, state law and the Kentucky Constitution would not allow Mr. Johnson to be admitted. Mr. Johnson said: "If I am not admitted, I want to know the reason why. I have no apology to make for being a Negro. I stand on my rights as an American citizen."
He sued, and in March 1949, Federal District Judge H. Church Ford ruled in Lexington, Ky., that Mr. Johnson was entitled to attend the university's graduate school. Judge Ford said that the defense had failed to prove that Kentucky State College for Negroes at Frankfurt provided opportunities equal to those at the all-white university in Lexington.
Later in 1949, Mr. Johnson and about 30 other blacks matriculated at the university. But his entry led to the burning of crosses on the campus. He left school the end of the 1949 summer session without obtaining a degree, saying that his motive in suing had been simply to help black students gain entry to the school.
He went on to teach -- mainly history, but also economics and mathematics -- for a total of 33 years at Central High and to become an assistant school principal at three other Louisville schools and to serve on the school board of Jefferson County, which includes Louisville.
Mr. Johnson also was president of the Louisville branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. He was prominent in successful struggles to achieve parity in salaries for black teachers with white teachers in Louisville, to forge open-housing laws and to integrate public housing throughout Kentucky.
In 1991, he contended that a proposal to end the mandatory busing of elementary school children in Jefferson County would mean a swift return to separate and unequal education for blacks.
His wife, Juanita, died in the 1970's. He is survived by a son, Lyman Morrell Johnson, of New Jersey, and two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Black-Owned Bookstores Defend Niche

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

DATELINE: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif.

 BODY:
When Coretta Scott King visits here on Oct. 12 for her only Southern California stop in a speaking tour in the West, the event is expected to draw 10,000 people to a minor-league baseball stadium and bring the city center to a standstill. Church choirs are rehearsing for a performance, and a special section is to be set aside for local residents who helped establish a City Hall memorial to Mrs. King's husband, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
Such fine-tuned planning, intended to elicit support from image-conscious city officials and community groups alike, has become the trademark of the Phenix Information Center, a tiny bookstore here that specializes in black authors and is responsible for Mrs. King's appearance. 
It is a survival strategy being put to the test by independent booksellers, including the estimated 300 black bookstores nationwide. These stores have recently benefited from a resurgence of black authors and an abundance of titles.
But some suggest that the zenith has been reached. Now, cautious publishers are pruning their book lists as hardcover sales decline. Independent booksellers fear their business could suffer, with fewer literary celebrities to draw crowds and generate sales momentum. The new publishing economics means a forced course in self-reliance for booksellers, who must depend less on publishers and more on their own ideas for events.
That is the stock in trade of Joann and Feron Roberts, both 41, who modestly began Phenix in 1992 with $5,000 in savings, their Christian faith and a corner in an art gallery. The couple have built Phenix into one of the nation's top 10 black bookstores by regularly drawing high-profile black writers. Manie J. Barron, who sells books by black authors to retailers for Random House, estimated the store's annual sales at $250,000, about average for a specialty bookseller.
The success of Phenix has been no easy feat. Since 1990, the ranks of independent booksellers have declined nationally by a third, a time that parallels the expansion of superstores like Crown Books, Borders and Barnes & Noble and the emergence of discount chains like Price/ Costco and Dayton-Hudson's Target Stores as big booksellers.
Other black bookstores, like Esowan in Los Angeles, Black Images Book Bazaar in Dallas and Hue-Man Experience in Denver, have successfully competed against low-cost chains using their depth of selection, investments in new authors, book clubs and customer loyalty built through involvement in community affairs.
In 1995, when Colin Powell was weighing his Presidential aspirations, Phenix was one of only two black-owned bookstores to lure the retired general to a book-signing during a 20-city tour to promote his memoir, "My American Journey." And unlike the other, Afrocentric Books in Chicago, Phenix helped set up a speaking engagement as well: General Powell wound up addressing an overflow crowd that filled the civic auditorium.
"What Joann and Feron have been able to achieve in such a short time is phenomenal," said Mr. Barron of Random House, the Advance Publications unit that published the Powell book. "The word is out on them among black authors."
Other well-known black authors have also ventured 70 miles east from traditional Los Angeles literary venues, coming here to an old railroad and citrus town. Now a city of 174,000, San Bernardino is struggling with urban problems like downtown blight and the fear of crime. About 17 percent of the city's population is black, more than twice the percentage in the state, while the median income is $33,000, a third lower than the California median.
Phenix is one of a half-dozen black-owned businesses in the city's historic district, many of them drawn by city officials trying to woo pedestrians back to an area emptied by a nearby enclosed mall. "We didn't realize there was such a cultural need," Mrs. Roberts said.
Phenix has turned out big crowds for well-known authors like Maya Angelou and Walter Mosley, and celebrity writers like George Foreman, Johnnie Cochran and Christopher Darden. Pumpkin-colored walls and lofty ceiling fans give the 1,400-square-foot store a library's warmth and airiness. The store also sells used paperbacks by black authors, along with greeting cards, wrapping paper and wedding invitations with ethnic graphics.
Unlike most big Phenix events, Mrs. King's visit is not a result of a publisher's promotional tour but comes from the Robertses and their wish list of hard-to-get black luminaries. "We put together very good proposals," Mrs. Roberts said.
For Sunday's event, this meant adding to the stadium address a $65-a-ticket reception with Mrs. King, who will hand out autographed copies of "My Life With Martin Luther King," a book usually available only at the King Center in Atlanta.
Despite the couple's marketing flair and record of selling hundreds of books at signing events, Phenix still struggles for credibility with some publishers, who may steer authors clear of specialty stores for fear a book will lose mainstream appeal. "What is it you have to do?" asked Mr. Roberts, who was disappointed when Phenix was rejected as a possible itinerary stop for Anita Hill, whose memoir, "Speaking Truth to Power" was just published by Doubleday, a unit of Bertelsmann.
"This battle between the bookstores is very real," said Oren Teicher, a spokesman for the American Booksellers Association in Tarrytown, N.Y. "It's independents versus chains, but it's also a lot of new players. For the first time, the independents and chains represent less than 50 percent of book sales."
W. Paul Coates, publisher of Black Classic Press in Baltimore, said that most major publishers and chain booksellers recognized the importance of the black market. "But they don't know how to market to the black community," he said. That has benefited small black publishers and bookstores, he added.
Mr. Coates warned that publishers' efforts to rein in returns of unsold copies will change the business of specialty booksellers and strand some writers. "Those hard decisions are going to affect all authors, black authors included," he said.
Phenix, which has competition from two national chain outlets in nearby malls, serves as a resource for black history for academics and as a cultural hub. The Roberts give workshops on subjects from Kwanzaa to credit repair, hold poetry readings for unpublished authors, show their wares at community events and distribute fliers in their store for black cultural activities.
"It's more than a bookstore," said Patricia Rodgers Gordon, a career development officer at a local college, who stopped at Phenix recently to pick up a pair of King tickets and unexpectedly ran into old acquaintances. "It's for fellowship."
Even so, Mr. Roberts is readying for a sea change. He thinks Phenix's reputation for personal service and community involvement will sustain the store. "If they stop sending black authors, we'll go back to our roots," he said. "We'll adapt."

HEADLINE: Greenspan Advises Caution On New Rules for Banking

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, called today for an overhaul of Federal rules so that banks could keep pace with technological changes.
But he also cautioned that Congress and regulators should move slowly in making changes so as not to upset the banking system and the economy. 
 If the rules are changed drastically now, "we may well end up doing more harm than good," Mr. Greenspan said in a speech to the annual convention of the American Bankers Association.
Addressing the gathering of 2,200 bankers and regulators, Mr. Greenspan said he sympathized with bankers who want a freer hand to compete with other financial institutions domestically and with foreign banks that are increasingly snapping up banking business in the United States.
Innovations in telecommunications and computer technology have blurred the lines between banks and other types of financial companies and have made the banking industry far more global. But Mr. Greenspan called on regulators and lawmakers to proceed with "caution and humility," saying their record of accurately predicting changes in the industry is not good.
In recent years, regulators have eased restrictions on banks wishing to underwrite securities and to sell insurance and investment products. But lawmakers have moved more slowly: banking legislation became stalled this past summer in the Commerce Committee of the House of Representatives.
At the bankers' gathering, Eugene A. Ludwig, the Comptroller of the Currency, warned that the underwriting standards of banks, especially for commercial lending, had continued to slip, adding that the fast pace of innovation and competition had seduced banks into making bad loans. The trend, he said, is worst in commercial lending but also apparent in retail banking.
Mr. Ludwig said that while banks had tightened their credit card lending standards and in many cases cleaned up their credit card portfolios, examiners have reported an increase in credit risk in almost every other category of retail loans.
Mr. Ludwig, the top regulator of 2,800 federally chartered banks, announced several steps examiners would take to correct the slippage. They will review credit underwriting standards with senior management of every national bank and meet with the chief executive of any bank where they find lending problems.
At the same gathering, Andrew C. Hove Jr., the acting chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said that rapid technological changes and globalization of the banking industry had forced his agency to question the role of deposit insurance. Mr. Hove called for an F.D.I.C. symposium in January to "explore refinements to the current system."

HEADLINE: Microsoft Is the Latest Target of Nader's Consumer Crusade

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5

 BODY:
The Microsoft Corporation, which has so far fended off accusations from competitors that it holds monopoly power over the computer software industry, has now drawn a new adversary, the consumer advocate Ralph Nader.
Mr. Nader and several of his public interest organizations are preparing a national campaign against the growing economic power of the Redmond, Wash., software publisher, contending that Microsoft is a craftier and more potent force than many monopolists of an earlier era. 
 Mr. Nader's very name is evocative, given the number of consumer crusades he has undertaken. But those activities may have diluted his influence in Washington, where he first made his name with a crusade against another consumer giant, General Motors, more than three decades ago.
And perhaps his most widely noted campaign in recent years was not against anything, but rather, for himself. His run for President in 1996, however, did not get far.
Still, Mr. Nader met earlier this month with top officials of the Justice Department's antitrust division, urging them to take action against Microsoft.
"Recently, people in many different kinds of businesses have been expressing fear and criticism about your company's business practices and strategies," Mr. Nader wrote in a letter sent on Thursday to William H. Gates 3d, chairman of Microsoft.
Mr. Nader and Essential Information, one of his organizations, are planning a conference in Washington on Nov. 13 and 14 to discuss Microsoft's strategy and its influence on the software market.
Speakers will include longtime Microsoft opponents like Scott McNealy, the chairman of Sun Microsystems, and Gary Reback, a Silicon Valley lawyer who has battled Microsoft on behalf of a number of its competitors.
Mr. Gates has been invited, but a spokesman for him said he doubted that the Microsoft chairman would attend and that the software publisher made a poor target for a public interest campaign.
"The ironic thing about this is that personal computer software is one of the most competitive markets of any industry," said Mark Murray, a Microsoft spokesman. "Consumers are benefiting from this trend toward more powerful computers and less expensive software."
But Mr. Nader said executives with whom he had discussed Microsoft had objected to its business practices, which have frequently leveraged the company's dominance in the operating system market into new software application areas.
He said that he believed that the antitrust issues raised by Microsoft's control of personal computer operating systems were different from those that have traditionally arisen in other industries. "This is a strange type of monopolistic practice," he said. "It doesn't immediately move to monopoly price. But there is a lot at stake here in terms of control of content and innovation."
The Justice Department is continuing to investigate a variety of Microsoft activities, including its acquisition of Vxtreme Inc., a Silicon Valley developer of technology for sending audio and video over the Internet. In July, however, the Federal Trade Commission rebuffed a request from a group of senators and declined to open a new inquiry into the company's business practices.

HEADLINE: Nationwide Phone Directory Assistance, on the World Wide Web

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

 BODY:
For some users of the World Wide Web, calling telephone directory assistance at 411 or 555-1212 may become a thing of the past if a partnership of two companies catches on.
Who Where Inc., a provider of on-line E-mail address directories and other information services, and Directory Net, which sells computerized telephone directories to big corporations, plan to jointly announce today a fee-based Web service intended to give small businesses and individuals computer access to the same telephone directory data bases that the nation's regional Bell companies use to process local 411 calls. 
 Having access to all this local data will offer the equivalent of a continuously updated on-line national telephone directory, Directory Net executives said.
The service, called Who Where Connect Now, which will be available beginning today, is priced to be competitive with local 411 calls, and lower than long-distance directory inquiries, company officials said. The monthly fee is $9.90 for the first 22 requests and 45 cents for each additional request during that month. The site's address is http:// wwcn.whowhere.com.
There are already many sites on the World Wide Web, typically supported by advertising, that offer a "white pages" search service for phone numbers. But the data typically come from printed versions of local telephone directories and can quickly become outdated.
"People are disenchanted with calling 411; you routinely get wrong phone numbers," said Bill Doyle, a senior analyst at Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass.
The new service will allow users to find a phone number by typing in a person's or business's name and the city -- or even just the state. It will also allow a search based on simply typing in a telephone number to disclose the name and address linked to that number.
Directory Net currently offers a similar service for large businesses and organizations that may need to find hundreds of phone numbers an hour, but it requires the use of Directory Net's own proprietary software and can cost thousands of dollars a month.
Big clients of this service include the Internal Revenue Service and the Student Loan Marketing Association, or Sallie Mae, as well as various credit-checking companies. That service competes with a similar offering, called Find America, from AT&T.
"This is a great way for Telstra to try to figure this market out," Mr. Doyle said, referring to Directory Net's parent company. "However, the economics of the deal aren't that great. It's really hard to get people to pay for information on the Web."
Who Where is based in Mountain View, Calif. Directory Net has its headquarters in Alpharetta, Ga.
The two companies would not disclose the financial details of the deal, other than to say they planned to share any revenue generated.

HEADLINE: Over the Din of New Media, a Voice for the Audio Arts

BYLINE: By LAURIE J. FLYNN 

 BODY:
"Sound matters!" Elizabeth Cohen preached to the audience of 600 audio experts. "No longer will we be the bastard child to pictures!"
The assembled group was the Audio Engineering Society, meeting last spring in Seattle, and the speech was part of Ms. Cohen's one-year campaign as the organization's president to bring more attention to the audio arts. 
 In a world where images are king, Ms. Cohen wants to bring more attention -- and respect -- to the universe of sound technology.
After all, she pointed out, sound effects and music make up a huge part of the emotional experience of, say, going to the movies. And the Internet, the new generation of compact disks known as DVD, and the coming era of digital television all represent new frontiers for audio, and new territory in which the audio-engineering profession will need to stake its claim.
"We have at least 50 percent of the multimedia experience and less than 12 percent of the bandwidth," Ms. Cohen said in a recent interview. "Bandwidth," of course, refers to an information system's carrying capacity, and in the audio profession's view, sound typically gets too small a share.
As the elected head of the nation's largest organization of audio professionals, an eclectic 12,000-member society of audio technicians, inventors, consumer electronics marketers, theater operators and even Hollywood movie producers, Ms. Cohen, who is 43, may be in a better position than just about anyone else to point out the crucial role sound plays in everything from movie studios to movie theaters to home movie cameras.
With a Ph.D. in audio engineering, she represents a new generation of audio professionals who take for granted the digital language of computers, and who point to the Internet as the next big challenge for the audio profession.
In her term as president, Ms. Cohen has also represented another significant transition for the Audio Engineering Society, which recently held its biannual convention: she is its first female leader. And in that capacity, her peers say, Ms. Cohen brings a unique perspective to a field in which women are drastically outnumbered.
"Elizabeth has less traditional ways of approaching audio," said Marina Bosi, vice president of technology, strategy and standards at the film-sound company Digital Theater Systems, who will be the society's second woman president when she takes office later this year.
Perhaps Ms. Cohen's greatest contribution, Ms. Bosi said, will be her energetic promotion of new media, such as the Internet and DVD, to a profession that has often appeared resistant to change.
That Ms. Cohen has risen to prominence in the boys club that is the audio profession is no surprise to Ms. Bosi and others who know her. While an undergraduate at Bennington College in the early 1970's, she worked at Bell Labs, then the incubator of the nation's first communications satellite, as well as many of the other most significant audio accomplishments of the era.
"It was the best toy store in the whole planet," Ms. Cohen recalled.
But unlike most acoustics engineers, whose love for the subtleties of sound started with a penchant for tinkering with electronic equipment, Ms. Cohen attributes her early interest in sound to a more broad-ranging curiosity, as well as a love for music and the cultural milieu in which she came of age.
For Ms. Cohen, it all started in Flatbush, Brooklyn, where as the daughter of Maxine Duberstein, a New York State Supreme Court justice, and as a student at the Brooklyn Quaker Friends School she was introduced to a musician named Mickey Hart, the grandson of a family friend, who would eventually become the drummer for the Grateful Dead. Little did Ms. Cohen know then that the introduction would set the stage for her career.
"It was not a conscious connection, but it gave me access to a constant stream of creative people," Ms. Cohen said.
After Bennington, while living in the San Francisco Bay area in the 1970's and 80's, Ms. Cohen found herself part of the inner circle of the Grateful Dead, and she collaborated with Mr. Hart on two books. She now says her association with the band helped prepare her for the audio world in which she would eventually work -- perhaps even more so than her doctorate in acoustics engineering from Stanford, where she still holds the title of consulting professor of electrical engineering.
She never did much work as a recording engineer, but she has spent a lot of time in recording studios, testing the acoustical impact of new technology. In addition to teaching and presiding over the Audio Engineering Society, Ms. Cohen owns a consulting firm, Cohen Acoustical Inc., in Los Angeles, which specializes in room acoustics.
Five years ago, she oversaw the acoustical redesign of the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences Performance Hall in Los Angeles, and her services are in such demand that the two archrivals in digital movie sound technology -- Dolby Laboratories and Digital Theater Systems -- each hired her to design their screening rooms.
But it has been as president of the Audio Engineering Society, with its 75 chapters internationally, where Ms. Cohen said she had had the greatest impact.
The current focus in audio standards, as in the PC industry, is to insure they are "open" -- that is, not favoring one particular vendor's approach but allowing for many compatible approaches.
"Standards should be things that nurture new ideas, not inhibit them," Ms. Cohen said.
The group was influential in the development of standards for digital video disks, or DVD, which are expected to have a huge impact on the growth of the video, audio and multimedia industries. And the society's standards committee is working on a technology called Fire Wire, to make it easier to connect the components of a home theater system, among other applications.
These days, of the many huge challenges facing the audio business, there is none as profound as the Internet, Ms. Cohen said. The technical issues involve network bandwidth and other factors that affect the quality of sound as it moves in computer code through the sometimes narrow maze of the Net.
The organization is helping with the Internet 2, a project by higher education, government and industry to develop a more advanced -- and higher-performance -- successor to the overburdened Internet. The Internet 2 is expected to operate at transmission speeds 10 to 100 times that of today's Internet, opening opportunities for audio, she said.
With such high speeds, music students around the world could play together as if they were in the same room. A live concert could be enjoyed by millions, regardless of where the musicians were, without loss of quality.
And this time around, Ms. Cohen vows, sound is going to get its fair share of the network.
"We have met the challenge of performance in the limited bandwidth, but we're not going to take it anymore," she said. "We're trying to be one step ahead of the game this time."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Down With Chips!

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
I'm starting a new political movement. It's called "Americans Against Voice Mail."
Why? Because the main reason so many people have lost jobs, been forced to change jobs, or been able to upgrade their jobs in the last tumultuous decade is not a lowering of U.S. trade barriers. It's technology. A Mexican working at 75 cents an hour didn't take the job of our office receptionist; a microchip did -- the one that operates the voice mail device in all our office phones. A Chinese making 75 cents an hour didn't take that auto worker's job; a robot did. A Brazilian making 75 cents an hour didn't take your neighbor's grocery job; a supermarket scanner did. 
 So I want you to get up now, unplug your phone, go to your window, throw your phone out and shout: "I'M NOT GOING TO TAKE IT ANYMORE! SAVE AMERICAN JOBS! BAN VOICE MAIL! POTATO CHIPS, YES. MICROCHIPS, NO!"
Sounds crazy, I know. But it's not half as crazy as the Mad Hatter's tea party going on in Congress today, where lawmakers are telling you to throw the Mexicans, Chinese and Brazilians out the window instead. They are doing that even though every serious economic study indicates that the bulk of job loss (and creation) today is produced by technological change and deregulation and only 20 percent can be attributed to freer trade. But railing against microchips won't get you elected; railing against Mexicans will.
And that's why despite the passage of Nafta and the GATT global trade accord, and despite the fact that the U.S. economy is the envy of the world, Congress is on the verge of denying the President the "fast track" authority he needs to sign free trade agreements with the rest of South America -- on the argument that free trade is responsible for killing jobs.
This is really sad. And it's all Bill Clinton's fault. He began his Presidency by declaring that health care reform was the critical issue for America today. Wrong. The critical issue for America is that we have entered this period of incredibly rapid change, in which the technology revolution and the integration of global markets are combining to transform everyone's workplace, market and community -- eliminating old jobs and churning new ones. And for the U.S. to thrive in this world it needs a new, integrated approach to health care, welfare, education, job training and free trade.
Mr. Clinton talked about each of these individually, but never put them into a single, comprehensible framework. As a result, says the Harvard economist Dani Rodrik, "the connections and complementarities in all these areas got lost in the public debate and it allowed ideologues and extremists to gain the upper hand in each of these areas."
Mr. Clinton thought it was enough to just be right about the economics of free trade. It's not. Even if trade really does account for only a small part of job-churning in our economy, politically and psychologically it looms much larger. If Mr. Clinton had been smart, he would have defused this anti-trade angst by accompanying his "fast track" bill with a "Rapid Change Adjustment Act." It could have included pilot projects for public employment for displaced workers, tax breaks for severance pay for displaced workers, and an extension of the Kassebaum-Kennedy act, so that laid-off workers could keep their health insurance longer. And $2 billion in U.S. assistance to the Asian, African and Latin American development banks to promote training of women, anti-child-labor programs and environmental cleanup in countries we trade with.
If Mr. Clinton's fast-track request had been combined with such a package, and put into a framework that defined for people the revolution we are going through right now, his opponents would be having a much harder time. Mr. Clinton could have satisfied those who really care about the labor and environmental strains that accompany rapid change, while marginalizing the Neanderthals in Congress who just want to build walls of protection or pander to trade unions.
The frustrating thing about Mr. Clinton is that he really gets it. He understands the information economy and trade, and the need to cushion them with training, safety nets and community-preserving programs. He's got all the pieces, but he never puts them all together in a sustained way. So there's a hole in the heart of Clintonism, and Dick Gephardt is driving a truck right through it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Mr. Clinton and Global Warming

BYLINE: By ROBERT B. SEMPLE JR. 

 BODY:
The debate over global warming has taken on all the characteristics of a political brawl, complete with spin doctors and aggressive advertising. A badly confused public is told one day that only a quick and dramatic reduction in energy use can avert meteorological disaster, then warned the next that any such prescription would send energy prices through the roof and the economy through the floor.
If he is smart about it, President Clinton can turn this increasingly polarized argument to his advantage. Most Americans are at least vaguely aware that rising atmospheric temperatures pose real if remote threats. They are also eager to know whether there are ways to address that threat that are both effective and affordable. It is here that Mr. Clinton can make a difference, positioning himself as a moderate in a debate that has so far shed more heat than light. 
 Between now and December, when the industrialized nations will meet in Kyoto, Japan, to negotiate a treaty controlling emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases, Mr. Clinton must devise a specific American proposal. He has already committed himself to "realistic and binding" limits on carbon emissions, but has not said what these targets should be and how to reach them. He is unlikely to be any more specific today in his remarks to a White House conference on global warming, a gathering aimed mainly at sharpening public awareness of the issue. But he has already sketched out four principles that will guide his Kyoto proposals.
First, he believes, along with most mainstream scientists, that man-made gases produced by the burning of fossil fuels like coal and oil are contributing to warming and that unless these gases are reduced, bad things -- coastal flooding and widespread droughts -- are likely to occur late in the 21st century. Second, he believes that no global emissions-control system can succeed without the leadership of the United States, which produces one-fifth of the world's greenhouse gases with only 5 percent of the world's population.
Third, he is convinced that developing countries like India and China, which are projected to throw off huge greenhouse emissions, must be part of any global warming agreement -- if not right away, then soon. This is a contentious subject. The Europeans argue that these countries need more time to grow and cannot now be forced into an international regime. The Senate, however, has said that it will not ratify a treaty that does not bind developing countries to enforceable targets.
Fourth, Mr. Clinton wants a system that will not impose intolerable strain on the American economy. He has already rejected as disingenuous (and much too expensive) a European proposal to reduce emissions 15 percent below 1990 levels by 2010. He clearly prefers a more gradual approach, and seems also to have ruled out new gasoline or carbon taxes (neither of which would fly in Congress anyway) and strong new regulations. His preferred approach is to set firm national limits on emissions and then let individual industries meet those targets using the cheapest means possible, either by switching to cleaner fuels or by making far more efficient use of energy.
There is one other element to Mr. Clinton's strategy that he has not talked about, but which may well be his ace in the hole in Kyoto as he tries to draw developing countries into the mix while providing flexibility for American industries. Devised by the Environmental Defense Fund, this is an emissions-trading scheme in which rich nations that cannot meet their assigned targets without crippling taxes or investments would be able to "buy" pollution permits from poorer countries whose economies are so inefficient that even the tiniest adjustments can achieve big reductions in greenhouse emissions. That money, in turn, would help developing countries invest in cleaner technologies.
This may not satisfy the Europeans, who find Mr. Clinton's faith in technology and efficiency touching but unrealistic, or those economists who believe that anything short of a stiff tax on carbon-based fuels will not get the job done. But Mr. Clinton has two constituencies, one in Kyoto and the other in the Senate. If he means to win over both, a modest course may be his only course. ROBERT B. SEMPLE JR.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Rejuvenated Yale Marks Bountiful Fund Drive

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
When Yale embarked on its $1.5 billion capital drive in May 1992, the largest ever announced by a university at the time, the mood on campus could not have been more strife-ridden. Yale was running a $12 million deficit and expected the red ink to increase. Buildings were in growing disrepair. A strike had closed classes and dining halls. Faculty members protested a plan to shrink their numbers by more than 10 percent. And there was a general loss of confidence in the president, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., who announced his resignation less than a month later.
But Yale plunged ahead. And with the fund drive's completion, announced Oct. 1, the university is celebrating its own turnaround. 
 "It's kind of like going through a riptide, with currents moving in two or three directions at once," said Gaddis Smith, a Yale history professor who is writing a history of the university for its 300th anniversary in 2001. "And then suddenly you're through it and in smooth water. That's what happened to us."
The campaign, which raised $200 million more than the goal, was helped by the robust economy and a runaway stock market that prompted alumni to open their wallets. But there were moments during the campaign -- including Mr. Schmidt's departure, the resignation of the campaign chairman and the highly publicized return of a $20 million contribution to the Texas billionaire Lee M. Bass -- when it seemed more like the perils of Pauline.
"If I were totally honest, I would have said I didn't think we would succeed, and if we did, we would only get to the finish line limping and exhausted," said John J. Lee, a Yale trustee and chairman of the fund drive.
Instead, Yale is on a rebound. Competition for admission is up. The budget is balanced for the first time in six years. The endowment is $5.8 billion, third highest among American universities after Harvard and the University of Texas. New buildings are going up, and old ones are being repaired. Long-troubled relations with New Haven are improving.
There is still restiveness among faculty members, who have absorbed years of cuts; given the prosperity, they assert that Yale can now afford to lift its hiring freeze, which they say allows only very slow change in academic emphasis. "It is a system that moves at about the speed of a glacier," said Donald M. Crothers, chairman of the chemistry department.
Still, others are quick to say that Yale should not go overboard. "We should not spend like drunken sailors," said Sabatino Sofia, a professor of astronomy.
Yale's fund-raising campaign looked none too steady when it was announced in May 1992. The university's provost and the dean of the college had just resigned, and Mr. Schmidt followed shortly. The chairman of the campaign, Vernon R. Loucks Jr., a longtime trustee and chief executive of Baxter International Inc., resigned the next year, after his medical supplies company agreed to pay a fine for violating Federal law by cooperating with an Arab boycott of Israel.
Enter Mr. Lee, a business turnaround expert and former Ivy League basketball star. In the beginning, he said, persuading people to give "was a very hard sell, because the level of credibility was very low." Still, the low point was yet to come: the announcement in 1995 that Yale would return $20 million to Mr. Bass because it could not agree on how his donation to pay for professors of Western civilization would be spent.
"The potential damage of the Bass matter was not the absolute dollars, although $20 million is obviously a lot of money," Mr. Lee said. "It was the potential for creating an incorrect image of Yale as a place that was stressed from within, with conflicting political agendas -- the potential to pollute the political environment for raising the rest of the money."
Yale scheduled meetings around the country, Mr. Lee said, to assure alumni that the episode was "not a manifestation of a political correctness," but a lack of administrative continuity as the university went through three presidents and provosts in just a couple of years.
A major theme of the sessions was that the administration would stabilize under its new president, Richard C. Levin. After a year under an interim president, Howard R. Lamar, Yale reached for Mr. Levin, a soft-spoken economist and consultant, who was briefly dean of Yale's graduate School of Arts and Sciences and was known for his ability to bring factions together. Mr. Levin came to Yale for his Ph.D. in 1970 and stayed on as a professor, specializing in deregulation and antitrust.
Mr. Levin has not significantly altered the strategy set by Mr. Schmidt -- to spend money on buildings, to contain faculty growth and other costs and to try to improve conditions in New Haven. But he is credited with pursuing it in a more conciliatory manner than Mr. Schmidt, who was criticized for being an aloof, absentee president who did not understand the institution.
Mr. Levin, on the other hand, has managed to pursue much of Mr. Schmidt's agenda, but without the turmoil. To raise Yale's contributions to New Haven, for example, he created a grant program for faculty and staff who buy homes in the city, encouraged course work in the city and touted it to prospective applicants as an ideal location for students interested in urban affairs.
"We see a real sense of engagement, not just at the top of the university, but pervading the whole university," said New Haven's Mayor, John DeStefano Jr.
There have also been visible improvements on Yale's campus. On Science Hill, there is the new Nancy Lee and Perry R. Bass Center for Molecular and Structural Biology, with its modern laboratories and open corridors to encourage collaboration. Down the hill is the handsome new Henry R. Luce Hall, housing the Center for International Studies, with large open spaces, huge arched windows and expanses of light wood. At the center of the campus is the renovated reading room in Sterling Memorial Library, where leaks have been stopped and computer ports added, giving a modern twist to an old Gothic building. "We took something enormously important to the entire community and fixed it," Mr. Levin said. "It's almost a metaphor for our whole program."
Yale is now planning the rehabilitation of the remaining science laboratories, the renovation of the undergraduate houses, and construction of a new dormitory to accommodate students as it renovates the houses, one by one. Yale's capital spending has quadrupled from four years ago and now tops $250 million a year. Its $1.1 billion operating budget was balanced in part by cutting faculty slots about 5 percent and by increasing spending from the growing endowment.
Even with a balanced budget, Yale administrators understand they have much left to do. They have bought a modicum of labor peace with six-year union contracts, but charges that the university is unfairly preventing graduate students from organizing have yet to be resolved. Faculty members are impatient for growth, fearful that without it departments will fall behind. And New Haven, though on the upswing, remains a city with many poor neighborhoods whose manufacturing base has largely disappeared.
Yale's provost, Alison Richard, reflected these pressures and the mood among Yale's administrators when asked about the capital campaign. "With the end of a campaign, you pause and you celebrate -- but not for long," she said. "We have great ambitions and great needs. We need to go on from here, and we will."

HEADLINE: Seeing Politics, and Mirrors, In the Coverage of Capitol Hill

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Sandy Hume, the star reporter of The Hill, a weekly paper, is among a new breed of correspondents burrowing so deep inside Congress that legislation itself has become largely beside the point. And a proliferation of the news he calls "the juicy inside stuff" is making this corner of the world more insular than ever.
A growing number of news outlets offering almost instantaneous updates to and about Congress have quickened an already frenetic pace. Two highly competitive newspapers -- The Hill and Roll Call -- several faxed newsletters and new on-line publications cover politics and personalities. 
 But much of the resulting mountain of reportage both originates and is consumed on the Hill, and some of it reads like in-house messages from one lawmaker to another. Often it is so site-specific and ephemeral that it becomes outdated within hours and never leaves the environs of the Capitol.
"I can spend all day on the Hill and not know what a single vote is about," said Mr. Hume, the 28-year-old son of the television journalist Brit Hume. "Almost everything they vote on is irrelevant to our mission. What we do is even more inside baseball than what the vote's about."
Several heavy consumers of Capitol news say this increased focus on not just inside-the-Beltway but inside-the-building news makes lawmakers more isolated.
"It creates this looking-glass world of mirrors reflecting more and more off one another and less and less of the outside world," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York.
With shortened news cycles requiring ever faster reactions, some legislators and staff members say the House in particular, which has never been considered a contemplative institution, has become even less so.
"These newsletters and daily operations have sped up the game and intensified the political nature of the place by making people respond almost instantly," said Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin. And the growing emphasis on insider gossip, he said, focuses too much attention on "government as entertainment."
On the other hand, some readers point out that the extensive coverage also makes it harder to hide pork or plain misbehavior.
The expansion has already gone well beyond what was thought the market would bear, with advertisers -- sometimes the same lobbyists who serve as news sources -- willing to pay relatively high rates to appeal to readers who make laws. The Federal Government is shrinking, the cold war is over, and Americans apparently find news from Washington less compelling than ever. But on Capitol Hill, self-described news junkies still cannot get enough.
Tony Rudy, press secretary for Tom DeLay of Texas, the House majority whip, describes a typical week: "Of course on Wednesday you get in early to see what The Hill wrote, and on Monday and Thursday it's Roll Call. At noon you get on the Internet for Hotline -- Hotline is like the Bible. Then Congress Daily at 3 o'clock, which gives you what happened at all the press conferences up to 2 o'clock."
Roll Call, a twice-a-week newspaper that has about 40 staff members, has been around since 1954. The Hill, with a staff of 28, came on the scene three years ago. The newsletters, all founded in the last decade, include CQ News Monitor, a 24-page sheet that focuses on floor action; Hotline, a newsletter available on line that does no original reporting but summarizes the top political stories of the day, and Congress Daily, a 12-page newsletter offering news twice a day on the people and politics behind lawmaking. Among the more recent entries in the field are on-line products like National Journal's Cloakroom, CQ News Alert and Allpolitics, sponsored by CNN and Time.
All of these and more are considered must-reads in a phenomenon that David Rapp, executive editor of Congressional Quarterly, calls "information paranoia."
 Howard Wolfson, chief of staff for Representative Nita M. Lowey, Democrat of New York, said: "You're afraid to miss something because information is the most important commodity. The more you have, the better off you are, so it just becomes a time-management issue that you have to do other things other than read newspapers. You budget the best you can."
A favorite sport of Congressional staff members during the time that is not spent reading inside reports, several of them said, is guessing who gave which unattributed quotations, then dissecting and rating them.
Recent fare included a story in The Hill that the chief of staff of a Republican opponent of same-sex marriage, Representative Charles T. Canady of Florida, had announced that she was a lesbian and had quit to work for a gay-rights group. An article in Roll Call noted that two House Republicans visited Cuba during the August recess but had not been criticized by their colleagues.
Some stories, like Mr. Hume's July report breaking the news of the unsuccessful Republican rebellion against Speaker Newt Gingrich, do get picked up by larger papers and television, and these local publications are widely used by Congressional staff members to get the attention of the wider media. (Mr. Hume's editor in chief, Martin Tolchin, brags that that story "did for us what Watergate did for The Washington Post.")
Sometimes, bigger papers only come around after someone else has published and thus legitimized a story -- and made yesterday's unconfirmed speculation today's conventional wisdom. But there are some complaints that this kind of pickup lowers the standard for publication of scandalous gossip.
In-House messages are commonly traded through these publications. Mr. Wolfson said his boss, Ms. Lowey, and other Democrats who support abortion rights recently used Congress Daily to send a message to Representative Henry J. Hyde, the Illinois Republican. They wanted him to know that they would try to vote down the spending bill for the Departments of Labor and Health and Human Services unless he changed language that they feared would have prohibited health maintenance organizations from receiving Federal money if they offered abortions. (The two sides have reached an understanding that kept but did not expand a ban on abortions paid for with Federal money, Mr. Wolfson said.)
Advertisers are sending messages, too. In a recent edition of Roll Call, ads urged Congressional support for American Indians, for a $32- billion-a-year highway improvement program and for giving President Clinton "fast track" negotiating authority for trade agreements. Advertisers in the Congress-centric press include big trade associations like the Made-in-the-U.S.A. Coalition and policy lobbyists like Citizens for State Power and the America Smokers' Alliance, as well as companies like Northwest Airlines and AT&T. The Hill charges $7,200 for a full-page color ad, Mr. Tolchin said.
Some local ads also focus on staff members who are apparently working late to keep up with their reading. "Tired of late-night greasy take-out?" one ad for a restaurant in The Hill began.
With low costs and relatively high ad revenue, Roll Call's reputation as a cash cow for its owner, the Economist Group, has drawn many of the newer competitors into the fray. "I don't think we've even scratched the market yet," said Jerry Finkelstein, chairman of The Hill, who said the paper would more than break even this year. In September, both The Hill and Roll Call reported record ad revenues.
The Hill, owned by Mr. Finkelstein's company, News Communications Inc., says it has "the largest circulation of any Capitol Hill publication." Mr. Tolchin put the circulation of The Hill -- which is mostly distributed free -- at 21,000. Roll Call has a circulation of about 17,500: 5,000 paid and 12,500 free. The annual subscription rate for Roll Call's paying readers is $225.
Profit margins at Roll Call are often as high as 40 percent, say people who know about the publication's finances. And even owners of less profitable publications said they thought there was room for virtually all comers. And there are rewards other than money for peddling your papers to some of the most powerful people in the world, they suggested.
"You have a lot of growth, not a lot of people making a lot of money," said John Fox Sullivan, publisher of the scholarly National Journal, which generally operates closer to the bone and was recently sold by Times Mirror to David Bradley and a group of investors including members of senior management. 'But people are building up very valuable assets because we're major players in the capital of the entire world."
And many of the newer entries in this corner of the market are spinoffs of established publications. The National Journal, for example, owns Congress Daily and Hotline, which sells for a pricey $4,200 a year. Its World Wide Web service, Cloakroom, began operation in July, and another newsletter, Daily Energy Report, is due this month. National Journal inaugurated a new look with a redesigned magazine last month.
Congressional Quarterly, which has been getting some competition from Congress itself since the institution began posting roll call votes on the Internet, is likewise designing several new services in addition to CQ Monitor and the on-line CQ News Alert, which is scheduled to expand in December.
At the other end of the spectrum, a glossy new competitor for Washingtonian magazine, Capital Style, hit the streets last month. Its editor, Bill Thomas, said the monthly, also owned by The Economist, would cover Washington "as a show-business town." He described Congress as "535 lounge acts all struggling to be Johnny Headliner."
Is there any limit to the hunger for inside Washington news -- if only inside Washington? "There's constant expansion," said John Morton, a media analyst who also publishes a newsletter on the newspaper industry. "There probably is a limit, but it hasn't been reached yet. There does seem to be an unending appetite for this stuff."

LENGTH: 1761 words

HEADLINE: Doubts on Cost Are Bedeviling Climate Policy

SERIES: THE WARMING WORLD: Confronting Climate Change

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
With President Clinton having accepted the dominant view among scientists that global warming is a serious matter, the increasingly urgent debate over what to do about it has largely shifted to the question of how restricting emissions of heat-trapping greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide may affect the nation's economy. And there, perplexity reigns.
The future severity of climate change is uncertain enough, and its future physical impact on particular countries and regions is more so. The uncertainty multiplies yet again when people try to calculate the costs and benefits of taking action to reduce greenhouse emissions. 
 "There's a lot more uncertainty about the economics than about the climate," said Dale W. Jorgenson, an economist at Harvard University who specializes in environmental questions.
Carbon dioxide is produced by the burning of fossil fuels like coal, oil and natural gas, which are the energy foundation of the modern economy. Some players in the debate, notably industries that produce fossil fuels or use lots of them, argue that serious economic damage would result if use of the fuels were significantly cut. Others, like environmentalists and advocates of alternatives to fossil-fuel energy, say the economy as a whole would gain because it would use energy more efficiently.
In between is a range of estimates, typically based on uncertain assumptions about how various aspects of the economy would respond to cuts in the use of fossil fuel and how strategies for cutting emissions would actually work.
All of this will be under the spotlight in Washington today at a daylong conference on climate change sponsored by the White House. Mr. Clinton, who plans to take part in the meeting, supports legally binding international action to cut emissions, but not at the price of harming the United States economy.
He is under intensifying pressure to come up with a specific proposal for reducing emissions. The United States proposal is generally seen as critical to efforts by the nations of the world to negotiate cuts at a meeting in Kyoto, Japan, in December. It is widely expected that Mr. Clinton's proposal will be announced later this month, either just before or at a pre-Kyoto negotiating session that begins on Oct. 20 in Bonn.
But as the moment of truth approaches, even some leading members of the Clinton Administration have all but thrown up their hands over the difficulty of obtaining clear answers to some crucial economic questions. Janet L. Yellen, the chairwoman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, told Congress in July that it was futile to try to develop a set of economic models that can "give us a definitive answer as to the economic impacts of a given climate change policy." Computerized models are the main analytical tool economists use.
"If anybody tells you that he or she has the definitive answer as to the costs and benefits of particular climate change policies," Dr. Yellen said, "I would suggest that you raise your collective eyebrows."
Can anything useful be said that might aid the search for a solution creating the least economic strain?
There is general agreement that reductions of emissions would come at some cost to the economy and that the size of the cost depends largely on the size of the cuts and how rapidly they are carried out.
Energy costs would very likely rise, at least for a time, and some industry sectors, it is generally agreed, could be hit hard if they were not able to adapt quickly enough. Chief among these is perhaps the coal industry; coal burning emits the most carbon dioxide per unit of energy, and the nation's utilities depend heavily on it.
But many economists also say there are a number of ways to cut the costs substantially, through policy measures. One is by imposing a tax on fuels in proportion to their carbon content. The revenues from the tax would be used to reduce other Federal taxes, thus pumping money back into the economy. Many economists see a carbon tax as the most economically efficient way to reduce emissions. But any sort of energy tax is likely to face deadly opposition in the Republican Congress.
So attention is focusing on another possible cost-reducing mechanism: emissions trading. In this arrangement, the Government sets an overall cap on emissions and issues permits to companies to emit carbon dioxide within that limit. Companies that find it more difficult and expensive to limit emissions could buy permits from those that find it easier and cheaper. The price of the permits is set in an open market.
Proponents of this plan, now in use for industrial sulfur dioxide emissions, say it cuts overall costs significantly. But many economists argue that unless the permits are initially auctioned by the Government and the proceeds used to reduce other taxes, much of the cost-cutting benefit to the economy would be lost.
The United States also favors extending the cap-and-permit idea to the international arena. Richer countries, which emit lots of carbon and would find cuts relatively expensive, could pay poorer ones, partly in technological assistance, to reduce some of theirs. Proponents of this idea say that since it would be cheaper to make cuts in developing countries, the cost both to the United States and the global economy would be lower.
A third way to reduce costs, some economists say, is to allow some flexibility in the timing of reductions. They argue, for instance, that forcing industries to replace their physical plants with more energy-efficient ones before their natural economic life is over would be very expensive.
A fourth cost-cutting idea, cited by environmentalists and advocates of alternative energy sources like solar and wind energy, is for government to aggressively promote the adoption of more fuel-efficient technologies. These are myriad, and range from small things like devices making it unnecessary for television sets to use power when they are off, to large things like automobiles that deliver 60 or 70 miles a gallon to ways of burning coal more efficiently.
A recent study by five of the Government's national laboratories concluded that vigorous promotion of such technologies could reduce carbon emissions to 1990 levels by the year 2010 while saving enough energy to at least offset the cost of putting the technologies in place. It was the latest in a long line of studies that have come to similar conclusions; some have found, in fact, that the energy savings from new technologies would increase gross domestic product, which is the total of all goods and services produced, by 1 or 2 percent a year over the long run.
Other economists, principally those who model the economy's overall operations, dispute this optimistic assessment, while acknowledging that some gains are possible through new technology.
"Virtually all analysts believe that there's some low-hanging fruit out there," said Richard Richels, an economist at the Electric Power Research Institute, a research organization in Palo Alto, Calif., that is supported by the power industry. The disagreement, Mr. Richels said, is over how much technological fruit can be easily picked.
A recent study by Robert Repetto and Duncan Austin of the World Resources Institute, an independent research group in Washington, found that such "bottom up" assessments as the five-laboratory study, which try to add up the expected impact on the economy from a wealth of new technologies, probably overstate the potential energy savings.
But the World Resources Institute also found that some conventional "top down" models, which analyze the economy's overall performance, tend to overstate the costs. Typically, the top-down models say reducing emissions to 1990 levels by 2010 would trim gross domestic product by 1 or 2 percent, with some predicting much greater losses.
Mr. Repetto and Mr. Austin examined 162 estimates from 16 models and found that 80 percent of their differences could be explained by what they assumed about economic uncertainties.
For example, the prediction turns out more optimistically if one assumes that the economy responds relatively easily to changes in policy, that noncarbon fuels are readily available and easily adopted and that damages from air pollution and climate change are averted as a result. Opposite assumptions produce more pessimism.
Predictions that a carbon tax or a cap-and-trade policy would seriously harm the economy are unrealistic, the two researchers wrote, because "they stem from worst-case modeling assumptions."
Assessing the damages of climate change, and therefore the benefits of averting it, is perhaps the chanciest task of all, and relatively few economists have tried it. One who has, William D. Nordhaus of Yale University, says his best guess is that benefits to the overall market economy of the United States may just about balance costs over the next century. But that guess, Mr. Nordhaus said, comes "with big uncertainties."
The most important uncertainties, said Mr. Jorgenson of Harvard, have to do with how much economic growth will take place in future decades even in the absence of any climate problem. Unlike some industry leaders, who argue that the uncertainties warrant doing nothing about emissions, Mr. Jorgenson says they are an argument for taking preventive action in the interest of future generations. But he also says he believes that the cost of reducing emissions to 1990 levels by 2010 would be too high and advocates a more modest policy.
But if the policy is too modest, say many involved in the pre-Kyoto international talks, it risks losing credibility with developing countries, which have refused to undertake binding reductions until the richer nations show that they are serious.
What's more, the Administration and the Senate, whose ratification would be required on any Kyoto agreement, have refused any deal that does not in some way include the poorer countries. Then there are the Europeans, who have proposed cutting emissions 15 percent below 1990 levels and are increasingly at odds with the United States over the issue.
However things turn out, flesh-and-blood political realities are likely to overshadow uncertain science and economics in the diplomatic endgame at Kyoto.
 
Warming World
This article is one of a series that have appeared since Aug. 12 on the science, politics and economics of climate change with the approach of an international meeting in Kyoto, Japan, in December to discuss limits on greenhouse gases.

HEADLINE: Putting Politics Aside

BYLINE: By LAURIE GOODSTEIN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
By choosing to convene a religious revival meeting of Christian men on Saturday in the nation's political capital, the leaders of the evangelical men's movement called Promise Keepers were forced to spend much of the day forswearing any political motivation.
The men who attended the event say they committed their lives to Jesus, not to the Republican Party, and they say they should be taken at their word. 
 However, this massive mobilization could have political and social repercussions in an era in which conservative evangelical Christians are feeling increasingly vulnerable as the nation becomes more and more religiously and culturally diverse. What will it mean when hundreds of thousands of men go back to their homes, energized by speakers who pumped them up on Saturday to "take back our country for Christ"?
Skeptics immediately envision a Christian army marching in lock step. But more likely the impact will be so local as to be felt household-to-household or man-to-man.
These men tend to steer away from talk of political issues; instead, they talk about "relationships," and that is where the Promise Keepers will try to make their mark.
Most of the attention to Promise Keepers focused on what the group has to say about relationships between the sexes, but at Saturday's event the leadership clearly signaled that what now tops their agenda is relations between the races.
At the rally, Bill McCartney, the former University of Colorado football coach who founded Promise Keepers seven years ago, announced what amounted to a deadline for Christian churches to end their own racism. Mr. McCartney, who still goes by the nickname "Coach," told the crowd that his goal was to gather a multiracial rally of Christian men outside every state capitol at noon on Jan. 1, 2000, to pronounce that the church has eradicated racism within its own ranks.
"That's brave rhetoric," said the Rev. Robert M. Franklin, president of the Interdenominational Theological Center in Atlanta, the largest predominantly African-American seminary in the country. Mr. Franklin traveled to Washington on Saturday to observe the Promise Keepers rally, and said he was impressed at the way black and white men intermingled there. In a survey of rally participants, The Washington Post found that 1 of 7 of the men who attended was black.
"But there's so many problems facing the black church," Mr. Franklin said, "particularly problems related to poverty alleviation and crime that I think the effort at racial reconciliation will only garner support from the black church if it is linked to problem solving in urban poor black communities. If they get that, I think this could be quite a hopeful development." But, he added, "I haven't seen evidence of it yet."
Mr. McCartney also directed the men to form closer relationships with their local churches and their ministers. "Pastors," Mr. McCartney said on Saturday, "you have been working with half a squad. You have been working with mostly women. But that's going to change. These guys are coming back."
Churches do tend to be "predominantly female enclaves," said William Dinges, associate professor of religion at the Catholic University of America, in Washington, also attended the rally as an observer. Whereas Promise Keepers' goal of ending racism in the church is "political naivete, which is probably their Achilles' heel," Mr. Dinges said, the goal of infusing male energy in the church is realistic.
"They are preaching to the converted," Mr. Dinges said. Polls show that a majority of the Promise Keepers are already active members of churches. Indeed, many who traveled to the rally did so on chartered buses, planes or trains with other members of their church groups.
Promise Keepers drew on this church infrastructure to mobilize the numbers it summoned to Washington. Neither Promise Keepers nor government agencies are making any official crowd estimates, but it is safe to say the gathering numbered in the hundreds of thousands.
Six years ago, Promise Keepers drew 4,200 men for its first event in a basketball arena in Boulder, Colo. Since then, the group has drawn, by its estimate, about 2.6 million men to 61 stadiums in cities around the country. Historians call it one of the fastest-growing religious revivals in American history.
The Washington Post poll found that 46 percent of Saturday's participants considered themselves Republican, (28 percent said they were independent, and 15 percent Democrat) and 61 percent considered themselves either conservative or very conservative. Eight percent said they were liberal.
Some conservative groups and members of Congress took advantage of the event to try to marshal support. The Family Research Council, a conservative lobby headed by Gary Bauer, distributed a pamphlet and built its mailing list by fielding workers offering free aerial photographs of the event to those who signed up for it.
Critics on the political left and in feminist groups warn that Promise Keepers is a "Trojan Horse" for the religious right. And certainly many in Promise Keepers oppose abortion and homosexuality.
But in interviews, Promise Keepers participants characterized themselves as largely apolitical because, they said, they did not believe in political solutions to what they see as spiritual and moral problems. The Washington Post poll found that while 6 in 10 men said they had a favorable impression of the religious right, only 26 percent said they considered themselves members.
Over coffee on Saturday night, four friends from the Detroit area who drove to the rally together said that for them the Promise Keepers event was a spiritual "pep talk" for leading righteous Christian lives.
"We can't change people through politics," said Vito Mazzara, 36, a United Parcel Service driver from North Branch, Mich., who brought his 11-year-old son to the rally. "Our job is to have a lifestyle of integrity. I do it with my customers on my route, with my bosses. I don't call in sick if I'm not sick. My bosses know that."
It is not possible for people or political systems to change things like economic inequality, injustice and prejudice, the four men agreed.
"It's never going to be fair," said Tim Laden, 49, a real estate appraiser from Redford, Mich.
The only answer, they said, is "changing hearts" to persuade people to accept Jesus Christ as their savior. The men said the rally had inspired them to share their faith with non-Christians. But outright proselytizing rarely succeeds, said Darrell A. DuBay, 36, an account executive for a building automation business. "Before I became a Christian I had people try to force religion on me, and nobody likes that."
Much of the media coverage of Promise Keepers highlighted men who were looking to rebound from serious problems, like addictions, divorce or abuse. But the four men from Michigan are probably just as typical in that they are husbands and fathers in what they characterized as intact, traditional families.
Nevertheless, they said, Promise Keepers served to remind them to be more responsive to the needs of their wives and children.
"My wife runs a part-time business, and I tend not to give her enough time off," said Ignacio Gneco, 36, a carpenter from Redford. "She dresses all the kids, and I could do that. I don't even know where the clothes are."
