HEADLINE: Pesticides Contribute to Food Safety Problem;
Growing Your Own

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Sept. 29 front-page article on the dangers of importing food into the United States suggests the need for all of us to learn where to get wholesome food locally and to grow our own food. 
 Community Supported Agriculture farms allow city dwellers to purchase the crops grown by a local farmer. Subscribers get fresh food that is harvested in a timely manner and trucked to their homes dozens instead of thousands of miles.
A few fruit and nut trees planted in a courtyard and a community vegetable garden in a vacant lot can supply the food needs of dozens of families. Bean sprouting can be done in a small kitchen all year round. These ways of taking responsibility for our food supply will also prove to be economical and beneficial to the environment.
 
JERRY HENKIN
White Plains, Oct. 3, 1997
 
The writer is on the board of the Northern Nut Growers Association.

HEADLINE: The Eve of Construction;
Refugees From City Fear They've Started a Boom

BYLINE: By MONTE WILLIAMS 

DATELINE: COLD SPRING, N.Y.

 BODY:
By moving from a Hoboken, N.J., brownstone to Putnam County, Aegis Frumento, a New York lawyer, and his family found what seems impossible in the region these days: a house on a 5 1/2-acre plot of wooded land for $270,000, good schools, relatively low taxes and a community where crime is almost unheard of.
Mr. Frumento and his wife, Jane Vagnoni, bypassed Westchester County altogether in settling here with their three children. "You can't find anything like this in lower Westchester for less than a million dollars," he said. 
 The couple is representative of many families who, whether unable to afford Westchester or wanting to get more for their money or seeking a more bucolic setting, have discovered Putnam and made it the fastest growing county in the state. Putnam's population grew by about 7,000, or 8.4 percent, between 1990 and July 1996, according to the United States Census Bureau.
New residents are lured by the county's good schools, rural character, affordability and low rates of crime and unemployment. "We've been called one of the best-kept secrets in the metropolitan area," said Edward Heelan, a real estate broker and developer.
But Putnam's growth is rapidly transforming an area that a generation ago was a rural retreat for New Yorkers. Many people who moved to Putnam in search of a simpler way of life feel threatened by the accelerating growth.
Complicating matters is that much of Putnam is in the New York City watershed. Fearful that unbridled development is also threatening the purity of water carried from reservoirs here to the city's residences and businesses, the city's Department of Environmental Protection is enforcing the first new pollution rules for the watershed in 44 years, some of which could dictate where development can take place. One indication of the bitterness of that fight is that 100 developers and landowners, 98 of them from Putnam, have sued the city for the value of their lost property and development rights.
As Putnam expands, many fear that it will go the way of southern Westchester County, once a haven for those fleeing the ills of the city, but now faced with urban problems like traffic, crime, pollution and poverty.
"New Rochelle and Mount Vernon once called themselves the city of homes," said Elizabeth Fuller, librarian for the Westchester County Historical Society. "They were residential places, where you built nice parks and had fresh air, but then they got large."
Up until the 1940's, much of Westchester consisted of farmland, summer resorts and large estates, Ms. Fuller said. In the 1950's, the county became a bedroom community and major corporations started moving their headquarters into Westchester.
In Putnam County, with subdivisions and office buildings cropping up on what was once farmland and a community of lakeside second homes, there are fears that the county may lose its rustic beauty, the very thing that attracted many people here in the first place.
Drawn by the combination of a bucolic atmosphere and easy access to urban centers, William Clare, 36, and his wife, Shawn, 42, moved almost five years ago from Port Chester, a largely working-class village in Westchester, to the Putnam town of Southeast, where they bought a town house. Mr. Clare, a court officer, and Mrs. Clare, a secretary, both work 45 minutes away, in White Plains.
"We have all the major arteries right here," he said. "Danbury is 10 miles away for shopping. And we had hoped to start a family and we thought the schools would be better. The taxes are much lower than in Westchester."
In Putnam, the median sales price for a single-family home was $172,500 in the second quarter of this year, compared with $306,000 in Westchester, according to the Westchester-Putnam Multiple Listing Service. In 1995, Putnam, home to Gov. George E. Pataki, ranked 61st out of the state's 62 counties for both violent crime and property crime, according to the State Division of Criminal Justice Services. The median household income in 1993 was $54,939 -- the highest in the state. In 1996, only 4,167 of its 90,983 residents, or 4.6 percent, were below the poverty level, the lowest percentage of poor people of any county in the state. The unemployment rate was 2.9 percent in June -- tied with Albany County as the lowest in the state.
Most of Putnam's residents commute to jobs in New York, Connecticut, Westchester or Dutchess Counties. Mr. Frumento has a 70-minute ride into Manhattan, much longer than the trip from Hoboken. "But it's a quality commute," he said. He always gets a seat on the Metro-North train and with his laptop computer, cellular phone and briefcase, he finds that his ride is often the most productive time of day.
The Putnam County Executive, Bob Bondi, thinks the environment is a major reason many people are drawn to the county. "There are no cities in Putnam, so there's no urban blight," he said. "And there are plenty of trees."
But one factor that mitigates against development is that much of the county is in the New York City watershed, and all of the 11 reservoirs in the county are owned by the city. With tougher watershed regulations in place, there are those who say there is little chance that the county will become overdeveloped. Still, more than 7,100 acres of land that drain into reservoirs are slated for development or have new construction under way, according to Nell Keeler, an environmental analyst. Depending on whom you talk to, the regulations are either too strict or too lax.
Judith Jones, a philosophy professor at Fordham University who moved from Yonkers to Mahopac earlier this year, thinks the restrictions are not tight enough and that development is out of control. "Every parcel I pass is for sale," she said. "Before you tear down the ecosystem, you should ask yourself if it's good for humans or for the rest of the ecosystem."
One of the biggest projects planned for the county is a 450,000-square-foot retail outlet center in Kent. Mr. Heelan is the broker and consultant for the project. Putnam has very little retail. "If you want to buy a dress, you have to go to Danbury, Poughkeepsie, White Plains or Mount Kisco," said Ross M. Weale, president of the Putnam County Economic Development Corporation.
Joseph L. Belvedere, the town supervisor of Kent, is one of the retail center's biggest supporters. "Our tax base has been shrunk by the watershed requirements," he said. "The town needs an economic taxpayer besides homeowners. A lot of the costs, which the watershed regulations put on the town, are not reimbursed and the amount that is set aside for reimbursement is hardly enough."
In the town of Southeast, a huge multiplex cinema has been planned by Hoyts Cinema Corporation. It has drawn opposition, even though the county has no movie theaters. The site for the proposed cinema is across the street and downhill from the East Branch reservoir and it borders the watershed.
"The parking lot is blacktop and impervious," said Michael Caputo, a member of a civic group opposed to the multiplex. "In addition, the project will increase traffic tremendously. It's a quiet road, and by Hoyts's own estimate, there would be 745 cars during the peak hour."
Mr. Bondi thinks there is room for the county to grow and still maintain its attractiveness. But some residents think that if Putnam is not careful, it could become like nearby Danbury, Conn., where malls and heavy traffic abound. "I like a place where there's not a traffic jam every 100 yards or so," Ms. Jones said. "I like a nighttime that's actually quiet. Thousands of people feel like I do, and that's the reason we have the growth. Everybody tries to get the same thing, and no one ends up getting it."

HEADLINE: Trash Disposal System Is Fragmented by a Court's Ruling

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Waste collection and disposal in New Jersey have never been simple matters, although there have long been two constants: that the state's disposal costs were the highest in the nation and that the state controlled where the garbage ended up.
Whether household trash was separated and recycled locally and then burned in an incinerator to produce electricity, or bundled together at huge transfer stations and taken by truck to landfills in the state or elsewhere, state law has for more than two decades regulated it like a public utility. 
 The state directed county officials how to dispose of the garbage and gave them the exclusive right to borrow millions of dollars to finance those arrangements. The counties then passed the costs to homeowners and businesses through local taxes or the fees paid to private carters.
But in New Jersey, which generates about 10 million tons of trash each year, the constants can no longer be relied upon. Last May, a Federal appeals court found the disposal arrangements to be anticompetitive and unconstitutional. The state has asked the Supreme Court to hear the case, but most officials expect that the court will turn down the request during its new term, which begins Monday.
As a result, arrangements that have existed for 25 years are being questioned. From Gloucester County in the rural south of the state to densely populated Bergen County in the north, communities have been altering their garbage disposal plans in the hope of lowering their costs.
In the process, those communities are calling into question the financial arrangements that have long secured some $1.6 billion in bonds issued around the state for a range of waste-disposal operations. At the same time, the state has sent letters warning municipal officials that the state's system remains in effect until the Supreme Court issues a final ruling, and communities that alter their arrangements may face fines.
Eric Wisler, a partner with the law firm of DeCotiis, Fitzpatrick & Gluck, a specialist in waste disposal that is representing 10 of the state's 21 counties, said that "there is no 'one size fits all' anymore" and different communities are striking off in different directions.
"The fallout of the decision is that things are falling apart," said Michael Hogan, counsel to the State Environmental Commissioner, Robert C. Shinn Jr. Mr. Hogan said the state had already published for comment the outlines of a replacement plan in the event that the ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit stands.
"We are troubled by what is happening, and each county seems to be adopting a different approach in anticipation of the state plan finally falling," Mr. Hogan said. "There is a whole menu of options for them, but litigation seems to be a side dish with most of them."
In Essex County, for instance, officials have gone to court to break a contract they have with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which built and owns the Essex County incinerator in Newark. County officials said they could cut their disposal costs to $63 a ton from the current $73 a ton by using out-of-state landfills.
In Gloucester County, officials have sued to reopen their local landfill and to break the decades-old agreement with Wheelabrator-Frye Company not to compete with the company's incinerator. If the county is successful, its disposal costs would plummet to $57 a ton at the landfill from $99 a ton now at the incinerator, county officials said.
For New Jersey residents like Cindy Calotta of Maplewood, the fragmentation of the state system is likely to force them to pay attention to something that they rarely think about. Ms. Calotta pays $300 a year to a private hauler who must take the town's trash to the incinerator owned by the Port Authority. "After living in New York City and paying nothing, it's a lot of money," she said. "But we have gotten used to it."
Caught in the middle are agencies like the Bergen County Utilities Authority, which in 1988 borrowed more than $110 million to build a transfer station and signed a contract to deliver all of the county's waste to the incinerator operated by Union County. Three Bergen towns have struck out on their own since the court ruling in May. They have contracts to dump their trash at New York and Pennsylvania landfills at rates 30 to 40 percent less than what the county authority must charge to pay off its bonds and honor its contracts.
"We're just holding our breath," the chairman of the authority, Fred Criscuolo, said. With the defection of three towns so far, the county authority is falling short of the revenue it needs to meet debt payments and has had to tap into reserve funds.
With an average disposal fee of $87.97 a ton, New Jersey has the highest waste disposal costs of any state, according to Solid Waste Digest, a trade publication. The national average is $37.76 a ton. New York's average cost is $76.58 a ton, while Connecticut's is $65.36, the digest said.
The state's system went into effect in 1970 and was aimed at curtailing illegal in-state dumping. But it was expensive, resulting in $110 million annually in what the courts have called "excess tipping fees" for New Jersey residents. Local agencies spent millions of dollars to develop and build transfer stations, landfills or expensive waste-to-energy incinerators.
Allen Morrison, a spokesman for the Port Authority, noted that protecting the environment was a "desperation issue" for communities at that time. Incinerators like the one in Newark were seen as investments in economic development. But perhaps more important, the Port Authority had the money to build the incinerator, thereby freeing local governments from having to raise taxes immediately to pay for the project.
But Mauro Tucci, the chairman of the Essex County Utility Authority, said that the county is now locked into contracts with the Port Authority, signed in 1990, that require it to pay $73 a ton, even as the Port Authority's incinerator is taking in waste from New York City for only $40 a ton. "It may have been groundbreaking at the time, but this deal is no longer a good one for Essex County," he said.
In Camden, the county waste authority issued $220 million in bonds to build an incinerator and then turned over the plant to a private company, Foster Wheeler, to operate. The county agreed to pay $94 a ton to dispose of its waste in the incinerator. Now, though, said Mr. Wisler, the lawyer representing Camden and a number of other counties, Camden wants to abandon the incinerator and find cheaper landfill disposal.
Mr. Wisler said that the county was willing to pay the debt on the plant, even if it goes unused, because the county feared the impact a default would have on its credit rating.
"Camden is one of those counties which has worked hard to get their bond ratings up from the lowest investment-grade rating," said Mr. Wisler. "After a lot of sacrifice, they are on strong financial footing and don't want to risk losing that."
By contrast, in nearby Mercer County, Princeton Borough officials filed suit on Sept. 16 to block a county waste disposal plan that would require the municipality to continue to dispose of its waste with the county at a cost of $109 a ton.
David Goldfarb, a Princeton City Councilman, said the borough contends that the Federal court ruling last May not only banned the state from commanding where waste should go, but banned the county from doing so as well. Therefore, the county cannot force residents to make good on a $110 million debt for planning an incinerator that was never built, Mr. Goldfarb said.
"It's time for the improvement authority and the state to pay the price for what they have done and stop crossing their fingers and hoping lightning will strike and save them," he said.
When private haulers began challenging the state system in 1994, state officials expressed fears in court papers of an apocalyptic fragmentation that they said would "wreak havoc on the financial and environmental well-being of New Jersey." What has happened instead is a slow hemorrhaging that will eventually change the face of waste disposal in the state.
John Rooney, the Mayor of Northvale in Bergen County and a longtime opponent of the state system, was the first to take his community out of the system after the court ruling. He has nevertheless been putting aside some of the savings his town is realizing from cheaper disposal to help pay the debt the county has incurred for its transfer station. "I don't think the money was spent wisely over those years, but that is a different issue," he said. "I'll pay for the debt, but I won't pay for them to stay in the garbage business."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
The Mariners Fall Short of Raised Expectations This Year

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE

 BODY:
IT has come to this with the Seattle Mariners: Once upon a time they skulked about in the soft underbelly of the American League, but now they trudge in the nether world of good teams with high hopes that never quite won a World Series, or even reached a World Series.
They have the best player in baseball and the best left-handed pitcher in baseball and possibly the best designated hitter and the best young shortstop, too, but they were eliminated by the Orioles, 3-1, yesterday, in the first round of the playoffs. 
 There is reason to wonder if time and realignment and expansion and economic decisions will alter this team before it ever reaches the promised land.
"Our season's over, we all go home, in different directions," Ken Griffey Jr. said yesterday. "We all think about spring training."
Spring training does not sound like a lot of fun for a glamour team that has become one of the best draws in baseball. Griffey hit 56 home runs this season and Randy Johnson won 20 games, but in this four-game series, Griffey hit no home runs and batted only .133, and Johnson lost the first and the fourth games, even though he struck out 13 batters yesterday.
"What, you think I didn't pitch well today?" Johnson replied to somebody who brought up the defeat much too soon in the interview session.
The Mariners had reason to be defensive and sad. They came of age in 1995 by stunning the Yankees three straight times in Seattle, in one of the great recent post-season series, and they saved baseball in Seattle and charmed the voters into going for a new ball park in 1999. But will a pennant and a world championship banner ever flap in the brisk Puget Sound breeze?
"We won 90 games for the first time ever here in Seattle," said Lou Piniella, the manager. "We drew over three million fans. We won our second division title in three years. I told our kids after it was over that they had nothing to be ashamed of."
"They played their hearts out all year," Piniella said. "We fell short in our goal, but when you get to this level of competition, that can happen."
A team can erode from within, for one reason or another. The Pittsburgh Pirates were that team in the early 90's, reaching the league championship series three times and losing, once in heartbreaking fashion to an Atlanta pinch-hitter named Francisco Cabrera, and then the Pirates could not pay their stars, and free agency killed them.
Realignment could be the villain for the Mariners. The sport that spends millions of dollars on utility infielders is trying to save money on airplane fuel, so the Mariners are lusting to be switched over to the National League, which does not employ the designated hitter. If the Mariners change leagues, they may not have a spot for Edgar Martinez, merely one of the fearsome hitters of his time, but who has not played a position regularly in five years.
"Yeah, it kind of makes me angry," Martinez said as red-eyed teammates hugged each other. "I could play a position if they told me to prepare. But I don't think this is the end of the Mariners. They still have good players." The saddest player in the clubhouse was Jay Buhner, the shaven-headed power hitter who became a regular in 1991, the first time the Mariners ever reached mediocrity with 83 victories.
"I'm proud of being a Mariner," Buhner said, his pale eyes burning. "I remember us reaching .500. What's so frustrating is that we had chances to go further but we haven't done it. I don't know what's going to happen. There's so much up in the air. If there's realignment, who's in your division?"
"It only lasts so long," said Buhner, who is 33. "We've got guys signed for one more year. If we lose Edgar, we lose a quiet leader. We can't afford to lose a dominating guy like him. My God."
This year the Mariners set a major league record with 264 home runs, but they traded Jose Cruz Jr. to Toronto for two relief pitchers who did not help. Jose Cruz Jr. is still only 23 years old, but the season is over for the Mariners.
"You can't say you had a bad season if you don't win the World Series," Griffey said. "Houston didn't have a bad season. San Francisco didn't have a bad season. If you go out there and have good years, you see what happens afterward. Are you saying that only one team has a good season every year?"
No, that is football mentality, that everybody but the Super Bowl winners are craven sissies. The problem is perspective. Once the Mariners bashed the Yankees in 1995, they raised hopes they may never fulfill.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Seattle starter Randy Johnson trying to regroup during the first inning yesterday, when the Orioles scored the only runs they needed to eliminate the Mariners. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: N.F.L. WEEK 6: YESTERDAY'S GAMES;
Bucs Find Trouble Playing From Behind

BYLINE: By THOMAS GEORGE 

 BODY:

BUCCANEERS 16
PACKERS 21
GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 5 -- The Tampa Bay Buccaneers have been built for close, grind-it-out games, and the Bucs enjoy themselves most when they get a lead. That way, they can pound the other guys in the fundamentals of football. 
 But what happens when the Bucs drop far behind?
That had not happened this season, which was one reason Tampa Bay opened with a 5-0 record. But today the Green Bay Packers made sure Tampa Bay played from behind, and the defending Super Bowl champions showed the Bucs, before 60,100 fans at Lambeau Field, that they can play the game any way you choose. Fast or slow. Ahead or behind.
Green Bay was up, 21-3, at halftime. And though Tampa Bay won the second half, 13-0, and had the ball at the Green Bay 42-yard line with 1 minute 52 seconds to play before stalling, it was Green Bay that showed a champion's ability to win.
Green Bay triumphed, 21-16, and improved its record to 4-2. Tampa Bay slipped to 5-1 though it had 10 more first downs than Green Bay, 138 more total yards and 153 more rushing yards, ran 16 more plays and finished with nearly 9 minutes more of possession time.
"Yeah, nice numbers for them," Packers safety Eugene Robinson said. "But we won the game."
Tampa Bay Coach Tony Dungy could not argue. "Usually the best team wins," Dungy said. "They showed their character, but I think we showed ours, too. Those are the defending champs, though. There is a lot of talk about them being dead, but I don't think so."
That talk has been eating at the Packers. After their slow start -- including a loss at Detroit last week -- the pressure and criticism had begun to mount from the outside and within. Reggie White gathered his teammates before this game, moved the cameras and microphones away and privately told them that the fans do not play the game. The news media does not play the game. The Packers do, White said, and it was up to them to turn the team's fortunes around.
So, though Tampa Bay took a 3-0 lead in the first quarter, Green Bay bounced back with a 21-point second quarter. Brett Favre hit Antonio Freeman on a 31-yard scoring strike early in the quarter, and then, with 44 seconds left, Favre found Freeman again on a 6-yard scoring pass. But the play of the game happened between those two touchdowns.
Green Bay was up, 7-3. Favre fumbled at his 18 on a quarterback sneak: Tampa Bay ball. On the next play, Buccaneers quarterback Trent Dilfer tried to throw a screen pass to fullback Mike Alstott, but Packers end Gabe Wilkins wound up the receiver instead. Seventy-seven yards later, including some nimble running and a major leap over Buccaneers by the 295-pound Wilkins, the Packers were ahead, 14-3.
"It happened so fast, I don't remember every little detail," Wilkins said. "I could see them coming to my side of the defense, and then the ball was right there in my face."
Tampa Bay's Warrick Dunn rushed for 125 yards, and it was his 2-yard run with 10:11 to play that made the score 21-16. Then the Bucs got sacks from Regan Upshaw and Chidi Ahanotu to force Green Bay to punt. Tampa Bay was ready for its final gasp.
The Bucs started at their 4 with 4:59 left and moved quickly and efficiently to the Green Bay 42, but on third-and-6 and fourth-and-6 Dilfer could not complete passes to Dunn, who was isolated against linebacker Wayne Simmons.
Favre said: "It was like a playoff game. It had that atmosphere, the intensity was there. I assume Tampa Bay will be there at the end."
We can assume that Green Bay will be there, too.
 
SAINTS 20
BEARS 17
Da Coach 20, Da Bears 17.
Mike Ditka got revenge in his first game against the franchise that fired him almost five years ago, as his New Orleans Saints defeated Chicago on Heath Shuler's 89-yard touchdown pass to Randal Hill with 5 minutes 39 seconds to play last night.
Moments after a livid Ditka screamed at an official for what he felt was a bad penalty call, the coach was pumping his fist in celebration of Hill's leaping catch over Tom Carter.
Ditka, who coached the Bears to victory in the 1986 Super Bowl, spent much of the game agonizing over his team's poor play. The Saints blew a 13-3 fourth-quarter lead, committed three turnovers and failed to convert a single third down.
In the end, however, New Orleans won for the second time in three games while Ditka's former team fell to 0-6.
"We didn't do anything, we made a couple of plays and got fortunate," Ditka said. "We got lucky on a play and that's all I can say."
But it was not all he could say. He was animated all night.
"I yelled at everybody," he admitted. "I should yell at myself."
Was the yelling worth it?
"Yeah, I'm going to do it until I die," Ditka added.
The Bears must defeat Green Bay next week to avoid matching the worst start in their 78-year history. They lost their first seven games in 1969, when they finished 1-13 for their worst season.
During pre-game warm-ups, Ditka strolled to the center of the field, talking with his successor, Dave Wannstedt, for several minutes. And when the team left after the warm-ups, several hundred fans cheered Ditka, who walked with his head down into the locker room.
Ditka came back for the start of the game to a warm reception.
Ditka was fired after a 5-11 season in 1992, finishing with a 112-68 record with the Bears. (AP)
 
LIONS 13
BILLS 22
Barry Sanders came into the game looking to find the end zone on a running play. Unfortunately for him, Buffalo found him in the wrong end zone yesterday.
Sanders, without a rushing touchdown this season, was tripped by Bruce Smith and tackled by Phil Hansen for a safety, breaking a 13-13 tie with 2:12 left.
"I bet that doesn't happen very often," Hansen said. "There was just no place to run in there. We had back-side pressure, front-side pressure. It was just a great defensive effort."
Sanders finished with 107 yards for his fourth straight 100-yard game. It was not enough for the Lions. "We held him in check," said Bills linebacker Chris Spielman, who started his career with the Lions. "I've seen him for eight years, and I know what he can do. I think we did an admirable job." (AP)
 
VIKINGS 20
CARDINALS 19
Yes, the Cardinals lost another close one.
Minnesota's Eddie Murraykicked a 38-yard field goal with 10 seconds left as the Vikings came back from a 9-point fourth-quarter deficit to beat luckless Arizona.
Minnesota had taken over after the Cardinals' Kevin Butler missed a 31-yard kick wide left with 52 seconds to play.
Brad Johnson took the Vikings 62 yards in 37 seconds to get within range of the winning kick. His final completion was a 43-yarder to tight end Andrew Glover open over the middle that carried to the Arizona 20.
All I knew was I was going to catch it, because it was an excellently thrown ball, Glover said.
Murray's winning kick, sent the Cardinals to their fourth defeat by a total of 11 points.
Last week, Butler missed two field goal attempts in the fourth quarter in a 19-18 loss to Tampa Bay.
Murray also kicked his 234th consecutive extra point, tying the N.F.L. record set by Tommy Davis of San Francisco from 1959 to 1965. He had to make it from field-goal length because of a 10-yard holding penalty on his first try.
The Cardinals put together a strong drive to the Minnesota 6 before their hard luck struck.
LeShon Johnson was thrown for 1- and 7-yard losses on consecutive plays, leaving Butler to try the 31-yarder.
I don't care what happens, Cardinals quarterback Kent Graham said.
We've got a good team. We're going to stay together, and we're not going to finger-point, because this team could be 5-0, and it ticks me off that we're not. (AP)
 
BENGALS 13
JAGUARS 21
The play developed like so many others for Mark Brunell and the Jacksonville Jaguars. He rolled to his left, found his receivers covered and saw room to scramble.
For the first time since tearing ligaments in his right knee, Brunell never gave it a second thought. He ran. Brunell was back to his old self, throwing for three touchdowns and showing his potential as a scrambler.
Brunell's 14-yard scramble in the fourth quarter set up his 12-yard touchdown pass to Willie Jackson. The score put the Jaguars in control for good.

STEELERS 42
RAVENS 34
In the first half, after his third interception, Kordell Stewart stood on the field with his hands on his hips. Then his shoulders sagged as he let out a huge sigh.
In the second half, after his second touchdown pass, Stewart hopped like a kid and skipped off the field. He had rallied the Pittsburgh Steelers from a 21-0 deficit to a 28-24 lead.
Stewart had come up with a new variation of Slash -- inept in the first half and infallible in the second -- as the Steelers tied a team record for best comeback victory. The Steelers also rallied from 21-0 down in a 30-24 victory on Dec. 15, 1985, against Buffalo.
"It's about trust, man," said Stewart, who strained a quadriceps late in the game. "You throw three interceptions, guys can go in the tank. It's not over until there's three zeroes left in the fourth quarter. Anything's possible when you believe."
After setting up three Baltimore touchdowns with interceptions before halftime, Stewart threw three touchdown passes after the break and appropriately capped the day with a 74-yard scoring run.
The Ravens blew a second-half lead for the 11th time since they came to Baltimore last year.
"After the game, guys are saying that we have to learn from this," Baltimore's Vinny Testaverde said. "But I thought we learned from it last year. If we don't give it the extra effort, we're always going to be a .500 team." (AP)

Broussard, the Seahawks' third-string running back, came off the bench to put some zip into Seattle's running attack after it was held to 19 yards in the opening half. I haven't run like that since 10 years ago when I played at Washington State, he said. (AP)

HEADLINE: Death Penalty Is Posing Test For Prosecutor

BYLINE: By JOHN SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
The Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, facing the biggest test yet of his personal opposition to capital punishment, must decide by Wednesday whether he will seek the death penalty against a man accused of killing a police officer in May.
Gov. George E. Pataki, the police union and the victim's parents have all publicly and vigorously urged the District Attorney to argue for the death penalty. When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani named a street after the officer, Anthony Sanchez, earlier this month, he said the case was "precisely the reason the death penalty was established in New York." 
 "I have urged the District Attorney," the Mayor said, "to seek the death penalty in that case. It is our view that the death penalty would be appropriate, considering that Officer Sanchez was murdered by someone fleeing another crime."
The facts of the case are simple. Officer Sanchez, a decorated officer with an unblemished, 10-year record, responded to an armed robbery call on May 19. Climbing the stairs of the apartment building in Chelsea, he intercepted a gunman and was shot once in the neck. Police officers searching the area found Scott Schneiderman cowering in the basement with superficial bullet wounds and Officer Sanchez's service revolver.
The police charged that Mr. Schneiderman, a failed stockbroker, had gone to the building intending to rob his wealthy father. But, they said, he botched the job and ended up killing Officer Sanchez during his escape.
Mr. Schneiderman has yet to come to trial, but the debate over the case began almost immediately after his arrest. Mr. Morgenthau, seen as the leading prosecutor in New York City and probably the most influential law enforcement figure in the state, is a longstanding opponent of capital punishment and has so far not sought execution in any case. Most of the other political groups involved in the debate, from the police union to Governor Pataki, are in favor of the death penalty.
The Governor, in particular, has been willing to intervene when he thinks a district attorney will not enforce the law. Soon after the death penalty was reinstated in 1995, District Attorney Robert T. Johnson of the Bronx announced that he would not seek the death penalty in any case. After he declined to seek capital punishment in the case of a murdered police officer, Governor Pataki ordered the State Attorney General to take over the case. Mr. Johnson sued, but the courts upheld the Governor's right to intervene.
Taking on Mr. Morgenthau would probably be a much more difficult task. For one thing, Mr. Morgenthau, who has been District Attorney for 23 years, has more political weight than Mr. Johnson. And the Manhattan District Attorney, while making his personal views known, has carefully avoided any sweeping pronouncements on the death penalty and has said he will abide by the law and consider each case on its own merits.
In fact, Mr. Morgenthau has established a capital offense committee, including some of his most senior prosecutors, to advise him on cases that could involve the death penalty. The six-member committee includes his first assistant, James M. Kindler; the trial chief, Nancy Ryan, and the office's top homicide prosecutor, Peter Casolaro. The committee members, who declined to speak about the case, have varying opinions on capital punishment, and an average experience of more than 20 years.
The committee has met repeatedly to evaluate the Schneiderman case and has visited the crime scene more than once. In making a recommendation, the members are expected to consider the facts and circumstances of the crime as well as any pertinent data about Mr. Schneiderman's background or his state of mind at the time. Whatever the recommendation, it will not be binding. The final decision will remain the District Attorney's.
One question will be whether Mr. Morgenthau, who is 78 and running unopposed for another four-year term, wants to cap his career by seeking a punishment that he has consistently opposed. He has declined to discuss specifics of this case but answered questions about the death penalty with an array of arguments about efficiency and public safety.
He produced a recent survey by Quinnipiac College showing that a majority of New Yorkers -- ranging from a slim majority in the suburbs to a strong one in the city -- oppose the death penalty. Crime statistics show that murder in Manhattan is now at the level of 1937, and since Mr. Morgenthau took office in 1975, the number of murders in Manhattan has fallen from 648, to 200 in 1996. Then there is the economic argument. According to Mr. Morgenthau, a 1993 Duke University study showed that it cost the state of North Carolina $2 million more to execute an inmate than to imprison one for life.
Writing in a 1995 article for the Op-Ed page of The New York Times, Mr. Morgenthau labeled the death penalty "a mirage that distracts society from more fruitful, less facile answers."
"It exacts a terrible price in dollars, lives and human decency," he wrote. "Rather than tamping down the flames of violence, it fuels them while draining millions of dollars from more promising efforts to restore safety to our lives."
Both Mr. Pataki and Mr. Giuliani have spoken with Mr. Morgenthau about the Schneiderman case. The Governor declined to talk about the conversation, except to say, "This is precisely the type of case for which the death penalty was passed."
The Governor said it was his duty to insure that the state's laws were upheld. He said that if Mr. Morgenthau makes a decision based on the particulars of the Schneiderman case and according to the guidelines of the law, he will have no cause to replace him in the case.
"My decision," Mr. Pataki said, "will be based on my belief as to whether or not his decision is made on professional as opposed to philosophical grounds. I have enormous confidence in the integrity of District Attorney Morgenthau. In the event he does seek a particular course of action in a case, he will be honest enough to truly state the reason."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 7, 1997, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the pending decision by the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, on whether to seek the death penalty in the killing of a police officer referred incorrectly to Mr. Morgenthau's re-election effort this year. He is not unopposed; Harry Kresky is running on the Independence Party line.

HEADLINE: A Taste for Catfish Lands a Bird in Trouble as Farmers Seek to Arm

BYLINE: By LES LINE 

 BODY:
HARDLY anybody loves the double-crested cormorant. Least of all fishermen, who since Colonial days have tended to view these large, greenish-black water birds with hostility in the belief that they consume tremendous quantities of commercial and game fish. Until the early 1960's, fishermen on the Great Lakes in Canada, with official acquiescence, destroyed cormorant colonies by killing the adult birds with shotguns and smashing their eggs.
The double-crested cormorant, also known as the crow-duck, is a protected species in the United States. But in a new twist to an old conflict, the fairly recent popularity of catfish on the American restaurant menu and dinner table has led to a proposal by the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service to allow fish farmers in 33 states to kill unlimited numbers of the birds. 
 The service is expected to make a decision on adopting the proposal later this year.
The soaring demand for catfish fillets has created a fish-farming boom in the South, where double-crested cormorants migrate in winter. In Mississippi alone, more than 100,000 acres of Delta land is dedicated to catfish production. These large, shallow ponds, crammed with up to 60,000 catfish an acre, are highly visible from the air and are magnets for fish-eating birds, especially cormorants.
Biologists say this catfish cornucopia has contributed significantly to a cormorant population explosion in recent years, which has in turn led to increased predation on fish stocks. Growers say they are losing millions of dollars' worth of catfish each year to the birds, and they demand relief.
"Nobody is in favor of massacring the birds," said Louie Thompson, who raises catfish fingerlings on 350 acres of ponds near Thornton, Miss. "But we want a little more latitude to protect our crops." Mr. Thornton, who is president of the Catfish Farmers of Mississippi, said that several thousand cormorants roosted in cypress trees on an oxbow of the Yazoo River near his farm. "We've been able to reduce our losses by harassing the roosts," he said, "but it's expensive to keep running them off all winter long."
Because the species is protected, catfish growers currently need permits from the Fish and Wildlife Service to shoot a limited number of cormorants -- a maximum of 50 a year in Mr. Thornton's case -- and they must report the number of birds killed. Those requirements would be lifted by the proposed order.
From 4,000 to 8,000 cormorants are shot every year by fish farmers in the South with no noticeable impact on the wintering population, said Dr. John Trapp, a biologist with the Migratory Bird Management Office of the Fish and Wildlife Service. He wrote in The Federal Register that the rule change "is expected to result in only a modest increase in the number of double-crested cormorants taken at aquaculture facilities."
Mr. Thornton agreed with that. "They're smart birds," he said. "They get wary of people and guns pretty quickly."
The highest take of cormorants under the relaxed rules, Dr. Trapp projected, would be around 92,000 birds a year, or 5 percent to 10 percent of the continental population. "This will be more than offset by the recruitment of young birds into the population," he said.
In a letter to the Fish and Wildlife Service, Jim Ekstrom, president of the National Aquaculture Association, said programs "at the farm level are inherently limited in their ability to control burgeoning cormorant populations." Mr. Ekstrom, who owns a striped bass farm in El Campo, Tex., said the agency also "must implement or supervise a program of roost dispersal and even the destruction of cormorant nests and eggs."
But conservation groups say the depredation order would set a dangerous precedent. It is intended, in large part, to ease an administrative and budgetary burden for the fish and wildlife agency, which keeps track of the permits and the number of birds killed, the groups say.
Kathleen Rogers, the wildlife counsel for the National Audubon Society in Washington, said: "We recognize there is a problem in five states, but to issue aquaculturists a blanket permit to kill as many cormorants as they want, everywhere but in 15 Western states, is a strange solution. The punishment doesn't fit the crime."
Ms. Rogers said the problem could be addressed by issuing local permits that were limited to months when cormorants were likely to cause abnormal economic losses to catfish growers.
The bird at the center of the dispute is the most common of six species of cormorants that breed in North America, and it is the only one found around inland freshwater lakes and rivers. Named for the tufts of white feathers that appear on its head in spring, the double-crested cormorant is typically seen perched on rocks or pilings with its wings spread to dry, or riding low in the water, with its head and neck exposed like a submarine's periscope.
In North America, the double-crested cormorant nests from the Pacific coast of southwest Alaska to the Atlantic coast of Newfoundland and south to the Gulf of Mexico, but 61 percent of the breeding population is concentrated in the northern prairie states and provinces, especially the large lakes of Manitoba, and along the Great Lakes. About 26 percent of the population breeds in Canada's Maritime Provinces and Maine. In fall, thousands of birds from this 1,860-mile-wide expanse of breeding range funnel into the heart of the catfish farming industry, at the confluence of the Arkansas and Mississippi Rivers.
Relentless persecution and the loss of natural wetlands to agriculture kept double-crested cormorant numbers low until laws protecting the birds were passed early in this century and the Federal Government went on a dam-building binge, creating huge lakes stocked with fish. The interior cormorant population began an eastward expansion through the Great Lakes in 1913 and reached the upper St. Lawrence River by 1945, only to be devastated by the effects of DDT and other toxic chemicals after World War II.
But in the 1970's, with DDT banned and the catfish industry expanding in the birds' wintering grounds, the number of cormorants exploded. The population on the Great Lakes alone increased 300-fold between 1973 and 1993, a period when the number of catfish farms in Mississippi, Alabama, Arkansas and Louisiana grew to 1,193. In 1982, there were 794 such farms. (In 1993, 496 million pounds of live catfish, worth $353 million, were delivered to processing plants.) Recent estimates of the total double-crested cormorant population in North America range from one million to two million birds.
An adult cormorant weighs about 4 pounds and will eat a pound of fish a day, but studies have repeatedly shown that in natural circumstances, the birds feed largely on small, noncommercial species like alewives. But a Mississippi Delta catfish farm with as many as 1,000 acres of ponds is a decidedly unnatural environment. The typical catfish pond is a 20-acre rectangle side by side with other ponds, and Dr. Trapp, of the Fish and Wildlife Service, wrote that "the practice of using large ponds developed in the 1970's, when cormorant numbers were low."
Because the ponds are large and close together, Dr. Trapp explained, it would be difficult to cover them with nets to keep out the birds.
Dr. Trapp said cormorants consumed an estimated 18 million to 20 million catfish, mostly fingerlings, on the Delta in winter, or about 4 percent of the total. But he emphasized that a number of factors influenced the level of cormorant predation, like the abundance of natural fish populations in the area.
"It is not uncommon for many fish farmers in a region to suffer little or no economic damage from cormorants, while a few farmers experience exceptionally high losses," he wrote.
Mr. Ekstrom, of the National Aquaculture Association, said the proposed order to allow the killing of cormorants by fish farmers -- as well as by growers of other food fish, bait fish and decorative species, like koi -- "is vital to our industry."
But conservationists contend that the proposed order would discourage fish farmers from investing in long-term solutions to the problem of bird predators. Ms. Rogers, of the National Audubon Society, said, "Farmers who are investing in new facilities should design ponds that can accommodate net structures, and the Fish and Wildlife Service should work with aquaculturists to develop non-lethal control methods."

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Schools as a Path to Political Power

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
Tonight we meet Donna Mengel, a school board member in a Philadelphia suburb, as she is denying charges that she made a remark about "Jews burning in hell." But "New School Order" is not essentially a report on anti-Semitism. Ms. Mengel turns out to be leading a campaign in the North Penn School District in Lansdale, Pa., to save money and shape the curriculum by scrapping plans to build a high school ("Kill that project!") and seeing to it that teachers concentrate on the basics instead of giving attention to sex education, art, music and the like.
The ominous title of this nine-month inquiry by Gini Reticker suggests that the Mengel forces represent an ideological movement that is establishing itself in communities around the land, with the Christian right asserting its values and flexing its muscle in public schools as a path to political power. 
 The hourlong program tells its story mainly through heated moments at school board meetings and interviews with pro-Mengel parents ("It's a war to protect our kids") and her beleaguered opponents. It's a rout. Abetted by conservative Christian churches, Ms. Mengel becomes president of the board. The high school principal leaves. The longtime personnel director resigns, charging that "mean-spirited and vindictive" board members have destroyed morale. Several thousand residents petition to secede from the district.
The restless camera (no narration) catches the high pitch of the controversy but leaves the details vague. The report is tantalizing enough to make you want to know more. Is North Penn an extreme case? Are similar battle lines -- political and economic conservatives allied against more liberally inclined elements -- being drawn so harshly in many other places? Is "New School Order," with its connotation of totalitarian movements past, just a scare phrase or a realistic glimpse of things to come? There's plenty here for further investigation.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 61 as Broader Indexes Set Records

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Declining interest rates on the bond market moved stocks higher yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining more than 60 points. And though other major stock market indexes had more modest point gains, those moves were enough to push those indexes to new closing highs.
Financial service companies like J. P. Morgan, Travelers Group, American Express, BankAmerica and Chase Manhattan, which tend to benefit from falling interest rates, posted strong gains. 
 Energy stocks also rose, even as crude oil prices retreated as concerns about tensions in the Persian Gulf eased. Exxon, Mobil and Chevron were among the sector's biggest gainers.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 61.64 points, or nearly eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 8,100.22. The Dow is now less than 160 points from the closing high it set on Aug. 6.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed at 972.69, up 7.66 points, setting a new closing high for the fourth consecutive trading session. The Nasdaq composite index also reached its fourth consecutive new high, adding 6.04 points, to 1,721.91.
As larger issues moved higher, the Russell index of 2,000 small-capitalization stocks also inched up 2.18 points, to 461.70, to set a closing high for the seventh consecutive session.
Yesterday, stocks took their cue from the bond market, where the yield on 30-year Treasury bond slid to 6.26 percent, from 6.28 percent on Friday. In addition, analysts said that after the release on Friday of the September employment report, the market had returned its focus to third-quarter corporate earnings.
As gauged by companies' expectations of earnings, the quarter is still on track to produce double-digit percentage gains in the S.& P. 500, said Charles Hill, director of research at First Call.
So far this quarter, about 64 percent of companies making such announcements have said that earnings could falter, Mr. Hill said. That level is in line with previous quarters, he added, but "we're pushing the envelope in being able to say 'business as usual.' "
After earlier waves of corporate warnings about warnings led to analysts' reducing their third-quarter forecasts, some strategists began to predict that earnings could actually come in stronger than expected.
Still, investors yesterday continued to punish companies that said their earnings might fail to meet expectations. Silicon Graphics, La Quinta Inns and Kulicke & Soffa all fell after reporting that earnings could weaken in the third quarter.
Silicon Graphics plunged 8 13/16 a share, to 18 1/16; it was the most actively traded issue on the New York Stock Exchange, with more than 16.7 million shares changing hands, and its 32.8 percent decline was by far the the biggest drop.
La Quinta tumbled 4 7/8, to 18 1/8, and Kulicke & Soffa, which makes equipment used to manufacture semiconductors, dropped 8 1/8, to 39.
"That just shows you that the market is fully priced," said Jim Benning, a vice president at BT Brokerage in New York. "Everything has to be exactly right. Any company that misses its expectations by even a small amount is going to get hurt."
Hank Herrmann, chief investment officer at Waddell & Reed, suggested that investors penalized Silicon Graphics, La Quinta and Kulick particularly because each company was in a sector that had been performing well. Thus, their problems were largely unexpected, he said.
"There wasn't a lot of suspicion that these were places to look for trouble," Mr. Herrmann said.
"If the market is fully valued, it tells you level, it does not tell you trend -- and the trend is higher," he added. "But because valuations are so poor, if you have an accident, then you are going to fall."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Up In Optimism On Economy

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Faced with reduced prospects of an interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve after a benign employment report on Friday, and with few economic reports due early this week, investors bought Treasury securities yesterday amid optimism that economic growth was slow enough to keep inflation at bay.
The 30-year bond gained 10/32, to a price of 101 19/32, with the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, at 6.26 percent, down from 6.28 percent on Friday and a 19-month low. 
 Last week, at the central bank's monetary policy meeting, Federal Reserve officials kept the Federal funds target rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans, unchanged at 5.50 percent. The employment report, like other recent economic data, hinted that growth had moderated, which has cheered bond market participants, whose investments are eroded by inflation.
The market's rise yesterday was also attributed to buying from overseas and by investors covering short positions -- that is, buying back borrowed securities to cover failed bets that the market would fall. For foreign buyers, the United States bond market remains the most attractive in the world.
Ken Logan, managing analyst at Technical Data of Boston, said the market was aided by the apparent calming of tensions in the Middle East, which let oil prices settle to levels that the bond market was more comfortable with.
Gerald A. Guild, senior vice president of the taxable fixed-income department at Advest Inc., said he, like other analysts, believed that bond yields were dropping because market participants were not concerned about inflation and because they also felt that the economy could not sustain its rapid rate of growth.
"Until now people have not accepted the notion that inflation is really under control and demanded an excessive premium" of more than four percentage points in the difference between inflation and bond yields, he said. Historically, he added, the premium has been three percentage points or less. That means there is considerable room for the yield on the 30-year bond to drop, even below its low of 5.79 percent in 1993.
Standard & Poor's MMS International, a market research and analysis firm in San Francisco, said that while professional Fed watchers remained split on when the next rate increase would come -- with six out of 21 surveyed on Friday now expecting a tightening in November and 11 of 21 expecting one in December -- "the market has voted even more clearly, pushing the chances of a tightening out to nine months."
Yesterday, in an address to the Rockland County Business Association in New York, the New York Federal Reserve Bank president, William J. McDonough, said the Fed's policy continued on the tight side, with a bias toward increasing rates.
Rates at yesterday's Treasury bill auction were in line with expectations, but with limited investor interest now that the three-month rate is below 5 percent. At auction yesterday, the three-month bill remained at 4.93 percent, unchanged from last week, while a six-month bill was sold at a rate of 5.01 percent, or about 7 basis points less than a week ago. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

HEADLINE: Silicon Graphics Expects A Loss, and Its Stock Dives

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Shares of Silicon Graphics lost a third of their value today after the company said it expected to report a loss for its first fiscal quarter.
The loss, which the company attributed to unexpectedly weak sales in the quarter ending on Sept. 30, came after a surprisingly strong fourth quarter, in which Silicon Graphics said it had successfully put product-transition issues behind it. 
 But the recent quarter was only the first time in two years that Silicon Graphics had met, let alone exceeded, Wall Street analysts' estimates, and for many investors today's announcement appeared to shatter whatever credibility the company retained. As of late last month, Silicon Graphics executives were still telling analysts that they would meet Wall Street expectations.
"They don't have a chief financial officer; they demonstrably do not have good internal controls or a coherent forecasting and planning process," said Doug van Dorsten of Hambrecht & Quist. "They are $120 million under my revenue forecast, and I was at the low end."
The disappointing sales were particularly hard to understand during an economic boom, when the company has a fresh product line and when its major rival, Sun Microsystems, has continued to report robust results. Some analysts say Silicon Graphics seems to be following the example of Apple Computer, staking out the high ground in technology even as prosaic but more aggressively managed competitors grab ever-greater shares of the market.
Silicon Graphics shares closed today at $18.0625, down $8.8125, on volume of 16.7 million shares on the the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts said its business model, which required both high profit margins and high growth, might no longer be sustainable. Although the company still offers the highest-performance work stations and servers, especially for niches like the graphics market, it is not addressing broader areas of high-growth potential, which are increasingly served by Sun and Hewlett-Packard.
The company said today that it expected to report revenue of approximately $760 million, compared with $765 million in the comparable period a year earlier. It expects a net loss of about 20 cents a share, excluding the effect of charges associated with the acquisition of Paragraph International. Silicon Graphics had a net loss of $22 million in its first fiscal quarter last year.
"We anticipated a seasonally weak September quarter, especially after record revenues in the June quarter," Edward R. McCracken, the chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. "But the results were significantly lower than our expectations."
Mr. McCracken said the sales of servers -- larger computers shared across networks, which had accounted for significant growth in recent periods -- were disappointing, especially in the United States.
"In hindsight, our strong June quarter, coupled with longer selling cycles associated with the enterprise business, affected demand in the September quarter to a greater extent than we anticipated," he said.
Best known for building the computers used to create special effects like the dinosaurs in "Jurassic Park" and its sequel, "The Lost World," Silicon Graphics supplies high-performance computers for such diverse purposes as oil exploration and aerospace. For a time, the market's appetite for Silicon Graphics' dazzling machines seemed insatiable, and the company maintained an annual growth rate exceeding 40 percent. But growth slowed in 1995, and quarter-to-quarter results have varied.
Although the company has been believed vulnerable to an onslaught from high-powered personal computers using the Intel Pentium processor and the Microsoft Windows NT operating system, analysts said such machines had so far had only a minor impact. The real competition is from other work station vendors, as Sun and Hewlett-Packard have progressed in overall system performance, and more specifically, in graphics applications.
New personal computer-based work stations from Compaq, Dell Computer and Gateway 2000 present a challenge at the low end of the market, but that has never been a major part of Silicon Graphics' sales.

HEADLINE: 10 Bosnian Croats Surrender to War Crimes Tribunal

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Oct. 6

 BODY:
After several months of intense negotiations between Washington and Croatia, 10 Bosnian Croats, including one of the most-wanted war crimes suspects in Bosnia, turned themselves in to the international tribunal in The Hague today.
The surrender of the group -- which included Dario Kordic, a powerful Bosnian Croat political leader accused of engineering an "ethnic cleansing" campaign -- was a major step in Croatia's effort to improve its standing with the United States. 
 Mr. Kordic was charged in 1995 with expelling and murdering scores of Muslims from the Lasva Valley in central Bosnia in 1993, virtually emptying the valley of its Muslim inhabitants. One of the best known massacres in the valley took place in the village of Ahmici in April of that year. Many Muslim families, including children, were said to have been burned alive in their homes in Ahmici. All 10 men taken into custody today were charged in connection with the Lasva incidents.
In Washington, the State Department's spokesman, James P. Rubin, said today that Croatia's cooperation signaled "a new determination" by President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia and Bosnian Croat leaders to comply with the Bosnia peace accords.
The pressure from Washington was applied to Croatia, which wields considerable influence over the ethnic Croatian portion of Bosnia, where many of the suspects were living openly. Mr. Kordic was living in an apartment owned by the Croatian Government, according to Croatian press reports.
While Mr. Rubin stopped short of promising that Washington would ease the pressure it put on Croatia when it blocked loans from the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, he said the cooperation would be taken into account when loans for Croatia were reconsidered.
Mr. Rubin and others also reiterated warnings to Bosnian Serb suspects and said the Croats' willingness to turn themselves in "is an example that other indictees would be well advised to follow."
United Nations and American officials who have investigated what happened four year ago in the valley created by the Lasva River say Mr. Kordic and the others who surrendered today set off a stream of murder and terror designed to wipe the area clean of anyone who was not a Croat.
At the time, Mr. Kordic was the head of the Bosnian annex of the nationalist Croatian party led by President Tudjman.
The Croatian nationalists said the Muslims and the few Serbs who lived in the Lasva Valley were enemies of the Croats and had to be removed so that Croats could live in peace.
In fact, the officials say, the attacks ordered by Mr. Kordic were intended to give Mr. Tudjman's political party control over a strategic part of Bosnia.
Today, most of the area remains substantially under the control of leaders who follow instructions from Mr. Tudjman's party. Few of the original residents who survived have been able to return.
Military forces said to have been under Mr. Kordic's authority reportedly went on a rampage of killing and pillaging in 14 villages and towns. They are accused of crimes against humanity for persecuting Muslims on religious, ethnic or political grounds.
The indictment charges that they murdered detainees, attacked undefended towns, murdered political leaders and professionals, and plundered homes and businesses.
The arrival of the suspects in the Netherlands today doubled the number of war-crimes suspects in the tribunal's custody, accounting for a large part of the indicted Bosnian Croats and Muslims. Only Belgrade and the Serbian leadership in Bosnia continue to ignore the international warrants.
According to Western diplomats, however, NATO commanders are considering a plan to arrest the two top Bosnian Serb suspects -- Radovan Karadzic, the former political leader, and Gen. Ratko Mladic, the former military leader -- but not until after the Bosnian Serb parliamentary elections on Nov. 23.
Robert Gelbard, the senior American envoy to the Balkans, vowed tonight in Belgrade that Dr. Karadzic would end up in The Hague.
"Until people such as Radovan Karadzic, Ratko Mladic, Veselin Sljivancanin and Milan Martic and others get to the Hague for justice and fair trials, we won't rest and others won't either," he told reporters.
Before the 10 suspects departed today, Mr. Kordic read a brief statement saying that Croats had been "subject to tremendous unjust pressure from the international community."
"We shall endure all this as we have endured everything so far, and return with our heads up high," Mr. Kordic told an emotional group of friends and supporters, many of whom were weeping openly.
The suspects, all dressed in dark suits, flew out of the Croatian city of Split this morning on a Dutch military transport plane.
When the men landed in the Netherlands around midday, they were escorted to the tribunal's detention center at Scheveningen, a suburb of The Hague, to join 10 other suspects in custody, including two Bosnian Croats, Gen. Tihomir Blaskic and Zlatko Aleksovski. General Blaskic, who was charged in the same incidents as Mr. Kordic, gave himself up to the tribunal in April 1996.
Shortly after the indictments, President Tudjman named General Blaskic to a senior post in the Croatian Army. Last December, while he was awaiting trial in the Hague, General Blaskic was awarded a medal by Mr. Tudjman.
Though about one hundred Bosnian Croat soldiers assigned to two elite units were directly involved in the terror campaign, there was only enough evidence to indict the 10 who surrendered today and General Blaskic, according to American officials.
The other nine suspects who surrendered today are Mario Cerkez, Drago Josipovic, Marinko Katava, Zoran and Mirjan Kupreskic, Dragan Papic, Vladimir and Ivan Santic, and Pero Skopljak, according to The Associated Press.
According to United Nations and American officials, the men who surrendered today could well offer important evidence against senior Croatian political leaders who are thought to have overseen not only the crimes in the Lasva Valley but also the strategy of terror for political ends in much of the rest of Bosnia.
The group that arrived today agreed to go to The Hague after receiving assurances that their cases would go to trial in three to five months.

HEADLINE: The Battle For Hearts And Tonsils;
Hospitals Specialize To Enhance Profits

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: EDINBURG, Tex.

 BODY:
As traditional hospitals with more offerings than Macy's decline, a new type is taking their place: the specialized hospital or clinic, designed to conquer a profitable niche.
Profit-making hospital chains are leading the way in opening category healers like heart hospitals, cancer centers and rehabilitation facilities. But many general hospitals, for profit or not, are also choosing to become more specialized. More alert than ever to where they are making and losing money, these hospitals are expanding and marketing their most profitable services. 
 Here in South Texas, Universal Health Services, the nation's third-largest hospital chain, bought Edinburg Hospital, an outdated general hospital, from the city three years ago. Universal Health built a new hospital, which opened on Aug. 1 with a traditional range of services but also a focus: delivering babies in a women's pavilion with its own wing and a colonnaded entrance as prominent as the main one. The company is meanwhile guiding the older building through its own recovery, as a specialized hospital for rehabilitation and long-term care.
At its McAllen Medical Center, however, 20 minutes to the south, Universal Health is competing against someone else's specialty hospital. Just down the street there lies the new McAllen Heart Hospital, with a revolving red heart mounted on the roof. By agreeing to share profits with doctors, it lured five McAllen Medical Center cardiologists. McAllen Medical rushed to expand its own heart program before its rival opened last year, advertising itself on television as a "state of the heart hospital for cardiac care."
Often, the huge number of patients the category healers handle leads to improved quality and lower costs. Salick Health Care's cancer centers at nine hospitals, soon to include St. Vincent's in New York, please health maintenance organizations with low costs and chemotherapy patients by staying open 24 hours a day, with valet parking always available. The Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, having opened a Center for Women's Health on the East Side of Manhattan three years ago, offering one-stop shopping for specialists, is considering another at the hospital's Washington Heights campus. And the Healthsouth Corporation's rehabilitation hospitals throughout the country boast of lowered costs and shortened stays.
"There's a transformation from a health care system organized primarily by the providers to a system organized by the needs of the patient," said Regina Herzlinger, a Harvard Business School expert on hospitals. "A hospital that does everything for everybody just won't be as efficient as a focused provider." In her new book, "Market-Driven Health Care" (Addison-Wesley), she cites McDonald's as an instructive example of "focused factories" that can deliver consistent products or services at lowest cost.
But having hospitals behave more like purveyors of french fries can have untoward consequences. Traditional hospitals accuse their new competitors of draining away the most profitable services, leaving more complicated or money-losing treatments to them. While the McAllen Heart Hospital's emergency room caters largely to cardiac cases, the McAllen Medical Center gets the car-crash and shooting victims.
Larger hospitals are finding it more difficult than ever to support costly services like emergency helicopters, neonatal intensive care and trauma centers for gunshot wounds. "If the services to generate positive income wind up getting taken out of institutions like this," asked Michael Israel, chief executive of Duke University Hospital, "how do you find the funds to provide the services society needs?"
When overburdened public hospitals in Los Angeles and Chicago had to limit the number of trauma patients brought in by ambulance, private hospitals reduced their services so they would not receive a costly deluge. Federal laws prohibit patient dumping, but hospitals are not obligated to handle accident victims whom they cannot capably treat.
Many hospital administrators acknowledge that specialized competitors have forced them to become more cost-conscious and focused themselves. Hospitals have improved enough to lift their profits or surpluses to 5.7 percent of revenues in 1995, according to the most recent figures. The gain was the highest since 1986. Many hospitals are also receiving higher payments from Medicaid to compensate those with large shares of uninsured patients.
Competition, stingier Government payments and the dictates of H.M.O.'s have closed more than 700 general hospitals in a decade, leaving 5,200 in 1995, according to the American Hospital Association. But in the same decade, the nation gained almost 100 rehabilitation hospitals, for a total of 171. A catch-all category of other specialty hospitals, including cancer and heart, rose to 110 in 1995 from 74 in 1989.
Many that remain general hospitals have still become more specialized. The chains try to buy clusters of hospitals in a region, then economize by parceling out specialties. Tenet Healthcare Inc., the nation's second-largest chain after Columbia/HCA Healthcare, has 12 hospitals in South Florida. It steers most heart surgery to just three, whose open-heart operations have risen one-third in four years. "You do not need," said Michael Focht, Tenet's president, "to have two open-heart programs within five miles."
Hospitals find surgery especially profitable. In heart and orthopedic surgery most of all, even routine procedures still pay well and require elaborate scans and tests. Delivering babies, unpopular until a few years ago because of the liability risks, has become a money-making activity because of high Medicaid reimbursement.
Medcath Inc., based in Charlotte, N.C., pronounces itself so pleased with its heart hospital in McAllen that it opened another one in Little Rock, Ark., last March, with others starting business in Tucson, Ariz., this month, Phoenix next spring, Austin, Tex., late next summer and then Bakersfield, Calif., and Dayton, Ohio.
In Texas, where managed care has taken hold only recently, Denton Cooley's Texas Heart Institute at St. Luke's Hospital is one of the busiest surgery centers in the nation, with 2,400 operations a year -- costing about 20 percent less than those offered by most competitors, with measurably better outcomes.
Among those newer to the game, the Heart Institute at Winthrop-University Hospital in Mineola, N.Y., more than tripled its open-heart surgery volume over five years. The Long Island hospital's publicity campaign includes mailing calendars to every household in its area, with more frequent bulletins to the elderly.
Healthsouth takes marketing much further in trying to endow its 135 rehabilitation hospitals and thousand or so clinics with a brand name as recognizable as Wal-Mart. Sports figures helping to publicize the brand include Michael Jordan, Tom Glavine and Emmitt Smith. Healthsouth has become especially profitable by figuring out how to offer rehabilitation for everything from sports injuries and birth defects to strokes and some surgery for much less than general hospitals can.
In trying to hang on to their more profitable departments, some hospitals are finding themselves defenseless against the new, specialized breed. From Houston's Methodist Hospital, the city's largest, a group of about 18 orthopedic surgeons left with dozens of nurses and aides two years ago for Columbia/HCA's new Texas Orthopedic Hospital nearby.
At Methodist, they had to compete for beds and operating rooms. At Texas Orthopedic, the 10 operating rooms, 46 hospital beds, 43 day-surgery recovery beds, physical therapy rooms and new doctors' offices are exclusively theirs.
" 'All the beds are mine?' the doctors said," according to Marsha Casey, a former Methodist executive. " 'Wow. I'm there.' "
Several of the doctors became hospital co-owners, sharing in the profits. Texas Orthopedic, handling only a limited range of injuries, can offer its services more profitably than less specialized hospitals. If a patient has a heart attack, she will be whisked to another hospital, maybe Methodist.
This summer, Columbia/HCA also announced plans to turn a former general hospital in Houston into a children's hospital, and the company is considering new children's hospitals elsewhere. The ability of such Columbia/HCA hospitals to attract and keep their staffs is likely to suffer, however, because of plans by the company's new management to avoid having doctors as investors.
To attract medical stars, hospitals can wind up bidding against each other, sometimes into the millions, threatening the cost savings that set them apart. The Salick cancer centers build new operations and offer much higher pay.
The company might soon face a very familiar rival. Earlier this year, Zeneca P.L.C., a British drug maker, bought control of Salick Health Care, forcing out Bernard Salick, the founder. Mr. Salick pondered his next move for all of a day, then formed a new company to open AIDS centers. He soon hired David Ho, the researcher who developed the drug "cocktail" now preferred in AIDS treatment. Mr. Salick plans his first AIDS center in New York, opening in perhaps a few months, with others in Los Angeles, Miami and San Francisco. He also plans to return to cancer care.
Salick Health Care, meanwhile, is trying to specialize even further by opening breast centers for detecting and treating breast cancer and other ailments. The first breast center opened in Manhattan on East 61st Street between York and First Avenues earlier this year. With construction set to begin on its first cancer center in New York, at St. Vincent's, by the end of the year, Salick Health Care hopes to have four or five more hospital sites around the area.
But not every specialty pays off, making some niche programs just as vulnerable as many mainstream operations.
On the East Side of Manhattan, Lenox Hill Hospital closed its New York Pain Treatment Program in February. While the program never had a loss, said Norman J. Marcus, the program's director, it was not as profitable as areas like orthopedic and heart surgery, in which Lenox Hill is expanding.
The pain program will survive only as a much smaller, independent entity with 5 doctors instead of the former 30.
In a prepared statement, Terence M. O'Brien, Lenox Hill's chief operating officer, said that the hospital evaluates programs based first on its patients' needs. But, he added, "Our programs must also prove to be economically viable and consistent with our strategic plans and mission."
Dr. Marcus put it differently. "You want to do things," he said, "that bring in the greatest amount of money in the shortest period."
