HEADLINE: Pentagon Chief Says Iran Gas Deal Won't Hurt Ties With France

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen said today that whatever action the United States took in response to a French oil company's decision to invest $2 billion in Iran would not undermine close relations between the United States and France.
The statement followed several hours of talks here between Mr. Cohen and the French Defense Minister, Alain Richard. The United States has objected to the privatel French oil company Total S.A.'s decision to put $2 billion into exploitation of an Iranian natural gas field, with Russian and Malaysian partners. 
 "We believe that transaction will substantially enhance Iran's ability to acquire the revenues necessary to acquire missile technology and weapons of mass destruction," Mr. Cohen said today. "What action will flow from that remains to be determined, but we intend to maintain a close relationship with a very good ally."
"We both want to see Iran end state-sponsored terrorism and end its efforts to acquire missile technology and weapons of mass destruction," he added.
Mr. Richard said that all 15 European Union countries had withdrawn their ambassadors from Teheran after a German court finding that Iranian leaders had ordered the killing of three Iranian Kurdish dissidents in a Berlin cafe in 1992.
"When there is a terrorist action that is proven, we will draw the consequences," Mr. Richard said. He declined to say whether France agreed with American assessments that Iran was trying to acquire the technology to build nuclear weapons, and missiles to carry them, from Russian and other experts.
Mr. Richard said the French Government had told officials of Total that there was no reason, in international or French law, for them not to go ahead with the investment in Iran. An American law, the Iran-Libya Sanctions Act authorizes the Clinton Administration to impose sanctions against American subsidiaries of any company that invests more than $20 million in Iran.
American officials said in recent days that they are still assessing the Total transaction and have yet to decide whether the Clinton Administration will impose sanctions.
"The United States has not decided what action to take, but will enforce the law," Mr. Cohen said. Later, he added: "I understand the position the French have taken. It is my hope that Minister Richard understands the position the United States Government has taken."
Unlike Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, who said last week that he personally "rejoiced" in Total's decision, Mr. Richard also appeared determined to play down rather than highlight differences between Washington and Paris over the step.
"We stand very vigilant over Iran," he said. "We observe with interest the ongoing changes in Iranian domestic politics, with the hope that they will someday yield resolve to build a more peaceful relationship with neighboring states."

U.S. Experts Dispatched

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Clinton Administration is sending legal experts to Malaysia, Russia and France to investigate whether the Iran deal violates United States law.
The United States wants to make sure that any sanctions it might impose against the companies involved in the deal will stand up to a court challenge, the State Department spokesman, James Rubin, said today. He said legal scrutiny of the contracts could take some time.

HEADLINE: Banks Take On Credit Unions Over the Limits of Membership

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Two fierce competitors for the consumer banking dollar banks and credit unions -- battled before the Supreme Court on its opening day today in arguments over the validity of a Federal regulation that has permitted credit unions to expand far beyond their traditional base among employees of a single company or members of a single occupation.
The question in the case is the proper interpretation of a 1934 law, the Federal Credit Union Act, which brought credit unions under Federal regulation and required them to limit their membership to "groups having a common bond of occupation or association" or to groups within a particular community. 
 For 48 years, the Federal regulators read that language as requiring that credit union members share a single "common bond," typically a common employer. In 1982, however, the National Credit Union Administration reversed course and issued a new interpretation, under which a credit union could include unrelated groups, as long as each group was defined by its own common bond.
The agency wanted to expand the membership base, and thus preserve the viability, of small credit unions suffering from the collapse of small businesses during the recession of the early 1980's. The impact of the new interpretation was dramatic. Credit unions, which are nonprofit, tax-exempt cooperatives financed by shares bought by their members, expanded in all directions.
Today, 3,600 of the 7,000 federally chartered credit unions have members from multiple occupational groups, including many of the biggest credit unions, with 32 million members and 79 percent of all credit union deposits. Credit unions now offer most of the services offered by banks, from checking accounts to home mortgages, often at a lower cost because of the credit unions' tax-sheltered status and reliance on volunteer labor.
Last year, the American Bankers Association and a group of North Carolina banks convinced the Federal appeals court here that the 1982 interpretation was invalid. The bankers challenged the expanded charter of the AT&T Family Credit Union, in Winston-Salem, N.C., which was opened in 1952 to serve employees of the Western Electric Company. It now has 300 separate employee groups, including employees of a Coca-Cola bottler and the Duke Power Company. The appeals court said that "common bond" in the 1934 law meant a single common bond. Still unresolved, and not part of the case now before the Supreme Court, is whether multiple-group credit unions will have to divest themselves of their new members -- some 158,000 employee groups -- if the Justices uphold the appeals court.
Arguing the Government's appeal today, Seth P. Waxman, the acting Solicitor General, told the Court that the 1934 law was, at the least, ambiguous in its reference to "groups having a common bond." Mr. Waxman said there was "no way to tell from the statute" whether credit unions were limited to a single group or whether they could serve multiple groups, each with its own common bond.
Mr. Waxman's emphasis on ambiguity was at the heart of the Government's defense of the 1982 regulation. Under the Court's precedents, administrative interpretations of ambiguous Federal laws are entitled to deference from the courts as long as those interpretations are reasonable.
Michael S. Helfer, arguing for the banks, said the statute was not ambiguous.
"There has to be one common bond per credit union," Mr. Helfer said, adding that Congress would not have written a limiting definition at all if it meant that credit unions could expand infinitely by adding additional groups.
The Court actually spent little time today on the merits of the case, National Credit Union Administration v. First National Bank & Trust Co., No. 96-843. Most of the hourlong argument was spent on whether the banks were the appropriate parties to challenge a regulation that was not addressed to them.
The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit ruled in 1996 that the banks were "suitable challengers" because their interests were at stake as competitors of credit unions.
Mr. Waxman urged the Justices to find that the bankers lacked the standing to challenge the regulation because, despite their interests as competitors, the banks did not fall within the "zone of interests" addressed by the statute. He said that when Congress included the common bond provision in the credit union act, its intent was not to shield banks from competition but to strengthen the fledgling credit unions by making sure that members had a connection with one another.
Mr. Helfer, arguing for the banks, urged the Justices to take into account that "legislation is almost never passed with one purpose" but usually has multiple purposes.
Although arguments over standing tend to be obscure, the question of competitors' ability to challenge regulations that affect their economic interests is a basic and surprisingly unsettled issue in administrative law.
Whatever decision the Court makes in this case, the competition between banks and credit unions is likely to shift to Congress. A bill already introduced in Congress would enact the 1982 regulation into law. If the Court rules against the credit unions, the unions and their members will push for this legislation, and the banks can be expected to oppose it.

HEADLINE: A Warm Climate Prevails as Experts Study Ecological Problems

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
President Clinton today convened a daylong conference on climate change that produced a series of optimistic discussions about harnessing technology, ingenuity and the entrepreneurial spirit to save the planet from global warming.
Mr. Clinton peppered experts with questions and ruminated aloud on how to prod the most energy-intensive economy in the world to break its addiction to fossil fuels, and how to negotiate a treaty by the end of the year that will bind the rest of the world to do the same. Vice President Al Gore and Cabinet members were on hand, and the balcony at Georgetown University was packed with appreciative students from Mr. Clinton's alma mater. 
 There was almost no talk of energy taxes, heavy-handed regulations or other unpopular measures to make swift, deep reductions in the use of energy and the emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases that trap heat in the atmosphere and threaten widespread ecological damage in the next century.
Instead, Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena held up solar roofing tiles and said they are on the verge of economic feasibility. Mary Good, an investor who is a former Administration official, spoke of the potential to grow algae and convert it into clean fuel. And Tom Casten, president of Trigen Energy Corporation, said that the deregulation of the utility industry would help double the efficiency of electricity plants.
E. Linn Draper, president of American Electric Power, a major utility company, said Americans would be more likely to invest in energy conservation if the Administration would create a system of pollution-permits trading to encourage cost-effective reductions in emissions.
Fred Krupp, executive director of the Environmental Defense Fund, an advocacy group that favors market-based incentives to reduce pollution, said that greenhouse gas emissions could be brought below 1990 levels by 2005. The Administration has been leaning toward establishing a less-ambitious target, with emissions leveling off at 1990 levels by 2010.
Only at the end of the day, after Mr. Clinton left, did a panel of economists inject a somewhat more dismal tone to the proceedings, warning that it would not be painless to cut energy use so deeply.
"As I listen to all this, I am concerned that we are greatly underestimating the size and complexity of the undertaking," said William Nordhaus, a professor of economics at Yale University. "We are not going to introduce these wondrous technologies unless we increase the cost of energy."
Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers, one of Mr. Clinton's economic advisers who has been counseling caution as the Administration debates its negotiating position, was more sanguine in public. "The question is not whether we can respond effectively to this threat," he said. "We can and I believe we must."
Mr. Clinton encouraged the attendees to accentuate the positive as they discussed what is described as a serious global problem.
But Mr. Clinton seemingly recognizes that there is no easy solution to the steady growth of greenhouse gas emissions.
Groping for alternative policies that would encourage consumers to buy energy-saving products, he mentioned four alternatives: raising the price of energy, lowering the price of new technologies, creating market-based incentives for people to invest in saving fuel, or increasing the public's awareness of the problem.

HEADLINE: Women at Helm of New Hampshire Politics

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: CONCORD, N.H.

 BODY:
Walk down the long, silent halls of the New Hampshire State House, and self-important looking old men with names like Styles Bridges, Huntley N. Spaulding and Henry Quinby peer down at you from their oil portraits in musty complacency.
But enter the offices of the most powerful politicians in New Hampshire today, and suddenly, that old world is turned most resoundingly on its head. 
 For this granite-faced state is fast becoming the closest thing the country has to a political matriarchy, run by the first tandem in American history of a female Governor and a female Speaker of the House. The deputy speaker is a woman to boot, and 31 percent of the seats in the Legislature are filled by women.
Even though politicians here shy away from sex stereotypes, they say that the style in the 178-year-old State House has become decidedly Venusian of late, with a new emphasis on listening, inclusion and compromise emanating from the Governor's office. That could be why things are running so well, they say, because by the usual political measures, they should be a mess.
Gov. Jeanne Shaheen, whose auburn hair and virtuous demeanor call to mind the revamped torch-raising lady of Columbia Pictures, is a Democrat. The Legislature is two-thirds Republican. And Donna Sytek, a House Speaker known to unstintingly speak her mind, disagrees deeply with Mrs. Shaheen on issues like abortion and taxes.
But although there have been wrangles, they have been civil ones, both sides say. In her first nine months in office, Mrs. Shaheen has managed to get enough done, from new public money for kindergartens to a generally acclaimed budget, to earn the highest approval rating of any politician in the state. She won with 57 percent of the vote, and recent polls show that she is more popular now than she was then.
"I believe in consensus building," Mrs. Shaheen, the first woman to be the Governor of New Hampshire, said in an interview. "I think women tend to view decision-making in that way. So that's certainly been a focus for me.
"I think most people would agree I'm less confrontational than some of my predecessors have been," she said.
Some of her predecessors would go even further than that.
"The fact is, Jeanne Shaheen has had a much easier time than I did," said former Gov. Stephen Merrill, the popular tax-cutting Republican whose place she won after he chose not to run again.
"She says, 'I'm the Governor, they're the Legislature; we're working together for your best interest,' " he said. "When I was Governor, I said, 'I'm Steve Merrill, I fight these people every day for you.' "
Of course, some, including Mrs. Shaheen herself, point out that with lawmakers so stacked against her by party affiliation, she had better find ways to get along with them or she is sunk. But she also firmly believes, she said, that "no one party has a lock on the best answers."
Anita Perez Ferguson, president of the National Women's Political Caucus in Washington, said that Mrs. Shaheen's style and substance largely conformed to what national studies have reported about women in political power: that they tended to focus on "service" issues, like health care and education, and that budgets in those areas tended to grow when they were in power. When women rule, she said, "communication and dialogue become less combative."
At this point, Mrs. Shaheen is doing so well that she is almost universally expected to be re-elected next year, though former United States Senator Gordon J. Humphrey and several others are expected to run against her. New Hampshire, which chooses its Governor every two years, has never denied a second term to a sitting Governor who wanted it.
But politicians and analysts caution that her success does not necessarily reflect any deep change in the traditional Republican domination of New Hampshire. Nor, they say, has New Hampshire's new status as the state where women have unusual power occasioned much eyebrow-raising among its crusty Yankees.
New Hampshire's House of Representatives, with 400 members who each get a measly $100 a year, has long been a training ground for women in politics, they note. Governor Shaheen herself served three terms in the 24-member State Senate.
When those close to her or opposed to her explain the Jeanne Shaheen phenomenon, they tend to focus on her personal qualities, her diligence and natural political talent, and her disciplined ability to fashion a well-defined set of messages and then remain "on message" through thick and thin.
"She is the most disciplined campaigner I've ever seen," Mrs. Sytek said. "I've never seen a politician stay on message as she did."
Furthermore, averred Mrs. Shaheen's irrepressible husband, Bill, an entrepreneur and lawyer who quit his district judgeship to help her campaign, "There's not a dishonest bone in her body."
"Honesty goes a long way with people here," he said. His wife is so honest that, at 50, she doesn't even dye her hair, he said, adding that it has not gone gray because he is the one who does all the worrying.
When she was running, Mrs. Shaheen focused on four and only four main issues. She stressed education, and she has since moved the state toward providing public kindergarten for all children and overseen a 40 percent increase in investment in local-level education. She called for lower electricity rates, which she has been fighting intensely to achieve through deregulation.
She also called for broader access to health care, which she has pursued, and good jobs for all. (She cannot take credit for it, but the New Hampshire economy is going at such full tilt now that unemployment is at 2.7 percent and employers tell tales of bringing in homeless people and training them, less out of altruism than pure desperation.) She also took "the pledge" that New Hampshire voters traditionally require, to impose no broad-based new taxes.
By the time she ran for Governor, Mrs. Shaheen was already a consummate political strategist who had learned from campaigns she had managed for others. As she and her husband reared their three daughters in the last 20-odd years, they also became some of the most accomplished Democratic political operatives in the state.
Mr. Shaheen -- who is called Billy, as his wife is called Jeannie -- helped lead Jimmy Carter's come-from-behind New Hampshire campaign in the 1976 season, and Mrs. Shaheen performed similar magic for Gary Hart in the state in 1984.
Last fall, as the Republican candidates savaged one another during primary season, Mrs. Shaheen serenely ran a textbook campaign.
"Here she is surrounding herself in loveliness, and our guys are killing each other," Mrs. Sytek recalled ruefully. "We had a whole summer of Jeannie in pale blue, Jeannie in green, Jeannie in pink. It worked."
In recent months, Mrs. Shaheen's conciliatory style and legislative know-how have continued to work. There have been fights over issues like how big a tobacco tax there should be, but no blow-ups, all agree.
"We're both practical politicians, both much more interested in getting to the goal than in who did what," Mrs. Sytek said. "We're both more interested in governing than grandstanding."
Mrs. Sytek disparages some of Mrs. Shaheen's work, commenting that she seemed to have set up more task forces and study committees than the last four governors combined and that her budget had been so well received because she "kidnapped" the Legislature's best budget analyst and avoided any major moves.
"She ruled out any ambitious new initiatives and stuck to her knitting," Mrs. Sytek said. But she nonetheless called their relations "cordial, productive and constructive."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Federal Express to Buy Trucker for $2.4 Billion
Federal Express plans to buy Caliber System, a trucking company, for about $2.4 billion in stock, in an effort to snatch more business from the strike-weakened United Parcel Service.
The deal enables Federal Express to match U.P.S. in offering a wide range of delivery options, from its trademark air express to Caliber's local-package traffic. Page D6. 

Loss Warning Hits Silicon Graphics
The shares of Silicon Graphics lost a third of their value after the company said it expected to report a loss for its first fiscal quarter because of unexpectedly weak sales. D8.
 
Big California Bank Deal
H. F. Ahmanson sought to strengthen its West Coast banking operations with a $901 million stock deal for Coast Federal Savings. The purchase will make Ahmanson, parent of Home Savings of America, the third-largest bank in California. D7.
 
Lucent Chief To Step Aside
Lucent Technologies said that Henry B. Schacht, left, who guided its spinoff from AT&T, had ceded his post as chief executive to Richard A. McGinn, Lucent's president. D2.
 
Bond Rally Helps Stocks Advance
Subdued fears of inflation and diminished tensions in the Middle East helped strengthen the bond market, pushing the yield on the 30-year Treasury to the lowest level since February 1996. D19.
 
Stocks rose on the tonic of lower interest rates in the bond market. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 61.64 points, to 8,100.22. D10.
 
The Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Board Options Exchange began trading futures and options on the Dow average. Market Place. D10.
 
Motorola Up, but It Issues Warning
Motorola's quarterly earnings rose 29 percent, helped by sales of wireless phones and chips. But profit from paging fell and the company warned of slower sales growth. D9.
 
Higher Offer for Worms of France
The Agnelli family of Italy and Assurances Generales of France bid $5.4 billion for Worms, the French sugar, paper and insurance company, topping an earlier offer from the investor Francois Pinault. D23.
 
Talk of Settlement Lifts Digital
The shares of Digital Equipment soared after a report that the company was in negotiations to sell its troubled Alpha chip line to settle a patent infringement suit against Intel. D5.
 
Generous Payment at Occidental
Occidental Petroleum will pay its chairman, Ray R. Irani, $95 million to buy out his old contract and replace it with a new agreement that ties his compensation more directly to performance. But compensation experts said the one-time payment itself was extraordinarily munificent. D5.
 
Competing for the Banking Dollar
Banks and credit unions battled before the Supreme Court in arguments over the validity of a Federal regulation that has permitted credit unions to expand far beyond their traditional bases. A23.
 
GTE Sues Over On-Line Listings
GTE filed an antitrust suit accusing the five regional Bell companies, as well as two Internet companies, Netscape and Yahoo, of conspiring to limit competition in the market for on-line yellow pages. D10.
 
Smart Cards for the Smart Set
A test of so-called chip cards, plastic-and-silicon substitutes for coins and small bills, was started on the stylish Upper West Side of Manhattan by Citibank, Chase Manhattan, Visa and Mastercard. B1.

HEADLINE: Sex Complaint Surfaces Against Whitman Official

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Just after Christine Todd Whitman became Governor of New Jersey in 1994, a woman accused one of her Cabinet choices of making unwanted sexual advances. After an investigation by the Attorney General substantiated the complaint, the Governor kept the man, Gualberto Medina, in office and sent a reprimand to his file.
The complaint is described by confidential state documents obtained by The New York Times from a person who has worked for Democratic officials. The incident began when a woman who was then a reporter for The Philadelphia Business Journal tried to interview Mr. Medina, who had been selected as Commissioner of Commerce and Economic Development. Mr. Medina, a lawyer and accountant, made "inappropriate, offensive physical and verbal sexual advances" to her, according to the documents signed by the Attorney General. 
 With Mr. Medina's swearing-in ceremony two weeks away, Mrs. Whitman took swift action to settle the matter, and kept it from becoming public.
Mr. Medina was ordered to seek counseling and was given a written reprimand, which was signed by Mrs. Whitman and placed in a confidential file in the State Division of Criminal Justice. The reporter, Diane Mastrull, was informed of the Governor's action and was assured in a letter from the Attorney General at the time, Deborah T. Poritz, that if Mr. Medina's improper conduct recurred, "swift and appropriate action" would follow. Mr. Medina was sworn into office on March 30, 1994.
Becky Taylor, the Governor's communications chief, said that the documents about the complaint are "legitimate." She said that the Governor had tried to keep the matter confidential to protect the reporter. "My impression is she does not want any publicity," Ms. Taylor said.
Mr. Medina, who was out of the country on state business today, released a statement, but refused a request for a telephone interview. "I recognize my behavior was perceived as being offensive," his statement said. "In retrospect, I realize I exercised poor judgment. The matter was resolved to the satisfaction of all parties without a formal complaint being filed."
Ms. Mastrull now works for The Philadelphia Inquirer and was out of town on assignment today. She did not respond to phone messages left for her asking for comment. Her former editor at The Philadelphia Business Journal, Jack Roberts, who was aware of the situation, said that she continued to cover the State Commerce Department until she left the publication about a year ago. He refused to discuss the specifics of the complaint against Mr. Medina. "This was a personnel matter involving confidentiality matters with my reporter," he said.
The revelation of the complaint against Mr. Medina and the effort by the Governor's office to keep it from becoming public come as Mrs. Whitman is facing a re-election challenge from James E. McGreevey, a Democratic State Senator and the Mayor of Woodbridge Township.
The issue of sexual harassment has become troublesome for the Whitman administration. In recent weeks, Democrats have criticized the Governor for spending $175,000 to settle a case brought by a state employee who said that she was sexually harassed by the state Republican Party Chairman, Chuck Haytaian, when Mr. Haytaian was the Speaker of the State Assembly. Democrats have suggested that Mr. Haytaian, who is heavily involved in Mrs. Whitman's re-election campaign, should have to the pay the settlement costs and legal fees back to the state.
Mrs. Whitman has defended the state's handling of the Haytaian matter, saying that it is the state's responsibility to defend its employees in such situations. Mr. Haytaian has vehemently denied that he harassed his accuser, Beth Herbert, an administrative assistant at the State House, but in July the state agreed to the settlement.
Noting the timing of the story -- four weeks before the Nov. 4 election -- Ms. Taylor expressed concern that the Medina case would help Governor Whitman's critics. "This is obviously the silly season, and clearly somebody is out to really hurt the Governor," she said. "If you have to write something like this, is there any way you can hold it until after the election?"
The Whitman administration's effort to resolve the Medina matter is detailed in letters written to the woman, and to her lawyer. In one letter, dated March 14, 1994, Ms. Poritz concedes that "our investigation substantiated your allegations."
Ms. Poritz, who is now Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court, assured the woman that in addition to the written reprimand, the Governor and her chief counsel at the time, Peter G. Verniero, would meet with Mr. Medina "to discuss his conduct." Also, she wrote, "Commissioner Medina will participate in counseling as directed by me."
Ms. Taylor said that the Governor had decided to go forward with Mr. Medina's appointment despite the complaint because the woman had specified that she was not seeking his dismissal. Also, Ms. Taylor said, no tax dollars were used to settle the matter, but Mr. Medina "paid a small amount" to cover the woman's legal fees.

HEADLINE: Clinton Vetoes 38 Military Items, Drawing Many Lawmakers' Ire

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
President Clinton used his new line-item-veto power today to pinpoint and strike from a vast military construction law more than three dozen projects across the country, angering home-district lawmakers who had won Congress's support for them as essential to the national defense.
Interfering in the time-honored ritual of pork-barrel budget politics for the second time this year, Mr. Clinton deleted a total of 38 spending provisions worth $287 million. The projects affected were as varied as a new aerial gunnery range at Fort Drum, N.Y., and a new Air Force paint shop in Texas. 
 "The old rules have, in fact, changed," Mr. Clinton said before exercising the veto in front of reporters in the Oval Office. "The use of the line item veto here will insure that we focus on those projects that will best secure our strength in the years to come."
While vetoing some new projects, Mr. Clinton left intact 107 others, worth more than $500 million, that Congress had added to the Administration's request in passing the Military Construction Appropriations Act, signed into law by the President six days ago.
And he made no deletions among $36 million worth of extra projects in Mississippi, home of Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, or among extra projects in Alaska, home of Ted Stevens, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee.
The President said that in trimming the $9.2 billion that Congress had decided to spend, he was guided by Pentagon priorities and service personnel's needs, not politics.
"The projects I have canceled are all over the country, in the districts of lawmakers of both parties," he said. "These are tough calls involving real money and hard choices."
Of the projects canceled, 25 were in Republican Congressional districts, only 13 in Democratic districts. But White House aides argued that some of the affected Republican districts abutted those of Democrats, who had also wanted the projects, or were in states represented by at least one Democratic senator.
Congress can now pass legislation to restore the projects that the President vetoed today. But if he vetoed them again, it would take two-thirds votes of both houses to override him.
It was the Republicans who supplied Mr. Clinton his extraordinary new veto power, by which the President may reject individual items of spending or tax legislation within one week of signing the legislation into law. The line item veto was unsuccessfully sought by Presidents for more than a century before the Republicans included it in their 1994 Contract With America and then enacted it in 1996. Although a court challenge to the line item veto's constitutionality is widely expected, no suit has been filed since Mr. Clinton first exercised the power in August.
While his own state was spared, Senator Stevens, of Alaska, attacked the President's action. He said that during the budget negotiations earlier this year, Congressional Republicans and Mr. Clinton agreed to almost all the provisions that the President struck today.
"This was an arbitrary political decision to make the President look good," Mr. Stevens said of the veto. "This is not what the line item veto was intended for. These are not pork projects, these are things the military wanted and needed."
He noted that even with the Congressional additions, the total military construction bill amounted to $600 million less than last year's.
Like other Republicans, however, Mr. Stevens said he continued to support the line item veto.
Mr. Clinton and his aides were careful to emphasize today that they did not consider the vetoed projects to be worthless pork. Indeed, Mr. Clinton said there was simply disagreement over which military needs were immediate.
"Many of the projects I have chosen to cancel have merit," he said, "but should be considered in the future."
Mr. Clinton said he had used three criteria in evaluating each project. He said he was vetoing those that "were not requested by the military, cannot make a contribution to our national defense in the coming year and will not immediately benefit the quality of life and well-being of our men and women in uniform."
Mr. Clinton's aides argued that beyond its immediate savings, his use of the line item veto would deter excessive spending down the road.
"If you want to have real fiscal discipline for the future, the President and members of Congress have to be willing to make those tough choices and live by them," said Gene Sperling, the chairman of the National Economic Council.
Mr. Sperling predicted that lawmakers would ultimately understand that Mr. Clinton was seeking to instill fiscal discipline, and would not punish him by torpedoing his legislative agenda. At present, for instance, Mr. Clinton is locked in a tough fight to win enhanced authority to negotiate international trade deals.
Not every Republican criticized the President's decisions, and at least one, Senator John McCain of Arizona, applauded them.
"After careful review," Mr. McCain said in a statement, "I believe the President's list of items on which to use the line item veto is fair and balanced."
Nor were all Democrats pleased.
Mr. Clinton struck a $5.2 million Army National Guard support center in South Dakota, the home state of his ally Tom Daschle, the Senate minority leader. Mr. Daschle told The Associated Press that he did not object to the President's criteria, but added: "That doesn't mean I'll accept the consequences in the long term. Ultimately, I believe in this project."
Others who saw projects killed in their districts or states used words like "outrageous" to describe the President's action.
"The problem with this Administration's defense policy is that there is no long-range military strategy," said Representative John M. McHugh, Republican of New York, whose district was to have received a new aerial gunnery range at Fort Drum.
And Representative John Hostettler, Republican of Indiana, said, "It's unfortunate that the President has put politics above the health and safety of our men and women in uniform, especially with regard to my project."
Mr. Hostettler was referring to a $4.1 million item for a chemical and biological warfare detection center at the Crane Naval Surface Warfare Center in his district.
But like Mr. McHugh, Mr. Hostettler said he still believed he had been right to vote last year for adoption of a line item veto.
"I still think in the hands of a person of integrity, this would be a good process," he said. "So hopefully someday we'll have someone like that."
Some other Congressmen noted that vetoed projects in their districts were in the military's long-term plans, even if the Pentagon had not requested money for this year. Therefore, they said, their disputes with the White House may prove to be merely a disagreement over timing.
Representative John J. LaFalce, Democrat of New York, saw a $2.1 million construction project at the Niagara Falls Air Reserve Station, in his district, canceled today. He said in a statement that "the project is part of the Air Force's five-year budget plan, and I will therefore continue to push for its funding."
Mr. LaFalce added that he considered the line item veto's constitutionality to be "dubious at best."
"I would not be surprised if there is a successful court challenge to the line item veto," he said.
But Franklin D. Raines, director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, suggested that a court challenge based on today's vetoes was unlikely, since they generally affected military bases.
Because no private individuals have an interest in such bases, Mr. Raines said, "for most of these projects it would be difficult" for any plaintiffs "to establish that they had a personal interest in the outcome of the President's decision."

 BODY:

NEWS
Fictional Fame for Wahoo
 Business has been booming in Wahoo, Neb., since the late-night talk show host David Letterman decided last year to move his fictional home office from Grand Rapids, Mich., to the town of about 4,000 people. "We actually have tourists now," said Helen Sloup. She manages her son Bob's downtown surplus store, which sells T-shirts imprinted with a caricature of Mr. Letterman with a big cigar and toothy smile along with Letterman bumper stickers. Sales have been in the thousands. A must-see site is the official home office: A phone booth on the corner of Fifth and Broadway. The town's Economic Development Director, Jane Daufeldt, said the Mayor recently sent Mr. Letterman an invitation to visit. The star can travel by limousine or John Deere combine.

Out of the Past 
 He wrote under names like Antosha and Man Without Spleen. But his real name was Anton Chekhov, and the November issue of Harper's Magazine will feature nine so-called lost stories by the Russian playwright and novelist that have never been published in English. The stories were unearthed by Peter Constantine, a poet, multilingual translator and Chekhov expert while poring over yellowed volumes of late-19th-century Russian literary journals, where he recognized the bylines as Chekhov pen names. All nine stories were written when the author was in his early 20's. The November issue of the magazine goes on sale on Oct. 21.
 
Day of Laurels
The winner of the 1997 Nobel Prize in Literature is to be announced early tomorrow in Stockholm. A Foreign Ministry spokeswoman said the recipient of the prize of about $1 million would be named at the ornate headquarters of the Swedish Academy, which selects the annual winner. Last year's winner was the Polish poet Wislawa Szymborska.
 
Bright History
Greece's Culture Ministry announced yesterday that 12 ancient landmarks would be lighted at night beginning next year. Only the Acropolis is now illuminated. It will be joined by sites like the temple of the oracles at Delphi and the monastery of Daphne in Athens. The Olympic Academy, on the site where the games were held in ancient times, will also be illuminated. The night lighting, to be installed by the spring, is part of an attempt by the Culture Ministry to safeguard and enhance historic sites.
 
Yen for Entertainment
Miramax Films says its release "Shall We Dance?" has become the highest-grossing Japanese film in United States box office history. With $7.333 million it has surpassed the $7.318 million for "Ran," Akira Kurosawa's version of "King Lear," which was released in 1985, when ticket prices were lower.
 
From Page to Screen
Andrew Morton's book based on interviews of Diana, the late Princess of Wales, is to be turned into a major film about the breakdown of her marriage to Prince Charles. Martin Poll Films said it had acquired motion picture rights to "Diana: Her True Story" and would search Britain for an actress to play the Princess.
 
INSIDE
Forbidden Delights
Bootleg disks vex record companies, but bootleggers make an important cultural contribution. Critic's Notebook, page 2.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Mark Is Up Amid Doubt About Italy's Joining the Euro

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar touched a three-month intraday low against the mark yesterday, reflecting demand for the German currency amid signs that Italy's budget crisis threatens Italian participation in the euro.
Traders said the euro, the European common currency set to be introduced in January 1999, would be stronger if Italy did not participate. Signs that the euro will be strong have tended to strengthen the mark. 
 The dollar recouped some losses, though it still ended down against the mark. The late dollar rally also helped awaken what had been quiet trading against the yen, giving the dollar a lift in that market.
A struggle in Italy's Parliament over the 1998 budget has led to speculation that Prime Minister Romano Prodi could resign and has left Italy's participation in the common currency in doubt, traders said.
"If Italy's not in the euro, it produces a strong euro," said Jeremy Fand, foreign exchange strategist at the Bank of Boston.
After the dollar dropped to 1.7443 marks, the weakest since late June, it rebounded to settle late in New York at 1.7571 marks, down from 1.7583 late Monday. The dollar cost 122.56 yen, up from 122.00. The British pound cost $1.6176, up from $1.6155.
Traders said the turmoil could keep Italy from meeting economic criteria for joining the euro. That brightened the outlook for the euro, as some European governments have feared that Italy might not control its spending after joining, thus undermining the integrity of the shared currency.
Later in the day, the dollar erased much of its declines because of bargain-hunting and worries about escalating tension in the Middle East, a situation that usually strengthens demand for dollars. The Pentagon said yesterday that Iraqi aircraft were violating the "no fly" zone in Iraq.
A rally by the mark against the yen also bolstered the dollar against the yen, said Alan Kabbani, senior trader at First Union National Bank.
Earlier in Asian dealings, the Malaysian ringgit rallied for the first time in three days and the Indonesian rupiah gained for the first time in 10 days after central banks of both countries intervened to buy the currencies and halt their steep declines.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Sun Sues Microsoft In Dispute Over Java
Sun Microsystems accused Microsoft of trying to steal its Java computer software language in a lawsuit that illustrates the struggle between the two computer industry giants over which will control the standards used by hundreds of thousands of programmers.
The suit seeks unspecified damages and a court order that would stop Microsoft from shipping its Internet Explorer 4.0 browser, which contains a version of Java. Microsoft rejected Sun's accusations. Page D4. 

Gains Continue for Stocks
The stock market, buttressed by favorable earnings reports and falling interest rates, rose again, sending most of the major stock indexes to record highs. Though the Dow Jones industrial average was the exception, falling short of its all-time high by 81 points, it did rise by 78.09, to 8,178.31. D12.
 
The rally in Treasuries continued, too, sending the yield on the 30-year bond down to 6.23 percent from 6.26. D10.
 
To Treasury investors, a long bond means 30 years. And in the corporate market? Try 1,000 years. At least, that is the maturity of a new issue sold by a subsidiary of Republic National Bank. Floyd Norris: Market Place. D12.
 
Less Passion For Plastic
Consumer borrowing rose at an unexpectedly slow pace in August, the Fed reported, further evidence that the economy is not growing at an inflationary speed. D8.
 
Loss Is Bigger Than Estimated
Advanced Micro Devices, struggling to compete with Intel, reported a bigger loss than expected, even after a recent warning by the company that it would take a financial hit. D4.
 
Executive Turmoil at Dresdner Bank
A top official of Dresdner Bank resigned from the company's board of managers after having admitted to evading income taxes. The announcement came only a few weeks after both the chief executive and the chairman of the German bank's supervisory board announced their own resignations. D4.
 
Amgen Hepatitis C Drug Approved
Amgen said that it had received F.D.A. approval to market Infergen, a new drug for treating chronic hepatitis C, a viral infection of the liver. D2.
 
F.D.A. Overhaul Bill Advances
The House passed an F.D.A. modernization bill that would allow faster approval of new medicines for AIDS, cancer and other diseases and would make it easier for doctors to prescribe experimental drugs. A16.
 
$800 Million Bank Deal
The North Fork Bancorporation agreed to buy New York Bancorp, parent of the Home Federal Savings Bank, for $800 million in stock to expand its business on Long Island and in Brooklyn. D12.
 
A Nafta Fight Without the U.S.
While the United States and Canada have generated the big money, and the United States and Mexico the big political battles, the third connection of the North American Free Trade Agreement -- Canada and Mexico -- has gone generally unnoticed. Until a recent series of squabbles began, that is. A1.
 
From Skyscrapers to Ivory Towers
"F.I.A.S.C.O.: Blood in the Water on Wall Street" is the title of a lively new account of the shark tank at the foot of Manhattan, by Frank Partnoy, a former derivatives salesman who now professes to make a happier living as an assistant law professor. Has he been to any faculty meetings yet? D2.
 
Debate Over Sale of Helium Reserve
President Clinton has signed a bill to sell off the nation's helium reserve -- one of the most ridiculed of Federal programs -- to private industry, which has long contended that it can supply helium more cheaply to agencies like NASA. But in a vivid demonstration that cutting the Federal budget is rarely as easy as it seems, some experts are now saying that maybe the helium reserve was not such a dumb idea after all. A12.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Aid Plea By Indonesia Appears Near

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Struggling to defend its beleaguered currency, Indonesia appears on the verge of asking the International Monetary Fund for financial help, American officials and Asian diplomats said today.
If Indonesia requests aid from the I.M.F, it will become the third country in Southeast Asia, after Thailand and the Philippines, to declare that its financial troubles have forced it to seek some kind of rescue package. But the final decision to seek such help, officials say, will hinge on a decision by President Suharto, the longest-serving national leader in Asia, whose family is deeply involved in many of Indonesia's biggest ventures. 
 "It is a complicated issue, and I don't think it is certain that Suharto has made a decision yet," an American official said today.
Part of the complication is that Indonesia's financial condition is far better than Thailand's was this summer, when the I.M.F. put together an emergency package of loans to stabilize that nation's suddenly teetering economy. While Thailand depleted its foreign-currency reserves in a last-ditch effort to prop up its currency, the baht, Indonesia still holds foreign reserves of about $27 billion.
Over the next few months, however, the Indonesian Government and Indonesian companies must repay tens of billions in dollar-denominated, short-term debt, and the recent currency devaluations have left companies scrambling to find dollars to make those payments.
One of the mysteries surrounding Indonesia's currency crisis is a basic question no one seems able to answer convincingly: Why is it happening now?
This summer, when Thailand was still reeling and its currency's value was falling, there were widespread fears that Indonesia would suffer from "contagion effect" -- the situation when a currency crisis in one country spills over into others. That threatened to happen in 1995 when Mexico suffered its devastating peso crisis, but an American-led bailout stopped the problems from spreading.
The Thai situation, though, more or less stabilized six weeks ago. That led to a widespread assumption that there would be little contagion. The assumption proved wrong; the Indonesian rupiah has lost roughly 35 percent of its value since Jan. 1, most of that in the last few weeks.
"This could just be the work of speculators looking for another target," another American official said recently. In that case, he added, the I.M.F.'s entry might be largely symbolic, intended to send a message to the markets that Indonesia had the resources to prevent a further fall. But in return for any loans, Indonesia may have to agree to terms set by the I.M.F. -- and the fund's major underwriter, the United States -- and this could prove politically difficult.
Mr. Suharto, for example, has protected Government-backed projects -- including an effort to build a national car -- in which members of his family are big investors. Dumping some of those projects might become a condition of any loan.
Other austerity measures could spark domestic unrest, which has become an increasing problem throughout Indonesia. Last weekend, President Suharto warned that the Indonesian military might soon be called upon to put down further protests.
National bailouts are becoming more common these days, and at the I.M.F. and the World Bank there are teams of experts monitoring Indonesia's financial health on a daily basis, officials at the two institutions say.
"Both institutions are, of course, working with the Government very closely," said an official who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "But at this point, there is no package on the table yet."
While Indonesia runs a current account deficit, it is of a manageable scale, the officials said. Last year, that deficit was 3.5 percent of Indonesia's economic output, less than half the size of Thailand's. Moreover, Indonesia continues to benefit from strong export growth, running about 9 percent a year, while Thailand's exports were flat.
Should the crisis continue and force the Indonesian Government to raise interest rates to help halt the currency slide, it could expose weaknesses in the country's banking and financial systems, officials said. But they also said that unlike Thailand, where financial institutions were overexposed to risky real estate ventures, Indonesia's banks seemed relatively stable.
"In a way, the situation is very puzzling because there are no concrete new facts to justify the market's behavior," said an official who is tracking the situation for an international aid agency. "It does seem that the amplitudes of the exchange-rate movements are exaggerated by the thinness of the market."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Just in time for the millennium: an issue of 1,000-year bonds.

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
WILL Republic National Bank still be around in 2997?
It appears that bond investors are confident it will. Lehman Brothers said yesterday that it was offering $250 million in 1,000-year bonds for Safra Republic Holdings S.A., a European subsidiary of the New York bank holding company. A Lehman official said the offering was going well, but was not yet sold out. 
 The bonds were sold with a coupon of 7.125 percent, and priced to yield about 92- to 94-hundredths of a percentage point more than 30-year Treasuries now yield, or about 7.21 percent.
If all goes well for bondholders, they will get that amount of interest each year for the next 1,000 years, and then will get their money back. Given that no currency in the world has yet endured for 1,000 years, it is not easy to estimate what a dollar will then be worth.
There is no guarantee that the bonds will stay outstanding for anything like that long. The bonds can be bought back by Republic at any time, Lehman said, but that call provision is a relatively harsh one, with Republic having to buy back the bonds at a price that would give the investors a yield of 25 basis points -- or hundredths of a percentage point -- more than the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond at the time of the call.
In essence, Republic sold a security that will be viewed by investors as similar to a preferred stock, which has no stated maturity date. And it is likely that banking regulators will view the bonds as equivalent to preferred stock when assessing the company's capital structure.
But Republic will be able to deduct the interest payments it makes from its taxable income, as it can deduct any interest payments. Dividend payments on preferred stock are not deductible.
The Clinton Administration, worried about a number of 100-year bond issues by corporations, proposed last year that interest not be deductible on bonds with a final maturity of more than 40 years after issuance. But Congress rejected the proposal. Still, many lawyers believe the Treasury would reject deductions by an American company on bonds with a maturity of more than 100 years.
Republic, the American company, has only a minority interest in the European subsidiary, which is based in Luxembourg. And it believes that under Luxembourg law the interest payments will be deductible.
The fact that the bonds did not sell out on the first day shows that investors needed some persuading, as they did a few years ago when 100-year bonds returned for the first time since the late 19th century. Those old 100-year bonds were sold primarily by railroads, with investors taking comfort in the fact they were sold in "gold dollars," which guaranteed that investors would be compensated if the dollar was devalued relative to gold.
Alas, that promise was outlawed by Congress in the 1930's, an act that was upheld by the Supreme Court on a 5-to-4 vote, and those 100-year bonds proved to be exceedingly poor investments, as interest rates rose well above the low rates at which they were issued.
In the late 1970's and early 1980's, owners of 30-year Treasury bonds suffered big losses if they sold their bonds, because rapidly rising interest rates had driven down the value of existing bonds. Those bonds carried the assurance that investors would get their money out, in nominal dollars, in three decades, a fact that helped to hold down the losses. These bonds will take 100 decades to mature, and thus would be expected to perform even worse if rates did soar.
It is obvious that no buyer of 1,000-year bonds will be around at maturity, and institutions that buy bonds tend to assume that they will be able to sell the bonds in time if it appears that interest rates are soaring, as would be likely to happen if inflation were to recur. At the moment, inflation is quiet, and few expect it to revive in the near future.
In the early 1980's, investors would have laughed at the idea of such bonds. Now, the fact that such bonds can be issued is yet another indication of how little worry there is that inflation could ever come back.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Drift Higher in Light Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities drifted higher yesterday in light trading, with yields still at their lowest levels since early last year. Investors remain cautiously optimistic that the economy is not expanding at a pace fast enough to heat inflation.
The 30-year bond rose 12/32, to a price of 101 31/32, with the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, at 6.23 percent, down from 6.26 percent on Monday. 
 Traders said price gains were muted by several factors. Among them, corporate borrowers, who compete with Treasury securities for investor cash, are lining up this week to sell about $6 billion of debt in the public market as borrowing rates have come down recently.
Corporate debt issues offer higher returns, but also higher risk, than Treasury securities, and securities firms managing corporate bond sales often sell Treasury securities from their portfolios to protect themselves against losses if rates rise before the issue is sold. After the deal is done, they go back to buy Treasury securities.
Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of the fixed-income department at J. W. Charles Securities in Boca Raton, Fla., said there was some central bank buying, which helped lift prices. But primarily, he added, investors were growing comfortable with bond prices after the recent gains, particularly with no interest-rate increase by the Fed expected in the near future.
"In my opinion, what we're seeing is an affirmation to the new price levels in the market," he said.
"Further gains, however, may be difficult without more proof that the economy is slowing," he said. "It takes a while to get over the sticker shock, and the new trading range."
Mr. Pugliese said he did not expect Friday's report of the Producer Price Index for September to be a problem for the market, because producer price data have been benign for months.
With trading in Treasuries subdued, activity in the corporate market caught many investors' attention, particularly a novel security issued by Safra Republic Holdings S.A., an affiliate of the Republic New York Corporation. The banking company, run by Edmond J. Safra, sold $250 million in 1,000-year bonds to Lehman Brothers, which will try to sell them to investors with an interest-bearing coupon of 7.125 percent.
But Jack Ablin, executive vice president and head of the fixed-income department for Barnett Capital Advisors, called the 1,000-year bond a "misplaced security."
"It's really an equity-like security in the bond layer of the capital structure," he said. "I don't think it will appeal to bond investors here, necessarily, because of its perpetual maturity. However, European buyers are more likely to buy a perpetual instrument."
Today, the Treasury plans to sell $8 billion of inflation-indexed five-year notes, by reopening an issue it first sold in July. With few signs of inflation in the economy, there is a chance that demand for the securities, which compensate for inflation during the life of the notes, will be limited.

HEADLINE: How Hot Is Hot?

BYLINE: By Bill McKibben; Bill McKibben is the author of the forthcoming "Maybe One: A Personal and Environmental Argument for Single-Child Families."

DATELINE: JOHNSBURG, N.Y.

 BODY:
History can be made in subtle ways, almost without anyone noticing. This happened on Monday at President Clinton's conference on global warming. The meeting was intended to build national support for some effort to reduce carbon dioxide output in the United States, a pep rally before our team heads off in December to Kyoto, Japan, for the negotiations on a treaty regulating global emissions of greenhouse gases.
But behind that cheerleading, Mr. Clinton seemed to move the goalposts of the climate game in dangerous ways. Here's how the scoreboard changed: 
 Before the Industrial Revolution, the world's air contained about 275 parts per million of carbon dioxide, the main heat-trapping gas. By now we've burned enough fossil fuel to reach 365 parts per million. We can already see the effects: higher temperatures, increased rainfall and glacial melting.
But when scientists warned about the really scary probabilities -- coastal flooding, widespread drought and so on -- they always said these would happen if we didn't keep carbon dioxide from doubling, to 550 parts per million. That level was what all the greenhouse fuss was about.
By Monday's gathering, however, holding carbon dioxide to a "mere" doubling seemed to have become our unofficial national goal. On one chart that the President's advisers kept returning to, the path of doubled carbon dioxide showed up as "the green line" in the graph's center -- implying that holding emissions to this level had become the new target. The line of greatest danger had shifted to 700 parts per million. In other words, the President seems to be resigned to the fate scientists once feared.
It's not that the scientists have decided that a world with doubled carbon dioxide will be more benign than they thought. In fact, their predictions have grown more frightening.
But holding atmospheric concentrations below a doubling would require swifter action than the President seems to back. It could still be done. Computer models show that strong global action by 2005 could stabilize the carbon dioxide level below 450 parts per million, which is still quite high but not as dangerous. But Administration economists predict such action might harm the economy as much as the oil shocks of the 1970's.
Forced to choose between the chance of a recession in the next few years and the near certainty of drastic environmental change 50 years away, Mr. Clinton seems ready to side with the economists. Politics may leave him no choice. But it's a tragic change. He will no doubt claim to be choosing the middle path, but until the last few weeks that was the very route we were pledged to avoid.

HEADLINE: Borrowing Pace Slowed During August

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Borrowing by United States consumers increased at a slower-than-expected pace in August, further evidence that the economy is cooling, Federal Reserve figures showed.
Consumer credit rose by $4.3 billion for the month, to $1.229 trillion, after rising a revised $6.0 billion during July, the Fed said in a report released today. 
 Previously, the Fed said July borrowing increased $6.5 billion. Before today's report, analysts had forecast an increase of $4.6 billion in August.
Analysts watch the Fed's credit statistics because it helps them gauge changes in consumer spending, which accounts for a majority of overall economic activity.
The Fed's subdued reading could signal households are paring back on purchases and growing more cautious with their finances. It also could reflect efforts by banks to toughen lending standards after a record one million personal bankruptcy filings last year.
Today's report follows Labor Department statistics Friday that showed job growth -- a major influence on consumer spending -- slowed in September from earlier in the year. Also pointing to a more subdued economy, domestic auto sales dropped 3.8 percent in September from a year earlier.
Still, a slowdown in consumer credit growth might not be entirely caused by restrained spending or tougher lenders. Many consumers have turned to lower-interest, tax-advantaged home equity loans, which are secured by real estate holdings and are not included in the Fed's credit statistics, to refinance other debts.
Despite the evidence of a slowdown, Alice Rivlin, the Fed vice chairwoman, today gave a optimistic assessment of the economy.
"We really are having a period of good news," Ms. Rivlin told a regional conference on the Community Reinvestment Act sponsored by the Fed's Cleveland branch. "We have an economy which seems to be growing as fast as it can without generating inflation."
The Fed report showed credit was expanding at a 4.2 percent annual rate during August, down from the 5.9 percent pace of borrowing in July.
By category in August, revolving loans, which include credit cards, increased $3.0 billion; auto loans fell $600 million, the first decline since March, and other types of installment loans increased $1.8 billion, following two months of declines.

HEADLINE: Whitman Is Criticized For Handling Of Complaint

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
A group of Democratic legislators, all of them women, criticized Gov. Christine Todd Whitman today for her handling of a 1994 sexual harassment complaint against her Commissioner of Commerce and Economic Development, Gualberto Medina.
In a letter to the Governor, the legislators asked for "full disclosure" of the details of the sexual harassment complaint, which was filed shortly after Mr. Medina was confirmed in January 1994 as Commerce Commissioner. 
 At the time, the Governor's office substantiated the complaint that Mr. Medina made "inappropriate, offensive physical and verbal sexual advances" to a female reporter. But Mrs. Whitman chose to keep Mr. Medina in office, filing a formal, though confidential, reprimand against him and ordering him to seek counseling.
"Your administration's handling of this incident and related matters sends a strong signal to all women employees that their legitimate grievances about sexual harassment will not be fairly addressed," said the letter, which was signed by State Senator Wynona Lipman and Assemblywomen Barbara Buono and Loretta Weinberg. All three of the women are playing leading roles in the campaign of James E. McGreevey, the Democratic candidate for governor.
With just one month to go before the Nov. 4 election, Mrs. Whitman, a Republican, has found herself in the unusual position of being an incumbent woman defending her administration and her party on the issue of sexual harassment. Democrats have also criticized Mrs. Whitman in recent weeks for spending $175,000 in state funds to settle a sexual harassment lawsuit against another top Republican official, Chuck Haytaian, the former speaker of the State Assembly.
In the Medina case, there was no lawsuit filed, and according to the Governor's office, no taxpayer money was spent on the settlement.
Mrs. Whitman today defended her handling of the sexual harassment complaint against Mr. Medina, and urged her Democratic opponents to move the focus of the campaign on to "the real issues."
She also raised questions about the disclosure of the sexual harassment case. It was first reported today in The New York Times after confidential documents about the case were provided by a person who has worked for Democratic officials. "It is now clear that the Democrats will do anything to distract voters from their failed record of job killing and high taxes," Mrs. Whitman said. "The fact that this story was driven by a person identified as having worked for Democratic politicians speaks volumes about its motives."
Mrs. Whitman defended her administration's handling of the matter, saying she was following state guidelines while trying to protect the identity of the woman who filed the complaint. She said that even though Mr. Medina's official swearing-in did not take place until March 30, 1994 -- after she had learned of the complaint against him -- he was already serving as Commissioner, and therefore the state's guidelines on investigating sexual harassment complaints had to be followed.
She said that documents describing the complaint and the reprimand were placed in confidential files in accordance with the state's procedure for protecting victims in such matters. "The tragedy is that in the report that appeared today that woman's name was made public," Mrs. Whitman said.
The woman, Diane Mastrull, who at the time of the incident was a reporter for The Philadelphia Business Journal, is now a reporter at The Philadelphia Inquirer. She is out of town, and has not returned telephone messages seeking comment. Mr. Medina, who is in Puerto Rico on business, has refused requests for interviews. He did issue a statement on Monday, saying, "I realize I exercised poor judgment."
On March 14, 1994, after the incident occurred, the Governor's Attorney General at the time, Deborah T. Poritz, wrote to Ms. Mastrull and explained several steps that were being taken to discipline Mr. Medina. "These steps are being taken to insure that this unacceptable conduct by the Commissioner does not recur," Ms. Poritz wrote. "It is our understanding that you are comfortable with these steps and that you do not feel that termination of the Commissioner's Office is appropriate or necessary."
Mr. McGreevey did not attend any public events today, but his spokesman, Richard McGrath, seized the opportunity to criticize the Governor's handling of sexual harassment complaints. "This latest revelation of sexual harassment by high officials in the Whitman administration displays a disturbing trend," he said.

HEADLINE: Cuba's Communists Likely to Hold Line

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Revolutionary banners and slogans are posted everywhere, and some 1,800 delegates have already arrived in the capital. After months of preparation that have emphasized ideological discipline and "socialist values" over change, Cuba's Communist Party begins its first congress in six years on Wednesday.
The three-day meeting, sandwiched around the 30th anniversary of the death of the Communist icon Che Guevara, is expected to ratify some changes in the composition of the 225-member Central Committee and the smaller Politburo, the subjects of perhaps the most curiosity to ordinary Cubans and to foreign diplomats and academic specialists. 
 But all indications are that the party intends to hold the line on vital and vexing political and economic issues.
"Everything suggests that the leadership does not want this congress to examine fundamental policies," said Jorge Dominguez, a professor of government at Harvard University who is an expert on Cuban politics. "That does not necessarily mean that nothing of substance will occur, but I am expecting more of a cheerleading effort than a serious discussion."
But at a news conference here today, Esteban Lazo Cardenas, a member of the Politburo and party First Secretary for the capital, argued otherwise, saying, "This is going to be a historic congress, not just because of the moment, but because of what is going to be discussed." He added, though, that "there can be no change of principles."
The tone for the congress, which is closed to the foreign press, has been set by an eight-page platform, made public this spring, that reaffirms Cuba's commitment to a one-party state, saying that "the party is in a better position today than ever to perfect its role as society's guide."
It also calls on Cubans to "strengthen our unity and will to resist" the United States, which it says seeks to "liquidate the Cuban nation and enslave its people."
"In Cuba, there will be no return to capitalism, because the Revolution will never be vanquished," the document says. "The nation will continue alive and will continue to be socialist."
The last party congress was held in October 1991, a time of severe economic dislocation and ideological uncertainty, coming as it did as the Soviet Union was collapsing. Then, more than half of the Central Committee was replaced, with many pre-revolutionary Communists and former guerrilla combatants giving way to younger, less proven people.
Since then, President Fidel Castro has grudgingly allowed the creation of a parallel dollar-based economy and opened Cuba to foreign investment and tourism, initiatives that would have been ideologically unacceptable in the past, to keep the economy afloat. The congress is expected to ratify those changes, but to proceed with great caution regarding further advances.
The Chinese Communist Party, during its own just-concluded party congress, moved decisively to reduce the role of the state in the economy and force government enterprises to stand or fall on their own. At a news conference here Monday, Jose Luis Rodriguez, Minister of the Economy, made clear that no such reforms were in the offing for Cuba.
"Ours continues to be a socialist model, in the sense that the state is not only responsible for the general welfare, but has a leading role" in the economy, Mr. Rodriguez said. Though there is a limited place for private initiative and enterprise, he added, Cuba does not view them as "an essential element to the development of our country."
Like the 770,000 members of the party, ordinary Cubans will also be looking to the conclave for clues as to who will be leading them in the next five years. No changes are expected at the very top, of course: Mr. Castro will remain in charge of both the party and the Government, with his younger brother Raul as his designated successor.
But Mr. Castro, who is 71, has appeared thinner and pallid in public in recent months. As a result, popular interest in who might be groomed for future responsibilities has intensified.
Many diplomats and academic specialists are predicting an enhanced role for Vice President Carlos Lage, who is regarded as a pragmatist.

HEADLINE: G.O.P., Eye on '98, Builds Education Plank

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Stealing a technique from President Clinton, Speaker Newt Gingrich was using an inner-city school as a backdrop to promote proposals with which Republicans hope to cut into the Democratic advantage on the vote-rich education issue.
In the cheerful yellow library of Hine Junior High School here, Mr. Gingrich posed with teen-age girls and members of the House Republican leadership, then highlighted a series of education bills making their way to the House floor. 
 "We're here today to say we believe the real learning occurs in the local community," he said, his setting a school that has shed its reputation as Horrible Hine to become an education success story. "It's the local students, the local teachers, the local parents."
Mr. Gingrich's appearance at the school, on Monday, was a vivid display of how the Republicans have had to readjust their strategy since the days when their education policy amounted to little more than calling for the abolition of the Department of Education.
When Mr. Clinton, campaigning for re-election last year, suddenly unveiled an array of education initiatives ranging from his support for uniforms in the public schools to his proposal for tax credits for college tuition, the Republicans initially scoffed. But here was Mr. Gingrich promoting an education agenda that the Republicans could call their own, and staging precisely the kind of photo opportunity that Mr. Clinton has made a staple.
"The bind Republicans put themselves in for a while was with the rhetoric 'Let's close the Department of Education,' " said Ed Goeas, a Republican consultant. "If you lead with that, it closes large segments of the public off from thinking you care about education."
That perception is a particular problem for Republicans looking toward the 1998 Congressional elections. Polls show that education is becoming a leading public concern as other issues recede with the continuation of economic prosperity and the end of the cold war. And Frank Luntz, a Republican pollster, recently warned his party in an advice manual that in education, "politically and rhetorically Democrats have left us in the dust."
In his State of the Union Message in February, Mr. Clinton called education "my No. 1 priority for the next four years" and proposed a 10-point plan that included plugging classrooms into the Internet, adopting national tests to measure children's performance in reading and math, and increasing Federal assistance to college students.
Riding this agenda during the negotiations that led to the balanced-budget agreement this year, Congressional Democrats portrayed themselves as the defenders of education programs. And every few days they stage another education event, whether it is the showcasing of computers for the classroom or announcement of a drive to create a Federal construction fund for decrepit public schools.
Congressional Republicans are now countering with proposals of their own.
To some extent, their program involves political repackaging. At the heart of their agenda are several proposals for school tuition vouchers, long advanced by Republicans as a way to allow students to opt out of public schools and create competition that would force bad schools to improve. The idea is also thought to have appeal among swing Roman Catholic voters who pay to send their children to parochial schools.
In addition, Senator Slade Gorton, Republican of Washington, has tacked on to a spending bill a measure that would turn Federal education aid into block grants free of regulation by the Education Department.
And Congress is expected to vote later this month on another bill, sponsored by Senator Paul Coverdell, Republican of Georgia, that would allow parents to establish special savings accounts that they could use to pay expenses -- as varied as private school tuition and computer purchases -- related to their children's elementary and secondary education. Under the bill, a family could put as much as $2,000 a year into this special account, and all interest would accumulate tax-free.
But it is vouchers that remain the centerpiece of the Republican program. And with some strategists warning that the party could leave itself vulnerable if it appeared to be favoring private schools at the expense of public schools, the Republicans are also putting forth in the next few weeks spending measures that would benefit public-school children. One, for example, would provide grants for reading teachers, and for parents to buy tutorial assistance, a counterpoint to a Clinton proposal to train students in the national service program to act as reading tutors.
Still, the terms of next year's campaign debate over education are already becoming clear, and to a large extent they involve vouchers. Mr. Clinton has accused "some in Congress" of working to "diminish our country's commitment to public education by siphoning badly needed funds away from our public schools into a voucher program that would support private academies" with a "very limited number of students."
Mr. Gingrich has countered with an echo of the old attacks on limousine liberals.
"I think anybody who is going to vote no should send their child to the worst school in their state," the Speaker said. "Don't tell us you have the right to move to the suburbs, you have the right to move to a very small town with a good school system, you have the right to send your child to a private school, but by the way, if you're poor and in public housing, you have no hope."
Although Senator Daniel R. Coats, Republican of Indiana, failed last week in trying to attach a $7 million tuition voucher program for the District of Columbia to a District spending bill, he fell only two votes short of the 60 needed to break a Democratic filibuster. That was a high-water mark for the years-long effort. Republican leaders are vowing to keep the program alive in the House, and it may be passed there later this week.
But the most interesting test for the Republican program may be whether Mr. Coverdell's proposal for education savings accounts can get the extra two votes needed to get past a Democratic filibuster. In July, Mr. Clinton issued a last-minute threat to veto the entire balanced-budget agreement unless the provision was removed. The President's aides say the Coverdell measure is a cousin of tuition vouchers, because the tax revenue lost by the Government might wind up paying for private school tuition.
Mr. Coverdell counters by saying that although parents could use the money in the savings accounts to pay private school tuition, in most cases they would simply supplement their children's public school education, by buying computers or paying for tutors. "If 9 out of 10 students are in public schools today," the Senator said, "then I guess I would assume that 9 out of 10 savings accounts are going to be in support of a public-school child."
Such debates are expected to grow in intensity as Congress pushes to end the session in November. The White House has issued a string of education-related veto threats on spending bills, hoping to fend off voucher programs and push adoption of Mr. Clinton's plan to give school districts standardized tests on fourth-grade reading and eighth-grade math.
