HEADLINE: New TV Ad For Rowland Shows Voters His Soft Side

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Oct. 7

 BODY:
After cultivating a reputation as a conservative Republican who slashed welfare benefits, pushed for a broader death penalty and took on state employee unions, Gov. John G. Rowland today began an effort to highlight his softer side: he cares about children.
More than a year before the gubernatorial election, Mr. Rowland has started to broadcast a television commercial that Democrats are calling the first ad of his campaign. In the 30-second spot, he is shown playing with Legos with youngsters in a nursery school setting and touting his plan to provide health insurance to 90,000 poor children. 
 "To me, there's nothing more important than our children," Mr. Rowland says in the commercial. A subtitle flashes on the screen urging viewers, "Help Our Kids: Support the Husky Plan," a reference to Mr. Rowland's proposal to provide subsidized health insurance to children who are not eligible for Medicaid.
The advertisement started running a day after Mr. Rowland, with the support of Democratic legislators, called for a special legislative session to pass the new plan.
Dean Pagani, Mr. Rowland's spokesman, denied that the commercial was politically motivated. "The ads are not directly linked to his re-election campaign," he said. "I'm not denying that it could have some political impact, but it's not part of the strategy."
Mr. Rowland has described the commercial as an effort to build support for his initiative. Yet no one is opposing the Husky Plan, and Democrats supported a similar initiative in March that Mr. Rowland largely ignored.
"If ever there was a clarion call to a nonbattle, this was it," State Senator Kevin Sullivan, the leader of the chamber's Democratic majority, remarked today. "I don't think people have to look too far to understand this is a campaign ad."
Although Mr. Rowland has not officially declared his candidacy, his campaign committee has raised more than $1 million and paid for the commercial.
The commercial seems like a page out of President Clinton's campaign book -- advertising early in the contest so the candidate defines himself before his opponent can.
An incumbent who has cut taxes, restricted welfare benefits and presided over an economic comeback, Mr. Rowland appears to be a strong candidate for re-election. But polls this summer have shown him to be vulnerable, and one Democratic opponent, Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, was found to be in a virtual dead heat with him. The polls showed that Mrs. Kennelly did substantially better with women than Mr. Rowland did.
Education and children's health care are likely to be among the top issues for Democrats, and in her opening salvo last month, Mrs. Kennelly repeatedly emphasized her commitment to families.
Connecticut's bid to increase the number of insured children is not singular. Earlier this year, Federal legislation allotted $24 billion to the states to extend health insurance to more children over the next five years. Mr. Rowland's plan would cost about $55 million annually, with $36 million coming from the Federal Government.
Mr. Rowland's proposal includes three initiatives. About 37,000 poor children who do not qualify for Medicaid would be eligible to join a state-subisidized private insurance plan, similar to one offered state employees. The plan would step up efforts to reach another 37,000 children who are eligible for Medicaid but not enrolled. Mr. Rowland's plan also would accelerate the eligibility of thousands of 17- and 18-year-olds who otherwise would not be able to enroll in Medicaid until July 1.

HEADLINE: Closing of Helium Reserve Raises New Issues

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: AMARILLO, Tex.

 BODY:
Of all the Federal programs that have ever come under attack, perhaps none has been more ridiculed or more reviled than the national helium reserve, here on the high plains of the Texas Panhandle. It is a collection of pipelines and pumps and vats and, most of all, a seemingly staggering amount of helium: 31 billion cubic feet, enough to supply current Federal needs for 100 years.
"Amazingly stupid, even by Government standards," P. J. O'Rourke, the conservative humorist, said of the program, which forces Federal agencies to buy helium at inflated prices from the reserve. "The poster child of Government waste," said Christopher Cox, the California Congressman who led the fight to get rid of this veritable Fort Knox of helium. 
 But now that President Clinton has signed a bill that will get the Government out of the helium business and sell off the nation's helium reserve to private industry, which has long claimed that it can supply helium more cheaply to agencies like NASA, the issue is turning out to be more complicated. In a vivid demonstration that cutting the Federal budget is rarely as easy or as simple as it seems, some experts are even daring to say it: maybe the helium reserve wasn't such a dumb idea after all.
The jury is still out on just how much money will be saved by closing the operation near here, in part because the new law, for reasons that might prove daunting even for a Nobel laureate in economics, still requires the Government to pay an inflated price for helium. In some of the first contracts signed for privately supplied helium, irritated National Aeronautics and Space Administration officials note that the price, around $70 per thousand cubic feet, is roughly the same that they paid for helium from the reserve.
The American Physical Society, a prominent group of physicists, warns that getting rid of the nation's helium stockpile is profoundly shortsighted. Though most people may think of helium as the thing that fills balloons and blimps, it is essential in all kinds of scientific pursuits, including the space program. For future generations, scientists say, it will be vital in the development of superconducting power lines, magnetically levitated trains, new kinds of generators and motors, and technology not yet even dreamed of.
No one is predicting that the Government's helium operation, in tumbleweed country about 25 miles north of Amarillo, will be magically revived. "Everything you see here -- it's all going to go," said Robert Robertson, an operator in the plant's control room. "The death warrant has been signed."
Nonetheless, even a cursory examination of the privatization of the Federal helium program, which the President set into motion when he signed the law a year ago, suggests that so far, instead of saving money, it has led to a messy accounting quandary in which the benefits are not yet clear.
Because the stores here are so large, the law requires that the helium, stored in a massive underground dome, be sold off slowly, over the next two decades, so as not to disrupt prices in the growing world market for helium. And in what, in effect, creates a secondary market in which Government agencies will bid for helium at above-market prices, the helium must be sold at prices that will fully pay off the $1.4 billion "debt" the helium conservation program has accumulated since President John F. Kennedy helped begin it in the 1960's so the nation's space program would have a reliable supply.
But because the debt is actually money that is owed by one Government agency to another, paying it off is basically a paper transaction intended to clear the helium reserve's ledger. The Congressional Budget Office has already ruled that paying off the helium program's debt will not do anything to reduce the national debt, currently at $5.3 trillion or so.
The bottom line, of course, is just how much money the Government will save by buying helium from private suppliers like the Exxon Corporation. Even the Helium Advisory Council, the industry group that has lobbied vigorously for privatization, says it is not easy to calculate the saving, partly because the new law has not yet cleared the way for the true privatization of the helium program, which would mean selling at market prices.
Carl Johnson, chairman of the council, predicts that the closing will save money. But when he was asked just how much taxpayers would save annually and when they would start seeing the saving, he said, "It's a very difficult question, and I don't even know how I would begin to answer it."
Representative Cox, a Republican from Orange County, Calif., who led the crusade to kill the helium program, was more definitive, saying the saving would eventually amount to about $24 million a year: $20 million from the greater efficiencies at private plants, compared with the antiquated complex here, and $4 million from lower helium costs.
But NASA, the main Federal recipient of helium, has yet to save any money because of the privatization.
"We were all in favor of helium privatization, but we missed something here," said Steve Parker, a procurement official at the Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral, Fla. "Your question is, are we getting the savings we were promised? That's a no. We're still paying inflated prices for the accrued debt."
Meanwhile, because nobody knows what will happen to the world market price for helium in coming decades, no one can say for sure whether selling off the national reserve is a good idea in the long run.
"What it really boils down to is this: Do you think this is true debt that is costing the American taxpayers, or is it a cost of a strategic decision to conserve crude helium?" said Timothy R. Spisak, general manager of operations of the helium program here. "Remember, you've still got an asset out here, 30 billion cubic feet of helium. If you sell it off, you don't have it anymore."
Colorless, odorless and largely inert, helium is unique among Earth's 100 or so elements because it remains liquid even at just above absolute zero, which is roughly 460 degrees Fahrenheit. That makes it extremely useful as a pressurizer and a coolant.
Robert L. Park, a professor of physics at the University of Maryland and the director of the Washington office of the American Physical Society, said that helium would have vastly increased uses in the future and that selling off the Federal reserve might one day be seen as a catastrophically heedless decision. He urged Congress to find some way to mandate an increase in the size of national reserves, even if they are held by private industry.
The supply-and-demand equation involving helium, which is nonrenewable, is extremely complex. The problem is that helium is a byproduct of natural gas and that it is not always economical for companies to extract it. Currently, only about half of the 6.7 billion cubic feet of helium taken out of the earth each year is separated from natural gas and saved. The rest disappears into the atmosphere.
But critics of the Government reserve program say concerns about the current loss of helium are overblown. They say there is no reason that the future demand for helium cannot be met by private industry, which already supplies 90 percent of the helium used in the United States.
"The physicists are right and more expert on the value to science of helium than any source you could consult," Representative Cox said. "But the physicists are not experts on economics and markets. And a great deal of what's at stake here is the latter and not the former."
In the Texas Panhandle, where the helium operation's staff of 165 will be whittled to a skeleton crew of about three dozen in the next few years, there has long been a sense of local pride in the program and outrage over the national scorn heaped upon it.
"The public's been misinformed," said Trooper Barker, a worker at the plant. "They think it's all some big joke about putting gas in blimps. Well, I've never once had a blimp fly out here and say, 'O.K., fill 'er up.' "
Mr. Barker said that once private industry took over the helium, it would find ways to raise the price, an opinion widely shared in Amarillo.
"If NASA calls tonight and says, 'We need 20 tank cars,' we'll get it out of our plant tonight," said Terry Byrd, the production and maintenance manager, during a tour of the site. "Private industry might charge a premium to do that."
The helium program has had its defenders over the years, but the widespread national criticism has often made them seem to be voices in the wilderness. In a column two years ago, Gregory Curtis, the editor of Texas Monthly magazine, said that the derision was undeserved and that the helium conservation program was "in fact an example of government working at its best." Mr. Curtis said workers and managers at the helium program were "intelligent, efficient and proud of their work, exactly the opposite of the thick and lazy bureaucrats Federal workers are often said to be."
The program has often been on the verge of elimination. In 1993, Bill Sarpalius, a Democrat who was Amarillo's Congressman, persuaded President Clinton to keep the program alive. The President, struggling to gather a majority for his budget bill, spoke to Mr. Sarpalius four times on the day of the vote.
"Sure I talked to the President about helium," Mr. Sarpalius, who was later defeated for re-election, said at the time. "I talk to everyone I can in the Government about helium. And when I had the opportunity to explain to him that this was not really a billion-dollar loss, that this is a program that makes money for the Federal Government, that there's another side to this picture, he was fascinated by it. He was really interested in helium."
Mr. Sarpalius voted with the President, and the program was spared another year.
But in 1996, with a conservative Republican Congressman, William M. Thornberry, now representing Amarillo and sentiment rising against the program, its gradual elimination was approved. Sometime around 2015, all the helium now in the Federal reserve is expected to be owned by private industry.
"There will be savings," said Representative Cox, who is the father of 3- and 4-year-olds. "We won't know how much until my kids are out of college."

HEADLINE: TV Notes;
Upkeep of a Star

BYLINE: By LAWRIE MIFFLIN 

 BODY:
In the inflationary battle to hold onto top talent, Disney's ABC has just agreed to increase the paycheck of Tim Allen, star of "Home Improvement," to $1.25 million per episode next year, which will be his and the show's eighth season.
That puts Mr. Allen, who had been making $750,000 per episode, in the same income bracket as Jerry Seinfeld, who makes more than $1 million (it is unclear how much more, because some of his pay comes in NBC stock options). The next highest earners are said to be Mr. Seinfeld's co-stars, Julia Louis-Dreyfus, Jason Alexander and Michael Richards, at about $600,000 each per episode. 
 Salary envy has spread to the inspirational drama "Touched by an Angel," where Della Reese, the senior angel on the show, says CBS failed to keep a promise to double her current salary (reported to be under $50,000), the way it had doubled the pay of Roma Downey, who though she plays the junior angel is the show's biggest star.
CBS replied in a statement that it was "puzzled" because the network had reduced Ms. Reese's work hours so that she could devote more time to her church (she is an ordained minister) and had offered "to raise her salary by a significant percentage," and that the network hoped to negotiate with her in "good faith" soon.
Meanwhile, the well-paid David Duchovny, the co-stars with Gillian Anderson on Fox's "X-Files," has begun telling people he won't return for another season unless the show transfers to Los Angeles from Vancouver, where it has been produced for all its five years.
He wants to spend more time with his wife, Tea Leoni, whose NBC sitcom "Naked Truth" is produced in Los Angeles. LAWRIE MIFFLIN

LENGTH: 928 words

HEADLINE: New York Grind

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN 

 BODY:
"LOOK, I'll be honest with you," Albertina Fiumano was saying one evening recently, standing in her 25th-floor apartment in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, gazing at the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. "I'm 100 percent American. This is a great country."
She wasn't talking about the view, the Constitution, the economy, the President or even Columbus Day. She was talking about something equally -- peculiarly -- American: her garbage disposer. 
 Mrs. Fiumano, 78, who calls herself "very particular," was one of more than 200 New York City residents to receive free garbage disposers in a 21-month study of their impact on the municipal sewerage system. On Saturday, this city of tough nuts -- which, by the way, are not recommended for disposers -- officially legalizes this quintessential postwar appliance, this "hunk of better living," as it was once called, for apartments and houses.
The sell is on, as plumbing industry executives and disposer companies, armed with peekaboo kitchen sinks and transparent pipes, try to persuade New Yorkers -- collectively, this week, the archetypal 1950's "Mrs. Consumer" -- to get in synch with modern American civilization.
But some are reluctant. Standing by the shrink-wrapped watermelons at the Fairway market on Broadway, Anne Larsen, the editor of Kirkus Reviews, summed up the city's do-without machismo. "I don't care if they are in New York or Des Moines," she said of disposers. "I don't own a car, a dishwasher, an apartment. Nothing!"
A sort of Tilt-a-Whirl for food, garbage disposers ("Disposall" is a General Electric brand name) grind eggshells, chicken bones and other food to bits. Prone to make gargling sounds -- or thumps when a melon rind comes along -- they must be fed with care. Fibrous foods like celery, artichokes and corn husks are no-no's, though ice cubes and lemon cleanse and scour disposers' palates. (The effects of New York staples like chayote, creme brulee and baby white asparagus are unclear.)
Disposers typically cost $300 to $700 when installed, as required, by a licensed plumber. High-priced designer icons, including a $950 Viking model, are already emerging.
Disposers have been banned in most of the city since the 1970's, owing less to the Glad bag and Hefty lobbies than concerns about the city's aging infrastructure, particularly in neighborhoods with sewer systems that combine sanitary wastes and storm water.
The city's study concluded that disposers would have minimal impact, said Charles Sturcken, chief of staff in the Environmental Protection Department, but the long-range effects will also be monitored. Meanwhile, one company, In-Sink-Erator, is marketing its product as good for the environment, the "safe, sanitary and environmentally sound way to eliminate biodegradable waste."
But some sanitation specialists disagree. "It adds more solids to the system, which makes treatment facilities work harder," said Peter Sattler, an environmental planner for the Interstate Sanitation Commission, which urged the city to keep the ban. "We're talking 13,000 tons a day of household garbage. Unless there is beneficial re-use" -- recycling -- "humans will always contribute to the waste stream."
The boundless promise of the disposer -- "your sink will be clean every minute of the day" -- reflects a throwaway ethos of a bygone era. In the 1920's, similar devices were tested at municipal waste sites, but in the 1950's, they were promoted as the darling of the dream kitchen.
By then, the disposer "symbolized middle class America's obsession with cleanliness and convenience," Suellen Hoy, a historian, writes in her book "Chasing Dirt: The American Pursuit of Cleanliness" (Oxford, 1995). It reflected postwar prosperity, a belief in the limitlessness of natural resources. (Interviewed by telephone, she was quick to add, "I love my disposal.")
Disposers are nearly unheard of in Europe, noted Susan Strasser, a social historian, who wrote "Never Done: A History of American Housework" (Pantheon, 1982). In 1927, John W. Hammes, a Racine, Wis., architect, began to tinker with tin snips and a soldering iron after watching his wife carry out garbage. He founded the In-Sink-Erator Company in 1938, but his contraption reached few kitchens until after World War II.
As Ms. Strasser put it, "It suited a culture of consumption based on both ever-increasing desires for household appliances and on casual attitudes about throwing things away."
Ruth Schwartz Cowan, a historian at the State University at Stony Brook, N.Y., notes that the labor saved has tended to be of the male variety. "In the stereotypical division of household chores," she said, "it has been the man who takes out the garbage." Which in New York apartments can mean merely strolling down the hall to the chute.
But disposers have insinuated themselves into the affections of some New Yorkers. Wilson Cabrera, who is from Ecuador, sat at his dining table in Bay Ridge with his wife, Susan, who is from Trinidad. They make baby food from scratch for their 6-month-old son and cook goat the Ecuadorean way, in beer.
Mr. Cabrera recalled that in Ecuador, people disposed of their garbage "the natural way": the animals ate it. "It was a poor country," he recalled. "Things were made of what was around. Aluminum foil was re-used, and children rode on big wooden spools used to wrap telephone cable, instead of bicycles."
"At the beginning I was a little skeptical," he said of the disposer he received free as a study volunteer. "But this is a big city, and life is full of garbage."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Greenspan's Comments Push Dollar Lower Against Mark

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the mark yesterday after Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, roiled financial markets and a report raised concern that the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, might soon raise interest rates.
The dollar also fell against the yen in Asian trading after Japanese officials proposed tax cuts aimed at stimulating the economy. 
 In testimony before the House Budget Committee, Mr. Greenspan said that the economy might be unable to keep growing at its current pace without stimulating inflation. Following those remarks, stocks in American markets suffered their worst one-day drop in almost a month and bonds registered their biggest decline in two months.
The selloffs raised concern about global investors shedding assets denominated in dollars.
"Greenspan's comments are having a negative effect on the dollar," said Stephen Gallagher, an economist at Societe Generale. "There are global flows out of the dollar."
The dollar extended its losses against the mark after the German daily Handelsblatt said it would report today that a majority of the Bundesbank's policy makers are prepared to raise interest rates. The Bundesbank council members are scheduled to meet today.
"Until we hear different from the Bundesbank, the report leaves a mystique in the marketplace about a rate rise," said Domenick Presa, chief currency trader at Dresdner Bank. "That adds to what happened after Greenspan's comments. A lot of people bought marks today."
The dollar settled at 1.7485 marks in New York trading, down from 1.7571 marks on Tuesday. The dollar cost 121.05 yen, down from 122.56. The British pound strengthened to $1.6223 from $1.6176.
While most traders did not expect German central bankers to raise rates today, many said they expected an increase by the end of the year. Higher rates would strengthen demand for the mark, which has fallen almost 12 percent against the dollar this year.
The dollar's weakness against the yen reflected remarks in Japan by senior members of the governing Liberal Democratic Party, who called for a significant cut in income taxes to stimulate the economy.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Coffee Prices Rise as a Storm Threatens Mexico's Harvest

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Coffee futures prices rose yesterday on speculation that a hurricane approaching the Pacific coast of Mexico could cause damage and shipping delays of the country's crop at a time of low inventories and strong demand.
The hurricane "could disrupt the harvest for a couple of weeks," said Carlos Knoepffler, president of the Miami Coffee Merchants Corporation, a coffee importer. 
 Among other commodities, gold -- a traditional hedge against inflation -- rose after Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned that the economy might be growing rapidly enough to spur inflation. Corn also rose.
The hurricane is expected to bypass Chiapas, home to 32 percent of Mexico's coffee, though it could damage crops in Oaxaca, which produces 19 percent of the crop of four million to five million bags. Mexico is the largest supplier to the United States market, representing more than 20 percent of coffee imports.
Coffee for December delivery rose 4.85 cents, or 3 percent, to $1.67 a pound on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange. Coffee prices are up 43 percent so far this year.
Gold rose after Mr. Greenspan suggested that a low unemployment rate could push wages and prices higher, creating a setting for inflation. Some investors buy gold when inflation, or the threat of inflation, reduces the value of fixed assets like bonds.
Gold for December delivery rose $2, or six-tenths of a percent, to $335.30 an ounce on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Corn jumped to a four-and-a-half-month high amid expectations for strong domestic and export demand in the months ahead.
Cattle, hog and poultry populations all are larger than a year ago, according to the Department of Agriculture. As a result, the Government expects domestic demand for feed to rise 4.7 percent, to 5.55 billion bushels during the marketing year that began Sept. 1 from a year earlier. Corn is the primary ingredient in livestock feed.
Corn for December delivery rose 3 cents, or 1.1 percent, to $2.8275 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade, the highest for a contract closest to delivery since May 20.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Europeans Reject U.S. Plan On Electronic Cryptography

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Oct. 8

 BODY:
The European Commission has rejected proposals by the United States aimed at insuring that police agencies can crack coded messages over telephone and computer networks.
In a lengthy report released today, the European Commission said the American approach could threaten privacy and stifle the growth of electronic commerce and that it might simply be ineffective. 
 The report appears to all but doom efforts by the Clinton Administration and the Federal Bureau of Investigation to establish a global system in which people who use cryptography would have to deposit a "key" for unlocking their codes with an independent outside organization. As envisioned, the police or intelligence agents would be able to use this key once they got court approval to carry out a wiretap. The plan has been vigorously opposed by the computer industry, which fears that it would jeopardize sales to foreign customers.
Because of the Internet's borderless nature, American officials have long acknowledged that their plan is workable only if most other countries adopt similar systems. If not, people could simply route their communications through countries with no restrictions.
The White House had already run into heavy opposition from civil rights groups, the computer industry and Congressional Republicans. And earlier this year, the United States failed to muster any support for its plan from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a consortium backed by more than 40 countries.
But the European Commission's blunt opposition, reported today in The Wall Street Journal, went considerably further, raising a slew of objections to "key recovery" and "key escrow" systems. Among them were these:
*Hackers could find new ways to breach security. "Inevitably, any key access scheme introduces additional ways to break into a cryptographic system," the report said.
*The systems could weaken European data-privacy laws. "Any regulation hindering the use of encryption products," the report said, "hinders the secure and free flow of personal information."
*Even with a "key escrow" or "key recovery" system, criminals cannot be entirely prevented from using strong encryption.
More broadly, the European Commission said, any kind of key-based system could jeopardize the rise of electronic commerce. "If citizens and companies have to fear that their communication and transactions are monitored with the help of key access or similar schemes," the report said, "they may prefer remaining in the anonymous off-line world."
American officials did not disguise their disappointment, and challenged the Europeans to come up with better alternatives.
"I am a little surprised," said William Reinsch, Deputy Secretary of Commerce in charge of export administration. "My question to the European Commission is, where do they think the market is going? Our sense is that corporations engaged in electronic commerce want key recovery in some form, because they want to recover their own records and to monitor their own employees."
Beyond high-minded policy issues, European officials quietly acknowledge that they have political and economic concerns. For one thing, several countries do not like the idea of deferring to an American system that might allow American companies to dominate the next generation of security products.
The German Government, meanwhile, is worried that American authorities might have improper access to data on German users -- possibly violating Germany's tough new laws on data protection.
But the European Union is far from united. Britain has generally sided with the United States in supporting an international system for regulating data encryption.
Indeed, the European Commission remained vague about what alternatives to the American system it might actually favor, nor does the report attempt to block member countries from setting up key-based systems if they want to.
American computer and software companies greeted the European policy declaration as a victory.
"Even the hard-line Governments, the U.S. and the United Kingdom, have said that any cryptography restrictions have to be internationally coordinated because otherwise you can just download material from another country," said Chris Kuner, a lawyer in Frankfurt who represents Netscape Communications and other networking companies in Europe.
"This shows that Europe does not agree with the idea of mandatory key recovery. This idea that that is the only possible regulatory framework for the world has been clearly rejected."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Loading the trade agenda with divisive issues could backfire.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
THE politics of free trade used to be simple. Exporters and the international-minded political establishment were for it. Unions and industries vulnerable to imports were against it.
Now, you can't tell the players without a scorecard. Organized labor is still manning the barricades. But by shifting the focus from old-fashioned protectionism to new-fashioned concern with human rights and the environment, unions have sown dissension among the free traders. 
 While President Clinton may be inclined to meet the unions halfway, any significant tilt to the left is likely to alienate the Congressional Republicans he needs to win the "fast track" authority critical to negotiating further trade liberalization. Indeed, even academic economists, who give free trade lobbies their intellectual imprimatur, are threatening to jump ship if Mr. Clinton compromises.
Last week some 50 academic trade specialists -- a who's who led by Robert Baldwin of the University of Michigan and Jagdish Bhagwati of Columbia -- warned that overloading the trade agenda with divisive new issues could "halt the opening up of world markets."
Mr. Bhagwati was blunter. "Linking human rights and the environment to trade is the lazy man's solution to extremely difficult problems," he argued, "and a recipe for failure all around."
Presidents have had fast-track authority -- that is, discretion to negotiate trade agreements that Congress must vote up or down without amendment -- for the last two decades. And for good reason: without fast track, there can be no effective bargaining with foreign governments since any tentative deal would be subject to death by a thousand amendments in Congress.
That is why those who oppose extending the North American Free Trade Agreement to include other Latin American economies or to another round of global trade liberalization also oppose renewal of fast track. But with a Republican majority in Congress and an open trader in the White House, protectionists don't have the muscle to kill fast track by direct assault.
The politically astute alternative, favored by the House minority leader, Representative Richard Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, is to make common cause with human rights and environmental groups. Mr. Gephardt wants to condition fast-track authority to include minimum labor and environmental standards in any new treaty.
So what's wrong with insisting, say, that Indonesia bar child labor, or that East African farmers leave grazing room for elephants? Some economists argue national sovereignty must be respected at any cost short of turning a blind eye to slavery or genocide. But most oppose burdening the trade agenda on more pragmatic grounds.
For one thing, many Congressional Republicans will not go along because they fear America would have to change its own labor standards -- notably state "right to work" laws -- to conform to the European approach. For another, it would complicate the already difficult problem of piecing together agreements with dozens of interest groups. The Asian tigers, for example, would probably balk at interference in their labor laws.
More important, many economists argue, activists are putting the cart before the horse. Open trade, they say, is the key to rapid income growth in developing areas, and high income leads to adoption of tough social and environmental rules.
Gene Grossman, an economist at Princeton and a signatory to the economists' statement on fast track, has documented this process. Pollution typically rises during early stages of economic development, just as it did in 19th-century Europe. Later, it declines as economies become rich enough to afford clean air and water.
In any case, Mr. Bhagwati argues, there are already escape hatches under World Trade Organization rules for boycotting imports from countries with particularly objectionable social policies. Two-thirds of the members may collectively obtain a waiver from nondiscriminatory import obligations. Or a single nation can just say no to foreigners' practices, blocking imports and accepting limited retaliation by the trade group.
The hard political question here is whether the economists' effort to get the President to stand up to protectionists on labor and environmental standards will make further trade liberalization more or less likely. Robert Z. Lawrence, an economist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, did not sign the economists' statement because he wanted to give the White House flexibility to cut a deal that allows Congressional Democrats to save face. "A reasonable effort at compromise should be attempted," he concluded.
But Mr. Bhagwati and company fear that fast track has become an end in itself -- that President Clinton will give away the substance to claim political victory. A compromise that advances neither the cause of free trade nor elevated social standards, Mr. Bhagwati argued, "is unworthy of a great nation known for leadership on both."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. Official Assails China On Trade Gap

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Commerce Secretary William M. Daley, apparently trying his best to sound angry, today attacked China's growing trade imbalance with the United States.
Visiting Beijing for trade talks, Mr. Daley said he tried to pressure China's leaders to open their markets further or do anything that would reverse the widening gap between what China sells to America and what it buys. 
 "The trends have just got to change," Mr. Daley said after meeting President Jiang Zemin. "It's just unacceptable for them to continue this way."
His words, however, essentially repeated complaints that United States officials have made over the last 10 years with little discernible effect, since the imbalance has enlarged. The Commerce Department estimates the trade gap will reach $44 billion this year.
With his trip aimed partly at laying groundwork for President Jiang's meeting with President Clinton in Washington at the end of this month, Mr. Daley was also engaged in some multisided diplomacy that reflected the Clinton Administration's tricky position in China.
On one side, acting as American business's biggest booster, Mr. Daley encouraged Chinese officials to buy American and, more specifically, commit to a pending deal for up to $2 billion of Boeing aircraft.
At the same time, with the Clinton Administration sensitive to accusations it is capitulating to Chinese demands to make sales here, Mr. Daley went out of his way to sound tough, attacking Beijing for keeping out American goods.
"When they're growing at the pathetic pace that they are today," Mr. Daley said, referring to United States exports to China, "we need to see significant change."
China's market is hardly open -- Mr. Daley pointed to distribution controls, import licenses and special product standards as typical barriers -- but as a poor country, it is debatable how many Chinese could afford American products.
Chinese officials contend that the imbalance comes mostly from the huge American demand for China's cheaply made goods, like shoes and toys and electronics, and less from Chinese Government policy. As China's Trade Minister, Wu Yi, put it this week, the imbalance comes from "historical inevitability."
To appease the United States side a bit, Ms. Wu announced today that China would soon send a buying mission to the United States to sign what she called "substantial economic contracts." Failing to identify the timing, value or kind of goods involved, however, suggested that the announcement was largely symbolic.
Mr. Daley acknowledged that the trade dispute was so brittle that neither side could even agree about how to compile trade statistics: The United States counted $40 billion more in imports from China than exports in 1996; China said it only sold $10 billion more than it bought.
Many economists say the true figure lies in between, because each side fudges figures with the trade that passes through Hong Kong. Asked about the discrepancy today, Mr. Daley said trends were important, not specific figures.
But he insisted the Clinton Administration would pursue more trade and cooperation with China.
"Ignoring reality by retreating from the global economy and China's expanding role in it is not an option," Mr. Daley said.
Washington supports China's entry into the World Trade Organization, Mr. Daley said, but only on terms acceptable to the United States and other members. Chinese officials have demanded "developing nation" status that would allow them delays in opening their markets.
Asked about the possibility that China might win permanent most-favored-nation trade status with the United States -- which Beijing has repeatedly demanded -- Mr. Daley said it was unlikely until "we see progress on a whole host of other issues."

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Fed Chief's Statement

BYLINE: By Dow Jones 

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, omitted large portions of his prepared text in his oral testimony yesterday before the House Banking Committee in Washington. He chiefly spoke on long-term budget issues like Social Security and Medicare. But the financial markets reacted to the prepared remarks, which were released yesterday morning. Following are excerpts from his prepared testimony: 
 If the recent two million-plus annual pace of job creation were to continue, the pressures on wages and other costs of hiring large numbers of such individuals could escalate more rapidly. To be sure, job growth slowed significantly in August and September, but it did not slow enough to close, from the demand side alone, the gap of the demand for labor over the supply from increases in the working-age population.
Thus, the performance of the labor markets this year suggests that the economy has been on an unsustainable track. That the marked rate of absorption of potential workers since 1994 has not induced a more dramatic increase in employee compensation per hour and price inflation has come as a major surprise to most analysts. . . .
To be sure, there is still little evidence of wage acceleration. To believe, however, that wage pressures will not intensify as the group of people who are not working, but who would like to, rapidly diminishes, strains credibility. The law of supply and demand has not been repealed. If labor demand continues to outpace sustainable increases in supply, the question is surely when, not whether, labor costs will escalate more rapidly.
Of course, a fall-off in the current pace of demand for goods and services could close the gap and avoid the emergence of inflationary pressures. So could a sharp improvement in productivity growth, which would reduce the pace of new hiring required to produce a given rate of growth of real output.
Productivity growth in manufacturing, as best we can measure it, apparently did pick up some in the third quarter and the broader measures of productivity growth have exhibited a modest quickening this year. Certainly, the persistence, even acceleration, of commitments to invest in new facilities suggests that the actual profitability of recent past investments, and by extension increased productivity, has already been achieved to some degree rather than being merely prospective.
However, to reduce the recent two million-plus annual rate of job gains to the one million rate consistent with long-term population growth would require, all else equal, a full percentage point increase in the rate of productivity growth. While not inconceivable, such a rapid change is rare in the annals of business history, especially for a mature industrial society of our breadth and scope.
Clearly, impressive new technologies have imparted a sense of change in which previous economic relationships are seen as being less reliable now. Improvements in productivity are possible if worker skills increase, but gains come slowly through experience, education, and on-the-job training. They are also possible as capital substitutes for labor, but that is limited by the state of current technology. Very significant advances in productivity require technological breakthroughs that alter fundamentally the efficiency with which we use our labor and capital resources. But at the cutting edge of technology, where America finds itself, major improvements cannot be produced on demand. New ideas that matter are hard won.
Short of a marked slowing in the demand for goods and services and, hence, labor -- or a degree of acceleration of productivity growth that appears unlikely -- the imbalance between the growth in labor demand and the expansion of potential labor supply of recent years must eventually erode the current state of inflation quiescence and, with it, the solid growth of real activity. . . .
Aside from the question of whether stock prices will rise or fall, it clearly would be unrealistic to look for a continuation of stock market gains of anything like the magnitude of those recorded in the past couple of years.

HEADLINE: Beltway Accounting

BYLINE: By Fritz Hollings; Fritz Hollings, a Democrat, is a Senator from South Carolina.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The Congressional Budget Office has just pointed out a reality: the "balanced budget" is not balanced. And there is little hope that it will become balanced.
The budget office's "Economic and Budget Outlook" states on page 34 that the deficit for the current fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30, will be $34 billion, the lowest since 1974. The deficit last year was $107 billion. After 2001, the deficit, the office predicts, will be eliminated. 
 A great accomplishment, if these estimates were true. But they are not. These estimates make the deficit appear smaller by including revenue that is intended for other purposes, such as the Social Security trust fund.
The budget office did calculate the deficit with this revenue excluded, and the deficit is much higher for the 1997 fiscal year: $177 billion. The budget will not be balanced after 2001; in fiscal year 2002, there will be a deficit of $161 billion. The budget office predicts that for each of the next 10 years we will spend more than $100 billion more than we receive. The debt will soar to more than $7 trillion dollars by 2008.
When the Government spends more than it receives, not only does the debt increase but so do interest costs on the debt. Interest costs are like taxes -- they can't be avoided, they must be paid.
The tax money that goes to paying the debt and its interest has been increasing by $15 billion a year, taking money away from worthwhile projects like highway and school construction. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that for the 1997 fiscal year, the payment of the debt and its interest cost us $358 billion -- almost a billion dollars a day.
I had hoped that this year, with a good economy, we would stay the course: freeze the budget, with no spending increases and no tax cuts. Instead we passed the "balanced budget," which increased spending for the next year by $52 billion and cut taxes or revenues by $95 billion.
Politicians in Washington are congratulating themselves on passing a balanced budget. But there will be a day of reckoning in the next five years. The economy will slow down, and interest rates will rise. And lo and behold, we will find that the balanced budget was nothing but smoke and mirrors.

HEADLINE: North Korea's Favorite Son Wins Top Title

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 8

 BODY:
North Korea's "Dear Leader," Kim Jong Il, today assumed the country's top leadership post, which had been vacant since the death of his father, the "Great Leader" Kim Il Sung, three years ago. Some experts say they believe the official elevation creates possibilities for changes in North Korea that could reverberate around the Pacific Rim.
Mr. Kim is the globe's least-understood national leader in the world's most mysterious country, presiding over an army that is one of the world's biggest, with tons of chemical weapons and perhaps a few nuclear weapons at its disposal. Now Mr. Kim, who is 55 and has never traveled outside the Communist world, appears to have greater authority to expand a gradual opening-up of his country and develop ties with America if, as some experts believe, that is what he wants to do. 
 "North Korea is now headed for a free-market economy," said Kim Myong Chol, who formerly edited a North Korea-affiliated newspaper in Japan and has ties with members of the leadership in the North Korean capital. "In Kim Jong Il's mind, not everything about capitalism is bad."
Few experts agree that North Korea is headed for a market economy any time soon. But Kim Myong Chol's willingness to make such comments underscores the new currents of thinking that are stirring in North Korea and that may become more evident now that Kim Jong Il has the title of general secretary of the ruling Communist Party.
Some analysts expect modest but important changes in the years ahead, partly out of desperation because of the hunger and economic catastrophe that grips the country. Others emphasize that Kim Jong Il has already been effectively running the country for several years and anticipate little or no change.
But the formal rise to power of Kim Jong Il suggests that the mourning period for the father has now ended, and the younger Mr. Kim has dropped some tantalizing hints that changes may now be in order.
The South Korean Government issued a statement that seemed to express a cautious welcome to Mr. Kim, voicing hope that his election would increase stability in North Korea and lead to improvements in relations between the two countries.
"We've always been aware that North Korea was under the control of Mr. Kim Jong Il before this official announcement," a senior South Korean Government official said today. "But now that he will have the actual post of head of the party, the North Korean Government may be more stable, more responsible and more predictable."
The position of President has also been vacant since the death of Kim Il Sung, and it is unclear whether Kim Jong Il will later assume that post as well.
North Korea is in many ways less a Communist state than a reincarnation of an ancient Korean kingdom, in which the ruler's mandate is based not on political mechanisms but on birthright and Confucian loyalties. Thus while it might have seemed odd elsewhere in the Communist world for a son to inherit power from his father or for the nation's top leadership posts to be left empty for three years after the death of a ruler, both patterns are borrowed directly from Korean history.
Similarly, the Korean press has lately described phenomena like trees blossoming out of season, which to Westerners may seem an odd thing to make a fuss over but is understandable to Korean traditionalists as a sign that the Mandate of Heaven is passing.
"On the morning of Sept. 22, fishermen of the fishery station in Rajin-Sonbong City caught a 10-centimeter long white sea cucumber while fishing on the waters off Chongjin," the official New Korea News Agency reported. "They said the rare white sea cucumber has come to hail the auspicious event of electing comrade Kim Jong Il as party general secretary."
"Seeing the mysterious natural phenomena," the agency continued, "Koreans say comrade Kim Jong Il is indeed the greatest of great men produced by Heaven and that flowers come into bloom to mark the great event."
Mr. Kim has often been portrayed, particularly by South Koreans, as little more than a playboy terrorist with a passion for films. But some scholars say that Kim Jong Il has a more serious side, and in the last few years he has presided over a modest economic liberalization, with invitations for foreign investment and a growing number of private markets emerging in the countryside for food and clothing.
In a remarkable series of tape recordings smuggled out of North Korea, Mr. Kim can be heard admitting that centrally planned economies do not work as well as the market. Moreover, in a major essay published in August -- largely ignored because it was long, dreary and full of slogans -- Mr. Kim gave the clearest indication that he might pursue more flexible policies.
"Improving the relations between the North and the South is an urgent requirement," Mr. Kim wrote. He called for putting into effect long-frozen accords between the two Koreas and expressed willingness to negotiate with South Korea and also improve relations with Japan and the United States.

HEADLINE: Greenspan's Remarks Roil Stocks and Bonds

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
The stock and bond markets fell sharply yesterday after Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, suggested that they should not assume interest rates will remain low for some time to come.
The remarks caught investors and traders off guard, especially in the interest-rate-sensitive bond market. Though stock prices recovered a bit, bonds suffered the biggest one-day drop in more than two months. 
 In testimony before Congress, Mr. Greenspan warned that a shrinking labor market coupled with rising demand for skilled workers could push wages higher and fuel inflation. That would force the Fed to raise the target on its short-term interest rate.
However, many analysts viewed Mr. Greenspan's comments as a warning rather than a strong indication that the Fed will raise interest rates at either its November or December meetings.
They also said the Fed chairman was trying to remind investors that the recent strong rallies in stocks and bonds cannot last forever. Some characterized his reminder as gentler than the one he delivered last December, when he asked whether the market rally then was a sign of "irrational exuberance."
The stock market may have taken a similar view yesterday. Although the Dow Jones industrial average fell as much as 126.72 points during the session, a modest rebound left the index off 83.25 points, or 1 percent, at 8,095.06.
While the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index finished lower, the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index gained 4.50 points, finishing at 1,741.77, another new high. The Russell index of 2,000 smaller companies fell 0.12 point, to 463.66.
The S.& P. 500 closed at 973.84, down 9.28 points.
In the bond market, which is more vulnerable to negative comments from the Federal Reserve, there was no recovery from its immediate selloff after Mr. Greenspan began testifying at 10 A.M.
The 30-year bond tumbled 1 24/32, to a price of 100 4/32, the biggest one-day decline since Aug. 1. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, increased to 6.36 percent, from 6.23 percent on Tuesday. Bondholders lost about $17.50 for every $1,000 invested.
"I think he wants to warn people that he may have to do something," said Charles Pradilla, chief investment strategist at Cowen & Company in New York, speaking of the possibility of an increase in interest rates.
"Remember, this is the man who didn't like the market 20 percent ago," Mr. Pradilla added.
Josh Stiles, senior bond strategist at I.D.E.A., a financial consulting firm, said the bond market fell so sharply because many investors and analysts had begun to assume the Fed would not raise rates until sometime next year, if at all. This assumption became more widely accepted after August and September job growth turned out weaker than expected.
"The market having already priced out the prospect of a rate hike until June was caught completely by surprise," Mr. Stiles said.
But analysts also said that even if the Fed decided to lift interest rates next month, that increase should not halt the economy's growth.
"The bull market is far from over," said Larry Rice, chief investment officer at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross. Although Mr. Rice said he thought the stock market was overvalued and could fall as much as 10 percent, it should resume climbing. But some saw reason to pause in Mr. Greenspan's comments.
"I do think there is something to what the chairman is saying," said Cliff Waldman, an economist with the National Federation of Independent Business, a trade association for more than 600,000 small companies.
According to a federation survey conducted in September, 17 percent of small-business owners said that finding qualified workers was their main problem, ahead of taxes and regulations. That percentage is near a high of 18 percent seen in August and comes when hiring plans are at an all-time high, Mr. Waldman said.
As a result, these companies may be forced to increase prices or decrease hiring plans, he said.
"What he's saying is not out of the ball park," Mr. Waldman said. "If the continued run-up in financial assets is because investors are betting inflation is all but dead, that bet's becoming a little riskier."
In trading yesterday, technology issues bucked the overall decline.
Gateway 2000 moved up 4 3/16, to 34; Microsoft inched up 2 1/2, to 139, and Texas Instruments rose 4 3/4, to 137 5/8.
While Mr. Greenspan's concern about inflation jolted both the stock and bond markets yesterday, it may have provided the backdrop the Treasury needed to auction $8 billion of Treasury Inflation Protection Securities.
The sale was a reopening of the Government's five-year inflation protection securities, first sold in July. They were sold yesterday at a high yield of 3.60 percent, below the 3.65 percent expected.

HEADLINE: Ford Planning To Spin Off Lending Unit

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Seeking to persuade investors that its stock is undervalued, the Ford Motor Company said late today that it would distribute to shareholders its 80.7 percent stake in its highly profitable consumer and commercial lending unit, handing out shares in the Associates First Capital Corporation worth nearly $18 billion.
Ford executives have long contended that the stock market has failed to account for the auto maker's valuable financial businesses in allowing Ford stock to trade at a price-to-earnings ratio just half that of the overall market. The nearly $18 billion in Associates shares to be spun off now represent a third of Ford's market value of $57.6 billion, yet Ford's earnings from its stake in the Associates made up just 7.8 percent of its second-quarter profits. 
 "We believe the market value of the Associates is neither fully nor consistently reflected in Ford's stock price," said Alex Trotman, Ford's chairman and chief executive. "Because the market views Ford as an automotive company, it has not fully recognized or rewarded us for our diversification in nonautomotive financial services businesses."
But the spinoff, one of the biggest in corporate history, would leave Ford even more dependent on the highly cyclical automotive business. The Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered Ford's corporate credit rating and its senior debt rating to A from A+ tonight, while affirming its commercial paper rating at A-1. The Chrysler Corporation already had an A rating, while the General Motors Corporation has an A- rating.
Moody's Investors Service reaffirmed Ford's credit rating at A1.
Scott Sprinzen, a managing director at S.& P., said that Ford's valuable stake in the Associates had given bondholders more reassurance until now that they would be repaid even if the automotive business ran into serious difficulty. "This very valuable asset will no longer be there for bondholders," he said, adding that the credit downgrade reflected about $80 billion of Ford's $164 billion in outstanding stock.
But Ford's immense cash reserves, which stood at $18.18 billion on June 30, still provide bond investors with considerable reassurance, he added.
Analysts still welcomed Ford's move. "This is something that was at the top of the wish list for shareholders," said Scott Merlis, the president of Merlis Automotive International Inc., an investment banking and research firm in Westport, Conn.
Ford can partly offset the effects of any recession in the United States by continuing to expand its car sales overseas, Mr. Merlis said. "Associates was not big enough as a percentage of total earnings to totally offset a downturn anyway," he said.
The spinoff will require a ruling from the Internal Revenue Service that it is tax-free to shareholders, which could take several months. Ford said that its plan would be to distribute roughly one share of Associates stock for every four shares of Ford stock.
The announcement was made after the close of trading. Ford shares rose 37.5 cents to close at $48.25, and hit a 52-week high during the day of $48.6875. Associates shares climbed 87.5 cents to close at $64.
Ford acquired Associates for $3.35 billion in 1989. It received $1.9 billion in an initial public offering in May 1996 of 19.3 percent of the Associates shares.
Ford earned $197 million in the second quarter from its stake in Associates, or 7.8 percent of Ford's total second-quarter earnings of $2.53 billion.
Mr. Trotman said today that Ford planned to maintain its dividend at the current level of 42 cents a share. With the absence of Associates' earnings, this could mean that Ford would pay out a higher percentage of its automotive earnings, unless these earnings rose sharply.
Associates, which is based in Dallas, has been the target of some criticism this year from consumer advocates who contend that it charges excessively high interest rates to low-income borrowers. The finance company has denied any wrongdoing and has said that such criticisms were inevitable in the consumer lending business.
Mel Stephens, a Ford spokesman, said that the criticism was unrelated to Ford's decision to spin off the rest of Associates.
Huge spinoffs have become increasingly popular in corporate America, as institutional investors have decided to diversify their portfolios by buying stock in many companies in different industries instead of a few diversified companies.
Ford has already held an initial public offering this year for nearly a fifth of the Hertz Corporation, while G.M. is expected to sell a 20 percent stake in its auto parts subsidiary, Delphi, as soon as next year and perhaps the rest of the subsidiary later. G.M. also cut loose the Electronic Data Systems Corporation last year, which previously traded as a special class of G.M. stock.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1149 words

HEADLINE: Greenspan Cautions on Inflation; Change in Tone a Jolt to Investors

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned today that inflation might be on the horizon, jolting investors who had grown used to the ideal economic conditions of the last year and increasing the chances that the central bank might soon raise interest rates.
His caution signal was seen by analysts and in the financial markets as an abrupt change of tone and emphasis. For much of this year Mr. Greenspan has cautiously backed the view that technological advances and other factors have improved the economy's capacity to hold off inflation despite a run of strong growth and a decline in unemployment to near a quarter-century low. 
 Mr. Greenspan's statements blindsided Wall Street, where evidence that the economy is on an even keel had sent stock prices back up to near record levels in recent days. Stock prices plunged immediately after release this morning of his remarks prepared for a Congressional committee and recovered considerably, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at 8,095.06, down 83.25 for the day. Bond prices dropped sharply and the dollar fell. Markets in much of the rest of the world also fell.
Economists, many of whom had been predicting that the Federal Reserve would leave interest rates unchanged for the rest of the year since there are few visible signs of inflation, said it was now possible that the central bank would raise rates as soon as its next meeting, on Nov. 12. That would increase borrowing costs, putting the brakes on the economy in an effort to keep inflation from accelerating.
Mr. Greenspan, whose suggestion that investors might be suffering from "irrational exuberance" had rocked markets around the world last year, also sent shudders through Wall Street today with a reminder that the bull market would have to cool off eventually.
"Aside from the question of whether stock prices will rise or fall, it clearly would be unrealistic to look for a continuation of stock market gains of anything like the magnitude of those recorded in the past couple of years," Mr. Greenspan said.
Though Mr. Greenspan's comments on the risk of inflation made up a substantial portion of his prepared testimony to the House Budget Committee, in his oral remarks to the committee he concentrated on the failure of Congress to take advantage of the strong economy and make more progress on politically painful issues like the need to overhaul Social Security and Medicare.
Mr. Greenspan also questioned whether the Federal Government could follow through on its plan to balance the budget by 2002, warning that a lack of political will to follow through with planned spending cuts or a willingness to adopt overly optimistic economic assumptions could land the country to a fiscal mess.
The Federal Reserve last raised rates in March, when it pushed its Federal funds target rate up by a quarter-point, to 5.5 percent. It has left monetary policy unchanged at four meetings since then, despite signs that growth continued to run considerably higher than the 2.2 percent or so that is widely seen as the Fed's "speed limit."
Richard D. Rippe, an economist at Prudential Securities, said Mr. Greenspan was "splashing a little cold water in the face of this bullish market trend" and reminding investors not to indulge in overoptimism.
"It doesn't mean a big new problem has been uncovered, nor does it necessarily mean the Fed will change monetary policy," Mr. Rippe said. "But it does serve to remind us that there are some risks in the picture and that some of the trends may not be sustainable."
Mr. Greenspan's testimony comes as economists, including those within the central bank, are debating whether huge investments by American business in technology are yielding as-yet-unrecorded gains in productivity, allowing companies to absorb cost increases without passing them along to consumers in the form of higher prices.
Over the last year Mr. Greenspan has become the most influental supporter of the idea that something basic has changed, although he has hedged his support for the notion of the "new economy" by saying that its effects might be limited and that it did not mean that inflation was no longer a threat. Still, his public flirtation with the idea has been one reason for the optimism in the financial markets, analysts said.
Mr. Greenspan gave no indication that he was abandoning his views about technology and productivity. But in a clear shift of emphasis, Mr. Greenspan emphasized the most traditional of economic rules, that continued reductions in unemployment would lead eventually to higher wages and then higher prices.
The root of the problem, Mr. Greenspan said, is a situation that is in other ways welcome: the country is running out of new workers.
He said the robust pace of job creation had pushed unemployment so low that unless the economy cooled off employers would have to begin offering higher wages to attract the workers they need. While workers would applaud higher wages, especially after eight years in which inflation-adjusted pay has declined, rising labor costs typically ignite a cycle that leads to higher prices and endangers the economy's ability to continue growing. The unemployment rate in September was 4.9 percent.
"If the recent two-million-plus annual pace of job creation were to continue, the pressures on wages and other costs of hiring large numbers of such individuals could escalate more rapidly," Mr. Greenspan said. "To be sure, job growth slowed significantly in August and September, but it did not slow enough" to eliminate the risk of a wage and price upward spiral.
If demand for labor continues to exceed supply, it "must eventually erode the current state of inflation quiesence and, with it, the solid growth" that the economy has been enjoying, Mr. Greenspan said.
"To be sure, there is still little evidence of wage acceleration," Mr. Greenspan said. "To believe, however, that wage pressures will not intensify as the group of people who are not working, but who would like to, rapidly diminishes, strains credibility. The law of supply and demand has not been repealed."
Mr. Greenspan's comments were particularly surprising to economists because the most recent round of economic statistics -- especially a report last Friday that job growth in September was lower than expected -- indicated that the economy was slowing on its own.
"The standard interpretation of the last employment report was that it showed some slowdown in the demand for labor and perhaps in the economy," said Paul L. Kasriel, an economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "Greenspan's comments seemed to dispel those notions. There's a growing sentiment on the Federal Open Market Committee that the Fed is going to have to do something soon and the economy is unlikely to slow down enough on its own to reduce inflationary pressures."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Greenspan Jars Markets With Warning on Inflation
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned that inflation might be on the horizon, jolting investors who had grown used to the ideal economic conditions of the last year and increasing the chances that the central bank might soon raise interest rates.
Mr. Greenspan's remarks were surprising because for much of this year he had cautiously backed the view that technological advances and other factors had improved the economy's capacity to hold off inflation despite strong growth. Page A1. 

Stock and bond prices fell sharply after Mr. Greenspan's remarks, though share prices rebounded somewhat as some analysts viewed his comments as simply a caution about high valuations and not necessarily an indication that a rate increase was imminent. The Dow industrials, down as much as 126.72 points during the day, ended 83.25 lower at 8095.06. The movement was more pronounced in the Treasury market, where the 30-year bond yield jumped to 6.36 percent from 6.23. D10.
 
Big Jury Award Against Chrysler
A jury ruled that Chrysler should pay $262.5 million to the parents of a 6-year-old boy who was killed when he was thrown from a mini-van with a defective rear latch in a traffic accident. A17.
 
Europe Throws Out 'Key Escrow'
European officials rejected proposals by the United States aimed at insuring that police agencies can crack coded messages over telephone and computer networks, a plan known as key escrow. D4.
 
Criticism for Congress and Bankers
On the eve of a Congressional hearing on a proposed accounting rule that has drawn fierce criticism, Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the S.E.C., sharply attacked Congress and the banking industry for intervening in the independent process by which such rules are written. D9.
 
Debating Insurance Measure
Some of the biggest insurance companies in the country squared off against consumer advocates in a New York State hearing on legislation that would allow policyholder-owned insurers to sell stock. D2.
 
Marvel Plan Crumbles
The plan to reorganize Marvel Entertainment Group, the comic and trading-card company, collapsed as some secured creditors balked. Those creditors evidently were enticed by a plan put forward at the last minute by Toy Biz, a company partly owned by Marvel, to reorganize Marvel on terms arguably better for the secured creditors but clearly worse for existing Marvel shareholders. Floyd Norris: Market Place. D10.
 
Sharp Words on China Trade
Commerce Secretary William M. Daley repeated American officials' decade-long complaints during a visit to China, criticizing it for its growing trade imbalance with the United States. D4.
 
'Fast Track' Measure Advances
The House Ways and Means Committee voted to give President Clinton broad authority to negotiate global trade agreements, but the Administration won the support of only a handful of the panel's Democrats despite a flurry of lobbying. A28.
 
Tobacco Rules Seen as Ineffective
Regulations adopted by the Federal Government last year to make it harder for children to buy cigarettes and chewing tobacco are unlikely to have any effect on rates of teen-age tobacco use, according to a new study. A16.
 
Los Angeles Times Shuffle Seen
Shelby Coffey 3d, the editor of The Los Angeles Times for nearly nine years, is said to be on the verge of leaving that job, according to numerous people at the newspaper. D24.

HEADLINE: In Her Own Words

 BODY:

RUTH W. MESSINGER
In a speech to the Fifth Avenue Association, a group of Manhattan business leaders, at the Waldorf-Astoria: 
 "What really works is to have fewer poor people, so we don't have to spend as much to meet their needs. HEADLINE: Messinger Vows Help for Small Businesses

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
Declaring that "we have a job crisis in New York City," Ruth W. Messinger outlined an economic development strategy yesterday that would direct tax breaks and other municipal assistance to small businesses, which she said were best positioned to generate jobs and put more city residents to work.
Ms. Messinger, the Democratic candidate for mayor, said she would eliminate the commercial rent tax, which applies to businesses south of 96th Street in Manhattan, cut the unincorporated business tax and seek to lower the sales tax. She also said she would make it easier for small businesses to get loans. 
 Speaking to about 250 members of the Fifth Avenue Association, a Manhattan business group, at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria, Ms. Messinger warned that Wall Street "is the only economic engine driving this city" and that "too many of our chips are on Wall Street." She said that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had given too many tax breaks to big corporations and said that, as mayor, she would concentrate on businesses with fewer than 100 employees.
Ms. Messinger derided Mr. Giuliani for what she called his failure to address the city's 9.5 percent unemployment rate, which is more than double the national average.
"With this high number of people unemployed, we are becoming increasingly a city of the very rich and the very poor," Ms. Messinger said.
"I have talked over the last several months about the things that I think we need to do to help individual people in need," she said. "I am not going to go through any of those issues now because in many ways, those are only stopgap issues. What really works is to have fewer poor people, so we don't have to spend as much to meet their needs. I think we do that by growing and diversifying the economy of this city more than we have."
She said she would require all businesses that receive city tax abatements or that win city contracts to guarantee that a majority of their new employees were New York City residents. She pledged a particular emphasis on emerging industries, like biomedical technology and advanced computer software.
Ms. Messinger vowed to create an office of science, technology, higher education and medical research "to help both the new small firms in those fields and the older more established institutions that show some promise of being able to build and expand. Because I think that's where jobs will be in the next century."
Fran Reiter, Mr. Giuliani's campaign manager, also addressed the Fifth Avenue Association luncheon, telling the group of business leaders that the Mayor's tax breaks for large corporations had saved tens of thousands of jobs.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Income Gap Widens

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
The gap between New Jersey's well-to-do and lower-income residents widened during the first half of the decade, according to a Rutgers University study released yesterday.
Between 1990 and 1995, the average wage for the state's low-wage earners slipped nearly $1 an hour, to $7.25, said Leslie McCall, an associate professor of sociology at Rutgers and a co-author of the study. 
 The average wage for the top 10 percent of wage earners climbed 90 cents, to $28.58 an hour, over the same period.
The figures complicated what otherwise appeared to be a rosy employment picture; from the end of the last recession in 1992 through 1996, the state has seen a net gain of 180,000 jobs, she said.
"We can't any longer assume that with job growth we're going to see wage growth," said Ms. McCall, who noted that many of the new jobs were at the low-wage end of the service sector.
