HEADLINE: AIDS Research in Africa: Juggling Risks and Hopes

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Cecile Guede, a 23-year-old H.I.V.-infected mother and patient in an American-financed AIDS treatment experiment here, doesn't yet know if the disease has spared her year-old son.
Like scores of other women who have taken part in the same tests, she has no idea whether she received medicine or a dummy pill. And she may never be told. 
 It is now more than a year since she took pills prescribed to her in the program meant to determine the effectiveness of a short course of the anti-AIDS drug AZT in preventing pregnant mothers from passing the virus to their children.
A longer treatment with the drug is known to significantly reduce the rate of transmission of the virus from mother to baby, but the cost and complexity make it prohibitive in the third world. That is why tests to determine the effectiveness of various lower levels of the drug have been conducted here, the Dominican Republic and Thailand. The use of placebos in these tests, however, has set off a furor among medical ethicists in the West.
Ms. Guede, however, still does not quite grasp -- even after repeated questioning -- what exactly a placebo is or why she might have been given that instead of a real medicine.
"They gave me a bunch of pills to take, and told me how to take them" said the woman, who is illiterate. "Some were for malaria, some were for fevers, and some were supposed to be for the virus. I knew that there were different kinds, but I figured that if one of them didn't work against AIDS, then one of the other ones would."
For Ms. Guede, the reason to enroll in the study last year was clear: it offered her and her infant free health care and a hope to shield her baby from deadly infection. Unmarried and unemployed, this new mother, like many others, said the prospect of help as she brought her baby into the world made taking part in the experiment all but irresistible.
Still, the question of whether she and other pregnant women knew the implications of consenting to a placebo test hangs over the project, which is financed by the National Institutes of Health and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. It has set off a raging debate over medical ethics in the United States but has barely raised a ripple in this poor West African country of 11 million.
In the United States, tests of intensive treatment with AZT, known as the 076 regimen, and comparing the drug's effects with those of placebos ended in 1994 once it was shown that the drug sharply reduced transmission of the virus from mothers to their babies. It would be virtually impossible, doctors say, to receive approval for tests in the United States on AIDS-infected mothers using placebos now that the 076 regimen has been proved effective.
But other medical ethicists argue differently: There is no question of 076 being adopted in Africa because of its high cost, they say, and that is precisely why a low-cost method is needed. Some people say the best way to do that is to compare different low-cost methods, with no placebo group, but others say this would take longer and be less reliable.
"We cannot afford the 076 regimen," said Dr. Rene Anatole Ehounou Ekpini, a local health-care worker employed in the program.
"We already know what the alternative is to what we are doing," said Dr. Ekpini, who spoke in the simple state-run maternal and infant-care clinic in Koumassi, a working-class district Abidjan where the trials are being conducted. "The alternative is giving everyone here the placebo treatment, because if you step outside, that is what pregnant women with the disease are getting here: nothing."
In the United States, proponents of the AZT trials have said that the women who take part are willing volunteers who knowingly accept the risks.
But extended interviews with a handful of the women, made available to a reporter by the researchers, made it clear that despite repeated explanations, the understanding of these mostly poor and scantily educated subjects does not match the complexity of the ethical and scientific issues involved.
Social workers and nurses employed in the experiment do brief potential subjects about the nature of the testing program. A session in which one H.I.V.-positive woman was invited to take part showed just how quickly the details of the testing are disposed with.
Minutes after she was informed for the first time that she carried the virus, one pregnant woman, Siata Ouattara, still visibly shaken by the news, was quickly walked through the details of the tests, as well as general advice about maintaining her health and protecting others from acquiring the disease.
In less than five minutes, in which the previously unknown concept of a placebo was briefly mentioned, the session was over, and Ms. Ouattara, unemployed and illiterate, had agreed to take part in the tests. Asked what had persuaded her to do so, she responded, "The medical care that they are promising me."
One of the most highly educated of the women who spoke to a reporter, a 31-year-old single mother with a degree in law who gave her name only as Nicole, said she had never been made to understand that the medicine being tested, AZT, was already known to stop transmission of the virus during pregnancy.
"I am not sure that I understood all of this so well," Nicole said. "But there were some medicines that they said might protect the mother and the child, and they wanted to follow the evolution of my pregnancy and the effectiveness of the treatment."
Pressed further, Nicole, like the other mothers, said that she had not been told the results of blood tests on her 1-year-old.
Asked how she would feel if she learned tomorrow that she had received a placebo when a proven treatment existed, Nicole's tone changed abruptly. "I would say quite simply that that is an injustice," she said.
Then, regathering her composure, Nicole posed the problem another way. "At the time they explained this to me, I asked myself the simple question of whether I had any choice," she said. "As long as there was a possibility to save my daughter, I had to try."
For other mothers who took part in the test, the confusion was far more profound. Some acknowledged that they understood little.
"I don't remember exactly what they told me," said Valerie, a frail 28-year-old seamstress. "They said that it would help my child, and that it would ease my childbirth too."
Several Ivorian doctors objected to the ethical questions being raised over the tests, saying outsiders consider Africans incapable of weighing their own interests.
"One has the impression that foreigners think that once white people arrive here, they can impose what they want and we just accept it in ignorance," said Dr. Toussaint Sibailly, one of the doctors in the project. "If that was once the case, those days are long past."
Still, though the testing here was reviewed and approved by an official Ivory Coast board of ethics, a senior health official seemed surprised when told that a test like the one underway in Abidjan could probably not take place in the United States.
"If the country that is paying for the study cannot accept conducting it, then we can't be expected to accept it either," said Dr. Issa Malick Coulibaly, the senior health official with oversight over the AZT research.
An American scientist with the project said later that the Ivory Coast had never been told that this type of research could be performed in the United States, only that the experiment was designed according to the strictest American and international standards for medical research. American scientists involved in the experiments were told by the United States Embassy not to speak on the record about their work.
The women taking part in the study seemed to have a sense of obligation when they were told that the trials are meant to find an affordable drug regimen that can save tens of thousands of lives in the future.
"If the scientists say that it has to be this way, then I can only agree with them," said a mother named Salimata, who spoke as she clutched her tiny 4-month-old daughter. "People are trying to help us, and if a bunch of people have to die first, I am ready to risk my life too, so that other women and their babies can survive.
"If I got the placebo, that will hurt, for sure. But there is no evil involved."

HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN FINANCE: LITIGATION;
Largest Fine To Be Paid For Donation

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
A Pennsylvania landfill company agreed today to pay an $8 million fine, the highest penalty ever for a campaign-finance violation, in connection with a scheme to funnel $129,000 in illegal campaign contributions to 10 political candidates, a Federal prosecutor said tonight.
The company, Empire Sanitary Landfill, agreed to the fine in pleading guilty to the conspiracy before Judge Thomas Venaski of Federal District Court in Scranton, Pa., said David A. Barasch, the United States Attorney in Harrisburg. 
 The plea sets the stage for the trials of six men on scores of felony and misdemeanor counts that could bring long prison terms and heavy fines on conviction, Mr. Barasch said. The six are charged in a separate 140-count indictment accusing them of making the illegal donations, including to the campaigns of Bob Dole and President Clinton in the last election, and then covering them up, Mr. Barasch said.
The Dole Presidential campaign was the biggest beneficiary of the Empire scheme, receiving $80,000 in April and May 1995, while the Clinton-Gore campaign got $10,000 in September 1995, Mr. Barasch said.
He emphasized that there was no evidence that Mr. Clinton, Mr. Dole or any of the other recipients had any inkling that they were getting illegal money in the scheme, which was first reported today in The Washington Post. Mr. Barasch said some campaigns had returned it some time ago but that representatives of two others, whom he declined to name, had called him in the last two days, belatedly wanting to know where to refund the money.
"I told them to talk to their lawyers," Mr. Barasch said.
Those indicted were Renato P. Mariani, former owner and president of Empire; Alan Stephens, a former officer; two other company officials, Michael Serafini and Leo Del Serra; Frank Serafini, Michael's uncle and a Republican State Representative from Lackawanna, and Robert Giglio, a plumbing contractor who had done work for Empire.
Frank Serafini and Mr. Giglio are accused only of perjury in their grand jury testimony, Mr. Barasch said. They are accused of trying to hide their knowledge of the larger web of payments, repayments and disguised payments, he said.
Typically, Mr. Barasch said, Empire workers would be told to bring in a check to make a campaign contribution. They would, and they would be reimbursed, either out of disguised corporate funds or out of Michael Serafini's personal account, Mr. Barasch said. Some of the contributions were made while Empire was lobbying in connection with a trash-transportation bill in Congress in which the company had a keen interest, he said.
Mr. Barasch said other campaigns that unwittingly received illicit money included those of Senators Arlen Specter and Rick Santorum, both Pennsylvania Republicans; Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, and Representative Bill Paxon, Republican of New York.
Empire was acquired in December 1996 by USA Waste Services, a Houston disposal giant, which has agreed to pay the $8 million fine, Mr. Barasch said.
Frank Serafini's lawyer, Sal Cognetti, said his client would fight the charges, which were based in part on "responses to ambiguous questions."
Trial dates have not been set.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 38; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 1901 words

HEADLINE: Weekend Excursion;
Beside the Hudson, The Lure of Art

BYLINE: By DINITIA SMITH 

DATELINE: HUDSON, N.Y.

 BODY:
"You notice that I write in an absent-minded sort of way, crossing out and inserting words," the Hudson River landscape painter Frederic Edwin Church wrote in 1891 to a friend from Olana, his home near here. "Well, it is owing to the magnificent effects this morning. The beautiful clouds, and opalescent atmosphere, and lovely tints in the landscape, distract me everywhere."
Church, Thomas Cole and the other painters of the Hudson River School were drawn to the area by the grand vistas of the river and its headlands, by the dramatic sky and particularly by the light, which seemed, especially in summer, to lie upon the landscape in a pinkish haze. Sanford Robinson Gifford, a well-known Luminist painter who lived in the city of Hudson, made it his life's work to study the effect of this light on the atmosphere, the river and the mountains of the region. 
 A century later, artists are returning to the Hudson Valley, many of them refugees from New York City. They are attracted by the landscape and the pink light and by the lower rents fostered by community leaders seeking to revitalize the area as a cultural showplace.
Some artists keep weekend homes in the area. Ellsworth Kelly has a house in Spencertown; William Wegman, in Ghent. The Russian expatriate artist Mihail Chemiakin lives full time in Claverack. Others have begun to take studio space in the small city of Hudson itself (population 8,034), the hub of this growing artistic realm, and they are creating a community that in many ways resembles that of the North Fork of Long Island in the 1950's and 60's, when Jackson Pollock, Willem de Kooning and other artists made their homes here.
Painters and sculptors have begun to rent studio space in Hudson's fine old crumbling buildings alongside the antiques dealers who have taken root there in recent years. Richard Artschwager rents a house, which he uses part time, on Union Street. Edward Avedisian lives on Warren Street. The photographer Lynn Davis has a house on Fourth Street.
And art galleries have begun to spring up in the city's vacant storefronts, including the Carrie Haddad Gallery, one of the first to arrive, and Kendall Art and Design; both show contemporary art. There are also two ceramicists' studios and the Hudson Valley Arts Center, which offers arts and crafts. Along with the artists have come renovations and new restaurants: the Charleston, the Cascades, the Paramount Grill, Earth Foods, and Oasis, a coffee shop.
 
An Arts Walk
 In recognition of its growing stature as an artistic center, Hudson will put its artists and their work on display over the Columbus Day weekend, when it holds its third annual Arts Walk on Oct. 12 and 13. Proceeds will help raise money to purchase public art for the city. At 46 sites, all along Warren Street, in the vacant storefronts and in the new galleries that have sprung up, there will be exhibits by 100 Columbia County artists.
On Oct. 13, there will be an auction of work by Columbia County artists at Time and Space Limited, a gallery and performance center on Columbia Street. Included will be an autographed poster by Mr. Kelly and a work by Mr. Chemiakin. At the 1855 Opera House, which a local group has long been trying to restore as a cultural and civic center, there will be the first exhibition by local artists from the 1940's and 50's, among them Stanley Bate.
The Arts Walk will also have music, including an alphorn concert on the courthouse steps and chamber music at six exhibition sites. For children, there will be crafts demonstrations and the opportunity to help build a hot-air balloon, which will be launched at noon on Oct. 13.
 
A Roller-Coaster History
 Hudson, a city of Federal and Victorian houses, with their brackets and milled cornices, is a diorama of American architectural history. But for years it has seemed to cling to life on the edge of the river, buffeted by cycles of poverty and prosperity. Now, like Peekskill, 40 miles to the south, Hudson is encouraging artists to settle, as a way of revitalizing a community that always seems to be in peril.
Founded in 1783, Hudson has had a shaky past. As one early history puts it, it was settled by "somber, undemonstrative Quaker men" seeking a good port for their whaling ships in the area, which had the last deep port on the river. In its early days it was a prosperous place; in 1829 a whaling ship arrived at the city docks "under discharge of cannon, and amidst the acclamations of citizens and sailors." The history also says, "The city is well and substantially built, and many of the residences are of great elegance, beautifully embowered."
Hudson's merchants traded with Curacao, the Windward Islands and Cuba. But soon the whaling industry declined; whale oil was replaced by petroleum; railroad tracks were laid along the river, and Hudson lost its ascendancy as a port.
After the Civil War, Hudson enjoyed a renaissance, becoming a manufacturing center bristling with tanneries, iron foundries and mills. The city was called the wooden match center of the world. During Prohibition, Hudson also became mildly notorious for its speak-easies and houses of prostitution along Columbia Street.
By the 1960's, Hudson's economic base had shrunk, and the city seemed to be clinging for its very life to the headland. Houses were boarded up, windows shattered. There was a melancholy to the empty streets lined with venerable buildings, a reminder of a once-thriving community.
But the place has always maintained a peculiar hold on artists and writers. In 1978, the poet and art critic John Ashbery bought a 19th-century house of rough-hewn stone near the courthouse. His home is a grand, dark place, filled with paintings given by artist friends. It reminds him of his grandfather's home in Rochester, a place where he had always been happy as a little boy.
"This is a late fantasy fulfillment," Mr. Ashbery said recently. "When I was growing up, I had this unrequited desire to live in a small town, and Hudson conformed to my idea of what a small town should be. It has that quality which I was always nostalgic for."
There is a completeness to Hudson, a sense of a finite town, everything within reach: the grand courthouse, the post office, the library in the old city almshouse, which dates from 1818. There are drug dealers in Hudson, too. "But we don't have murders or violent crime," Carrie Haddad said.
In the 1970's, a Federal grant enabled Hudson to restore its sidewalks and facades and to install new street lights. Two years ago, a citizens' group hired a planning firm to map a strategy to revitalize the town, and the Hudson Vision Plan resulted. One proposal was to encourage artists to move to the city. A group, Historic Hudson Inc., was started -- with Mr. Ashbery as a founding member -- to preserve the city's architectural and cultural heritage. Another aspect of the plan was a project to restore the waterfront and provide access to it once again.
With a $30,000 grant from the state and the Federal Government, the city removed three gas tanks from the shoreline. Now, with $175,000 in government money in place, there are plans to build a park on the riverfront, with a gazebo, a restaurant, nature trails and fishing areas, and to enlarge the docks for tour boats.
A year and a half ago, the old St. Charles Hotel was restored with a low-interest loan from the Hudson Development Corporation. Community leaders also hope to refurbish the Seventh Street Park and to move an 1850 statue of Venus back to its original site in the center of the park.
 
A Home for Artists
 Among the new artists to arrive in Hudson is Peter Barton, a sculptor and abstract painter whose work has vivid, expressive strokes thickened by beeswax. "I was drawn by the architecture," he said. "You get up and work among beautiful buildings." Another draw, Mr. Barton said, was that "David Kermani offered me free studio space on the third floor above his shop."
David Kermani, a former director of the Tibor de Nagy Gallery in Manhattan who now owns an oriental rug store on Warren Street, is a prime mover behind Hudson's revitalization. Mr. Barton gave up his TriBeCa loft, which he had rented for $1,000 a month, for a $450-a-month apartment on Allen Street in Hudson. He will show one of his installations at the store during the Arts Walk weekend. It is a piece made from wire and chain molded into three-dimensional forms, with drawings.
Tony Thompson, who paints Hudson River landscapes, was one of the city's homesteading artists. He and his wife, Margaret Saliske, a furniture restorer and sculptor, left New York City for Hudson nine years ago.Mr. Thompson's work has been shown at the Museum of Modern Art and is in a number of corporate collections. The couple paid $140,000 for a three-story white Greek Revival house with Ionic columns, which they have renovated.
Mr. Thompson's paintings are representational landscapes of the Hudson River Valley, sometimes with their color planes broken up into abstractions, and often surrounded by his wife's elaborate frames. Their work will be on view during the Arts Walk at 415 Warren Street.
During his nine years in Hudson, Mr. Thompson has painted the same scene over and over again, the view from Hudson's Promenade Hill of the 19th-century Hudson lighthouse, the river and the Catskills beyond. It is much the same view that drew his predecessors in the 19th century.
"The light changes so drastically," he said. "You get these huge piles of clouds, then the mist at noon. It burns itself out, and the light becomes brighter. A storm goes by. It clears again."
"I work in my studio," Mr. Thompson added, "and when I happen to notice the light change, I zip down on my bike to the end of Warren Street. It's like having a theater there. You look outside and see what's playing, and then you can watch the show."

PUB-DATE: October 10, 1997

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 36; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 959 words

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;
Exploring the Misery Of a Desperate Era

BYLINE: By JOHN RUSSELL 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
When the Yale Center for British Art first opened here in 1977, it presented a view of England and English life that was predominantly Arcadian. The countryside in the 18th century looked idyllic. So did life in English country houses, large and small. Horses and dogs were well bred and well fed. Life in the slow lane in England was no cause for anxiety. Work was work, but very few people died of it.
The horrors of the downside of life in a later England were hardly touched upon in the Yale Center until 1988, when they were surveyed at length in an exhibition of mostly mid-19th-century art called "Hard Times." And at this moment, the hard times of our own mid-century are getting comprehensive coverage in "Humanist Landscapes: Humphrey Spender's Photo-Documents, 1932-1942." 
 Now 88, Mr. Spender was a pioneer photojournalist in the 1930's, when there was a deferential look to the picture pages in most of England's more substantial newspapers. He, on the contrary, practiced what the great German photographer August Sander had preached in 1931: that "photography should express the whole brutal, inhuman spirit of the time in universally comprehensible form."
As a point of view, that sure had topicality. It was in the mid-1930's, and throughout much of the northern half of England, that the English Depression bit deepest. Industries that had flourished for centuries lost out to foreign rivals. Areas that for many generations had lived by coal-mining were systematically downsized. Ships and shipyards were about to lose much of their traditional role. Unemployment stalked the streets, and living conditions plummeted. Anyone who has seen the movie "The Full Monty" will know that those conditions still exist, even in a once-great city like Sheffield.
In 1936, George Orwell lived rough and lived hard as he explored the areas in question. In his book "The Road to Wigan Pier" (1937), he described in detail and at first hand the dehumanizing conditions in which many thousands of English men, women and children were having to live.
What emerges at once from the show now at the Yale Center is that Orwell had both a mate and a match in his near-contemporary Humphrey Spender. Like Orwell, Spender neither melodramatized nor begged for attention. He, too, had traveled the afflicted areas not as a sightseeing tourist but as a fellow human being. In his perceptions, he was everywhere plain and simple, though never without subtlety.
It is relevant that Spender's elder brother, Michael, had lived in Germany while working for the company that produced the Leica camera. For Humphrey Spender the camera was, therefore, "like family." It is also relevant that his younger brother was Stephen Spender, a key figure among the younger English poets in the 1930's. But the decisive moment in his career was when he became aware of the potential of news photography, in which candor would be allied to immediacy. This he learned primarily while in Germany and Austria before 1933.
In England in 1936-37, Spender ran almost in tandem with Orwell, though neither knew the other and Orwell had not yet published "Wigan Pier." But Spender, like Orwell, had seen how unemployed miners would scramble on all fours up precipitous heaps of slag in search of small pieces of usable coal. And like Orwell, he had lived among the poorest of the poor and won their confidence.
But Spender was also a dramatist who missed nothing of the actualities of the almost derelict cities. He could sit for an hour in a public house and come back with a photograph that looked like a scene from an English equivalent of O'Neill's "Iceman Cometh."
If a city architect came around, notebook in hand, to decide which houses would lose their tenants and which should be spared, Spender caught every nuance of terror in the tenants' faces. And if a housewife still insisted on scrubbing her doorstep, he recorded the big generous half-circle with which she left it spotless.
He could also be very funny. At the Yale Center for British Art, there is a picture of a "Working Man's Hair Specialist" at work in the streets in Bolton. An update from the age of Hogarth, the image is nothing short of hilarious.
As for the "Commercial Travelers' Dance" in Birmingham in 1939, millisecond timing fixes the unexpectedly wild comedy of the scene.
Even so, mass-market newspapers didn't much care for his photographs. (Too "disturbing," they said). But in October 1938 Spender was taken up by "Picture Post," a new illustrated weekly with a more combative attitude to the day's disasters. So far from alienating the public, "Picture Post" racked up 1.35 million subscriptions by the end of the year.
Spender stayed with "Picture Post" till 1942, when he was drafted into the British Army. He did not make conventional "war photographs," but his every image stays with us.
In "Fighter Pilots Resting on Alert," taken at the height of the Battle of Britain, he gently reminds the reader that these very young men, bundled up and half asleep in full battle rig, might at any moment be sent out on a sortie from which none of them would return.
The Yale Center's exhibition is embellished throughout with paintings, drawings, books and other printed matter that documents the interaction between photographers and painters, novelists and students of society.
The final section includes a series of vintage copies of "Picture Post." Their tattered state testifies to the eagerness with which each issue was passed from hand to hand as a lifeline to news that was hard to find anywhere else.
"Humanist Landscapes: Humphrey Spender's Photo-Documents, 1932-1942" remains at the Yale Center for British Art, 1080 Chapel Street, New Haven, through Nov. 9.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Perceptions: "Working Man's Hair Specialist" (1937), a photograph taken on the street in Bolton, England, by Humphrey Spender. (Yale Center for British Art)

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 3; Column 5; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 404 words

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
Some Philosophy Lessons From a Cunning Monk

BYLINE: By D. J. R. BRUCKNER 

 BODY:
A Tibetan lama, street smart and in exile, drops in on a high-powered Yale economist and stands the modern Western world on its head in Don Thompson's "Tibet Does Not Exist." This monk has little to say about the current suppression of the Tibetans by the Chinese, and he seldom asserts his Buddhist philosophy to change the minds of the economist, several academic colleagues and a couple of students.
In fact, although he is portrayed as an incarnation of past lamas, it is apparent from the outset that he has a refined sense of mental mischief; it is rarely possible to tell when he is serious and when he is just seeing what he can get away with. 
 Mr. Thompson is more apostle than playwright, and much of the script makes a good outline for a primer in Buddhism. But there is genuine humor here. And Brian Clay Luedloff, the director, along with a spirited cast, inject some of their own into the production by the Theater for Human Rights.
Fewer than 15 of the play's 90 minutes are didactic. This group treats the rest as good-mannered and amusing patter, and all the characters except the monk seem to be constantly tripping over the unspoken rules of their fastidious political correctness.
What dramatic development there is depends entirely on two people: Dominic Cuskern as the economist and Les J. N. Mau as the lama. Mr. Cuskern is as coolly arrogant as he should be to begin, and by the end he seems embarrassed to let anyone notice a transformation. Mr. Mau is so funny that it is surprising to find that after a while you are apprehensive about how cunning his monk might be under all that warm, loony unworldliness.
The playwright's reticence works: Tibet is much on your mind as you leave.
 
TIBET DOES NOT EXIST
 
By Don Thompson; directed by Brian Clay Luedloff; sets by James A. Bazewicz; costumes by Laurie A. Churba; lighting by Richard Latta; sound by William Kollar; production stage manager, Alexandra De Collibus; general manager, Sharon Tinari. Presented by the Theater for Human Rights, John Lynch artistic director; Diana Takata, managing director; Walter Goodwin, and Will Arntz. At TriBeCa Performing Arts Center, 199 Chambers Street.

SECTION: Section A; Page 23; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 722 words

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Gutless in New York

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
In New York City one battle has been lost, by surrender. But in Washington and around the country, conservatives and liberals of courage continue to fight for the religiously persecuted of the world.
 They need the courage. They are standing up to one of the best-funded and -organized lobbies ever put together to serve the interests of the persecuting dictatorships. 
 In New York, Peter F. Vallone, Speaker of the City Council, marched up the freedom hill last spring. He presented a bill that would bar the city government and companies with which it signs contracts from doing business with any of 15 countries listed as religious persecutors.
Business executives were furious. They said it would hurt trade with those dictatorships. It would -- the only pressure for religious freedom the city could apply.
Yesterday Mr. Vallone responded. He did not narrow the bill and its consequences, as he might have, and yet maintain the pressure. He just spun around, marched down the hill, all the way, and withdrew his bill.
Instead he presented a set of "principles." Businesses agreed that they themselves would not "discriminate," which all of them have already promised. They would tell their managers abroad about the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which most of the tyrannies involved have signed and ignored for 50 years.
No penalties against the guilty countries if they did not cease persecution, or against U.S. business serving them, are even mentioned.
The story is embarrassing for the city and for those of us who thought Mr. Vallone's guts would match his mouth. On we go, without him.
The struggle in Washington is about withholding some American subsidies from the dictatorships that persecute Christians, Buddhists and other religious minorities by arrest, torture and execution. This persecution has been repeatedly documented by the U.S. Government.
The penalties are small -- not higher tariffs, official boycotts or economically painful sanctions, but cancellation of non-humanitarian aid and U.S.-endowed loans. Never has America been asked to do so little for so many against such evil -- but still in the name of Heaven to do something.
The sponsors of the bill were so eager to get support for some action that they did not focus on China. But the shoe squeezed Beijing, producing acute pain in the American China lobby: organizations of American companies, a clutch of former high officials now involved with China and, of course, the White House.
One Administration problem with the bill was that after charges of religious persecution were investigated for up to a year, subsidies would be lifted unless the President ordered them continued, with explanation. That could put him on the human rights spot, which he does not enjoy.
But what really bothers the lobby is that the anti-persecution movement crosses political lines. It involves prominent Republican members of Congress like Representative Frank Wolf of Virginia and Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, the bill's sponsors. It includes the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the Christian Coalition, veteran conservative leaders like Gary Bauer, head of the Family Research Council, and the liberal human rights leader Representative Nancy Pelosi of California.
But there is still influential opposition among liberals who are nervous about religion touching politics, even politics against oppression, and fear that Mr. Bauer has a "secret" agenda. If he does, it is a strange way of going about it -- angering the business community and other conservatives, and clergymen like the Rev. Billy Graham and his son Ned, who are opposed to the movement and to rocking Chinese boats.
All the Bauers, Pelosis, Wolfs and Specters have to gain is their own peace of mind and the knowledge that most Americans support them.
Speaking of peace of mind:
On March 16, Chinese police arrested Xu Yongze, a Protestant leader of China's underground churches, his wife and six other Chinese Christians. The charge was "disrupting public order." Nothing was heard from him afterward. Now Compass Direct, a U.S. religious news service, reports that on Sept. 17 he was sentenced to 10 years in a labor camp.
Does that interest those who pretend a press release about "principles" will free a single human rights prisoner from his cell?
